column3: Stéphane Paut (aka Neige) has been composing sunny
column4: shoegazing post-black metal under the Alcest moniker. Alcest's third LP
column5: Les Voyages de l'Âme
column6: feels like his ultimate statement on this particular approach. Paut
column7: who first made his mark playing purer black metal
column8: has been at Alcest longer than he contributed to the eccentric
column9: raw
column10: politically tricky black-metal crew Peste Noire. During Alcest's run
column11: his dynamic genre-meshing post-punk black-metal quartet Amesoeurs came and went. While he'll likely continue working with German musician Herbst on the blackened post-rock band Lantlôs
column12: he's not the one piloting that ship (ditto Forgotten Woods). That
column13: and Old Silver Key
column14: his collaboration with members of Drudkh
column15: felt like a half-baked one-off. All to say
column16: despite the insane list of associations and circles affixed to his name
column17: the multi-tasking French multi-instrumentalist has been increasingly focused on this one higher profile
column18: very personal project.

column1: The attention he's given Alcest has given him time to hone (and ramp up) the signature sound. Instead of shifting things
column2: or looking for ways to expand the aesthetic
column3: he's been trying to perfect something very specific. When I spoke to Neige about Alcest in 2007
column4: he said the concept for the band was connected to ""visions"" he had as a child of ""an indescribably beautiful place  where everything-- trees
column5: glades
column6: and brooks-- produces a pearly light  and where a faraway and celestial music floats in the air like a  perfume."" The songs recorded under the Alcest name are ""the musical  testimony of these experiences."" It's a fairy or dream land that he's trying to recreate sonically
column7: and each record apparently clarifies and better maps something that's been in his head for a long time. So
column8: while the dogged reliance on a particular formula is essential to the project
column9: it's problematic if you're looking for variation.

column1: It shouldn't be a surprise that Les Voyages
column2: translated ""The Journeys of the Soul
column3: is the most accomplished Alcest offering. That's the way things have been going for a while. (Per usual
column4: Paut handles everything but the drums
column5: again tackled again by ex-Amesoeurs/Peste Noire player Winterhalter of Les Discrets
column6: and ex-Alcest/Amesoeurs guitarist Fursy Teyssier
column7: also of Les Discrets
column8: did the artwork.) Part of Alcest's charm
column9: though
column10: has been the project's imperfections: The haze of the 2005 two-song
column11: Charles Baudelaire-cribbing debut Le Secret-- its abrupt shifts between nature recordings
column12: clean dream-pop acoustics
column13: and raw black metal-- was transfixing and
column14: despite all the beauty
column15: strange.

column1: Seven years later he's clarified and crystallized that approach
column2: sure
column3: and lost something in that translation. (It's hard to go back into the shadows once you've left them.) In one sense
column4: it is a return to form. 2010's Écailles de Lune took on a darker cast. It was a fine record
column5: but Alcest sound best when he's chasing after sunspots. You do get plenty of that here
column6: along with the usual smeary French singing and pretty shoegaze sentimentality. The standout moment
column7: I think
column8: is the transition from the more frantic ""Beings of Light""-- a soaring
column9: angelic blur that opens with a kind of airy choir-- to the almost eight-minute ""Faiseurs de Mondes""
column10: a track that makes use of the group's heavier tendencies (plenty of black-metal howls) alongside a catchier pop riff and a very dense melodicism. In ""Beings of Light""
column11: it's unclear if he's saying anything or just holding notes
column12: and it doesn't really matter.

column1: When Alcest made their New York City premiere a couple of years ago-- a show I helped organize-- Paut had lost his voice
column2: so he handed over his vocal duties to someone else in the band
column3: touring guitarist Zero. Paut
column4: in turn
column5: stood in the background. It felt natural to me; he's not really a frontman. Here
column6: when everything's as clear as it is on Les Voyages de l'Âme
column7: he feels almost too exposed
column8: and the big climaxes he's reaching for don't arrive. There's no denying the beauty
column9: but it feels weirdly muted-- or perhaps just unsurprising. Paut doesn't write pop songs memorable enough to exist entirely as pop
column10: and at this point enough people are blending black metal with a variety of softer genres that those explosions don't send shivers like they did in the past. Surprise is essential to his plan. Now
column11: instead of straddling and bridging two genres in unique ways
column12:
it feels as if he's treading water in both.

The Heartless Bastards never got tagged as the next saviors of rock'n'roll
column2: although they certainly possess all the relevant traits: a strong grounding not in blues but in blues rock
column3: a conservative aesthetic that nods to rock history but is never beholden to any one particular artist or scene
column4: and most importantly a frontwoman with a commanding voice. Perhaps their name was too misleading or their lineup too precarious
column5: but the Bastards escaped the mantle that's been assigned to everyone from the Strokes to the Black Keys and most recently to the Alabama Shakes. If that has left them out of enviable company
column6: at least they've managed to attract a loyal audience and even star in a crucial ""Friday Night Lights"".

column1: Their first for Partisan Records
column2: Arrow is their crunchiest album since Erika Wennerstrom gutted the original trio in 2008 and rebuilt the Bastards as a quartet. Largely discarding the fiddle
column3: pedal steel
column4: and banjo that fleshed out 2009's The Mountain
column5: the band and producer Jim Eno of Spoon strip things down to emphasize guitars and the rhythm section as much as vocals. They open these songs up
column6: both enabling a heavier sound and making room for some weighty jamming. The result is less fussy than <i>The Mountain
column7: with room enough for some Skynyrd Southern rock on ""Late in the Night"" and Santana percussion on ""Skin and Bone"". They've developed a larger musical vocabulary
column8: but the results can be cumbersome: With timpani and crackling guitar right out of a Morricone soundtrack
column9: the nearly seven-minute centerpiece ""The Arrow Killed the Beast"" is more melodramatic than dramatic
column10: weighted down by import and exaggerated ambience.

column1: Perhaps the Bastards have begun courting the rock-revivalist constituency on Arrow. ""Whenever you need a pick-me-up
column2: you gotta have gotta have rock'n'roll
column3: Wennerstrom sings on ""Got to Have Rock and Roll"". Despite the dry classic-rock riff and chugging momentum
column4: the song makes for a tepid endorsement. ""Skin and Bone"" is much less corny
column5: as Wennerstrom sings
column6: ""Oh
column7: I want it to be like when I was young."" She may not be speaking specifically about rock'n'roll
column8: but that line succinctly sums up listeners' evolving relationship with music and a desperate desire to connect as strongly as we did in our youth. Most of the Bastards songs address travel rather than age
column9: which is how most touring bands interpret the write-what-you-know adage. ""Staring out at the city skyline
column10: a marathon is going down the street
column11: Wennerstrom sings on opener ""Marathon"". The song is about how life is a ""long race home
column12: and dangling participle aside
column13: it's an immensely awkward image to open the album.

column1: Wennerstrom has always been a fairly workmanlike songwriter
column2: although her voice and her band compensate when words fail her. The lyrics on Arrow are best when they settle for serviceable instead of strive for profound
column3: and the line that resonates with the most meaning is also the one of the simplest: ""Oh I got you on my mind
column4: she sings throughout ""Late in the Night""
column5: and the romantic implications become clearer and bolder with each repetition. It helps that the Bastards play loud and hard enough to nearly drown out her vocals
column6:
reveling in the musical as well as the sexual tension. That's arguably more rock'n'roll than another song about rock'n'roll.

Aside from founder Dylan Carlson
column4: drummer Adrienne Davies is the only member of Earth to play on each of the four studio albums the drone-metal syndicate has made since re-forming seven years ago as an elegant blues band. On last year's <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15072-angels-of-darkness-demons-of-light-1/"" target=""_blank"">Angels of Darkness
column5: Demons of Light 1
column6: she added an immediate
column7: omnipresent grace. She swung softly during opener ""Old Black""
column8: commanding the music's slow shifts with a righteous thump. And she carefully triggered album apex ""Descent to the Zenith"" with a light-footed march that served as the swivel for the rest of the band's melodic swoops. For all the deserved talk of Carlson's refinement and control as a guitarist
column9: Davies was arguably his superior
column10: guiding the quartet along with an unspoken
column11: perfect resolve. Without her steady presence
column12: one assumed
column13: all of those light tones and slight menace might wash into blur
column14: like watercolors escaping a drain.

column1: It's surprising if not discomfiting
column2: then
column3: that the second volume of <i>Angels of Darkness
column4: Demons of Light opens mostly without Davies. For the first 12 minutes
column5: she resigns to almost auxiliary roles. On opener ""Sigil of Brass""
column6: Carlson explores elliptical snippets of a short guitar progression
column7: a leader advancing with caution. Cellist Lori Goldston and bassist Karl Blau pick up his patterns
column8: stretching the same sounds above and beneath his picking with long exhalations. But Davies plays only her cymbal
column9: and barely
column10: adding occasional clatters that seem mostly like reminders that she's still behind the kit. She's even less present on ""His Teeth Did Brightly Shine""
column11: the sort of slow
column12: shimmering strut that she's motored with Earth for the better part of a decade. Instead
column13: Blau mostly thumbs the beat with his bass as Carlson teases out guitar-effects flotsam beneath the sidewinding lead line. Davies merely offers bits of shakers and shells
column14: her percussion becoming an occasional footnote to its normal narrative thread.

column1: Somehow
column2: though
column3: these tracks and their themes don't wash away or turn into seismic smears that would have suited Earth back when ""Kurt Kobain"" was offering up guest vocals. Recorded during the same sessions that yielded volume one of this series
column4: they show the strong skeleton
column5: sans distraction. More importantly
column6: they confirm the suspicion that the crew Carlson gathered for the Angels of Darkness recordings is the most sympathetic
column7: versatile
column8: and unselfish group he's ever had. Without Davies
column9: these first 12 minutes are some of the most muted in Earth's catalog
column10: showcasing a band comfortable not only with its quiet but also with how a listener can hear clearly from one side of the mix to the other (compared especially to the impenetrable stuff of two decades ago). This is the epitome of cool
column11: quiet confidence.

column1: But it isn't lopsided growth
column2: as Angels II isn't simply the softer side of its predecessor. ""The Corascene Dog"" is gentle but glinting
column3: with Carlson and Goldston trading sinister dialogue between their strings. And despite its classically suggestive title
column4: ""Waltz (A Multiplicity of Doors)"" is actually one of the most abrasive looks yet at Earth 2.0. Goldston wrenches astringent wails from her cello
column5: while Davies trades her generally quiet thunder for a heavier foot and a relentless tide of cymbals. Blau lets every note linger with a little extra emphasis
column6: and Carlson tucks a web of foreboding guitar effects beneath the serrated guitar line. Earth saves the most revelatory moment for last. ""The Rakehell"" generously infuses funk
column7: with Davies' syncopated trot serving as the structure beneath a lysergic smear. Carlson plays bass
column8: using the low notes mostly to state the melody so that his guitar can push beyond it. He refracts
column9: multiplies
column10: and manipulates the tone
column11: using the guitar to find the midpoint between a Meters organ and a wailing
column12: heavy-metal lead. In an unlikely move in a career full of them
column13: Earth add much younger bands like Sun Araw and Eternal Tapestry to their list of contemporaries.

column1: Indeed
column2: for all the talk about this still-nascent phase of Earth versus that earlier frame-shifting phase
column3: the twin <i>Angels of Darkness
column4: Demons of Light releases actually reveal a band with interests broader than such a binary might suggest. Earth aren't simply softening and separating their drone metal as if by centrifuge
column5: or trying to be stately rather than beastly. These tracks are built on the brethren of blues
column6: rock
column7: and metal
column8: but they wouldn't be compelling without pieces of bop buoyancy
column9: minimalist restraint
column10: classical consonance
column11: and near-liturgical resolve. Oh
column12: and believe it or not
column13: funk. This version of Earth has simply given Carlson more room and more assistance to explore
column14: well
column15: darkness and light-- in his own time
column16:
of course.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17447/homepage_large.5d2858ab.jpg|Biokinetics|30240.0|Porter Ricks|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Type']|2012-02-14 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:22.704424|"

If you bought Porter Ricks' Biokinetics on CD in the 1990s and the disc is still intact
column2: consider yourself lucky: The original edition is currently trading for $65 and up on Discogs. The price has something to do with the album's place in history: Biokinetics
column3: a touchstone of experimental techno
column4: was the first album released on Berlin's widely worshipped Chain Reaction label. But scarcity is a bigger factor: Biokinetics
column5: like all of Chain Reaction's CDs from that era
column6: came packaged in an aluminum tin that tended to crack the CD it was supposed to be protecting. (As a comment on Discogs notes
column7: ""Another Chain Reaction release
column8: another metal box that eats up CDs."")

column1: Fortunately
column2: 16 years later
column3: John Twells' Massachusetts-based Type label has stepped up with a reissue of the landmark album
column4: not just on CD (this time in a standard jewel case) but also
column5: for the first time
column6: on 2xLP and digital download. It's a welcome reissue
column7: and long overdue. It comes as certain ideas from techno's fertile
column8: experimental
column9: mid-1990s period are being picked up by a range of underground musicians. Many of these ideas have permeated so deeply into the culture that it's hard to remember a time without them
column10: but we wouldn't have Burial
column11: to name just one of the duo's distant descendants
column12: without Porter Ricks' seafloor crackle and mottled-granite color scale.

column1: Porter Ricks were the duo of Thomas Köner
column2: a sound artist and ambient composer
column3: and Andy Mellwig
column4: a techno producer who also recorded as Continuous Mode and
column5: with former Monolake member and future Ableton founder Gerhard Behles
column6: as Async Sense. Released in 1996
column7: Biokinetics was Porter Ricks' debut album
column8: gathering tracks from three vinyl EPs released that year along with three songs exclusive to the album. It had been years since I last listened to it
column9: and the Type reissue surprised me first by reminding me how diverse the album is. ""Chain Reaction"" has long since become shorthand for a certain fusion of buoyant dub
column10: hazy ambience
column11: and coiled techno
column12: but on Biokinetics
column13: none of these has quite settled into place; it's a dynamic
column14: unpredictable mixture of pulse and hiss.

column1: The opening ""Port Gentil""
column2: a precursor to the template Wolfgang Voigt would adopt under his Gas alias
column3: pairs soft
column4: monochromatic tones with a muted 4/4 pulse. On the surface
column5: it couldn't be simpler
column6: but as it pulls you in
column7: you become aware of shifting contours and unusual dimensions
column8: the interplay of light and shadow; it sounds like a string section tuning up atop a freight train trundling through a deep canyon.

column1: ""Nautical Dub"" hews closer to textbook techno
column2: with muscular bass pushing relentlessly forward
column3: but it's hardly conventional. There are no sharp edges
column4: for one thing: Percussive accents have been buffed to a dull gleam
column5: and the upper register of the track
column6: normally reserved for crisp
column7: cutting hi-hats
column8: is diffused into a fine-gauge spray that sweeps back and forth like a lawn sprinkler. Only ""Port of Call"" assumes dancefloor techno's chiseled boom-tick profile
column9: but this time it's the low end that's fizzed to near nothingness. A few years later
column10: Pole would famously construct an entire aesthetic around the vagaries of a broken Waldorf filter
column11: but Biokinetics was first: Everything sounds broken here
column12: all frayed cables and dusty contacts
column13: and every gesture toward techno clarity feels like a trade-off made at the expense of another element that's left to crumble.

column1: Dub techno has since become one of electronic music's most mannered styles
column2: but here
column3: Porter Ricks' tracks feel not so much like compositions
column4: much less stylistic exercises
column5: than answers to very specific
column6: fairly arcane questions-- what happens when we route this LFO through that filter? How many divisions can we parse between the downbeats? How can chaos be turned into rhythm
column7: and how far can a repetition be stretched before it's rendered senseless? Where is the boundary between tone and white noise?

column1: On ""Biokinetics 1""
column2: a heaving
column3: wheezing synthesizer struggles to stick to a regular pulse as it's fed through disorienting delay and looped back upon itself
column4: stumbling and confused. As an experiment in stretching a groove to the breaking point
column5: it's as exhilarating as anything in the history of techno. ""Port of Nuba"" and ""Nautical Nuba"" submit drum machines to a similar warping process
column6: resulting in rhythms that gallop like teams of horses. Here
column7: you can hear the origin of Thomas Brinkmann's tumbling cadences of a year or two later
column8: as he used a double-armed turntable to draw elliptical rhythms out of the grooves of records by Wolfgang Voigt and Richie Hawtin. And while we're talking about precedents
column9: the leaden dirge of ""Biokinetics 2"" lays the groundwork for the bleak
column10: trudging techno of Andy Stott and his Modern Love labelmates.

column1: That Biokinetics is an album about currents is reflected in its seafaring titles
column2: such as ""Nautical Dub""
column3: ""Nautical Zone""
column4: ""Port of Call""
column5: etc.
column6: and also in the way that the record's energies feed back into itself. What Porter Ricks learned from dub was less about particular rhythms or stylistic tropes than about the path that a sound travels as it wends its way through the mixing desk
column7: and how it comes out transformed on the other side. Dub's hall-of-mirrors approach to versioning
column8: meanwhile
column9: informs the way that many tracks here are variations upon one another: ""Port Gentil"" and ""Nautical Zone"" bookend the album with nearly identical chords
column10: while ""Nautical Nuba"" and ""Port of Nuba"" recycle the same drum patterns
column11: using filters and delays to achieve very different results. Spontaneity is woven into the fiber of every track; it's easy to hear how some of them may have begun with the same sounds and patterns before the musicians' hands worked their magic on the filters
column12: EQ
column13: and delay
column14: rendering each take unique and unrepeatable.

column1: Like Detroit's Drexciya
column2: Porter Ricks (who took their name from a character from Flipper
column3: the 1960s film and television series) used aquatic metaphors to get at larger ideas
column4: both musical and otherwise. Ocean currents
column5: electrical currents
column6: sound waves
column7: feedback; dub
column8: techno
column9: minimalism
column10: noise; exchange as a fluid back-and-forth but also
column11: as Drexciya pointed out
column12: as a loaded dynamic
column13: fraught
column14: unequal-- they all swirl together
column15: rippling in time and veering out of sync
column16: as though pulled by complicated gravitational forces. Biokinetics is above all a music of tides
column17: suggesting rhythm as both celestial stroke and as a vibration deep in the body
column18:
bubbling at the molecular level.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17449/homepage_large.d60234f6.jpg|White Flame|28900.0|Lil B|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2012-02-14 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:23.473306|"

Not only is Lil B an incredible producer of rap music
column2: he's also an incredible consumer of rap music. Over the past three years
column3: he's arguably invented his own microgenre with ""based music
column4: but a good number of the hundreds of songs he's released in that time are open love letters to other rap artists or regional sounds
column5: from OJ Da Juiceman to Cormega. Any borderline insomniac can sometimes find B on Twitter when night bleeds into morning
column6: tweeting furiously and enthusiastically about rappers such as the 504 Boyz
column7: who have long been out of the spotlight
column8: if they ever were in the first place.

column1: White Flame is B's latest entry into his Flame series
column2: an ongoing string of mixtapes that can be all over the place musically but often delve into the sounds and slang of classic New Orleans rap
column3: right down to the covers
column4: which are spot-on tributes to 1990s Pen & Pixel collages. They've also featured B close to his most unchained
column5: which has led to songs that are fascinating
column6: bizarre
column7: and fantastic as well as ideas that are so unbelievably bad that they can come from only one person.

column1: On all fronts
column2: White Flame doesn't disappoint. There are tracks-- some hyper-lucid and some decidedly absurdist-- that will likely be some of the best songs that Lil B puts out this year. There is also a ridiculous near-diss track aimed at the Game
column3: a song that liberally samples ""I Would Die 4 U"" and another called ""BasedGod Fucked My Bitches"" that throws a preposterously mismatched drum loop under a generous sample of Daft Punk's ""One More Time"" for six and a half minutes. Predictably it's a pick-and-pull record
column4: but those willing to sift can find plenty of reminders of why B is
column5: if not vital
column6: then at least still enduring.

column1: Like most tapes in the Flame series
column2: White Flame peaks when B is at his most wild. Here he often reverts back to the wild-eyed gangster
column3: pseudo-gender-bending persona he developed on last year's Bitch Mob tape
column4: resulting in hilarious and extremely singular tracks such as ""Bitch of the City""
column5: ""I'm Fabio""
column6: and ""Poppin V"" that blur the line between rapping and rambling and in many ways challenge what the art form is designed to do. The songs are purposefully funny and
column7: like plenty of rap music
column8: trade as much on charisma and the ability to coin catchphrases as anything
column9: but they also beg the question of why exactly we need Lil B doing his most sincere B.G. impersonation while bragging for an entire track about taking ""grandpa pills"" in the first place.

column1: Well
column2: maybe we don't
column3: but it's hard to listen to tracks like those-- balanced with more traditional songs like ""Surrender to Me"" and ""Neva Switch""-- and not feel an affinity for what Lil B is pulling off. His subversion of the conventions of the genre remains strong even as he becomes further assimilated into the mainstream
column4: but more importantly he's coming from a place of love and reverence with regard to the music that he's twisting. There is no artifice or endgame
column5: just a weird dude having fun with the music he-- and plenty of others-- grew up listening to. The best of White Flame won't convince those already turned off by Lil B
column6: and some of it is outright useless
column7: but the tape illustrates that he's still operating at a high level. The next few Lil B tapes are already just a keystroke away
column8: but White Flame has songs to come back to
column9: both for pure entertainment and if you ever find yourself wondering just how exactly the guy who raps
column10: ""I can't believe it's not butter/ I'm Fabio
column11: can keep pumping out so much unique
column12:
good music.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17445/homepage_large.1ebffc10.jpg|We Are the Works in Progress|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Asa Wa Kuru']|2012-02-14 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:23.870481|"

Blonde Redhead singer Kazu Makino is from Kyoto
column2: Japan
column3: a few hours' drive from where a 9.0 earthquake and resulting tsunami caused toxic meltdowns at the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant in 2011. Though rebuilding efforts have been extensive
column4: the effects of the disaster continue a year later
column5: and in many cases the people of Japan still have no way of knowing if their food has been contaminated by radiation. This compilation
column6: bringing together unreleased tracks from friends and likeminded musicians such as Deerhunter
column7: Four Tet
column8: and Terry Riley
column9: is Makino's attempt to raise money and support for ongoing relief work in Japan.

column1: Charity records are a tricky thing
column2: since it can be difficult to make a group of artists' songs hang together like a traditional album. Some of the most notable examples (1993's No Alternative
column3: 2009's Dark Was the Night) got around this by using kind of a mixtape format
column4: offering stylistically varied songs from loosely related bands buffet-style. We Are the Works in Progress
column5: though
column6: takes more of an AOR approach. Each of the cuts here are similar in pace (slow) and coloring (gray)
column7: and there's a somber
column8: almost funereal quality that ties them all together. For example
column9: Blonde Redhead's reworked ""Penny Sparkle"" is such a natural transition from John Roberts' ""Berceuse"" that you could mistake them for the same musician.

column1: That cohesiveness goes a long way
column2: but sometimes gets misspent on material that's a little on the weak side. There are some big names here
column3: artists we expect to deliver on a consistent basis
column4: but unfortunately they don’t give away their prime stuff. A good example is the Deerhunter contribution ""Curve""
column5: a slow-building ambient rock piece that is perfectly pleasant-sounding but lacks the danger and emotional rawness that marks the band's best work. This is to be expected on a compilation like this
column6: really
column7: and Makino says as much in the liner notes but flips it as a positive. ""Many of these tracks are works in progress
column8: hence the name... Unfinished things often carry more energy.""

column1: That's true in certain spots. The best tracks here have a sketchy
column2: rough-hewn quality that suggests an artist stumbling onto something promising. Pantha du Prince's ""Bird on a Wire"" sounds like a precursor to his breakout Black Noise material
column3: teasing the combination of grit and airiness that made that album so compelling. Most of Works is not as strong
column4: existing primarily in B-side territory
column5:
but there is something thematically satisfying about its looseness. Here's a record dedicated to a place that was wrecked and is trying to rebuild. The devastated parts of Japan won't resurrect in a day; it's a slow process of gray areas and false starts and moments of promise. That's how this music feels.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17441/homepage_large.aff7cbda.jpg|Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sea Lions But Were Afraid to Ask|30039.0|Sea Lions|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Slumberland']|2012-02-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:16:24.426830|"

Out of all the post-millennial bands that have largely benefited from the C86 tape's renewed interest
column2: Sea Lions are one of the few who actually sound like they were pulled directly from the compilation rather than a band adopting a vogue influence. The treble-heavy production is parallel to that of first-wave twee-punk. The guitars go way past indie pop's minimum quota for jangle. It's quite feasible that if you played Sea Lions for someone who wasn't aware the album was released near the end of 2011
column3: they'd assume that they were a super-obscure band from the early or mid 1980s.

column1: There's a stigma that comes along with having a style that represents a very specific time period
column2: a school of thought that says anything thoroughly nailing a past era is regressive and harmful to the forward movement of music. But those influences had to come from somewhere
column3: so why not cut out the middleman and go straight to the source? Especially if you can find a way to infuse it with your own personality. In that sense
column4: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sea Lions But Were Afraid to Ask makes for a boilerplate
column5: but immensely satisfying
column6: noise-pop record. Dissonant and angular instrumentals are scattered throughout
column7: giving the  album a light experimental edge. Major-key romps are punctuated with  glockenspiel
column8: woozy tremolo bar work
column9: and noisy guitar chicken-scratch. The ballads shuffle like 1960s R&B classics.

column1: Frontman Adrian Pillado is a songwriter who closely adheres to the sensibilities of DIY twee. He has a playful and unsophisticated baritone that suggests either a less dour Ian Curtis or a more English Calvin Johnson. His lyrics focus on the awkwardness of young relationships
column2: the allure of childhood
column3: and burrowing his head underneath as many blankets and pillows as he can find. Sometimes he gets so caught up in his own neuroses that his voice trails off-key
column4: but it's never in a way that feels like self-pity or melodrama. Pillado is charming and full enough of character to make his songs consistently entertaining
column5: a trait he shares with the frontmen of all his influences
column6: from the obvious ones (like Beat Happening and Orange Juice) to the less expected (like Crass).

column1: Part of Everything's success is that it follows the time-honored indie pop tradition of being short and sweet. Brevity and brisk pacing are characteristics the band seems quite familiar with: They manage to cram 15 tracks into a time frame of 29 minutes
column2: with only three of the album's songs passing the 2:30 mark and none that even grazes three minutes. In fact
column3: a few of the shorter tunes grind to a halt at completely unexpected endpoints
column4: which is a jarring but effective way to get a listener's attention. The way these songs end doesn't make them sound unfinished in any way
column5: but it's apparent that the band would rather not coast on a good riff or melody long enough to lose its luster.

column1: Almost any band could take only the basic elements of indie pop and make a listenable album. Many
column2: many bands already have. What makes Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sea Lions But Were Afraid to Ask above-average is the band that made it
column3: one willing to adjust its sound so it's slightly off-center
column4:
reverent of the past but not to the point where it completely hinders their ability to push things forward.

"|16282.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16282-everything-you-always-wanted-to-know-about-sea-lions-but-were-afraid-to-ask/|7.4|Martin Douglas

The title of Tennis' second album could almost as easily describe the first. The music on last year's Cape Dory bobbed sweetly between Brill Building tunefulness and classic indie pop production values
column2: and the basic lyrical themes were at least as old as jazz standard ""A Sailboat in the Moonlight""
column3: hold the moonlight. But the sailing trip that inspired the Colorado-based band's debut also fulfilled something newer: the internet's need for easily digestible narrative. Luckily
column4: core married couple Alaina Moore and Patrick Riley had a real knack for breezy
column5: deceptively simple beach-pop that could get lodged in your head and inspire your own seafaring daydreams. Or at least make you jealous.

column1: Another story would seem to apply to Young and Old
column2: and it's the one about the ""difficult"" sophomore record. Musically
column3: Tennis have broadened their horizons just the right amount
column4: adding rock'n'roll muscle and a more purely pop clarity under the oversight of the Black Keys' drummer Patrick Carney
column5: who produced. A few songs still hit at the sense of love-drunk reverie that turned older tracks like ""Marathon"" and ""South Carolina"" into blog and college-radio hits. But Tennis couldn't keep writing sailing songs forever
column6: and the new batch doesn't pull us into their world quite as easily-- and it's not only for lack of convenient biographical shorthand. They've gone from under the boardwalk to stuck in the middle.

column1: For all that
column2: a whole lot of what's new here improves on the debut. Under Carney's direction
column3: Tennis upgrade their sonics without losing the fuzz. In fact
column4: sometimes there's even more fuzz
column5: such as in the nicely clanging lead riff on the album's first advance mp3
column6: sprightly piano-popper ""Origins"". Moore's full-throated lilt and multi-hued keyboard
column7: along with Riley's lissome guitar lines
column8: still aren't that far down the innocent coast from Beach House's supine dream-pop
column9: and now there are extra layers of vocal harmonies
column10: such as the appealingly Free Design-jazzy sha-la-las on ""Petition"". But Carney especially brings life to the percussion
column11: whether it's the huge handclaps on ""My Better Self""
column12: a swooning standout reminiscent of the Owls' underrated mid-2000s indie-pop gem ""Air""
column13: or the snapping snares on ""High Road"".

column1: ""Paradise is all around
column2: but happiness is never found
column3: Moore sings on that last song
column4: which might've been a strong unifying theme for the sophomore album-- a melancholy flipside to the debut's paradise-is-paradise uplift. Sure
column5: the songs on Young and Old occasionally bring back the romance of movement (optimistic ""Traveling"")
column6: and they're often introspective
column7: but instead the effect tends to be too confused
column8: stilted
column9: or generic to really pack the same wallop. The album's first words
column10: on mellow strummer ""It All Feels the Same""
column11: are ""took a train
column12: a potentially intriguing counterpart to sailing that isn't properly explored elsewhere on the record. Rather than at sea or on the railroad
column13: the lyrics lean toward awkward abstraction: ""Will you make my children bear the consequences everywhere?"" asks ""Origins"". Even on ""My Better Self""
column14: Moore philosophizes clumsily
column15: ""What is innate
column16: I do not know/ But meaning comes and it goes.""

column1: She sort of has a point
column2: though. As easy as it is to criticize acts that come to us with a ready-built narrative alongside their music
column3: storytelling and image-making have always been crucial elements of pop. What matters isn't whether a record comes with extra-musical buzz attached
column4: but whether the music is good enough to capitalize on that buzz. Cape Dory
column5: to my ears
column6: was; Young and Old is another example of a promising young act that found an audience quickly on the internet before fully coming into its own powers. In other words
column7: it's pretty good
column8: but also a bit disappointing. There's still plenty of time
column9: though
column10: and by album three
column11:
the duo that never originally set out to make music will have something else that can be invaluable for a working band: a little more experience in the trenches.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17422/homepage_large.8d2064ae.jpg|And Never Ending Nights|28881.0|Loops of Your Heart|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magazine']|2012-02-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:25.698099|"

Axel Willner has had loops on his mind a lot lately. He should
column2: probably: A broad definition of ""loop"" would encompass every single component piece of Wilner's work
column3: especially given his fondness for manicured sampling as the Field. His third Field album
column4: Looping State of Mind
column5: dropped last fall
column6: and here he returns as Loops of Your Heart
column7: a new project in the vein of the masters of German electronic music from whom he takes many of his cues.

column1: I'm always surprised
column2: when revisiting the Field albums
column3: how fast the tracks are. Willner's tempos blur his loops into proto-trance
column4: and they would sound furious if they weren't so pretty. On And Never Ending Nights
column5: Willner slows his roll. His loops
column6: instead of being swept into currents of sound
column7: ripple in muddy puddles. The result is a small and willing homage to the earthen psychedelia of artists like Ash Ra Tempel
column8: Cluster
column9: and Klaus Schulze.

column1: It's an attractive position for Willner to take: The Field records are airtight and modern
column2: rarely betraying influence. Never Ending Nights is too sober to effect the Martian moonscapes of those early electronic masters: It is compact in concept and execution. Where Tangerine Dream and Ash Ra Tempel allowed their instruments to fever for 20 and 30 minutes
column3: Willner attacks and releases precisely. Maybe we're all inured to these extended
column4: chapped arpeggios
column5: or perhaps Willner is too tethered to his predecessors
column6: but Never Ending Nights settles into a comfy pocket somewhere between motorik patter and ambiet drift.

column1: Willner is most successful when he tunes one of his sequencers to a snake-y rhythm. ""Broken Bow"" clangs and quivers for three minutes before a prowling synthesizer and growling guitar feedback hijack the track. ""Lost in the Mirror"" is too simple and good to screw up: a phasing arpeggio tickles the red as saucers hover. It is one excellent note. But if Willner seems in exact control of rhythmic elements
column2: he's less certain of glacial ones. ""Neukölln"" and ""Cries"" both lack conviction
column3: trusting the lapping tones of his keyboards to provide both beauty and structure.

column1: Never Ending Nights does contain one truly modern moment. During the opening minutes of ""Little You
column2: You Should Develop""-- a pretty
column3: faded bauble-- titular electronic splinters rise from the background. It's the singular sound-- I kid you not-- of a cell phone brushing too close to a speaker (and just as you check for flashing lights while driving and listening to hip-hop
column4: so too will you check the location of your phone). Loops of Your Heart isn't as darkly imaginative as Black to Comm or as committed as Emeralds
column5: and we are long past the point where we can call this manner of composition ""experimental."" Willner
column6: though
column7:
is an able synth scientist and a reverent listener.  Never Ending Nights contains just enough detail to save it from pastiche and in doing so offers a glimpse into Willner's influences.

The Maccabees emerged at a time when UK bands had it good. In the mid-2000s
column3: the Futureheads
column4: Bloc Party
column5: and Arctic Monkeys all released exciting debuts. And there was enough connective tissue between the groups to make them feel like they somehow belonged together-- shared post-punk influences helped in that regard. These bands made sense both in isolation and as a whole; the Maccabees debut record
column6: Colour it In
column7: slotted just fine on the racks next to Maximo Park.

column2: the world of indie bands in the UK is more fractured
column3: and the Maccabees struggle to find a foothold. They are the sort of band that looks much better in a throng. There's nothing especially remarkable about them and
column4: at this point
column5: they feel like a reflection of the stalled state of British indie music in general. Perhaps as a way to shake things up
column6: the band's third record
column7: <i>Given to the Wild
column8: looks to the sound of Wild Beasts and Foals
column9: two of the few real UK indie success stories of the past couple of years. On a similar tip they also enlist Tim Goldsworthy of DFA fame to produce
column10: though there's very little you would usually associate with him on this record.

column1: Setting aside the obvious grabs from other bands and sounds
column2: there are moments where the darker hues suggest that this is in fact a more interesting direction for the Maccabees. ""Child""
column3: for example
column4: revolves around an elastic bassline
column5: brass
column6: and descending guitar patterns
column7: and the harmonies are nicely laid for the first couple of minutes. The sense of restraint is effective
column8: allowing enough space to open up for each of those pleasing elements
column9: but then the final couple of minutes spoil things
column10: especially when an uninvited gaudy
column11: prog-guitar line crowds the party.

column1: Elsewhere on Given to the Wild
column2: the Maccabees grasp for big sounds and big ideas but fall way short. On ""Forever I've Known""
column3: singer Orlando Weeks does his best Win Butler impression
column4: and it's so accurate you could be forgiven for checking the liner notes for a guest appearance credit. It doesn't stop with the voice either. Weeks also mines classic Arcade Fire tropes with his lyrics-- mortality
column5: time
column6: loss-- but there's no narrative
column7: just a jumble of barely connected platitudes and simplistic resolutions such as
column8: ""Forever I've known
column9: nothing stays forever."" They shoot for the bigger picture again on ""Pelican""
column10: but there's no insight or depth to clichés such as
column11: ""One thing's for sure
column12: we're all getting older"" and ""Before you know it
column13: pushing up the daisies"". These are sentiments that would feel banal on a Facebook news feed
column14: let alone an album by a major label recording artist.

column1: Any hint of an interesting idea or sound on this record has been done better by somebody else-- and quite recently
column2: too. Surely there's nobody that would trade the rich textures and awkward sexual drama of ""Plaything"" by Wild Beasts for a bland quickie with anything on Given to the Wild. The personalities on this album are so blank the songs may as well be performed by apps
column3: and sung by Siri. The overriding message you get from Given to the Wild is that life is too short. As it clocks in at nearly an hour
column4: but feels much
column5: much longer
column6:
you finally think they might have a point.

Field Music have spent most of their career making post-punk for pop lovers. Like their North East England brethren the Futureheads and Maximo Park
column2: the duo had a penchant for playing cut and paste with clichés-- paying melodic homage to Paul McCartney
column3: but going art-school with its song form.

column1: But when the band's core members
column2: brothers Peter and David Brewis
column3: re-emerged from a three-year hiatus in 2010
column4: it seemed like they had ironed out their reservations about straightforward rock'n'roll. Not only was their comeback record
column5: Measure
column6: a double album-- the true standard for rock excess-- but it found them writing full-fledged songs
column7: complete with verses
column8: choruses
column9: and guitar solos.

column1: That's all over now
column2: though. Field Music's latest album
column3: Plumb
column4: finds them returning to the deconstructionist impulses that guided their earliest records. With 15 songs in 35 minutes
column5: this is Field Music at their most baroque-- a record of sweetly melodic miniatures that coalesce into form only long enough to tumble into the next meticulously designed song suite.

column1: Over the years
column2: Field Music have become the world's leading ambassadors of the a distinctly British musical style
column3: that of quaint suburban sensibility shot through with a dry self-depreciating sense of humor. The album's first three songs-- ""Start the Day Right""
column4: ""It's Okay to Change""
column5: and ""Sorry Again
column6: Mate""-- tumble into one another
column7: linked through a series of brain-teasing time signatures and transitions. But the subject matter is the stuff of the workaday world. ""Trying to beat the traffic
column8: meet the train only guessing the time
column9: sings David
column10: pondering his commute over solemn piano chords.

column1: ""Choosing Sides"" navigates between an odd time verse and a straight-laced chorus before jettisoning both feels for a buttoned-up take on electro funk. ""I want a different idea of what better can be that doesn't necessitate having more useless shit
column2: sings like a man who has come to a tough impasse with an Ikea instruction manual. For Field Music
column3: quiet desperation is still the English way
column4: even when they're riffing on Prince.

column1: They're better at this stuff now than they used to be
column2: though. The band's first releases
column3: Field Music and Tones of Town
column4: plied the same cut and paste techniques with less success. One plinky keyboard part gave way to the next
column5: often with little to help distinguish between ideas. Plumb has more dynamic. Where older Field Music songs used to rely heavily on static keyboard riffs
column6: they've learned to strip down and leave space for the drums tug the song forward. Each song-snippet sounds distinct and fully realized.

column1: But it's a bit disappointing to see the Brewis brothers walk away from Measure's more conventional approach. That record's best moments
column2: like the shimmering Big Star homage
column3: ""You and I""
column4: were patient and spacious. Plumb is a little too fussy. Great hooks rise up
column5: but are quickly abandoned in the rush to the next good idea. Taken out of context
column6:
Plumb's best songs don't stand on their own quite as well. It's better to take them on all at once in single gulp.

In Bill Brewster and Frank Broughton's Last Night a DJ Saved My Life
column3: the authors point out how the earliest acid-house tracks produced in Chicago in the late 1980s had more ties with the avant-garde than with the house sound that was getting Top 40 attention in certain parts of the globe. Listening back to Phuture's epic ""Acid Tracks"" outside of a club environment can push you into a cold
column4: harsh
column5: solitary state of mind. It's not quite the sound of dance music retreating from its inclusionary vibe
column6: as packed dancefloors spread out over innumerable acid revivals can testify. But early acid tracks like Lil' Louis' ""Video Clash"" and Armando's ""Downfall"" point inward more than they do outward
column7: accelerating away from the hands-in-the-air solidarity of club culture and into a far more isolated space.

column1: Most of the acid revivals over the years have disengaged from that side of the genre-- Fatboy Slim and the big beat movement of the mid-to-late 1990s took all the slippery twists of the Roland TB-303 and funneled them into happier
column2: stadium-filling anthems. But lately there's been a small band of musicians picking up on the raw
column3: untrammeled nihilism of the earliest acid house tracks
column4: singling out the sheer brute force of its core components and fusing them with outside influences. Factory Floor are the most high profile among them
column5: single-handedly creating their own new acid underground with additional nods to pop
column6: industrial
column7: and the clear-lines aesthetic of their partial namesakes
column8: Factory Records.

column1: In New York
column2: the Venezuelan electronic musician Carlos Giffoni
column3: mostly known for his excursions into noise
column4: has spent the last few years digging into a similar set of influences. His No Fun Acid project
column5: named by mashing up components of his No Fun festival and record label with his obvious debt to the sound of DJ Pierre and his cohorts
column6: was flooded with tinny pitter-patter drum patterns and the burbling screeches of a thoroughly agitated 303. On ""Evidence""
column7: a two-song 12"" for Ford & Lopatin's Software label
column8: Giffoni takes the next logical step in the evolution of that sound
column9: imprinting more of his personality on the work by cloaking it in the nebulous textures of his prior output.

column1: In a recent installment of the Out Door
column2: Marc Masters highlighted how a number of mainstays in the noise scene have retreated from all-out sonic assault
column3: turning to quieter corners for inspiration. ""Evidence"" ties into that trend
column4: beginning with a simple piano and vocal piece that mirrors the feeling his label boss
column5: Daniel Lopatin
column6: as Oneohtrix Point Never
column7: conjured up with Antony on ""Returnal"" in 2010. From there
column8: Giffoni coats the track in an inflexible block of acidic sound and his detached
column9: colorless vocal
column10: creating a jarring juxtaposition between delivery and verse (""it would be so easy to fall in love with you""). It's sparse and unrelentingly downbeat
column11: with a few cracks of light hacked into the murk by guest player Laurel Halo
column12: credited with ""manually mechanized piano and synth riffage.""

column1: The other track here
column2: ""Desire in the Summer""
column3: is similarly drained of emotion
column4: sounding like the slashed-up noise passages from Giffoni's Arrogance slowly sinking into battle with his new acid impulses. Again
column5: his bone-dry delivery percolates throughout
column6: positioning him as a survivor standing in the rubble as two genres go to war around him. This is a departure for Giffoni
column7: even from the more club-friendly No Fun Acid project. But it feels like a natural space for him to land in
column8: a way to align the abandon of his noise projects with the avant side of club culture that has obviously inspired him. ""Change is good
column9: Giffoni said
column10: in a 2010 interview with the Quietus. On ""Evidence""
column11: that desire for change has thrown key restraints on his sound
column12:
galvanizing him to create his most unique and bullish musical statement to date.

If you're unfamiliar
column2: Die Antwoord operate on the principle of ""zef
column3: a philosophy of intentional ignorance and crassness. It's the latest in series of personas for rapper Ninja
column4: né Watkin Tudor Jones
column5: but even with that conceptual bent in mind
column6: it's still hard to process Die Antwoord as an idea
column7: especially on Ten$ion where they replace what made them sometimes intriguing and slightly subversive with tired and tropes and lazy lyrics. In some ways it's the worst of both worlds: We've seen and heard it all before
column8: and now it's dumbed-down even further. The blunt simplicity of Ten$ion could be seen as the mastery and refinement of a fledgling aesthetic (stupid for the sake of stupid). But this is a step back. Whatever cultural interrogation Die Antwoord might have been performing with $O$-- and it was hard to tell-- is totally absent here.

column1: Die Antwoord abandoned their deal with Universal because of perceived pressure to be ""like everyone else out there at the moment
column2: and it's immediately clear from Ten$ion opener ""Never Le Nkemise 1"" that their sound has gotten a whole lot more... expensive. Earlier tracks like as ""Enter the Ninja"" and ""Wat Kyk Jy?"" hinted at big-room ambitions but still sounded endearingly cheap and shoddy. But ""Never Le Nkemise 1"" begins with a blockbuster-worthy bit of string-led melodrama and pseudo-choral vocals and quickly slams down into a-- what else?-- dubstep throwdown
column3: all fiery blazes of scorched-earth LFO threatening to drown out Ninja's screeches of ""that's why we keep it motherfucking gangsturrrrr!""

column1: Say what you want about this zany group of South Africans
column2: but attention-grabbing early singles like ""Enter the Ninja"" at least showed a clever dimension to their sound
column3: with quick-fire raps that were easy enough to get swept up in. But there's nothing remotely thought-out or careful about Ten$ion. Not that anyone expected subtlety from Die Antwoord
column4: but this is id rap at its worst
column5: and even their excess lacks scope or imagination.

column1: By its very nature
column2: the Die Antwoord project is style-over-substance
column3: but Ten$ion goes out of its way to prove that point. The boasting shouts of ""'EY SEXEE
column4: 'EY SEXEE"" on the chorus of ""Hey Sexy"" are hopelessly awkward
column5: and Ninja's Ludacris crib
column6: ""Get out the bitch
column7: get out the way
column8: feels like an embarrassingly misguided attempt at relating this duo to mainstream hip-hop currency-- a decade too late. If their lyrics are emptier than ever (""I took drugs at the age of 13/ Jesus Christ/ What the fuck?"")
column9: their attempts at shock value ring disturbingly hollow. If you aren't getting a little restless by the album's ending stretch
column10: ""DJ Hi-Tek Rulez"" might snap you out of a cock-eyed stupor with its gruff
column11: digitally altered grunts of ""DJ Hi-Tek will fuck you in the ass... You can't touch me
column12: faggot
column13: amid other violently homophobic slurs. There's no shortage of allowances made for this kind of stuff in hip-hop
column14: on an album this silly and concerned with dumb
column15: thoughtless fun
column16: it's especially troubling. It doesn't sound anything like a joke in the impenetrably convoluted layers of irony and self-mythologizing that is Die Antwoord.

column1: What are we left with then? Die Antwoord were stuck with the ""rave-rap"" tag from the beginning
column2: and it wasn't too bad a description
column3: emphasizing not only the trio's danceability and playfulness but also its stark-raving-mad
column4: go-for-broke tendencies. But this time around
column5: the emphasis is on the ""rave."" Which is great for the in-house production but detrimental to pretty much everything else. The songs here are even less collected than before
column6: jumping from flashpoint to flashpoint in a frenzied hunger to see how many times they can climax in each four-minute chunk of energy. It's exhausting
column7: and the fragmentary
column8: dissociative scatter takes the vitality and primacy out of the music. For a band so obsessed with its own self-consciously humorous image
column9: Ten$ion in part fails because it feels so strangely humorless.

column1: So while they might have succeeded in their quest to bypass the constraints of major-label rules and pressures-- apparently Universal rejected the album for being too vulgar-- they've gone and picked the most unfortunate parts of their oversized
column2: manufactured personalities to highlight. Ten$ion is proof that you need more than just aesthetic and press savvy to really get by. They might have left their potentially comfortable new home to forge their own path
column3:
but Die Antwoord sound like they have no idea where they're going.

Total running time of Year of the Tiger: 37:35. Total running time of the Ramones' debut album: 29:04. Total running time of Nick Drake's Pink Moon: 28:22. Total running time of Fela Kuti's Expensive Shit: 24:13. Let's call this an album
column2: OK? In any case
column3: Fucked Up have been releasing long songs for each year of the Chinese Zodiac since 2006
column4: although they're running a little behind at the moment. (The Year of the Tiger ended in February 2011; we've passed through the Rabbit Year and are now in the Dragon Year.)

column1: Year of the Tiger is a pair of tracks that have been around for a while-- the band claimed to have finished the title song almost two years ago. It's the first music we've heard from the band in a while that doesn't have some formal connection to their David Comes to Life project. ""Year of the Tiger"" itself is a 15-minute song with a very long lyric (apparently by guitarist Mike Haliechuk) about an aging tiger approaching his death. Fucked Up's lead bellower Damian Abraham gets most of the words to himself
column2: although he's also got some support: former Del-Byzanteens singer/keyboardist Jim Jarmusch-- yes
column3: fine
column4: he's a director
column5: too-- intones a few verses
column6: and either Annie-Claude Deschênes (of Duchess Says) or Katie Stelmanis (of Austra) or both add the pretty hey-I-can-actually-sing vocals that FU have been using for contrast with Abraham's voice over the past few years.

column1: The marvelous thing about ""Year of the Tiger"" is that it's actually a fully constructed song
column2: not a vamp-with-solos or a chain of vaguely related pieces segued together; it builds and builds and builds
column3: with one new riff after another uncoiling itself and wrapping around the pillar of all the others. It's bombastic as hell
column4: of course-- the keyboard part is the closest Fucked Up have ever come to Meat Loaf-- but this is the product of a band that thinks big. The song's weak point is its lyrics
column5: which have lots of sharply observed images (""his castle of gristle and bone"")
column6: but also too many passages with dodgy or overwrought diction (""that deathly coddle of light""). Abraham's guttural howl is a great equalizer of lyrics
column7: but the sung sections reveal the words' awkwardness: Lines such as
column8: ""Light drips like paint from heaven/ A shining pall on the horizon
column9: are easier to get away with screamed than chirped.

column1: Fucked Up's blog describes the second side of Year of the Tiger
column2: ""Onno""
column3: as ""a weird rager
column4: which is about right. It appears to be a full-on 22-minute instrumental palindrome
column5: a pyramidal stack of drones and riffs with a crashing forward-and-backward beat-- the closest thing they've ever produced to Melvins' more extreme recordings
column6: or to Hüsker Dü's ""Dreams Reoccurring"". For a ""studio experiment
column7: it's exceptionally listenable: Again
column8: this band is great at arrangements
column9: and every five-second segment of this record sounds almost but not quite like the one next to it. If it were in a movie soundtrack
column10: it'd have to be in a sequence with a violently strobing red light. It's too much
column11: too much
column12: too much-- exactly what we rely on Fucked Up for
column13:
that is. Who would ask for anything less?

Some records are defined by the time and place of their creation
column2: but Young Magic's piecemeal approach has the opposite effect. It doesn't sound like it came from a certain somewhere
column3: but rather everywhere. And it's a surprisingly cohesive work considering that it was recorded in several different countries and sutured together from singles and B-sides that have been around since 2010. So yeah
column4: Melt-- that's a great word for Young Magic's debut
column5: but ""blur
column6: ""smear
column7: or ""dissolve"" would also be acceptable.

column1: I suppose it goes without saying that Melt might inadvertently align itself with hyphenated genres many of you are looking to conscientiously avoid. It's a reductive
column2: but not completely off-base
column3: assumption. Sure
column4: these tracks are underpinned by West African rhythms (""The Dancer"")
column5: Brainfeeder's non-quantized drum smacks (""Sanctuary"")
column6: and the stutters of dubstep (""Drawing Down the Moon""). But for all of the trio's globe-trotting origins (two are Australian ex-pats
column7: one is a native Indonesian
column8: and all have traveled to multiple continents)
column9: there's an introversion and physical distance which bring to mind kids looking for the perfect beat while hunched over samplers and laptops in their apartments.

column1: But while the reverb is ample and the edges are soft
column2: it's a choice more functional than fashionable
column3: a conscious production decision to solder together disparate sounds into a textured whole. The rare times they're present
column4: guitars are tremeloed and processed to sound like balalaikas as opposed to chorded instruments
column5: and while the melodies are often pumped out by harsh
column6: exaggerated synths
column7: the percussion most often takes the tone of household objects-- rattling coins on ""Sparkly""
column8: pitched water jugs on ""Slip Time""
column9: alarm clocks and cell phones elsewhere.

column1: It's a cushy listen
column2: if not only always distinctive
column3: particularly since the shorter tracks often amount to a cooled
column4: deep-blue gelatin that holds the previously released singles together. But those three tracks instantly stand out less because of their familiarity and more because it's where Young Magic really leans into the listener rather than kicking back. Aggression isn't really their game
column5: so the chain-gang lurch of ""Sparkly"" effectively starts Melt on a slowly menacing opening note
column6: while the warped war chant of ""You With Air"" undergoes subtle digital damage that gives it tonal ambivalence. The centerpiece ""Night in the Ocean"" has a fairly self-explanatory title
column7: but an accurate one-- at once pulverizing and pristine
column8: it's an HD stunner amidst mostly Hipstamatic surrounding. These are also the best showcases for the interplay of Young Magic's vocalists: Melati Malay's coo flutters and glides as more of a shoegazey texture than a vessel for communication
column9: and while certainly not as pretty
column10: Isaac Emmanuel has something of a wounded half-rap that's ultimately more distinctive. Particularly when they trade off stoned mutters and airy ecstasy on ""Night in the Ocean""
column11: you could imagine Salem
column12: had they formed during the best semester abroad ever.

column1: But Melt can just as easily be seen as pragmatic
column2: offering solutions to questions left unanswered by some of the more disappointing trajectories taken by fellow indie psych travelers who once called NYC home: Are you a Yeasayer fan who instantly felt buyer's remorse the moment ""The Children"" introduced the wonky electro boondoggle Odd Blood? Wished High Places still sounded as
column3: well
column4: high as they did on their EPs? Just wanna see Here We Go Magic underwater? Melt has got your back. But those comparisons are every bit as useful for contrast-- you could get a sense of these bands' personalities beyond the manner in which they arranged their sounds
column5: and it's tougher to parse what Young Magic have to say. Are Young Magic hippies? Naive adventurers? Shut-ins obsessed with looping pedals? Melt conjures these admirable comparisons while avoiding any sort of concrete answer
column6:
but ultimately Young Magic can aspire to more by letting us know where they're coming from in a figurative sense.

Paris-dwelling DJ and producer Fetisch
column3: who makes up one half of Terranova with the Berlin-based house and techno-oriented artist &ME
column4: could no doubt spin a yarn or two about pivotal events in the history of club culture. If you're looking for someone who's been there
column5: done that
column6: and has all the scars to prove it
column7: Fetisch is your man. He's spun records at Danceteria and Tunnel in New York; recorded at Conny Plank's legendary Cologne studio; found himself at the epicenter of the original illegal rave boom in England; and worked with Manuel Göttsching
column8: Tricky
column9: and Ari-up from the Slits. Their latest record even features a bizarre cameo from German horror and exploitation actor Udo Kier. It's clearly a career that bears no particular focus or shape
column10: with the many-sided tracks on Hotel Amour spinning off from the all-embracing approach Fetisch has gleefully wallowed in over the years.

column1: As such
column2: this is a record with a handful of standout songs struggling and straining against one another after being crammed into the standard album format. It feels like a collection of tracks screaming for individual attention
column3: like precocious children all holding their hands up at the same time in class. The strength of Terranova's vocal collaborators are the primary cause of that
column4: with Fetisch and &ME drawing on some fiercely individual talent. Copenhagen-based singer Tomas Høffding leaves a sizable imprint
column5: in particular on ""Question Mark""
column6: which is positioned somewhere between the blubstep croon of Jamie Woon and Antony Hegarty's work with Hercules and Love Affair. Elsewhere
column7: the soft vocal intonations of Khan lend Hotel Amour the aura of post-rave comedown
column8: particularly on the blissfully understated ""So Strong"".

column1: The stylistic thrust of this album is caught somewhere between the current and the deep past
column2: with shades of modern pop production layered over the stripped-back grooves of vintage house. There aren't too many straightforward club bangers here
column3: but there are a few old school thrills to be derived from the undulating TB-303 bass ripples of ""I Want to Go Out"" and ""By My Side"". But taking such an unabashedly retro approach on certain tracks feels jarring when Terranova strive to be forward-thinking elsewhere. ""Take My Hand""
column4: the standout here
column5: is all coarse
column6: sputtering rhythms
column7: clattering tin-pot drums
column8: and heavily dubbed-out vocals. The closing ""Prayer""
column9: featuring Kier's glowering spoken-word extracts and a straight-down-the-line piece of torch singing from German vocalist Nicolette Krebitz
column10: is driven by the same kind of ambition DJ Hell was stirring up on his outstanding 2009 album Teufelswerk.

column1: But those tracks are mostly anomalies
column2: with too much of Hotel Amour sinking into territory that has been heavily mined in recent times. Billie Ray Martin gives an impressively robust vocal performance on ""Make Me Feel""
column3: but there's nothing in the limp backing that elevates it beyond the bevy of pallid trip-hop clones that clutched hard to the coattails of Massive Attack's Blue Lines 20 years ago. There's been a deluge of producers striving hard to work a darker edge into their material over the past decade
column4: and it feels like it will take something very special to stand out in a marketplace bursting at the seems with alleyway-dwelling artists scrambling to translate early-morning post-ecstasy cityscapes into song. This isn't that record
column5: but in ""Take My Hand"" and ""Prayer""
column6: there is a way out of the gloom
column7:
providing some distance from the genre mimicry it ducks into elsewhere.

Imbogodom's music can feel like walking inside a strange house at night and finding yourself momentarily startled by the sound of your own breath. Equal parts psych-folk songsmithery and musique concrète
column2: the project came together when New Zealand's Daniel Beban
column3: a multi-instrumentalist and tape artist
column4: was chalking and splicing tape for a living at the BBC World Service. Intrigued by some discarded reel-to-reel tape machines he uncovered inside the station's studios
column5: he began building compositions out of tape loops
column6: and invited his guitarist friend Alexander Tucker to come jam.

column1: Like their 2010 debut
column2: The Metallic Year
column3: the group's new record
column4: And They Turned Not When They Went
column5: reflects the slightly hallucinatory experiences that can arise from staying up very late at night and opening your ears. Recorded partly at the BBC's Bush House
column6: and partly in a lighthouse in the marshy Dungeness region of Kent
column7: it unfolds in a series of atmosphere-dripping vignettes
column8: shuttling strangely and abruptly from ramshackle folk to astral ambience and the sounds of a bell striking the wee hours of the morning. And They Turned Not When They Went opens with the deep
column9: resonant groan of London's Big Ben
column10: gently folded into tape-manipulated whirs
column11: loop-de-loops
column12: and grinding drones.

column1: But Imbogodom's music is more than just library-music clichés. Wherever they fall on the scale from abstraction to songcraft
column2: the album's 10 tracks reflect a constant negotiation between sound manipulation and live instrumentation
column3: or analog tape machine and guitar
column4: cello
column5: piano
column6: vocals
column7: drums
column8: and any number of non-musical objects that one of the two members might happen to pick up. Songs trail off with cascading echoes that recall the transitions of dub music; notes are manipulated to take on new meaning.

column1: The layered vocal line on album standout ""Heir Looms""
column2: for example
column3: is easily pretty enough to stand on its own
column4: but it is all the more beautiful for the moments when it shifts abruptly
column5: echoing into oblivion or pitched up an octave. Similar manipulations on ""Welcome Away"" transform a spoken word ""wrong number"" skit into a haunted phone call from the other side of the mirror
column6: and extreme slowing of vox on tracks like ""Etchum Buoy"" and ""I Am Here
column7: I Am Gone"" yields a cross between throat singing and the breathing of a sleeping creature. Listening to Imbogodom's second album
column8: there's the feeling that
column9: beyond its interest as a technical exercise
column10: speeding or slowing a given sound can set something free within it.

column1: Not all of the sounds here are easy on the ears
column2: and the music can encompass discomfort
column3: even ugliness. Cello can sound warm and rich or exposed and raw; the loose-skinned
column4: off-kilter drum patter and tuneless guitar picking on ""Window Faces"" sounds like an intentionally clumsy attempt at an acoustic marching band. You may not feel pleasure all the way through And They Turned Not When They Went
column5: but if you're drawn to the bizarre
column6: inconstant emotional terrain of late-night wakefulness
column7:
you'll find something honest.

Goldfrapp have spent the past decade moving back and forth between icy electro-glam and atmospheric balladry
column3: delivering these extremes in tonally consistent albums that dare to alienate listeners who favor one style over the other. Despite this polarity
column4: the duo has a remarkably consistent aesthetic
column5: with a gloss of aloof sexiness and cinematic glamour connecting the sci-fi cabaret number ""Utopia""
column6: the sinister S&M throbber ""Strict Machine""
column7: the swelling ballad ""Black Cherry""
column8: the glam rock stomp ""Ooh La La""
column9: and the spacey yet pastoral folk tune ""A&E"".

column1: The Singles
column2: their first hits collection
column3: makes a virtue of their range. The 14-track set pares their catalog down to only their 12 most successful singles and two new recordings
column4: resulting in a tight hour of their finest material sequenced like a dynamic
column5: eclectic pop album. A few worthy singles didn't make the cut-- the joyous ""Alive""
column6: the lushly psychedelic ""Caravan Girl""-- but concision trumps completism here
column7: and chronology is tossed out in favor of cohesion.

column1: Though Alison Goldfrapp and Will Gregory excel at crafting delicate
column2: seductive ambiance
column3: their most distinctive and influential music updates the aesthetics of glam rock with a harsh
column4: electronic edge. Their electroclash-era breakthrough hits ""Train"" and ""Strict Machine"" are built upon a mercilessly tight schaffel beat that highlights the lyrical themes of decadence and submission. A number of songs from this period aimed for this sort of severe sexiness
column5: but Goldfrapp nailed the tone by emphasizing elegance over sleaze
column6: and by evoking complicated
column7: often contradictory emotions rather than simply foregrounding a lewd subtext.

column1: The cuts from Supernature
column2: their finest album
column3: continue on with this general sound but loosen up to express giddy infatuation on ""Number 1"" and sensual swagger on ""Ooh La La""
column4: their most successful single to date. ""Ride a White Horse""
column5: perhaps their greatest song
column6: contrasts their oppressive dominatrix beat with an ecstatic
column7: airy chorus that provides a few moments of spiritual relief before returning to a lockstep that signals a barely repressed lust. Nearly a decade on
column8: these tracks still sound fresh and futuristic
column9: and despite generally getting lumped in with dance music
column10: they point in a direction of new possibilities for glam rock.

column1: With a body of work so focused on raw sexuality
column2: it can be easy to overlook the emotional content of Goldfrapp's music. Alison's vocal performances tend to be rather understated
column3: serving lyrics that deal with nuanced conflicts between pleasure and pain
column4: or giving voice to desperate
column5: lonely characters. ""A&E""
column6: the first single from their gentle
column7: often bleak 2008 record
column8: Seventh Tree
column9: is an outstanding showcase for both her lyrical and vocal strengths as she sings from the perspective of an incredibly lonely woman driven to a suicide attempt while waiting around for a phone call from a man she's not even sure she likes. The details are rich and vivid
column10: but the drama is muted
column11: even as her voice hits a gorgeous crest at the song's peak.

column1: Though Alison Goldfrapp is the star
column2: her vocals often defer to the sound of Gregory's arrangements
column3: which typically fill in the emotional range of the songs with melodic counterpoints and sonic detail. ""Melancholy Sky""
column4: one of the two new tracks on this compilation

column7: loungey debut
column8: Felt Mountain
column9: but Gregory's approach has evolved with time
column10: integrating elements of each record along the way. These songs may be a deliberate move to come full circle at the end of this retrospective set
column11: but they could just as well point to a future in which the duo can comfortably let all aspects of its sound coexist on one record
column12:
as they do on this collection.

Lindstrøm's second proper solo album
column2: Six Cups of Rebel
column3: does away with both the taut sexiness of his early work and the warm yacht breezes of Where You Go I Go Too in favor of something more bombastic but strangely cloistered. The pressure here builds and builds
column4: but rather than taking flight
column5: tracks like ""De Javu"" struggle with a misdirected explosion of percussion that flattens out into a farty bass riff smothered in layers of percussion. It's bloated
column6: lifeless
column7: and weighed down with its own multi-tracked mayhem
column8: a thick
column9: wet coat of gloss dragging propulsion down to a crawl more than anything else.

column1: Excess is nothing new for Lindstrøm
column2: but on Six Cups of Rebel he sounds lost. Synths layer endlessly and drums bang and clank-- this is some Emerson
column3: Lake & Palmer shit-- but whatever power they might possess is lost as the clutter breeds a numbing sense of saturation. The breathing room that was essential to Lindstrøm's original charm

column1: His last album-length effort

column5: garbled vocals are caught up in the soupy current of overdubs
column6: strangled of momentum or melodic cohesion. Even worse
column7: on ""Magik""
column8: they're pitched-down into ugly
column9: unnatural tones
column10: one of those ""what could he have possibly been thinking"" moments made only worse by the creepy backing chorus that emerges halfway through. It's cringe-inducing
column11: another misstep for a record that's already treading unsure ground.

column1: Rebel has a few nice moments. ""Quiet Place to Live""
column2: which spends its first three minutes hobbling on an awkwardly uneven vocal hook complete with stabbing bursts of electric guitar
column3: suddenly melts into a stunning keyboard breakdown halfway through. It's gorgeous in that silvery Lindstrøm way but completely aimless
column4: drenching the track in generic prettiness that wears after a few bars: The vocals continue to clash and everything sounds strangely out of tune
column5: as if he just dropped the organ carelessly on top of an entirely finished track. That brief glimmer of hope dissolves

column7: little drum fills and other pertinent details like specks of glitter on a gaudy neon canvas only adding to the fatigue. ""Call Me Anytime"" takes up a whole nine minutes

column2: an elongated horizon of shimmering keyboards and vocoders

column4: Lindstrøm's vocals fit better here

column7:
