The old order of Underground Rap went rudderless for a variety of reasons. Illegal downloading ruptured the already weak tendons of small independent labels. Fans favored 1990s nostalgia over out-there artistry. Top producers got tired of dealing with rap-biz bullshit and opted for MC-free experimentations with jazz
column2: soul
column3: and electronic. But my favorite theory is that most people got tired of rappers rapping about rapping.

column1: Due to its nature as a reactionary sect
column2: for the underground to evolve
column3: it had to do something more than stand athwart history and yell
column4: ""chill!!"" (In this re-enactment
column5: William F. Buckley is played by KRS-One). And there is no more elliptical act this side of a Steve Reich riff than writing lyrics about your lyrics. Yeah
column6: it might have been a building block in the on-and-on-to-the-break-of-dawn days
column7: but as George Harrison and Fatlip pointed out: All things pass. Swag will be ill before we know it.

column1: Over the last 24 months
column2: an ideology-free counter-culture rebuilt itself
column3: waving different banners and maintaining few borders. It's an underground in lowercase letters
column4: a constellation encircling everyone from Detroit amphetamine enthusiast Danny Brown to sardonic arsonists Das Racist and Open Mike Eagle
column5: to anesthetized Oakland cloud rappers
column6: to the Prosciutto-plumped adenoidal New Yorker Action Bronson
column7: and the cold-hearted Hempstead Rambo
column8: Roc Marciano. It includes older gods like Ishmael Butler (Shabazz Palaces/Digable Planets)
column9: Aesop Rock
column10: Brooklyn Bomb Squad scion El-P
column11: and the Dungeon Family's Killer Mike. So fluid are its boundaries that the latter two did a record together funded by Adult Swim money.

column1: Enter Sandman. So anachronistic as to appropriate the slang
column2: ""Homeboy."" Born name: Angel Del Villar. An ex-teacher
column3: Ivy League undergraduate
column4: and Hofstra Law student psychologically aligned to the older underground of 1995
column5: when the term meant Beatnuts and Do You Want More?!!!??!
column6: not Jurassic 5 and flip-flops. Sandman is the type of rapper beloved by hip-hop traditionalists: proudly old school
column7: technically savage
column8: and lyrically sharp. In the all-star game of the new subterranean
column9: he is the guy with flawless fundamentals
column10: wearing his socks high and his cleats sharp and polished.   So it was little surprise when the surviving infrastructure of the 1990s immediately supported Sandman: underground hip hop radio
column11: the Nuyorican Poets Café
column12: the XXL Chairman's Choice column
column13: and rap's Daily Worker
column14: Okayplayer. The straw poll was sealed when Sandman signed with Stones Throw
column15: one of the last garrisons of the late 90s
column16: an imprint blessed with the resources to shower him with proper promo
column17: branding
column18: and an array of dazzling sun- and smoke-carved beats.

column1: East meets west on Subject: Matter
column2: Sandman's debut EP for the label of Madlib and Dâm-Funk. To accompany the introduction
column3: Sandman added a subtext to his six-song collection
column4: noting on its cover that they encompass content that ""no one has ever rapped about before in the history of rap music. Unfortunately not a very difficult thing to do."" Sandman is as Queens as the Unisphere
column5: and his braggadocio bears a boldness that suggests that he grew up in the Bridge not Elmhurst. It's probably unnecessary arrogant
column6: but it also reflects a welcome sign of ambition. Few deducted points from Lil Wayne for boasting that he was the greatest rapper alive (even if 49 percent of the electorate disagreed). Nor should they blame Sandman much for his myopic history.

column1: After all
column2: the man can rhyme. A former saxman
column3: Sandman takes a modal approach with his screwball flow that dips and dives
column4: stops and starts. He bevels his patterns at bizarre angles
column5: employing a vocabulary worthy of Lisa Simpson. He's unapologetic about his intelligence
column6: and even if it skirts the line of pretension
column7: he keeps a progressive approach. Not only does he carefully weigh the importance of ""being nice
column8: he's focused on vivid storytelling too. Subject: Matter is both a self-challenge and the hurling of a gauntlet. Sandman wants to see his peers expand their imagination. And while the modern-day rap world has no scarcity of songs channeling topics of the zeitgeist (the entirety of XXX
column9: 1/3 of Watch the Throne
column10: whatever you make of Lil B)
column11: his originality is warmly welcomed
column12: if not demanded.

column1: So though ""The Miracle"" parallels the storylines of Pharoahe Monch's ""Rape"" and Mos Def's ""Love""
column2: it offers a penetrating analysis of the act of creation from Sandman's side. ""Unforgettable"" tells the tale of the woe brought onto a man too sprung on his ex. It mirrors a less-graphic version of Ghostface Killah's ""Marvel""
column3: but Sandman spins his own saga of picking up mediocre girls at Best Buy and sexing them while reminiscing on his last conquest. ""Canned Goods"" is about canned goods. Closing track ""Soap"" pictures a biblical deluge washing away the inequities of the world.

column1: The psychedelic
column2: elegiac beats are handled by 2 Hungry Bros
column3: Ben Grymm
column4: the Audible Doctor
column5: rThentic RTNC
column6: and the latest Stones Throw rated rookie

column1: After coasting in half-realized bliss for so long

column3: an electro-acoustic pioneer and inventor whom the Soviets put to work developing surveillance technology
column4: Daphne Oram seems like a star-crossed figure-- a visionary tripped up by circumstance and
column5: perhaps
column6: her own eccentricities. But a new anthology of Oram's work
column7: drawn from over 400 tapes she left behind after her death in 2003

column1: Oram's idiosyncratic methods and eccentric pursuits suggest the classic profile of the ""outsider"" artist
column2: but she spent much of her career deep inside the system. When she was just 18
column4: Oram found work as a studio engineer at the BBC. Her official duties there were often unglamorous
column5: but she took advantage of the studio to pursue her own experiments with magnetic tape and tone generators. The BBC's resources were actually quite meager
column6: at least compared to the studios in European cities like Paris and Cologne
column7: but Oram was resourceful: one story has her gathering all the BBC's tape machines together and working through the night on an electro-acoustic composition
column8: then dismantling the array and putting its components back in their proper places before work the next morning.

column1: Magnetic tape was a relatively recent medium
column2: and electronic sound generation was still in its infancy
column3: but Oram already grasped their enormous artistic potential. As she wrote in her 1972 book <i>An Individual Note: Music
column4: Sound
column5: and Electronics
column6: ""In my work I am not concerned with synthesizing orchestral sounds-- we have excellent orchestras for making those sounds. My interest is in making new sounds which are musical."" In 1957
column7: she recorded the first all-electronic composition to be played on the BBC
column8: and in 1958
column9: she finally received funding to open an electronic-music studio
column10: the BBC Radiophonic Workshop. Oram and her bosses had very different ideas about its purpose. She had imagined a research facility on par with the electronic-music studio at Cologne's NWDR or the Groupe de Recherche de Musique Concrete at Paris' RTF
column11: but the BBC was less interested in avant-garde composition than sound effects and background music
column12: regarding the Radiophonic Workshop-- so named to appease the musicians' union and other music departments at the BBC-- as a kind of sci-fi Foley studio. (Indeed
column13: today
column14: the Radiophonic Workshop is best known for the music and sound effects it produced for Doctor Who.) After just one year
column15: Oram left the BBC
column16: setting up her studio in a house in Kent.

column1: There
column2: she pursued a range of work
column3: both personal and commissioned
column4: including sound effects for Jack Clayton's 1961 film The Innocents and various television commercials. The commissions
column5: combined with a research grant
column6: helped fund her main project: a home-built apparatus called the Oramics Machine
column7: a combination synthesizer and sequencer that generated sound waves by ""reading"" hand-painted film strips with a reverse-engineered oscilloscope.

column1: It looked like a gigantic Meccano contraption
column2: and it was
column3: by all accounts
column4: a tremendously complicated device. What's more
column5: it was a perpetual work in progress
column6: under constant modification; only Oram and the engineers she employed really understood it. It's unclear when she stopped using the machine. By the late 1980s
column7: she told an interviewer that she had moved onto working with computers
column8: although she remained intent upon designing a system to read hand-drawn inputs. She suffered a series of strokes in the 1990s
column9: and she died in 2003. The Oramics Machine was left gathering cobwebs in Tower Folly
column10: which fell into ruin.

column1: The Oramics Machine was recently restored for the London Science Museum's exhibition Oramics to Electronica: Revealing Histories of Electronic Music
column2: coinciding with a growing re-appreciation of her work. But no matter how much biographical detail comes to light
column3: Oram and her work remain shrouded in mystery.

column1: This first volume of The Oram Tapes
column2: compiled from a trove of over 400 tapes held by Goldsmiths College
column3: reinforces that impression. Where 2007's Oramics 2xCD set brought together the quixotic warbles of her Oramics compositions with quirky genre studies and commercial commissions-- sound effects
column4: advertisements for Lego and power tools-- this release emphasizes her darker
column5: more minimalist and abstract sounds.

column1: Across 44 tracks
column2: the album is by turns hypnotic and jarring
column3: veering from sinewy drones
column4: suggestive of Kevin Drumm
column5: to pieces that sound like icicles being cleared from the eaves of a wind-chime factory. The prevailing mood is dank and claustrophobic
column6: however
column7: fogged with clammy reverb and bristling with strange clicks and alien voices.

column1: It sounds as futuristic as it did then
column2: but don't expect hi-fi: despite mastering by renowned Berlin's Dubplates & Mastering facility
column3: the audio can be murky. It's not hard to believe that the original tapes lay moldering in a box for years before their restoration. But that sense of decay actually contributes to the emotional resonance of the music. There's a veiled quality to much of it
column4: and a sense that there's so much more there than meets the ear

column1: The anthology is thin on data; few of the tracks have dates attached
column2: and there's little information on what Oram was using to make a particular piece-- or even why. Experiments with pulse and delay rub up against musical sketches
column3: spoken descriptions
column4: even a recording of a baby's birth. Two tracks titled ""2001 Effects Tape"" were presumably intended as submissions to Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. It all raises the question of how much of this Oram intended as music
column5: and how much the tracks are simply fragments of her work
column6: sketches torn from a notebook. But the compilers have made the most of the jumbled source material. In the liner notes
column7: they write
column8: ""As most of the tapes in the archive contain limited factual information
column9: descriptions or dates
column10: a chronological assessment of Oram's work was impossible to present. It is for this reason that we chose to arrange the tracklisting with an emotional narrative in mind
column11: as albums are often sequenced.""

column1: They've succeeded here. Purely as a listening experience
column2: it's wonderful. I've had it playing on nearly constant repeat during days of below-freezing temperatures in Berlin
column3: and there are times when I can't decide if the music is the perfect complement to the climate or vice versa. It's both gripping and distracting
column4: fading into the background and then jumping back out at you. In the few segments where Oram speaks
column5: detailing her craft
column6: it feels less like an archival document than a kind of relic
column7: a spectral emanation. Recalling the early belief in the phonograph as a spirit medium

column9: music and magnetism will lead us towards meta-physics""-- only reinforces the idea that there's something truly auratic humming in the grooves.

column1: In an Invisibile Jukebox feature in The Wire
column2: People Like Us' Vicki Bennett said of Oram

column4: unique frequency

When the Irish techno producer Donnacha Costello released his debut album
column3: Growing Up in Public
column4: its title crystallized a key dilemma of any emerging artist: At what point do you decide you're ready to venture out of the bedroom? That was back in 2000
column5: well before the internet had shifted into high gear; since then
column6: the coming-out process has gotten only harder.

column1: Barcelona's John Talabot and his first album
column2: ƒIN
column3: make for an interesting case study of the musical debutant: This is actually the artist's second time around. Under a different alias
column4: as a resident DJ at one of Barcelona's techno institutions
column5: he began his recording career in the mid 2000s
column6: making punchy
column7: melodic dance music with a clear debt to labels such as BPitch Control and Border Community. A few years later
column8: around the same time that Barcelona's techno scene and the styles that fueled it began to go stale
column9: his own productions began to shift. He eased into a mid-tempo chug and set aside buzzing synthesizers in favor of sun-bleached samples
column10: trading neon fizz for dandelion fluff. Like a company de-listing itself from the stock market
column11: the local fixture took himself private
column12: assuming a new alias and wiping the slate clean.

column1: It was a smart move. In the past two years
column2: Talabot has become an exemplar of a new breed of producers working at the intersection of deep house
column3: disco
column4: and indie pop
column5: and he has carved out his own niche somewhere between the slow-motion theatrics of artists such as Mark E and Tensnake
column6: the globe-trotting jewel tones of Four Tet and Caribou
column7: and the psych-pop rush of Animal Collective and Delorean. Having interviewed him a few times
column8: I don't think there's a calculating bone in the-artist-currently-known-as-John-Talabot's body
column9: but he has nevertheless benefited from being in the right place at the right time. His slow tempos
column10: supersaturated colors
column11: and tropical accents fit right in with the woozy
column12: humid dance music that's currently in vogue
column13: and he has found himself in esteemed company-- remixing the xx
column14: recruiting Glasser's Cameron Mesirow for guest vocals
column15: and releasing on Young Turks. He's currently on tour in Australia with SBTRKT
column16: another indicator that his star is on the rise.

column1: Ironically
column2: this all means that
column3: his quasi-anonymity aside
column4: Talabot finds himself growing up in public all over again as he graduates from singles and remixes to the full-length album form. Perhaps it's those raised stakes that make ƒIN feel like such a triumph. Across the album's 11 tracks
column5: Talabot builds upon his distinctive sound-- bursting with color
column6: nostalgic but never retro
column7: easy-going yet slightly unhinged-- without repeating himself.

column1: Talabot's early singles tended to follow a single trajectory
column2: beginning with a bed of chunky percussion and then piling on loops of acoustic guitars
column3: Philly strings
column4: and soaring
column5: pitched-up voices
column6: usually culminating in a swollen
column7: almost over-the-top climax. He hasn't entirely abandoned that approach
column8: but he hasn't remained shackled to it
column9: partly because he has shortened his track times considerably: Where his singles and remixes routinely ran seven
column10: eight
column11: even nine minutes
column12: most of ƒIN's tracks come in around the four-minute mark
column13: giving him the opportunity to experiment with more modest ideas that say their piece and move on.

column1: The album's first three songs show off his range. The opening ""Depak Ine""-- at seven-and-a-half minutes
column2: it's the LP's longest cut-- is disco by way of Depeche Mode
column3: with stabbing synths
column4: eerie vocal samples
column5: and an inexplicable chorus of croaking frogs. (The title resembles the brand name of a mood-stabilizing drug
column6: which might explain the shift from minor to major halfway through; perhaps the frogs denote side effects?) ""Destiny""
column7: a co-production with Madrid's Pional
column8: is one of the album's obvious standouts
column9: with beautifully harmonized vocals over lilting Caribbean chimes and a cozy
column10: reassuring chord progression. Then
column11: like a kind of palate cleanser
column12: the three-minute ""El Oeste"" is a sleek little miniature of melting synthesizers
column13: scraggly drum machines and dub delay that gradually swells into a folky
column14: Boards of Canada-gone-house vibe.

column1: A few times
column2: Talabot tries to recreate the sensation that he nailed on ""Sunshine""
column3: an early hit that was as subtle as an ice-cream headache. With its stabbing chords and sped-up vocal loops

column5: with everything pushed into the red and teetering on the verge of collapse. ""Journeys""
column6: the album's only misstep

column9: and the vocals

column1: A kind of happy melancholy informs most of the album
column2: but that unity of mood doesn't get in the way of the songs' potential to surprise. As many times as I listen

As a result

Thirty-five years into their start-and-stop career
column3: Wire are not short on live albums. This is the 15th they've released since 2004 through their own Pinkflag imprint
column4: covering all three incarnations of the band: the brittle
column5: brainy punks who hurtled artward from 1976 to 1980
column6: the poppy
column7: brainy ""beat-combo"" that branched out toward both alternative radio tunes and monomaniacal hammer-drone from 1985 to 1992
column8: and the tough
column9: brainy old guys who reconvened in 2000 and have been bearing down hard ever since. But the only really significant live Wire discs are the out-of-print Document and Eyewitness-- a bootleg-quality set centered on an abrasive 1980 gig that featured almost entirely new material-- and 1989's It's Beginning to and Back Again
column10: which was so heavily reworked in the studio that it's barely a live album at all.

column1: That shortlist hasn't changed with the new addition to the pile. The formal distinction of The Black Session is that it's the first recording to feature Wire's most recent stage lineup. (For those who haven't been following closely
column2: founding guitarist Bruce Gilbert left in the mid-2000s; Margaret Fielder McGinnis of Laika replaced him on tour for a few years
column3: and
column4: since 2010
column5: Matt Simms has augmented the remaining trio of original members on tour.)

column1: The days when Wire would turn up for gigs with a set of material the audience had never heard before
column2: or save the throwbacks for the encore
column3: are behind them. At this gig
column4: they run through the better part of 2011's Red Barked Tree
column5: basically ignore everything else from the past 24 years except for 2002's hardcore-velocity ""Comet""
column6: and toss in a couple of old favorites. It's particularly unsettling to hear ""Map Ref. 41ºN 93ºW""
column7: one of their most precisely constructed studio singles
column8: in a sloppy garage-band rendition-- metronomic drummer Robert Grey struggles to keep the tempo steady
column9: and singer/guitarist Colin Newman sounds uncomfortably exposed when nobody joins him for harmonies on the chorus. The final encore is one that rejoined their repertoire in 2000 and stayed there: ""Pink Flag""
column10: with its original two-chord structure replaced by a single blaring E chord at which they hammer for seven minutes or so until it disintegrates into end-of-show chaos.

column1: For Wirephiles
column2: the value of The Black Session is the live treatments of the Red Barked Tree tracks. As elegantly textured as that album was
column3: it also sounded reserved and unconvinced in places
column4: and tried to pass off some old Wire ideas as new ones. These versions have more fire and bite to them
column5: even on slow numbers like ""Down to This"" and ""Adapt""
column6: and the band has rearranged ""Clay"" to not sound quite so much like a faint carbon copy of 1978's ""I Am the Fly"". There's no getting over the resemblance of ""Moreover"" to Wire's 1979 single ""A Question of Degree""
column7: but it's mostly an excuse for them to stomp hard
column8: and for Simms and Newman to contrast a tightly wound little riff with a high-pressure spray of noise.

column1: In the context of Wire's catalog
column2: this is just another document of incremental change
column3: and not even the best live recording they've made lately (that would be their gorgeous Daytrotter session from 2008). Still
column4: if this were the only Wire record in existence-- a debut album by a new quartet
column5: three of them in their late 50s
column6: captured live on French radio-- it'd be bracingly new even in 2012
column7: an original take on punk minimalism
column8: guitar sound
column9: singing technique
column10: tunefulness vs. dissonance
column11: and so on. ""My God! They're so gifted!"" Newman yells in ""Two People in a Room""
column12:
and as usual he could be referring to himself and his collaborators.

Mux Mool's 2010 debut full-length
column2: Skulltaste
column3: held the promise of a whatever-works adventurer who could excel in just about any direction he was pointed. It was easy to assume after the fact that if Brian Lindgren focused on just one of his strengths-- Americanized French touch
column4: fat-bottomed analog hip-hop
column5: gauzy-yet-speaker-rattling downtempo ambient-- he could produce the next phase of a defining sound with real mutation potential. Planet High School narrows his scope and draws a more specific target
column6: streamlining those aforementioned touchstones into a blend of synthesized airiness and thick bass that sounds a bit like g-funk for planetariums. But as with his best tracks
column7: the common thread that runs through each song is a sense of restless metamorphosis
column8: the sense that there's no use wearing out a good loop when there's plenty of space to throw it around.

column1: There's a confident immediacy to the beats that initially drive them-- whether agitatedly hopped-up (""Raw Gore""
column2: ""Cash for Gold"") or floating at cruising speed (""Ruin Everything""
column3: ""Palace Chalice"")-- and Lindgren gives himself the space to jostle and upend their structures in freewheeling ways. There are so many rhythmic and melodic layers to each track that he often produces attention-getting dynamics just by fiddling with one of the elements
column4: dropping in or pulling out a bassline's notes to shift momentum without losing tempo
column5: or pushing a deceptively simple drum break into supple polyrhythms. It's not just about waiting for big drops or build-build-build-release catharsis; it's about constructing a track that ricochets inside itself
column6: splits
column7: regroups
column8: and counteracts itself several times in just a few bars without once losing grasp of its own forward movement. It's undeniably danceable
column9: but the pop-and-lock routines you could set to this might tear ACLs.

column1: It's when Lindgren tries to accelerate too far into frenetic overload that things start shaking apart. There are only three cuts of 10 that let the works go spiraling uncontrolled into the grandstands
column2: but they're pretty confounding
column3: trading off manic glitchiness and bewildering juxtapositions that upend what could have been a more naturalistic flow. ""Get Yer Alphabets (Guns)"" is the grimiest
column4: threatening bro-step wobbles and hiccup-spasm snares before settling on a warbly Squarepusher-ish bassline that doesn't quite lend itself to nuanced manipulation-- so it gets Benihana'd into an Adderall freakout instead. ""Live at 7-11"" sabotages its hypnotic
column5: swooning funk halfway through for a series of drum'n'bass crescendos that border on non-sequitur
column6: then peters into a woozy
column7: tacked-on codeine keyboard coda. And ""The Butterfly Technique"" tries to do for lo-fi samples what the other tracks did for thick analog sounds
column8: but if you can get past the stuck-doorbell intro and a frantic
column9: piano-driven attempt to grasp on to some semblance of groove
column10: you're still dealing with a pile-up of sounds that don't quite mesh. So maybe Mux Mool can't literally do everything-- but for the bulk of Planet High School
column11:
he's got himself an engaging something.

"|16242.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16242-mux-mool-planet-high-school/|6.7|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17419/homepage_large.0c93cd45.jpg|Feel the Sound|2092.0|Imperial Teen|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Merge']|2012-02-07 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:41.093343|"

At this point
column2: Imperial Teen's brand of sweet
column3: boisterous pop has been confined to indie's fringes
column4: but the band seems perfectly content to do its own thing in perpetuity and impervious to fashion. The time when Imperial Teen's music could have been considered sellable to America's radio suits
column5: that late-1990s moment when alt-rock shrugged off grunge gloom for gloss and smiles
column6: feels like it happened in another lifetime. As for all of the sounds that have come and gone in indie-land since-- from garage-rock revival to dance-punk to whatever the hell we're calling chillwave in the post-mortem period-- they might as well not have happened in Imperial Teen's world.

column1: This dogged insularity in the face of indie's endless trend-hopping is essentially a good thing
column2: even if you have to be down with Imperial Teen's basic routine of slick and déjà vu inducing power-pop hooks
column3: oveer-sugared harmonies
column4: and immediately sing-alongable choruses to need more than one record. And ""routine"" is the right word here
column5: even if I don't mean it as an insult. Following the band's relaxed
column6: ""let's put out an album every four or five years for fun"" release schedule
column7: the new Feel the Sound is sunny and bubbly
column8: but the bulk of these songs follow a very specific template with the rigor of any furrow-browed academic composer.

column1: A steady bubblegum beat
column2: somewhere between ABBA in motorik mode and the Archies-go-C86
column3: sets things up. Soft vocals
column4: sometimes harmonizing in time-honored indie pop tradition and sometimes solo
column5: carry us through a low-key verse. Then comes the explosive
column6: joyful chorus. Repeat a handful of times
column7: and we're out. Feel the Sound does its best to keep things varied by once again stretching beyond the stripped-down DIY guitar jangle of vintage indie pop. Imperial Teen haven't lost their knack for shining up these simple and familiar forms with careful (but not suffocating) ornamentation. And true
column8: things get a little darker in the album's middle stretch. But since this is Imperial Teen
column9: we're talking a rather gentle and non-threatening brand of darkness. ""Over His Head"" had me imagining a world where Sarah Cracknell joined a Cure tribute band rather than Saint Etienne
column10: their lone single winding up on a K-Tel compilation of moody goth-pop classics
column11: and ""Hanging About"" catches a similar vibe
column12: where pensive post-punk takes the proverbial chill pill.

column1: For the most part
column2: though
column3: from robotic-but-rambunctious opener ""Runaway"" to the late-album one-two closing swoon of ""It's You"" and ""Overtaken""
column4: Feel the Sound leans on Imperial Teen's puppyish charm and love for soft-rock's smooth bliss. The rock songs are revved-up but not macho. The ballads are written by folks who've studied the songs of 1960s and 1970s greats rather than smearing a bunch of feedback over some weedy purloined hooks. And yet
column5: despite their tendency toward pop formalism
column6: Imperial Teen are hardly the Ramones
column7: and Feel the Sound's got plenty of variety even within its own rather strict songwriting guidelines. It's not going to surprise anyone
column8: least of all longtime fans
column9: but it's not like there are dozens of similar acts around at the moment demanding your attention. And indie pop's current lesser lights usually lack for Imperial Teen's care and craft
column10: two aspects not to be knocked when dealing with the restrictions of the old verse-chorus-verse. Imperial Teen know what they like
column11: are content to do it well
column12:
and there's still more pleasure in that than next-big-thing culture often lets on.

"|16260.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16260-feel-the-sound/|6.2|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17408/homepage_large.822e6471.jpg|Paralytic Stalks|3139.0|Of Montreal|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2012-02-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:41.657322|"

of Montreal are not a band. Or
column2: at least
column3: they haven't been for quite some time: Since 2004's breakthrough sixth full-length
column4: Satanic Panic in the Attic
column5: Kevin Barnes has largely written
column6: recorded
column7: and performed every album on his own
column8: occasionally calling on outside collaborators (Janelle Monaé
column9: Solange Knowles
column10: Jon Brion) to add flourishes. He made the decision to shift toward creative solitude nearly eight years into a career that has now spanned 16
column11: and the decision made sense. Since Satanic Panic
column12: Barnes has treated the LP form as a highly personal forum exploration
column13: a place to indulge his every whim without regard for his audience.

column1: In that sense
column2: of Montreal's latest
column3: Paralytic Stalks
column4: is more of the same: Barnes recorded it in his own Sunlandic Studios with the assistance of strings arranger/performer Kishi Bashi and a smattering of session musicians
column5: and has stated that the album is meant to be taken whole. But even for a songwriter as sonically adventurous as Barnes
column6: something feels different this time around. He's always been fond of concepts (2008's alter-ego-happy Skeletal Lamping
column7: the funk freakouts of 2010's False Priest)
column8: but on Paralytic Stalks
column9: he sounds completely adrift
column10: as if his thousand-synapses-firing-all-at-once approach finally blew a massive fuse.

column1: When I spoke with Barnes this past fall about the influences driving the creation of Paralytic Stalks
column2: he cited difficult 20th-century composers such as Charles Ives and Krzysztof Penderecki
column3: predicting it'd be a hard sell for most listeners before doubling back and referring to it as a ""colorful pop record."" The truth lies somewhere in the middle. It is
column4: without a doubt
column5: his most fragmented album since the tail end of the project's Elephant 6 days
column6: which is saying a lot considering the tiny stitched-together segments made Skeletal Lamping such a challenging
column7: divisive album. To me
column8: that record sounded like a pleasurably jumbled mess of endless possibilities; Paralytic Stalks just sounds like a mess.

column1: The seam in Paralytic Stalks' patchwork comes at the midpoint of ""Ye
column2: Renew the Plaintiff""
column3: which delineates the album's two halves. The front half plays to strengths Barnes' has honed over the last eight years-- stuffed production on the brink of exploding
column4: melodies that constantly change direction
column5: and unhinged vocal performances. The hooks just aren't there
column6: though
column7: and that's a big problem
column8: considering that even Barnes' most esoteric records have had their share of memorable take-aways (Skeletal Lamping's ""An Eluardian Instance""
column9: False Priest's ""Our Riotous Defects""). With the possible exception of ""Malefic Dowery""
column10: which is surprisingly lush
column11: little here sticks.

column1: The ""20th-century classical music"" influence comes during the album's second half: Its songs run longer
column2: and they're packed with dissonant drones
column3: screeching noise
column4: and
column5: in the case of ""Exorcismic Breeding Knife""
column6: a surging orchestral cacophony. It's challenging stuff
column7: a distant cousin to the kind of abstractions that Barnes flirted with on last year's thecontrollersphere EP. Barnes doesn't go all-in
column8: but rather
column9: pastes bits of psychedelia
column10: stuttering synth-funk
column11: and hushed piano balladry on the ends of ""Wintered Debts"" and ""Authentic Pyrrhic Remission""
column12: which all feels utterly wasted given the shapeless and indistinct surroundings.

column1: The most disappointing aspect of Paralytic Stalks is that lack of personality behind the music. Barnes has treated songwriting as a personal therapy session
column2: and the recording studio as a psychologist's couch under mirrored ceilings. On 2007's brilliant <i><a href=""http://www.pitchfork.com/news/43989-of-montreals-kevin-barnes-talks-new-album-cassette-box-set-his-career/"" target=""_blank"">Hissing Fauna
column3: Are You the Destroyer?
column4: he faced off with his super-ego amidst infidelity
column5: depression
column6: and self-destruction; the following year's Skeletal Lamping contained so much him that he needed an alter-ego
column7: the glammy sexpot Georgie Fruit
column8: to get it all out there.

column1: The words ""personal"" and ""dark"" have been referenced in Paralytic's promotional lead-up
column2: but without a lyric sheet
column3: it's nearly impossible to tell that Barnes is singing about anything
column4: save for the surprisingly straightforward ""Malefic Dowery""
column5: which goes back to the the subject of infidelity. I don't doubt that this is a personal album for Barnes
column6: but on Hissing Fauna
column7: that was obvious-- all you had to do was listen. Here
column8: we're left sorting through lyrics like
column9: ""True love never mattered/ The two donkey jaws that were removed from our hearing.""

column1: It's hard to blame Barnes for being tired. Since the project's 1997 debut
column2: Cherry Peel
column3: of Montreal haven't gone a year without issuing some sort of new material. By now
column4: he's akin to a Steven Soderbergh
column5: an artist so driven to follow his muse that
column6: even in the face of exhaustion
column7:
the thought of retirement only spurs him to work more. The thoroughly unenjoyable Paralytic Stalks might be a sign that Barnes should take some time off and let the inspiration come to him.

"|16250.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16250-paralytic-stalks/|4.6|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17403/homepage_large.303f2020.jpg|Onwards to the Wall EP|5424.0|A Place to Bury Strangers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2012-02-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:42.276395|"

In November of last year
column2: A Place to Bury Strangers released ""So Far Away""
column3: the first taste from Onwards to the Wall
column4: the follow-up EP to their 2009 sophomore album
column5: Exploding Head. As a song
column6: ""So Far Away"" carried a lot of the same hallmarks of the material that had immediately preceded it
column7: but unlike the screeching
column8: industrial-minded manic power that defined much of their terrifically visceral self-titled debut
column9: it's a groomed
column10: economic kind of song that rounds-off all of the dangerous
column11: splintered ends. More notable was the video that accompanied the track
column12: a sort of ""flipbook"" montage of frontman Oliver Ackermann's own personal Hipstamatic photos
column13: stitched together to create a stop-motion-animation effect
column14: except with real live people and settings. Like rifling through the iPhone of a very busy and well-traveled guy
column15: it's actually a unique
column16: voyeuristic peek into the progression of a person's year
column17: complete with amorous cavorting
column18: gigging
column19: and passenger-side window boredom
column20: all set in some pretty stunning locales. But it should be said that
column21: aside from containing plenty of APTBS-related snaps thrown in the mix
column22: it's not a video that feels terribly representative of Ackermann's band. After a half-decade
column23: A Place to Bury Strangers aren't an act that's allowed their music to do much moving around
column25: they've let moodier tendencies prevail. In other words
column26: if the ""Stay Away"" video had solely been a document of APTBS's progression
column27: it wouldn't have been nearly as engaging.

column1: Onward to the Wall opens with ""I Lost You""
column2: and while it remains firmly in the band's wheelhouse
column3: it feels indicative of the APTBS that lives in the mind: A pummeling onslaught of of banshee-wail guitar stacked on top of a chugging motorik bass riff
column4: plus some gnarly
column5: rancid feedback. In essence
column6: it's a no-prisoners take that
column7: while nothing new
column8: is welcomingly jarring. It is by far the best of the five tracks offered here
column9: a return-to-form that seems to take the more calculated moves on Exploding Head and re-routes them back in the right direction. Unfortunately
column10: the rest of Onward to the Wall takes even fewer chances than Exploding Head did. The reality begins to set in that
column11: try as they might
column12: this is a band resigned to making ""mature"" post-punk tunes instead of tapping into its live-wire essence. Because when the title track shares more in common with an old She Wants Revenge cut than the slow-lane Dum Dum Girls cut it secretly wants to be
column13: well
column14: we got a problem. In essence
column15: if there's anything to be learned from this EP
column16: it's that the majority of APTBS's career can be chalked up to playing it safe. Which
column17: for a lot of us
column18: is wildly disheartening.

column1: It isn't to say there aren't some great little moments tucked in here and there. ""Nothing Will Surprise Me"" brings in bracing cat-in-heat guitar moans over a hardcore backbeat
column2: plus there's the aforementioned ""I Lost You"". But it means we're left with three other tracks that are characterless at best. I've never been too big a fan of Ackermann's goth-y
column3: dead-eyed delivery
column4: but it seems here as if the music is using his vocals as something of a guiding light. It amounts to a mostly homogenous
column5: toothless EP that seems to be aiming for a greater appeal
column6: but ends up appealing very little.

column1: Perhaps the most problematic thing about Onward to the Wall is its timing. As the profile of New York City bands making dangerous
column2: abrasive
column3: and loud music becomes increasingly elevated
column4: you can't help but yearn for the APTBS of five years ago. It would've been great to see them help supplement a bill along with the ranks of pig-fuck revivalists
column5: black metal revisionists
column6: and nü-noiseniks. Here
column7: they sound disconnected from what made them so visceral and captivating in the first place
column8: as if they're almost scared to go back. Instead
column9: they've resigned to making more color-by-numbers post punk that uses too many grays and not enough pure blacks
column10: and as time goes on
column11:
it feels as if their paint brush water is being incrementally diluted by half.

"|16244.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16244-a-place-to-bury-strangers-onward-to-the-wall/|5.8|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17404/homepage_large.c9f6b146.jpg|Keep it Together|30108.0|The Doozer|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Woodsist']|2012-02-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:42.803449|"

It seems as if every singer-songwriter with ""weird"" characteristics gets compared to the greats such as Syd Barrett
column2: or even the under-the-radar greats such as Chris Knox. Those comparisons won't be going away anytime soon for Cambridge
column3: UK singer-songwriter the Doozer
column4: though he's abandoned his solo setup and recorded Keep it Together with 11 other musicians. The style of his fourth album is actually far removed from Knox and Barrett. In its grab-bag-orchestra instrumentation and library-quiet charm
column5: the Doozer's songs are more in the realm of Glaswegian twee. Considering the experimental
column6: homespun vibe of the three albums that came before it
column7: Keep it Together's colorful arrangements give it the kind of vibrancy and pop-friendliness his past work was lacking.

column1: Opener ""Burning Bright"" shows the newly assembled band putting its best foot forward. Leaning on a sturdy vocal melody
column2: the track goes a long way on a simple chord progression
column3: scattered lyrics suggesting new beginnings
column4: and a buoyant string section. On Keep it Together as a whole
column5: the instruments come together surprisingly well for an artist normally used to a vastly more minimal setup. The songs are often lush and ornate
column6: and for any lover of unconventional instrumentation
column7: there are a few genuine surprises. (Sitar! A tuba reportedly bought from the Salvation Army!) Once the novelty of the added bells and whistles wears off
column8: however
column9: all you have is a pretty-but-boring pop album.

column1: Aside from ""Burning Bright"" and ballad ""The Island""
column2: the other songs barely deviate from the same plodding tempo
column3: making the album's 41 minutes seemingly last hours longer. There's rarely a surge in energy or even a mild outburst: The guitars are strummed politely
column4: and the drums are played with brushes. Even the aforementioned tuba loses its luster about halfway through ""Jobsworth"". In graduating from a cast of one to a cast of a dozen
column5: the Doozer not only jettisoned the more challenging aspects of his past albums
column6: he also got rid of what made them interesting.

column1: This could be forgiven if he were a more compelling songwriter
column2: but the added to clarity has made his lyrics unbearable to listen to. In trying to sound a little more poignant than your average songwriter with nothing to say
column3: Keep it Together has choruses built on dull motivation (""Fold Up Chair"")
column4: simple math (""The Island"")
column5: and elementary-school ecology (""Lowest Point""). Half-baked imagery peppers each of its songs: A man carrying a milk jug
column6: a rabbit scurrying around a hutch. Even if finding poignancy in the mundane was the Doozer's task
column7: there are no remarks on why the characters in his songs do what they do; they just do them and are off to the next part of their incredibly average day.

column1: There's a sense of mystery that surrounds the Doozer. Because there's almost no information about his personal life
column2: all we have to go on is his pseudonym and the music he's released. Considering the intrigue of his past work
column3:
Keep it Together makes a good case for why certain people choose to lead enigmatic lifestyles: Sometimes there's very little going on underneath the surface.

"|16245.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16245-keep-it-together/|5.8|Martin Douglas

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17406/homepage_large.af0c34e9.jpg|Man With Potential|30088.0|Pete Swanson|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Type']|2012-02-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:43.326069|"

Pete Swanson has long led a dual life as a noise musician (most famously in the late
column3: lamented duo Yellow Swans) and a social worker helping the homeless and mentally ill. When I asked him last year if he found any connections between those pursuits
column4: he recalled testing a virtual-reality machine that simulates schizophrenic hallucinations. To Swanson
column5: the bombardment of illogical stimuli felt ""psychedelic in the most terrible way""-- and similar to his music. ""There are these elements that [are] very concrete and consistent and musical
column6: and people can latch onto these things
column7: he said. ""But then there are all these other things happening-- distortions being introduced
column8: [and] chaotic elements that don't contribute musically
column9: but determine the trajectory of the piece.""

column1: That description certainly fits Man With Potential
column2: perhaps more than any other record he's been involved with. The handful of cassettes and LPs he has released since Yellow Swans disbanded in 2008 have had their share of distortion and chaos. But none has offered something this easy to latch onto. It comes in the form of a consistent
column3: prominent beat-- so prominent that some claim Swanson has ""gone techno."" This isn't completely new territory for him
column4: though-- Yellow Swans could drop a heavy beat too
column5: especially on their throbbing 2004 album Bring the Neon War Home.

column1: But even that blast of nuclear dance-noise didn't have the insistence and drive of Man With Potential. On most of the tracks
column2: this drive is like a caffeine-infused heartbeat
column3: pumping blood into a mix of buzzing tones
column4: rising waves
column5: and cutting noise. Swanson is usually partial to drones
column6: but here his approach is more precise and almost pointillist
column7: often sounding like a symphony of dot-matrix printers. Swarms of chirps
column8: whirrs
column9: blips
column10: and pops dart and dive around each other
column11: but they're all grounded by a relentless
column12: nerve-affecting pulse.

column1: Those words may make Man With Potential seem hyper and frenzied
column2: a blizzard of blinding sound. At times it does feel that way. ""Misery Beat"" opens the album in the midst of panic
column3: pounding and squeaking like Swanson has been sprinting for hours and we're just catching up. But the beat also has a calming effect. It stabilizes what might otherwise be dizzying
column4: like a sedative that makes chaos feel less frightening. It might sound paradoxical
column5: but there really is a meditative aspect to Swanson's flying noise. That's not surprising given his history of infusing all kinds of sounds with Zen-like serenity.

column1: In fact
column2: as fun and oddly danceable as these tracks can be
column3: the best are the most rhythmically serene. They're also the noisiest-- the granular grit of ""A&Ox0"" swells into soothing waves
column4: while closer ""Face the Music"" is the album's only slow track
column5: as bass lines rise into something like abstract metal or hardcore New Age. All those adjectives may be a lot to swallow
column6: but on Man With Potential Pete Swanson's ability to encompass many sounds and moods knows few bounds
column7:
if any.

"|16247.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16247-man-with-potential/|8.5|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17409/homepage_large.041934e6.jpg|Better Luck Next Life|29005.0|Royal Baths|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kanine']|2012-02-06 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:44.603717|"

The San Francisco garage-psych world isn't a bastion of optimism
column2: but it's a little too sunshiney for Royal Baths. Perhaps that's why the duo moved to Brooklyn ahead of the release of its second full-length
column3: Better Luck Next Life
column4: an album gloomy almost to the point of self-parody. It's nine songs about black souls
column5: black hearts
column6: S&M
column7: and dark lords pounded out over Bo Diddley beats. They don't skimp on the details
column8: either. For Royal Baths
column9: there is no question: The world is a vampire.

column1: In the past
column2: Royal Baths' music has been tagged as psychedelic if only because of their geographic proximity to groups like the Fresh & Onlys
column3: Thee Oh Sees
column4: and Ty Segall. But this latest set of songs yields little in the way of incense and peppermints. It's a sludgy
column5: turgid take on the blues
column6: swiping it's chief inspiration from the Velvet Underground but supplementing heavily with sounds from mid-1980s goth rockers like the Gun Club and the Bad Seeds. Each song is a handful of grotty chords strummed on a guitar with every string tuned to the same note.

column1: Royal Baths' debut LP
column2: Litanies
column3: was cobbled together in the band's practice space on a Tascam 388
column4: the Bay Area's leading choice for fuzz-tinged DIY-recording. The grotty production imbued their songs-- which were bleak and droney
column5: but eerily twee and melodic-- with an extra edge. This time around
column6: some of the grit is gone. So are the Aleister Crowley-meets-Beat Happening hooks. Whatever pop pretenses Royal Baths harbored
column7: they've mostly let them slide
column8: ditching verse-chorus-verse for static Diddley rhythm tracks that buoy Jigmae Baer's seedy monologues.

column1: For a record that concerns itself so heavily with evil
column2: though
column3: Better Luck Next Life is fairly subdued. Baer delivers his lyrics in a reedy
column4: muted tenor that wobbles in and out of key. It's an intentional effect
column5: meant to enhance the music's creep factor by delivering darkness in a disaffected voice
column6: but the blasé attitude makes it harder to buy in.

column1: The ecstatic call-and-response aspect of the blues is mostly missing. On ""Burned""
column2: Baer allots himself several minutes to trance out and unwind into the music while Cox pummels his guitar. But most of the songs are just short stories recited over droney chords. And the prose gets a little purple: ""Bloody landscapes are my daydreams
column3: bodies fall/ If I could touch the hem of Satan I would crawl
column4: sings Baer on ""Black Sheep"".

column1: But you can't quibble with Royal Baths' sincerity. They look the part
column2: for sure. Dressed in shredded paisley hand-me-downs
column3: guitarist Jeremy Cox resembles a zombie-makeup version of Jefferson Airplane's Marty Balin. Their tour ride is a Chevy Suburban spraypainted matte black. They're an iffy live band
column4: but on stage they project their weirder impulses well-- pummeling the audience with feedback
column5: barely hewing to the structures of their songs. On good nights
column6: the band conjures a singularly eerie vibe. But on Better Luck Next Life
column7:
it's not always coming through.

column1:

In the time since AraabMuzik linked up with Dipset and pegged himself to their reemergence with the door-smashing ""Salute"" beat
column2: he's become a web-2.0 model of the hip-hop producer as brand
column3: mapping his aesthetic vision onto an array of contexts. The surface-beautiful Electronic Dream
column4: for example
column5: introduced him to a wider audience in part because it veered from the tougher-sounding beats Araab makes for rappers. But it still made sense next to what came before
column6: offering up an entrancing
column7: self-contained sound that grabbed at dance club roots but darkened and abstracted its samples to suggest something private and intimate. And he has a serious live reputation
column8: with a unique approach to performance. AraabMuzik is a virtuoso percussionist whose instrument just happens to be an MPC pad
column9: and longtime Dipset fans and fashionable interlopers alike elbow one another for space around his table
column10: collectively freaking out over the physical spectacle. He's also booked for a Coachella slot this year
column11: and says he's planning to release a collaborative project with equally doted-upon Harlem rapper A$AP Rocky. You'd be hard-pressed to find a producer with as much reach as a solo commodity as Araab right now. He's having a moment.

column1: Given all of that
column2: the timing of Instrumental University feels off. It's a serviceable sampler of harder-knocking beats cleaved off largely unmemorable recent releases from some of his most trusted collaborators-- Lloyd Banks
column3: Fabolous
column4: Jim Jones and
column5: of course
column6: Dipset pals Cam'ron and Vado
column7: among others. And while it's perfectly natural for a producer in AraabMuzik's position to make a beat tape-- it's a time-honored rap tradition
column8: after all
column9: and he's indulged before-- it's not something that fits the arc of his current upswing.

column1: As the cover implies
column2: this is a release presumably aimed at beat nerds and aspiring rappers looking for tracks. That's disappointing if you're still high on Clams Casino's re-imagining of what this sort of thing can be-- his thick and stoned Instrumental Mixtape from last spring reinvigorated the idea of the producer as auteur instead of background figure. But Instrumental University sticks to a more traditional script. Given the fact that he's charging money for these tracks (many of which first appeared on free mixtapes)
column3: and peppering them with his increasingly annoying drop
column4: ""You are now listening to AraabMuzik
column5: Instrumental University might seem like a self-congratulatory stopgap if the beats weren't so consistently expert and sleek.

column1: He moves from the horror-film piano chords and signature echoey screams of ""1
column3: 3 Grind"" to the soul-sampling
column4: nearly Dipset-classic vibe of ""Ain't Mad Acha"". The same sensibility is obviously behind it
column5: but these tracks are built from a very different foundation than those found on billowy Electronic Dream. And because there are no beats taken from real hit-hits here (the instrumental from ""Salute"" and the unrelenting chipmunky smack of ""Rubberband Stacks"" are the closest we get)
column6: Araab avoids that unsatisfied lurch of anticipation for a familiar verse that never drops. In fact
column7: there's a strong inverse relationship between the listenability of the instrumentals and the strength of the tracks with verses.

column1: So this is background music
column2: sure
column3: a workmanlike collection of beats that oscillates within a narrow but extremely proficient range of sound. Still
column4: even for its failings as a proper album
column5: Instrumental University is still quintessential Araab
column6: constantly walking the razor-sharp line between glimmery and ominous. At this point
column7: he's still known first and foremost as someone who can pound the living daylight out of a set of MPC pads. But we're again reminded that his identity also rests in his distinctive ear for uneasy mood
column8:
a quality subtle and delicate and not tied to any one technique.

From music message boards to The Guardian
column2: the term ""hipster house"" popped up late last year to describe a recent wave of dance music being made by ""rock"" or otherwise non-dance types. It encompasses acts like Miracles Club
column3: Ital
column4: and their 100% Silk labelmates
column5: as well as like minds from the more established Italians Do It Better and DFA (Matmos member and Pitchfork contributor Drew Daniel rightly traces the approach's roots all the way back to Throbbing Gristle). The common thread is live electronic instrumentation and lo-fi recording as aesthetic choice (surely
column6: these acts could just as easily afford to drop Ableton onto their laptops as buy rhythm boxes). The approach may recall house's 808 roots
column7: but implicit in that troublesome ""hipster"" is the idea that these rock kids aren't taking dance music seriously or playing by its rules-- that they're treating it with the irony typically ascribed to the 2000s' favorite strawman. All of which makes Brooklyn duo Blondes both an archetypal hipster house act and a rewarding example of the tag's limitations.

column1: Archetypal because the duo of Zach Steinman and Sam Haar improvises on live instruments
column2: records tracks in single takes rather than endlessly re-tooling them in software
column3: and generally approaches making house tracks with an outsider's disregard for convention. The pair met while studying music and studio art at Oberlin College
column4: which also birthed nü-disco producer Morgan Geist
column5: amongst other acts
column6: and they bring both learned musicianship and a collegiate friendliness toward jamming to bear on their self-titled full-length debut.

column1: Their songs begin with an idea or two-- a beat
column2: an effect
column3: a bassline
column4: or synth phrase-- and gradually accrete more layers
column5: steadily drifting toward a sustained climax before fading out piece by piece. It's the meandering feel of a jam locked into a linear structure: tracks that privilege house's hypnotic repetitions over its cathartic patterns of build-and-release. Blondes' formal transparency-- the way you can see each element as its being added-- makes it easy to imagine them playing these songs live
column6: but they handily avoid the lo-fi ""live PA"" quality that makes some of their putative peers less than suitable for club sound systems and dance floors.

column1: Blondes collects three previously released 12""'s and a pair of new songs
column2: each arranged as oppositional A- and B-sides: ""Lover""/""Hater""
column3: ""Business""/""Pleasure""
column4: ""Water""/""Wine""
column5: and ""Gold""/""Amber"". These flipsides aren't exactly dub versions of their related tracks
column6: but they are frequently more subdued reflections-- the bright synth arpeggios and displaced voices on the A-sides submerged into deep house bass thump or ambient atmospherics on their reverse.

column1: A second disc of remixes generally pulls the tracks even further towards their polar extremes
column2: with typically mixed results. Optimo's JD Twitch ratchets up the tribal thump of ""Lover""
column3: while Dungeon Acid remake it as a sweat-dripping subterranean epic at 11 minutes. Andy Stott's ""Pleasure"" becomes a muffled deep house throb
column4: while Teengirl Fantasy's remix of ""Wine"" ups the lush synth pads and adds some piano tinkling
column5: and Bicep's remix of ""Water"" adds a pneumatic jacking beat and echoing diva vocals. Laurel Halo and Rene Hell respectively make ""Gold"" and ""Amber"" into gaseous ambient and an elegiac organ variation. At worst
column6: the remixes are fine but superfluous for all but the specialty DJ or completist; the highlights above make at turns interesting
column7: useful
column8: and simply pleasurable revisions.

column1: Early reviews situated Blondes as better headphone listening than dance-floor filler
column2: and while their releases prior to these 12""'s were more downtempo
column3: this also points to the fact that their songs are simply well produced
column4: as pleasurable on a pure sonic level as they are practical. Despite retaining a relaxed
column5: lightly psychedelic feel
column6: Blondes' songs are properly functionalist grooves. They may lack the rise-and-fall amplitude of traditional house
column7: but on what everyone from Philip Sherburne to the Moritz Von Oswald Trio have recognized as electronic music's ""horizontal"" axis
column8:
they succeed admirably. Only one h-word needed.

Almost three years ago a band called Trailer Trash Tracys surfaced on a No Pain In Pop compilation. Their song ""Strangling Good Guys"" stood out with its satisfyingly distorted drums and haze of lusty shoegaze pop. It was a cut that sounded fresh
column4: powerful
column5: and ended up feeling ahead of a curve that gave us the similarly fuzzy pop of the first Best Coast
column6: Pearl Harbor
column7: and Smith Westerns demos.

column1: A couple of singles and a long delay later
column2: the band finally arrives at its debut record
column3: Ester. While it's not a bad record
column4: it ranks as a disappointment. The re-recorded version of ""Strangling Good Guys"" acts as a handy capsule to illustrate its problems: The blown-out drums of before are now neutered and low in the mix
column5: and the toothy shattered-glass guitars are muzzled by newly flat production. It sounds like a song recorded by committee and subject to endless revisions
column6: each new take diluting the original's potency. The delight of the demo version was that it felt like it existed on instinct and gut feeling
column7: whereas this just sounds over-thought and dull.

column1: There's a minute of a great song in ""Dies in 55""
column2: but that also falls apart beneath cluttered
column3: confused elements. We're treated to awkward drum rolls
column4: non sequitur bass drops
column5: and a bassline that might well be offbeat
column6: though in such a rhythmless environment it's difficult to tell. There's nothing solid to glue these stuttering ideas together
column7: and what started brightly quickly becomes a mess.

column1: Trailer Trash Tracys sound much better when they mine simple patterns. ""You Wish You Were Red"" is carried by a basic beat
column2: nonchalant guitar
column3: and a sparse bass pattern. The economy of ideas means that each good one has space to really work. The restraint lends the song an airy glow and also allows Susanne Aztoria's honeyed vocals to come to the fore.

column1: ""Candy Girl"" is another high point. The song first emerged a couple of years ago and
column2: unlike ""Strangling Good Guys""
column3: sounds as good as ever. The booming electronic drums and dirty
column4: crackling guitar still carry a feeling of effortless cool as Aztoria's vocal swoops and dives. Her impressive knack for a tune is the band's big strength
column5: and it's a shame that too often those melodies are squeezed or thrown off course by unnecessary parts.

column1: ""Engelhardt's Arizona"" is a perfect example of this. Aztoria's yearning vocal fizzes with intrigue
column2: sounding a bit like Nina Persson of the Cardigans
column3: but it's almost impossible to pick out any nuance beneath a maddening guitar part that feels like the product of somebody who just learned hammer-on techniques and wanted to show them off.

column1: That the 30-odd minutes of Ester took so long to finalize makes for a slightly baffling proposition
column2: given that its two best moments sound so casually off-the-cuff and effortless. At this point it's hard not to feel like the Trailer Trash Tracys who sounded pretty vital in 2009 have been left behind by a whole slew of bands that followed their starting gun and reached the finishing line quicker
column3:
and better.

""I do not like change! I do not like change!"" When Tobin Prinz hollered those lines on Prinzhorn Dance School's 2007 self-titled debut
column2: he was speaking in the crotchety voice of an uptight conservative caricature. But
column3: judging by this five-years-in-the-waiting follow-up
column4: the line serves as a handy bumper-sticker advertisement for his own band's cryogenically sealed post-punk aesthetic.

column1: If Gang of Four famously extracted the sex out of funk
column2: then Prinzhorn Dance School suck the funk out of Gang of Four
column3: retaining their violent guitar spasms
column4: ominous bass throbs
column5: derisive vocal interplay
column6: and the claustrophobic
column7: Entertainment!-style production
column8: but breaking up the 4/4 fluidity into hiccupping
column9: epileptic rhythms that
column10: true to the PDS name
column11: would seemingly require some educational instruction on how to dance to them. Where most bands reemerge from an extended absence exhibiting changed perspectives and freshly absorbed new influence
column12: Prinzhorn Dance School remain defiantly un-evolved. No string sections
column13: dubstep makeovers
column14: or
column15: hell
column16: even a single cheery synthesizer line for these two; the challenge of telling the two albums apart could form the basis of a great dorm-room drinking game. But then
column17: as that first record made clear
column18: Prinzhorn Dance School's proudly spartan setup is simply a reflection of the harsh
column19: unforgiving
column20: hand-to-mouth nature of modern English life-- and it's not as if an interim economic collapse has made the situation any more promising.

column1: And so Clay Class presents familiarly despairing scenes of ""granite-gray"" skies and ""concrete hinterlands
column2: while the band's instrumental economy extends to the songwriting
column3: which can quantify the magnitude of the global recession in a single dispiriting couplet (""Got off the treadmill
column4: treadmill/ Got in the breadline
column5: breadline"") or disarmingly evocative image (""A tin of mixed fruit/ On special occasions""). As co-vocalists
column6: Prinz and partner Suzi Horn rarely play off one another
column7: or try to assert their individual identities; rather
column8: their disparate voices-- a withering
column9: monotone sing-speak for him
column10: hyperactive yelps for her-- simply deliver the same dispiriting news with different degrees of anxiety.

column1: In the absence of any marked sonic or thematic progression
column2: Clay Class at least captures the duo's growth as song arrangers
column3: as they utilize their limited tools to greater dramatic effect. Where the songs on PDS' debut tended to stop once the duo ran out of things to say
column4: Clay Class harnesses the band's repetitive bassline riffs and stuttering drum breaks to subtly ramp up the intensity (as on the extended shout-it-out chorus of ""Your Fire Has Gone Out!"") or uses them as foundations for melodic exploration: over the course of its five minutes
column5: ""Turn Up the Lights"" magically changes its tenor from paranoid to optimistic without ever deviating from its core bassline or metronomic kick-drum beat. And with their usual matter-of-fact manifestos replaced by a more gentle harmony vocal
column6: ""I Want You"" stands as Clay Class' greatest breakthrough
column7: as the duo hew toward pop xx-ability by proffering a more personal
column8: intimate narrative than their hardened worldview normally allows. Compared to the dramatic artistic strides that kindred spirits These New Puritans made on their sophomore release (2010's Hidden)
column9: Clay Class feels disappointingly stagnant. But it does offer encouraging signs that a blade of grass or two can sprout up from cracks in Prinzhorn Dance School's cold
column10:
concrete world.

If the hardest thing for a new rock band to do is be original
column2: then the second hardest is to be scary. Most artists deploying horror-movie imagery and shock tactics inevitably succumb to campy theatricality (as seen in everyone from Marilyn Manson to the earliest iteration of the Horrors)
column3: or are quick to explain it away as just a ruse (e.g.
column4: Odd Future saying they're just joshin' with all that rape-and-murder business)
column5: and lest we forget that the most well-worn metaphor used to describe death metal invokes a character from Sesame Street. But the songs that have startled me the most-- Suicide's ""Frankie Teardrop""
column6: Nick Cave & the Bad Seeds' ""Hard-On for Love""
column7: the Jesus Lizard's ""Killer McHann""-- are unnerving to me not so much for their overt aggression as their matter-of-fact realism
column8: where the line between singer and subject is blurred
column9: and sound and fury coalesce into a vivid
column10: very real portrait of violent psychosis.

column1: New York foursome Pop. 1280 are not shy about showing their hand-- they take their name from a Jim Thompson crime novel about a killer cop
column2: and they've given their first full-length album the self-explanatory title of The Horror. Pop. 1280 wallow in the same pool of pigfuck sloppy seconds as East Coast contemporaries Pissed Jeans and the Men
column3: but where those bands respectively soften their blows (somewhat) with wry observations about domesticity and knowing classic-rock references
column4: Pop. 1280 offer no such salve. If the ray-gunned synth-punk stylings of the band's debut 2010 EP
column5: The Grid
column6: suggested a certain fondness for cheeky
column7: B-movie thrills
column8: The Horror is a far more traumatic experience
column9: conjuring all the dystopian futurism of an early David Cronenberg film
column10: but delivered with merciless
column11: medieval brute force. The first words we hear on the album are ""two dogs fucking""; it proves to be The Horror's most romantic lyric.

column1: Band co-founders Chris Bug and Ivan Lip recorded The Horror with a different drummer and keyboardist from The Grid
column2: and the difference is immediately palpable-- rather than provide a clear separation of bass
column3: synths
column4: and Lip's Birthday Party-esque guitar scrapes
column5: the three elements are often compacted into one monolithic
column6: doomy frequency that hangs over the record like a cloud of black smoke. But new drummer Zach Ziemann does a fine job of pushing the proverbial boulder up the mountain. For all its oppressive heaviness
column7: The Horror has energy and verve to spare: ""Bodies in the Dunes"" sets its apocalyptic death-toll imagery to a heart-racing tribal stomp that doesn't relent for five minutes
column8: while ""New Electronix"" sounds like a summit between 1990s Touch and Go greats Brainiac and Girls Against Boys. Ironically
column9: when Bug starts shouting out explicit dance-move instructions (""Hips to the right/ And hips to the left!"") on ""Nature Boy""
column10: the song's convulsing groove slows to a sludgy grind
column11: making his directives sound less like an invitation to shimmy than militaristic orders shouted at some poor captive trapped at the bottom of a well.

column1: Bug isn't the most dynamic vocalist-- sounding not unlike Liars' Angus Andrew played at 16 rpm-- but for a band as harsh as this
column2: he need not display a range of emotions so long as he convincingly conveys the right ones: grim and grimmer. And it's The Horror's dirgey digressions that actually best showcase his cold-blooded character
column3: whether shaming a submissive subject into acting like a dog on ""Beg Like a Human""
column4: or taking no small amount of glee in describing the agonizing process of dying by the noose on ""Hang Em' High"". In a world this bleak
column5: the best you can hope for is a quick
column6: easy death
column7: and yet even then Pop. 1280 won't let you off that easy-- as Bug cautions us at the outset
column8: ""Life after death is a painful life."" But he can rest assured that
column9: with an album as unabashedly grim and unforgiving as The Horror
column10:
he needn't have to worry about being granted eternal salvation.

There's a disarming honesty to the way Michigan-based husband and wife duo Windy & Carl communicate with one another. A blog post from Windy
column2: published in late 2011
column3: describes the making of We Will Always Be

column8: she wrote. That type of candor doesn't stop at the written word; it also bleeds through into the duo's music. Often their work is collaborative
column9: at other times there are vast expanses of sound featuring Carl playing alone. Either way
column10: this album
column11: their first since Songs for the Broken Hearted in 2008
column12: is executed with openness and sincerity
column13: making it feel as if the usual barriers between audience and performer simply aren't there. When Windy & Carl lock together

column1: This record shifts through three distinct phases
column2: with a definitive beginning
column3: middle
column4: and end. It travels from temperate ripples at the start through craggy rock faces in the center. The close is like an impossibly smooth glide across freshly laid snow. As with most of Windy & Carl's music

column6: which shifts from rueful acoustic work (""For Rosa"") to forceful
column7: repetitive drone rock (""Fainting in the Presence of the Lord""). The spaces in-between those extremes are smudged with color

column9: Windy & Carl's work often resembles the sound of a couple retreating from the world in order to understand their place within it.

column1: The way We Will Always Be is put together only adds to that feeling. It resembles an orderly dissection of the relationship cycle
column2: where unruffled
column3: carefree beginnings melt into discord and conflict
column4: ultimately settling into the strange kind of parity that outsiders to any long-term relationship find hard to fathom. Their musical assimilation of that rocky mid-section
column5: where the delicate framework of understanding built up around a couple feels as if it could crash and fall at any minute
column6: is the most spectacular. It begins in the climb out of ""Remember"" and into ""Fainting in the Presence of the Lord"". The latter
column7: almost 19 minutes long
column8: is full of cadaverous twirls of processed noise
column9: which get sucked into an atom-smashing guitar loop that trudges into the middle of the song
column10: heaving it to a lumbering close. Whatever Windy & Carl are working out here
column11: which even Windy's candid blog posts don't reveal
column12: it's clearly taken them to some dark places.

column1: Despite feeling like the work of a couple laying themselves bare
column2: it's also music to get lost in

That duality of purpose is one of the greatest strengths Windy & Carl possess-- the ability to conjure up contrasting feelings through their work. It's what makes an album like We Will Always Be worth returning to often

Here's an incomplete recap of the Twilight Sad's self-reported listening syllabus leading up to their third album

column3: Magazine
column4: Autechre

column6: Nine Inch Nails. In other words

column1: Now here's a nearly complete list of who No One Can Ever Know actually sounds like: The Twilight Sad. That's also a good thing. No One Can Ever Know is kind of a failure as a total sonic rebranding
column2: but it's a strong transition for the band into something a little more form-fitting while carrying over their commitment to morose atmosphere and Graham's handsome vocals

column1: Still

column3: two records whose wildly bright timbres and celebratory attitudes exist somewhere way the fuck on the other side of the world from where the Twilight Sad set up shop. That's still the case if song titles like ""Kill It in the Morning"" and ""Dead City"" are any indication of what's to come
column4: and they sure are. It's tough to pinpoint the exact contributions
column5: but whether Weatherall was meant as a spiritual adviser or a contributor is a moot point-- the Twilight Sad intended for this to be a frigid
column6: militant
column7: and rhythmic record
column8: and they got it.

column1: The main difference is the shape these songs allow themselves to take: ""Cold Days From the Birdhouse"" and ""I Became a Prostitute"" achieved weapons-grade catharsis by cresting and crashing unexpectedly
column2: visually represented by right-angle dynamics. No longer able to fall back on volcanic distortion to bring the big moments
column3: the Twilight Sad have more curvature and forward motion
column4: something closer to the color-drained gothic clangor of Pornography-era Cure (""Don't Look at Me"") or ""Street Spirit""/""Knives Out"" Radiohead (particularly ""Sick"") than any of the post-punk firebrands they namechecked. Accordions (or approximations thereof) wheeze
column5: artificial strings moan
column6: and guitars are thick with distortion
column7: yet everything feels of a single piece
column8: and at first it makes No One feel a bit limited dynamically compared to its predecessors. But it's a record more about obsession than release
column9: and the mesmerizing
column10: cyclical guitar figures of ""Sick"" and the throttle-down locomotion of ""Don't Move"" make the best use of repetition as a conveyance of passion.

column1: Easy as it is to dwell on the instrumental changes
column2: No One focuses on what might not be Graham's rangiest performance
column3: but certainly his most absorbing. His vocals have always been too prominent to make the shoegaze comparisons stick
column4: and he's just less of a competitor for sonic space this time around
column5: which is key to understanding No One's appeal. Though an undoubtedly emotive singer
column6: Graham isn't much of a details guy-- there was something post-traumatic about Fourteen and Forget
column7: the sudden rupturing of the music acting as a counterbalance to Graham's lyrics
column8: which were evocative in a general sense and every bit as repressed in a literal one. The emotions were identifiable
column9: the events not so much. There was no real way to determine what they were ""about"" specifically
column10: which is true of No One Can Ever Know as well
column11: but there's a crucial role reversal for both Graham and the listener
column12: in that the former is an aggressor rather than a victim and the latter is assumed to actually be in on the conversation rather than being a therapeutic sounding board. Or maybe we're in on a confession-- Graham's words are carefully chosen and ominous
column13: something like an urgent call on a tapped phone. Something has clearly gone wrong
column14: possibly a murder but definitely a love crime.

column1: Throughout
column2: Graham does little to distinguish between the two
column3: he and an unnamed other ""paired off in the violence."" The chorus of subtly dramatic opener ""Alphabet"" contains the Twilight Sad's most surefooted melody and Graham's most legible declaration: ""So sick to death of the sight of you now/ Safe to say I've never wanted you more."" Likewise
column4: on ""Don't Move""
column5: Graham's brogue smears the album's two parallel
column6: primal instincts (""I want you more than you will ever know"" and ""I'll hurt you more than you will ever know"")
column7: his dead-eyed recitation of those words betraying that he's hanging on for dear life to any kind of sanity. It's not really accurate to call ""Kill It in the Morning"" delayed gratification-- not when No One is actually the most sedate and evil Twilight Sad album-- but after five minutes of spiky industrial grind
column8: the music drops out for an exasperated Graham to yell

column1: It gives the feeling of a story completed

column7: the attempts to push the boundaries of sound and setting result in the least-insular Twilight Sad album to date-- the kids are still on fire
column8:
they've just left the bedroom.
