Even among the topmost tier of hallowed indie rock labels
column2: it's tough finding an imprint that's permeated underground music's subconscious as profoundly as Flying Nun. Founded in 1981
column3: when punk's initial explosion was still ricocheting around globe
column4: the Christchurch
column5: New Zealand-based label put its faith in scrappy
column6: locally grown pop-- music that was heavy on the jangly guitars
column7: but generally low on polish
column8: bands like the Clean
column9: the Bats
column10: the Chills
column11: and the Tall Dwarfs.

column1: Virtually every decent guitar record pressed in the three decades since has owed some sort of debt to the Kiwi jangle pop-- see Galaxie 500's On Fire
column2: Pavement's Slanted & Enchanted
column3: or Yo La Tengo's Painful. I'm convinced that ""Pink Frosty""
column4: from Fugazi's End Hits is a nod to the Chills' spooky post-punk classic
column5: ""Pink Frost""
column6: though I've never taken the initiative to verify it. (But
column7: come on; listen to them back to back and tell me that they aren't similar.)

column1: More recently
column2: bands such as Real Estate
column3: Woods
column4: Vivian Girls
column5: and Crystal Stilts (basically
column6: anything on Brooklyn-born record label Woodsist) have picked up the torch for the jangle-pop side of imprint's oeuvre. It would wrong to label it a revival
column7: though. In 30 years
column8: the Flying Nun sound has never slipped too far from the conversation.

column1: Tally Ho is Flying Nun's greatest-hits record
column2: released partly to honor the label's 30th birthday. A 2xCD set
column3: the compilation bundles together tunes from across the label's catalog
column4: from late-1980s classics to material gleaned from more recent signings. Flying Nun is no stranger to comp records. The label has already gathered together its out-of-print singles (Where in the World is Wendy Broccoli?)
column5: lauded its contributions to the indie-pop landscape (Speed of Sound)
column6: celebrated at least three birthdays with label-history-spanning mix CDs (10th
column7: 21st years) and
column8: for the 25th anniversary
column9: an exhaustive 4xCD box set.

column1: This time around
column2: they go for the middle ground. The late-1980s groups that established the label's legend are all accounted for and frequently represented by their most recognizable songs
column3: such as the Chills' shimmering ""Heavenly Pop Hit"" and the Clean's three-chord classic
column4: ""Tally Ho!"" from which the collection takes its name. But Tally Ho also weaves in some of the roster's lesser known acts-- bands like Look Blue Go Purple
column5: Sneaky Feelings
column6: and the Headless Chickens
column7: that
column8: until now
column9: only your Audio Galaxy-mining college roommate ever had the wherewithal to dig up. The comp makes a concerted effort to avoid short changing Flying Nun's newer additions
column10: but most seem skippable when slotted alongside groups from the label's late-80s to mid-90s golden era.

column1: Hearing 30 years of Flying Nun records stacked up alongside one another speaks well to the breadth of the label's taste. While the Dunedin Sound-- the jangle pop tones favored by the Chills
column2: the Bats
column3: and the Clean-- tends to steal the spotlight
column4: Flying Nun's aesthetic is not easily pigeonholed. The label also ponied up the cash to release aggressive and noisy music
column5: such as the Gordons
column6: New Zealand's answer to Flipper (who later morphed into the more overtly psychedelic Bailter Space)
column7: and scrape and drone pioneers the Dead C. Loud
column8: brutal
column9: druggy music that couldn't possibly score a radio hit
column10:
even at the bottom of the world.

On paper
column2: Doc Daneeka and Benjamin Damage seem like such a perfect match that you'd expect any musical collaboration to mirror their work apart: Damage
column3: with or without erstwhile partner Venom
column4: has specialized in bouncy bass-driven house heavy on UK funky snares
column5: while Doc Daneeka has peddled a slightly more rigorous but no less athletic take on precisely the same sound (check 2010's furrow-browed but undeniably huge remix of Breach's ""Fatherless""). So it's surprising how subtle
column6: sedate
column7: and frankly unlike their former selves They!Live turns out to be; the transformation reminds me of raver friends who hooked up on a drug binge and then promptly moved out to the suburbs to grow vegetables together.

column1: There was a honeymoon moment where the partying trajectory carried through the first flush of romance: On their first single together
column2: last year's aptly named ""Creeper""
column3: Daneeka and Damage hit upon the best of all possible worlds
column4: offering a throbbing bad dream of strobing
column5: bleepy synth organ riffs over remorseless 4x4 kick drums
column6: if not ""Show Me Love"" then maybe ""Show Me Anxiety"". In the tune's second half
column7: after a build up that becomes more deliciously interminable with each replay
column8: they unleash a thunderous rave breakbeat rhythm over a woman's outraged declaration
column9: ""you're nasty!""-- the massiveness of the revelation made possible only by the drawn-out nature of the slow-reveal. In its simplicity and patience
column10: ""Creeper"" seemed at odds with both the rave revivalism it superficially referenced (in truth the result was closer to early Underworld) and the typically cluttered post-everything maximalism of current UK dance music (not to mention Damage and Daneeka's own pasts).

column1: They!Live stretches the already strained relationship further
column2: offering nine voluptuously melancholy tech-house slowburners
column3: each trying to outdo the other for how tightly wound it can hold itself
column4: how reluctantly it can give up its secrets. In many ways this is a fine thing
column5: not least because even as they embrace grayscale
column6: pseudo-minimal tech-house with gusto
column7: the duo cannot help but infuse the arrangements with its trademark rhythmic restlessness
column8: evidenced less by a riot of percussion than by its careful
column9: strategic deployment within slippery
column10: snaking grooves
column11: like the papery
column12: syncopated snares weaving in and out of the distracted
column13: sleepy female vocals of ""Battleships""
column14: or the stop-start tango struggling to emerge out of the bleak techno pound of ""Ellipsis Torment""
column15: or the tiny
column16: irresistible drum rolls that seem so out-of-place and yet so welcome on the otherwise severe
column17: glacial closer ""Bleach & Penicillin"".

column1: But it's a problem for They!Live that a foreshortened
column2: less charming ""Creeper""
column3: if not the album's loudest moment
column4: remains by some distance its most memorable and gregarious
column5: with only the melancholy stutters of ""Charlottenburg"" and the clipped
column6: synth-driven house of ""Juggernaut"" coming remotely close. Part of the problem
column7: though only part
column8: is that the duo have swapped a Spartan (albeit decreasingly so) musical landscape for a densely populated one
column9: and then set out about erasing any tell-tale signs that they haven't been living in the neighborhood forever. Maybe they need to hang out with the locals more: Like many UK producers who have travelled to Berlin and become entranced by its techno culture
column10: Damage and Daneeka have absorbed much of the city's musical seriousness and subtlety
column11: and some of its emotional sweep
column12: but too little of its frenzy or perverse sense of humor. It'd be much easier to love
column13: as opposed to merely like
column14: They!Live's glistening
column15:
long-form tech-house soundscapes if there were more bombs and curveballs hidden amongst its lovingly pruned forest glades.

Old Ideas is
column2: in its own tender
column3: smirking
column4: Leonard Cohen-y way
column5: a clever title. In one sense
column6: the ideas here are ones we've heard from Cohen before: Life is a nostalgic
column7: sorrowful experience punctuated by the occasional joke; language can clarify as much as it can obscure; and lust is one of the highest forms of prayer. In another sense
column8: Cohen is telling us that the ideas on this album-- home
column9: healing
column10: origins
column11: and endings-- are ideas that take on a starker
column12: more metaphorical weight as time goes on. We can trust Cohen to know: Over the past 77 years
column13: he has
column14: in a graceful but inevitable way
column15: become old.

column1: Cohen's voice has always sounded deep
column2: flat
column3: and naturalistic-- the kind of performance that attempts to sound like it's no performance at all. To describe the changes in it over the past 10 or 15 years
column4: I defer in part to those little booklets that come around the necks of good Scotch: A powerful body of peat smoke with a briny finish. In essence
column5: a whisper-- the voice of a voice whose center has been carved away. Old Ideas doesn't remind me of Bob Dylan as much it does of late Johnny Cash records
column6: or even Charlie Louvin's Steps to Heaven: documents of voices so heavy and close that to hear them is to smell the singer's breath and see the gradient of yellow on their teeth.

column1: It's easy to think of Cohen as a folksinger since ""folksinger"" is common shorthand for musicians who tend to privilege words over music. Cohen
column2: though
column3: tends to go where his musical collaborators and arrangers lead him
column4: whether it's grimy dive-bar ballads
column5: disco
column6: bare-bones guitar blues
column7: or orchestral elaborations. For a Zen monk who started his career as a poet
column8: Leonard Cohen has used a lot of synth horns.

column1: Old Ideas is a spare
column2: low-key album rooted in blues and gospel-- maybe the closest thing he's made to ""folk"" music since the early 1970s. Backup singers sing passionate
column3: wordless melodies; the bass sounds like the big
column4: upright kind. I think it's his first studio album in 20 years to not rely exclusively on drum machines for percussion. The musical setting suits the state of his voice
column5: which is meant as a mixed compliment: One of the great things about hearing his 1980s and 1990s albums was trying to reconcile his heroic presence with all the Casios. Some of the best moments on Old Ideas-- like the bizarre foregrounding of synthesizer during the album's first thirty seconds-- prove that Cohen and his collaborators have the wits to remind listeners that as soon as tape is rolling
column6: nothing-- no croak
column7: no wail
column8: no plea-- is all-natural.

column1: Cohen's voice alone
column2: though
column3: is a gorgeous
column4: singular instrument. It carries in it a quality that is difficult to discuss without either becoming sentimental or appealing to the misguided idea that just because you play an acoustic guitar or sing close to the microphone
column5: what you do is more honest than someone who attempts to create an experience of truth in some other way. It's a voice that mimics states of human yearning: The point at which we start to sound too tired or worn-down to speak
column6: the point at which we start to cry
column7: the way we whisper to people whom we are very
column8: very close.

column1: Maybe it's only context that makes me think that songs such as ""Show Me the Place""
column2: where his voice becomes so weak it nearly falls silent in the middle of a line
column3: is anything more than maudlin. Maybe the past 40-plus years of music serve as some kind of apology
column4: as though to publicly reckon with the fact that according to the World Bank you are fast approaching life expectancy is something Cohen-- or any human being-- needs to earn their right to.

column1: This is not the best album Cohen has put out. It is also not The Bucket List-- certainly not cheap or trivial or trading on his age alone. The songs are decent
column2:
the singing is stunning. He claims to be naked and filthy. He claims to be a lazy bastard. He claims to have been a slave for love. But he has claimed these things before. He is as old as he has ever been.

The institution of classic rock-- and all the FM-radio stations
column2: VH1 specials
column3: and ""Disco Sucks"" rallies it has propagated-- is built upon a certain they-don't-make-'em-like-they-used-to purism. But the genre's most esteemed icons have ultimately survived because they've occasionally been willing to break down rock's rigidity to absorb decidedly non-rock influences
column4: be it the Stones flirting with reggae and disco on Black and Blue
column5: Paul McCartney trying his hand at new wave on McCartney II
column6: or Neil Young's infamous synth-pop odyssey Trans. None of these may count as those artists' definitive works but
column7: given that rock'n'roll itself began as an unholy union of blues
column8: jazz
column9: folk
column10: and country
column11: these sorts of sacreligious stylistic detours and genre experiments were arguably truer to the music's original spirit than anything that tried to milk fresh inspiration from the I
column12: IV
column13: and V chords.

column1: Jennifer Herrema's first band
column2: Royal Trux
column3: understood this all too well
column4: as she and partner Neil Hagerty broke down and reassembled their 1970s blues-rock foundation into all sorts of distorted shapes over the course of a tangled
column5: tangential 10-album discography. But since that band dissolved in 2001
column6: Herrema has been following a more linear path with her post-Trux outfit RTX
column7: who
column8: with each successive record
column9: have been gradually refining and polishing themselves into the last hair-metal band standing-- a stance so antithetical to prevailing indie-rock mores
column10: it's practically avant garde. If Royal Trux were about deconstructing rock mythology
column11: RTX aggressively reasserted it
column12: from the cover-art drawings of Herrema that look like they were cribbed from some daydreaming high-school student's notepad
column13: to giving their studio albums titles such as JJ Got Live RaTX that suggest they're some long-lost concert bootleg
column14: to the intra-band references (RTX being an acronym that first appeared in the 1990 Royal Trux track ""RTX-USA"") that casts Herrema's entire oeuvre as some sort of secret-society code waiting to be deciphered.

column1: The narrative gets even more convoluted with the arrival of Black Bananas
column2: which boasts the same personnel as RTX; copped its name from an RTX song lyric; and whose debut album title
column3: Rad Times Xpress IV
column4: makes a smidgen of sense only if seen as the fourth RTX effort. (It also includes a song titled
column5: confusingly enough
column6: ""RTX Go-Go"".) And RTX's penchant for straight-up sleazy rock'n'roll carried through to the new band's first public offering last fall
column7: a faithful cover of the Stones' ""Before They Make Me Run""
column8: complete with an uncannily Neil Hagerty-like guest vocal from Kurt Vile that actually makes the song sound more like Royal Trux than anything RTX ever attempted.

column1: But that cover selection proves prophetic not for its form but for its source: 1978's Some Girls
column2: arguably the Stones' most stylistically varied album
column3: what with Mick Jagger channelling his New York-nightlife escapades into the Studio 54 strut of ""Miss You"" and the CBGB snarl of ""Shattered"". Following the same logic
column4: Herrema fashions Black Bananas as an alternate-universe RTX who aren't afraid to absorb more modern influences like synth-pop
column5: hip-hop
column6: French-touch house
column7: and (for 10 seconds of ""RTX Go-Go"" at least) dancehall
column8: while guitarist Brian McKinley lays off the usual Eddie Van Halen histrionics in favor of lysergic Eddie Hazel funk. The album doesn't so much begin as burst its dam
column9: with opener ""It's Cool"" arriving in such a thick surge of wah-wahed guitars and phased-out synths
column10: it takes you a minute to realize the song actually adheres to standard blues structure.

column1: In accommodating all of these disparate sound sources in a limited-range but densely textured mix
column2: Rad Times Xpress IV finds a direct antecedent in Royal Trux's 1998 classic Accelerator (which essentially sounded like an arena-rock band playing inside of a vacuum cleaner) while feeling remarkably of a piece with contemporary strains of chillwave and electro-rock. (To wit
column3: Black Bananas' first North American tour sees them opening for Sleigh Bells.) Where past RTX albums faithfully approximated the flash and thrash of 1980s metal with all the diligence of a Civil War reenactment
column4: Rad Times Xpress IV illuminates how well that music lends itself to more experimental renderings (the tape-decayed boogie of ""TV Trouble"" and ""Hot Stupid"" sound like Aerosmith as produced by Ariel Pink; ""Rad Times"" crosswires Kraftwerkian funk and KISS crunch) while the songs seemingly engineered to hold onto RTX's denim'n'leather constituency yield surprises: ""Acid Song"" is actually a sultry slow jam
column5: and ""Killer Weed"" rides its Ted Nugent riffs into a dubby denouement. However
column6: even as its title track excitedly welcomes us to ""The future! The future!
column7: Rad Times Xpress IV doesn't shy away from referencing Herrema's notorious junkie past
column8: as ""Foxy Playground"" recounts all the times and ways she ""could've died."" But instead of playing up the pathos of that sentiment
column9: the song's slinky bounce effectively plays it for laughs
column10: and for good reason: Twenty-four years into her musical career and still busting skulls
column11:
Jennifer Herrema is not about to let a little rumination on mortality get in the way of a rad time.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17394/homepage_large.05cae3ff.jpg|I Love You|28802.0|Jason Urick|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2012-02-01 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:16:52.587689|"

The changes in a single Jason Urick track are gradual and sometimes imperceptible. But his musical development across records he's made for Thrill Jockey since his band Wzt Hearts broke up is clear. Husbands
column2: from 2009
column3: offered mostly thick drones
column4: suggesting a digital take on Spacemen 3's further-out meditations. Dub-inflected loops lurked beneath the drones on 2010's Fussing & Fighting 12"". Now
column5: on his best effort yet
column6: I Love You
column7: Urick's dub obsessions have moved to the front of the room.

column1: Urick hasn't abandoned drone-- layers of noise and columns of sound remain primary colors in his palette. But what sticks strongest in memory after I Love You flows through your ears are the hypnotic cycles of bass
column2: beat
column3: and melody. Think of drone as the light Urick shines on his loops
column4: or the water he sprays on them: The sheen makes them glisten and thicken as they slowly gain texture
column5: but they hold up through the noise
column6: rarely burning out or washing away under the busy sonics.

column1: The clearest and perhaps catchiest example is I Love You's middle track
column2: ""Ageless Isms"". It opens with a reggae hook
column3: which Urick douses in brittle screech
column4: warps with wavy noise
column5: and stretches with phases that seem to stop time. All of these moves make the song radiate
column6: even as the original hook gets cut until it bleeds. By the end
column7: that hook is no longer prominent
column8: but its ghost persists like a shadow stretching past the horizon.

column1: Such morphing is perhaps what Urick means when he explains how the album title (taken from a film about a man obsessed with a talking keychain that says ""I love you"" incessantly) became a personal mantra. ""[I kept] running the phrase over and over in my head
column2: he says in press materials
column3: ""until the words started to break down and render the phrase foreign again."" Oddly
column4: the album's most interesting piece
column5: ""Don't Digital""
column6: is its least repetitive. But the way Urick melts all his sounds together
column7: and the hue of Eastern ritual they exude
column8: gives the track a devout feel. It's cyclical in a way that suggests something primal
column9: like the movement of tides or the rotation of the earth.

column1: Which makes the cover image of I Love You-- the crystal-clear ""Blue Marble"" shot of the earth from space-- a bit obvious. But Urick seems uninterested in hiding ideas under ironic distance or opaque sonics. As complex and dense as these five songs can be
column2: you can always hear everything going on. So even when he closes the record with his thickest cut
column3: ""Syndromes""
column4:
there's a clear vision that's apparent long before his drones shrink down to a lone rhythm. Maybe that's what Urick means by I Love You-- he's too enamored of the sounds he gathers to lock them up in noise.

Last year was a weird one for albums by rap duos. We had Jay-Z and Kanye
column3: Eminem and Royce Da 5'9""
column4: and of course Gucci Mane
column5: who released two major label duo albums-- the disappointing Ferrari Boyz with Waka Flocka Flame and the bizarre BAYTL with Kreayshawn associate V-Nasty. This time out
column6: Waka pairs with French Montana
column7: who has worked extensively with the currently imprisoned Max B
column8: formally of the Harlem based Byrdgang.

column1: Coming from Atlanta by way of New York City
column2: Waka's energetic and aggressive style has endured longer than most probably would have suspected. When he released his first single
column3: ""O Let's Do It""
column4: he was mostly known as the guy standing in the shadows of old Gucci Mane and OJ Da Juiceman videos. French Montana has been around for a few more years than Waka in the New York mixtape circuit
column5: but last year's ""Choppa Choppa Down"" and his most recent single
column6: ""Shot Caller""
column7: got him signed to Bad Boy Records and got his name out there nationwide.

column1: Given the players
column2: you might expect Lock Out to be an East Coast rap affair
column3: but with a couple of exceptions (the bouncy seriousness of ""Dat All"" and the triumphant finale of ""Promise"")
column4: the tape sounds well-grounded in the streets of Atlanta. The production on Lock Out is handled mostly by two producers with whom Waka has worked extensively (Southside and Lex Luger)
column5: alongside other lesser-knowns who share an appreciation for dark
column6: brooding beats that are
column7: ultimately
column8: pretty hard to distinguish from one another. The first half of the tape finds French Montana struggling to find his footing as his flow reduces songs to a slow creak
column9: while Waka affirms his ability to rip any rap instrumental he comes across. ""1230"" has a great opening verse by Waka
column10: and he delivers one of the strongest hooks on the mixtape
column11: but the momentum that track builds is lost as soon as French appears
column12: as he just cannot keep up with Waka's pace.

column1: French Montana does have a few moments like ""Call It Dat""
column2: a rare track where they display an equal amount of intensity. The same goes for ""We Mobb"" featuring Prodigy
column3: where French sounds right at home and Waka shows going back to his New York roots can work
column4: as they rap over the beat from Mobb Deep's vintage ""Hell on Earth"". But the more you hear the mixtape
column5: the more you wish they'd found a better middle ground. The first single from Waka's upcoming album
column6: ""Round of Applause""
column7: produced by Lex Luger
column8: is a great slice of Atlanta strip club music in the vein of Travis Porter
column9: and it's a good match for French's style
column10: since it would allow him to relax his flow a bit. French's recent hit single ""Shot Caller"" is a jazzy New York cut that could use a regional expanding verse energy ball verse from Waka to give it more radio and club appeal. On these songs
column11: you get a better sense of why they'd want to work together
column12:
but Lock Out never comes close to that promise.

A cinephile friend recently described a gross tactical error made by Oscar-fave The Artist: It approached silent films as a genre rather than a method for making them. Musicians make this mistake too. Consider vocal processing. The amount of time spent warping
column3: burying
column4: and looping the human voice has increased exponentially as artists have found it an effective tool for bridging the gaps between man and machine (James Blake)
column5: ecstasy and violence (the Weeknd)
column6: past and present (Ariel Pink). R&B's delirious emotional states have proven particularly fertile ground for artists like Jacques Greene
column7: How to Dress Well
column8: and Autre Ne Veut.

column1: Successful applications
column2: all
column3: and while actual output varies
column4: these artists have enough in common that foggy vocals have become a zeitgeist of modern underground music. Enter o F F Love
column5: a French transplant living in Berlin
column6: who-- you guessed it-- has mistaken this choral thicket for an end-game. With its sounds of pop and R&B stylized to abstraction
column7: it is impossible to imagine Probably Love
column8: o F F Love's debut LP
column9: dropping any time but the present. One year ago it would've seemed obscure; one year from now
column10: it will sound archaic. o F F Love exists as a prism that refracts the most facile aspects of chillwave
column11: witch-house
column12: and PBR&B to deleterious effect and
column13: in doing so
column14: provides a glimpse of how damaging indie rock's obsession with memory and obfuscation can be.

column1: o F F Love's penchant for obscurity is not just musical. Little is known about the producer
column2: who hides his face behind a scarf and ballcap. Mangled phonetics (e.g. ""Makeupworz""
column3: ""Missthemway (Again)"") aid in building the mystery
column4: I suppose. What little o F F Love media exists-- a spare website
column5: a YouTube channel
column6: a SoundCloud-- indicate an interest in teen-pop fanaticism
column7: potentially fecund territory for a deconstructionist. This fascination proves to be entirely visual
column8: however
column9: as Probably Love establishes a template of queasy vocal refrains
column10: dull kick drums
column11: and aerosol-laced synths. The vocals are provided by o F F Love himself. Or they're sampled. Either way
column12: human voices are slathered in Auto-Tune
column13: reducing the opportunity for a big reveal or the establishment of a discernible vocal presence.

column1: I suspect Probably Love was recorded entirely using software
column2: but ultimately that doesn't matter: What matters is that this album sounds like it's been filtered through an overheated laptop's cooling fan
column3: so shrill is its palate. Probably Love smolders in this dissonant
column4: digital pit
column5: its every minor chord
column6: snare hit
column7: and intonation laid to waste by hot
column8: harsh circuits. The tempos do not help. Probably Love sputters
column9: distended phrasing and echoing snares left to linger: The shrieking
column10: nauseous interjections of ""Be Around U"" and rudderless vowels of ""Everyday
column11: My Holy Day"" are egregious offenders. The cumulative effect is advanced narcolepsy
column12: someone blowing spit bubbles with soft synths and drum machines. When o F F Love does allow a quicker tempo to invade-- such as on the almost pretty masturbation fantasy ""Beating for You""-- it predictably drags his vocals out of the muck as well.

column1: Perhaps you think I'm missing the point
column2: that o F F Love's blur&B contains some hard-won beauty or relevant commentary. But Probably Love isn't beautiful; its ugliness and pessimism exhaust me. And what greater point could he be making? Probably Love is the frightful dead-end of so many recent trends
column3: the point at which we lose sight of what question is being answered
column4:
what volley is being returned.

Sharon Van Etten's first proper album
column2: Because I Was in Love

column4: hid her guitar
column5: and shoved her back home to New Jersey. That album's tracks
column6: and those of the home recordings she also released that year
column7: were sparse
column8: Van Etten's voice sometimes barely above a murmur
column9: as if she were trying to figure out how to make music at the lowest functional volume. Her next record
column10: 2010's Epic
column11: was almost more of an EP-- just seven songs-- but it was a leap forward in sound and spirit. Epic pulled in little bits of kickdrum and pedal steel and electric guitar
column12: and ended with ""Love More""
column13: on which she proclaimed
column14: over a doubled harmonium and wavering synth
column15: ""You chained me like a dog in our room/ …It made me love
column16: it made me love
column17: it made me love more.""

column1: Van Etten first recorded ""Love More"" for WXPN and Weathervane Music's Shaking Through web series
column2: which captured the session on video. It was one of her first in-earnest collaborations with other musicians
column3: and can almost see new synapses firing behind her eyes: <i>this is what music can be

column5: who wound up producing Tramp
column6: her first album for Jagjaguwar. The new tracks come from a year and a half of sessions wedged in whenever Dessner and Van Etten were both off tour. It includes appearances by Wye Oak's Jenn Wasner
column7: Julianna Barwick
column8: Dessner's brother/bandmate Bryce
column9: and other friends of the sort that apparently tend to ""just drop by"" when you're a celebrated musician/producer with a studio in your Brooklyn garage. That Van Etten has been given the time and space and resources to feel out her path
column10: unhurried by the tyrannous buzz cycle
column11: is both a total luxury
column12: and totally vital.

column1: It's the default assumption that a female songwriter
column2: performing under her own name
column3: is ""confessional
column4: that she's serving up some dark part of her soul for the world's consumption. And maybe one day Van Etten will slip into the voices of strangers just as easily as she inhabits her own. But for now
column5: confession is still very much the thing. ""It's self-therapy
column6: Van Etten has said to nearly every interviewer who has asked
column7: and more and more that seems to refer to both the writing and the production of her songs; that she can draw out the words
column8: bring them into a room with other human beings
column9: and together with them lay something beautiful on tape is both transformative and redemptive.

column1: Matters of mistrust
column2: isolation
column3: and uncomfortable togetherness dominate Tramp
column4: rolling through every track like a sick
column5: creeping fog. Maybe Van Etten is still nursing the psychic wounds carved into her by that one Tennessee boyfriend
column6: or maybe it's something else; either way
column7: she sounds
column8: at last
column9: good and angry and ready to put up a fight. First comes the dark jangle of ""Warsaw""
column10: then the calculated frankness of ""Give Out"" (""You're the reason why I'll move to the city/ Or why I'll need to leave”). On ""Serpents""
column11: the album's lead single
column12: she scoffs
column13: ""I had a thought you would take me seriously."" As guitars strain at their tethers and Walkmen drummer Matt Barrick pounds out marching orders
column14: the plea she issued three years ago on ""Much More Than That""-- ""please don’t take me lightly""-- quavers
column15: crumples
column16: turns to ash.

column1: After the torching comes the slow
column2: steady burn. ""Kevin's"" sounds like an Epic latecomer welcomed into Tramp's fold
column3: Van Etten’s voice
column4: falling somewhere between Cass Elliot's range and Cat Power's emotional register
column5: turns darker and resigned
column6: the whole song one long smoky exhale. ""Leonard"" is a dreamy
column7: abashed waltz; tickled by ukuleles and kicked along by a big bass drum; it reveals the album's lone confession that seems to stem from anything close to guilt. It's an admission that takes three go-rounds of the chorus to make itself fully known
column8: Van Etten shuffling around the hard truth: ""I am bad""-- ""I am bad at loving""-- ""I am bad at loving you.""

column1: The album's brightest spot comes with the steady
column2: strummy ""We Are Fine""
column3: in which Van Etten talks through a panic attack with a friend (""Take my hand and help me not to shake/ Say I'm all right
column4: I'm all right""). Beirut's Zach Condon sings harmonies and a verse of his own
column5: the song written with him in mind
column6: Van Etten says
column7: not just because she first plucked it out on a ukulele
column8: but because they both do battle with the gnarly beast of social anxiety. There's often no clear balm for Van Etten's laments
column9: but ""We Are Fine"" is both the means and the end
column10: the sickness and the cure in one.

column1: Tramp is maybe best thought of in terms of having a Side A and a Side B; otherwise
column2: the middle section falls into a weird mid-album slough that doesn't quite jibe with Van Etten and Dessner's generally excellent sense of timing and space. Imagine a click
column3: a pause and a careful flip between the fractured
column4: meandering ""In Line"" and ""All I Can""

column9: indeed)
column10: the last track's final scrape threading back into ""Warsaw""'s opening thump and clank.

column1: ""I want my scars to help and heal
column2: Van Etten sings on ""All I Can"". That healing comes
column3: in part
column4: from the making of the music-- that act of physically locating the pain in some way that can be accessed and then shelved as life tumbles on. But it comes
column5: too
column6: from being pushed out into the world
column7: to people who now say
column8: ""Yes
column9: we are here
column10:
and we are listening.""

Even when Underworld weren't big
column2: they always aimed at being huge. I don't just mean the widescreen progressive house they made
column3: two decades of which are collected on the 25 tracks of the new Anthology
column4: but their brand of not-quite-trance/not-quite-techno floor-fillers were indeed self-consciously epic and transportive. Following the late-1980s acid-house revelation that turned so many UK synth-pop also-rans into DJ kings
column5: Underworld came to specialize in the kind of dance music that felt constrained in a tiny club space
column6: records with enough space and depth to lose yourself in the swirl and flow
column7: whether you were standing in a festival field surrounded by thousands of other bodies or strapped into a pair of headphones on your lonesome.

column1: Underworld had a live rock band's feel for pacing and drama
column2: but were born-again house music evangelists
column3: through and through. ""Dark and Long (Dark Train)"" was the structuring principle for music of their peak music
column4: as well as the title of one of their deepest
column5: moodiest cuts. Despite Karl Hyde's nagging half-spoken and half-sung mantras
column6: Underworld never really flirted with ""songwriting."" Though his fragmentary
column7: pre-millennium tension babble could be equally silly
column8: Hyde wasn't the grimacing focal point of Underworld
column9: as the two MCs were in the Prodigy. Even when they were stars
column10: taking to festival stages rather than DJ booths
column11: Underworld never tried to be personalities
column12: letting DJ culture continue to dictate the shape and force and presentation of their music. Unlike unrepentant hookmeister Norman Cook
column13: Underworld also didn't go for big-stoopid-chorus and earworm-loop immediacy
column14: even when forced to shave their singles down to broadcast length. They simply attempted to recreate the peaks-and-valleys of a club cut in miniature. ""Born Slippy .NUXX"" may be more head-wrecking at its proper length
column15: but the video version was like a hyper-condensed advert for the same effect
column16: angelic intro giving way to massive hard house drums that are the song's real hook.

column1: This dance essentialism disguised as crossover friendliness may have limited their appeal to pop fans once the ""electronica"" boom went pfft and many fair-weather compilation buyers realized they really didn't care for 12-minute instrumentals after all. But it makes Underworld ripe for rediscovery by a generation of new college kids who've dedicated themselves to recreating the 1990s house music they were barely alive for. After all
column2: if you've got to go retro
column3: go big. It's no surprise that Anthology collects these tracks at their full 12""-mix lengths
column4: rather than their highlight reel-style radio edits. All the more for you to swim around in. And those peaks certainly take you higher when the builds have been teased out to the limit.

column1: Plenty of DJs and producers have made ""huge"" dance records that nonetheless feel rather small as pop artifacts because they're aimed at insular subcultures. Several of Underworld's biggest records
column2: in the musical sense of the word
column3: were recorded and released when they were indeed club-circuit draw on the rise and a music press rumor to the wider world
column4: especially in America. 1993's ""Rez""
column5: which builds with the controlled grandeur of pre-cheesy continental trance but uses much of Detroit techno's sonic signature
column6: would have been no one's idea of a chart smash. Its melodic hook is too abstract. Its repetitive structure is still aimed at all-night dancing rather than earworm immediacy. But the track's whole vibe is also too big to ignore
column7: as if it's straining to some DJ's crates for a suburban pop-techno radio utopia that didn't yet exist. If so many of these singles still sound like world-flattening anthems today
column8: more than a decade after Underworld's commercial peak
column9: it's partially due to the overwhelming ambition the music still projects
column10: the idea that through luck and timing and canny cross-media promotion and a kind of benign will-to-power
column11: they could bring (mostly) instrumental electronic music to a mass audience.

column1: They got their wish
column2: though only many years into their career and after several failed attempts that have more or less been airbrushed from their official history. This most recent best-of collection is subtitled ""1992 to 2012"" because 20 years makes a respectable round number for official retrospection. But you'd be hard-pressed to claim their earliest albums
column3: where the best you can say is that they pulled a half-decent sartorial imitation of Depeche Mode on the sleeve art
column4: as part of the band's real legacy. Acid house's sweeping the UK in 1988 both freed them from silly pop preening and pointed out that their real strength was in stringing together adrenaline-pumping climaxes along spacious beatscapes. They had a good run
column5: about as long as any of their peers
column6: and the idyllic ambient house and blown-out filter disco sieved from 2002's A Hundred Days Off for Anthology promised good things for how Underworld would weather the rapid trend-shifts of new millennium dance.

column1: Then the great house contraction occurred
column2: and suddenly Underworld (like so many of their peers) seemed massively out-of-step with the gaunt form dance hipness took with minimal. Almost a decade later
column3: huge is back
column4: in many forms
column5: but what you hear now
column6: with Underworld's particular brand of hugeness no longer the face of dance populism
column7: is how it's the subtlety that keeps these anthems repeat-listenable
column8: as much as the hands-aloft moments. Damned as dance music afflicted with gigantism when techno started starving itself of hooks
column9: Underworld were masters of restraint
column10: nuance
column11: and pace compared to today's prole-friendly producers
column12: such as Skrillex and Deadmau5. There's all the attention to detail of your average deep house bore
column13: along with a lot of pleasing bombast and (it must be said) some pretty damn dodgy lyrics. Don't play them for any neon-clad goobers craving only the biggest bass drops
column14: but if you're looking for a long and dark journey that eventually arrives at euphoria
column15:
you could still do a lot worse.

The two full-lengths from Wisconsin-to-California duo Peaking Lights make the band alumni of both the Night-People and Not Not Fun labels. If you find that part of their biography a bit incomprehensible
column3: you may also be unaware that their 2011 full-length
column4: 936
column5: was something of a triumph among the subset of music fans who still buy cassettes. Peaking Lights are currently at the heart of a new crop of underground
column6: psychedelic pop groups. Their primitive sun worship is underpinned by a murky foundation of dub and drone
column7: the layers filtered through the aural equivalent of a Xerox machine. You feel as if you are listening in on Peaking Lights
column8: and their mantric hit ""All the Sun That Shines"" has always reminded me of a description the poet Allen Ginsberg once offered of Arthur Russell: ""Buddhist bubblegum.""

column1: Peaking Lights are DIY in a raw sense; co-leader Aaron Coyes even makes his own synthesizers. That detail is worth rehashing as a reminder that the group has thus far produced distinctly bohemian music. Its slow
column2: deadpan atmosphere could be most appropriately paired with incense and burning candles. But between the layers of 936's hissy meanderings
column3: there's a lot of breathing room
column4: making the songs prime canvases for remixing. Not Not Fun began commissioning a remix EP for its dance-oriented imprint 100% Silk in February 2011
column5: but in the time required to finalize the release
column6: Peaking Lights signed to Domino's Weird World label and issued a separate collection. The most successful reworkings on these releases are those that leave Peaking Lights' meditative character intact.

column1: While the idea of L.A.'s ""Ambassador of Boogie Funk"" Dâm-Funk remixing anything sounds worthy of a few spins
column2: his take on ""All the Sun That Shines"" for Weird World is more or less a cover
column3: transforming the track with a slick sheen and subtle four-on-the-floor click. It's imaginative and well executed
column4: but by the nature of being a Dâm-Funk creation
column5: it compromises Peaking Lights' earthy
column6: breathing tones for something a little too polished. It feels as though it'd work better as his own B-side. The same goes for Oakland zoner-rap duo Main Attrakionz
column7: who use elements of ""Marshmellow Yellow"" and ""Amazing and Wonderful"" as cloud-ground for a few skilled verses. Electronic duo Patten turn ""Hey Sparrow"" into something more esoteric
column8: but drag it out to the point of feeling unedited. What the Weird World comp lacks is cohesion
column9: which is unfortuante since dub and reggae connoisseur Adrian Sherwood's impressive remake of ""Tiger Eyes (Laid Back)"" is easily the best cut on either set. The British producer maintains the song's atmosphere and relaxed mystique
column10: but makes its production boom
column11: burying a subtle swarm of laser-like synths under crisp vocal melodies.

column1: The 100% Silk EP draws its remixers straight from the label's own pool of DIY dance producers
column2: who since last year have emphasized a specific
column3: low-budget sound inspired by Italo disco and early Detroit house and techno. It's hypnagogic dance music for misfits and outsiders
column4: pinning a punk philosophy to one indebted in some sense to Ariel Pink and YouTube's endless free music archive. Ital's Daniel Martin-McCormick
column5: who also fronts the punk trio Mi Ami
column6: offers a standout expansion of ""Marshmellow Yellow""
column7: adding a driving beat and thudding bass that quicken the original's pace while maintaining its two-dimensional cool. Xander Harris adds spiky
column8: galactic synths to ""Birds of Paradise""
column9: shedding the song of its echo wash while building the electronics in isolated layers
column10: reminiscent of Peaking Lights' own technique. No remix of ""All the Sun That Shines"" is a match for the album cut's alien sing-song charm
column11: but Innergaze offer a welcome twist with warped vocal samples and a cosmic chug. On ""Tiger Eyes""
column12: Cuticle pushes the vocals high and swaps gloom for wavering
column13: sky-high synths. The 100% Silk EP calls for repeat listens due to its maintenance of 936's cohesive
column14: textured voice
column15:
and even more so for carrying on the album's ethos.

Though the creative nucleus of the Fresh & Onlys consists of frontman Tim Cohen and bassist Shayde Sartin
column2: guitarist Wymond Miles is an equally valuable component of the band. Of course he is: It's not like he's a second-chair French horn player for Arcade Fire
column3: he's the lead guitarist of a relatively straightforward garage-rock quartet. Aside from being 25% of the band
column4: his work is integral to the group's success: It's difficult imagining what ""Grey-Eyed Girls"" would sound like without his rippling
column5: jangly leads or ""August in My Mind"" and ""Waterfall"" minus his Morricone-in-a-punk-basement fretwork. But regardless of how essential he is to his group

column1: That said
column2: Earth Has Doors feels like the diametric opposite of ""fiddling around."" The same could be said about his life. After writing these songs hunched over an eight-track four years ago
column3: Miles shelved his solo work in favor of responsibilities familial (he has a child)

column5: their fourth in the past 36 months)
column6: and intellectual (he has a degree in the humanities). The latter is clearly displayed on the EP

column1: But instead of looking inside of himself and realizing his life is insignificant in the bigger picture
column2: Miles faces the lens outward
column3: touching on the initial allure and subsequent emptiness of drugs
column4: the vapidity of consumer culture
column5: and even the metaphysical. He's explained what he was trying to accomplish: ""Sonically the mood had to reflect the somberness of moving between the existential chaos of my 20s into this new perspective of living... The mysterious hues of the soundscape reflect a sense of curiosity and possibility in the canyons of sound."" In laymen's terms
column6: the EP quickly taps into 1960s and 1970s prog bluster

column3: with the soundscapes taking a backseat to two dramatic tunes. Its opener softly picks an acoustic guitar and before long
column4: everything is blasted skyward and the song feels spacious and ominous at the same time
column5: like a helicopter hovering over a field. ""Temples of Magick"" is miles heavier
column6: using tiny bits of squall that squeal in the background. Miles sings in an incredibly wearied voice toward the end of the song

column1: Side B begins with ""As the Orchard is With Rain""
column2: a floaty
column3: melancholy instrumental
column4: featuring the ambiance of gusty wind
column5: guitar with rapid drop-of-a-dime tempo changes
column6: and a few droning violins circling underneath the sound of thunder (aka a few noisy guitars). The final track ""Earth Has Doors

column8: before the song breaks down into a agonizingly slow coda that
column9: like much of the EP

column1: Really
column2: with an EP so dramatic and high-concept

column4:
even if nobody else knew it.

Simple suits Laura Gibson. The Oregonian songstress knows the power a few well-chosen words and clear images can carry-- all the better when complemented with an economy of instrumentation-- and she put this know-how to good use on her two previous solo outings
column4: 2006's If You Come to Greet Me and 2009's Beasts of Seasons. Those records also benefited from their intimacy and frankness
column5: both embodied in Gibson's voice. It's a gentle thing
column6: wise but vulnerable
column7: and it wraps itself around the vowels with a nasal quality that calls to mind the earliest decades of recorded music. That voice returns more versatile than before on La Grande (sorry Francophones
column8: it rhymes with ""demand"")
column9: which finds Gibson shedding some of her characteristic simplicity
column10: spreading her wings
column11: and trying a few new musical styles on for size in the process.

column1: A newfound momentum is evident from the moment the opening title track rolls in
column2: all galloping drums
column3: see-saw bass
column4: dust-bowl guitars
column5: and spectral moaning. It ain't exactly ""Rawhide""
column6: but it's a more assertive move than we're used to from Gibson
column7: whose previous records began quietly and gracefully. From there La Grande dips and sways
column8: holes up and sprawls out again
column9: not unlike the rugged terrain of the northeastern Oregon locale from which the album derives its name. Gibson's quiet moments are still her most striking: ""Crow/Swallow"" comes close to capturing the elegant melancholy of Greet Me standout ""Broken Bottle""
column10: while on closing track ""Feather Lungs"" Gibson makes use of a cappella 1940s vocal-group harmonizations to soften the edges of a song plainly about final repose. However it's thanks to more upbeat tracks such as ""The Fire""
column11: ""Skin
column12: Warming Skin""
column13: and the aforementioned opener that these more intimate offerings shine in contrast. This
column14: perhaps
column15: is a lesson learned from Beasts
column16: where a stream of pared-down tracks on the record's latter half
column17: while each affecting on its own
column18: tended to smear together in succession.

column1: New sounds of yore continue on ""Lion/Lamb""
column2: with its bossa nova rhythm
column3: and ""The Rushing Dark""
column4: which drifts in and out like an old spiritual sung from a passing river barge. ""Skin""
column5: easily the record's most momentous track
column6: is
column7: appropriately
column8: also its sex jam: Lines about ""secrets... hidden in the hems of summer dresses"" and leaving ""seeds to break and swell"" alternate with a rousing wordless chorus of ""ooh-ooh-oohs"" while our narrator must keep reminding herself
column9: ""it's only skin
column10: warming skin
column11: warming skin."" Meanwhile
column12: the romance that may well have led to such skin-warming is given its due on ""Red Moon""
column13: which has Gibson expressing her desire to ""drink up"" her lover's ""poetry"" on what sounds like a vintage microphone. This comes served over Latin-inflected guitar and a recurring sample of an old waltz record
column14: all new looks for the usually more restrained Gibson.

column1: Rather than another exercise in genre-dabbling and dilettantism
column2: La Grande succeeds as a cohesive work thanks to the persistence of Gibson's vision. As a songwriter she's preoccupied with those timeless questions of the human condition
column3: but seldom if ever stumbles into pretension or self-satisfaction. Themes of love
column4: loss
column5: regret
column6: and mortality crop up often
column7: and
column8: significantly
column9: they're well-served by the surrounding songcraft. One wouldn't expect Gibson's latest to bowl over any audiophile chasing the wow!-factor
column10: but for the patient
column11: contemplative listener
column12:
La Grande-- much like the campfire depicted on its cover-- is a record worth warming to.

What happens to a dream fulfilled? More specifically
column2: an American dream fulfilled
column3: rags turning to riches with the snap of a manicured finger
column4: kissing James Dean in Gatsby's swimming pool
column5: getting played on the radio. This is a central question animating Lana Del Rey's Born to Die. Our heroine has all the love
column6: diamonds
column7: and Diet Mountain Dew she could ask for
column8: yet still sings
column9: ""I wish I was dead
column10: sounding utterly incapable of joy. To paraphrase Liz Phair
column11: if you get everything you wish for and you're still unhappy
column12: then you know that the problem is you.

column1: Given the waves of hype and backlash over the last six months
column2: it can be easy to forget that we're here
column3: first and foremost
column4: because of a song. ""Video Games"" struck a nerve not just because it was an introduction to Del Rey's captivating voice but because it seemed to suggest something as-yet-unarticulated about the way we live today. Whatever her intention
column5: as a metaphor about disconnect and detachment from our own desires
column6: ""Video Games"" felt frank
column7: pointed
column8: and true
column9: and it had a chord progression and melody to match. The ultimate disappointment of Born to Die
column10: then
column11: is how out of touch it feels not just with the world around it
column12: but with the simple business of human emotion.

column1: The singer born Elizabeth ""Lizzy"" Grant may have made her mark with a grainy homemade video that brought to mind other grainy homemade videos in the indie sphere
column2: but the slick sound and sentiment of ""Radio""
column3: Born to Die's most straightforward statement of purpose (""Baby love me 'cause I'm playing on the radio/ How do you like me now?"")
column4: places it firmly within the realm of big-budget chart pop. Born to Die was produced by Emile Haynie
column5: whose credits include Eminem
column6: Lil Wayne
column7: and Kid Cudi
column8: and the album's impressively lush atmosphere might be the one thing that will unite its detractors and apologists.

column1: The album's recurring themes ooze out of every note: sex
column2: drugs
column3: and glitter hover in the yawning atmosphere around Del Rey's breathy vocals. There are strings and trip-hop beats and bits of 1950s twang
column4: and the melodies
column5: assembled with assistance from hired-gun songwriters like Mike Daly (Plain White Ts
column6: Whiskeytown) and Rick Nowels (Belinda Carlisle's ""Heaven Is a Place on Earth"") are built to stick. But for an album that aims for fickle radio listeners
column7: many of its pop signifiers feel stale and ill-fitting. On ""Million Dollar Man""
column8: Del Rey drawls like a highly medicated Fiona Apple
column9: and ""Diet Mountain Dew"" and ""Off to the Races"" aim for chatty
column10: sparkling opulence
column11: this singer doesn't have the personality to bring it off.

column1: The album's point of view-- if you could call it that-- feels awkward and out of date. Whether you take a line like ""Money is the reason we exist/ Everybody knows that it's a fact/ Kiss kiss"" with a 10-carat grain of salt is up to you
column2: but even as a jab at the chihuahua-in-Paris-Hilton's-handbag lifestyle
column3: it feels limp and pointless (unlike
column4: say
column5: Lily Allen's mock-vapid but slyly observant 2008 single ""The Fear""). Still
column6: the dollar signs in its eyes aren't an inherent strike against Born to Die: Even in the wake of an international debt crisis and the Occupy movement
column7: it was hard not to fall for Watch the Throne. But that's because Jay and Kanye made escapist fantasy sound so fun. Del Rey's gem-encrusted dreamworld
column8: meanwhile
column9: relies on clichés (""God you're so handsome/ Take me to the Hamptons"") rather than specific evocations. It's a fantasy world that makes you long for reality.

column1: And speaking of fantasy: The conversation surrounding Lana Del Rey has underscored some seriously depressing truths about sexism in music. She was subjected to the kind of intense scrutiny-- about her backstory and especially her appearance-- that's generally reserved for women only. But the sexual politics of Born to Die are troubling too: You'd be hard pressed to find any song on which Del Rey reveals an interiority or figures herself as anything more complex than an ice-cream-cone-licking object of male desire (a line in ""Blue Jeans""
column2: ""I will love you till the end of time/ I would wait a million years
column3: sums up about 65% of the album's lyrical content). Even when Del Rey offers something that could be read as a critique (""This is what makes us girls/ We don't stick together 'cause we put our love first"")
column4: she asks that we make no effort to change
column5: escape
column6: or transcend the way things are (""Don't cry about it/ Don't cry about it."") In terms of its America-sized grandeur and its fixation with the emptiness of dreams
column7: Born to Die attempts to serve as Del Rey's own beautiful
column8: dark
column9: twisted fantasy
column10: but there's no spark and nothing at stake.

column1: The critic Ellen Willis once wrote of Bette Midler: ""Blatant artifice can
column2: in the right circumstances
column3: be poignantly honest
column4: and she expresses the tension between image and inner self that all of us-- but especially women-- experience."" But Born to Die never allows tension or complexity into the mix
column5: and its take on female sexuality ends up feeling thoroughly tame. For all of its coos about love and devotion
column6:
it's the album equivalent of a faked orgasm-- a collection of torch songs with no fire.

column3: but he's more than that. His second full-length statement

column5: is a sumptuously produced and deeply enjoyable hour-plus slab of weed-clouded rap
column6: but it's more than that. I've spent the past four days immersed in it
column7: trying to resolve its conflicting impulses and ferret out all of its weird corners
column8: and the only thing I can say for certain is that
column9: while listening to it
column10: I feel pulled completely into someone else's center of gravity
column11: which is maybe the most gratifying listener's sensation there is.

column1: The record's first layer is sheer sound: Habits & Contradictions is full of plush
column2: inviting
column3: high-thread-count production
column4: the kind that pulls you toward fat headphones and a chair. Like Kendrick Lamar's Section.80
column5: there is a woozy drag to the drums and a thick
column6: clotted feel to the sounds surrounding them. It shares a metabolic rate with Houston screw music
column7: but the album's chilly mood is closer to the heron'-gray-skies gloom of RZA and Mobb Deep. In fact
column8: when <span style=""color: #222222; background-color: rgba(255
column11: 0.917969);"">Mobb Deep affiliate the Alchemist shows up halfway through Habits on ""My Homie""
column12: he feels right at home.

column1: Habits & Contradictions is
column2: accordingly
column3: a dark and moody listen
column4: but it never bogs down in momentum or succumbs to despair. ""There He Go"" flips a sample of Portland trio Menomena's brittle ""Wet and Rusting"" into a hard-hitting anthem. ""Druggys Wit Hoes Again""
column5: with its gabbling bursts of vocal samples and bone-jarring snare kicks
column6: is a prime slab of Bay Area gangsta music. Even when everything slows to a crawl
column7: there are small sounds tucked in everywhere
column8: enlivening the darkness: the spaghetti-western guitar twangs on ""Sacrilegious""
column9: or the heavy-breathing Portishead drum break of ""Raymond 1969"".

column1: It helps that Schoolboy is an odd
column2: genuinely unpredictable presence who sometimes seems to be rapping entirely for his own amusement. There's audible dryness in his voice as he drunkenly croons the off-key hook
column3: ""House fulla money/ Tub fulla bitches
column4: on ""How We Feeling""
column5: and you can hear he's holding the words in air quotes
column6: as if he's just trying the words on
column7: since they're the Sorts of Things One Says in Rap Songs. On ""Nightmare on Fig St.""
column8: he teases the opening ""Ball so hard"" bars of ""Niggas in Paris"" for no obvious reason
column9: and then launches into sharply worded threats (""The landlord
column10: turn your lieutenant into a tenant"")
column11: head-turning non sequiturs (""We drive to pussy more than we do to church/ No AC but the heater WOOOORK!"") and a riot of demented ad-libs.

column1: This lily-pad hopping means that it takes a while for the buried emotion in Habits to surface. Schoolboy raps in a wearily flat voice that evokes Prodigy's
column2: and his lyrics deal with all the dark stuff of gangsta rap: poverty
column3: violence
column4: drugs
column5: hopelessness. But his music has none of gangsta rap's implacable
column6: survival-at-all-costs forward motion. Schoolboy's music is dank with the lousy weather of disappointment
column7: with human-sized failures. When he tells us about selling oxycontin with a lifelong friend who sold him out
column8: he doesn't sound like murderous Vengeance Incarnate; he just sounds hurt. His tangled past as a set leader of the Hoover Crips
column9: meanwhile
column10: leaks out in small bits. ""Contradictions in my thoughts
column11: and I just execute my feelings
column12: he mutters on ""2 Raw""
column13: and it hints effectively at an unspoken well of remorse.

column1: Schoolboy Q has little of Black Hippy alpha Kendrick Lamar's gloomy-paladin aura
column2: or his rap-Hamlet charisma. But it's worth noting that
column3: at least right now
column4: Schoolboy is making stronger music than Kendrick. Habits & Contradictions sounds comfortable in its skin
column5: at home its own quiet strangeness
column6: in a way that Section.80 never manages. It's better-paced. He's probably not going to be a break-out star
column7:
but it's hard to imagine that there will be many more original or satisfying rap long-players this year.
