column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17377/homepage_large.e398d26d.jpg|Patience (After Sebald)|29716.0|The Caretaker|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['History Always Favours the Winners']|2012-01-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:03.344078|"

Leyland Kirby has been making music as the Caretaker since 1999
column2: but 2011 proved to be the project's breakthrough year. An Empty Bliss Beyond This World was the right record at the right time
column3: a meditation on decay and loss that was beautiful on the surface but also had layers to peel. It reached listeners with only a passing interest in music from the experimental sphere
column4: much in the manner of William Basinski's early-millennium series Disintegration Loops
column5: because it brought together ideas about archives
column6: appropriation
column7: memory
column8: and the accretion and disappearance of cultural objects. The name of Kirby's project comes from Jack Nicholson's character in The Shining
column9: and Bliss was the album as a large
column10: empty
column11: and haunted building
column12: imparting a feeling of loneliness at the edge of the world. Sampling and manipulating crackling 78s with sweet dance tunes from the 1920s and 1930s
column13: Kirby's tracks dangled in front of you and turned slowly
column14: rods on a mobile that was gradually falling apart.

column1: Following a solo album
column2: Eager to Tear Apart the Stars
column3: that was nearly as fine
column4: Kirby returns with a new Caretaker record
column5: this one the soundtrack to a film by director Grant Gee about the German writer W.G. Sebald. According to Kirby
column6: this material was actually recorded before Bliss
column7: and Patience (After Sebald) is clearly the product of a similar process
column8: though the record's overall mood is quite different. Instead of haunted jazz-age ballroom numbers
column9: Patience draws from the music of Austrian composer Franz Schubert
column10: sampling and manipulating (in some cases
column11: very heavily) 78 recordings of his piece Winterreise. From its title on down
column12: the Schubert piece brings to mind a frozen world
column13: and Kirby responds in kind
column14: crafting an album that hints at the season's chill with characteristic complexity and ambiguity.

column1: Given the nature of its source
column2: Patience is mostly built from manipulated samples of piano and voice. ""When the Dog Days Were Drawing to an End"" loops a single keyboard fragment from a waltz-time section and punctuates the end of each cycle with a barely perceptible voice
column3: and lets the melody
column4: saturated with noise
column5: spin in place for nearly five minutes. ""The Homesickness That Was Corroding Her Soul"" uses a warbly piano interlude for its repeated refrain
column6: with the instability of the pitch imparting a sense of unease and tension. On the opener ""Everything Is on the Point of Decline""
column7: hiss and rumble is pushed way out in front
column8: so you can just barely make out the music beneath a blinding sheet of distortion. These are simple motifs
column9: but they show an uncanny sense of balance and feel anything but accidental.

column1: But the album grows more interesting in its second half
column2: as the processing gradually overtakes the source material and transformation becomes the prevailing theme. ""In the Deep and Dark Hours of the Night"" coats the piano line in a thick syrup of slap-back echo and layers it under a piercing layer of hiss
column3: making the music feel simultaneously distant and close
column4: like it's either coming from inside your head or is so far away you can barely make it out. ""No One Knows What Shadowy Memories Haunt Them to This Day"" and the closing ""Now the Night is Over and the Dawn Is About to Break"" takes the guttural male vocals from Schubert's piece and stretches them out
column5: turning single syllables into tense
column6: uneasy drones. The effect
column7: oddly
column8: will remind some of the Justin Bieber slowdown from a while back
column9: which sounded like Sigur Rós being pulled through a black hole's event horizon. Kirby's voices
column10: heard late in the record after the unsettling beauty of the piano loops
column11: reinforce the feeling of collapsing into something
column12: the howls
column13: that could stand in for pain or ecstasy
column14: suggest that something will never be the same.

column1: The brilliant thing about the Caretaker project is how it mashes together emotional states into something complex that can sound different each time you hear it. While the surface hiss and 78-groove crackle
column2: which are sometimes so loud they overwhelm the music the grooves carry inside them
column3: bring to mind decay and death. The immersive
column4: womb-like nature of Kirby's approach also conjures childhood and a life stretched in front of you
column5: filled with possibility. So this music
column6: so basic on one level
column7: is both warm and cold
column8: blackened by mortality and twinkling with life
column9:
somehow evoking the wonder and absurdity of existence itself.

"|16220.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16220-patience-after-sebald/|8.0|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17371/homepage_large.9d5f91b2.jpg|To Solemn Ash|30152.0|Rising|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Exile On Mainstream']|2012-01-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:03.874150|"

The young Danish sludge trio Rising have a familiar sound
column2: but their ability to pen vast
column3: melodic anthems is sharp enough that originality isn't really an issue. Especially if you're into rockers in the tradition of Baroness or Remission-era Mastodon. Unlike the more recent versions of those older groups
column4: Rising aren't into ""experimentation."" To Solemn Ash
column5: their 10-song debut
column6: offers straightforward metal that may come laced with the occasional acoustic interlude
column7: but could definitely be reproduced in the smallest
column8: shittiest club in the world without the help of guest musicians
column9: triggers
column10: a psychedelic choir
column11: or a laptop. (The collection
column12: released across Europe in October
column13: saw its American release earlier this month.)

column1: They've found multiple ways to come off expansive and compelling within a tight
column2: traditional framework. In fact
column3: To Solemn Ash goes places a 2009 EP and even a 2010 single couldn't without sounding too much different from either of the earlier efforts. Rising are ramping things up here
column4: and honing a specific style
column5: all without stepping outside of well-worn genre lines.

column1: The sequencing helps. Immediately likable opening track ""Mausoleum"" and ""Sea of Basalt""
column2: the song that follows it
column3: find bellowing vocalist/bassist Henrik Hald
column4: guitarist/backup vocalist Jacob Krogholt
column5: and drummer Jacob Johansen (the one new addition after their last recording) firing on all cylinders: ""Mausoleum""'s dynamics feel like tectonic shifts
column6: and remain immensely hummable; ""Basalt"" finds them nodding at Kylesa with gruff multi-tracked vocal shouts and instrumentation that continually ebbs
column7: crests
column8: and regains momentum until the final bit of feedback. (Which raises a question: How do three dudes from Denmark sound so much like four or five folks from Georgia?)

column1: Rising don't maintain this focus for 48 minutes
column2: but there are plenty of ""wow"" moments like the six-minute Torche-meets-Neurosis of the mid-tempo ""ballads"" ""Cohorts Rise"" and ""Under Callous Wings""
column3: the frantic Converge-like riffing on the album's shortest track ""Through the Eyes of Catalysis""
column4: and the way you feel like you can suddenly imagine High on Fire as a (very powerful) pop band while listening to ""Heir to the Flames"".

column1: The trio isn't afraid to groove or veer into somewhat poppier territory
column2: and can pull it off without sacrificing heaviness or getting too cute: They simply know how to write great riffs
column3: and newbie producer Jakob Reichert Nielsen should probably be giving tutorials to ""star"" recordists who don't yet know how to make metal sound huge
column4: polished
column5: and just-raw-enough in their more renowned studios. It's worth repeating: For all the quality
column6: head nods
column7: and goosebumps this album provides
column8: Rising are
column9: more or less
column10:
a basic sludge-metal band. And it's refreshing not having to also pull out the words ""post"" or ""avant"" to describe them.

"|16214.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16214-to-solemn-ash/|7.6|Brandon Stosuy

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17375/homepage_large.7b2c63c1.jpg|U&I;|26552.0|Leila|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2012-01-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:04.506797|"

Leila Arab's position as an outlier to the electronic music scene was firmly established through her 1998 debut
column2: Like Weather. What's remarkable about that album is how cut adrift from the world it feels
column3: with the London-based Iranian musician dragging a series of collaborators into a musical bubble that still now
column4: some 14 years later
column5: feels like a singular transmission from a unique talent. Much of it is eerily prescient; the curdled funk riff and stomach-churning lethargy of ""Don't Fall Asleep"" mirrors the kind of feeling the Weeknd have been dabbling in at the start of this decade. But
column6: as is the case with many debut albums that set such a high bar
column7: providing a second and third act for the stylistically assertive Like Weather proved problematic. On U&I she's taken a different tack
column8: dumping the celebrity collaborators (Terry Hall
column9: Martina Topley-Bird) of her 2008 record
column10: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/12270-blood-looms-and-blooms/"">Blood
column11: Looms and Blooms
column12: and even parting company with longtime singer Luca Santucci.

column1: Instead
column2: this album finds her working with the Berlin-based American DJ and musician Mt. Sims
column3: who provides the only vocal contributions to U&I. There have been other changes
column4: too. The scanty arrangements of yore
column5: filled with crooked corners and dark cracks
column6: have mostly been papered over. In their place comes a series of tracks that contain the most straightforward music Leila has produced to date
column7: with vast strips of pulverizing industrial noise providing the combative spine that contorts awkwardly through this record. Even when she slows things down on U&I
column8: there's a palpable feeling of ugliness; ""In Consideration"" is pitched somewhere between uneasy operatic trills and Throbbing Gristle-style discord; ""In Motion Slow"" contains the same kind of collapse-of-utopia glassiness as early Aphex Twin tracks such as ""Heliosphan"" and ""Hedphelym"".

column1: In a sense
column2: that's the biggest flaw with U&I-- it's too easy to feel out where Leila has been sourcing this material. Whereas before she was operating in a peculiar vacuum
column3: now it feels like she's breathing in the same air as the rest of us. Some of the emotion has dissipated as well-- there's nothing as beautifully forlorn as the Donna Paul-sung Like Weather cut ""Feeling"" here. Instead
column4: we get the end-of-the-world blood rush of instrumental tracks ""Activate I"" and ""Eight""
column5: which butt up against the Mt. Sims-fronted material. The latter is often undercut by gnarled bass synth work
column6: sometimes to stirring effect (""All of This"") and at other times edging toward the pop-nihilism of Nine Inch Nails circa-""Head Like a Hole"" (""Welcome To Your Life""). It's only when the darkness is vanquished
column7: such as on the zesty ""(Disappointed Cloud) Anyway"" and the spidery echo of the title track
column8: that it feels like the pair is gelling.

column1: There isn't a singular focus to any of Leila's albums-- she works best when she seems to be confounding herself with her own ideas
column2: all cooked up by indulging unlikely impulses and allowing a series of collaborators to make an imprint on her work. Strangely
column3: pairing with just Mt. Sims on U&I appears to have resulted in less-focused output
column4: with the duo gradually circling a grimy musical plughole
column5: only managing to pull themselves out via less cluttered material in the back half of the record. It's the mystery and wonder of prior Leila albums that are diluted here. The sense of anatomizing her work and not being able to figure out why it all slots together so perfectly dissipates dramatically when you're being bludgeoned by the stentorian howl of ""Welcome to Your Life"". It's unlikely Leila will take a backward step from here
column6:
as she clearly never has in the past. But she could do a lot worse than digging out Luca Santucci's phone number next time out.

"|16218.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16218-ui/|6.2|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17373/homepage_large.29be6e7a.jpg|Feel Me EP|28843.0|Evan Voytas|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dovecote']|2012-01-27 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:05.020929|"

If there's one thing to feel relieved about where our nostalgia-crazed moment is concerned
column2: it's that we as a society may finally get around to losing all that annoying
column3: self-aware awkwardness about vintage loverman R&B. The coke-chic irony
column4: the automatic equation of wah-wah guitar with mustachioed porno kitsch
column5: the focus on caricaturized libido at the expense of the chops of the singers who gave voice to it-- that all has to go. The alt/indie sphere did its best to work through those issues via stage-winking outlets like Har Mar Superstar and Midnite Vultures
column6: but they were still steps towards an ability to approach the influence of Prince or Michael Jackson or Hall and Oates without requiring 15 layers of self-conscious distancing.

column1: Yet to pull it off
column2: you need to remember that old joke about how important sincerity is: Once you learn to fake it
column3: the rest is easy. For Evan Voytas-- a Los Angeles multi-instrumentalist singer who sounds like he had to wade his way through Beck's ""Debra"" to get to Prince's ""The Beautiful Ones""-- that kind of commitment seems completely out of his grasp. The question of whether someone really means it when an artist dredges up old sounds isn't going away anytime soon
column4: and after a couple of EPs and <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICfvWD3W-T0"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">an abysmal
column5: shrill-yet-affectless cover of ""Nothing Compares 2 U""
column6: it's the only question left to ask about Voytas' music. His latest EP
column7: Feel Me
column8: drops as a short but grueling tour of some of the most cloying
column9: feeble soul-without-soul to dribble lamely out of wherever. The Playskool pop-funk that Voytas mistakes for peak Jam/Lewis is sickly enough: It stumbles around to hit a few loosely modernized
column10: synth-driven takes on half-remembered Hi Records backbeats (""When We Could All Float Away"")
column11: L.A. Doobies/Dan studio rock cut with baking powder (""You Don't Even Know Where It's At"")
column12: and perfunctory boogie funk with all the propulsive energy of a Casio preset (""Can't Let Anybody Know Who You Are""). There's actually a recurring melodic shrug in the title track that stops two notes short of the stereotypical faux-Chinese riff that Carl Douglas used for ""Kung Fu Fighting"". Sir Nose lives.

column1: But the problem above everything else is his voice-- you can't get around it
column2: under it
column3: or away from it
column4: much less into it. At its most innocuous
column5: there's a sort of Owl City twerpiness to it
column6: a softbatch indifference trying to pass for mysterious shyness. But he also leans toward a high wail so shrill-- imagine Barry Gibb as Jon Lovitz's ""Annoying Man""-- that any potential sincerity comes across as a desperate affectation. It's drenched in this grating nasal sibilance that sounds like an eye-rolling whine no matter what the message is. And there's a noncommittal emptiness to all that pitched-up whimpering-- loosely reflected in the deep-as-their-titles themes of songs such as ""When We Could All Float Away""
column7: ""The Weightlessness""
column8:
and ""Can't Let Anybody Know Who You Are""-- that makes it impossible to catch on to any real drive or desire. You can't feel something that doesn't feel anything.

"|16215.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16215-evan-voytas-feel-me/|3.3|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17357/homepage_large.cover.jpg|Nehru Jackets|29388.0|Heems|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Greedhead']|2012-01-26 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:05.601896|"

Last November
column2: Das Racist-- the quick-witted rap trio responsible for two of recent memory's most irreverent and engaging mixtapes and one divisive full-length-- made their national TV debut on ""Conan""
column3: performing lead single ""Michael Jackson"" from their 2011 album proper
column4: Relax. The scene was set for all the makings of great agit-prop theater: two stone-faced women smacking the living shit out of crash cymbals
column5: crazed instrument swapping
column6: and not to mention an actual Michael Jackson impersonator showing up to bust some time-honored moves during the noisy coda. It was like Andy Kaufman had he been raised on Illmatic and cable TV: Das Racist's secret strength is that you're never quite sure whether they're laughing with you or at you
column7: but when they are at their best
column8: their wise-ass approach also feels inclusive. The ""Conan"" appearance
column9: however
column10: was anything but welcoming. Heems (Himanshu Suri) and Kool A.D. (Victor Vasquez) mumbled through their verses
column11: leaving the sloppy music to do the heavy lifting. Which made some sense
column12: considering the record they were promoting was built to polarize. The paranoid Relax felt like a warning shot
column13: a suggestion that maybe we'd all gotten a bit too close.

column1: And now we have two of three promised mixtapes from the DR camp
column2: Heems' Nehru Jackets and Kool A.D.'s The Palm Wine Drinkard (hype-man extraordinaire Dapwell's bid is up next.) While both lack the accessibility that marked the first two Das Racist tapes
column3: they allow the rappers to indulge their most far-out ideas. Heems and Kool A.D. sound like they don't care what anyone thinks
column4: and the accompanying freedom brings back some of that early charm. Though the approaches are notably different-- with Nehru Jackets sticking closer to the Das Racist script and Palm Wine Drinkard spending most of its time in the deep end-- the tapes are filled with unexpected payoffs.

column1: If there was any question as to whether Kool A.D. was the true freak of the group
column2: the first few minuts of The Palm Wine Drinkard lay it to rest. The opening track-- featuring the full seven minutes of Outkast's ""Spottieottiedopaliscious"" instrumental
column3: junked up with what sounds like the din of a busy high school woodshop laid over top-- is annoying and offputting
column4: but things get better. It could have skated by on the easy charms of stuff like ""Lagrimas Blancas"" (a funky chest-beater that finds A.D. cooling out by the pool in Barcelona
column5: with an appropriate new mantra to match: ""Bitch
column6: I'm James Murphy"")
column7: or the ass-shakingly friendly remixes of DR's ""You Can Sell Anything"" and ""Booty in the Air"". But when A.D. really stretches himself
column8: some of the most bizarre ideas turn into something interesting. Most notable are the three post-Drake R&B tracks
column9: presented free of smugness or irony: The cottony
column10: seductive ""Ganglion of Lightnings""-- a 2008 track from A.D.'s Wesleyan group Boy Crisis
column11: repurposed here-- is both sincere and intimate
column12: conjuring a fluid dreaminess that feels sincere. Even when it fails
column13: The Palm Wine Drinkard still entertains.

column1: Heems' Nehru Jackets is a nice counterpoint Palm Wine's experimentation. It's a no-fuss
column2: traditional mixtape full of solid features (Danny Brown
column3: Action Bronson
column4: and Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire) and some terrific production
column5: all credited to Heems' childhood friend Mike Finito. ""We definitely listened to a lot of Company Flow and Def Jux stuff in high school
column6: Heems told MTV Hive this month of the pair's affinity for the currently defunct New York indie rap label. It shows-- Finito's production is both enigmatic and hard-edged (plus
column7: there's his dead-on El-P imitation on ""Mike Finito Raps Too"")
column8: full of junky drums
column9: idiosyncratic sampling
column10: and plenty of Punjabi influences.

column1: Followers of Das Racist (or Heems' Twitter feed
column2: for that matter) know that racial and socio-economic topics are always close at hand
column3: but Nehru Jackets is not an overtly political record. Of the tape's 25 tracks
column4: only a few dig into the specifics of any given issue. ""NYC Cops""
column5: which first showed up on a Stereogum's Strokes cover tribute compilation
column6: is borderline harrowing
column7: a vitriol-spitting rundown of the NYPD's checkered past
column8: with the too-short
column9: self-explanatory ""Juveniles Detained at Guantanamo Bay"" striking a similar chord.

column1: But Nehru Jackets as a whole is pretty loose
column2: filled with free-associative raps that find Heems in various states of alertness
column3: sobriety
column4: and engagement. It's also way too long. As he explained in the same Hive interview
column5: putting Mike Finito on was one of the primary goals here: ""I figured the only way for people to hear [his talent] is if I hop on these joints and give my man some shine."" Finito's work is one of the tape's strengths
column6: but it also leaves Heems with a lot of ground to cover
column7: and much of the material ends up feeling unfocused. In this setting
column8: Heems is at his best when surrounded by better rappers
column9: when he's able to mirror their enthusiasm and energy. If these two mixtapes prove anything
column10:
it's that these guys need each other.

"|16199.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16199-heems-nehru-jackets-kool-ad-the-palm-wine-drinkard/|6.5|Zach Kelly

column3: junked up with what sounds like the din of a busy high school woodshop laid over top-- is annoying and offputting
column4: but things get better. It could have skated by on the easy charms of stuff like ""Lagrimas Blancas"" (a funky chest-beater that finds A.D. cooling out by the pool in Barcelona
column5: with an appropriate new mantra to match: ""Bitch
column6: I'm James Murphy"")
column7: or the ass-shakingly friendly remixes of DR's ""You Can Sell Anything"" and ""Booty in the Air"". But when A.D. really stretches himself
column8: some of the most bizarre ideas turn into something interesting. Most notable are the three post-Drake R&B tracks
column9: presented free of smugness or irony: The cottony
column10: seductive ""Ganglion of Lightnings""-- a 2008 track from A.D.'s Wesleyan group Boy Crisis
column11: repurposed here-- is both sincere and intimate
column12: conjuring a fluid dreaminess that feels sincere. Even when it fails
column13: The Palm Wine Drinkard still entertains.

column1: Heems' Nehru Jackets is a nice counterpoint Palm Wine's experimentation. It's a no-fuss
column2: traditional mixtape full of solid features (Danny Brown
column3: Action Bronson
column4: and Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire) and some terrific production
column5: all credited to Heems' childhood friend Mike Finito. ""We definitely listened to a lot of Company Flow and Def Jux stuff in high school
column6: Heems told MTV Hive this month of the pair's affinity for the currently defunct New York indie rap label. It shows-- Finito's production is both enigmatic and hard-edged (plus
column7: there's his dead-on El-P imitation on ""Mike Finito Raps Too"")
column8: full of junky drums
column9: idiosyncratic sampling
column10: and plenty of Punjabi influences.

column1: Followers of Das Racist (or Heems' Twitter feed
column2: for that matter) know that racial and socio-economic topics are always close at hand
column3: but Nehru Jackets is not an overtly political record. Of the tape's 25 tracks
column4: only a few dig into the specifics of any given issue. ""NYC Cops""
column5: which first showed up on a Stereogum's Strokes cover tribute compilation
column6: is borderline harrowing
column7: a vitriol-spitting rundown of the NYPD's checkered past
column8: with the too-short
column9: self-explanatory ""Juveniles Detained at Guantanamo Bay"" striking a similar chord.

column1: But Nehru Jackets as a whole is pretty loose
column2: filled with free-associative raps that find Heems in various states of alertness
column3: sobriety
column4: and engagement. It's also way too long. As he explained in the same Hive interview
column5: putting Mike Finito on was one of the primary goals here: ""I figured the only way for people to hear [his talent] is if I hop on these joints and give my man some shine."" Finito's work is one of the tape's strengths
column6: but it also leaves Heems with a lot of ground to cover
column7: and much of the material ends up feeling unfocused. In this setting
column8: Heems is at his best when surrounded by better rappers
column9: when he's able to mirror their enthusiasm and energy. If these two mixtapes prove anything
column10:
it's that these guys need each other.

column2: rootless ""Sleepover"": ""Lock the door
column3: I'll take your coat/ Let's pretend that it's summer

column1: This album is about the comings and goings that can consume a certain kind of twentysomething's life

column12: the British Mills singing on one side as a West Coast tomboy
column13: struggling to make sense of all the r's
column14: and on the other as a clipped Boston debutante with a Mid-Atlantic lilt. Papini's voice falls somewhere in the funny middle space between the sisters' harmonies
column15: whatever Midwestern drawl she might be shoving aside yearning from the wings

Hospitality should fare a bit better.

It may upset folks rooting for Howler that they continuously get compared to the Strokes
column3: but it's not like the band doesn't deserve it.  After all
column4: these affable Minnesotans offer the sort of spry and strummy ""no bullshit"" rock music that made tons of folks spring for the more expensive and less tastefully covered version of Is This It more than 10 years ago. That Howler's transformation from local faves to darlings of the international music press was aided by favorable write-ups in both The New York Times and the NME
column5: as well as the breathless
column6: semi-mythic pursuit of Rough Trade Records-- the storied UK label reportedly flew overseas to sign the band based on its unsolicited demo-- only help strengthen the spiritual bond between these two groups.

column1: It also helps (or hurts) that Howler frontman Jordan Gatesmith often offers his thoughts about love and loneliness in the same sort of laconic faux-macho groan that Julian Casablancas should've trademarked. But while Gatesmith
column2: at the ripe age of 19
column3: isn't much younger than Casablancas was when the ink dried on the Strokes' first contract
column4: he's not nearly as comfortable striking the same disaffected poses.  If anything
column5: Howler suffer the more Gatesmith resembles Casablancas
column6: partially because he's not pitching the same kind of game.  Howler's hearts are firmly affixed on their sleeves
column7: right below a magic-marker version of the Weezer ""flying W.""  When Gatesmith's yawp collides with Howler's more sensitive sentiments-- for example
column8: his shirt-rending complaints about necking on ""Wailing (Making Out)""-- it's not a good look.  Howler are better off when Gatesmith veers towards flattering another New York City music icon
column9: Joey Ramone (as on ""This One's Different"")
column10: or simply making sure that he doesn't get too excited.

column1: At this point in their ridiculously young career
column2: though
column3: Howler's best look is when Gatesmith isn't on the mic.  As mentioned
column4: Howler have got a little Strokes in their music as well
column5: though any semblance of post-punk cool's been swapped out for some truly old-time rock'n'roll vibes. Gatesmith might still be playing catch up with the Rolling Stones (according to this interview with the MinnPost)
column6: but the group's deployment of Chuck Berry-esque licks and various Spectorian flourishes (including yet another ""Be My Baby"" drumbeat nod) shows they at least have a cursory knowledge of the classics. They also have a way with dynamics; I wouldn't be surprised if the two-tiered guitar assault essayed on the chorus of ""Beach Sluts"" was the result of someone wanting to approximate what the 11 on the volume knob would sound like.

column1: Why the album kicks off with ""Beach Sluts"" and not a standout track like ""Back of Your Neck""
column2: though
column3: is beyond me.  The latter's affable charm (corny Bonnie & Clyde shout-out notwithstanding) is a much better first foot forward. But that track finds itself on the album's back end
column4: grouped with the hazy (possibly shoegazey) ""Free Drunk"" and carefree
column5: surf-friendly ""Black Lagoon""
column6: all of them highlights.  Instead
column7: the album follows up a somewhat bracing introductory note with an assortment of OK to not-so-OK tunes that ultimately congeal into an undifferentiated
column8: if intermittently enjoyable
column9: lump
column10: before ending on a high note.  In other words
column11: America Give Up is inconsistent and derivative yet promising
column12:
and not nearly as impressive as some early adopters would have people believe: a pretty typical rock group's first album. And there's absolutely nothing wrong with that.

If you thought Pyramids' rapid-fire style-hopping
column3: from trad doom metal crunch to post-rock's technical ecstasy
column4: was exhausting on their 2008 debut album
column5: then prepare yourself for an almost hour-long collage that makes their old stuff seem downright uniform. If you enjoyed the gnarled oomph of Horseback's take on bottom-heavy black metal
column6: then get ready to hear that heaviness reduced to the merest eerie echo floating through that collage. Yet while their solo releases could frustrate via skill-without-conviction
column7: or feel like retreads of well-worn metal sounds
column8: these two bands seem newly invigorated by working together
column9: and the collaborative A Throne Without a King takes a real chance
column10: risks real failure
column11: and goes further out than either group has on its own. While so much avant metal fails to truly scramble the genre's rules
column12: often offering little more than weakened takes on metal's essentials
column13: Pyramids and Horseback have jointed forces here to create a stylistic mutant.

column1: A Throne Without a King will probably repulse the folks out there sporting Repulsion tattoos. It will also probably puzzle those who prefer their black and/or doom metal with a comforting glaze of My Bloody Valentine-style melody. That's a shame
column2: but it's hardly surprising. True
column3: there are few moments of hardcore riffage and burning-at-the-stake screams. And there are moments of swirling beauty that could have easily been lifted off a shoegaze (or even early IDM) record. But rather than simply smushing two sorta-complementary genres together
column4: Throne explores extremes of abrasive and soft
column5: oblique structure and seeming formlessness
column6: rather than simply recycling elements from the-genre-known-as-extreme-music. A long-form collage of feedback and fractured electronics
column7: where the wary won't be asking ""is this metal?"" so much as ""what is this?"" If that kind of exploratory amorphousness
column8: with a side of blackened ugliness
column9: sounds appealing
column10: you probably already know if you need this. In one of our rapidly disappearing brick-and-mortar record stores
column11: the sticker might read: ""Recommended if you like dark ambient
column12: old-school academic tape edits
column13: horror movie sound design
column14: the fringes of improv electronics scene
column15: etc.""

column1: Though the main attraction is clearly the album's titular four-part epic
column2: which sprawls for close to an hour
column3: Throne opens with two relatively short and palate-readying tracks
column4: a solo outing from each band. Ostensibly this will allow new listeners to get some idea of the particular aesthetic universes Pyramids and Horseback usually inhabit
column5: before the rest of Throne obliterates those reference points entirely. Pyramids' contribution sounds like recent Mego in a mellow mood
column6: alternating brief hair-raising moments of dissonance with placid electronics. Horseback title their piece in honor of left-field composer Henry Flynt
column7: and you can (very) vaguely hear Flynt's influence in the way this tribute to Norway's corpse-painted heroes collapses midway through into pure drone
column8: only to rebuild itself for one final assault. ""A Throne Without a King"" parts one through four
column9: however
column10: sounds not much like either of those modes
column11: except for maybe tiny traces sprinkled through its vast and unruly whole.

column1: As with so many longform experimental compositions
column2: boredom lurks when things get too loose. Part three aims at some kind of icky Ferrari/Dockstader musique concrète
column3: all ominous clangs and rattling iron
column4: but goes on way too long
column5: sapping the drama until it all starts to sound like some goth kids aimlessly futzing around in dad's toolshed. Much better are the moments when Throne goes majestic rather than minimalist. Part two pits angelic choirs against disruptive blasts of static; part four subjects glacial atmosphere à la Wolfgang Voigt to what sounds like several corrupted mp3s' worth of digital distortion. It's here Pyramids and Horseback evoke certain metal qualities
column6: the grandeur and the gloom
column7: the brutality and fearlessness
column8: without needing to actually draw on metal's vocabulary. If they'd managed that across the whole piece
column9: ""A Throne Without a King"" might be a minor masterpiece of modern
column10: unsettling sound manipulation. As it is
column11: while it's impossible to claim that every minute of Throne will grip you
column12: even if you’re already attuned to this sort of untethered drift
column13: it's a strong
column14:
spooky soundtrack for these early frostbitten months of the year.

Wisdom and Soul From the King of Calypso 1962-1974|30146.0|Mighty Sparrow|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Strut']|2012-01-26 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:08.060473|"

Trinidadian calypso
column3: like 1980s rap
column4: is the sound of current events masquerading as  dance music. Or
column5: put another way
column6: it's a style that uses the social space of the dancefloor to deliver news and opinion. Great calypso singers exploit the same idea your kindergarten teacher did: That lessons are more happily-- and subliminally-- learned when set to rhythm and song.

column1: No singer has had a longer career in calypso and soca than Mighty Sparrow. He was born in 1935
column2: won his first major prizes in 1956
column3: and still  tours. His best anthologies are considered starting points for anyone  exploring the genre-- a project I accept is probably off the radar for a  lot of listeners
column4: especially in North America
column5: where ""calypso"" has the unfortunate reputation as that stuff they play in the background of ads for all-inclusive vacation packages.

column1: The music supporting calypso singers is catchy and formulaic
column2: and like all  catchy
column3: formulaic music
column4: it requires craft and discipline-- a calypso  band is only as good as its ability to subtly vary its tunes without  upstaging its singer. The music
column5: affable and upbeat as it may be
column6: is backlighting for its singer.

column1: Sparrow's personality is big
column2: complex
column3: and contradictory. He plays the fool for two verses only to prove his wisdom in the third. He boasts and judges. He unwittingly insults himself with a huge grin on his face. On ""Jean and Dinah""
column4: for example
column5: he celebrates the departure of American  soldiers because it'll give him a better chance to score a hooker.  Politics and sex are treated with the same irreverence-- both
column6: after  all
column7: are just stages for human folly. Sparrow songs offer a perfect kind  of satisfaction
column8: the kind viewers get from the neat circles of sitcoms  and folktales. At the end
column9: everyone-- often including Sparrow himself-- ends up out on their asses.

column1: His sense of humor is particular to the marginalized and disenfranchised. The past 500 years of Trinidad's history is a history of occupation-- first by the Spanish from Columbus' time until the end of the 18th century
column2: when it was surrendered to the British
column3: and used as a naval hub  by the United States during World War II. Sparrow's songs hint at  imperialism and national identity
column4: but in the lighthearted way of  someone who ultimately can't do anything about them. Laughter
column5: in  essence
column6: is the source of Sparrow's intelligence but also of his self-preservation.

column1: On ""Don't Go
column2: Joe""
column3: for example-- which can be found on the compilation Volume One-- Sparrow sings about an American soldier who seduces his sister
column4: Millie  and then runs back to his wife and kids
column5: but not before Millie  pickpockets him. In a surprising line
column6: he witnesses the soldiers crying  in port. This shakes his expectations of them-- for a second
column7: they're  humanized. The song is at its core a comedy
column8: but one shot through with the heartache of watching the imperialists have their way.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: neither ""Jean and Dinah"" nor ""Don't Go Joe"" are on Sparrowmania!. None of his best songs are
column3: really. The collection's cover has a nice
column4: vintage feel
column5: the kind that says we're a comprehensive reissue label that cares about quality and selection
column6: and while Strut has released some high-quality compilations
column7: this isn't  one of them. Ultimately
column8: it's just another collection in a pile of  Sparrow collections divided between incisive
column9: entertaining tracks
column10: five-minute double-entendres about boners
column11: and one-off experiments cherrypicked from a long and inconsistent career. Also
column12: the sound  is curiously awful
column13: as if the music were mastered from a cranked-up transistor radio.

column1: Ah! how it pains me to type that. People deserve a two-disc Sparrow comp to bury all other Sparrow comps
column2: but this isn't it (Smithsonian's First Flight
column3: from 2005
column4: is much better
column5: though it falls off before Sparrow hit his  prime). It's all sad and fitting
column6: in a way: Music from a former colony  gets marginalized by imperialist countries
column7: haphazardly packaged
column8: and  easily ignored. Hopefully
column9:
it's the kind of joke Sparrow can take.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17353/homepage_large.cover.jpg|MU.ZZ.LE|28603.0|Gonjasufi|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warp']|2012-01-25 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:09.525788|"

Gonjasufi's 2010 release A Sufi and a Killer succeeded largely on the strength of an engagingly odd presence: the simultaneously croaky and sweet voice of Sumach Valentine
column2: which sent initiates scrambling to identify fellow travelers
column3: from Captain Beefheart to George Clinton to John Fahey. It stood up as a strong example of psychedelic rock rewired for an audience more attuned to Madvillainy than The Madcap Laughs. But it still scanned a bit more like a shared vision than an individual voice: The album was just as much a revelation for the Gaslamp Killer
column4: who helmed the bulk of the production and laid down his own mark with a sprawling slate of beats that complemented Valentine's vocalizations.

column1: When the album that introduces a unique vocalist to a newly expanded fanbase also happens to do the same for its equally distinct producer
column2: you wonder how each will fare on his own. If last year's freebie 9th Inning EP was a catch-up session of self-created
column3: unreleased older tracks meant to remind newer fans of his broader repertoire
column4: MU.ZZ.LE scans like a means to transition from A Sufi and a Killer's multiple-identity psych into more personal territory. And it does this in a way that reinforces what made that previous album great.

column1: Gonjasufi and fellow San Diegan noise-break purveyor Psychopop have centered their production around a codeine-paced
column2: heavy-headed swoon that still manages to bristle with an undercurrent of stress. Psychopop handles beats for four of the 10 cuts
column3: and their half-speed wooziness is like the musical equivalent of the slow-motion running you might experience in an unsettling dream. The headswimming electric piano blues of ""White Picket Fence"" and the loping
column4: pendulous guitar in ""Feedin' Birds"" set the pace
column5: ethereal as it is
column6: and get a surprising amount of pull from their downtempo floatiness. But Gonjasufi's own production is just as steeped in dubbed-out
column7: crumbly atmospherics. The bass in ""Venom"" glows and throbs
column8: peppered with a jingling percussion timbre halfway between a tambourine and a handful of change. ""Blaksuit"" sounds like a vintage funk 45 flipped to 33
column9: its twangy loop pacing back and forth like a half-finished thought. And even when the snares pop
column10: as they do on ""Nikels and Dimes""
column11: they do so through a thick coating of resin and ash.

column1: If you think that means MU.ZZ.LE is a passive
column2: inert slog of an album
column3: keep in mind that every trudging
column4: straining step of the way is cut through with Gonjasufi's voice
column5: which is still a hell of a thing. The unconventional cast of his voice might be Valentine's most immediately recognizable trait
column6: but it's not his deepest. Every last creaking wail
column7: blown-out mutter
column8: and wounded drone is heavy with reflection
column9: and after a few listens it all starts to sound less like altered-mind eccentricity and more like raw
column10: unfiltered feeling. For all the talk about shroomed-out weirdness and otherworldly mysticism that's surrounded his music
column11: there's a more crucial sense of a real
column12: laid-bare emotional core here.

column1: All those shaky notes and half-intelligible murmurs disintegrating into decaying echoes might run parallel to an oddball Lee ""Scratch"" Perry sensibility
column2: but they evoke frustration and dejection vividly. The words aren't always clear through the fog of reverb
column3: though this might be by design
column4: some statement on how the plain truth of honest words can be sometimes hard to understand. But the agitated sentiments remain clear
column5: whether castigating against the abuse of privilege in ""Nikels and Dimes"" or straining to maintain an interpersonal connection on ""Rubberband"". When Sumach's wife April has a wraithlike torch-singer turn in the second half of ""Feedin' Birds"" and distantly doubles up his lead on ""Skin""
column6: it's to act as a sweetly voiced counterpart to lyrics that allude to guilt
column7: death
column8: and a search for love. And when the funereal lo-fi new wave of ""The Blame"" emerges near the end of the 24 1/2-minute running length
column9: it's the late peak of a record that wrings out a devastated man's crisis of consciousness-- ""You say I'm not supposed to kill/ Keep walking with my head high/ But every time I go somewhere/ I feel the dread inside their eyes."" MU.ZZ.LE might be a transitional point on Gonjasufi's path and it shows just one face of an eclectic
column10:
multifaceted performer. But it's also that rare album that feels meditative and cathartic all at once.

Young Montreal producer Jacques Greene is very good at one thing: extracting a vocal snippet from some all-but-forgotten R&B star of the recent past (Ashanti
column3: Brandy
column4: Ciara) and then proceeding to build a shiny and modern combination of house and two-step underneath it. His best tracks thus far are like graduate-level versions of Billboard busters David Guetta and Calvin Harris' shame-free fist pumpers; they're subtle and spacey
column5: but Greene leaves in enough kick and hook to keep everything floor-friendly. In his world
column6: voices are repeating ghosts caught between the beat. And
column7: depending on the time of day
column8: they can sound euphoric or a little lonely. Just look at the video for his track ""Tell Me"". There are two tipsy models heading back to their very expensive
column9: very solitary hotel rooms after what we can only assume is a night of $28 Midori sours-- it's not a hangover clip as much as a still-sorta-buzzed-at-6-a.m. clip. Jacques Greene makes music for models to stumble back to their suites to. Nothing wrong with that.

column1: Last year had him perfecting this formula across two excellent LuckyMe EPs
column2: The Look and Another Girl
column3: when he wasn't convincingly turning Thom Yorke into a proper diva and filling the geek-chic quota in pal Azealia Banks' ""212"" video. But Concealer
column4: the inaugural release on his new Vase imprint
column5: changes things up. The two A sides find Greene indulging his R&B tendencies more than ever before
column6: with opener ""Flatline"" even featuring original vocals from fellow Montrealer Ango. But the track doesn't sound like a savvy spin on radio also-rans as much as a wannabe also-ran itself; the ironically flat lead vocal comes off like sub-par Drake karaoke while the skittering instrumental recalls Timbaland in latter-day ""Apologize"" mode. Clearly
column7: it's one thing to gush about R&B heavies like The-Dream and Drake in interviews and cannily slip them into DJ mixes-- both of which Greene has done-- but quite another to successfully emulate them.

column1: Much better is ""These Days""
column2: where the 21-year-old once again squeezes the most out of a well-chosen sample-- Mario's 2004 album cut ""Couldn't Say No""-- while also moving forward
column3: switching out standard kicks for bottom-crawling tom hits. On the flip side are two more traditional two-step tracks
column4: ""Clark"" and ""Arrow""
column5: both unfortunately not quite living up to the lofty rep Greene has quickly earned. Whereas The Look and ""Another Girl"" displayed a tidy sense of dynamics and a just-right ear for attention-getting sonic finery
column6: these two simply glide by on their own blandly classy ambiance. For someone who has nailed that exquisite limbo between foreground and background
column7: Greene lets ""Clark"" and ""Arrow"" drift away too easily.

column1: To reiterate: Jacques Greene is very good at one thing. That one thing is unique and not easy to pull off. And there are still undiscovered corners for this producer to take his sample-based club sound before he jumps into the realm of more traditional song structures and vocals (which probably shouldn't be thought of as a be-all
column2: end-all anyhow) or extended instrumentals
column3: à la the nine-minute ""Arrow"". So Concealer has all the marks of a transitional release
column4: a feeler. While constant reinvention is a nice ideal
column5:
it's not for everyone.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17360/homepage_large.cover.jpg|File Under Sacred Music: Early Singles 1978-1981|853.0|The Cramps|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Munster']|2012-01-25 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:10.581053|"

The Cramps were record collectors before they were a band. When Erick Purkhiser and Kristy Wallace met in 1972
column3: they discovered they were both into the same kind of thing: the music of 15 years or so earlier that had been all about kitsch and shock and sleaze
column4: with shitty sonics and snarling
column5: hiccuping singers
column6: and hilarious over-the-top bravado. In the early 1970s
column7: being into ""50s rock'n'roll"" meant American Graffiti and Sha Na Na and ""Happy Days"". Wallace and Purkhiser preferred the nasty also-rans-- the records that actually tried to be the threat to society that people sometimes pretended pop music could be.

column1: It wasn't much of a leap to starting their own band in the same mode. Purkhiser reinvented himself as Lux Interior
column2: the slavering
column3: writhing
column4: nearly naked
column5: ectomorphic frontman of the Cramps
column6: and Wallace was Poison Ivy Rorschach
column7: a ""bad girl"" in leather and wigs and velvet who tore off one ichor-dripping 12-bar guitar riff after another. They didn't have a whole lot in common with their early punk scenemates other than big guitar noise
column8: but punk rock gave them license to do sleazy
column9: shocking
column10: sopping wet rock'n'roll without having to bother with the usual thin veneer of respectability.

column1: The Cramps were an institution for over 30 years
column2: until Lux's death in 2009. They were one of the few punk-era bands who were well served by aging
column3: since they were trying to come off like creepy
column4: depraved old people in the first place. But they were always a better singles band than an album band
column5: and a way better live act than a singles band. Most of the songs that made their reputation are collected on this suitably trashy set. The vinyl version of File Under Sacred Music is
column6: appropriately
column7: a ""collectible"" box of the band's first 10 singles in replica sleeves--or rather
column8: it would be except that four of them were never actually issued as singles at the time. (The Cramps always did snicker at anything that claimed to be authentic.)

column1: That's probably the ideal way to hear this material: Lux
column2: Ivy
column3: and their ever-rotating associates made the kind of strong
column4: silly records that are best in hot-sauce doses of between three and six minutes. They occasionally came up with fabulously personal-space-invading originals like ""Human Fly"" and ""New Kind of Kick""
column5: the latter of which features two lines that explain their raison d'être: ""Life is short/ Filled with stuff"" and ""I learned all I know by the age of nine."" The better part of File Under Sacred Music
column6: though
column7: is the crate-digging covers that were their calling card.

column1: Their first single (produced
column2: like a lot of their early material
column3: by Alex Chilton) was a cover of one of the most familiar trash-rock staples
column4: ""Surfin' Bird""
column5: extended to five minutes with a sloppy gnarl of guitar and drum noise. They subsequently shied away from anything that familiar. Instead
column6: they turned their attention to obscurities whose quirks they exaggerated to the point of perversion. Jack Scott's ""The Way I Walk"" was slowed down to a psychotic limp
column7: with Lux hyperventilating every line and Ivy screaming bloody murder in the background; Ronnie Cook & the Gaylads' nutty novelty ""Goo Goo Muck"" turned into a hilariously lascivious threat on which Lux shrieked
column8: trilled
column9: gurgled
column10: and enunciated the title like it referred to whatever bodily fluids your parents feared most.

column1: The title of File Under Sacred Music is a joke about the dusty record stores the Cramps loved
column2: as well as about their own discography: Songs the Lord Taught Us was the title of their first album
column3: Songs the Cramps Taught Us the name of one of the many series of bootlegs of the original songs they covered. But the amazing
column4: out-of-control music they saved from oblivion could show them up
column5: at least on record. To hear the Novas' feral pro-wrestling novelty ""The Crusher"" (""Do the hammerlock
column6: ya turkeynecks!"") next to the Cramps' cover is to understand the difference between lunatics who've somehow ended up with a mic in front of them and record collectors doing a solid
column7:
deliberate impression of lunatics.

For someone who has spent the bulk of his musical life sourcing inspiration from the past
column2: Neil Hagerty hasn't made many backward movements through his own career. When Pussy Galore reformed for one of Yo La Tengo's annual Hanukkah shows this past December
column3: he was nowhere to be seen. The Royal Trux reissues Drag City's put out barely seem different from the original releases. And any thoughts of him getting back together with former Trux partner Jennifer Herrema seem more remote than ever
column4: especially as she just delivered her best album in years under her new Black Bananas guise. Despite apparently living by a never-look-back creed
column5: there are usually a few signifiers in each new record by the Howling Hex-- a strained
column6: phlegm-ridden growl
column7: a stack of stodgy riffs-- that make everything he does suitably Hagerty-esque. Even the title Wilson Semiconductors feels like an obscure nod back to the inert object fetishization of ""Ray O Vac"" from Thank You.

column1: This is an EP of four long songs that continues the drum-less setup on the 2008 Howling Hex record Earth Junk
column2: with a simple guitar/bass/vocal set up getting the job done. It's ragged and detached
column3: with dips into tight song structure followed by long
column4: meandering guitar passages that feel like you're tied up in a loose strand of thought circling Hagerty's brain. He's lived out in the desert in New Mexico for some time now
column5: and it's not hard to hear that influence at work here
column6: especially on the ranchero flavor of the waltz-time closer ""A Game of Dice"". Except
column7: this being Hagerty
column8: it's sci-fi ranchero
column9: full of squelching
column10: thickset guitar parts
column11: joined by a reedy vocal line that makes it sound like it was recorded when he needed to pee real hard. It probably was. So
column12: in many ways
column13: this is an extension of the work he began on Earth Junk
column14: albeit with a few divots to negotiate along the way.

column1: On the opening ""Reception""
column2: Hagerty works up a bouncy guitar undertow over which his vocal finger wagging warns up-and-comers about the perils of entering the music game. It's got the kind of authoritative cadence that his best work always has
column3: where you feel like you're suddenly privy to a nugget of invaluable information
column4: no matter how silly it looks on the page. In that sense Hagerty works in a great rock'n'roll tradition
column5: where delivery begets meaning. The intent derived from the whiney
column6: doubled-up vocal line
column7: ""Reception
column8: it can take a long time
column9: can be parsed in a million different ways. But the way Hagerty conveys it-- swamping the mix
column10: dripping with resonance-- leaves you in little doubt that some kind of indeterminate wisdom is being imparted by a tyrannical autocrat
column11: and it's time to simply shut up and take notice.

column1: But
column2: as with most material the Howling Hex have produced
column3: Wilson Semiconductors easily passes from that kind of despotic strut to something more freeform. ""Brunette Roulette"" is an extended guitar exercise
column4: shorn of vocals
column5: edging close to the nine-minute mark with no particular place to go. It draws elements of freak folk into the mix
column6: with a frantically strummed acoustic guitar loop underpinning strident soloing followed by a honeyed coating of flange two-thirds of the way through. ""Play This When You Feel Low"" is an unfocussed bridging of both worlds
column7: with wild avant soloing conjoined to heavily reverbed vocals that struggle to find a place to sit comfortably. Each track here encounters a similar problem at some point. There are plenty of impulses worthy of exploration
column8: but too often they end up tarnished by a listless desire to meander without direction
column9:
making Wilson Semiconductors feel more like a stopgap than a valuable addition to Hagerty's canon.

What's left to say about the Pop Ambient series? That it appears every winter? Check. That it has become a bit of a chore? Done. That shifts in its tone and content are subtle? Been there. That it rarely breaks artists of note? Got it. It has become difficult to tease differences out of the series as its chapters have grown voluminous
column2: and I'll submit that the real question we need to ask about the Pop Ambient series is not what remains unsaid but what the series itself has left to say. Pop Ambient 2012 arrives at a time when ambient and experimental artists routinely sing for their supper
column3: offering theoretical frameworks and positioning their works as commentaries on music
column4: media
column5: and memory.

column1: The goals of the PA series and its artists are largely sonic
column2: bridging the gaps
column3: however tenuously
column4: between electronic music
column5: modern classical
column6: and pop. The series' flower motif suggests a kinship with Erik Satie's concept of furniture music
column7: or music explicitly intended for the background. Gorgeous soundtracking is a fair
column8: modest goal of ambient composers
column9: but music of this ilk-- from Leyland Kirby (and his Caretaker alias) to Emeralds to Oneohtrix Point Never-- has felt so vibrant and rich in recent years that the offerings here seem slight. Stop me if you've heard this one before: PA12 contains another new Wolfgang Voigt side project (Mohn
column10: with Jörg Burger)
column11: a Kompakt techno stalwart making his first-ever series contribution (Superpitcher)
column12: and notable outsiders (Simon Scott). Intrigued? Which volume of the series did you pull off the shelf to listen to in anticipation of these revelations?

column1: Forgive the cynicism. The failure of PA12 has little to do with the individual tracks
column2: most of which could
column3: at worst
column4: be harmlessly swapped out for the third-most-forgettable offering on any given PA compilation. There are highlights
column5: as always: the beautiful simplicity of the piano that steers Superpitcher's ""Jackson""; Wolfgang Voigt's ruptured
column6: surprising orchestrations on ""Rückverzauberung 5"". Five years after lighting up PA07 with the Field's ""Kappsta""
column7: Axel Wilner debuts his new guise
column8: Loops of Your Heart
column9: whose ""Riding the Bikes"" closes PA12 with lacy
column10: somnambulent guitar. (In other words
column11: the only new standout on PA12 is the alias of an artist who has already released three full-lengths for Kompakt.) There are more obvious missteps than in previous years
column12: though. On ""Richmodis""
column13: Triola masses clanging minor chords into a long
column14: useless noir. Mohn's comp-opening offering
column15: ""Manifesto""
column16: is not just slow and ringing but comically ponderous. Magazine's self-edit of ""The Visitors Bureau"" is pro-forma symphonic drift.

column1: Just as Now That's What I Call Music 40 hardly suggests permanence
column2: PA12 is damned by its place in a series that grew stale several years ago. This is not even the best ambient compilation Wolfgang Voigt has appeared on in the past year: Kompakt regulars Andrew Thomas and bvdub (who makes an appearance here) compiled Air Texture Vol. 1
column3: a frothy
column4: generous collection that outmaneuvers PA12 at every turn. Ambient music feels rich and diverse right now
column5: willing to engage with wider worlds. The expanses of PA12's tracks belie how cloistered and small the compilation actually is. There's nothing wrong with music that knowingly fades into the background
column6:
so long as you accept that sometimes the only room you're wallpapering is your own.

""Good ol' Freddie Mercury is the only guy that advises me
column2: Craig Finn sings on ""No Future""
column3: from his first solo album
column4: Clear Heart Full Eyes. Later in the same song
column5: he calls out another 1970s rock icon: ""The best advice I've ever gotten was from good ol' Johnny Rotten
column6: he confesses
column7: before launching into a few lines from ""God Save the Queen"". As rock touchstones go
column8: Queen and the Sex Pistols aren't too far off the beaten path; he could have quoted Alex Chilton or Damo Suzuki or even Elvis Costello
column9: but that would miss the point. Finn is after the artists and music that try to make rock a communal rather than a private experience. So he's an unlikely hero for the cloistered and segmented indie rock crowd
column10: which we're told prizes obscurity over accessibility. Ironically for a band whose lyrics depicted geographically specific subsubcultures
column11: Finn's day-job group the Hold Steady brought a bar-band approach back into the indie rock world. They strove for broad appeal
column12: which circa 2005's Separation Sunday sharpened their guitar attack and made them sound almost dangerous.

column1: Over time
column2: however
column3: that same populism softened the Hold Steady's edges and blunted their urgency
column4: and Finn's solo album
column5: whose title is cribbed and scrambled from ""Friday Night Lights""
column6: may be the culmination of that particular trajectory. If most solo albums at least make an effort to distinguish themselves from the artist's main outlet-- to justify their very existence-- Finn's chief tactic on these songs is to play everything close to the chest
column7: to dial the music back and the intensity down. That's fine for songs such as ""Western Pier"" and closer ""Not Much Left of Us""
column8: but deadly for ""When No One's Watching"" and ""Honolulu Blues""
column9: which sound like he's consciously trying to avoid sounding like his main band. The guitars rarely venture toward riff or melody; instead
column10: they provide atmosphere and mood. But so much of Clear Heart Full Eyes cries out for louder guitars
column11: Springsteen-like drama
column12: and the kind of precise sloppiness the Hold Steady did so well in the late 2000s.

column1: The album works best when it sounds freshest and furthest away from the music we typically associate with Finn. ""Terrified Eyes"" shuffles around on a laidback beat and a rangy
column2: almost alt-country guitar
column3: as he takes the conspiratorial tone of a tour guide pointing out the sites of crimes and scandals. ""New Friend Jesus"" rambles acoustically
column4: although Finn makes the title character sound like a punchline. That's odd considering how much of the album is given over to some of his most blatantly Catholic (or is that catholic?) lyrics. If Separation Sunday rewrote the rules and rituals of religion as street-level spirituality
column5: Clear Heart Full Eyes mostly plays it straight.

column1: Like some of the best Hold Steady albums
column2: these songs are all interconnected
column3: full of recurring characters and settings
column4: so that even when the tempos lag and the guitars noodle
column5: Clear Heart is pulled along by pure narrative momentum
column6: giving it an immersive power that it doesn't necessarily earn. But that's Finn's main appeal: He's a born storyteller who's chosen rock as his medium. On Clear Heart he creates a new world with unique characters and rules
column7: which are concrete
column8: specific
column9: and evocative. While it pales alongside some of the Hold Steady's best albums
column10: these songs are so entangled with those people and places-- with those Holly and Charlemagne mythologies-- that they never grow tedious or ignorable. So perhaps Finn is turning into someone like Mercury or Rotten
column11: acting as adviser to a new generation of listeners. Like them
column12: he came on like a man on a mission
column13: but now that it's been accomplished
column14:
he sounds like a man trying to figure out what comes next. Clear Heart is just good enough to keep us listening.

"|16201.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16201-clear-heart-full-eyes/|6.0|Stephen M. Deusner

Toronto-based XO crew member DropxLife was partly responsible for ""Initiation""
column2: one of the highlights of the Weeknd's Echoes of Silence and one of that act's most distinctive tracks
column3: all choppy seasick drums and demonically distorted vocals. Aside from his vague association with Tesfaye and company
column4: there's not much to be found about the mysterious producer. He's let a few of his own productions trickle out over the past few months
column5: and collected them in a free-to-download mixtape called Furthur
column6: a short collection of instrumentals that handily profiles an intriguing new name in an increasingly overcrowded set of knuckle-dragging
column7: mopey hip-hop beatsmiths.

column1: Well
column2: to call it hip-hop wouldn't exactly be accurate: in a fashion similar to Balam Acab and Holy Other's
column3: the slow swing and drowsy drop that DropxLife favors is a whole lot more trip-hop than hip-hop. We're talking real trip-hop here: There are moments on Furthur that sound uncannily like mid-1990s Bristol-- Portishead
column4: Massive
column5: Tricky-- updated for 2012
column6: and the ones that don't tend to lean on other arbiters of downtempo like DJ Shadow
column7: maybe even Thievery Corporation. Not to be relegated to copycat or crate-digger
column8: however
column9: what makes DropxLife feel less like a retro fetishist is the distinctly digital nature of his work: Loaded with filters
column10: effects
column11: and heavily-processed sounds
column12: Furthur has more in common with cloud-rap than the scratchy vinyl samples of early trip-hop.

column1: What the trip-hop dimension does for Furthur is to lend it a relaxed
column2: almost carefree vibe: Like a tranquilized RZA
column3: this is unfiltered spliff music with a vaguely orientalist bent
column4: almost too languorous to even imagine someone spitting over it without getting tangled up in the long washes of sound or angled lashes of string instruments. Take opener ""MadexMen""
column5: centering around some filtered coos and a strummed guitar
column6: with slow
column7: glitchy drums that sound like they're sliding off each other: This is remarkably lazy stuff
column8: taking the codeine crawl of Clams Casino and like-minded acts to a new plateau of dazed and blazed.

column1: Clams Casino is an essential reference point here: The raspy breezes and gauzy gasps that coat tracks such as ""BexForever"" feel torn right from his page. There are differences of course-- the sub-bass in ""BexForever"" feels far more brutal than anything I've heard by Clams
column2: and a lot of Drop's beats heave and lurch with a wide-arced pendulum swing. But it's still hard not to hear him in the bits of tabla and other light percussive touches that scuff the surface of ""StillxShots"" in a way uncannily similar to the New Jersey producer's ""Numb"". Taken on their own terms
column3: DropxLife's tracks are more physical
column4: cleaner
column5: composed of disparate elements; if Clams seems to mould and bend songs out of monolithic shapes
column6: DropxLife builds them piece-by-piece from the ground up
column7: but you probably wouldn't think twice about uttering them in the same breath anyway. It's this lack of personality that makes Furthur a merely pleasant listen rather than a truly stimulating one.

column1: Furthur's best moments come when DropxLife goes nuts with the delay effects
column2: creating a dazzlingly shimmering surface that skips and skates over the low end to disorienting effect
column3: like walking the wrong way down a moving conveyor belt (the motion-sickness phasing on ""1stxFlr"" or the dry heave guitar on ""TripXEnt""). But we shouldn't forget who people are rightly going to associate DropxLife with
column4: and highlight ""RedxBloor"" indeed sounds like a chopped-and-screwed Weeknd track
column5: featuring a heart-wrenching vocal sample not unlike the disembodied female voices that pop up on Weeknd tracks ""Lonely Star"" and ""Next"". Even just that snippet of a vocal endows DropxLife's sluggish torpor with a vivacity the rest of it lacks
column6:
a liveliness he's going to need to develop if he wants to be anything more than another bloodshot bedroom beatmaker.

If you heard Resolution before knowing anything about the band who made it
column2: you'd be forgiven for mistaking Lamb of God's latest as the high-production
column3: major-label debut of an energetic
column4: upstart crew. At 14 songs and 57 minutes
column5: Resolution feels like the sort of unedited
column6: exhaustively long collection a label might get behind to see if at least one of the songs lands with a wide audience.

column1: Such signs are everywhere on Resolution: Each of the choruses in these rigid Pantera-cum-Slayer recasts are aggressively emphasized

column8: barrel ahead
column9: shift at the bridge

column11: and implode at the exit-- they take care to show that

column14: too
column15: the sort of band that boasts the promise of a varied future. There's the convincingly sludgy opener

column1: But Resolution is Lamb of God's seventh album and their fourth for Epic Records

column3: too
column4: peaking with a chart position of No. 2 for their most recent record
column5: 2009's Wrath
column6: which earned two Grammy nominations and sold a few hundred thousand copies. Those past stats and the Virginia band's status as relative metal statesmen for the mainstream make Resolution that much more disappointing in context.

column1: Despite the handful of hooks that do stick and those big ""risks
column2: like the acoustic blues strums at the start of single ""Ghost Walking"" or the belligerent boogie that opens the much better ""Invictus""
column3: Lamb of God's general lack of adventurousness makes them mostly indistinguishable from their heroes and
column4: budget excepted
column5: the bulk of their contemporaries. After a decade of becoming arguably the biggest American metal band that either didn't exist when George H. W. Bush was president or didn't come from a cartoon
column6: you would hope that Lamb of God had earned the right to be adventurous
column7: to try and stretch their legacy wider than that of a band subservient to its predecessors. Resolution simply sounds like a refinement of their past
column8: with their unquestionable technical prowess (especially impressive is the occasional interplay between guitarists Mark Morton and Willie Adler and drummer Chris Adler) funneled again into songs that would lose any distinction in a mixtape of their peers.

column1: On ""Invictus""
column2: this record's most structurally and lyrically compelling track
column3: Randy Blythe roars the album's least instant but most interesting hook: ""You brand it a crisis/ I name it an honor/ To face what arises/ To remain unconquered."" That ethos reappears throughout Resolution
column4: an album that
column5: despite all this talk of bravery
column6: lacks the resolve to sound anything but normal and predictable. With so much history and more than a million album sold
column7: you'd think sounding mistakably young would be a compliment. But on Resolution
column8: it doesn't equal a band bursting forth with ideas or burning with ambition; it means that
column9: apart from the number of records they've sold
column10:
Lamb of God still need to find a way to make an impression last longer than an album cycle.

You could say that no two LPs by venerated-yet-underrated Scottish avant-rock artist Richard Youngs sound alike
column3: and in the main you'd be right. How can you sum up a musician who's appeared on dozens and dozens of records over the last 20 years
column4: rivaling Sun Ra and Merzbow in their similarly fecund and all-over-the-map output? Of course
column5: even someone who contains multitudes occasionally repeats himself
column6: and there are obvious sonic links from one Youngs release to the next. For one thing
column7: his keening voice remains as instantly recognizable on the new Amaranthine as ever
column8: as does his idiosyncratic-unto-inscrutable phrasing
column9: where excessively drawn-out lines trade off with obsessively repeated lyrical fragments. But even still
column10: you'd be hard-pressed to draw a direct line between Youngs' previous two albums and the haunted murk of Amaranthine
column11: even as it focuses on (and amplifies) many of his central obsessions.

column1: For example
column2: his longstanding interest in pushing rule-bound forms like folk and rock and devotional music into the rule-free space of improvisation
column3: or stretching their inherent repetitive natures past the accepted limits. These two modes are taken to a visceral extreme on Amaranthine. Rock is smelted down into a pervasive drone-roar that suggests the music's power while abandoning almost all of its familiar structural elements. Meanwhile
column4: the steady state of that drone is counter-pointed by wild junkyard percussion that denies the very existence of the backbeat. The howl of ecstatic jazz is stripped of any blues or swing until just the yearning for total movement in any direction remains. Youngs' singing veers between liturgical formality and an expressionist bleat that mimics Albert Ayler's horn at its most mournful. It's a long and wooly journey into a rather forbidding place. Intriguing
column5: at times overwhelming
column6: and voyeuristic like a peek into a private ceremony. But still forbidding.

column1: On a casual listen
column2: Amaranthine sounds loose and repetitious in a way that suggests the players shut their minds off and got down to some primal state of in-the-moment music making. The obvious suggestion is that you should do the same as a listener
column3: letting the emotion of the sound wash over you. And sure
column4: that's one way to approach it. Amaranthine certainly has the feel of a tribal incantation playing out in real time
column5: of a group losing itself in the unconscious flow
column6: captured in the kind of fuzzed-out fidelity that more recalls a field recording of a wayward cult than an academically precise studio session. The elements that make up Amaranthine are drawn from various strains of free music at their most direct and primal. It's an ""experimental"" album that hits you first on a gut level. Youngs on Amaranthine can sound shamanistic or mind-erasing or beyond words
column7: any of the terms we usually apply to immersive and free-flowing music that seems out to bypass the intellect for chills up the spine and tingling of the arm hairs.

column1: But the one word you'd never use to describe Youngs
column2: however emotionally expressionistic he can get
column3: is ""primitive."" As usual
column4: a scrupulous intelligence lurks behind Amaranthine's seemingly off-the-dome journey into innerspace. For instance
column5: only an assured musician would attempt the dichotomous mixture Youngs pulls off here
column6: two approaches that might seem at first to be at odds with each other: the mantra-like repetition of drone and the anything-goes invention of free music. Though his music can often have a homemade feeling-- if nothing yet quite as ""séance in the barn"" as Amaranthine-- Youngs is someone who's thought out each aesthetic left-turn as carefully as any arts-grant-endowed composer. He never simply shakes things up for the hell of it
column7: and the new terrain he stakes out almost always turns out to lie within his strengths
column8: however dissimilar it seems from his previous projects on first blush. But even still
column9: it makes sense that Amaranthine is super-limited-edition. His more recent albums-- the skewed pop of 2010's Beyond the Valley of the Ultra Hits and the fractured folk minimalism of 2011's Amplifying Host-- may have been (relatively) more user-friendly. But Amaranthine is among the spookiest and least-tethered sets Youngs has released in years
column10:
not quite for-fans-only but definitely for those who wanna go way out.
