About a year ago
column2: it seemed easy to predict what Dylan Baldi's first great album would probably sound like. After the release of the Turning On
column3: a self-recorded collection of CD-Rs filled with tuneful alt-punk songs wrapped in tinfoil and steel wool that was released by the tiny California imprint Bridgetown Records
column4: Cloud Nothings' self-titled debut on Carpark was an identifiable point on a familiar trajectory. The clarity afforded even by its modest budget made sweet and airy singles like ""Forget You All the Time"" and ""Should Have"" sound revelatory
column5: while more overtly aggro tracks like ""Rock"" and ""Not Important"" felt thin and regressive
column6: unnecessary vestiges of lo-fi provocation that didn't do Baldi many favors.

column1: And then ""No Future/No Past"" arrived as the first single from Attack on Memory. It was brightly produced but tonally dark with a queasy anti-melody-- a confrontational act that suggested that Baldi was going off script. Turns out ""No Future/No Past"" is the least representative track on Attack on Memory
column2: but it opens the album with a necessary slate-clearing. While a full record of fizzy pop-punk would've been welcome
column3: Cloud Nothings are trying for more. As an accidental concept album affirming the enduring power and purity of early emo (as defined by Dischord
column4: Deep Elm
column5: and especially Jade Tree)
column6: Attack on Memory feels above all necessary
column7: a corrective for indie rock making allowances for everything except music that actually rocks.

column1: The overhaul is radical: It's literally a different band from the one that made Cloud Nothings. For one thing
column2: Cloud Nothings is actually a band now rather than Baldi's solo project
column3: retaining the lineup that toured with Fucked Up and likely learned a lot from them. While the freedom and ease of being a bedroom artist has its advantages
column4: you can't make your own Sunny Day Real Estate and Wipers records without a beastly rhythm section. Even beyond the short window of time that passed between Cloud Nothings and Attack on Memory
column5: this is a record that crackles with ""let's get this on tape now"" immediacy-- eight tracks
column6: about half an hour
column7: blunt lyrics
column8: big choruses
column9: lots of screaming. Fussing over these songs would've sapped their urgency.

column1: ""No Future/No Past"" is the first gauntlet Baldi throws down but it's not the most daunting. At more than nine minutes
column2: ""Wasted Days"" is far longer than anything on Cloud Nothings. As a radio edit
column3: it could be something like Cloud Nothings' answer to Foo Fighters' ""Everlong""
column4: a fanged beauty of barbed chords
column5: torrential drum rolls
column6: and impassioned emoting. But as it rolls on
column7: ""Wasted Days"" becomes simultaneously forbidding
column8: disorienting
column9: and psychedelic
column10: something like a black-and-grey kaleidoscope. As the band hurtles to the finish
column11: Baldi repeatedly yells
column12: ""I thought! I would! Be more! Than this!"" in a high-voltage scree as a painful paradox after such an ambitious display of more.

column1: Baldi has always been a hooks guy
column2: and Attack is every bit as catchy as the more rigid and user-friendly Cloud Nothings
column3: and the spaciousness of Steve Albini's recording gives plenty of room for these hooks to careen into each other: ""Stay Useless"" is an anthemic tantrum that shifts rhythm without warning
column4: the bludgeoning riffs of ""No Sentiment"" give way to the plaintive vocals and jittery snare runs on ""Our Plans""
column5: while ""Cut You"" fades out the record on a gracefully arcing chant that's equally vengeful
column6: self-loathing
column7: and hopeful.

column1: There's the temptation to give too much of the credit to Albini
column2: whose open-door policy has attracted an endless number of cred-deficient bands.  Attack on Memory is unmistakably his work-- Baldi's vocals are close-mic'd and raw
column3: the drums are loud as hell
column4: the guitars are economically panned and almost entirely free of effects processing
column5: and there's actual space in between of all of them. But here's Baldi explaining Albini's role to Pitchfork's Jenn Pelly: ""Steve Albini played Scrabble on Facebook almost the entire time [we were recording]. I don't even know if he remembers what our album sounds like."" It was meant as a compliment
column6: but the lesson is clear: A lot of producers would be better off stepping back and doing nothing. Attack on Memory isn't what typically gets classified as a ""headphones record
column7: but that's the best way to first experience how alive it sounds
column8: aggressively leaping out at you with real dynamics. Check the giddy explosions out of the pockets of silence punctuating ""Stay Useless""
column9: the offbeat harmonies and rhythmic stumble that sound like happy accidents on ""Fall In""
column10: or Baldi's serrated bark shredding the uneasy full-band détente following the solo of ""No Sentiment"".

column1: That's where you'll find Attack on Memory's key lyric
column2: ""No nostalgia and no sentiment/ We're over it now and we were over it then
column3: making the title's implications clear: If you enjoy this as a work of art
column4: there's an invitation to adopt it as cultural critique. Baldi shares stages and a label with Toro Y Moi and joked about ""Forget You All the Time"" being ""our most chillwave song"" at a Los Angeles show
column5: so the title is more of a call to be heard in the current climate rather than a total negation of it. But the last Fugazi album came out when Baldi was 10
column6: and it's easy to see ""memory"" as a stand-in for indie's stylistic pervasiveness: de-emphasis of guitars and live performance
column7: passivity over aggression
column8: past over presence
column9: singing like you don't care if you get understood or even heard. That just doesn't cut it for a lot of people his age who wonder if they'll ever witness ""The Argument""'s kind of life-affirming vitality firsthand.

column1: There's a fundamental irony in how a record titled Attack on Memory is such a sonic throwback
column2: while Baldi's lyrics obsess over arrested development and missed opportunities. But like the best of indie's recent guitar bands that dare to skew retro-- Yuck
column3: the Men
column4: WU LYF
column5: to name a few-- Attack on Memory is too visceral to feel like escapism
column6: too vital to feel like cheap revival. Not when this sound's death was the wrongful diagnosis of trendwatchers: Those of us who grew up on Drive Like Jehu
column7: Braid
column8: and Jawbreaker can listen to Attack on Memory and sense their artistic legacy is in good hands
column9:
but there will inevitably be teenagers for whom Attack on Memory stands to be that kind of record to call their own. And hopefully we'll all meet up in the mosh pit.

column10: DirteeTV.com is designed more as a showcase for Dizzee's label/crew Dirtee Stank than a chance for Rascal to flex on his lonesome. But when he hits the track
column11: Dizzee's rapping with an all-or-nothing ferocity that makes Boy in Da Corner sound like the kid he was. And the beats are often take-no-prisoners massive in a way that invites comparisons to Lex Luger

column5: but he's at his best in the tape's early stretch

Likewise he uses that old but still effective grime trick of taking a portentous bit of classical music and looping it to an extreme

column9: especially on ""Wavestation""

column11: cooking up something more like an arcade game rewrite of Dead Prez's ""Hip-Hop"" b-line.

column1: Like most of its American cousins

column11:
especially your own.

Nada Surf have managed a couple of feats in their two-decade-long career that might make any indie rock band envious: They broke out with a ubiquitous (if novelty) hit on MTV and alt-rock radio at a time when those were still the only channels by which to do so and
column4: perhaps more importantly
column5: they quietly outlived that popularity to score a second act as sweetly unassuming indie rock underdogs.

column1: On 2002's Barsuk release Let Go
column2: Nada Surf re-emerged as the little brother to label-mates Death Cab For Cutie-- the sophomoric 1990s angst swapped out for more deliberate melodies and softer arrangements both timely
column3: as that brand of indie rock was beginning to take over
column4: and timeless. A decade later
column5: soft-touch ""indie adult contemporary"" has become 2011's agreed-upon national wallpaper
column6: and Nada Surf are attempting to make some noise.

column1: Noting that they've ""always played faster and a little harder live

column6: always landing on that initial ""I.""

column1: The album is upbeat throughout
column2: especially by Nada Surf standards

Multiple songs dwell on feelings of disillusionment and lost youth. ""When I Was Young"" recounts the banal minutes of a day over willowy finger picking before the song swells and Caws wonders
column4: ""When I was young... what was that world I was dreaming of?"" ""Let the Fight Do the Fighting"" cautions
column5: ""You're gonna wish that you were young again/ You're gonna wish that it was fun/ You're gonna wanna have someone again."" Most troublesome
column6: though
column7: might be ""Teenage Dreams""
column8: the nth iteration of that song title in recent memory
column9: whose chorus
column10: ""It's never too late for teenage dreams
column11: comes dangerously close to the realm of ""30 Rock"" parody.

column1: These are larger existential longings than pining for another cross-over hit
column2: of course
column3: but they feed into an idea of the band as past its prime-- which is strange
column4: since Nada Surf seem so comfortable coasting. Caws' voice is still light and feathery
column5: the band members are all nimble enough musicians
column6: and songs such as ""Waiting for Something"" touch the same dull sweet spot that's secretly tickled by
column7: say
column8: the Gin Blossoms' radio hits. But for all its adeptness of craft and attempts at revitalization
column9: The Stars Are Indifferent to Astronomy still feels like an album with precious little at stake. The songs are fine but largely feckless
column10: and what could be an animating contrast between glum lyrics and upbeat music is too often hobbled by clunkers both generic (""I am lost in my mind when you go to sleep"") and specific (something about tarot cards). At a moment when indie rock could probably use a little kick in the ass
column11: Nada Surf seem to have the right instincts
column12: just maybe not the spleen to pull them off. Harder and faster isn't necessarily a young man's game
column13:
but it isn't really Nada Surf's either.

It might say something about the way things accelerate these days that it already feels like Gangrene have been around for ages. But tracing their lineage back through last year's Roc Marciano collaboration Greneberg and 2010's Gutter Water brings up a still-recent origin point in the Alchemist's 2009 all-star blowout
column2: Chemical Warfare. The precedent for the collaboration between Alchemist and fellow producer-slash-MC Oh No was strongly established on cuts like ""Acts of Violence"" and ""Under Siege""
column3: a couple of cartoonishly sinister tracks that pushed indie/street crossover rawness into a no-fucks-given irreverence about how raw it actually was. If you want a quick-and-dirty idea of what kind of flag they planted
column4: take into account that their equivalent of a funny-wigs ""Sabotage"" video was footage of them doing violent slapstick spliced into newscast tapes of the Rodney King riots.

column1: So why does it feel like they've been around longer? Besides the fact that Alchemist and Oh No are veteran presences on their own-- the ""We Gonna Make It"" producer meets the ""Supermagic"" producer would be a fascinating-enough odd-couple pitch-- there's been a lot of conceptual forward momentum at work in their last two-and-a-half years. If Gutter Water dragged the grimier tendencies of underground hip-hop through a dysentery-infected toilet party and Greneberg was Marcberg's weirdly invigorating hangover
column2: then Vodka & Ayahuasca is a stab at drunk-psych nightmarishness that runs on slasher-flick suspense. Throw in a bit of weirdo grossout comedy-- the intro track has one of the nastiest clips of someone puking I've ever heard on record-- and you've got a good indication of a couple of artists trying to outdo themselves in the outrageousness department.

column1: How much they succeed rests on how well these two fuse their production styles
column2: and Alchemist's knack with stoner-friendly
column3: vaguely arena-rockish loops
column4: recently exhibited at its best on Curren$y's Covert Coup

column6: ""Dark Shades""
column7: and ""Drink Up""
column8: and with their churning riffs draining the cathartic payoff out of their old acid-rock contexts
column9: what's left is a scraping
column10: growling squall. Pianos and synthesizers are dragged shuddering out from the basement and worked into nerve-twisting loops
column11: giving ""Top Instructors"" and ""The Groove"" a forceful tension. Basslines and breaks stay heavy and crisp
column12: even through the most weeded-out doom-tempo trudges
column13: while ""Flame Throwers"" and ""Odds Cracked"" in particular have enough bounce in them to keep a front-to-back listen from getting bogged down in murk.

column1: That atmosphere helps hold up Vodka & Ayahuasca's sense of anarchic
column2: altered-state unease when the lyrics don't quite cut it
column3: though the tolerable-at-worst punchlines and metaphors are easier to stomach the less dead-serious you take them. Alchemist's badgering flow is self-assured and self-aware enough to give even his clunkiest lines an ""I meant to do that"" affability
column4: turning his Marmaduke namedrops and organ-trafficking threats from corny to actually-kinda-funny. (It helps that when he's on
column5: he's <i>on
column6: his paint-huffer odyssey on ""Auralac Bags"" in particular.) Oh No's technique is standard-issue Left Coast abstraction
column7: prone to its share of attention-getting moments for internal-rhyme wonks
column8: and when he takes the reins there's some tightly-wound phraseology to dissect.

column1: But the most memorable lines either come from guest spots-- Kool G Rap and Roc Marciano flat-out repossess ""Gladiator Music"" and ""Drink Up"" respectively-- or the found-sound clips about hallucinogen freakouts and belligerent arrestees that provide the most unhinged moments. No matter-- if Vodka & Ayahuasca is worth listening to
column2:
it's not an easy equation of lyrics versus beats. What's crucial is that it feels like an album-length distillation of that moment in a horror movie where the suddenness of a character's death is overtaken by how exaggeratedly gruesome the aftermath is.

Hubble is the guitar-centric solo project of N.Y. native Ben Greenberg
column2: perhaps best known for his gymnastic fretwork in the avant-jazz collective Zs. Like that project
column3: the 26-year-old multi-instrumentalist could be described as DIY Brooklyn's answer to 1970s Manhattan crossover composers like Glenn Branca and Rhys Chatham
column4: artists who merged the endless repetitions of minimalism with the amplitude and instrumentation of punk. Greenberg is a trained jazz guitarist who's been gigging around the city in rock bands of all stripes since he was in middle school. He was a founding member of the defunct New York art-punk trio Pygmy Shrews
column5: and was recently recruited to play with local rock iconoclasts the Men
column6: whose Leave Home LP he engineered.

column1: Hubble Drums finds Greenberg channeling his affinity for high-intensity marathon jams into an elemental formula: a guitar
column2: a chain of delay pedals
column3: and a handful of melodic progressions
column4: most of them barely a second long. In the live setting
column5: Hubble's music can feel like a collision between Robert Fripp guitar noodling and minimalist experiments in phasing. As he draws each melodic fragment out into a sprawling
column6: 10-to-20-minute epic
column7: Hubble also becomes the spectacle of Greenberg struggling against himself
column8: pushing up against the limits of his own psychic and physical endurance.

column1: In the context of the contemporary synth revival
column2: the result will hold particular appeal for fans of Emeralds
column3: early Oneohtrix Point Never
column4: Keith Fullerton Whitman
column5: and other stargazing
column6: kosmische-inspired musicians in the practice of mining the meditative potential of the endless arpeggiation. The difference between them being that Hubble's music is partly a showcase of Greenberg's technical virtuosity
column7: the intensity of which makes it exausting for him to perform. Either through conscious manipulation or human error
column8: Greenberg seems to exhaust every possible micro-variation of each of the phrases he attacks. The catch is that none of the the melodies ever resolve themselves
column9: creating a state of suspension that can feel either like euphoria or anxiety
column10: escapism or entrapment
column11: without us even noticing the change. (Note that
column12: though I wasn't involved in its selection
column13: a track by Greenberg appears on a compilation I'm organizing with a friend.)

column1: Where Hubble Drums really inspires
column2: however
column3: is when Greenberg introduces a bit more textural play
column4: cranking the distortion on 20-minute closer ""Glass Napkin"" just enough to evoke a scorched Grateful Dead jam or a slightly over-indulgent Hendrix solo. It's uncomfortable and pleasingly familiar at the same time
column5: and it makes minimalism à la Terry Riley sound eerily compatible with what is probably the most maximalist rock-n-roll trick in the bag: shredding. Greenberg's recent collaboration with Tiffany Borders from the Space Telescope Science Institute and video artist Sheena Callage
column6: which sets ""Hubble's Hubble"" to imaging of actual Hubble telescope data
column7: gives a good visual metaphor for our listening experience
column8: both here and elsewhere on this beautifully troubling debut: an endless back-and-forth between details and expanses
column9: wide angles and extreme close-ups
column10:
anxiety and awe.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17339/homepage_large.99a53c43.jpg|Something|10351.0|Chairlift|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia'
Chairlift's second full-length
column2: Something
column3: is a major creative leap
column4: but on a superficial level
column5: it's not that different from their debut. They're still mining uncool and untapped corners of 1980s pop for inspiration
column6: and singer Caroline Polachek has doubled down on a vocal style that alternates between joyfully expressive and charmingly deadpan. But the melodies are bolder
column7: the arrangements have more snap and sparkle
column8: and Polachek has thankfully moved beyond the first album's overly cerebral lyrics to embrace emotionally potent lines that explore the subtler dynamics of romantic relationships and the evolution of character.

column1: Of course
column2: Chairlift aren't exactly the same group that broke into the outskirts of the mainstream when their 2008 hit ""Bruises"" found its way into an Apple ad. Founding member Aaron Pfenning split with the group after his romantic relationship with Polachek ended. (He now has an atmospheric disco project called Rewards.) Now a duo
column3: Polachek and multi-instrumentalist Patrick Wimberly have a different chemistry. Wimberly
column4: a producer on several Das Racist tracks
column5: excels at composing slick music that retains force and physicality
column6: which suits Polachek's voice and melodies. As a result
column7: Something is cleaner and more elegant
column8: buffing their crisp electronic pop to an immaculate sheen.

column1: Polachek's presence fades when the music gets too inert
column2: but Chairlift turn that potential liability into a strength on two of Something's most beautiful tracks: On ""Frigid Spring"" and ""Turning""
column3: she pushes her voice to a breathy
column4: ethereal extreme. More often
column5: though
column6: her voice is lucid and assertive. She's excellent with subtle phrasing
column7: selling wry lyrics without getting too smirky
column8: and conveying infatuation without sounding overly elated. She's especially fond of Robert Smith-like exclamations
column9: sometimes ending a key line with excited verbal punctuation. Her voice is technically proficient-- she sometimes recalls Fleetwood Mac's Christine McVie-- but her main strength lies in how clearly her personality comes across in these songs. Whether she's giving voice to a maniac in ""Sidewalk Safari"" or gushing with love in ""I Belong in Your Arms""
column10: Polachek sounds totally comfortable and in control.

column1: Though it's obvious that Polachek is often singing from the vantage point of characters (we'd obviously have heard about it if she actually ran someone down in her car)
column2: the emphasis on emotion and relationships is key to Something's success. It's notable that their debut's best song
column3: ""Bruises""
column4: was a straight-up love song
column5: while the clunkiest tracks belabored conceits that felt self-consciously imposed on the music. The most resonant lines on Something are disarmingly direct: ""If I gave you what you're asking for
column6: you know you wouldn't want it anymore
column7: ""Does my love only count if it's proved?
column8: ""My heart is beating fast and I wish that I knew why."" Polachek still indulges in high concept
column9: but with more grace and nuance
column10: as on ""Amanaemonesia""
column11: where she meditates on the cultural and psychological power of healing rituals. She's even more successful on ""Guilty as Charged""
column12: in which her verses lay out an elaborate trial metaphor that contrasts nicely with her cutting to the core of her character's emotional dilemma on the chorus.

column1: The song on Something that gets me in the gut is ""I Belong in Your Arms""
column2: a declaration of uncomplicated affection that makes the most of the band's embrace of faster tempos and open-hearted lyrics. Chairlift couldn't have pulled off a track like this back when they made pop music with scare quotes
column3: footnotes
column4: and caveats. But now that they've backed away from those defense mechanisms
column5: they've allowed themselves to go all the way in expressing a powerful sentiment. There are many songs out there that echo the tone and message of ""I Belong in Your Arms""
column6: but this one is no less joyous or affecting for lacking a unique concept. In cutting away their baggage and hang-ups
column7: Chairlift have opened themselves up to writing truly great pop.

For a producer who's been doing exciting things in bass music over the past year
column4: Travis Stewart's musical origins are barely traceable to the genre. Never mind that the beginnings of his catalog as Machinedrum predate the genre's ongoing cultural flashpoint by a decade-- until his recent move to Berlin
column5: the geographical space between him and the largely UK-based sound was vast. Ideologically
column6: however
column7: Stewart's attraction to bass music makes perfect sense. Over the past decade
column8: he's subtly shifted from misty downtempo to Prefuse 73-reminiscent glitch-hop to the sort of Dilla-fied beat ooze that refuses to go out of style. His 2010 release with the Glasgow label LuckyMe was titled Many Faces
column9: and the title seemed apt. As a solo artist
column10: Stewart doesn't like to stay in one place long.

column1: As Andrew Gaerig put it in his review of Stewart's fantastic debut LP with fellow producer Praveen Sharma (aka Braille) as Sepalcure
column2: ""bass producers tend to treat innovation like daily prayer."" At one time
column3: it would have been difficult to call Stewart as an innovator
column4: but then he released last year's Room(s) on the similarly hard-to-pin-down label Planet Mu. It was a heady
column5: sensual trip through the smeared-vocal technique that most first encountered on Burial's 2007 breakthrough Untrue
column6: incorporating the repetitive rhythmic kicks of footwork and coating it in atmosphere. The whole thing was an overwhelming swarm of sound
column7: more in line with the maximalist trends in electronic music discussed in Simon Reynolds' recent ""Maximal Nation"" piece. Compared to the marbled elegance of Sepalcure
column8: Room(s) is garish and cheeky
column9: but you can't deny the album's utter audaciousness.

column1: Relative to his work last year
column2: Stewart's new EP on LuckyMe
column3: SXLND
column4: is a minor effort. Stylistically
column5: the five songs on SXLND lie somewhere between Stewart's work on Room(s) and Sepalcure
column6: with slight variations-- the former's clipped strangulations are backed by a spare
column7: funky gallop on the title track
column8: while ""No Respect"" and closer ""DDD"" take the latter's smooth alleyway hymns out to the club
column9: courtesy of a steady 4/4 thump. Instead of pushing things forward
column10: he's making lateral moves.

column1: The most notable thing about SXLND is the fact that its title track's serves as the backbone for rapper Azealia Banks' latest single
column2: ""NEEDSUMLUV"". Heard here without her contribution
column3: it indeed sounds like a backing track. And that's the main issue with SXLND as a whole: There aren't enough standalong tracks
column4: just a collection of tunes that would sound great stuck in the middle of a solid DJ set (see
column5: for instance
column6: Stewart's recent FADER mix
column7: where the EP's material hit much harder than when isolated here). So this is one for committed fans
column8:
those who've been following along with Stewart's recent renaissance and trying to guess what his next move will be.

This is the fourth Alog record I've reviewed here in the last seven years
column4: and with each I have to assume that you're reading about them for the first time. Dag-Are Haugan and Espen Sommer Eide are electro-acoustic experimenters from Norway
column5: and they've yet to step out from the dimly lit corners of the contemporary music avant-garde: They've never ""broken through
column6: and at this point I doubt they ever will. Their music is not inaccessible
column7: but it does play with the idea of what music itself can be
column8: and they tend to avoid emotional manipulation. They present sound that is texturally rich and organized in an interesting way
column9: but they're not telling you to feel happy or sad when you listen to it. All of which is to say that they are way down the list of abstract sound-makers likely to appeal to people who have a limited amount of space in their daily listening for abstract sound.

column1: This is understandable
column2: but it's also a shame
column3: because Alog make wonderful music that sounds only better with time. Unemployed
column4: their most recent album for Rune Grammofon
column5: is very much a continuation of the arc of their previous records
column6: meaning that it doesn't really sound like any of them. Every Alog record-- and indeed every track-- carves out its own space
column7: and Haugan and Eide seem either incapable of or uninterested in repeating themselves. But while they don't have an overriding sonic signature
column8: they do have some broad qualities that drive their approach to music. Their music is whimsical
column9: frightening
column10: sentimental
column11: and atmospheric
column12: often at the same time. On this album
column13: they use location-based instrumental recordings
column14: found sound
column15: field recordings made on tour
column16: and mix it all with studio work that blends samples and live instruments. These elements and approaches are fused together in such a way that you never really know which sound came from where. The result is music that feels open and free
column17: which
column18: for me
column19: serves as a welcome reminder of how much my typical response to music is informed by idiom.

column1: In general
column2: there are two ideas that inform Alog's music. One the one hand you have playfulness. In the manner of
column3: say
column4: the Residents
column5: Alog's music has a strong sense of ""Let's try this and see what happens."" Tracks like ""Apeland""
column6: which seems to be a recording of a gorgeous organ of some kind
column7: but mic'd in such a way that the action on the keys produces both warm drones and a percussive tapping
column8: feels like the product of setting up some microphones in a room and having fun with sound. ""Baklandet"" seems like a folk song of some kind
column9: sung by a high voice that could be female
column10: but the acoustic instruments are tweaked and messed with slightly
column11: giving the pretty tune a destabilizing warble. ""Et Besok""
column12: a simple exercise in the emotional possibilities of vocal processing
column13: takes a voice and does strange things to it
column14: balling it up in effects and then spreading it back out so it assumes a new shape.

column1: When Alog aren't being playful
column2: they're exploring the idea of music as ritual. In some cases
column3: this comes out in their ear for layered and immersive drones that strike a balance between the electronic and the organic. Alog are good at making tracks that you can turn up and zone out to
column4: tracks that feel like rooms to explore. And then sometimes they turn up the heat. The 17-minute ""Last Day at the Assembly Line""
column5: which serves as the centerpiece of the record
column6: is an exercise is tension and catharsis. It mixes caveman drum pounding
column7: rapidly bowed strings that sound like gears grinding away in a machine
column8: and
column9: eventually
column10: voices that chant and coo but favor sound over language. It's a terrifically powerful track that manages to evoke both stasis and decay
column11: and it's continually either building up or falling apart. It definitely brings to mind krautrock
column12: like a super-stripped-down version of the cultish mantras of Amon Düül's Psychedelic Underground
column13: but pulling out a term like ""krautrock"" doesn't quite make sense. Alog get me thinking about what music is and how it works on an almost molecular level
column14:
so familiar ""sounds like"" references feel beside the point. Their music is enjoyable for how it gets me thinking in addition to how it makes me feel. It returns me to that state of hearing something new and alien for the first time and wanting to know more.

"|16193.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16193-unemployed/|7.9|Mark Richardson

It's funny now
column2: knowing what we know about Lil B
column3: to go back and watch the video for the Pack's 2006 track ""Vans""
column4: which features a then-17-year-old Based God tentatively slurring a perfectly amateurish verse about the importance of wearing skate shoes. Lil B is not completely a different person now-- he's retained a good amount of the intense goofiness present in both ""Vans"" and its video-- but he's obviously mutated into a much different and more singular artist since his days with the Pack. The song's producer
column5: Young L (he also raps the third verse)
column6: has also grown into his own since ""Vans"". But where Lil B's turned into a bizarre rap savant
column7: L has stuck to the slaps of hyphy that were the song's backbone
column8: gravitating toward construction and sounds that are less pop and more outwardly showy
column9: with rapping that often sounds like it's merely cruising along for the ride.

column1: This has presented a bit of a problem at times for Young L
column2: who
column3: across various mixtapes in the past few years
column4: has hit on some great tracks but generally had trouble matching the quality of his rapping to the quality of his producing. With Praktica
column5: his most recent tape
column6: he comes as close as ever to accomplishing that
column7: and the result is a record that feels for the first time like he's found the formula for making consistently good solo songs. His rapping is still more about charisma
column8: charm
column9: and knowing how to ride his own beats than about lyrics
column10: and the one song here that's tagged as a freestyle is indistinguishable from everything else on the tape. His rapping is both dumb and dumb
column11: and it's a style that works for him here because there's a youthful brashness and confidence in his delivery
column12: something that allows L to sell his rapping without coming off as trying too hard.

column1: Of course
column2: it doesn't hurt that the beats are uniformly great. L's production has always been spare
column3: heavy on keyboard beeps
column4: and equally reliant on bass and open space. On Praktica he cannibalizes sounds from Mario and Pac-Man in a way that is inspired and novel instead of gimmicky. At a crucially digestible nine tracks
column5: there is no overextension of the idea
column6: and the sounds of classic video games are so harmonious with the production style Young L's cultivated that you wouldn't even bat an eye if the samples he pulls weren't so immediately identifiable. As befits an internet-savvy artist who had a hit song in his teens and also owns his own clothing line
column7: L has always seemed filled to the brim with ideas
column8: and the tricks he pulls on songs like ""Arcade Pussy"" and ""Super Nintendo"" are some of his best yet.

column1: There is still something very raw about Praktica
column2: and L in general
column3: that will turn some people off
column4: and you almost have to be willing to approach his verses as if they're choruses-- where small phrases and snatches of melody will embed themselves in your head-- to fully appreciate his rapping. But there is something undeniably kinetic about this cocky
column5: self-assured artist honing his sound and skill level that helps make up for much of the tape's shortcomings. There may be a disappointing 20-track tape on the way
column6: but if L continues in this direction
column7:
we may bizarrely look back on ""Vans"" as the breeding ground for a few of the most distinctive young voices in West Coast hip-hop.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17340/homepage_large.cover.jpg|Back on Time|3339.0|Plug|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2012-01-20 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:21.311007|"

The vaults of electronic mischief spun from the fingertips of Cornish musician Luke Vibert are apparently well-stocked. Like his fellow West Country dweller Aphex Twin
column2: Vibert appears to have a dearth of unreleased material yet to see the light of day. These days most musicians and music fans have some form of useless archive-- the simultaneous rise of the mp3 and computer-based sequencing software guaranteed that a surfeit of recorded music would lay dormant on hard drives across the globe. Back when Vibert was starting out
column3: at some point in the early 1990s
column4: he seems to have been a digital junk soothsayer
column5: amassing a great body of work while the rest of us were tooling away on Prodigy message boards and getting to grips with AOL for DOS. Unlike the rest of ours
column6: his binary debris actually seems to have some value.

column2: Vibert released a series of EPs under the name Plug
column3: which served as a catchall moniker to present his typically twisted take on drum'n'bass. An album
column4: Drum 'n' Bass for Papa
column5: followed a year later
column6: around the time he was being courted by major labels. Trent Reznor's Nothing Records released Drum 'n' Bass for Papa in the U.S.
column7: handily packaging it with the prior EPs. As the popularity of the genre waned
column8: Vibert wisely bailed on Plug
column9: instead choosing one of his many other aliases to work under. But he couldn't shake what once seemed like a one-off fudging of popular genre tropes. In 2006
column10: an EP titled Here It Comes emerged
column11: comprising four unreleased Plug tracks. Now we've got another clearing of the vaults
column12: this time in the shape of a full-length LP comprised of Plug recordings Vibert made from 1995-1998.

column1: The original Plug records skirted under the radar of most serious drum'n'bass heads. It lacked the pile-driving ferocity of most Metalheadz releases and/or the jazz-tinged seriousness of Good Looking's output. There were other shades of drum'n'bass
column2: of course
column3: but very few of them touched on humor
column4: which remains a common touchstone for many of Vibert's projects. It's unlikely he was looking to hold down a residency at the Blue Note in pre-hip Hoxton (ironically
column5: the same venue where his current label
column6: Ninja Tune
column7: hosted their legendary Stealth nights). Instead
column8: he always seemed happiest working in his own sphere
column9: which
column10: for Plug
column11: meant blurring the lines between the bloodless white-knuckle ride of drum'n'bass and the easy listening boom that was gathering pace around the mid 1990s.

column1: Back on Time is barely separable from Drum 'n' Bass for Papa; it's essentially more of the same. Vibert's breakbeats still writhe and skitter
column2: methodically contorted around his eccentric choice of samples. On ""A Quick Plug for a New Slot""
column3: a lumbering beat slugs lethargically into the mix before a pinging sitar line forces everything to lurch into a sprightlier clip. The excellently titled ""Come on My Skeleton"" feels like it's straining under the weight of its own excesses
column4: with fat slabs of industrialized sound vying with twists of an opera singer climbing up into her higher range. The latter ends with Vibert pulling a rabbit out of the hat in the form of a straight-laced man claiming
column5: ""you might also become aware of your anus or genitalia."" Even on this older material he's an expert at diffusing tension in that way
column6: always ready with a banana peel to slip under the mix in case things are getting a little too serious.

column1: That pranksterish approach is the point where most people either get on or off board with Vibert. On Back on Time
column2: it works to his advantage
column3: largely thanks to his ability to balance out his humorous inclinations with an unnerving ability to sequence it all over an impressively brutal infrastructure. On ""Back on Time"" he's able to filter John Barry-esque string parts through indecipherable vocal bellowing and a beat that floods the mix with its tinny timbre. Even the relatively subdued ""Mind Bending"" ends up stacked high with junk
column4: with Speak & Spell-style speech synthesis vying for space with jerky analog loops and a wild-eyed raver shouting
column5: ""fucking excellent acid house."" That form of maximal japery foreshadows the work of Rustie and James Ferraro
column6: partially explaining why this material sounds fresh again. It's a kitchen sink-like flood of sound
column7: always on the verge of resembling a gigantic curveball being forced down your throat
column8:
but with Vibert pulling back from the humor brink at all the right moments.

Matthew Dear's transformation
column3: from bedroom techno polymath to live-band leader
column4: occurred over such a long
column5: seamless stretch that it's easy to take for granted just how surprising (and rewarding) it's been. In 2003
column6: Dear's wonky vocal anthem
column7: ""Dog Days""
column8: could have been taken as a micro-house producer's novelty
column9: a cheeky attempt at merging sappy indie pop with alien sound design. But while he kept on recording ""straight"" techno in a bewildering array of styles
column10: Dear's records under his own name continued shucking dance music's rules
column11: rhythmic and otherwise.  Techno's precision kept his Afrobeat and art-funk fixations from devolving into jam-band aimlessness. And lessons learned from those genres made his machine textures appealingly strange
column12: rather than preset bland. The four song Headcage EP both picks up where Dear's last record left off and shakes its influence enough to suggest where he might be headed next.

column1: Or maybe not. Like any good techno producer
column2: Dear appreciates the EP as an artform in itself
column3: rather than a way to rush out a set of not-too-dissimilar songs to keep fans happy between albums. That said
column4: it might also be the least ""techno"" material Dear's recorded. Two of the songs verge on a kind of singer-songwriter's ambient
column5: floating by with almost no backing at all. A third sounds like a sensitive rocker got hold of a Soulja Boy track and decided to make the best of it
column6: with winning results. This is Dear as laid-back charmer
column7: rather than forbidding electro architect. Compared to the dark (but not bleak) journey of 2010's Black City
column8: where Dear transposed the ""nighttime drive"" claustrophobia of old-school techno to a set of intricate almost-rock jams
column9: Headcage shakes off the late-night jitters for a sound so airy it threatens to evaporate into murmurs and empty space.

column1: Black City's density suggested that Dear was drawing aesthetic energy from what most of us would just suffer as the stress of living in a tightly packed urban environment. Here he seems to be yearning for the room to chill. The dark electro of Headcage's title cut
column2: vaguely reminiscent of various early-1980s British synth-pop bands without quite sounding like anyone specific
column3: might inititally trick you into thinking the EP will be the afterparty to Black City's bash. But Dear relaxes into something more comfortable and blissful as Headcage plays out
column4: suggesting two possible routes for his music in the future. ""In the Middle (I Met You There)"" is one of the most surprising cuts Dear's put his name to since ""Dog Days""
column5: a love song crooned (by the Drums' Jonny Pierce) over a bright hip-hop loop
column6: not too dissimilar from the 8-bit fizz being peddled by producers like Clams Casino
column7: that he fleshes out with shifting layers of keyboard buzz. It's as delightful-- chillwave with actual hooks and a sound rich enough to swim in instead of just wash over you-- as it is unexpected.

column1: But ""Street Song"" and ""Around a Fountain"" do away with anything as coarse as drums
column2: unless a flicker of static repurposed as a rhythm counts

The world of UK guitar music has changed in the decade since Snow Patrol signed their first major-label contract. A passing glance at the state of British mainstream radio neatly illustrates how it's shifted for bands of their ilk: When Snow Patrol inked a deal with Polydor's Fiction imprint in 2002
column3: Steve Lamacq still lorded over evenings on Radio 1. His ""Evening Session"" show was where I first taped songs by bands like Idlewild
column4: Snow Patrol
column5: and Seafood.

column1: Tune in tonight between 7 p.m. and 9 p.m.
column2: and you're more likely to catch Guetta or Skrillex than an ""indie"" pop band. It's pretty much the same during the day
column3: when hyperactive bass music and loud
column4: super-compressed pop music hold court. You might think bands like Coldplay
column5: Snow Patrol
column6: and Elbow would be beyond trying to square up to that world
column7: but Coldplay ushered in some subtle shades of R&B production on last year's Mylo Xyloto
column8: and on Fallen Empires Snow Patrol pick at similar threads with electronic touches of their own.

column1: That change in direction is evident on opener ""I'll Never Let Go"" as arpeggiated synth notes open and then carry the entire song. The build from there is slow-- growing as distorted guitars throw weight into the chorus-- but the song reaches ridiculous proportions when folk-pop singer Lissie provides gospel singing toward the finale (warning: she pops up on an additional three songs). You get the sense they're shooting for something epic
column2: something that would sound just as big as the pop bangers on radio
column3: but the results are goofy.

column1: Electronics appear heavily on another four songs
column2: enough for the band to describe the album as a showcase for their ""secret love of Techno."" Listening to those songs
column3: it seems less the product of five guys who secretly listen to Michael Mayer backstage before playing to 10
column4: 000 people
column5: and more like somebody who might enjoy the techno preset demo on a Yamaha keyboard.

column1: They sound more at ease in the second half of the record
column2: returning to the territory of big ballads and acoustic guitars. That portion of the album's ushered in by ""Berlin""
column3: a charming instrumental that sounds more like Sufjan Stevens or Jónsi (Owen Pallett and Nico Muhly provided arrangements here and elsewhere). Less edgy
column4: sure
column5: but signifiers like that are a much better fit for a band that has always had a knack for big arrangements.

column1: Songs like ""Lifening"" and ""New York"" bludgeon with sentiment
column2: but one of these per record could probably keep Snow Patrol in business for life on rom-com movie scores alone. They're the exact kind of home runs you get the feeling Snow Patrol could hit in their sleep. Which makes you wonder if
column3: in the future
column4: instead of toying with awkward electronics they might be better served sticking to what they already do pretty effectively. I mean
column5:
nobody's going to have Skrillex as the first dance at their wedding.

When people say the Kinks are one of their favorite bands
column2: they likely have a very specific Kinks in mind. And no
column3: it is almost certainly not any version of the band that existed after 1970
column4: though there were quite a few of them. There are good songs sprinkled through the latter-Kinks discography
column5: sometimes even in generous clusters
column6: but the band almost everyone means when they say ""The Kinks"" is really ""The Kinks in the 1960s."" Sanctuary's new Kinks in Mono box collects the entirety of the band's 60s output
column7: in mono
column8: as the title implies
column9: and in that respect
column10: it's a can't-miss collector's item.

column1: The music from this period of the band is unimpeachable
column2: so really the question that surrounds a release like this is: Who needs it? If you're in any way prone to dropping $150 on a Kinks boxed set
column3: there is a pretty good chance you already own all this music
column4: and if you bought the individual album reissues Sanctuary released in 2011
column5: you already have the albums in mono
column6: because those reissues included both stereo and mono versions on separate discs (except for The Kink Kontroversy
column7: which has only ever been available in mono). To be fair
column8: it's a well-designed package clearly created with a lot of love
column9: and it does augment the band's first seven albums with three discs of mostly essential EP and non-album 45 tracks
column10: but this
column11: too
column12: does little to distinguish it from those earlier releases
column13: which were generously appointed with bonus material.

column1: There is a reason that the Kinks' catalog is so constantly revisited
column2: of course-- its quality and enduring appeal pretty much ensure that record labels will be finding new ways to carve up the band's legacy and repackage it as long as people are willing to buy it in some sort of physical form. They established themselves early with their energy and their shredded-amp heaviness. Their albums
column3: EPs
column4: and singles from 1964 and 1965 are the most uneven included here
column5: but the good stuff is really
column6: really good. The punky
column7: distorted guitars on ""You Really Got Me""
column8: ""All Day and All of the Night""
column9: and ""I Need You"" are still thrilling
column10: and there are a lot of relative obscurities worth listening back to
column11: from the sharp Merseybeat of ""You Still Want Me"" to Dave Davies' slow and yearning ""I Am Free"".

column1: The thing about listening to all of this band's 60s output at once is that it shows a very clearly and incremental progression from that material to the establishment of the band's signature identity as the British rock scene's foremost appreciators of English life. While almost every other songwriter working in a rock band at the time was talking about altered states or sticking it to squares
column2: Ray Davies developed a vocabulary of traditional English life
column3: and even mocked Carnaby Street fashion on ""Dedicated Follower of Fashion"". The Kinks were culture without the ""counter"" prefix
column4: a rock band that anomalously acknowledged the dignity in the middle-aged woman who went out and bought a hat like the one Princess Marina wore
column5: the one that adopted the mannerisms of music hall without pastiche or irony
column6: the one that sang about tea and gooseberry tarts and favoring neighborhood life over new patterns of development.

column1: The band's 60s output culminated in Arthur (Or the Decline and Fall of the British Empire)
column2: a sweeping panorama of a post-war Britain that had lost its long-cherished identity
column3: a portrait of a family about to be separated by a hemisphere's worth of ocean as the son and his wife move to Australia
column4: leaving behind the title character to keep calm and carry on. I love psychedelia and teenage rebellion
column5: but I get the sense that a whole lot more people lived in the England Ray Davies wrote about than in the one everyone else sang about. We're trained to think of things like Antonioni's Blow-Up as the definitive portraits of London in the 60s
column6: but that's just part of the story. Arthur standing on the dock is just as big a part
column7: if not bigger.

column1: You'd be hard-pressed to find a more sensitive extended document of this England than you can hear on this set. Whether you need to unload your wallet for it is another story. If you like the 60s Kinks but don't own any of their music and want to
column2: well
column3: here you go. You can't go wrong
column4: and they're a band that presents well in mono. There's little in the way of audio experimentation on their records
column5: and even their densest recordings
column6: especially on Arthur
column7: don't need the added depth of a stereo picture to succeed brilliantly (the mono versions are uniformly better in the car
column8: for instance). So yes
column9: the music's as brilliant as it ever was
column10: and it's all here
column11:
well-housed. The only question is whether that's enough.

The catchall criticism for noise as a form of music is that
column3: because it often seems so unordered and illogical
column4: it must be simple and pedestrian. Play some for a cynic
column5: and short of outright disapproval
column6: you'll probably be greeted with a categorical response: ""I could do that
column7: too."" There are a handful of mostly irrefutable ways to come back at that idea-- ""Well
column8: you didn't
column9: for instance
column10: or
column11: ""OK
column12: tell me how."" But don't be so snappy
column13: not yet: Noise music
column14: at least for me
column15: should retain some element of mystery
column16: some air of unknowing; after all
column17: if it's an intentional obliteration of the structures and sounds you've known from the first time you heard ""Electric Company"" or ""Sesame Street""
column18: it should force you to ask the most basic questions of what it is
column19: how it is made
column20: and why it is made. And in the quest for those illusory answers
column21: the best noise
column23: and sound experimentation should either pull you in or blow you away
column24: reaffirming that the thing itself is more provocative than the motions behind it.

column1: This is all to say that Freermasonry-- the obliterative sixth album from Wold
column2: the Saskatchewan act led by the incredibly named Fortress Crookedjaw-- is ultimately enigmatic and entirely unknowable
column3: an intersection of noise
column4: metal
column5: and electronics that doesn't yield to such plainclothes criticism. Mean
column6: dense and multivalent
column7: with a lyrical conceit based on Masonic symbolism and Biblical scripture
column8: it's the rare loud music that begs to be louder still if you're to have any chance of understanding it. Freermasonry is a case study in controlling the illusion of chaos
column9: an elegantly constructed nightmare of sound where hearing one layer of serrated screams
column10: static bursts
column11: and feedback flares means you've missed some mass of activity somewhere else. Weirdly seductive rhythms tumble beneath a laundromat of blown-out tones and crackling vocals
column12: generally pulling your attention a dozen different ways.

column1: I've been listening to the album consistently for three months now
column2: and somehow
column3: I'm still surprised by what its 58 minutes sound like and accomplish. Paradoxically disorienting and direct
column4: Freermasonry is a constant tumult of surprising activity
column5: more unforgiving than most everything in the noise
column6: metal
column7: and drone scenes
column8: places where Wold kind of fits. It's not an album you casually hear and dismiss by saying
column9: ""Oh
column10: yeah
column11: I could've made this."" (Even defining the ""this"" is hard enough.) Remember how those backwards rock'n'hits sounded vaguely demonic? Imagine those sounding truly malevolent
column12: but with solid structure
column13: buried subtlety
column14: and an ideology developed well past the point of boogeyman Satanism.

column1: Freermasonry isn't Wold's most damaging effort; the slyly named 2010 disc Working Together For Our Privacy turned three songs into a 35-minute suffocation
column2: where an instantaneous deluge of distortion squashes everything beneath. About 2008's torturous Stratification
column3: Wold member Obey once said
column4: ""We transmogrified the idea of our soundscape to fit the notion of an unrelenting winter storm."" This time
column5: Wold actually make some concessions to cohesive album flow
column6: beginning with the two-minute garble ""Opening"" and always putting a relatively short track (be that three or six minutes) between 11- and 12-minute strangleholds. With its faulty click-clack rhythm and mix of lascivious and lugubrious lyrics
column7: the strangely alluring ""Dry Love"" essentiallly sounds like Cold Cave with its Prurient component grossly amplified. With its disruptive subdural bass and five-verse structure about ""bloody crescent moons
column8: ""Annex Axe"" even suggests dubstep (think Coki) ground down by a blender. Similarly accessible moments dot Freermasonry
column9: from the jumbled dance that starts the closing title track to the rock-like eruption that begins ""SOL"".

column1: But don't take those references as hints that Wold are somehow taking it easy; rather
column2: these moments of relief or familiarity simply make everything else that much more punishing
column3: so that
column4: when the beat all but disappears on the title track after several minutes
column5: you actually mourn it. This album always peaks at its most extreme
column6: especially with a series of three long
column7: harsh sermons of invective-- ""Free Goat of Leviticus""
column8: ""Dragon Owl Didactisism""
column9: and ""Working Tools for Praxis"". With quoted Scripture and a developed revisionist theology
column10: these tracks harangue definitive Biblical heroes
column11: positing that ""Peter epitomizes the sadomasochistic spirit of the New Covenant"" and
column12: later
column13: ""Lucifer… is a better tomorrow and the bringer of a future."" The sound matches the spirit perfectly
column14:
with three-dimensional folds of splintering static and garbled lines creating an anxiety strong enough to shake any beliefs.

Travis Egedy's last Pictureplane album
column2: Thee Physical
column3: was a crowded concoction of garish rave signifiers
column4: dance music clichés
column5: and the punk-inspired free-for-all collage aesthetic of his earlier work weighted with lyrical conceits surrounding gender identity. With beefier production values that pointed more directly toward trance and euphoric house
column6: it was undoubtedly the most complete and confident thing the Denver producer's created to date. But never a stranger to the internet
column7: Egedy's free download series
column8: Dimensional Rip
column9: has played host to a handful of jumbled
column10: messy mixes
column11: and the seventh installment is a full-blown Thee Physical remix album.

column1: Well
column2: sort of: It depends on how you define ""album."" Only five of Thee Physical's 11 originals are given the remix treatment
column3: and they're plopped down as an unordered clump of beats. I'm not sure how we're supposed to listen to this; on my mp3 player
column4: they're sorted alphabetically
column5: meaning three remixes of ""Body Mod"" are followed by a whopping seven reworks of lead single ""Post Physical""-- it's not the most measured playlist I've ever heard. In my iTunes
column6: however
column7: the tracks are assorted seemingly randomly
column8: splitting up the monotony but throwing in a whole lot of volatile randomness. So as much as we might want to call Dimensional Rip 7 an album
column9: in practice it's merely a collection of tracks for us to peruse and choose from.

column1: Even though the production values of Thee Physical seemed to pull Egedy away from the kind of homemade dance music made from big obvious samples (such as 2009's memorable ""Goth Star"")
column2: its remix companion hands the album over to a whole spectrum of DIY denizens
column3: from recognizable to obscure names. The results vary in quality just as much. For as many that simply aren't distinctive
column4: there's a number of cringe-worthy facepalms. Chicago's Fire For Effect seize on the slow
column5: belaboured theatricality of ""Post Physical""
column6: turning it into something saccharine and overblown
column7: while the less said about Craxxxmurf's headache-inducing take on ""Touching Transform"" the better. Dimensional Rip 7's sheer size has one advantage
column8: however: For every misstep there's a good remix lurking behind it. Ritualz's ""Alien Trance remix"" of ""Post Physical"" takes hold of the trance thread that weaves through Egedy's work and turns it rubbery and warped
column9: while Adeptus lay down a bed of lush synths and acid gurgles
column10: turning ""Trancegender"" into the aching duet with Zola Jesus it should have been in the first place.

column1: Dimensional Rip 7 features some prominent and well-timed guests
column2: too. Montreal woman-of-the-moment Grimes dismantles ""Real Is a Feeling"" and reconstructs it into one of her own pins-and-needles skeletons
column3: infusing the track with her breathy coos for a remix so delicate it almost sounds out of place on a package full of speaker-blown hymns to homemade dance music. But the crown jewel undoubtedly belongs to makeshift chop'n'screw master Physical Therapy. The New Jersey producer's own distinct style-- taking huge samples and inflating them until they're puffy clouds of distortion and then drenching everything in sad
column4: defeated
column5: lean-dripping slowdown-- is more than compatible with Pictureplane's
column6: and his take on ""Post Physical"" layers sirens
column7: heavy metallic breaks
column8: and the original's stirring synth riff. It's one of the collection's few moments that feels truly innovative
column9: one of the American underground's weirdest personalities putting his imprint on another bizarro underdog.

column1: That inspiring collaboration sits atop a veritable heap of information-overload excess
column2: and a project as cheeky but quietly ambitious as Pictureplane deserves nothing less than a sprawling song-vomit remix album. Like most of what he does
column3: it's far from tasteful and not always all that great
column4: but the highlights are some of the most fun and carefree electronic music from this side of the Atlantic. There's been a lot of talk about the American ""new rave generation"" fueled by artists like Skrillex and Deadmau5
column5: but it's really Pictureplane that embodies everything caricatured in images of those neon-clad teenagers. Honestly
column6: Dimensional Rip 7 is a complete mess and not even close to a coherent listening experience
column7:
but its highs are high enough to make wading through the mud a worthwhile endeavor.

Kathleen Edwards' fourth album
column3: <i>Voyageur
column4: was co-produced with Justin Vernon
column5: the man behind Bon Iver and creator of Pitchfork's 2011 album of the year. His involvement
column6: along with the fact that they are dating
column7: will inform the way many people approach the record
column8: especially since it finds Edwards striking in some new musical directions. After building three albums on a sturdy country-rock Canadiana frame
column9: she jettisons the bar-band guitars and twangy vocals in favor of a bigger sound marked by gauzy production and a fuller band that includes Vernon along with members of Megafaun
column10: Francis & the Lights
column11: and Peter Wolf Crier.

column1: It still sounds like an Edwards album
column2: but it's not hard to hear Vernon's influence. It's there in his yawping vocals on ""Chameleon/Comedian"" and in the bicycle bell on ""Going to Hell""
column3: a sound that's quickly becoming his signature. And he may well be present in the lyrics
column4: which chronicle not the end of one relationship and the start of another. The latter is most evident on the album's most upbeat song
column5: ""Sidecar""
column6: which evokes the dizzy excitement of new love
column7: chronicling nothing more momentous than a whole day spent together. So Voyageur is both a break-up and a hook-up record; it's less about relationships than the spaces in between
column8: where regret over the past and worry over the future can overlap and overwhelm.

column1: Accordingly
column2: there's more drama and dynamism in these songs than in her past work
column3: as Edwards reshapes her sound to accommodate those themes. Instead of the guitar solos and full-band jams that sounded like genre accessories
column4: she gives over more space to more complex instrumental passages that build or fade theatrically. Some listeners may ascribe such moments on ""Mint"" and ""Change the Sheets"" to her new collaborators
column5: but Edwards was examining these ideas on 2008's Asking for Flowers
column6: an album that rethought the inner workings of her songs while still grounding them in hardscrabble country music.

column1: That record wasn't as ambitious as Voyageur
column2: but it was rawer
column3: rougher
column4: and better. In fact
column5: Edwards often sounds lost in these new songs. She has a great voice-- dusty and rambunctious-- and she still knows how to bend or break a note to add almost unbearable gravity to a particular line or phrase
column6: but the new material asks her to strain her vocals uncomfortably
column7: especially when she's singing wordlessly during those instrumental passages. Generally
column8: she's keener on sensical lyrics than on voice-as-sound; she's an interpreter
column9: so the meanings of words often inform her delivery. On ""Mint"" and ""Going to Hell""
column10: her voice loses much of its personality without lyrics to guide her.

column1: Thematically
column2: these new musical avenues fit the lyrics nicely: Each song emphasizes change and risk
column3: and Edwards never resorts to tired sentiments or platitudes about healing and hope. On the other hand
column4: she does entertain a particularly tortured
column5: hell-in-a-handbasket metaphor on ""Going to Hell"" and writes a few clunkers on ""Change the Sheets"" (""Change the sheets and then change me""). That is as new and startling as any sound on the album
column6: as in the past Edwards has proved to be a very careful songwriter who made every line count. But Voyageur is her most traditionally confessional album
column7: and while that might allow other singer-songwriters a bit more gravity and urgency
column8: here the more intimate focus limits her lyrical range and stunts the album's impact.

column1: Ultimately
column2: it's a question of perspective. Edwards has written convincingly and often devastatingly about other people
column3: attempting to view the world from the point of view of an abducted girl
column4: a haggard housewife
column5: or a woman carrying the baby of a criminal. That empathic endeavor lent her songs real bite
column6: allowing her to sum up an entire life in a few well-chosen words. But on Voyageur
column7: Edwards seems to get outside herself
column8: never tries to get another angle on any particular issue
column9:
which saps the songs of their humor as well as their imaginative power.

In a 2009 interview with Pitchfork
column2: Super Furry Animals' frontman Gruff Rhys admitted he was first drawn to the Velvet Underground because he thought they were fellow Welshman

column5: in Le Bon

column7: disaffected voice was <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z4lZqDmCO9c"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a natural fit for Rhys' electro-fied side project

column1: Like many debut albums by folk-schooled solo artists trying to assert their identity
column2: Le Bon's Me Oh My (released in 2009 on Rhys' Irony Bored Records label)
column3: could come off as both whimsically precious (""Sad Sad Feet"") and state-of-the-world serious (""Terror of the Man"")
column4: but showed a willingness to disrupt its serene surroundings with cutting lyrical barbs and well-timed blasts of psychedelicized guitar fuzz. The follow-up
column5: CYRK
column6: does little to upset Le Bon's pastoral
column7: turn-of-the-1970s prog-pop alchemy (as she sang on Me Oh My
column8: ""I like what I like and I like what I know"")
column9: but as its title-- the Polish word for ""circus""-- indicates
column10: it's several degrees more playful and irreverent.

column1: Where Me Oh My tended to reveal its charms and idiosyncrasies gradually
column2: CYRK lets its guard down almost immediately with ""Falcon Eyed""
column3: a scrappy
column4: start-stop gallop that suggests Le Bon has been trading pen-pal notes with the Fiery Furnaces' Eleanor Friedberger. The song's punkish drive proves anomalous to what follows
column5: but its mischievous energy carries through to CYRK's statelier turns as
column6: much more so than on Me Oh My
column7: Le Bon uses her deadpan delivery to droll effect. She takes particular delight in infusing innocent
column8: golden-oldies-radio sounds with decidedly unromantic sentiment: ""Puts Me to Work"" is an ode to domestic unrest and ennui that nonetheless boasts all the sweetness and grace of the first-dance selection at a wedding
column9: while ""The Man I Wanted"" finds her communicating desire for her one and only through a catatonic stare
column10: before opportunistically asking him
column11: ""Where is the payout?""

column1: But more than just chart her progression as a singer and songwriter
column2: CYRK also sees Le Bon and her four-piece band developing into a crack psych-rock outfit that consistently leads the songs into unexpected places
column3: from the wiggy guitar jams that overtake the title track and ""Fold the Cloth""
column4: to the piano-rolled clamor on ""Through the Mill"" that sounds like a haunted house coming alive after dark. Tellingly
column5: the closing two-part suite ""Ploughing Out"" serves as an autobiographical testament to LeBon's personal and musical evolution
column6: beginning as low-key lullaby referencing her country roots and then yielding to an anthemic
column7: acid-rockin' celebration of escape (""we'll be on the last boat out of here
column8: she repeats excitedly) that spirals into joyous
column9: saxophone-fired cacophony. Le Bon's days as a farmgirl in northern Wales may be long behind her
column10: but she's clearly held on to certain agricultural principles: namely
column11:
that the right amounts of patience and nurturing can produce glorious yields.

column8: is ""not enough"": Lupe's so gifted that he remains nearly impossible to tune out completely

column1: Perhaps he can sense this perception in the air. Because like most rappers who've made promises to the conscious-rap crowd that they have no intention of keeping
column2: Lupe's music has grown increasingly sour
column3: half-assed
column4: and defensive as he's traveled further from the glow of his Chosen One days. Listening to Friend of the People
column5: his wearying
column6: dispiriting latest mixtape
column7: you don't leave with the warm and fuzzy  feeling promised in the title; you come away thinking that Lupe's  underlying message these days feels closer to
column8: ""Here you are
column9: you ungrateful motherfuckers; I've given you something else beautiful to tear apart.""

column1: Friend of the People comes out a little more than a year after Lupe's last mixtape
column2: Enemy of the State
column3: but if there's a thematic link between them
column4: it's beyond a dog's range of hearing. Enemy of the State was short
column5: punchy
column6: and highly enjoyable; for a third of Friend of the People
column7: you feel actively punished for paying attention. Part of the problem is beat selection: On Enemy
column8: he skip-roped nimbly over Radiohead's ""The National Anthem"" without embarrassing anybody
column9: but on Friend's ""Lupe Back""
column10: he allows UK bro-step goons Nero to assault us with endless
column11: bowel-loosening bass drops. Fiasco sneaks in some eyebrow-raising rap-industry jabs-- producer deals
column12: B.D.S.
column13: ""only as hot as your last beat""-- but they disappear in the chaos.

column1: Production has always been an Achilles' heel for Lupe: He's nimble enough to make you listen to him rapping over anything
column2: but his tin ear tests this hypothesis far too frequently. Mainstream
column3: aggressively macho dubstep seems to be his latest thing: Besides Nero
column4: we get Bassnectar's remix  of Ellie Goulding's ""Lights"" for ""Lightworks"" and alpha-bro Skrillex on ""SNDCLSH in Vegas"". Lupe throws every flow he's got against these  steel-beamed
column5: charmless corporate-office structures
column6: but his reedy voice slides harmlessly right off. He also goes out of his way to show us  he's keeping up with indie
column7: sampling ""On'n'On"" from Justice's garish hockey-prog new album
column8: and skimming some starry-eyed shimmer off the top of M83's ""Midnight City"". I couldn't help but wish he would stop straining and find some tracks that work as viable rap beats.

column1: There are fleeting moments on Friend of the People where he encourages you to look past all these problems. ""Joaquin Phoenix"" is full of head-turning lines
column2: both self-deprecating (""Fitted hat is Reynolds  wrap/ Because I don't trust the government"") and silly (""You be on that  glory hole/ You don't know who you fuckin' with""). On the page
column3: when he's engaged
column4: Lupe is invincible. Even his quasi-philosophical nonsense comes with a poetic touch-- ""Atheism's cheaper and accepts Visa"" might not mean anything
column5: but it's a sharply turned
column6: gnomic phrase. He even drops an incredible floss rhyme on ""Supercold"" just to show us he can: ""Christmastime diamonds singing carols on my chest/ Step up off the jet
column7: lookin' like a pharaoh in the flesh."" But he's just as likely to waste our time recounting the plots to 1990s gangsta movies (""Double Burger w/Cheese""). It cuts to the core of Lupe's problem: there's almost nothing he can't do. Sadly
column8:
he never does anything much.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17344/homepage_large.cover.jpg|Iron Balls of Steel|30164.0|Loincloth|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Southern Lord']|2012-01-18 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:28.316891|"

Picture a sasquatch strolling up to you on a busy street
column2: and you'll get a sense of the surprise inherent in this
column3: an honest-to-god Loincloth LP. For nearly a decade
column4: the band-- a burly
column5: ultra-technical instrumental-metal outfit with members split between Raleigh
column6: N.C. and Richmond
column7: Va.-- lurked in the shadows like some cryptozoological beast glimpsed only in a handful of tantalizing photographs. Prior to Iron Balls of Steel
column8: Loincloth's complete discography totaled four songs
column9: lasting a few seconds shy of 12 minutes.

column1: But there was magic in those tracks (first issued on a 2003 CD-R demo
column2: with two of the selections also appearing on a Southern Lord 7"" and a third on a Swami Records comp)
column3: which subjected majestic doom to merciless rhythmic dislocation. Their resolute rawness was like a stop sign held up against better-known technical-metal bands like Meshuggah
column4: whose complexity is tempered by mechanistic coldness. In this one brief dispatch
column5: Loincloth proved that it was possible for metal's essential caveman-ness to coexist with its burgeoning brainiac impulses. Yet for all their musical conviction
column6: Loincloth seemed ambivalent at best about their bandhood; the quartet never emerged for even a single live gig
column7: and for years
column8: an ill-maintained MySpace page was all that signified their existence. It seemed reasonable to conclude that Loincloth's hibernation was permanent.

column1: Late 2011 brought bittersweet news: A Loincloth LP was finally due
column2: but for reasons they're keeping private
column3: the band had completed it without guitarist Pen Rollings
column4: a key presence on the demo and a cult-hero avant-metal artisan known for his work in the head-spinning early math-rock trio Breadwinner. Rollings had helped bolster the Loincloth legend via a hilariously outspoken Chunklet interview
column5: in which he mocked Norwegian black metal's humorless facade (a sentiment expressed on the demo via the track title ""Church Burntings"") and discussed his experiences navigating the underground rock scene as an openly gay man. On paper
column6: the loss is a bummer
column7: but the disappointment fades once Iron Balls starts spinning; remaining guitarist Tannon Penland handles the increased load via skillful multitracking
column8: and the band's fearsomely precise rhythm section-- bassist Cary Rowells and drummer Steve Shelton
column9: both also of the recently reactivated Raleigh progressive-doom outfit Confessor
column10: whose polarizing 1991 masterpiece
column11: Condemned
column12: planted the seed for Loincloth's insular obsessiveness-- sounds huger than ever
column13: abetted by a crisp
column14: full-bodied production job.

column1: Crucially
column2: the 16-track
column3: 38-minute Iron Balls isn't just an entree portion of the appetizer delivered on the demo. Penland
column4: Rowells
column5: and Shelton seem to understand that their unwaveringly maximal math metal can be numbing
column6: and they've found novel ways of adapting their aesthetic to the LP format without opting for obvious compromises like guest vocalists
column7: covers
column8: or the dreaded remix. (A few tracks do make tasteful use of ambient-style atmospherics
column9: either as a backdrop or as interstitial material.) While some pieces here follow the zero-frills M.O. of the demo-- brutal brain-scramblers that exhaust themselves in little over a minute-- others strive for and achieve an actual emotional arc
column10: an epic narrative sweep that places Iron Balls in the company of recent work by wordless prog-metal titans Dysrhythmia.

column1: The best of the bite-size pieces are breathless marvels. ""Hoof-Hearted""
column2: the album's shortest track at 75 seconds
column3: juxtaposes a needling solo-guitar break with vertiginous drops into a hard-swinging
column4: full-band groove. After the initial kick-in
column5: the band works its way up to a series of white-water accents and quickly yanks the rug out
column6: again leaving Penland alone. The trio recaps this sequence in various fractured forms
column7: as though feeding their theme through a series of irregular gears; even after repeated listens
column8: the track retains its dislocating power
column9: but the basic motifs lodge firmly in your head. In contrast to the material on the demo
column10: tracks like ""Hoof-Hearted"" and Iron Balls opener ""Underwear Bomb""-- in which a swaggery
column11: prog-blues riff lumbers forward in the face of almost comically relentless mathy digressions-- leave you feeling strangely fulfilled
column12: not merely pummeled.

column1: On some tracks
column2: technicality overwhelms coherence. The dizzyingly nimble ""Shark Dancer""
column3: for example
column4: shows off Steve Shelton's trademark stuttering double-bass work (never simply a cruise-control drone) and counterintuitive use of cymbals (marked by rigorous hand-muting and oddly placed thwacks)
column5: as well as Cary Rowells' intrepid mirroring of his rhythm partner. But the piece zooms ahead without a clear thematic thread and fails to make a lasting impression. ""Slow 6 Apocalypse""
column6: which exhausts itself in a fit of Morse-code turbulence
column7: feels similarly elusive.

column1: In contrast
column2: several more fleshed-out pieces here transcend the stone-faced chug of the demo-- not to mention the pervasive silliness of Iron Balls' album and track titles-- and achieve an improbable pathos. ""Stealing Pictures"" begins as headlong midtempo math rock
column3: fueled by cyclical riffs that churn and mutate without pause
column4: but around the minute mark
column5: the tempo halves and Penland picks out a poignant theme redolent of warm-blooded 1990s post-hardcore (Quicksand comes to mind). Later in the song
column6: the band returns to this passage and lingers on it in uncharacteristically patient fashion. ""Long Shadows"" fixates on its own captivating motif
column7: woozy yet crystalline
column8: which the band uses as a launchpad for a weighty avant-doom adventure. On these pieces
column9: as well as other highlights like the glimmeringly textural closer
column10: ""Clostfroth""
column11: Loincloth peel back their armor-plated exterior to expose the beating heart within.

column1: By recording a full-length
column2: offering listeners a clear 360-degree view of their previously shadowy creation
column3: Loincloth have put their valuable
column4: longstanding mystique on the line. Iron Balls could've easily revealed that the project worked best as a one-off lark
column5: thriving on the strict limitations of the EP format. But it turns out that this monster looks many times more intriguing up close; without taking any easy shortcuts
column6: Penland
column7: Rowells
column8: and Shelton reveal here that their beast harbors genuine beauty. The disc ought to have the proud
column9: few Loincloth faithful weeping with joy
column10: but more importantly
column11:
it leaves room for a broader audience to hear what the fuss was all about.

"|16188.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16188-iron-balls-of-steel/|7.9|Hank Shteamer
