Alec Feld
column2: a young New York native who goes by Expensive Looks
column3: earned good notices a while back for ""Nothing More""
column4: a radiant song about loneliness. At this point
column5: you could be forgiven for feeling sleepy whenever you hear hazy synthesizers mixed with a wayward drum pattern. But even though it arrived hopelessly late to the chillwave party
column6: ""Nothing More"" was just too sticky to discount. It helped that Feld's voice
column7: which wouldn't sound out of place on a Wolf Parade or Animal Collective anthem
column8: was strong and commanding. But on Expensive Looks' debut LP
column9: Dark Matters
column10: the single is something of an outlier. It turns out that Feld's interest in that kind of immediacy is limited
column11: which accounts for both Dark Matters' appeal and limitations.

column1: Feld's music has a ravey
column2: enervated grandeur
column3: but the glare of style sometimes seems like a way to mask the lack of substance. Dark Matters feels like the solution to an equation whose variables include Toro Y Moi
column4: Neon Indian
column5: Nite Jewel
column6: Bibio
column7: Baths
column8: and Elite Gymnastics-- a timely concoction of lo-fi disco
column9: corroded analog textures
column10: submerged bass
column11: chipmunk soul
column12: and granulated funk. No one's saying that Feld is ripping anyone off-- this stuff is all just in the air. But that doesn't change the fact that this sound is currently feeling threadbare. That's why my favorite track on Dark Matters is also the weirdest: opener ""Your Dreams Our Week""
column13: which is divisible by only itself. Each stem of the track feels like an independent process
column14: and you get the sense they could slide apart at any moment. The result is a track with genuine tension
column15: willfulness
column16: and originality. In this strange way
column17: Feld's music may be best at its worst. Errors enliven it.

column1: This kind of audacity doesn't surface again until the last track
column2: ""Vanishers""-- which
column3: unfortunately
column4: is a senseless mess; the only seriously bad stretch on an otherwise charming record. The songs between ""Nothing More"" and ""Vanishers"" are pleasant to zone out to
column5: with potent moments of dark euphoria
column6: but hard to remember. With the possible exception of ""Moving Visions""
column7: the pop songs fall short of the heights of ""Nothing More""
column8: while the little interstitials feel random. It's good fun but never pushes against anything
column9: which is no fatal flaw
column10:
but no revelation either.

Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross' score for The Social Network was brilliant because it worked as a conventional film score even though its approach was boldly unconventional. The pair assembled a dense but brittle map of drones
column3: foreboding sound effects
column4: and delicate melodies
column5: submerging acoustic sounds in pools of digital filters. The result was something suited to filmmaker David Fincher's work-- brooding
column6: mysterious
column7: and tinged with anxiety. The film world agreed: Reznor's first foray into soundtrack work after putting Nine Inch Nails on hiatus landed him both an Academy Award and a Golden Globe. Who knew? Fincher clearly has confidence in their abilities
column8: as he tapped Reznor and Ross once again to score his latest movie
column9: the film adaption of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo. With the team earning another Golden Globe nomination
column10: it would seem like they're doing something right.

column1: Dragon Tattoo doesn't differ drastically from Social Network but it's not a retread. For starters
column2: this one's a three-hour beast
column3: spread out over three CDs
column4: six vinyl LPs
column5: or a whopping 39 digital files. So while The Social Network could be received as a digestible standalone product
column6: Girl With the Dragon Tattoo doesn't offer the same sort of flexibility. That's in part by design as much as structure: Where The Social Network had discernible motifs like ""Hand Covers Bruise"" and pseudo-techno like ""In Motion""
column7: the music here is more obtuse
column8: focused on building tension and defining space rather than conveying feeling or emotion through melody. Which means there are few standout tracks; instead
column9: the most arresting moments emerge out of layers of increasingly damaged sounds that set an uncompromisingly bleak mood.

column1: The score's overcast outlook is well suited to Fincher's portrayal of Sweden as an outwardly and proudly modern country overrun with the dehumanizing potential of technology. It's a place haunted equally by industrial remnants of past eras and shameful personal and political histories. The task of Reznor and Ross is to create something conflicted between technology and tradition
column2: and they opt for a sound that's essentially future-baroque: fiercely plucked strings
column3: ominous bass
column4: decaying chimes
column5: and spare pianos held together with meticulous post-processing.

column1: But where Dragon Tattoo excels in its role as soundtrack
column2: it falters in listenability: imagine something like Ghosts I-IV but almost double the length and without all the catchy parts. True
column3: it is easy to admire the sheer complexity of their work in small doses. Pieces like ""Hypomania"" drift into clouds of hellish distortion and re-emerge
column4: while ""Oraculum"" features vividly tactile drums that feel heavily removed from your typical Hollywood percussive suspense music. So while this might be a soundtrack
column5: it rises above mere Hollywood muzak.

column1: As the set drifts into its third and final disc
column2: the pace begins to pick up and form shapes that might be recognizable to Reznor adherents. ""Great Bird of Prey"" could be an instrumental leftover from The Fragile days
column3: while ""Infiltrator"" weaves in and out of sections of intensely energetic movement. ""An Itch"" traps what sounds like human screams and moans beneath an actual beat
column4: while the warbly ""Closer"" piano even makes a reappearance in ""The Heretics""
column5: a sly wink and nod to its composers' considerable musical history.

column1: For those fans who wouldn't want to spend $300 on a 6xLP box set of soundtrack music
column2: Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is likely to remain a curiosity apart from its two bookending vocal tracks. The movie's sleek opening sequence is soundtracked by the Reznor and Karen O's cover of Led Zeppelin's ""Immigrant Song""
column3: a mean reminder of the power Reznor's pop music holds at its most ferocious. On the other end of the spectrum
column4: the three hours wind down with a cover of Bryan Ferry's ""Is Your Love Strong Enough?"" by How to Destroy Angels (the band composed of Ross
column5: Reznor
column6: and wife Mariqueen Maandig). To hear a human voice so bright and clear after what's come before is a moment of pure pop relief. But pop is not what Girl With the Dragon Tattoo is about. It's reasonable to question the necessity of a score whose sprawling mass exceeds the length of the film it's meant for. But even if it doesn't quite work as a standalone experience
column7:
the real takeaway here is that Reznor and Ross may be ushering in an exciting new realm of possibility for mainstream film scoring.

T.I.'s place in rap history has been established; when he was counted out after his major-label debut barely rippled
column3: he released a series of buzz-building mixtapes that culminated in a Southern hip-hop classic
column4: Trap Muzik
column5: a point when he claimed his spot as King of the South. On Urban Legend he swatted at upstarts who would challenge him. And with King
column6: he crashed through to the national stage. By the time of Paper Trail
column7: the rapper had crossed over completely
column8: with ""Whatever You Like"" becoming the his first No. 1 hit.

column1: Beneath this narrative of triumph
column2: of course
column3: was a tumultuous undercurrent: A friend was killed in front of him
column4: drugs abused
column5: and unthinkable paranoia led to felony weapons charges
column6: jail time
column7: parole violations
column8: and more jail time. While an artist like Gucci seemed so reckless with the opportunities he had earned
column9: T.I. always gave the impression that he was striving to escape that trap. Fresh from his most recent dalliance with hard time
column10: the rapper is back in the scrappy mode of his early days; as it's ever been
column11: the worst thing you can do is count him out. But while Fuck Da City Up finds the rapper in a hungry mode
column12: it also has a vague sense of listlessness. It's difficult to get a feel for the rapper's story. He seems to have left the personal narratives and ethical tensions that charged his earlier works behind. In its place
column13: he has shifted his focus in twin directions: proving he's still got the energy of a rapper half his age (he does). And proving that he can still make bangers. This is where the tape doesn't reach the bar set by earlier efforts.

column1: It doesn't help that Fuck Da City Up dropped around the same time as Jeezy's comeback record
column2: and shortly before Ross' oxygen-stealing Rich Forever. Because T.I. just can't do blockbuster rap bangers like those two. His style was more dexterous nuance than bludgeoning Scarface mantras. Here
column3: his best moments seem to rely on the talents of his guests to create some (admittedly impressive) chemistry. Witness the superteam of Travis Porter
column4: Young Dro
column5: Tip
column6: and ""I'm on One""-producer T-Minus for the showstopping ""Hot Wheels"". ""On Purpose"" is another highlight
column7: and the collaborative team of Trouble and T.I. (""It's 'Trouble Man' riding with Trouble
column8: man
column9: them mu'fuckers in trouble
column10: man"") have a very real musical symmetry; it's easy to imagine that Trap Muzik's sense of moral strength may have had a heavy influence on Trouble's 2011 mixtape December 17th.

column1: Sonically
column2: you'd be hard pressed to argue that anyone but T.I. picked out these beats; bouncier and heavier on regal horn parts than the typical rap record today
column3: they retain the King vibe even though the producer names have changed. Perhaps the best production comes from Hit Boy
column4: who laces the amusingly named ""Harry Potter"" with a shimmering wall-of-sparks beat that deserves a better title. T.I.'s rapping throughout the tape retains the balance of smooth style
column5: a perfect Southern rapper's accent
column6: and the ability to telegraph energy through a dazzlingly rhythmic flow. But ultimately
column7: the songs simply aren't there
column8: certainly not ones that will rival Ross'
column9: and T.I.'s narrative here feels too weakly articulated to make up for songwriting shortcomings.

column1: While relying on biography to invigorate his raps a decade distant from the street life might be unrealistic
column2: when his music was at its most fascinating
column3: his willingness to wrestle with the moral dimension of his experiences helped streamline his music
column4: giving it verisimilitude that felt in short supply in the cutthroat world of street rap. It gave some of the more plain moments an impassioned purpose
column5: which allowed the listener to ignore hip-hop's cult of Bangers. It also helped sand down the rough edges on a musical level; while Jeezy's monolithic sound could sweep up listeners in its pure
column6: epic
column7: and totalitarian vision
column8: T.I. was always too flawed
column9: too self-aware to go for those sorts of transparent theatrics. This made for compelling rap music when his story was central. But when the only story is the one arguing for your own relevance
column10:
you end up with a lot of sound and fury.

In the early days of grime
column2: say around 2002 or 2003
column3: it was easy for Americans (many of us still using dial-up to snag single MP3 transmissions from the London underground) to feel like we'd never be able to keep up. Almost a decade later
column4: it still feels impossible
column5: but for entirely different reasons: Whether we're talking about freestyles caught on cell phones in clubs or fully thought-out mixtapes
column6: the brand-newest shit from grime's young turks and old hands is now instantly accessible. Much like the current state of U.S. rap
column7: grime unleashes an avalanche of semi-underground material every month
column8: and you can catch a headache just thinking about trying to process everything.

column1: No one represents the promise and perils of this state of affairs better than Wiley
column2: still one of the genre's most distinct voices and crucial producers. Up until 2006
column3: you could listen to the entire recorded output of this grime godfather
column4: from bedroom beat experiments to charting singles that reshaped UK urban music
column5: in just a couple of hours. Now it's arguable that even Wiley can't remember every track he's released in the past half-decade. In 2007
column6: he put out no less than six ""best-of"" mixtapes
column7: and he hasn't slowed down since. If anything
column8: since his brief brush with the UK mainstream in 2008 thanks to the pop-dance undeniablility of ""Wearing My Rolex""
column9: he's sped up
column10: as if his thwarted dalliance with a major label allowed him to see the futility of releasing one ""official"" album every few years in a cloud-based world. But Evolve
column11: available through the auspices of real-deal label Big Dada
column12: is clearly being marketed as one of the Wiley releases you should pay closer attention to.

column1: And you should. Gone are the sickly sweet R&B choruses from his last LP
column2: Chill Out Zone
column3: a sometimes gorgeous but mostly misguided foray into grime-goes-quiet-storm. From opener ""Welcome to Zion""
column4: we're clearly in old-school Wiley World
column5: as defined by the chilly synth tones and hand-drum-and-computer-clonk rhythms of his earliest singles like ""Igloo"" and ""Eskimo""
column6: albeit with a fresh-for-2012 production upgrade. It's no surprise to learn he's hooked up on a few tracks with Mark Pritchard from Africa Hitech
column7: whose best music similarly brings together twisted quotes from the history of rave and manic polyrhythms that feel conscious of Afro-Cuban tradition and post-human at the same time. In the early days
column8: no other producer had Wiley's strange feel for lurch-and-stagger funk
column9: for a shouldn't-work-but-does kind of syncopation
column10: and it's nice to know he hasn't abandoned his bizarre way with beats in favor of comfortably waist-winding grooves.

column1: Wiley hasn't totally given up on crossover success
column2: and Evolve is no way an hour-long return to pirate-radio mic-busting brutalism. But even the cuts aimed at dancers rather than freestyle trainspotters have a pleasingly off-kilter feel that owes more to the wilder side of dancehall and its endless global mutations. ""Boom Blast"" is an obvious stab at the party-rocking electro that's everywhere in mainstream pop these days
column3: but with wilder drums and a more menacing vibe. Its resemblance to ""Like a G6"" merely points out how stark that chart-topper was
column4: rather than how pop Wiley can go. He sounds revitalized as a rapper
column5: too. Gone are the mushy-soft love rhymes from Chill Out
column6: blessedly replaced on many of Evolve's deep cuts with the reams of breathless and bracing East London slang and hard-won introspection that once marked him a potential UK Nas rather than a fleet cockney Ja Rule. When he does indulge in mere playa braggadocio
column7: there's often a wicked and knowing silliness to help the boasts go down
column8: and the wildstyle bass manipulations on tunes like ""Link Up"" and ""I'm Skanking"" once again shout
column9: ""I'm a badman
column10: as loudly as the rhymes. Plus his sense of humor remains as twisted and idiosyncratic as ever. Perhaps only Wiley would concoct a minimalist
column11: almost gothic instrumental and then turn it into a skit about how hard it can be to catch a cab.

column1: It would be a shame if you do overlook Evolve out of fatigue
column2: since its one of his best
column3: a mostly single-minded return to the on-the-mic fierceness and computers-go-tribal rhythms that first made his name. But it would be totally understandable. In 2010
column4: he threw 11 .zip files of new beats onto an unsuspecting internet. I can barely remember a single thing about that particular data dump
column5: except a feeling of amazement slowly giving way to exhaustion. In 2011
column6: he put out not only three mixtapes
column7: but two of those as official albums
column8: at least one of which was another semi-classic almost lost in his manic flow. And not one to let more than six months go by without a new transmission from the Eskibeat bunker
column9: he's already back with his eighth available-in-stores full-length in a little less than eight years. This one's a keeper
column10: though
column11: and if you've tuned out on grime over the last few years
column12: either from negligence or overload
column13: here's an easy way to reenter grime's current moment
column14:
even if Wiley will likely declare it old news in a couple weeks.

Eighteen years ago
column2: a multi-instrumentalist from the West Coast and a songwriter from Australia released an album under the name Cardinal. It wasn't a huge hit
column3: but it did exert a big influence as one of the first albums of the 1990s to explore lush chamber pop in any depth. (Chamber pop is pretty much a nucleotide in the DNA of indie rock today
column4: which makes it easy to forget that it wasn't always that way.) The original 1994 Cardinal album was met with a flurry of acclaim
column5: but its spending many years out of print-- it was finally reissued in 2005-- meant not many people heard it after that initial burst.

column1: The American half of the duo
column2: Eric Matthews
column3: went on to have a successful career
column4: releasing solo albums and arranging for a lengthy list of other artists
column5: including Elliott Smith
column6: Tahiti 80
column7: and the Dandy Warhols. His partner
column8: Richard Davies
column9: who had already played in the Moles
column10: has kept going with a low-profile solo career. There seems to be no particular occasion that prompted their reunion
column11: but their re-emergence after such a long break
column12: sounding basically like they used to
column13: does afford us a chance to see how things have changed in almost 20 years. Their sound
column14: a fairly basic brand of mostly mid-tempo
column15: low-key indie rock adorned with brass fanfares and other decorative orchestration
column16: doesn't stand out as much as it did back in the days of grunge
column17: but it is still distinctive.

column1: Thing is
column2: for as much attention as they got back in the day
column3: Cardinal never made the most instantly memorable music
column4: and that holds true here as well. Davies likes to run his vocals through subtle processing
column5: and he especially likes doubling himself singing clean on one track and processed on another. Often the only effect of this is that it blunts the melody. Matthews answers those melodies with big bursts of trumpet
column6: but those answering statements can sound more mannered than felt-- across the album
column7: there's hardly any syncopation
column8: and with pretty much everything happening between the bar lines
column9: the album sounds tight and staid even as it shoots for grandeur.

column1: This is not to say Hymns doesn't have its moments. The first time Matthews hits us full-force with the brass
column2: on ""Carbolic Smoke Ball""
column3: it imparts a Bacharachian sweep to a song that otherwise walks in place. The reverberant piano of ""General Hospital"" nicely conjures the image of a cold
column4: empty hospital hallway; the upbeat ""Love Like Rain"" is a welcome diversion into something approaching power pop; and Davies' closing refrain on ""Rosemary Livingstone""-- ""I want you to change/ But stay the same""-- is a funny way of stepping outside the band for a second and getting into the head of a listener who maybe doesn't know what he wants from this reunion. Fair enough. The reunion wasn't expected
column5: and while it's nice to finally hear these two follow up on a promising debut
column6:
Hymns isn't likely to capture many people who weren't taken with the original Cardinal record.

Juicy J cuts to the chase early on Blue Dream & Lean: The entire chorus of ""Juicy J Can't""
column2: the album's third track
column3: is

column5: though not completely necessary on a mixtape that derives its title by rhyming the slang for cough syrup and soda with the name of a strand of weed. Juicy-- one half of legendary
column6: and legendarily bizarre
column7: Memphis rap group Three 6 Mafia-- seemingly spent most of 2011 ingesting enough recreational drugs to make Nikki Sixx raise an eyebrow
column8: and paying producer Lex Luger for beats so he can rap about it. Blue Dream & Lean is basically a continuation of Juicy's two collaborative mixtapes with Luger
column9: Rubber Band Business and Rubber Band Business 2. Despite Luger's producing only nine of the album's 28 tracks

column12: head-knocking production of classic Three 6.

column1: The success and failure of the mixtape are two sides of the same coin. On the one hand
column2: there's cohesion to Blue Dream & Lean that serves it well. The result of Juicy's chanting about taking drugs over tracks that are largely similar is that he pulls you into his world
column3: one where narcotics blur everything together until one day you have a 28-track mixtape
column4: yet you still need to title every song
column5: but you're so stoned that you just pick the dominant line from every chorus. Lesser artists have tried much harder to achieve the same effect and failed
column6: and Juicy pulls it off effortlessly. The flip side of that
column7: of course
column8: is that a 28-track mixtape featuring Juicy J chanting over largely similar beats is far too many tracks
column9: especially on the heels of two related tapes. Blue Dream & Lean could be chopped in half and be no worse for the wear
column10: but that's par for the course.

column1: It's a shame
column2: too
column3: because a combination of the best Luger-style tracks and the few songs that go in a different direction would make for a very good album. The opening quarter of the mixtape is especially inspired
column4: as it finds Juicy at the point where he's most concentrated on casually
column5: almost mindlessly
column6: talking shit. Interspersed throughout the album are songs like ""Big Bank""(produced by Drumma Boy
column7: one of the most diverse producers in the South) and ""Stoners Night 2""
column8: which break up the slight monotony but deserve to be highlighted even further. The latter
column9: done by notable up-and-coming producer Harry Fraud
column10: features a lush
column11: soulful sample that's a breath of fresh air amongst the album's suffocating palette.

column1: The latter part of the tape gives shine to blog favorites like A$AP Rocky
column2: Spaceghostpurrp
column3: Alley Boy
column4: and Kreayshawn
column5: all of whom sound much too eager to please. And though that's perfectly understandable
column6: it's quite jarring considering that Juicy is trading in his ability to make the listener believe that he's self-destructively destroying his body regardless of the consequences. Kreayshawn at least managed to score the best chorus

column8: ""you trippy
column9: mane?"" is the only time any of the aforementioned guests come off as carefree enough to hit on the album's vibe.

column1: Blue Dream & Lean is allegedly Juicy's first offering as a member of Wiz Khalifa's Taylor Gang
column2: and though hot new rappers using their newfound power to sign legendary veterans that have faded from the spotlight almost always leads to a failure to meet inflated expectations
column3:
there's enough here to suggest that Juicy could put out a really good album with the input of a dedicated editor.

Sonically
column2: the  Big Pink's 2009 debut delivered. A Brief History of Love's titanic choruses
column3: huge production
column4: and maxed-out volume were designed to explode on the radio. Though they didn't sound like Britpop
column5: the term was applied anyway because the Big Pink seemed in the swaggering lineage of bands like Oasis
column6: the Verve
column7: and Mansun. But bands who emerge so fully formed sometimes lack staying power and
column8: considering Big Pink co-founder Milo Cordell's roots running Merok Records during the cultural peak of blog-house and nu-rave
column9: the band had to be aware of their potential limitations. The follow-up
column10: Future This
column11: finds the Big Pink as boxed in as their predecessors
column12: recycling the same ideas with less conviction.

column1: The drop-off is clear in the album's first few seconds: ""Stay Gold"" bears blatant similarity to their previous hit ""Dominos"" but shifts the lyrical focus from consequence-free sex to homilies about staying true to your dreams. It's a troubling thread that runs throughout Future This: where the Big Pink once mastered the role of magnetic
column2: womanizing loners
column3: here their tilt towards positivity and pursuit of a connection with their audience comes off as uncomfortably needy. This results in ill-defined salvos like ""Jump Music"" that awkwardly try to position themselves as message songs despite having no discernable message.

column1: The Big Pink try to build a mythology by dropping references from their debut into new songs
column2: as if the two lyrically divergent records were of a conceptual piece. They also toss in a reference to the Stone Roses' ""I Wanna Be Adored""
column3: establishing kinship with another band that was ultimately sunk by not knowing how to follow up a huge debut. And later
column4: ""Hit the Ground (Superman)"" is every bit as gimmicky as ""Stay Gold""
column5: incorporating a sample of Laurie Anderson's ""O Superman"" into its halting
column6: Max Martin-like strut and illustrating the fatal flaw of Future This: their need to siphon the power of outside sources-- obvious samples
column7: prefab slogans
column8: even their borrowings from their own music. Where the Big Pink previously sounded invincible
column9: nearly every attempt to intellectualize or streamline their sound makes Future This come off as timid and malnourished.

column1: All of which makes the tender ""77"" a surprising closer. Touching on addiction and loss
column2: lead singer Robbie Furze sings
column3: ""You left such an impression on me/ Left on the debris/ Now I'm all fucked up/ And sometimes I forget I miss you."" It isn't exactly poetry
column4: but it does feel unmistakably personal for a band whose most vulnerable song to this point told a lover to leave them alone. It's an awkward start to humanizing the Big Pink
column5:
but a start nonetheless.

column12: and even then

column14: say
column15: the hissy ""The Brewery"". Still
column16: on a tape that could use a few more outliers
column17: skits
column18: practical jokes
column19: something
column20: this little bit of audience participation works wonders for engagement; you'd probably never hear Ceazar-n-Reason's lackluster ""Brewery"" verses if you didn't have to crank the song so loud to hear Raekwon at all. Couple that with the incongruous appearance of young Altrina Renee's post-Aaliyah/""E-Mail My Heart"" lunger ""Facetime""

column1: Ever since threatening defection from the Wu following 2007's intoxicatingly odd 8 Diagrams
column2: Raekwon's revealed himself to be a key figure in the Wu-Tang's conservative wing. His much-lauded 2009 LP was
column3: after all

column7: richly detailed

column9: gritty strings. It's a lane Rae absolutely owns

column5: when he drops a Twilight reference in his very first verse here

column7: but elsewhere
column8: Rae seems a little scattered

column10: if you're wondering

column11: over crackling
column12: cinematic RZA beats. Unexpected Victory's sound is too lousy-- and its stakes too low-- to ever possibly live up to his past glories. What's most frustrating

In the parlance of the increasingly vocal menswear blogging community
column3: Todd Terje is ""having a moment."" A combination of serendipity and opportunism
column4: a moment is a flash of triumph
column5: unplanned and difficult to reproduce. To offer some perspective
column6: cargo pants are also having a moment. Like Terje productions (as opposed to remixes)
column7: cargo pants disappeared for a few years mid-decade; now they're back
column8: and they look (sound) better than anyone remembers. Hell
column9: it was only six months ago when
column10: upon asking a friend if he had any interest in a Terje DJ tour stop in Chicago
column11: I received the following curt reply: ""No. I don't want to listen to a bunch of space disco shit."" But Terje's three-song Ragysh EP-- the one that included year-end chart barnstormer ""Snooze 4 Love""-- dropped and proved surprisingly sticky.

column1: This month he follows that with It's the Arps
column2: a four-track EP on ""space disco shit"" mothership Smalltown Supersound
column3: composed with an ARP2600 analog synthesizer. The first line of Vintage Synth Explorer's ARP2600 entry is
column4: ""The ARP 2600 is without a doubt one of the finest analog synthesizers ever."" Terje has always been a sound-- and not a retro-- fetishist. Why else devote his precious remix work to nu-disco bench players and classic rock mammoths in equal measure? It's no surprise then that he'd be tempted by a mystical artifact such as the Arp
column5: which
column6: like many old synthesizers
column7: looks like the kind of rune-encrusted rock-toy that his music's implied spaceships set out in search of. (The former astrophysics student is a rumored future space traveler.)

column1: Terje's own productions-- like those of labelmate Lindstrøm-- favor knob-twiddling disco
column2: like Giorgio Moroder without the pop-vocal instincts. He's confident and gifted enough to throw away an all-time piano loop on a Bryan Ferry remix. On It's the Arps
column3: he trades the sturdy eight-minute structures of Ragysh for a baggier and more colorful sound. ""Inspector Norse"" would be a pro-forma space-disco jam in lesser hands-- it has that bulbous bassline
column4: the tint of humor-- but Terje transforms it into a daytime noir
column5: one that spreads its pinging notes wide. The star of the show is the two-track ""Swing Star"" suite
column6: part one a wicked treadmill of double-time sequences over blocky bass and hiss-y drums. It's synth music as roadside fireworks: Light the fuse and back away quickly. ""Swing Star Pt. 2"" explores the same chord progression but with a cleaner palate
column7: and the result is a light-breeze boogie that feels like a comedown. (The fourth track ""Myggsommer"" is a narrow miss
column8: a vine-y synth doodle that suggests vintage synth flippancy can be as precocious as vintage guitar-tone exercises.)

column1: This might've been lost in the space disco explosion a half-decade ago
column2: but with his contemporaries wandering off into prog
column3: kraut
column4: and sundry other forms of out-music
column5: the clean lines and easy momentum of It's the Arps are really refreshing. And Jesus
column6: it's fun. The trouble with moments
column7: of course
column8: is extending them. Terje has the imagination. An upcoming Roxy Music remix suggests Terje will be a more consistent presence
column9:
which is fantastic: I'd really like not to be comparing him to fedoras in 2017.

San Antonio's Ernest Gonzales has been the quiet cornerstone of the L.A.-based Friends of Friends label
column2: one of the American west coast's most consistently surprising dance outfits.  Gonzales' music is about the beauty of contrast and dichotomy
column3: whether it's the collision of lifelike guitar and 8-bit synthesizer on his previous solo album Been Meaning to Tell You or his mixture of the cinematic
column4: sepulchral
column5: and cultural with the down-and-dirty dancefloor as Mexicans With Guns. His latest album picks up on the themes of Been Meaning to Tell You
column6: and as the title Natural Traits might suggest
column7: brings those ideals of nature to a more genune hybrid.

column1: Natural Traits finds itself at home in a whitewashed world of pastel and rounded shapes
column2: avoiding the hectic
column3: everything-at-once sprawl of modern ""bass music"" (particularly the American variety) in favor of careful
column4: deliberate movements. To call it simple would be diminutive
column5: but there's something distinctly digestible and affable about the slow-but-steady way Gonzales builds his tracks. It's typified in the album's stately opener
column6: ""The Prudence of Evolution""
column7: methodically layering soft drums on top of chords on top of two delicate 8-bit synth melodies that intertwine like DNA strands yet nimbly sidestep the juvenilia so often associated with the sugary sound.

column1: Those 8-bit feelers are the dominant melodic device on Natural Traits
column2: a thicket of flinty frequencies that never quite loosens its curious tension: The synth almost always sounds brittle and trebly
column3: set against gorgeous
column4: reverb-heavy guitar jangle and a set of drum sounds that range from hollow to realistic. When the two opposites combine
column5: as on the beautiful beatless centerpiece ""Peaks & Valleys""
column6: the result is somewhere between summery indie rock and something more indebted to electronic music
column7: a divide toed by the record with every track so that it occupies an in-between space in keeping with its equally middle-ground array of sounds and textures. It's an attractive medium rather than a middling one
column8: however; Gonzales' resolution is one that engenders approachability rather than dilution.

column1: As MOR as Natural Traits might sound
column2: however
column3: it willingly engages with dance music in a more direct way than Been Meaning to Tell You. Like his Mexicans With Guns project
column4: however
column5: they're rarely ""dance"" in a definitively genre-indebted
column6: quantized sense. Take highlight ""The Sentimental Sea""
column7: Gonzales' riff on 130-bpm house: The kick thumps balefully with little flourish
column8: but a fluid
column9: slippery loop brings it closer to something like sensual dub techno. That is
column10: until Gonzales' warm streams of bass and uplifting guitar plucks flood the track's second half
column11: turning it from arch savant-house into a landscape teeming with lush life. Elsewhere
column12: the percussion gets lost in a tug of war: In ""When Synchronicity Fails""
column13: Gonzales anticipates the rigid housey lope with a billowing guitar riff that trips over itself
column14: synthesizing syncopation out of thin air
column15: while ""The Heroic Lives of Particles"" plays with swung dubstep-leaning percussive patterns that lend a certain groove to the track's loose synth scribbles. They're moves that should be disorienting but instead sound easy in Gonzales' confident hands.

column1: Natural Traits succeeds largely on account of its relative modesty and transparency-- sometimes the most satisfying records are the ones where you can guess exactly how everything was built in the first place. Undoubtedly Gonzales' strongest statement yet
column2: it comes one step closer to achieving that impossible fusion of the synthetic and natural
column3: quietly experimental in spite of its own humility. Like most of his work
column4: it doesn't fit into any narrative but his own (though it does slot in nicely with the recent stretch of woodsy material that has defined Friends of Friends' better output for the past year)
column5: and it doesn't need to: Post-rock for the Flying Lotus generation
column6:
Natural Traits is 40 minutes of elegant pastoralism and refined instrumental songwriting at its best.

column3: and its strange
column4: secluded aura was reinforced by the fact that

column6: with Olausson's moody
column7: Skip Spence-like baritone nodding off in front.

column1: Given the album's powerful loner/outsider vibe

column3: however
column4: on Morning & Sunrise the opposite is true

column13: sounding as if the oracle has faded after it has provided as much counsel as it can.

column1: Transfixing as his voice and words can be
column2: on ""Riding on the Wind"" and ""Doctor's Deeds"" his guitar work is deceptively lucid and wholly captivating. And though there are fewer unexpected instrumental flourishes than on Moonlight Farm
column3: there are discreet touches-- a ghostly whistle here
column4: a shuffling country rhythm there-- on every track to reward those ready to sink deeper into the music's enveloping grip. As a whole the album makes an excellent companion piece to Moonlight Farm
column5: even if it lacks some of that record's initial otherworldly
column6: where-did-this-come-from impact
column7:
and raises anticipation for further dispatches from Olausson in the future.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17326/homepage_large.78d51a6f.jpg|Rich Forever|4880.0|Rick Ross|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Maybach']|2012-01-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:36.464736|"

With both Rick Ross and star producer du jour Lex Luger at the top of the rap game
column2: it's easy to forget how much of the former's career is now owed to the latter. Ross was a successful artist before he ever hooked up with Luger
column3: but his stunning transition from begrudgingly accepted popular rapper to one of the genre's most respected artists can basically be traced directly back to Luger's beat for ""B.M.F. (Blowin' Money Fast)""
column4: the song that will go down as the indelible single of Ross' career. The beat was so titanic that Ross-- who had gone to great pains to protect the self-constructed image of himself as an opulent drug kingpin-- shouted a chorus where he imagined himself as genuine
column5: real-life drug kingpins Big Meech and Larry Hoover. In one fell swoop
column6: Ross tore down his carefully assembled existence while simultaneously building up the one that paved the way for the career surge he's riding
column7: which has culminated in <i>Rich Forever
column8: the new mixtape that now stands as his artistic pinnacle.

column1: ""B.M.F."" is genius for many reasons
column2: but there is one crucial aspect of the song that makes Rich Forever tick: It was the first time that Ross ever really got mean. It's almost incredible to consider
column3: but despite his stature and physical presence
column4: ""B.M.F."" was the first intimidating Ross track since his debut single ""Hustlin'""
column5: the first since then that pumped a dangerous amount of adrenaline into your veins. In the four years between those songs
column6: Ross kept everything but wealth and women at a distance. He chose cinematic
column7: orchestral beats that colored that image perfectly
column8: and while it was no doubt an effective strategy
column9: songs like ""Maybach Music 2"" are the equivalent of a living room in a mansion where you'd be afraid to touch any of the furniture. ""B.M.F."" was Rick Ross as Dave Chappelle as Rick James yelling ""fuck yo' couch
column10: except the couch was actually his own. It was exactly what his career needed.

column1: Luger produces only one song on Rich Forever
column2: but his fingerprints are all over the mixtape
column3: and its roots are firmly in ""B.M.F."". It's the first Rick Ross full-length with an attitude
column4: and the result is a record where it finally feels like something's at stake for the Teflon Don. The aggrieved sneer of ""…these motherfuckers mad that I'm icy!"" permeates the album
column5: and the energy derived from Ross' contempt adds an important dimension to his character
column6: one that was missing when he got too comfortable making 1
column7: 000-thread-count music. The best beats here-- the ones that act as the backbone of the album-- are appropriately sinister
column8: and actually improve on the Luger template that has dominated street rap for the past 18 months. There's the grinding churn of ""MMG Untouchable""
column9: the haunted house bombast of ""King of Diamonds""
column10: and the appropriately glistening keys of ""Yella Diamonds""
column11: beats so good they render Luger's lone actual production (""Off the Boat"") totally unnecessary.

column1: The opening quarter of Rich Forever especially drips with disdain
column2: and though deviations into radio pop and the lush instrumentation he's long cultivated do pop up
column3: Ross sets a tone for the record early that courses through every track that follows. ""B.M.F."" did happen to crest with his marked improvement as a writer
column4: but it also magnified Ross' ability to pen spectacularly outlandish and vivid boasts
column5: and he stuffs a vast number of them into the first four or five tracks here. Ross calling his chain ""the ghetto's guillotine"" on ""High Definition"" or his Corvette ""so clean you'll think Bruce Springsteen rent that"" on ""Fuck 'Em"" or conveying his hunger for money by hilariously seething that he ""likes his nachos hot"" on ""MMG Untouchable"" is the mark of the Don at work
column6: not content to merely build verses around the names of luxury sunglasses brands. And when he does retreat back to the throne for a regal track like ""Keys to the Crib"" later on the album
column7: there's an undeniably spiteful glee in his voice that's missing from his earlier albums.

column1: Ross has jarred himself out of his comfort zone and gotten his hands dirty
column2: and in doing so he's also fleshed out an image of the boss as paranoid and constantly peeking over his shoulder. ""Last Breath""
column3: which smartly tabs Meek Mill (Ross' top underling) and Birdman (the bossest of all rap bosses) for guest verses
column4: undercuts images of ringside seats and all-white Beamers with a feeling of queasy desperation and lurking mistrust. Then there's ""Stay Schemin'"" which perfectly deploys a zonked-out French Montana to mumble-sing a hook about staying one step ahead of plotting enemies. Montana sounds so stoned that it brings to mind the image of Tony Montana lurching his head up from a pile of cocaine
column5: and it's a fascinating
column6: if not bizarre
column7: end to an album that starts with Ross at his absolute meanest.

column1: ""God forgives
column2: I don't
column3: is a phrase that pops up from time to time on Rich Forever
column4: and fittingly it's slated to serve as the title of Ross' upcoming album. He'd been batting around the slogan long before this mixtape existed
column5: but Rich Forever adds vindictive muscle to a motto that at one point might have come off as a hollow attempt at branding. It's a record that uses nastiness to cement the character ""Rick Ross"" as three-dimensional
column6:
and uses a barrage of bangers to cement the rapper Rick Ross as an undeniable force.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17331/homepage_large.c5707099.jpg|Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller I|1149.0|Drexciya|['Electronic']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Clone']|2012-01-13 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:36.876364|"

Forget James Cameron and his $200 million budget: Equipped only with outdated Japanese electronics
column2: Drexciya were the true masters of the deep. From 1992 until 2002
column3: the mysterious electro outfit created not only some of Detroit's most original and enduring electronic music; they created an entire imaginary world
column4: one of the greatest myth systems in the history of techno.

column1: A new compilation of the group's work
column2: the first in a planned four-volume anthology put out by Rotterdam's Clone label
column3: serves as a crucial introduction to Drexciya's worldview as well as
column4: of course
column5: their music. It's a good time for it: In the past two decades
column6: the meaning of ""electro"" has repeatedly mutated and diluted though its association with electroclash
column7: then Ed Banger's buzzy brand of dance music
column8: and
column9: lately
column10: big-tent commercial rave like Deadmau5 and Wolfgang Gartner. The Drexciya reissue rightly returns the spotlight to the original electro's signature rhythms and analog palette.

column1: From their first release
column2: 1992's Deep Sea Dweller EP
column3: Drexciya were obsessed with sub-aquatic realms. Their first tracks bore titles like ""Sea Quake"" and ""Nautilus 12""
column4: and the following year's Bubble Metropolis EP
column5: divided into ""Fresh Water"" and ""Salt Water"" sides and with center stickers depicting dolphins cavorting beneath craggy cliffs
column6: poured it on thicker with ""Aqua Worm Hole"" and ""Danger Bay"". The music was appropriately liquid
column7: with hi-hats like raindrops
column8: bass like the belch of some fanged denizen of the fathomless dark
column9: and blippy melodies bobbing like bioluminescent lures.

column1: Adapting the lurching rhythmic template of 1980s electro-funk acts like Man Parrish
column2: Cybotron
column3: and Jonzun Crew
column4: Drexciya emphasized the depth-charge qualities of a booming 808 kick
column5: and the electric-eel jolt of a zapping filter sweep. But it went deeper than that. The music was punctuated by cryptic interludes and scraps of code
column6: like an intercepted transmission from ""Drexciyan Cruise Control Bubble 1 to Lardossan Cruiser 8 dash 203 X""
column7: a head-spinning array of names and numbers relating to something called the ""Aquabahn"".

column1: Drexciya weren't just trafficking in metaphor and affect; they were telling a story
column2: one worthy of its own blockbuster film. Their ""Aquabahn"" was
column3: of course
column4: a reference to Kraftwerk
column5: whose robotic method act set an important precedent for Drexciya's own mythmaking. Played out across track titles and cover art
column6: one sheets and liner notes
column7: it went something like this: During the Middle Passage
column8: many pregnant women
column9: sick or dying or simply too much trouble for their captors
column10: were thrown overboard. The fetuses in their wombs
column11: still accustomed to a liquid environment
column12: survived. They thrived
column13: in fact
column14: growing fins and gills
column15: and made their home in the ruins of an underwater city
column16: where they mounted their counter-offensive against human greed and stupidity.

column1: The message fit with the militant stance of Detroit's Underground Resistance label collective
column2: with which Drexciya were affiliated
column3: and so did their anonymity. When James Stinson died
column5: I'm willing to bet that most fans didn't even know his name
column6: nor that of his collaborator Gerald Donald. Drexciya were rumored to be related to other shadowy electro projects of the era
column7: like Elecktroids and Dopplereffekt-- a creepy
column8: ostensibly antihumanist project featuring showroom dummies on its record covers and vocoded lyrics like ""We have to sterilize the population""-- but in the pre-Discogs era
column9: this was all speculation. To immerse yourself in Drexciya's world was akin to following a particularly far-out comic book
column10: where the misfits wrote the rules and justice always prevailed. It was punk as fuck
column11: frankly-- but from an Afrofuturist perspective.

column1: But for all the talk of combat
column2: Drexciya's was profoundly joyful music: impish
column3: rippling
column4: unpredictable
column5: and never anything less than profoundly funky. This is the first takeaway from Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller I. This first volume focuses on the group's first five years
column6: drawing from seven EPs released on labels like Underground Resistance
column7: Submerge
column8: and Warp. (Some tracks have been anthologized before
column9: on 1997's landmark double CD The Quest
column10: but that's long out of print.) Certain tropes predominate: whip-cracking 808 drum patterns
column11: squelchy synthesizer arpeggios
column12: dissonant bleeps and creepy chromatic chord progressions. But there's nothing formulaic about these tracks
column13: which range from the pensive funk of ""Aquarazorda"" to the double-time frenzy of ""Hydro Theory"" and ""Beyond the Abyss""; it's striking to realize how wildly Drexciya's tempos could vary
column14: especially when compared to the deeply regimented BPMs of today's subgenres of electronic dance music. Indeed
column15: Drexciya made few concessions to DJs: there are no 16-bar intros to facilitate mixing
column16: and at least one point
column17: you can hear a synthesizer pattern skip a beat
column18: probably because one of the musicians leaned on his sequencer at the wrong time.

column1: Lo-fi by today's standards
column2: recorded straight to tape
column3: in real time
column4: with analog machines
column5: Drexciya's sonics are unfailingly urgent and raw; there's more genuine menace in the roiling ""Sea Quake"" than in practically anything being made today. Clone's Alden Tyrell did a great job with the remastering
column6: preserving the music's wide dynamic range and letting each frequency positively sizzle in space. As hair-raising as the songs can be
column7: it's never an exhausting listen-- unlike too much contemporary electronic music
column8: mastered so uniformly loud that it leaves your ears gasping for air.

column1: It's easy to remember Drexciya primarily for their shtick. Academics love them for their applicability to concepts like Afrofuturism and the Black Atlantic. (Kodwo Eshun was particularly brilliant writing about Drexciya; their slippery maneuvers served as the perfect foil for his own techno-theoretical poetics.) Detroit true-schoolers hold them up as examples of Motor City militancy and analog purism. These are all valid positions
column2: but Journey of the Deep Sea Dweller I also reminds us of Drexciya's influence in other contexts
column3: as well. The opening ""Welcome to Drexciya"" is a beatless burble that wouldn't sound out of place on a record from Emeralds or Oneohtrix Point Never
column4: artists more commonly associated with the ""cosmic"" traditions of 1970s synthesizer music. Space is a place
column5: sure. But to immerse yourself in Drexciya's underwater world is to be reminded that there are other dimensions just as worthy of exploration.

column1: ""Are Drexciyans water breathing
column2: aquatically mutated descendants of those unfortunate victims of human greed?"" wrote a figure identified as the Unknown Writer in the liner notes to 1997's The Quest. ""Have they been spared by God to teach us or terrorize us? Did they migrate from the Gulf of Mexico to the Mississippi river basin and on to the great lakes of Michigan? Do they walk among us? Are they more advanced than us? How and why do they make their strange music? What is their Quest? These are many of the questions that you don’t know and never will. The end of one thing… and the beginning of another. Out.""

column1: These questions had a different kind of resonance in the 1990s
column2: before the answer to every question was just a click or two away
column3: before every new ""anonymous"" artist felt like a walking
column4: talking spoiler alert. To listen to Drexciya today is to wipe the slate clean. We may know James Stinson and Gerald Donald's names now
column5:
but their quest feels as cryptic as ever.

James Ferraro is having his moment. Far Side Virtual
column2: a world-building record of Windows start-up screen sounds signifying something about worldwide web convenience and Western cluelessness
column3: landed at the top of The Wire's ""Records of the Year"" list. So polarizing was its placement though
column4: that editor-in-chief Tony Herrington felt obligated to crunch the numbers.

column1: I thought the album was pretty good. It's charming at times
column2: and conceptually solid
column3: so there isn't much to fault it for
column4: unless you want to declare the entire conceit complete bullshit
column5: which some have understandably done. ""Remember when you were a little kid dicking with your first Casio for 45 minutes?"" music critic Christopher Weingarten tweeted
column6: ""James Ferraro does that onstage as a grown man.""

column1: Far Side Virtual also seemed critic-proof
column2: which was frustrating. If you praised it
column3: well
column4: you were hip to its heady concept
column5: though backed into such a corner that soon enough it may philosophically force you to give ""Best New Track"" to your iPhone's default ringtone. Negative reviews could be dismissed as the listener's simply not getting the joke.

column1: Ferraro helped moderate reactions as well. Previously a mystery man without an email address and just a few interviews here and there (and a much noisier
column2: more interesting sound)
column3: he went public
column4: doing critics' heavy lifting himself by explicating the album's intentions to Elle
column5: The Quietus
column6: and many others. The guy went viral. He trolled his way into the music conversation. And just as Far Side Virtual inexplicably arrived on year-end lists
column7: he put out a more obnoxious release: The free
column8: victory-lap mixtape under the name Bebetune$.

column1: Inhale C-4 $$$$$ finds Ferraro developing a mutant strain of mainstream rap and R&B. Auto-Tune is mimicked
column2: the skittering snares of radio rap show up
column3: and there's special attention paid to the sloppy mastering and obnoxious DJ drops common on mixtapes. It turns out however
column4: that hip-hop actually takes some finesse and knowledge to recreate-- and Ferraro just doesn't have the skills.

column1: ""Maccau Celebrities"" cribs its melody from T-Pain and Lil Wayne's ""Can't Believe It""
column2: and though it captures the sound of Wayne's syrup-drunk croons
column3: there's no emotive charm. ""#GRINDLYFE"" has some of the demonic guitar-crunch grandiosity of Flockaveli but does nothing with it
column4: and ""H20"" squiggles around like a Timbaland rip-off. Then there's ""Street Dream$$""
column5: a failed attempt at giving Gang Gang Dance's ""Glass Jar"" the sample-slicing
column6: drum pattern piling
column7: AraabMuzik treatment. It features hi-hats and hand-claps
column8: an airhorn
column9: a dripping water sound
column10: and some Drake-like Auto-Tune-- and it's a mess. Perhaps that's the point
column11: though?

column1: ""Street Dream$$"" begins with ""I can hear everything. It's everything time
column2: from ""Glass Jar"". It's a quote Ferraro has discussed before. In his interview with The Quietus
column3: he compared the phrase to Nike's ""just do it
column4: recommending GGD sell the phrase to Google. It's contemporary rap however
column5: the sound Ferraro is either poorly approximating or lazily mocking
column6: that truly embodies ""It's everything time."" Hip-hop has embraced ""the cloud"" like no other genre
column7: pouring MP3s onto the internet with little interest in how they fit onto an 80-minute CD
column8: running a flowering
column9: free internet industry right alongside the desiccated major-label album landscape.

column1: Instead of celebrating rap's industry-bucking impulse
column2: Ferraro misreads the signs and signifiers of the mixtape world as amateurism. DJ and producer tags echoing around in the background of rap tracks not only serve a pragmatic function in an era of no liner notes
column3: telling you who produced a track or put together the album
column4: but add some chaos that can skyrocket an already awesome song onto another plateau. They're part of the fun.

column1: In a 2010 interview with Hip-Hop Game
column2: AraabMuzik explained his aesthetic choices: ""I never sampled off vinyl. I've always been digital with it. Mp3 quality. I'm not really with the cracks and the old-sounding
column3: rough
column4: rugged-type sound... I'm with the clear
column5: quality sound."" See
column6: hip-hop's tinny
column7: digitized scream isn't a mistake-- it's a modern update of the golden era's warm
column8: analog hiss.

column1: Whether it's mainstream hitmaker Lex Luger and his snarling trap-rap maximalism
column2: or the gossamer
column3: stoned-out electronica of internet beatmakers like the Block Beattaz and Clams Casino
column4: it should occur to Ferraro that he's got a lot in common with rap's creative types. Or maybe he's aware of that and just has a snarky way of showing it. Because the tracks here feel endless
column5: like uninspired
column6: snarky parodies of rap instrumentals
column7: roving along for too long
column8: filled with too many recycled ideas and yet
column9:
not one worth considering.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17283/homepage_large.210a7cab.jpg|Fabriclive 61|5922.0|Pinch|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2012-01-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:38.098273|"

When Bristol legend Pinch released the out-of-nowhere ""Croydon House"" in 2010-- on the London-based Swamp81 instead of his own foundational Tectonic imprint-- it felt like a sea change. One of dubstep's most influential pioneers
column2: one of its diehard careerists
column3: had made his own version of a house record (and this was before 2011 when it became the norm). In keeping with his usual heads-down dubstep
column4: however
column5: ""Croydon House"" was murky
column6: dim-lit
column7: and paranoid
column8: not your standard garage-influenced thumper
column9: and his tracks since have seen him navigate a no man's land of in-between tempos and experimental rhythms
column10: culminating in the bewildering Pinch and Shackleton collaborative album at the end of last year. It goes beyond just productions: This summer
column11: Pinch started incorporating house into his DJ sets
column12: dedicating sections of his timeslots to the 4/4 stuff. Was he moving on from dubstep?

column1: It's this many-limbed and flailing
column2: vaguely house
column3: vaguely techno hinterland that Rob Ellis' long-overdue entry in the Fabriclive mix series occupies: The drums still swing and shake with that tribal energy that marks his best dubstep work
column4: but there's not always the snare on the third
column5: and sometimes there's a four-to-the-floor kick. The mix begins mid-track and cleverly continues the conceptual current that's been running through commercial mix CDs as of late: think Four Tet's own Fabriclive go for a similar example of artiness run amok in a dance mix. The nervily pulsating throb of Atlanta producer Distal's ""Venom"" both opens and closes the set
column6: sealing it into a closed circle that
column7: at least in its peripheries
column8: raises questions about the linearity of mixes in the first place. There's an obvious left-to-right motion here
column9: but there's no grand closer
column10: pensive opener
column11: or any real climax: Left to its own devices
column12: Pinch's mix never really ends
column13: the same bumpy journey over and over again
column14: bubbling and bubbling but refusing to boil over. Does it need to end for it to be a satisfying product? According to Pinch
column15: apparently not.

column1: This little tweak allows Ellis to play around with the sequencing
column2: and Fabriclive 61 begins with a gallop
column3: running through a surprisingly techno-tinged opening stretch
column4: with French producer F's overlooked (and hugely inventive) ""Slow Down"" colliding with Shed's latest in his rave-techno EQD alias: it's an almost confrontational greeting from someone once associated with the purest of dubstep
column5: and a true sign of the times for both the genre and one of its most prominent heroes.  The mix continues in this vein before fading out into beatless-near silence with Roly Porter's gorgeous mechano-classical ""Hessra""-- at which point Pinch's remix of Photek's ""Acid Reign"" storms out
column6: bringing the mix into more familiar 140-bpm dubstep territory.

column1: Where some recent dubstep mixes like Youngsta's Rinse CD or Distance's Dubstep Allstars Vol. 8 were fine showcases of the genre's steadfast traditionalist communities
column2: they were nevertheless tainted by the genre's turn inward (or the formulaic). Pinch's selection of pounding kicks
column3: crash-landing snares
column4: and LFO growls
column5: however
column6: sound both more vital and crucially more alien(ating) than ever. His choice of producers is impeccable
column7: mixing in old stalwarts who are at career highs (Distance's sound is as mean as its ever been
column8: and Goth-Trad's lost in some LSD rabbithole) and producers like Roska and Addison Groove who provide strange
column9: unconventional takes on the median dubstep tempo. It's the most exciting 30 minutes of relatively pure ""dubstep"" since Appleblim's career-defining <i>Dubstep Allstars Vol. 6
column10: taking that staggered ""dungeon sound"" and infusing it with all the psychological paranoia and jagged
column11: jigsaw-puzzle rhythms that defined his own best work
column12: both dubstep and otherwise.

column1: So how do we get from dubstep back to whatever Distal's ""Venom"" is supposed to be? Ellis one-ups the ""Hessra"" play
column2: dropping the loping limp of Illum Sphere's ""Promise a Secret""-- a tightknit blend of hyper-compressed string samples that's eventually gutted by Distal's more assertive track-- on top of Om Unit's jerky ""Pressure"". Which brings us right back to where we started
column3: traversing the most current iterations of the bass music continuum as viewed through Pinch's dusty
column4: obsidian lens.

column1: What makes the halving between tempos less jarring is Pinch's distinct aesthetic: the music here is damaged
column2: blackened
column3: and always foreboding
column4: no matter what tempo it's pounding at or what genre it might be interrogating. That unrelenting blackness can be suffocating
column5: and it's definitely unfriendly
column6: but it's never boring-- which is a lot more than you can say about most ""dubstep"" mixes these days. So while Pinch might not have moved on from dubstep completely
column7: he's definitely moved somewhere
column8:
and it sounds like an exciting place to be.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['JUKBOXR']|2012-01-13 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:38.679468|"

From the remote musical enclave of Fort Lauderdale
column3: the young electronic songwriter Malcom Lacey has posted five Arrange albums on Bandcamp over the past couple of years. High productivity is common among laptop-wielding bedroom auteurs
column4: but Lacey's no data dumper. Each release exhibits unity and care-- its own twist on a rapidly developing sound. The first one I discovered
column5: before anyone knew much about Arrange
column6: was Plantation
column7: which I said was ""thoroughly a breakup record."" But I was wrong.

column1: Now that Lacey has done a little press-- such as this interview with a South Florida weekly-- we know more. His first instrument was the piano; he's more inclined to slave over his ambient textures in private than to play shows in public; he likes Type Records and Perfume Genius. None of this was surprising. But one assertion caught me off guard: ""Most of my lyrical content stems itself from an abusive childhood and the relationship I share with my incarcerated father
column2: with whom Plantation standout ""When'd You Find Me?"" was a ""one-way conversation.""

column1: The revelation casts new light on Lacey's lyrics
column2: which draw opposed qualities-- hostility and tenderness
column3: discretion and confession
column4: self-hatred and self-help-- into uneasy truces. (He'd have fit in well on Saddle Creek in the early 2000s.) On new EP Five Years With the Sun
column5: Lacey is even more furtive than on Plantation
column6: his halting voice washing in and out of audibility
column7: and vanishing for long periods. In hushed tones
column8: he dramatizes the process of a gentle person grappling with dark thoughts-- now scathing
column9: now contrite
column10: lashing out and lashing in. His reticence comes to seem like an impulse for self-erasure
column11: which makes the moments when he overcomes it feel especially poignant.

column1: Is this palpable struggle what distinguishes Arrange from a thousand similar peers? It certainly isn't the music's substance
column2: a fairly standard amalgamation of synth-pop
column3: shoegaze
column4: ambient
column5: chillwave
column6: and hip-hop. Nor is it any iconoclastic style-- to the contrary
column7: I prize its preternatural patience and humility. And Lacey is already developing a go-to track structure
column8: which has a smoothly churning undercarriage of piano or guitar tones
column9: ranks of juicy synthetic plucks pulsing above
column10: and mechanical drums splashing the edges of the beats; all topped off with a synth lead that flaps like a tattered banner in a sluggish wind.

column1: Maybe it's something even harder to quantify: that vigilant
column2: moody
column3: quietly rapturous sensibility. While the orders of the day are pleasantly zoned-out or ethereally spiritual
column4: Lacey's music feels almost feverishly alert
column5: with breath-catching pauses and mercurial embellishments calling for close attention to its dreamy flow. Below the Kompakt-isms
column6: one hears the dulcet
column7: revolving intervals of the lullaby. This is music as a ward or charm
column8: its hermetic regularity holding a safe space against chaos. (It was recorded
column9: I'm told
column10: in a walk-in closet.) It doesn't sound like a young man hunting for blog buzz. It sounds like a personal search for redemption
column11: or at least some consolation
column12: one moment at a time.

column1: Careful sequencing makes Five Years With the Sun feel like an act of tentative revelation through gradual ascent. The immediate pop songs are divided by obscure but quirkily elegant set pieces: ""Gone With the Snow""
column2: where bizarrely treated vocals ride over glassy swells; ""Airplane Notes""
column3: a study in nocturnal counterpoint. The force gathered on the first half rises to a vertex on ""Cure""
column4: a burly production where Lacey opens up his voice with unaccustomed extroversion. ""Mt. Rainer"" vividly evokes traveling up switchbacks
column5: the winds and vistas bending around
column6: leading us up to the bright
column7: clear peak of closer ""Sun Showers""
column8: where all the album's fogs dispel.

column1: ""There's a glow/ and I can feel it
column2: Lacey sings plainly
column3: ""deep below the hollow point of me."" A couple of inaudibly murmured lines later
column4: we hear
column5: ""the way I felt when I first heard it say…"" But the thought goes unfinished. Instead
column6: a long instrumental passage culminates in a weary guitar anthem
column7: then peters out into running waters. He's not the type to make a sound just to fill space; he waits until he knows what he has to say. That's what keeps me hanging on every moment. Enticingly
column8: the open-ended conclusion of Five Years With the Sun promises more striving
column9: more growth
column10:
more suffering and deliverance to come.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17308/homepage_large.6501ffe3.jpg|Alone III: The Pinkerton Years|5558.0|Rivers Cuomo|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Geffen']|2012-01-12 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:39.507982|"

You'd think Alone III: The Pinkerton Years would work like Rivers Cuomo's past installments of vault clearance: In exchange for being offered these very #rare and #based freestyles
column2: you
column3: Weezer Superfan
column4: will not do something so petty as to question the need for their release. Ah
column5: but note the subtitle: ""The Pinkerton Years."" It's a powerful but potentially dangerous sales pitch. Alone III comes sidelong with The Pinkerton Diaries
column6: a $75 (and thus collectors-only) volume that compiles Cuomo's ""journals
column7: emails
column8: letters
column9: photos
column10: and school papers"" from the Pinkerton era and offers ""an intimate look into the writing and recordings of Rivers Cuomo from 1994-1997."" Which threatens not only redundancy but a complete undermining of Pinkerton's integrity. ""I thought Pinkerton was Cuomo's diary
column11: you might be thinking. ""He was holding back on us? Editing?"" Does this compromise the perceived purity of such a powerful record?

column1: Then again
column2: Pinkerton has always been accompanied by a healthy serving of half-truths
column3: tall tales
column4: and revisionist history. But you can see why so many want to give it a protected status: Cuomo was far more embarrassed by its Billboard failure than anything he actually said on Pinkerton
column5: and his output since then has been the work of someone with severe commercial abandonment issues. But Alone III doesn't feel like a cash-in like the Pinkerton reissue or 2010's Memories Tour
column6: in which the band (minus bassist Matt Sharp) played their first two albums in full. No
column7: this is something else entirely. With its whiplash sequencing (26 tracks in far less than an hour)
column8: low production values
column9: minute-long asides
column10: and pause-record tape overdubs
column11: Alone III seems to ask: What would've happened if Rivers Cuomo had wanted to be Robert Pollard or Lou Barlow for the rest of the 90s?

column1: So if you value these archaeological digs as an opportunity to construct an alternate band history
column2: Alone III is easily Cuomo's most worthwhile project since
column3: well
column4: Pinkerton. But what's truly surprising is that it satisfies in actuality as much as it does in theory
column5: and not just because it puts a bunch of Pinkerton songs in the mix. Alone III actually deconstructs that record by spreading out into three sections
column6: providing anchors for Cuomo's mini-suite ambitions rather than the lead-up to Pinkerton's autobiographical payoff (""Across the Sea""
column7: ""The Good Life""). Fully formed but raw-as-hell versions of ""Getchoo"" and ""Tired of Sex"" mesh easily with Cuomo's off-the-cuff material and allow Alone III to exist in its own orbit as a no-fi
column8: freewheeling
column9: and ultimately fun record that either Geffen or Weezer wouldn't allow themselves to ever release in the midst of the record industry's then-booming economy.

column1: Even with the impression that Cuomo is dipping into his private stock
column2: a lot of this will be familiar to non-diehards
column3: like the two-minute surge of ""You Gave Your Love to Me Softly"" that leans to the latter side of ""pop-punk"" and could've replaced ""Why Bother?"" on Pinkerton with a 180-degree attitude change. And it's tough to imagine Weezer ever pulling off something like ""Lisa"". Its blues-bend Kiss riffs would've been employed too smirkingly
column4: its charming chorus harmonies polished to anonymity
column5: and its lyric about a workplace crush (""I wish I didn't work for you/ All we ever seem to do is business/ Read and sign and fax this"") extended beyond its means into dad-humor.

column1: So those are the reasons why III is the most like an actual Weezer album of any of the Alone records
column2: and the least like a Cuomo yard sale. But the real pleasure is in how Alone III casts the creative up-ramp to Pinkerton as an inspired if not always productive time for Cuomo-- you can practically visualize his brain giddily whirring with a flood of new ideas and classicist ambitions. Sure
column3: there are 50-second sketches that have limited replay value outside of Alone III
column4: but they keep the end-to-end listen brisk and pleasurable. Elsewhere
column5: some songs are so self-explanatory and complete that they don't need much elaboration (""I'm So Lonely on a Saturday Night"")
column6: others crash into a dead end (""Oh God
column7: I'm Hungry""
column8: ""The End of My String"")
column9: and of course
column10: some are just flat out unlistenable (""What Is This I Find?"").

column1: In a Spin interview leading up to Pinkerton's re-release
column2: Cuomo expressed why he enjoyed going back to these tapes even though he's far more excited by his new material
column3: saying ""I was really touched by the emotion in my voice… there's so much sensitivity and pain."" Alone III's last track would seem to reiterate that: On ""One Glorious Moment""
column4: Cuomo gives a post-operation captain's log
column5: confiding to a tape recorder
column6: ""I actually peed for the first time on my own… it was a glorious moment. I'm going to try to set up some music to listen to
column7: goodbye."" That candor can be seen as being every bit as self-obsessed and pandering as Hurley or Death to False Metal
column8: but that last line sticks out. Alone III is a bracing
column9:
imperfect reminder of a time when music was something Cuomo just couldn't live without.

Glitch is one of those microgenres that seemed to disappear halfway through the last decade. When the German outfit Oval-- early on reduced to founding member Markus Popp-- made its return in 2010 with O
column3: it was hard to decide how to react. Especially since O was one of its most difficult and fussy efforts yet
column4: and largely divorced from Oval's previously established and instantly recognizable aesthetic as heard on landmarks like 94 Diskont and Ovalcommers. With a palette based on the sound of live instruments
column5: O lacked some of the algorithmic wizardry of Popp's best work and was a fatiguingly lengthy listen either way. You'd be forgiven for thinking that OvalDNA
column6: coming just a year later and clocking in with another 25 tracks-- and this after the complementary 15-track 12"" Oh-- is something like overkill.

column1: Here's the surprise: OvalDNA is actually a collection of bits and bytes from assorted Oval eras past. The even bigger surprise? While it indeed sounds like the old Oval we know and love
column2: there's nothing even remotely scatterbrained or assorted about this one. Not only is OvalDNA remarkably consistent and thematically sound
column3: it's so well-sequenced that its 25 tracks fly by in a glorious
column4: easygoing blur
column5: a far cry from that fatal fragmentation that ate away at O. Its variety renders these sounds in a fluid and volatile technicolor missing from even early records like Systemisch. In a way
column6: it's the best of both Oval worlds.  Included in the package is a DVD with ten bonus tracks
column7: a music video
column8: a documentary
column9: and 2000 AIFF files of sounds and elements from the entirety of Popp's musical output ""intended for music producers.""  Okay
column10: so maybe it's a little overkill
column11: but coming from an artist who made a public installation inviting people to render their own interpretations of his work (as part of 2000's Ovalprocess)
column12: it shouldn't really come as a surprise either.

column1: Like so much of this music
column2: sometimes it's hard to tell whether or not the decay and destruction that pries apart the layers is accidental or planned
column3: but here the manipulation feels effortless
column4: executed with a smart and steady hand. There are many varieties of Oval on offer
column5: though it's most often a warm-hued
column6: even honeyed sound palette rather than the acerbic distortion of
column7: say
column8: Ovalcommers. While some tracks like ""Savvy"" do focus on harsher
column9: more challenging sounds
column10: even these-- or the hushed
column11: rushed thermal swooshing of ""70 Kino"" and its choked string section-- feel oddly accommodating. OvalDNA doesn't dip into the same well of asceticism as the conceptually driven sound-design experiments you'll find on labels like Mille Plateaux or Raster-Noton; instead
column12: each stutter and skip feels melodically driven
column13: each sample caught and clipped mid-moment like a key to some larger world of musical delights that we're given glimpses of but are never actually led to-- dig the teases at jungle on ""Mare Fax""-- on account of the album's sprightly pace.

column1: Even if it can be a tease
column2: some moments on OvalDNA are downright welcoming: It's hard to think of anything from Oval since the legendary ""Do While"" as beautiful as ""Australasia"". One of the album's more compositionally complete tracks
column3: it juggles jerkily plucked strings
column4: organs that whir to life before being pulled apart into groaning rumbles
column5: and drums that stutter across the stereo spectrum at random. That might sound like a mess
column6: but the elements just slightly coalesce to form a stirring
column7: heart-tugging refrain gently morphing over the track's three-and-a-half minutes
column8: a chief example of the accidental alchemy of OvalDNA. ""Octaeder 0.2""
column9: which formed the centerpiece to Oval's live contribution to the Henri Pousseur tribute 4 Parabolic Mixes
column10: proves the emotional potential of these flurries of compressed ones and zeroes
column11: while the more recent Oval material is at least coincidentally referenced with a number of tracks that make live-instrument samples their focus (""Credit Line"")
column12: stumbling on an odd hybrid of acoustic and computerized sounds in the process
column13: like twang rendered with right angles.

column1: Approachability is one thing
column2: and OvalDNA has it in spades
column3: but there's also the issue of relevance: Can a veteran act in a largely outmoded genre still command attention with an outtakes collection? Certainly
column4: any fan of Oval (particularly those lapsed after O) will find a lot to love in OvalDNA's gentle reassurances
column5: but even for a newcomer
column6: these sounds are idiosyncratic and stimulating enough to get lost in. OvalDNA is curiously timeless
column7: as if these tracks were encased in amber
column8: still holding that intriguingly alien gleam and shine as back in Oval's halcyon days
column9: even polished up a little nicer this time. It might not be something we knew we still needed
column10: but at the least
column11:
OvalDNA is a solid addition to the canon of one of the most innovative electronic acts of the 1990s.
