Harlem rapper Vado has transformed himself from Cam'ron's unwelcome new sidekick to a mini prince of NYC goon-rap (with 2010's Slime Flu and last year's Gunz n' Butta) to
column2: currently
column3: That New York Guy Who Isn't Uncle Murda or French Montana-- all in the space of
column4: oh
column5: about a year and a half. In case you were wondering
column6: yes
column7: New York is still a brutal
column8: bewildering
column9: dizzying place to try and make it as a rapper
column10: and yes
column11: keeping up with rap nowadays is still basically a full-time job.

column1: That said
column2: I've had more fun listening to Vado (that's Violence and Drugs Only
column3: if you're curious) in the past two years than I have almost anyone else. He's funnier than French Montana and a much better rapper than Murda. Most of the fun stems from the sheer
column4: bellowing-gasbag sound of Vado's voice
column5: which cuts through basically anything you put in front of it. He's a whoopee cushion of infectious ignorance
column6: and he has a class clown's way with ensuring his remarks travel all the way to the front of the room. But he's also a crafty rapper
column7: and his latest mixtape
column8: Slime Flu 2
column9: delivers exactly what the original Slime Flu did-- high-speed
column10: tightly realized
column11: pugilistic goon rap-- to nearly as entertaining results.

column1: If it suffers at all
column2: it's largely because it feels and sounds too rushed-out
column3: perhaps in an attempt to re-spark Vado's fast-cooling buzz. He should have kept the album in production for a few more minutes-- even for a free rap mixtape
column4: the mastering is atrocious. The beats knock
column5: but even with headphones
column6: they seem to be bumping through a neighbor's wall
column7: and Vado's voice often sounds distractingly disembodied in the mix. This is odd and regrettable
column8: since the first Slime Flu banged loud and clear wherever you played it
column9: but there is still lots to enjoy. Top honors goes to Vado's ""inspiration"" joint
column10: ""I See You (Black People)""
column11: which surely deserves an award for mind-blowing use of a song-title parenthetical. The song
column12: built on a sepia-tinted piano loop and hand percussion
column13: all but dims the lights and burns the incense
column14: but apart from a single Obama namedrop
column15: Vado's not having it: ""Didn't notice
column16: recession happened when?""

column1: This irrepressible goofiness is the key to Vado's charm. Give him a beat
column2: any beat
column3: and he'll bludgeon his way through it like Yosemite Sam
column4: shooting in all directions. On ""Slime Anthem""
column5: he reinforces his loose Diplomats affiliation by putting together a blatant homage to ""Dipset (Santana's Town)""
column6: and his eyeball-rattling shouting is a dead ringer for Juelz Santana's. But his crisp way with words also allows him to kick gnarled
column7: writerly raps alongside a mumbling Raekwon on the very Raekwonishly titled ""Bed Piss"" without ever sounding young or out of his depth. He can kick funny
column8: credible game to ladies when he feels like it without turning syrupy or abandoning his rap style
column9: just like his mentor Cam'ron (who
column10: by the way
column11: Vado kept from the stage this time) on ""Louis V. Bag"" and ""All the Drama"". There are a couple of fun surprises
column12: too: freestyles over ""Ms. Fat Booty"" (he calls it ""Ms. Slime Booty""
column13: which he should have maybe rethought) and the plush beat from Kingdom Come's ""The Prelude""
column14: one of that album's few salvageable numbers.

column1: Absolutely none of this is earth-shaking
column2: nor does it carry that burning sense of now that keeps the frenetic pulse of street-rap moving forward. But Vado will be okay; New York may devour its own
column3: but if he can keep putting out solid projects like this one once or twice a year
column4: he can count on a small
column5: local-hero following. Maybe there's a Lloyd Banks-style <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dTR7yvONCV8"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Beamer
column6:
Benz or Bentley"" surprise hit for dude four or five years down the line. It would make me happy to see. Every city needs a solid B-team.

column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Feeding Tube']|2012-01-12 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:42.330923|"

It's hard to pinpoint the beginning of no wave
column3: the abrasive post-punk movement in late-1970s New York. But its legacy had a big bang. It came in the form of an unnamed festival at Manhattan's Artists Space
column4: spanning five nights in May 1978. Brian Eno happened to attend
column5: and what he saw and heard led him to produce No New York
column6: a scene-defining sampler that remains the most well-known no wave record. Some claim it also helped kill the scene
column7: but it's doubtful that any of the music would have such a strong ongoing influence without Eno's compilation.

column1: Though No New York included some great work from its four participants-- the Contortions
column2: Teenage Jesus & the Jerks
column3: Mars
column4: and DNA-- no wave fanatics have longed for audio documentation of the Artists Space festival itself
column5: and rumors have persisted that tapes exist. In 2008 two Teenage Jesus songs from the fest showed up on a new collection of their work
column6: but that's been it. Now Feeding Tube has worked with Mars bassist Mark Cunningham to offer the entirety of his band's two-set performance on a single LP.

column1: It's fitting that Mars are the first Artists Space participants to get such a release
column2: because the quartet's 1975 beginnings made them technically the first no wave band. But their elemental importance goes beyond mere chronology. Inside their brief lifespan lie the deconstructive
column3: anti-careerist seeds that drove the movement. Cunningham saw their arc as ""a countdown from ten to one
column4: and through their sliver of recorded output-- 11 songs totaling barely over a half-hour-- the tired rules of rock got pummeled into abstract art-noise.

column1: The same goes for the two sets here
column2: each of which takes up an album side and contains identical songs and running order. When the band revs up with ""3E"" and ""Helen Fordsdale""
column3: their riffy Velvet Underground leanings are apparent beneath amp distortion and vocal squalls. But only a few minutes later
column4: singer Sumner Crane babbles and growls unintelligibly
column5: guitarist China Burg lights string fireworks
column6: and every shard of sound melts like a pile of wicked witches. That path of destruction is even more intense in the darker
column7: nastier-sounding second set. It culminates in a brutal take on ""Tunnel""
column8: as Crane's insane howls make the studio version sound like a dance remix.

column1: Oddly
column2: for a band this wild and abstract
column3: such divergence is rather rare here. Most songs are played live the way Mars played them in the studio
column4: a testament to how controlled and honed their seemingly chaotic music actually was. Where you can hear a difference is in fidelity. Live at Artists Space is somewhat tinny and flat
column5: in a way that could wear out uninitiated ears. Part of that can be chalked up to dated source material. But the second set was recorded on professional equipment by the band's label head
column6: Charles Ball
column7: leading some to suggest reasonably that more mastering care (as well as more imagination in the cover design) could have improved this record significantly.

column1: Still
column2: Mars' performances during that now-legendary weekend are powerful enough to shine through technical limitations. Because their time was so short
column3: the band spent each moment at a high pitch. All their spilling energy had real purpose-- to show how quickly and thoroughly rock could be demolished using the tools that built it. Live at Artists Space may hiss
column4: but it also crackles with that enervated inspiration. If it's mostly for aficionados
column5:
that's ok-- anyone interested in Mars at all is likely a devotee.

"|16166.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16166-live-at-artists-space/|6.8|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17325/homepage_large.4a0a7a06.jpg|Rush Hour Presents Amsterdam All Stars|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rush Hour']|2012-01-12 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:43.021862|"

It says something about the state of electronic dance music that my favorite aspect of Rush Hour Presents Amsterdam All Stars is the fact that ""Vol. 1"" doesn't follow its title. Not that a second volume would be unwelcome; it's that we're in the midst of a run in which most compilations (from the big houses
column2: at least) are weighty
column3: extra-long attempts to define a genre
column4: rep a label
column5: or map a career. They are
column6: in other words
column7: short historical arcs offered by a scene that is still learning how to manage its past. In this context
column8: All Stars is a breath of fresh air
column9: purporting to offer nothing more than a glimpse of the current house music talent operating in or originating from Amsterdam
column10: Rush Hour's home base since 1997.

column1: The 12 exclusive tracks offered here are
column2: as advertised
column3: a set of raucous
column4: 4/4 shakers born in the 1980s in Chicago but possessing updated wardrobes. Given the label it's hardly a surprise
column5: but it bears mentioning that All Stars has absolutely nothing to do with the squeaky arena-fodder known as ""Dirty Dutch"" or Dutch House. All Stars might plausibly be presented as an alternative were it not for the fact that the very existence of labels like Rush Hour and their fanbases are testaments to the desire for substitutes. (If a massive Afrojack fan hears this comp and has her eureka moment
column6: I'll swear off colored vinyl for a year.)

column1: On the whole All Stars is dense and bold
column2: casting off any minimalist impulses in favor of buzzy machinations that rely on manicured loops in lieu of samples. I hesitate to describe this as an ""Amsterdam sound
column3: as it's more likely the result of a youth-oriented lineup. Dexter
column4: Melon
column5: and Newworldaquarium constitute the old guard here
column6: the latter's ""Liberty Hot"" being the comp's most sexual and incisive rhythm. But really the show is in the hands of contemporaries like Tom Trago
column7: whose foggy
column8: see-sawing ""Once Upon a Time in Amsterdam"" stirs my urban Euro fetishism
column9: and the perpetually on-the-verge Juju & Jordash
column10: whose brushed-steel drum programming is refreshingly aggressive. The standout newcomer is Maxi Mill
column11: a producer confident enough to stop momentum mid-track to make way for a burr-laden bassline.

column1: There are too many rote sawing strings and punchy synth pads
column2: but Rush Hour proves that Amsterdam is big enough to supply the talent and small enough to prevent All Stars from seeming unwieldy or obvious. If there's an overarching goal here it appears to be to convince you that you could have a good time at an Amsterdam club on a Thursday without a touring DJ in town. Used-CD bins are stuffed with obscure and ultra-specific house compilations from the early 90s. All Stars' small-ball focus is a throwback in this way; five years from now it will likely offer little utility
column3:
though I wouldn't make the same bet about the artists contained herein.

"|16169.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16169-rush-hour-presents-amsterdam-all-stars/|6.4|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17320/homepage_large.b31365d3.jpg|Live at the Paramount|3046.0|Nirvana|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Geffen']|2012-01-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:43.528998|"

One month after Nirvana released Nevermind
column2: they performed a gig at Seattle's Paramount Theatre on Halloween. A week after the show
column3: Nevermind would crack the Top 40. A month later
column4: it would be certified Gold. ""Smells Like Teen Spirit"" was climbing to alarming heights on the Billboard chart. There was an imposing phalanx of video cameras present at the venue
column5: to capture the gig in its entirety. The band was
column6: understandably
column7: a little freaked.

column1: There is plenty of live Nirvana already available to us: the half-hearted-feeling rush job that was From the Muddy Banks of the Wishkah in 1996; the commercial release
column2: last year
column3: of the beloved bootleg Live at Reading; the Unplugged record. But the joy of Live at the Paramount is hearing the charge of this moment: a great band newly famous
column4: still reeling and flooded with nervy adrenaline. Every single song on this setlist has already been featured once
column5: or more
column6: on some other Nirvana live record. But it's still invaluable.

column1: Kurt's voice sounds remarkably powerful here: He sang in a way that was obviously unsustainable
column2: even with the aid of heavy cough syrup
column3: and there's a thrill
column4: although a slightly selfish one
column5: of hearing his voice rip the air before he had begun to scream it down to the threads. His peculiar
column6: yowling phrasing may have been a deliberate choice
column7: or it might have been the only way he managed to wrangle those notes from a constricted voice box
column8: but there is a terrible
column9: riveting intensity to it: Words feel torn from him
column10: bearing fishhooks on their way out. ""Aneurysm""'s ""Love you so much/ It makes me sick"" becomes ""Laahve yeww sowl much et makes me SECK."" It physically hurts to hear
column11: as it always has
column12: but it gives you some of the most committed
column13: clear performances of Nirvana's canonical songs as you're likely to get.

column1: There is some time-capsule fun to have listening to Paramount-- one of the biggest cheers is for ""School""! Krist Novoselic makes a wince-inducing ""Smile
column2: you're on 'Candid Camera'"" joke! But the album's queerest
column3: and most fascinating
column4: punk-rock sociological moment comes from the protracted lead-up to ""Smells Like Teen Spirit""
column5: which was already the elephant in the room. You can practically see the feet-dragging and hand-twisting that leads up to it
column6: like antsy kids being herded into Sunday service.

column1: First
column2: Novoselic makes some noncommittal crack about the absence of Halloween constumes in the crowd (""unless you're all supposed to be punk rockers."") Then they play ""Floyd the Barber""
column3: one of the least melodic and sludgiest songs in the catalog. Afterward
column4: a time-killing little tongue-in-cheek instrumental jam. Then
column5: Novoselic's voice cuts back into the mic
column6: as he hollers
column7: curiously
column8: ""White boy funk sucks!"" Only after all this fidgeting is finished do those chords fire up. In the moment you can hear roaring to life the enormous machine that would
column9: less than a year later
column10: take Nevermind to multi-platinum status. The version is anything but noncommittal-- Cobain leans into every ""a denial"" harder than the last. It's exhilarating and poignant. You can hear they still unambiguously love this song
column11:
even if it was starting to make things complicated for them.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17294/homepage_large.2adb7c5c.jpg|Henge Beat|30145.0|Total Control|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Iron Lung']|2012-01-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:44.024400|"

For the most part
column2: ""supergroup"" is a relative term. It's a descriptor that itself holds a load of other nebulous
column3: subjective ideas
column4: such as ""success
column5: ""relevance
column6: and the notion of a ""primary band."" But with musicians-- especially nowadays-- being prone to enlist in three or four groups at a time
column7: devoting a fairly even amount of attention to all of them
column8: is there any way to logically keep track of which bands are bands and which bands are side-projects or supergroups?

column1: Total Control are as close to a supergroup as a tandem of cult Australian punks can get. Each member is involved in another band
column2: the most well-known of which being guitarist Mikey Young's Eddy Current Suppression Ring-- which
column3: if you only have a passing knowledge of current garage-rock
column4: can elicit the same sort of confused blank stare as if you told someone your band's most famous member also plays in the Growlers. Thankfully
column5: when mild obscurity is on a group's side
column6: they are allowed few expectations to conquer and the chance to legitimately surprise people. But even if you're intimately familiar with Eddy Current Suppression Ring
column7: UV Race
column8: Straightjacket Nation
column9: and the Collapse
column10: Henge Beat is startlingly good; good enough to surpass even the top-shelf efforts from the members' other bands.

column1: As you might expect from a band named after a six-minute Motels single
column2: Total Control possess a rich knowledge of a very specific point in music history. Though bearing no resemblance to the song in which they've derived their name
column3: most of their key influences were very much active in 1979
column4: the year the single was released. Opener ""See More Glass"" is indebted to Suicide's second self-titled album. Shades of late-period Roxy Music can be found in closer ""Love Performance"". Wire
column5: the Buzzcocks
column6: Joy Division
column7: and Swell Maps all slow up in the strands of Total Control's DNA.

column1: But if Henge Beat were simply a 36-minute post-punk genre exercise
column2: it wouldn't be nearly as entertaining. The band explores a different realm of possibilities in every song
column3: punctuating creeping lurches with ear-splitting explosions and delivering spacey instrumentals not incredibly far removed from elevator music right after. ""The Hammer"" is eerie
column4: black-clad darkwave. ""Shame Thugs"" sounds like alternate title screen music for beloved Super Nintendo RPG EarthBound. ""No Bibs"" comes off like SST hardcore thrown into vertigo. (If you have an older sibling that grew up in the 1980s and passed you all of their coolest punk records when they went off to college
column5: give them a copy of Henge Beat and they may shed actual tears of joy.)

column1: As if the ultra-cohesive fusion of punk music's fruitful first decade wasn't enough
column2: Dan Stewart (Straightjacket Nation) makes for a compelling frontman
column3: a lyricist weaned on Salinger and Philip K. Dick whose vocal range stays in the pocket but exhibits a great deal of versatility regardless. His taste in literature proves that he knows the value of a good narrator: The greedy factory owner in ""Retiree"" barks
column4: ""keep them at work
column5: in an icy
column6: robotic tone while looking at a gold watch ticking down the days. ""Meds II"" captures the redundancy of self-medicated culture-- through methods both legal and otherwise-- with the lyric
column7: ""Taking pills to remember to take pills to forget.""

column1: ""Love Performance"" can sound glittery and optimistic due to its blinking neon synths and ""these are not the last days"" refrain
column2: but it's actually a rumination on our fantasies of being eulogized (""In the last days
column3: they'll sing your praise"")
column4: finding Stewart pitching rocks at the celebratory stance of the supposedly righteous whenever they think the world's number is being called (think Y2k
column5: the rapture
column6: the end of the Mayan calendar). Album centerpiece ""Carpet Rash"" finds Stewart at his most detached vocally while crafting an array of evocative imagery (""Drinking detergent and licking the walls/ Eating your breakfast in shower stalls"")
column7: writing a song that fully embodies how desperate
column8: unfulfilling
column9: and hopeless sex can sometimes be.

column1: Throughout the entirety of Henge Beat
column2: there is a sharp fluidity in all of its elements
column3: from the interplay of the band's members to its lyrical concepts. In spite of being primarily described as a composite of members from other groups
column4:
Total Control display the kind of unity that veteran bands take years to cultivate. They make you realize that a lot of the best ""supergroups"" are merely regular old groups with members noteworthy for being excellent at what they do.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17310/homepage_large.ef1ffffa.jpg|Shadows EP|28145.0|Floating Points|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Eglo']|2012-01-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:44.572572|"

Versatility is tricky. Unless you're a legit polymath
column2: it's as easy to spread yourself thin as it is to create compelling work across several spectra. Polymath may still be in play for Sam Shepherd: In addition to his work as Floating Points
column3: he's a classically trained musician
column4: (outré-)jazz enthusiast and bandleader
column5: an in-demand DJ
column6: and a PhD candidate in molecular genetics. He is the brainy
column7: footloose heir to Four Tet's wild-eyed beatsmith throne (London seat). In addition to his range
column8: it's tempting to let these activities tell us something else about Shepherd: They all point toward studious refinement. Shadows
column9: a 2x12"" nearing 40 minutes in length
column10: suggests that Shepherd continues to filter his approach to rhythm and melody.

column1: To date Shepherd's varying output has bordered on the maximal. The Vacuum EP-- still one of the finest slabs of vinyl to emerge from a London scene that also gave birth to James Blake
column2: Joy O
column3: and Night Slugs-- found him painting outside the lines of house and bass music
column4: spreading squelchy melodies that owed more to hippie jazz than club music. Since then he's remained sneakily busy
column5: releasing a handful of tracks that sound generally brighter and more musical than those of his peers. In contrast
column6: when ""Sais (Dub)"" dropped on Record Store Day last year
column7: it sounded as if someone had jammed a mute into his trumpet: The track's smoky symphony of bass and beats barely hinted at his ever-present jazz melodies (an even more modest edit of ""Sais"" closes Shadows).

column1: A less generous reader of Shadows might skip ""refinement"" altogether and arrive at ""retreat."" The record-- which represents the longest
column2: most cohesive release Shepherd has offered-- sounds polite at low volumes (at most volumes
column3: actually)
column4: and I wouldn't blame anyone for mistaking it for a headphone record. But Shadows benefits from volume; open air and clean walls amplify its details. Over the course of five long
column5: progressive tracks
column6: Shepherd offers a series of minor orchestrations
column7: layering tasteful slabs of jazz (I'm assuming they're samples) over a dense crosshatch of bass and drum sequences. There are extended passages during which he offers little more than drum patterns at competing frequencies; ""Obfuse"" looms for more than three minutes before it hints at true melody.

column1: Elsewhere Shepherd is more forward. ""ARP3"" piles tasteful electronic keyboard over a sinister bassline that alternates between five and seven notes of passive evil. Any (sonic) ties Shepherd still has to London's bass scene can be seen in moments like ""ARP3"" and the distended fog of ""Realise""
column2: during which he hijacks deep house's stoned haze and poisons it
column3: however slyly. That he can perform such misdeeds and still come across as elegant
column4: musical
column5:
and inspired speaks to a talent that was never really in doubt.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17321/homepage_large.1f196f04.jpg|Escort|8177.0|Escort|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Escort']|2012-01-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:45.177038|"

The studio must be an oasis for Dan Balis and Eugene Cho
column2: the leaders of Escort
column3: New York's premier live disco ensemble. Do you have any idea how hard it is to play this stuff in a club without coming off like rank amateurs or soulless professionals? You have to be tighter-than-tight to replicate those metronomic rhythms
column4: while also being loose enough to play through any in-the-moment human glitches. You can't wrong-foot dancers
column5: but you also can't be so precision-tooled that you lose the sense of abandon that's essential to any good party. You're not competing with a drum machine
column6: which is tough enough to do. You're competing with Nile Rodgers' Chic
column7: a much more forbidding proposition.

column1: In the safety of a recording booth
column2: a band like Escort is allowed to flub multiple takes
column3: correct any mistakes
column4: and experiment without worrying about bringing the party down from its boil. They can tinker with their lush arrangements until they fit with the jigsaw-precision that was required of disco bands in the genre's pre-computer heyday. Escort is the result of all that fieriness and fine-tuning
column5: the band's debut album after a drawn-out series of singles
column6: teasing fans for more than half a decade. On the evidence
column7: Balis and Cho are two producers who've listened long and hard to the history of their favorite genre
column8: and who care about getting both the little details and the overall Broadway-meets-boogie vibe just right. They manage to replicate every Off the Wall horn blast and Patrick Cowley synth bubble with loving music geek precision.

column1: But Escort isn't just the pinnacle of 21st-century disco fetishism. (Though it would be a singular achievement even if it were.) It's a great pop album
column2: even if it's working off 1979's pop template rather than 2011's. Balis and Cho aren't quite up to Chic's level
column3: obviously
column4: as songwriters or players. But they've set themselves a similar task
column5: out to prove that refinement and abandon aren't mutually exclusive. Like disco the first time around
column6: Escort aims directly for the brain's pleasure centers
column7: particularly the one marked ""bubblefunk
column8: but there's also an intensity and attention to sound design that comes from being both an in-the-moment live unit and studio rat tinkerers. All this astounding detail work is there to add extra thrills to songs that are instantly accessible
column9: immediately charming. Rather than 12""-friendly extended disco remixes
column10: these cuts are shaved down to the essentials. And the grooves would be strong enough with half the bells and whistles.

column1: Escort just want you to have a damned good time
column2: even if you don't know Walter Gibbons from KC and the Sunshine Band. And they're willing to risk all sorts of cheesiness to get you there. So it's no accident that ""A Sailboat in the Moonlight"" seamlessly switches halfway thorough
column3: from hammy musical theater to lascivious funk. The ""mutant disco"" scene and the pre-crossover Loft underground cuts may be the pieces of the disco pie most palatable to indie-reared ears. But Escort remind revisionist critics that disco also had roots in supper-club schmaltz
column4: showbizzy soul
column5: and Las Vegas pomp. If there's a guiding spirit here
column6: it's not benevolent weirdo Arthur Russell but master entertainer August Darnell at his most eager to please. The rhythm track on ""All Through the Night"" has the kind of crisp minimalism you find on the best DFA singles. But the rapid-fire R&B sassiness of the vocal takes us straight to the roller rink on teen night. Sure
column7: it wouldn't play at a roller rink now
column8: competing with the brutalism of 2011's pop-dance producers
column9: but Balis and Cho's hearts are in the right populist place.

column1: Escort take obvious pains that this update on one of pop's most opulently orchestrated of genres can stand
column2: sonically
column3: alongside the classics. Those strings! Even if they had the money
column4: modern major labels still wouldn't lavish that much attention on recording a string section. And if that old-school analog lushness is computer fakery
column5: then I'm doubly impressed. But given Escort's rep for throwing down live
column6: I doubt it. It's easy enough to press a button and unleash a sampled swirl of strings or a blast of brass. It's something else entirely to be orchestrating violinists and trumpet players through a seven-minute monster groove. That kind of commitment is one reason Escort have ascended to the top ranks of neo-disco acts
column7:
swinging their way through the demands of disco with the consummate skill of the kind of crack big bands that were everywhere in the late 1970s.

Does it devalue Mobb Deep's output from the 1990s if I think they could still possibly perform at that level despite over a decade's worth of evidence to the contrary? Let me clarify: I'm not talking so much about The Infamous or Hell on Earth
column2: those would require reopening a window of commercial relevance for that rugged and raw aesthetic as well as Prodigy and Havoc reemerging as the fatalistic old souls of their early 20s
column3: preferably rocking Hennessy football jerseys. That's probably not going to happen
column4: and it's not entirely their fault. But they don't need any of that to aspire to the standards set by the still-awesome Murda Muzik
column5: their 1999 LP which
column6: in retrospect
column7: could be seen as a forerunner to DipSet's synthesis of deadpan
column8: absurdist violence
column9: and a general disregard for actual rhyming. They just need to be entertaining and not give a fuck
column10: and I mean-- have you seen Prodigy's Twitter feed since he got out of jail?

column1: But while @PRODIGYMOBBDEEP is more than capable of reminding us never to question his trendsetting nor what he brought to the table
column2: very little of that batshit sense of purpose or fun makes it to Black Cocaine. The trouble isn't that Havoc and Prodigy have run out of things to say
column3: or that they don't really have much to rap about anymore-- they're real
column4: you're shook
column5: and Prodigy will almost certainly have sex with your woman if only to make your bitch ass realize your own capability for being shook. That shit obviously never goes out of style
column6: but rather than the likely legitimate insanity Prodigy flexed on 2007's Return of the Mac
column7: the two wring inspiration from that mode with the stubbornness of trying to get that last bit of toothpaste out the tube.

column1: Once the author of the illest first lines (""Quiet Storm""
column2: <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=mobb+deep+shook+ones+part+2&oq=mobb+deep+shook+ones+part+2&aq=f&aqi=g10&aql=&gs_sm=e&gs_upl=9969l12968l0l13096l19l17l1l10l11l0l180l605l2.3l5l0"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Shook Ones
column3: Pt. II""
column4: the list goes on)
column5: Prodigy hardly comes up with one memorable rhyme during the entirety of Black Cocaine-- we get brief teases at Illuminati P conspiracy theorizing
column6: but little anyone who's seen a one dollar bill couldn't come up with. Likewise
column7: Havoc delivers bar after bar of near-mesmeric placeholders
column8: but he does boast about having ""a ledger on my MacBook
column9: so now you know Excel is the spreadsheet of choice for dunn accountants. Still
column10: at least they're not fronting like club attendees or sex symbols anymore
column11: and any remnant of G-Unit factory production is swapped out for wheelhouse Mobb with plenty of synthesized horns and ice-grilled hi-hats. But the title track and ""Conquer"" just remind me of any number of Infamy deep cuts whose titles escape me and whose quality doesn't inspire me to find out.

column1: If nothing else
column2: you can be happy that Alchemist is inevitably involved
column3: and I seriously doubt anyone's still holding ""Takeover"" against them if Nas isn't. While it's a distinct pleasure to hear Queensbridge's finest reconcile their differences
column4: it's a distinct disappointment all the same at the utter lack of spark present on ""Get It Forever"": Nastradamus is considered one of the least-inspired hip-hop records ever made
column5: and even then
column6: these guys could still come up with something as bracing and utterly badass as ""Family"". And you can also admire the stylistic window dressing as Hav and P try some kind of weird upper register flow on ""Dead Man Shoes"". But they never find their footing
column7: while you can imagine Bounty Killa spending the pauses during his offbeat hook wondering whether Gwen Stefani still has his phone number.

column1: And so Black Cocaine comes across as not particularly different than
column2: say
column3: recent records from Saigon or Uncle Murda or M.O.P.
column4: guys who should be able to use the cratered rap economy to their advantage and create the rawest
column5: most uncompromising
column6: and NY-centric hardcore hip-hop they so choose
column7: but who ultimately sound confused as to how to navigate a land with no boundaries. (Just bearing witness to ""Hell On Earth 2k11"" featuring French Montana and Waka Flocka Flame is kinda mindblowing either way.) Truth is
column8: Mobb Deep sound kinda unsure as to where they stand
column9:
too proud to truly change up their style and still too much of a name brand to have to.

Common is confused
column4: and who can blame him? His career has stumbled in  so many directions that confusion is kind of unavoidable. He's gone from being a troubled
column5: semi-alcoholic underground rapper
column6: to a knit-cap
column7: Soulquarian prince
column8: to Kanye West's older
column9: less-cool cousin
column10: to now
column11: just a friendly-looking guy who occasionally appears  in Gap ads. At this point
column12: it's anyone's guess who the ""Common"" on Common's records might be. The confusion reached its low point on 2008's Universal Mind Control
column13: in which we were introduced the mortifying sight of strip-club Common. Now
column14: The Dreamer/The Believer finds him banging his chest
column15: demanding to know when hip-hop got all soft and sweet
column16: and attempting to engage Drake in a war on wax.

column1: It's a bewildering spectacle
column2: but a painful midlife crisis can cut two  ways: In one corner
column3: yes
column4: we have the guy responsible for a song called ""Electric Wire Hustle Flower"" demanding machismo credentials from the former star of Degrassi: The Next Generation. But in the other
column5: we have the best
column6: hardest-hitting
column7: and most consistent Common album since Be. In fact
column8: The Dreamer/The Believer occasionally recalls the rough humanity and humble thoughtfulness of his still-untouchable mid-90s classics Resurrection and One Day It'll All Make Sense. It's hard to know where this guy still draws his creative fire from
column9: but there are points on this record where Common raps as if his gift for slick embedded wordplay and tactile storytelling was just in a pocket he hadn't looked in for 10 years.

column1: Much of the album's fuel comes from soul-rap veteran No I.D.
column2: who handles the majority of the production. The Chicago producer has undergone a startling creative  renaissance in the last two years: Until about 2009 he seemed destined  to live out his life as local legend
column3: the Godfather of  Chicago Rap and the Guy Who Taught Kanye West. Lately
column4: though
column5: he's become what DJ Premier used to be: the guy you hire when you want to cozy up to Unimpeachable Authenticity. Even better
column6: his latest work hits harder and more viciously than anything he's done before. ""Ghetto Dreams""
column7: featuring a fully awake Nas
column8: is the gulliest track Common has rapped on since ""The Corner"". ""Blue Sky"" chops up ELO's ""Mr. Blue Sky"" into a looping
column9: affecting plea. ""Celebrate"" is the best G.O.O.D. Music BBQ-jam since Kanye's ""See Me Now"". And the back-firing-Hooptee snare kick on ""Sweet"" almost lets you peek through your fingers as Common rails against ""hoe-ass"" rappers and informs us that he is ""to hip-hop what Obama is to politics.""

column1: Common raps so hard on The Dreamer that you can almost hear his neck veins throb. And for every bit of overcompensation-- he actually cracks a bottle over a dude's head in ""Raw""-- there's something vividly rendered and honest. That kind of honesty used to be Common's territory
column2: but he surrendered it long ago to smarminess: by Finding Forever
column3: he only seemed capable of rapping in fortune cookies.  On ""Gold""
column4: he paints fond memories of his early nights: ""Hats from  liquor stores
column5: to avoid syphilis/ Frivolous spending/ Drunk nights  with storybook endings."" ""Lovin' I Lost"" is disarmingly humble and  open-hearted about heartbreak: ""I must confess
column6: I miss the days of you  laying on my chest."" Of course
column7: there's still nothing worse than a Latter-Day Common Simile
column8: and goofy lyrics abound. But the reason The Dreamer/The Believer sticks-- and it does-- isn't because Common reclaims some musty real-dude credentials he never had: It's because something seems to have reminded him that he's not a persona
column9: but a real
column10:
blood-pumping human.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17315/homepage_large.0e7fcdd1.jpg|Elemental Parts 1 & 2|29335.0|Demdike Stare|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Love']|2012-01-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:47.184662|"

The British duo Demdike Stare continue grimly spelunking through a dank
column2: anxious netherworld on Elemental
column3: their first new music in over a year. Their sound hasn't changed significantly in the interim: Dark
column4: ambient drones tangle with scraps of post-punk and library music
column5: while strains of dubstep and techno settle like pathogens in the bloodstream. If ""dark"" was the organizing principle of their last album
column6: as Mike Powell said of Tryptych
column7: then ""darker"" is their current M.O.-- murkier
column8: more oppressive
column9: and more intense.

column1: Suffused in cavernous reverb and distortion
column2: Demdike Stare's hammered pianos and grinding
column3: stunted rhythms conjure a kind of post-apocalyptic hellscape. Samples of exotic drums and unfamiliar string instruments are pitched so low that the waveforms seem to fray about the edges. Whatever doesn't decompose is thrown into shuddering
column4: mechanical motion; I'm left with the image of giant machines tilling toxic soil
column5: spitting up shrapnel from battles long lost and forgotten.

column1: Almost uniformly slow
column2: sooty
column3: and diffuse
column4: the record can be disorienting; the more you listen
column5: the more individual tracks blur together. Barring a few elegiac passages
column6: there are few melodies to latch on to
column7: and the record's structure feels almost labyrinthine. Tracks may meander through several distinct phases with little regard for a conventional narrative arc; some simply hover
column8: digging in like a bad trip
column9: until they break in a burst of chorus. Elements flit in and out of earshot according to inscrutable whim
column10: and scattered lock grooves have the potential to fuck up your whole sense of time: I spent 10 minutes lost in a loop before I realized I needed to pick up the needle.

column1: There are pieces of recognizable musical codes scattered throughout-- twanging strings lifted from dusty Ocora samplers
column2: techno's steady kick drum
column3: the uneasy rumble of Nurse With Wound and SPK. Ragged synthesizers strafe across the spectrum like strobe lights in a British field
column4: ca. 1989. In its more harmonic passages
column5: the record's trapped-in-a-submarine atmosphere sounds directly inspired by Seefeel's great 1995 album Succour. The hand-soldered experiments of the BBC Radiophonic Workshop bubble up in squealing sine waves and erratic oscillations; those analog strokes are some of the freest sounds on the record
column6: suggesting lines of flight up and away from a potter's field strewn with mouldering recordings of yore.

column1: Two songs explicitly engage with current modes of club music: ""Mnemosyne"" follows Shackleton's experiments in fourth world dubstep
column2: with ululations laid over square-wave bass blurts and cracking snares
column3: while ""Ishmael's Intent"" taps into the ominous
column4: ethno-techno vibe of William Bennett's Cut Hands project.

column1: There's a lot of this kind of thing around at the moment-- in addition to Cut Hands
column2: this particular field of gloomy
column3: ethno-infected
column4: post-industrial techno includes Demdike Stare's label-mates Andy Stott
column5: G.H.
column6: Raime
column7: and the rest of the Blackest Ever Black label
column8: Ancient Methods
column9: Ekoplekz
column10: and the clockwork kalimba meltdowns of Harmonious Thelonious and the Durian Brothers-- and it's legitimate to ask what elevates Elemental above mere mannerism or fashion. (Now that Tiësto's peddling triangle t-shirts
column11: we can probably agree that the isosceles' hipster moment is over
column12: but the current fascination with esoteric
column13: sepulchral music and imagery shows little sign of abating.)

column1: Beyond the pervasive sense of doom
column2: which is only reinforced by titles like ""Mephisto's Lament"" and ""In the Wake of Chronos""
column3: the whole album package feels like a tribute to limited-edition fetish products of 1980s industrial music. While a 2xCD reissue featuring an altered tracklisting is due later in the year
column4: the album is currently out as a lavish
column5: quadruple-gatefold
column6: 4xLP set
column7: with the individual discs colored four different shades of purple: chrysanthemum
column8: violet
column9: rose
column10: and iris. (The first two pieces were included with the gatefold cover
column11: now sold out; the second will be available for purchase separately. It's blatant collector bait
column12: but it's hard to deny that it's a stunning piece of work.)

column1: The music itself
column2: though
column3: is plenty compelling all on its own. More focused than Tryptych
column4: Elemental hones in on its mood and conveys a genuine sense of mystery that goes way beyond mere affect. Part of it
column5: I think
column6: has to do with the fact that you never know quite what you're hearing. Is that a foghorn or a Moog? A chorus of reeds or a bees' nest? Where did those drums come from? Does it matter? The sound lingers in between the representational and the abstract
column7: and that ambiguity-- that impurity-- only increases its expressive dimensions. At several points
column8: Demdike Stare's album sounds uncannily like Chris Watson's recently released El Tren Fantasma
column9: a sound portrait of a Mexican railway in its last month of operation. Blurring the lines between documentary
column10: music
column11: and noise
column12: and between life and technology
column13: Watson's chronicle turned the real phantasmal. Demdike Stare do the opposite
column14:
conjuring a vivid fantasy world out of audio salvage and crusty circuitry.

On the third disc of this wood-paneled box set of Louisiana singer Robert ""Bobby"" Charles Guidry's lone album from the 1970s
column3: there's a half-hour interview with radio disc jockey Barry Hansen
column4: better known as Dr. Demento. They laundry-list the records released that week in 1972
column5: ranging from a posthumous Jimi Hendrix LP to John Fahey
column6: Tim Buckley
column7: Bonnie Raitt
column8: Nazareth
column9: Wet Willie
column10: and Martin Mull. To which Bobby Charles comments in his gentle
column11: stoned Cajun drawl: ""It's too bad
column12: a lot of good ones just have to get lost. It's unexplainable
column13: but they just do."" To which Hansen replies: ""Well... a lot of times they get picked up the second or third time around.""

column1: Warm and crackling as a campfire
column2: easeful and understated
column3: all of it suffused with Charles' nuanced blend of humor and empathy
column4: this 1972 eponymous album was one of the ""good ones"" that got lost. Think of this as the second or third time around for the album to finally find its people-- and there should be plenty of them. Considering that 4/5ths of the Band served as Charles' back up group here (augmented by Dr. John and Neil Young pedal steel guitarist Ben E. Keith)
column5: this is-- simply put-- one of the most sublime Americana records ever cut.

column1: Charles' story started two decades earlier
column2: when he wrote and recorded R&B standards like <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=bobby+charles+see+you+later+alligator&oq=bobby+charles+see&aq=0&aqi=g1&aql=&gs_sm=c&gs_upl=552l2682l0l4613l17l11l0l2l2l0l149l1054l2.7l9l0"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""See You Later
column3: Alligator"" and ""Walking to New Orleans"". The story goes that Chess Records signed the then-14-year-old sight unseen after he sang them ""Alligator"" over the phone. When he arrived in their Chicago offices
column4: though
column5: Leonard Chess flipped out: Not because Charles was underage
column6: but because he was white. After touring through a pre-integration South
column7: he wound up in Nashville by the late 1960s. A marijuana rap led him to head further north
column8: where he ultimately fell in with the musical community centered around Woodstock
column9: N.Y.
column10: recording at Dylan manager Albert Grossman's Bearsville Studios.

column1: From the opening twang and snare snap of ""Street People""
column2: it's clear Charles' songwriting acumen had grown beyond his early R&B roots. Over the slinking beat
column3: he details an itinerant life of what one would label a ""bum."" But rather than spin some tale of hard luck and woe
column4: Charles makes drifting from town to town and panhandling for spare change sound idyllic. ""Wouldn't trade places with no one I know/ I'm happy with where I'm at
column5: he drawls. A cowbell accents the punchline: ""Some people would rather work/ We need people like that.""

column1: Elsewhere
column2: there are organ-gurgling numbers about new love and community gossip
column3: lilting ballads about watching butterflies
column4: honking barroom numbers about growing old
column5: and gentle
column6: country-tinged numbers about spending all day in bed with your honey. And then there's the ode to Jesus to save him from his followers. All of it gets delivered with a sly grin and at a pace with which you might sip a beer on a back porch
column7: cast a fishing line into a creek
column8: or barbecue a rack of ribs: slow
column9: unhurried
column10: a sunny afternoon ahead of you.

column1: Some 25 previously unreleased tracks augment the original 10-song album
column2: ranging from the pleasant to revelatory. There are differently mixed singles
column3: three songs released only on a Japanese box set
column4: some half-baked songs
column5: but also the sound of Charles' shuffling toward a follow-up album that he never quite got around to finishing. Or
column6: as he put his M.O. on one chorus: ""(I'm) staying stoned and singing homemade songs."" There's the Band's telltale funk on ""Why Are People Like That?""
column7: Dr. John's piano commingling with Garth Hudson's gospel organ swells on the elegant crest of ""You Came Along"". Fans of Will Oldham's Arise Therefore will swoon for demos of Charles dueting with the Band's Rick Danko over a sputtering drum machine.

column1: When this set was originally made available through Rhino Handmade back in August (it's in stores now via distribution partner Light in the Attic)
column2: mid-album track ""He's Got All the Whiskey"" was already an album highlight. So it's uncanny hearing both it and ""Street People"" in a post-Occupy mindset. About as loud as ""Chappelle's Show""'s intro
column3: Dixieland horns
column4: Danko's bass
column5: and a snare's pop skitter about as Charles gripes: ""He got all the money."" It
column6: of course
column7: follows that ""The Man"" also has all the ""whiskey/ power/ women
column8:
the biggest crime of it being that ""he won't give me none."" It's a simple protest from Bobby Charles-- good-natured at its heart-- and hopefully it won't get ignored this time around.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17309/homepage_large.52be75bb.jpg|Items|30156.0|Household|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dull Knife']|2012-01-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:49.129018|"

There's not much information out there about Brooklyn trio Household or their debut Items
column2: but even if there was
column3: it wouldn't be easy to find. When I first heard the infectious
column4: spring-loaded ""Go Away""
column5: I naively typed ""Household Items"" into Google. What I found was
column6: of course
column7: not information about the record but instead some kind of timeless commentary on domestic boredom: top results included ""household items to masturbate with
column8: ""household items to make a bong out of
column9: and-- why not cut out the middleman-- ""household items that will get you high."" A few more precise keywords (""Brooklyn
column10: ""Young Marble Giants-influenced
column11: ""guitars that sound like they've been strung with rubber bands"") led me to the record on their Bandcamp
column12: but once I got listening I realized that Google
column13: in its sly wisdom
column14: might have had it right the first time. Items is an ode to domestic boredom
column15: romantic dissatisfaction
column16: and the emotional detachment that results from feeling imprisoned within routine.

column1: The most immediately refreshing thing about Household is that-- in a moment when most melodic punk comes with an obligatorily caked-on layer of distortion-- Items sounds cleaner than a Stepford Wife's countertop. Jenna Weiss-Berman's spartan percussion
column2: Isabel Freeman's bouncing basslines
column3: and Talya Cooper's pristine riffs interlock with utility and precision. Like Austin duo Yellow Fever and San Francisco's Grass Widow
column4: Household specialize in minimalist
column5: retro-tinged post-punk that's as indebted to indie pop as it is to Wire. But the wry attitude of Cooper and Weiss-Berman's vocals recall nobody so much as the patron saint of new wave sardonicism
column6: Waitresses frontwoman Patty Donahue. Listen close and you'll swear you can hear their eyeballs rolling all through the minute-long sass-fest ""Never After"". ""No-o/ Don't call me/ I'll call you
column7: Cooper promises. Yeah
column8: right.

column1: ""I always write these 'not-angry-just-disappointed lyrics
column2: '"" Cooper said in a recent interview
column3: and there's a fitting sense of restraint
column4: repression
column5: and even passive-aggressiveness that emerges from these tunes. ""Cold Hands"" paints a portrait of a love affair in shades of dull
column6: passionless gray (""Your laundry is folded and your dinner is made/ Your window shows cars and people
column7: they all look the same"") while the sarcastically titled ""Our Song""
column8: laden with Cooper and Weiss-Berman's off-kilter harmonies
column9: laments
column10: ""This is how we spend our days/ Nothing ventured
column11: nothing gained."" Because the record's so thematically dour
column12: Household are at their best when they kick up the tempo. ""Go Away"" turns a song about an emotionally unavailable lover into a briefly cathartic pogo jam: Cooper and Weiss-Berman's disparate vocal melodies braid in and out before combining into a minimalist's take on the anthemic chorus. ""Defective!/ Defective!"" they shout
column13: and it comes off like a death sentence for a relationship that sounds about as steamy as a broken microwave.

column1: Items doesn't show much range
column2: but at a taut 18 minutes
column3: it's over before its one note runs its course. Still
column4: with all this talk of drudgery and weariness
column5: you're right to ask: What keeps an album about boredom from being excruciatingly boring? In Household's case
column6: it's their grasp on melody (the songs are catchy and simple without sounding too sing-songy) and their savvy terseness (another band might stretch a song like ""Never After"" past the minute mark
column7: but it wouldn't have as much bite). The sole song to break the three-minute barrier is the finale
column8: ""Cold Hands""
column9: which also contains the only moment when that tightly contained passive aggression simmers to a boil. The track ends with Weiss-Berman raising her voice: As she repeats her initially mild-mannered refrain-- ""You've got the coldest hands anyway""-- it suddenly builds into a shout. It hints at a muted rage just below the surface
column10:
and makes us hope that Household's next release might find them kicking down doors.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17311/homepage_large.3f14682a.jpg|Vienna Blue|29029.0|Tin Man|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2012-01-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:49.702264|"

If you don't know Tin Man-- California-hailing
column2: Vienna-based Johannes Auvinen-- he's arguably one of modern techno's most cultish figures
column3: with a distinct sense of fashion and aestheticism both visually and aurally. But is he really techno? He made his initial fame off the back of a bunch of fabulous acid 12""s
column4: but he's always had a darker
column5: more experimental side
column6: and since 2009's Cool Wave has been incorporating an introverted and dignified half-goth
column7: half-baroque pop sensibility to his productions. Scared from 2010 was even less hospitable
column8: all spooky atmospheres and post-punk vocals
column9: and last year's follow-up
column10: Perfume
column11: brought back some of the techno-friendly snares and kicks but still centered around Auvinen's offbeat
column12: sometimes off-key baritone. For the most part
column13: it wasn't dance music. But last year also saw the release of the ""Nonneo"" 12""
column14: one of the year's most cherished techno missives
column15: a gently bubbling acid bath. As 2011 wrapped to a close
column16: Auvinen released another album
column17: this one completely free of charge: but which Tin Man would we get
column18: the weirdo dance auteur of ""Constant Confusion"" fame or something closer to Scared?

column1: The answer is neither. Inspired by his adopted home of Vienna
column2: Vienna Blue is a gentle chamber-pop record not like much else Auvinen has put to his name before. Real chamber stuff
column3: with cellos and violins overshadowing most of the synthesized elements. Auvinen calls it a ""winter album
column4: and the label fits: All cool hues of icy blue and white
column5: Vienna Blue inhabits a chilly but cozy place that suits stereotypically romantic images of the Austrian capital draped in snow. It's not totally foreign; just as Perfume and Scared shyly hinted at techno elements and structures
column6: the music on Vienna Blue shares that forward-thinking lateral movement
column7: only this time expressed with the gentle strokes and plucks of strings
column8: graceful rather than tracky.

column1: What can make Tin Man's music a little divisive-- what makes his albums difficult where his singles can be relatively smooth sailing-- is his own voice. Like a slurred and slovenly Stephin Merritt
column2: he shares that singer's idiosyncratic sense of cultured class
column3: but the cavernous space his vocals inhabit can be alienating and his melodies often feel makeshift or improvised. With the more tuneful accompaniment on Vienna Blue
column4: however
column5: his presence is less jarring: When his voice dips down to those dangerously low notes
column6: it blends in with the bass instruments instead of billowing out into an uncomfortably empty echo chamber. ""Music on the Radio"" might be his best vocal track yet
column7: in fact
column8: with dramatic pianos and a laborious kick drum finding some happy medium between classically tinged instrumentation and techno. It's moments like this that raise Vienna Blue above side-project gimmickry: ""Ice Blue Eyes"" pulses faintly with a barely there beat
column9: like it's impossible to tell what's ""real"" and what's artificial. Throw in Auvinen's groggy vocals
column10: and you've got yourself a gorgeous lullaby of flickering
column11: half-present sounds.

column1: Vienna Blue is split between longer
column2: more structured vocal tracks and instrumental interludes
column3: which range from string-led motifs (""Winterize"" is especially majestic) to near-ambient mood pieces (""Ok
column4: Improvise""). This lazily lapping flow nicely cuts up the length of the rather slow-moving record
column5: but can just as easily render it drifting and aimless. The real-life instruments lend it a natural quality like sonic wallpaper that subtly blooms and and swells
column6: but Vienna Blue lacks even the sparse momentum of his previous albums. The pleasantly slow creep of it all is rudely interrupted by the vocal tracks
column7: and those times when the vocals don't quite mesh with their surroundings (""Gratitude"") prove rather garish cracks in the record's otherwise uniformly glassy ice surface.

column1: As a whole
column2: Vienna Blue is always caught between classicist ideas of the stately and that deeply experimental techno bent
column3: so it never quite coheres. One thing Vienna Blue does make clear is Auvinen's uncompromising vision of his own style
column4: folding in all sorts of latent impulses and confident to the point of confrontational. He remains defiantly independent from scene or context: Just as unfairly limiting as it is to call this chamber pop
column5: it's equally ignorant to call it techno. ""Rockers
column6: ravers
column7: you best beware. This generation don't care
column8: he sang on Perfume's ""Rockers Ravers""
column9: and Vienna Blue caps off Tin Man's most intriguing year yet
column10: proving he really doesn't give a damn about genre. It might not be perfect
column11:
but ""chamber techno"" probably shouldn't work as well as it does on the best moments here: Leave it to someone as effortlessly suave and fearless as Tin Man to try and pull it off.

If you were around when Neutral Milk Hotel were a working band
column2: it would have been difficult to predict the stature they'd later acquire in the independent rock sphere. That they were great
column3: and special
column4: was clear to a lot of people following indie rock
column5: but they didn't necessarily seem like the kind of group that would develop into something amounting to a ""legend."" For one thing
column6: they were visible during the mid and late 1990s
column7: doing exactly the same kinds of things other indie rock bands were doing. They were on Merge
column8: putting out albums
column9: EPs
column10: and singles
column11: touring the same venues as young bands like Modest Mouse and Helium. They weren't under-appreciated and were by no means obscure; and the fact that they were part of a ""scene"" that made for such great copy-- the Elephant 6 Recording Company-- meant they got their share of attention in the indie music press.

column1: But then they went away. Jeff Mangum
column2: the project's creative force
column3: stopped releasing new music and quit playing shows. Yet unlike the followers of many bands from that time who moved on
column4: his fans didn't trickle away. Instead
column5: in place of a working band with a growing catalog
column6: Neutral Milk Hotel became an absent band with a growing cult. People were rediscovering this music
column7: and the median age of the Neutral Milk Hotel obsessive has continued to hover in the early twenties. Since Mangum's return to performing
column8: first as part of the Elephant 6 reunion in 2008 and then with a slate of shows last year
column9: Neutral Milk Hotel started to seem like something that existed in the present tense again. Possibly serving as a sort of tribute to this moment
column10: Mangum has released this limited vinyl-only box set
column11: which collects almost all of the material released under the Neutral Milk Hotel name and adds 15 additional rare and unreleased tracks.

column1: I've met people who adore In the Aeroplane Over the Sea and didn't know that Neutral Milk Hotel had ever released anything else
column2: so it's tempting to view everything Mangum released with an eye to the part it played in the Aeroplane story. And while it's a settled matter that Aereoplane is the high-water mark for the band (as well as being one of the best indie rock records of the last two decades)
column3: I can tell you that at the time there were plenty of people who felt that its predecessor
column4: 1996's On Avery Island
column5: was nearly its equal. Certainly
column6: Avery has a comparatively muffled sound and doesn't always seem to understand how to best showcase Mangum's gifts (his voice is often double-tracked and lower in the mix and hence less distinctive)
column7: but on a song-by-song basis it has almost as many great moments. The opening ""Song Against Sex"" is one of them
column8: a fuzz rocker with a hypnotically catchy and repetitive melody and lyrics that hint at the awkwardness and alienation that draws people toward Mangum's work. NMH's world is a place where sex is fumbling
column9: a reliably imperfect expression of an emotion that dreamers want to see perfected. And in ""Song Against Sex""
column10: drugs and porn and staged representations of lust are so repellent that the narrator wants to leave the world altogether. It's the kind of sentiment that teenagers who feel assaulted by their surroundings will continue to discover
column11: and its wide-eyed and wounded view of the world goes a long way toward explaining why they keep returning to this songwriter.

column1: Despite its vague and decidedly lo-fi profile
column2: Avery also has its share of experimentation
column3: and it's well integrated into the songs themselves. The album was produced by Robert Schneider of Apples in Stereo
column4: whose house-producer role in the E6 sphere you might compare to Conny Plank's in the German experimental rock underground. I believe that's Schneider's voice talking excitedly as ""Song Against Sex"" opens
column5: encouraging Mangum and describing his performance as ""perfect
column6: and Mangum has spoken repeatedly about how important his enthusiasm and belief was to the NMH project. The way Schneider and Mangum structured Avery
column7: it feels like a suite
column8: tunes bunched together with interludes and repeating motifs and details that fade away and then return a few songs later. The lurching ""Marching Theme"" may not have the memorable arrangement of the following record's instrumental ""The Fool""
column9: but the surging fuzz guitar and odd
column10: snaking keyboard melody form a superb bridge between the acoustic ""Baby for Pree"" and the electric variation on the same gorgeous melody that follows
column11: ""Where You'll Find Me Now"". The simple horn and organ duet ""Avery Island/April 1st"" connects that to the comparatively fierce ""Gardenhead/Leave Me Alone""
column12: and ""Naomi"" is another key Mangum track
column13: not least for its strangely wandering melody. The closing ""Pree-Sisters Swallowing a Donkey's Eye""
column14: 13 minutes on CD but 10 minutes shorter on vinyl
column15: is a throbbing drone piece that sometimes touches on noise music
column16: putting it in league with similar experiments by NMH's sister band
column17: Olivia Tremor Control.

column1: If Avery could reasonably be compared to other music going on in the Elephant 6 sphere in the mid and late 1990s
column2: Aeroplane is where Mangum created something with no easy reference points. Mixing Salvation Army band pomp
column3: hushed folk
column4: roaring power pop
column5: and almost unbearably intense guitar and voice songs that are difficult to classify
column6: Aeroplane still feels like one of a kind
column7: 14 years and countless inspired bands later. It's never not been a part of the conversation in indie rock since it was reissued in 2005
column8: and suffice to say that it has lost none of its power. It's always been mastered loud and with a mix that puts Mangum's voice right in your face
column9: and the remaster here is just a hair softer and rounder but otherwise wisely does little to alter its forceful sonic character. Aeroplane is the sound of an artist fully in tune with his creativity putting himself out there with an almost painful sense of vulnerability
column10: and the reverberations from that statement are still being felt after a decade and a half. I wrote at length about the record when it was reissued in 2005 and don't have much to add here
column11: except that the packaging and sound of this reissue are first rate. As an addendum
column12: the gorgeous picture disc/poster sleeve 7"" of ""Holland 1945""
column13: backed by a live version of ""Engine""
column14: first released in 1998
column15: is nice to have in circulation.

column1: Beyond the two proper albums
column2: the box offers a mix of revelations and welcome artifacts. Early song ""Everything Is"" has been been released in various configurations over the years
column3: as both a two-song 7"" and as a proper EP
column4: and it's included here in expanded EP form as a 10"". Originally released in 1994
column5: it finds Mangum in a much different place in terms of both songwriting and performance. This is where he felt most Elephant 6
column6: enamored with the pop of the 1960s and doing his best to sing sweetly
column7: in a higher and smoother register
column8: to make his voice palatable. The title track and ""Tuesday Moon"" (once identified on a comp as ""Love You on a Tuesday"") are basically solid
column9: down-the-middle guitar pop songs recorded crudely but with a hint of the spark that would lead to so much more. ""Ruby Bulbs""
column10: the first song Mangum ever officially released
column11: is raw and noisy and shouty and reflects Mangum's interest in aggro punk
column12: an influence that didn't otherwise surface on his records. All in all
column13: the Everything Is EP feels gestational and enjoyable but ultimately unexceptional; had things ended here
column14: Neutral Milk Hotel might be as well remembered as E6 compatriots the Gerbils.

column1: The Ferris Wheel on Fire 10"" EP
column2: on the other hand
column3: is the real treasure of the set. Hearing Mangum in acoustic mode (there are seven demos here and a recording from an in-store)
column4: it's striking how much these recordings from 1992 to 1996 sound so much more like his later style compared to what was issued on Everything Is. ""Oh Sister""
column5: from 1995 perfectly captures that moment of the growing boldness of his songwriting; the strums and vocals seem very ""Two Headed Boy""
column6: and it has some melodic and lyrical motifs from that song. ""My Dream Girl Don't Exist""
column7: possibly the most well-known unreleased Mangum song
column8: feels like a dry run for Aeroplane
column9: with strummed chords reminiscent of ""The King of Carrot Flowers""
column10: lyrics about a dead girl in the ground
column11: and a closing ""now she knows she'll never be afraid"" that was later used on ""Ghost"". The studio version of ""Engine"" is quite close to the version released on the B-side of the ""Holland 1945"" single
column12: and other songs (""A Baby for Pree/Glow Into You""
column13: ""April 8th"") found their way to On Avery Island. Hearing acoustic songs and demos from the early days of Neutral Milk Hotel and marveling at how fully realized they sound
column14: Ferris Wheel on Fire reminds me most of Time of No Reply
column15: the posthumous collection of Nick Drake rarities and outtakes that evokes the sound of Pink Moon more than either of his two other properly released records. It's certainly a fans-only collection
column16: but it also stands well on its own
column17: with a unified sound and mood.

column1: One 7"" included on the record serves more as an extension of Ferris Wheel
column2: with versions of songs released elsewhere. ""You've Passed"" and ""Where You'll Find Me Now"" both made it onto Avery. The first is not terribly different
column3: it sounds like the basic arrangement and sound had been determined
column4: but the fuzz guitar has more roar in the riff. The second is a welcome change-up: much slower
column5: more downcast
column6: less desperate
column7: less naked. The other 7"" has two versions of ""Little Birds""-- one recorded at home
column8: one with Robert Schneider-- which happens to be the one song here that was written after the release of Aeroplane. It's a harrowing composition that is dedicated to Matthew Shepard
column9: who was murdered two months before the song was composed in December 1998
column10: and its lyrics
column11: ""Another boy in town at night he took him for his lover/ And deep in sin they held each other/ So I took a hammer and nearly beat his little brains in/ Knowing God in heaven could have
column12: never could forgive him
column13: seem to reference the incident.

column1: It's clear in spending time with this set and listening to it in varying sequences that Mangum the songwriter liked to tinker. On this evidence he was not prolific
column2: but he also didn't waste ideas. Parts of songs pop up in other tracks
column3: variations get turned into extended sequences
column4: songs are divided into parts. The seven-or-so-year songwriting arc represented here yielded only about two-dozen completely distinct songs
column5: and a clutch more that are variations on some of those themes.

column1: An overlooked element of Neutral Milk Hotel's enduring appeal is that Mangum stopped making new music at the precise moment that music was about to become ""an internet thing."" A year after Aeroplane came Napster
column2: and pretty soon the way we hear and experience music would never be the same. But Neutral Milk Hotel remain
column3: as if preserved in amber
column4: in that moment when independent music was bought in stores and spread by word of mouth that came from actual mouths. A moment when people had to hold something physical in their hands to be able to experience the music
column5: whether tape
column6: vinyl
column7: or CD. And it's fitting that this box set has been assembled with care and high-quality materials that seem bound to last well into the time when the next generation discovers this music. ""There are some lives you live and some you leave behind
column8: Mangum sings in ""Gardenhead""
column9: and it's such a perfect line for this guy. He left the music-making life behind for years
column10: and now
column11: maybe
column12: he's inching back toward it. Even if he never gets there
column13: whether by choice or because forces of whatever kind conspire against him
column14: there's the music contained here
column15:
rich and beautiful enough to fill a career.

As Jay-Z once said
column3: ""Men lie
column4: women lie
column5: numbers don't."" Apparently
column6: that memo never reached Cam'ron and Vado
column7: whose latest joint mixtape
column8: <i>Boss of All Bosses 3
column9: is actually their fifth entry in an increasingly tired series. (It follows Boss of All Bosses 1
column12: and 2.8.) Diehard Dipset fans might turn up a few tracks here where the light of Cam's Purple Haze-era peak still flickers
column13: but Vado
column14: once New York's next great hope
column15: appears so rarely that the collaborative billing feels a little misleading.

column1: Boss of All Bosses 3 is symptomatic of the current era where only a handful of rappers can get albums in stores and on time. Rappers like Cam and Vado need to flood the market to keep their names on the blogs' front page
column2: but they also have to hope that the inherent diminishing returns of a seemingly endless mixtape series don't permanently turn off listeners. Vado should be keeping up with guys like A$AP Rocky and French Montana who have more or less assumed his buzz and replaced him in the food chain that decides which rappers might actually get to put out a real life album or take a little bit of radio airtime away from Young Money. Cam
column3: on the other hand
column4: is presumably looking to convince label execs that he's still a relevant artist worth an investment
column5: a proposition that stands to lead
column6: at best
column7: to a internet rumors.

column1: For listeners
column2: a tape like this begs the question: When is enough enough? At this point
column3: new Dipset just sounds like old Dipset
column4: and old Dipset is way more kinetic. The production here recalls the blustery symphonies of their heyday
column5: but Cam's disengaged flow
column6: which once felt like the epitome of cockiness
column7: no longer sounds hungry. He still cracks a few good lines and drops the occasional sideways reference
column8: but the Cam of ""sake
column9: Suzuki
column10: Osaka Bay"" is far in the rearview.

column1: A few tracks fare better than others: ""Keys in tha Damier"" isn't too far from the sample-driven bangers of Dipset yesteryear
column2: and ""Talk My Nigga"" has the fiercest rapping on the tape despite both rappers jacking their cadence from Crazy Town's ""Butterfly"". But the appeal of these tracks isn't likely to resonate with non-diehards.

column1: There's so much invigorating rap coming out of New York (and elsewhere) right now
column2: but Boss of All Bosses 3 isn't exactly among the most inspiring. There's no harm in plucking out a few dope tracks for a playlist
column3: but there's so much more heat
column4: spirit
column5:
and conviction in the back catalog. Isn't it about time you broke out disc two of Diplomatic Immunity?

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17296/homepage_large.d11c6e34.jpg|"Free Again: The ""1970"" Sessions"|28727.0|Alex Chilton|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Omnivore']|2012-01-09 00:00:00|2012|2016-06-11 17:17:52.960337|"

By 1970
column2: Alex Chilton was barely old enough to vote but already enough of a music biz veteran to be completely jaded by the industry. His short tenure in the Box Tops produced two million-selling hits
column3: ""The Letter"" and ""Cry Like a Baby""
column4: but the group's sound and direction were determined almost exclusively by producers Chips Moman and Dan Penn
column5: who rarely diverged from the group's R&B-laced rock'n'roll. They chose almost all of the Box Tops' songs
column6: dictated how they should be sung
column7: and relegated Chilton's own compositions to hastily recorded B-sides
column8: denying the singer not only his creative freedom but potential royalties as well. Whether this was the heavy hand of a svengali or the harried influence of a producer-cum-babysitter is debatable
column9: but after an aborted tour of Europe
column10: the Box Tops fell apart.

column1: Free from the demands of that hit group
column2: Chilton holed up in Memphis' Ardent Studios with producer/founder John Fry and engineer Terry Manning to record a batch of his own songs. The sessions were casual and low-key
column3: resulting in a full album of material that was never released. Instead
column4: Chilton formed a new band
column5: called Big Star
column6: which translated British power pop to American shores. But those 1970 sessions became lore among Big Star fans
column7: passed around as rumors or bootlegs until 1996
column8: when Ardent released them as 1970. That collection has since gone out of print
column9: and now Omnivore Records has reissued it with bonus tracks
column10: following up last year's excellent white-label edition of Big Star's Third.

column1: This music represents the midpoint between the Box Tops and Big Star almost too literally
column2: as Chilton volleys between blues-rock rave-ups like ""All I Really Want Is Money"" and softly sung pop ballads like ""The EMI Song (Smile for Me)"". The transitions can be jarring
column3: especially as he switches between his low
column4: gruff vocals and his mod-ish falsetto. It's hard to believe it's the same human being singing those songs. And yet
column5: on some level
column6: this collection may be one of the purest expressions of Chilton's personality-- not only his dreamy ruminations but also his coarse humor. According to the new liner notes by Bob Mehr
column7: Chilton made fun of Moman and other producers for being out of touch with current sounds
column8: specifically the British Invasion. This mocking spirit extends to ""All I Really Want Is Money"" and ""I Wish I Could Meet Elvis""
column9: which seem to take the piss out of the Box Tops.

column1: There's a telling contradiction embedded in these half-assed numbers: Chilton obviously adores the rhythm and bluster of these songs
column2: yet he has been conditioned to resent the style
column3: to view R&B as a hopelessly passé genre. His performances become caricatures of black blues vocals
column4: or perhaps caricatures of white approximations of black blues vocals. It can be an uncomfortable listen
column5: especially when he sings
column6: ""that's all I cares about in de world
column7: on ""All I Really Want Is Money"". Perhaps because we know about his troubles with the Box Tops
column8: Chilton's perspective-- that of a white teenager whose voice had been conditioned to resemble that of a black man-- remains oddly compelling in its jumpy defiance
column9: especially on the gloriously perverse covers of the Stones' ""Jumpin' Jack Flash"" and the Archies' ""Sugar Sugar"" (which gets mashed up with James Brown's ""I Got the Feelin'"").

column1: On the other hand
column2: songs like ""If You Would Marry Me Babe"" and ""All We Ever Got From Them Was Pain"" sound like templates for some of Chilton's best-known Big Star numbers
column3: contrasting his cynical streak with an earnestly romantic side. ""The EMI Song (Smile for Me)"" may be the sweetest and most delicate melody he ever wrote
column4: and ""It Isn't Always That Easy"" is a ruminative acoustic demo that exposes the ravages of Chilton's short career to date. On ""The Happy Song""
column5: he tries on a nudie suit for size
column6: and the country snare patter and steel guitar fit his vocals so perfectly it's not hard to imagine what other avenues he might have traveled in subsequent decades.

column1: Free Again doesn't simply predict his work with Big Star; in fact
column2: these songs eerily prefigure much of his solo material
column3: which deconstructed-- often messily or carelessly
column4: but occasionally beautifully-- everything he once held dear. Even as a teenager
column5: he had an inclination to undercut every expectation
column6: even his own. ""Every Day as We Grow Closer"" may be a quiet song with a lovely melody and a huge impact
column7: but he nearly ruins the effect by appending a short
column8: tongue-in-cheek jam at the end. For many listeners
column9: this aspect of Free Again may be off-putting
column10: like hearing a comedian tell only inside jokes. This release
column11: much like Rhino's 1970
column12: is certainly not intended as an introduction to Chilton's music. Instead
column13: it's more like an endpoint for devoted fans looking to connect the dots. As such
column14:
it provides a fascinating coming-of-age story of an artist who came into his own playing styles he knew he loved and others he only thought he hated.

"|16137.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16137-free-again-the-1970-sessions/|7.8|Stephen M. Deusner
