2010's Baby Style EP wasn't a fully formed mission statement for Keepaway
column2: but it provided them with the next best thing an emerging young band could hope for: a killer single and options. ""Yellow Wings"" was the last of the great tracks to emerge in the immediate wake of Merriweather Post Pavilion's enormous influence
column3: and although the EP's scattered nature made it easy to view the group as adept adapters of musical trends
column4: a sonic realization of their gregarious personality felt inevitable. The Brooklyn band can be pretty hard to peg
column5: but they maintain a very entertaining Twitter feed
column6: make hip-hop beats on the side
column7: and their debut
column8: Black Flute
column9: is being released on Das Racist's Greedhead label. So
column10: having our full attention and the weight of expectations
column11: how do Keepaway choose to reintroduce themselves? Here's the first line on ""Cake"": ""Everything/ Wa-oh-oh-oh-oh/ Tastes like lemons.""

column1: Okay
column2: so it's no surprise that these guys skew a little hackysack
column3: but it's not so much what Nick Nauman says right there
column4: but how it sticks out so blatantly. Black Flute executes a frankly baffling gameplan that forefronts Nauman's newly grating vocals
column5: the timbre and content of which serve as the anchors in Black Flute's thudding disappointment. They've done away with the wavy
column6: reverb-soaked production that typified ""Yellow Wings"" and ""5 Rings""
column7: which at least superficially feels like a wise decision: After all
column8: who hasn't tired of that kind of thing over the past couple of years? Of course
column9: that mindset overlooks the possibility that some acts are just better off with some sort of sonic obfuscation
column10: and Black Flute wholly hitches itself to group-hug harmonies and lyrics that are intelligible but inscrutable conflations of philosophy
column11: sex
column12: and religion. It's occasionally welcoming
column13: but mostly confusing in a manner akin to walking in on the culmination of a dorm-room bull session.

column1: Credit to Keepaway for being a band that seems to have an investment in what they actually say
column2: even if they do traffic in awkward carnality (so says ""Vital"": ""Every cat's gotta scratch
column3: gotta run/ Can I make you find the milk on the tip of my tongue"") and vaguely stoned revelations as impenetrable as adobe slabs. ""Hologram"" tries to coalesce Garden of Eden imagery with sci-fi futurism
column4: but mostly sounds like a Yeasayer demo
column5: and even without the trippy studio effects
column6: tracks like ""Royal Jelly"" tend to drift thanks to run-on fantasias like ""16 royal elephants/ I'm hardly running/ But I'm moving twice as fast as them/ Each one has a rider/ Dressed in royal armor."" I mean
column7: make fun of Rusted Root all you want
column8: but at least they yodeled what they meant.

column1: There's a certain logic to it all
column2: and some of Black Flute manages to lodge itself into your brain on sheer repetition
column3: even if it doesn't always feel particularly welcome. There are hooks situated within this fruitopia of light-stepping reggae (""Cake""
column4: ""Bomb Track"")
column5: Casio synth-pop (""Hologram"")
column6: and unmoored R&B balladry (the closing ""Purple"") that aspire to the sonically dry but lyrically louche configuration of early Prince. But in light of the lush production they contributed to Das Racist (especially ""Amazing"" from <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14662-sit-down-man/"" target=""_blank"">Sit Down
column7: Man)
column8: you question why they've grown so enamored with all these Tinker Toy drum patterns and a bass that occasionally sounds like it's not even plugged in. And so rather than stressing its lilting harmonies and sopping atmosphere
column9: ""Vital"" doubles down on Nauman's near-falsetto
column10: which has the shrieking edge of Avey Tare
column11: but none of the catharsis.

column1: Considering the promise Keepaway had initially shown
column2: you want to give Black Flute the benefit of the doubt
column3: digging past its surface miscues for deep-seated flaws that might not be their own fault-- is it the culmination of Animal Collective's opening the tent for Phishheads combined with the judgment-aversion fostered by the social networking presence of Brooklyn's increasingly chummy indie scene?  Or is it an LP-length extension of ""Deep Ass Shit (You'll Get It When You're High)""? Or maybe Black Flute just feels so suited for campus quads because it folds so quickly in the face of pragmatic scrutiny
column4:
its dime-thin arrangements and cashed-bowl musings equal parts self-denial and self-indulgence.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17306/homepage_large.4f5ee0e4.jpg|Glimmer|30153.0|Jacaszek|['Rock'
column2: 'Jazz'
column4: British critic Joe Muggs explored the way Berlin producer Anstam uses technology to emulate acoustic instruments-- and then
column5: push those sounds to places that actual players in an orchestra could never go. Muggs invokes the concepts of ""uncanny valley"" and ""trompe l'oreille
column6: related phrases describing the phenomenon of fabricated artifacts and intelligences mimicking ""real life"" to the point of being indistinguishable. ""The dividing line between the physical and digital worlds is fast fading away
column7: Muggs writes in a prelude of praise for Anstam's Dispel Dances
column8: ""in the process posing new questions about our relationship to what we’re hearing."" Most of Muggs' fascination with Anstam appropriately stems from a sense of wonder
column9: or imagining the possibilities of a set of computers refined enough to make digital music sound as though it were recorded in a studio but play music beyond the capabilities of human hands. It's a post-milliennial update of Conlon Nancarrow's player-piano rolls
column10: where the human becomes the controller
column11: if not the hands-on creator.

column1: Glimmer
column2: the new album by Polish producer Michał Jacaszek
column3: takes a much different path to a very similar sort of intrigue. Jacaszek has long operated at artistic thresholds. His 2009 album
column4: Pentral
column5: for instance
column6: seemed like an attempt to be as brutal and beautiful as possible. Without notice
column7: he'd burst from near-silent calm into speaker-splitting tones. If that sounds off-putting
column8: Pentral thankfully played more like an attempt to dismiss a binary than to bait and cruelly switch. For Glimmer
column9: Jacaszek combines a real-time ensemble-- here
column10: harpsichordist Małgosia Skotnicka
column11: clarinetist Andrzej Wojciechowski
column12: and himself on acoustic guitar and metallophone-- with his own web of electroacoustic effects.

column1: Jacaszek possesses the soft programming touch of Christian Fennesz. Sensitive and slight
column2: his electronics suggest a layer of lace sitting softly above patches of sculpted debris. As a composer with this small group
column3: Jacaszek recalls recent romantics like Texas' excellent Balmorhea and Sweden's delicate Tape; the music is often pretty but not cloyingly so
column4: meaning that there's space for foreboding and worry between the oboe's lifts and the harpsichord's fanciest runs. Rather than simply process previously recorded sounds
column5: he smartly trusses those qualities
column6: shaping an album that feels like some science-fiction waking dream. In an atmosphere that's very pleasant but vaguely eerie
column7: the humans and the robots interact
column8: each occasionally slipping behind the cover of the other. Jacaszek's again craftily corroded another binary.

column1: Glimmer's nine tracks work best as a whole
column2: built with hard-won peaks and long-sloped valleys that disappear into the distance. As the album progresses
column3: Jacaszek hints at previous themes and ideas
column4: using a classical trope to earn a sense of cohesion. It works
column5: too
column6: making the 41 minutes between the repetition that opens ""Goldengrove"" and the granulated whirr that signals the exit of ""Windhover"" seem compulsory. But there are remix-ready instrumentals here
column7: too
column8: from the Burial-like stasis of the gorgeous ""Dare-Gale"" to the swollen majesty at the center of ""As Each Tucked String Tells"". Think of Glimmer as a little symphony
column9: just with singles
column10: and made by a musician who can't decide between the roles of producer or composer. Really
column11:
he shouldn't anytime soon.

"|16150.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16150-glimmer/|7.7|Grayson Currin

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17304/homepage_large.7c0295f2.jpg|Themes For an Imaginary Film|30141.0|Symmetry|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Italians Do It Better']|2012-01-06 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:54.407777|"

Themes for an Imaginary Film arrives following the release of Drive
column2: the film which Italians Do It Better star and Italo-disco producer Johnny Jewel was originally tapped to soundtrack. But much of his work (created with assistance from longtime collaborator Nat Walker of Chromatics and Desire) went unused in lieu of Cliff Martinez's score. There's no point in pretending that the Imaginary Film of this collection's title isn't that movie. The cover depicts a steering wheel and dashboard. The intro track begins with vehicle sounds. And the lengthy 37-track score suits Drive's distinctive blend of grit
column3: glamour
column4: and abject loneliness. Befitting its standalone release
column5: though
column6: this project does stand alone
column7: and Themes for an Imaginary Film makes for an engrossing listen in a way that many film scores don't.

column1: Maybe it's because we can't hear the score over Drive itself
column2: but Themes for an Imaginary Film makes up for its lack of a visual counterpart by telling a story of its own. Evocative
column3: stirring
column4: yet restrained
column5: Jewel's mixture of eerie near-silences
column6: ominously bubbling synths
column7: and tearjerking melodies (rendered by real-life viola and cello players) is a formidable combination.

column1: For anyone expecting a quasi-album full of orchestral overtures or ambient mood pieces
column2: Themes for an Imaginary Film's opening run will set you right: ""City of Dreams"" and ""Over the Edge"" are driven by Jewel's usual assortment of grainy analog synths and brittle guitars
column3: and there's even a slight beat underlaid
column4: though it's more like a faint heartbeat than the disco-driven rhythms of Glass Candy or Chromatics. But by the time we get to track six (""Outside Looking In"")
column5: the beats disappear and are replaced by moody
column6: glacial waves of sound
column7: reminding us that this is
column8: in fact
column9: a film soundtrack.

column1: Appropriately
column2: Jewel's sonics are adjusted for their new setting. Though he uses his trademark sounds well
column3: the claustrophobic
column4: sweaty-club vibe that defines Chromatics and Glass Candy is completely absent. Compositions like the fantastic ""Behind the Wheel"" are either left completely dry
column5: with their synth elements at the fore sounding bigger and clearer (the harshly distorted ""Death Mask"" is almost wince-inducing)
column6: or awash with reverb
column7: like the woozy ""The Maze"" or the lonely electric piano lament ""Hall of Mirrors"". The spare
column8: disconsolate atmosphere perfectly complements the film it was meant for
column9: but it also makes for an immersive listen
column10: with an unusual amount of space allowed for within Jewel's music.

column1: At two hours and 37 tracks long
column2: Themes for an Imaginary Film is not exactly easy to digest in one sitting. But just as it bypasses many of the caveats associated with film scores
column3: so it does with overlong albums: Themes works as well as mood music as it does close listening
column4: and the way it swims between rhythm-driven beatscapes and ambient swells provides enough tension for it to unobtrusively grab your attention every once in a while. There's never too much drama
column5: and there's never too much silence. The record is immaculately paced.

column1: For you impatient listeners out there
column2: a number of highlights are worth taking out of their original context. In addition to the aforementioned
column3: ""Magic Gardens"" features an overwhelming synth line that sounds like the ""Streets of Philadelphia"" refrain blotting out the sun
column4: and with some fleshing out
column5: the teasingly short ""Nightshift"" (appearing twice) could easily be a Chromatics stunner. The lack of any sort of human presence-- outside of the automated voice that begins the score and the ambulance sirens and police radio that appear chillingly halfway through-- is shattered with the album's closer ""Streets of Fire"". Performed almost entirely a cappella by Chromatics singer Ruth Radelet
column6: the song is a stunningly naked
column7: somber ending to the 2.5 hours that precede it. Combining plaintive lyrics with a nursery-rhyme melody
column8: it trades the dangerous seductiveness or dirty street suavity of Jewel's other projects for pure sorrow.

column1: Themes for an Imaginary Film isn't a decadent disco soundtrack like Goblin might have made
column2: nor a noodly synth odyssey à la John Carpenter or Vangelis. Rather
column3: it's something completely Jewel's own
column4: blending his distinctively fragile synthetic textures with a suitably cinematic realism that he's rarely let show. Whether you treat it as background music
column5: incidental listening
column6: or a two-hour magnum opus
column7:
Themes for an Imaginary Film is a well-rounded portrait of a key figure in the American electronic music landscape.

"|16148.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16148-themes-for-an-imaginary-film/|8.1|Andrew Ryce

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17275/homepage_large.be093b50.jpg|Bestival Live 2011|873.0|The Cure|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['PIAS']|2012-01-06 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:54.941129|"

The Cure are nearly three-and-a-half decades deep in the game and have never been shy about monetizing their seemingly boundless recorded output. So it's something of a surprise that Bestival 2011 is their first official live record since the double-shot of 1993's Paris and Show
column2: which capitalized on Wish boosting the band to its commercial zenith. The Cure have kept busier than a band of its status has needed to since then
column3: releasing four studio records
column4: a second greatest hits collection
column5: and an intimidating
column6: comprehensive B-sides collection
column7: while Robert Smith parlayed his godfather status into guest spots on Blink-182 and Crystal Castles singles. But these things are often as novel as their setlist
column8: and Bestival's intentions could not be clearer
column9: accounting for the Cure's existence between 1993 and 2011 with a grand total of 10 minutes of music.

column1: Then again
column2: in a setting such as this one
column3: fans who paid a couple days' salary for festival tickets like to have their preconceptions confirmed. Since Paris and Show
column4: that's a one-hot-album-every-18-year average-- and I say that aware that a lot of people don't even have an abnormally generous relationship with Bloodflowers like I do. But even if the Cure's discography is riddled with redundancies
column5: the question becomes: Who is Bestival even for? Particularly if completists almost certainly own Show and Paris
column6: and newcomers to the band can (and often do) start with Staring at the Sea?

column1: Without a visual accompaniment
column2: Bestival is best viewed as a testament to the Cure's longevity and stylistic breadth. But while the collection speaks highly of the Cure's professionalism
column3: it never catches spark
column4: save for a performance of ""The Caterpillar""
column5: reportedly their first since 1984. And since each song sticks so closely to the script
column6: there's never much development of an internal narrative to make this performance seem worthy of documentation
column7: though you could let your ears go soft and see it as a sort of Benjamin Button effect where they scale from their most regal and sumptuous (""Plainsong""
column8: ""Open"") to the wiry punk of the Three Imaginary Boys cuts that close out the set.

column1: At the very least
column2: their professionalism extends to the actual recording-- the sound is crisp and clear
column3: and even Smith's stage banter sounds remotely intelligible. His voice has aged astoundingly well
column4: all the more impressive for how it maintains such a startling fidelity to its studio counterpart
column5: no matter if he's straining desperately on the atomically negative ""One Hundred Years"" or purring the come-ons of ""Lullaby"". Yet that clinical treatment robs the Cure's more expansive numbers (""Disintegration""
column6: ""Push"") of atmosphere and oddly minimizes them in open space
column7: Smith's passionate guitar work just sounding kinda weedy. And often the loudest element of the mix is this Tupperware-snap snare that haunts anyone who's been within earshot of a hi-fi Dave Matthews Band bootleg.

column1: Not to mention the times when the professionalism works against the intent of the material. Even if there was always something arena-rock about ""Shake Dog Shake""
column2: it's rendered toothless when stripped of the circumstantial psychosis from The Top's sessions
column3: and while they can't not play ""Boys Don't Cry""
column4: it's performed at a flat-footed ""we're gettin' too old for this shit"" pace. Meanwhile
column5: sticking ""The End of the World"" and ""The Only One"" amongst ""A Night Like This"" and ""Lovesong"" as if they're every bit as part of the firmament is surely a noble attempt at revisionist history.

column1: But man
column2: if you really want revisionist history
column3: get to the end of this thing. Now
column4: especially as it comes at the tail end of a two-hour peformance
column5: the spirited
column6: charged-up instrumental passages of this track are inspiring. But then Smith gets to the chorus and yelps
column7: ""I am the stranger... KILLING ANOTHER."" I thought my promo copy had a typo
column8: or it was a situation similar to when you could find copies of In Utero in retail stores with ""Waif Me"". ""Killing an Arab"" was misinterpreted by the same people Smith lashed out against on Cure's very embarrassing political rant ""Us or Them"" as being racially insensitive post-9/11
column9: but it's just profoundly depressing to hear the song rendered all but completely meaningless when the mass setting should make it all the more resonant.

column1: Which is really the dynamic that's confusing about Bestival-- it's easy to enough to understand the thrill of hearing ""Friday I'm in Love"" or ""Just Like Heaven"" amidst tens of thousands
column2: but at this point
column3: the Cure feel like less of a band than a traveling museum or theme park celebrating their past with the occasional new exhibit or ride to stoke interest. In other words
column4: a completely user-driven experience en masse: You want to remember them as minimalist
column5: ghostly post-punkers? They're touring Seventeen Seconds and Faith in the ""Don't Look Back"" format. If you prefer your mopes to be more drawn-out and reverberant
column6: there's the Trilogy DVD where they play Pornography
column7: Disintegration
column8: and Bloodflowers in their exact order
column9: exactly as they're played on record (its replay value is exactly what you'd expect). As for Bestival? It's what I suppose is a great reminder about the vastness of the Cure's actual catalog and their real-time vitality as a band as opposed to merely their influence
column10: but even two hours of their best stuff in this format feels less rewarding than spending 20 minutes cobbling together your own Spotify playlist. After all
column11:
the corollary to the Cure-as-a-business is that the customer's always right.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17307/homepage_large.8e8de640.jpg|Back $ellin' Crack|30154.0|Squadda B|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2012-01-06 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:17:55.590543|"

Last month
column2: 2011's breakout indie rapper Danny Brown sat down with Impose magazine after being named their rapper of the year. When asked who his favorite rap act of 2011 had been
column3: he named Bay Area duo Main Attrakionz
column4: whose prolific output and undaunted adoption of the burgeoning ""cloud rap"" sub-genre has earned them a growing profile and a diverse collection of fans. ""They talking street shit
column5: Brown explained of Squadda B and MondreM.A.N.
column6: ""but they talking it over those trippy-ass
column7: cloudy-ass beats."" The co-sign still felt a little surprising: On one hand
column8: anyone who has heard 808s & Dark Grapes II
column9: the group's most notable release to date
column10: knows how easily pleasing their half-baked creations can be. But on the other
column11: for a guy like Brown-- whose wildman persona is often one of his great draws on record-- putting on for two guys who are often criticized for both not having a ton of personality
column12: and sometimes being unable to think outside of their own little box
column13: seemed somewhat incongruent.

column1: Take for instance last year's I Smoke Because I Don't Care About Death
column2: the excellently titled but not totally memorable solo mixtape from Squadda B
column3: which featured a smattering of awfully cloudy tracks that found a guy sounding so comfortable in his own lane
column4: it seemed as if he'd never get over. Which is why Back $ellin' Crack
column5: which squeaked in right before 2011's final bell rang
column6: may provide some clues as to why we might be seeing more straightforward music coming from the Main Attrakionz camp in the new year. Just looking at that borderline-NSFW album cover above
column7: it's clear that Back $ellin' Crack is not strictly another cloud-rap affair. Instead
column8: Squadda has crafted a mixtape's mixtape
column9: with strong
column10: varied production styles that could complement any assortment of rappers. And while unsurprisingly lacking in content-rich lyricism
column11: this center-of-left approach proves to be a step in the right direction
column12: with Squadda's oddball tendencies and workmanlike demeanor still intact.

column1: There is a lot of personality to be found on Back $ellin' Crack
column2: but it's helpful that
column3: working outside of his normal routine
column4: Squadda never appears to feel the need to play keep-up or bend to the will of a beat. ""Down""
column5: which features barn-burning verses from MA affiliate Shady Blaze and Danny Brown himself
column6: is probably most indicative of Squadda's focus here. Some rappers would feel hard-pressed to set off the double-time fireworks just to remain visible
column7: but his ability to play the background and let others shine where applicable (one of the benefits of normally having to share the spotlight with another MC) is a real asset. Which isn't to say that he's using the rest of his time here most wisely: ""Rapgame""
column8: which boasts some Supreme Clientele-grade silkiness
column9: finds Squadda both reflective and funny (""Wonder if they think I'm lyin' about the shit I spit/ Can I at least get a chance to start lyin' about shit?"")
column10: while ""Van Halen"" opens with some weirdly appealing
column11: atonal singsong rap. But most fun of all might be ""The Greenova Way""
column12: with its Looney Tuned-up beat (courtesy of Squadda himself) allowing him to playfully jab at the pigeonholers: ""They call it cloud rap/ Wanna see me? Then look up!""

column1: But not all of Back $ellin' Crack is nearly as effective. The second half of the tape
column2: which heavily features MondreM.A.N.
column3: feels too safe compared to the material that preceded it. None of it really has anything to do with Mondre's presence
column4: nor the way Squadda and he sound on these tracks together-- in fact
column5: stuff like ""Conversations Pt. II"" makes for a solid entry in the Main Attrakionz catalog. But in context
column6: it's a step backward
column7: especially considering how much effort Squadda has put into taking the duo's established sound and repurposing it for audiences more drawn to conventional approaches. By the time ""Cream Soda"" shows up-- which unfortunately finds Squadda rapping over Fleetwood Mac's ""Landslide"" (what Frank Ocean hath wrought!)-- there's a distinct sense that Back $ellin' Crack's ambition has dried up.

the weird turn pro.

Rap's no stranger to backronyms. Wu-Tang was the Witty and Unpredictable
column2: Talented and Natural Gang. Thug Life became the Hate U Give Little Infants Fucks Everyone. But none is arguably more fitting than the J.E.T.S.' motto: Just Enjoy This Shit.

column1: At a time when rap's standard-bearers are often unnaturally saccharine or overbearingly Eeyorish
column2: Spitta
column3: Smoke DZA
column4: Mikey Rocks
column5: Fiend
column6: Young Roddy
column7: and Trademark da Skydiver are preternaturally indifferent to the perils of fame. Jet World Order is Alfred E. Neuman rap. What me worry? Just listen to the drawling hook of ""Exhale"": ""Never stressing over chicks or ends/ Light it up
column8: inhale
column9: exhale/ Blow it in the wind.""

column1: No need to trip when you're chemically focused on weed
column2: women
column3: and the winner's circle. This album has less range than the menu at In-N-Out
column4: but no one ever went there looking for tacos. Theoretically
column5: such tired terrain should make a record more dull than watching Adult Swim sober. But credit Curren$y and company for emulating the weed they smoke: They know to make being bored seem fun.

column1: A former member of the 40-man roster of No Limit and understudy at Cash Money
column2: Curren$y has clearly absorbed the label-building strategies of his former patrons. Wisely
column3: he's recruited a like-minded set that rarely diverges from his aesthetic
column4: but maintains enough identity to stay alert. There's Fiend
column5: the No Limit soldier and Ruff Ryders refugee in the midst of a minor renaissance
column6: who pops up on  ""Picture Perfect"" with a flow so smooth it should be permanently draped in a scarlet silk smoking jacket. DZA
column7: the ""fat boy of the set"" brings a dilated Uptown cool
column8: munching on crawfish
column9: and bragging about how your girlfriend Tweets at him. Trademark and Roddy get the most green lights
column10: and while both acquit themselves
column11: neither is yet a threat to take pole position.

column1: The compilation's purpose is self-evident: to leverage Curren$y's star and earn attention for his set. It's a role that rap crews have regularly employed since at least Marley Marl's In Control
column2: Volume 1. Most of the time
column3: it's a mixed bag
column4: depending on the label
column5: its roster
column6: and how much weed was wasted that day in the lab. Jet World Order doesn't exactly break the mold. But what it lacks in cohesion
column7: it covers in aimless cool. And with slow-roasted soul supplied by Monsta Beatz
column8: Cookin' Soul
column9: et al.
column10: the beats neatly align with the low-lidded laissez faire of the rappers.

column1: Jet World Order is the bizarro stoner twin of Self Made
column2: Rick Ross' Maybach Music comp from last year. Rozay
column3: Pill
column4: Meek Mill
column5: and Wale are the connoisseurs who want to get high from a $500 volcano
column6: order useless gadgets from Brookstone
column7: and eat expensive room service off arthropod platters. The Jets twist spliffs and make their women bring them take out.

column1: For all their occasional avarice
column2: they're weirdly sensible. On ""Exhale""
column3: Curren$y brags about still watching DVDs on the Playstation and spotting good commercial real estate deals. He manages to offer frugal relatibility and an aspiration ideal. Well-played. Rap is predicated on the idea of who would you want to get high with. And right now
column4: the Jets' run that lane.

column1: Rating an album like this feels like flipping through an issue of High Times
column2: where obsessives blather in microscopic detail about the fluorescence and genetics of a new strain of sativa. Sure there's a couple of mediocre beats and a few too many boilerplate verses about getting blunted
column3: but really
column4:
the only question that matters is whether you want to get high to this. You probably should just enjoy this shit.

Focus too long on any one part of Spills Out
column3: the third LP from psych-splattered Brooklynite post-punk manglers Pterodactyl
column4: and you risk losing track of the rest of it. The sprawling set from the shapeshifting band is bristling with basement-show energy one minute
column5: stacking haunting Zombies-style harmonies the next. The pixelated
column6: post-everything whoosh of their earlier
column7: more forceful records is still very much in evidence on Spills Out
column8: but it's as though their turn-on-a-dime cubism's been given the SpinArt treatment
column9: globs of melody pooling at its edges. This unlikely meetup-- of Les Savy Fav's hard-driving antsiness
column10: the Olivia Tremor Control's echoing psych-pop
column11: Abe Vigoda's clangy hot-weather punk
column12: and any three or four second-tier SST bands of your choosing-- sometimes smacks of eclectic overextension
column13: but for the most part
column14: Spills Out manages to revel in its own clutter.

column1: Spills Out's first five numbers are all about propulsion
column2: zig-zagging melodies and breathless vocals underpinned by insistent
column3: edge-of-calamity drumbeats. This
column4: in large part
column5: is the art-punking Pterodactyl of old
column6: never ones to shy away from melody
column7: provided they can make it move. At times
column8: the vigorous rhythms threaten to get the best of the trickily constructed tunes they're mobilizing
column9: but at this pace
column10: they leave precious little time to notice. The woozy lurch of ""Allergy Shots"" is quite a toneshift
column11: its duskily triumphant melody marching its way directly into your pituitary region. Though 2010's Arnold's Park saw Pterodactyl playing around with psychedelia-- the acoustic flitters of Sung Tongs-era Animal Collective
column12: among other things-- here
column13: Spills Out burrows its way into the rabbit hole on something of a mid-album mini-suite of thick
column14: woozy psych.

column1: Rife with spectral sound effects and blurry
column2: tape-stressing maximalism
column3: many of these songs could've fallen off the back end of last year's stellar Olivia Tremor Control reissues. Like the Olivias
column4: Pterodactyl wrest cohesion from calamity by soldiering surefootedly through all these far-flung juxtapositions
column5: presenting these disparate styles as though they're supposed to go together. But even on the sprightlier numbers
column6: Pterodactyl's formidable instrumental prowess sometimes blots out the songs themselves; with tempos slowed and melodies pushed to the forefront rather than rattling around the edges
column7: they're downplaying their strengths in favor of an experiment that proves only somewhat successful.

column1: When
column2: as on ""The Break""
column3: they match the two sides together-- its drums rollicking
column4: its harmonies circuitous-- Pterodactyl's messy vision for Spills Out is given its clearest expression. For the most part
column5: the record's final third does a nice job blending the two
column6: squeezing little bits of baroque-bent vocalism or sci-fi sound collage in between the pummels. Their knack for jittery melody's always fared best when matched to forward motion
column7: and though much of Spills Out seems to zip by in a blur
column8: it's assembled with enough care to never quite spin out from its center. It can be more than a little dizzying
column9: with all that stuff whizzing by
column10: to settle on any particular chorus or guitar riff for too long. But throwing yourself in Spills Out's path means letting it reconfigure your circuits
column11:
and it's hard to come out the other side not feeling pretty good about getting frazzled.

James Blake was such a central figure in the 2011 conversation that many folks lost sight of just how weird the London poly-wunderkind's indelible self-titled debut was and still is
column3: especially as a breakthrough document of underground pop. However
column4: for those attuned to the ever-changing trends of the UK bass music scene-- specifically
column5: listeners dazzled by Blake's phenomenal triptych of 2010 EPs
column6: The Bells Sketch
column7: CMYK
column8: and Klavierwerke-- James Blake's reliance on piano-based singer/songwriter electro-soul perhaps played it a bit too safe
column9: prompting comparisons to the once-outré
column10: now-gear spinning career of fellow avant-crooner Jamie Lidell.

column1: Despite a few fascinating B-sides and a particularly challenging double dose of dub released on the reliable bass label Hemlock
column2: this fall's underwhelming Enough Thunder EP didn't do much to quiet the ""supper club"" cries. For those most interested in his sound-warping production
column3: it comes as a relief that Blake chose to close the door on his prolific 2011 with another EP
column4: Love What Happened Here. Undoubtedly his boldest collection of tunes since the minimalistic
column5: spacey Klavierwerke EP
column6: the release features Blake at his most restlessly playful
column7: exploring new sounds and styles while also expanding on his already varied body of work. Newcomers brought in by the full-length will undoubtedly find the tracks intriguing; for the rest of us
column8: it's a reassurance that he still possesses his unique
column9: inventive approach to sound.

column1: Even though Love What Happened Here is a ""new"" release
column2: its side-long title track's been floating around the internet since the beginning of 2011
column3: surfacing a few weeks before James Blake saw proper release. Like many others
column4: I first heard it in radio rip form following its premiere on former BBC Radio 1 DJ Benji B's program. The novelty of listening to the tune was enhanced by Benji's breathless recounting of when he first heard the song during one of Blake's DJ sets. His excitement was
column5: and is
column6: understandable: ""Love What Happened Here"" seems to take pleasure in announcing its own presence
column7: as zesty organ stabs unfurl the red carpet down which the track's other elements-- a sharp click-clacking beat
column8: disparate vocal samples
column9: warm pinging tones-- saunter with ease.

column1: Revisiting the rip
column2: I wish Benji had quieted down during my favorite part when
column3: at the 49-second mark
column4: James lets loose a tickly
column5: conversational melodic run of tones that sound improvisational-- as if he's caught in a state of pure ecstasy for a second or two before slowly unfolding into the song's light
column6: funky groove. Blake's best work has always been detail-oriented
column7: providing the ability to take pleasure in the smallest things that are or aren't there. Like his ""second version"" of The Bells Sketch's ""Give a Man a Rod"" that appeared on Hessle's 2011 compilation 116 and Rising
column8: ""Love What Happened Here"" is about those small things
column9: stringing them together into a coherent whole that
column10: if put in a particle generator and separated molecule by molecule
column11: would still yield minor revelations.

column1: If ""Love What Happened Here"" represents James Blake at his most purely entertaining
column2: then the EP's two B-sides find him at his most engagingly experimental. Like many of his contemporaries in the UK bass scene
column3: ""At Birth"" is Blake's take on house music proper-- only
column4: this is house music done his way
column5: a 4/4 beat speckled with blurry tones and strangled voices
column6: including his own. After hearing him do the straight-and-narrow thing with his distinctive voice for the last 12 months
column7: it's certainly a treat to find him stretching the limits of his own vocal manipulation
column8: especially when it's used in such a haunting fashion.

column1: Love What Happened Here's closing track
column2: ""Curbside""
column3: is an entirely different beast and quite possibly the most surprising piece of music we heard from him all last year. Employed in able fashion at the closing minutes of Pearson Sound's fantastic BBC Essential Mix back in November
column4: ""Curbside"" is a seriously stoned slice of beat-tape paranoia
column5: a locked groove trapped beneath tumbling drums
column6: suffocated voices
column7: and pure aural steam. Structurally
column8: it most closely recalls the broken-weathervane hip-hop of J Dilla's Donuts cut ""The Twister (Huh
column9: What)""
column10: and I've heard other colleagues throw out comparisons to the Bomb Squad's confrontational production and the primordial stew of Los Angeles' Low End Theory collective. None of those comparisons are wrong
column11: but they're not exactly right: Both as a standalone single and a piece of James Blake's catalog
column12: ""Curbside"" is entirely
column13: idiosyncratically unclassifiable.

column1: Since its title track floated around for almost a year before its proper release
column2: there's been speculation that Love What Happened Here is a clearing-house release-- that the diminishing returns found within Enough Thunder could very well be more representative of where he's heading as an artist. As an optimist
column3: I'm willing to take such speculation as just that
column4: especially since interspersed releases like the ""Pan"" b/w ""Order"" single have suggested that Blake's more about following his fickle muse than adhering to some sort of pre-set career path. Either way
column5: given his still impressively prolific nature
column6: there's a good chance we'll know his next move sooner than later. No matter what direction he's facing
column7: though
column8: James Blake continues to move as an artist
column9:
and the thrill of witnessing those movements hasn't dulled.

So
column2: Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire's new mixtape is called Merry eXmas & Suck My Dick. Because Bad Santa would've been too obvious a title for this raunchy yet immensely likable anti-socialite? Or maybe eXquire likes a non-sequitur blowjob joke far more than the next guy and also needs to figure out a way to create timeliness for this thing
column3: seeing as it has absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with Christmas. Either way
column4: it's a fitting way for eXquire to end the year-- after all
column5: he finished 2011 with a much bigger profile than he began it with
column6: and if this is your first exposure to the guy's work
column7: he got there making about as many artistic concessions as you'd expect from a guy with the word ""Muthafuckin'"" in his name.

column1: It's a worthy cause for celebration. eXquire still maintains a huge chip on his shoulder and a related lack of patience for rappers ""doing their best Yeezy rendition"" and supplicating at the behest of internet tastemakers-- a line like ""Books by Marcus Garvey/ Skin swarthy/ Snuff the glitter off your Ed Hardy/ Honey BBQ strips from Hardee's and two 40s/ Bet I finish them shits before I get to my apartment"" from ""The Gold Watch"" serves as a tidy syllabus for eXquire's worldview
column2: equally inspired by time-honored alcohol abuse
column3: budgetary restrictions
column4: and a general disdain for others. But Merry eXmas isn't stoked by the same struggle and desperation of Lost in Translation
column5: and the relatively lighthearted vibe is pretty much necessary since it asks a lot of the listener: It's essentially an outtakes collection from a mixtape
column6: albeit one that
column7: for all intents and purposes
column8: felt like a label-funded debut. Nonetheless
column9: eXquire remains remarkably sharp
column10: taking more chances indulging in pure technical showmanship
column11: celebrating freedom from traditional song structure in the form of 90-second trials on ""What's Beef"" (""Biggie Tribute"") and A$AP Rocky's ""Peso"" (""R.I.P. Payso""
column12: credited to ""one of them A$AP niggaz I forgot"")
column13: while a ""backwards"" verse on ""Two 22's b/w Twenty Two 2's""
column14: double-time flows
column15: and fake patois all fold into eXquire's haughty
column16: smirking
column17: knucklehead voice that finds the missing link between G-Unit and Def Jux.

column1: If these really are the leftovers from Translation
column2: it explains why nothing quite leaps out at you like ""Huzzah"" or its remix-- it does reappear in name only as a glassy-eyed reinterpretation that does away with the hook entirely
column3: but eXquire and company make Merry eXmas too much of a blast to really concern oneself with the stakes involved. ""Two 22's b/w Twenty Two 2's"" might've gotten there had it not been padded out to six-and-a-half minutes by a ""Pretty Boy Swag"" parody and audio vérité from a roundtable discussion of cunnilingus. Those things do have their place on mixtapes
column4: but the decision to jam them right into the most obvious banger is an encapsulation of Merry eXmas' pleasures and faults.

column1: There are far more of the former than the latter
column2: though. As if you had to ask
column3: ""Killah Tofu"" indeed samples the Beets (""Doug"" version) and spends the rest of its run time forgetting it did-- pretty much anyone who gets on a track with Danny Brown these days holds on for dear life
column4: but eXquire plays a worthy foil by sounding like the gulliest dude to ever quote Harvey Danger. With beats from the Legendary Mr. Len and El-P
column5: this is still very much in the Def Jux wheelhouse
column6: familiar enough with funk and boom-bap to know how it can be defiled for their own purposes
column7: but also a reminder of a time when ""underground"" and ""backpack"" hip-hop didn't necessarily represent a limp
column8: aggression-free version of it.

column1: It's what often has him viewed against his will as a torchbearer for New York-centricity
column2: but he treats it like an actual physical place rather than some sort of mythic construct of hip-hop purity-- he announces ""Stella Artois and sour cream Utz"" as pillars of his diet and by the end
column3: he's probably namedropped 95% of his local bodega's inventory. He's certainly pliable as a voice and a personality
column4: but the lesser experiments start piling up toward the backend-- lurching coke-rap that channels Jeezy circa 2005 (""Nightmare on Fed Street"")
column5: ""Drunken Freestyle"" pretty much living up to its name
column6: and the high-NRG booty-bass tribute (""Power U Pt. 2"") that takes a big rip of Boris S.'s ""Don't You Wanna Pussy Ride"" and is the filthiest thing eXquire has put to tape (which is saying something).

column1: Yet Merry eXmas can be considered a continuation of Translation in how ""Power U Pt. 2"" completely makes sense in relation to something like the track ""S.C.U.M."" Few artists in any genre
column2: let alone hip-hop
column3: are making rawer and realer breakup songs than eXquire
column4: and ""S.C.U.M."" is his most despondent yet
column5: never asking for sympathy or justification in his actions (""I was numb to the experience/ Jerked my head back every time she tried to give me kisses"").  Sure
column6: on the very next track he's bragging about his ""lesbian broad who only fucks me"" and stewing over an impromptu orgy spoiled by a pal's wedding ring and a Charles Oakley Topps trading card (it makes sense in context
column7: trust)
column8: but it doesn't contradict eXquire so much as humanize him as someone trying to reconcile the instinct to be the better man while making and being a fan of morally reprehensible hip-hop. And really
column9: that's indicative of how eXquire's magnetism as an MC is much like Danny Brown's
column10: even though as rappers
column11:
their styles are wholly complementary rather than similar outside of a tremendous appetite for women and drugs. You leave their music feeling that there really isn't much of a separation between what they're saying and what they're living.

It's hard to determine what the biggest surprise is regarding BAYTL: that it wasn't a joke
column2: or that it isn't a joke. As far as the former goes: Yes

column5: has done a full album with V-Nasty
column6: the Kreayshawn sidekick who's famous only for being a white person that has vigorously defended her usage of
column7: and her further right to use
column8: the n-word. As for the latter
column9: BAYTL is a surprisingly competent and sometimes fun low-stakes rap album
column10: far from the disaster it could've been.

column1: Though there are many ways in which the album might have gone off the rails
column2: it's fairly easy to pinpoint why it often succeeds. One major reason is that Gucci and V-Nasty smartly decided to let underground big shot Zaytoven-- long one of Gucci's favorite and most fruitful collaborators-- handle the lion's share of the production. His beats are workshops in space and melody
column3: stretching keyboard notes (that mimic organs) like they're taffy until the rappers have a melodic
column4: yet unobtrusive
column5: canvas to paint on. In Gucci's heyday the two were a constant source of gold
column6: with Zay's production pairing harmoniously with Gucci's playful
column7: inventive flows. On BAYTL
column8: Zay is probably asked to carry too much of the load
column9: and his effectiveness becomes dulled over the course of the album. But allowing him to produce nearly the entire record brings professionalism
column10: cohesion
column11: and coherence to a project that threatened to have none of the above.

column1: V-Nasty
column2: for her part
column3: also acquits herself better than you would think. Her voice is atonal in a way that's more off-putting than interesting
column4: and her flow can get clumsy and cluttered at times
column5: but she's more or less up to the task of writing half of a decent album
column6: which is more than you could say for some rappers famous for being actual rappers. She gets by well enough on swagger and brashness
column7: and without the baggage her contributions would scan as acceptingly perfunctory. It would be hard to argue that the world needs V-Nasty's rapping-- and it doesn't
column8: obviously-- but she'll get clowned for being a try-hard white girl when in reality there were at least four worse rappers in XXL's ""2011 Freshman Class.""

column1: In a cruel and sad twist of irony
column2: easily the best verse on the album belongs to Slim Dunkin
column3: who shines on ""Push Ups"". Dunkin was murdered in Atlanta last month as he prepared for the filming of the video for that song. If there's anything truly exciting to be pulled from BAYTL
column4: it's Slim's marked improvement as a writer
column5: something that makes his premature death even sadder.

column1: As for Gucci himself
column2: he sounds sober and engaged
column3: which is a step up from where he was for most of last year. He's on autopilot here
column4: but he works so well with Zaytoven that the only drawback is that it allows you to dream of how good a full collaborative album between the two would've been three years ago. Gucci's major issue now-- even more than his lost affinity for cinematic imagery-- is that humor and creativity have been all but sapped from his writing
column5: leaving us an MC whose aggressive braggadocio comes off as unnecessarily defensive. When
column6: late on the album
column7: Gucci raps
column8: ""I'm not romantic
column9: but I cook my dope candlelit
column10: it's as stunning as if you ran into a good friend you thought you'd never see again. But
column11: just as quickly
column12: that Gucci disappears.

column1: BAYTL is a record that
column2: contrary to the hopes of some and the fears of others
column3: isn't a huge failure or massive embarrassment. The talent of all involved-- fading in some
column4: and bubbling in others-- ends up taking control of the sideshow. But with that said
column5: the album
column6: more than anything
column7: is a bizarre and unique artifact of rap music in 2011. It's a record that marks the time when the ""Gucci Gucci"" rapper's homegirl became notorious enough to do an album with Gucci Mane
column8:
and when Gucci Mane had fallen far enough to decide to go along with it.

It's hard to say where Jennifer O'Connor fits into the world. Over the past decade she's tried a few different nooks and crannies: After releasing her debut on her own Kiam Records in 2002 and a second album on Red Panda in 2005
column2: she joined the ranks of Matador Records
column3: who put out her next two LPs. She recorded the first for the new label in the wake of her sister's death from brain cancer; she'd lost another sister to a car accident years before. That record was warm enough
column4: and cool enough
column5: to nearly obscure the heartbreak writhing just under the surface
column6: but there was a certain darkness to the tracks
column7: a foundational uneasiness
column8: that lingered well into even the ostensibly cheerier Here With Me. O'Connor was dropped by Matador within the year of that third collection; her new record I Want What You Want comes on the heels of three years spent working odd jobs and piecing together a life bungled up by recording and touring (and
column9: well
column10: life) and finds her self-releasing through Kiam once more.

column1: The new songs aren't likable so much as largely undislikeable; they seem so unconcerned with anything other than their own gentle resolution that it's hard to fault them for any shortcomings. O'Connor leads each one with her acoustic guitar and her voice
column2: ever steady and sure
column3: and all the other parts are there
column4: solid and familiar-- drums
column5: bass
column6: all marbled with electric guitar. The songs are what they are; they are what they want to be. Each gets its own small
column7: shimmering moment-- an uptick of inflection at the end of a line
column8: a tiny twist of backing harmonies
column9: a particularly satisfying tambourine shake-- which all feel so good and so right that it's tempting to misread her ongoing studies in musical economy and subtlety as lack of ambition and self-satisfaction
column10: just to shame her into something grander.

column1: The circumstances of the lyrics are mostly nonspecific relationship tangles
column2: the stuff a singer less acutely familiar with soul-shaking personal tragedy might thrill in stewing in for 40-plus minutes. But O'Connor's songs are not vehicles of catharsis and exorcism so much as of acceptance
column3: of moving on from events already past-- though perhaps not so far gone that a gentle reminder of how to proceed isn't warranted. ""If you make up your mind
column4: you can change your life/ Change your life

Nate Young might not have meant the title of his 2009 LP Regression as a description of his musical direction. But the album's stark
column3: slow tones are a sonic reduction compared to his work with John Olson in Stare Case
column4: a project that itself trims back the noise the pair make as a part of Wolf Eyes. Young's path hasn't been completely linear-- Wolf Eyes often sound stark
column5: too
column6: and Regression included a few noisy moments.But his sequel to Regression
column7: Stay Asleep
column8: might be his most minimal work ever.

column1: Each of the album's five songs is built from two basic elements-- a loop of low notes and a metronomic beat. Synths and other electronics add small accents
column2: but often the bass and rhythm march forward unadorned. With this small arsenal of sounds
column3: Young makes music that gets tenser without actually changing much. It's tough to put a finger on how his repetitive notes can feel like a stair-climb instead of a still-life. Every track is pretty clean-- there are no hazy sonics or cloaking distortion. Yet when I listen
column4: I'm less aware of what's happening musically than the mood the music creates.

column1: That mood is almost always eerie and dark. Young's sparse approach gives Stay Asleep tons of negative sonic space
column2: making it as creepy as an unlit basement. The horror-movie feel is similar to that of Prurient's last record
column3: Bermuda Drain. But where Dominick Fernow openly mimics the tropes of 1970s slasher soundtracks
column4: Young's songs are more like analogues to onscreen suspense. In his tick-tock tones
column5: time seems to creep unstoppably toward potential doom.

column1: For Young
column2: though
column3: Stay Asleep isn't so much a countdown to danger as a guard against it
column4: ""a hex sign... that can protect against the 'evil eye.'"" As he explained to Tiny Mix Tapes
column5: ""I like the idea of distracting negative energy with art and holding it at bay."" Closer ""Collapse"" succeeds at that goal
column6: with piano chords that suggest rising optimism in the face of gloom. But it's also the album's weirdest track
column7: with Olson's horns and (ex-Wolf Eye) Aaron Dilloway's tape effects adding a warpy insanity. Ending with such a surreal tone suggests that the title Stay Asleep is an actual command. Maybe this isn't a horror movie but simply a dream
column8:
and the only real danger is waking up from its entrancing sounds.

column5: that take-no-prisoners
column6: ""I slap bitches

It baffles me when a DJ receives praise for weaving together different subgenres of electronic dance music. Techno and tech-house? Electro and Italo? Wasn't that
column2: like
column3: the second thought people had after they realized they could mix records? (Somewhere in New York
column4: Nicky Siano is sitting in a rent-controlled apartment spinning Led Zeppelin into Bobby Womack
column5: laughing his ass off.) This dynamic matters
column6: as France's Brodinski is one of a wave of European artists who have come to prominence as much for their mixing skills as for their productions (see also: Jackmaster). Fabriclive 60 is Brodinski's second commercial mix in addition to a handful of downloads
column7: and while it's correct to say that he deploys an array of genres during his 75 minutes on the decks
column8: it's more constructive to think of FL60 as a collection of whinnying
column9: vocally oriented dance tracks that Brodinski meticulously bends to his will.

column1: Brodinski has a way with these tracks that forces you to forget or disregard genre distinctions. During a potent three-song stretch
column2: he moves from house (Renaissance Man's ""Stalker Humanoid"") to UK funky (T. Williams' ""Heartbeat [Paul Woolford Remix]"") to footwork (John Roman's ""Petrified"")
column3: a game of genre-hopscotch capable of making your head spin. The result
column4: though
column5: isn't discombobulated or showy. ""Petrified"" isn't a DJ curveball or change of pace: It's a siren
column6: because the mix required a siren. An old athletic scouting maxim: Don't tell me what a player can't do; tell me what he can. So it goes with Brodinski
column7: who doesn't look at a track's particular rhythmic and tonal variances as obstacles; he uses a deft hand to tease out what they do have in common.

column1: FL60 is as fun and freewheeling a mix as you'd expect from someone who recently named his label Bromance Records. For dance music fans mostly focused on Berlin and London
column2: FL60 is a treat. Brodinski drags along relative unknowns and newcomers like Gesaffelstein
column3: TWR72
column4: and Renaissance Man. Switch and Andrea Martin's incredible
column5: inflammatory ballad ""I Still Love You"" deserves every bit of additional exposure it gets. Brodinski's own remix (as Gucci Vump) of Woodkid's ""Iron"" is a stormy
column6: brass-stained anthem. When Brodinski isn't painting in big
column7: bold strokes like this
column8: he strings you along with righteous
column9: uptempo thumpers from the likes of Instra:mental and Samuel L. Session.

column1: Fabriclive 60 features no agenda save perhaps making you and Brodinski grin. It's not a genre exploration (dBridge and Instra:mental's Fabriclive 50
column2: Pearson Sound) or an artist showcase (Omar S
column3: Ricardo Villalobos). It's not even really a ""party"" mix
column4: though you could use it as such. Brodinski isn't as varied and creative a mixer as Jackmaster
column5: but he has an ear for vocal melodies and a healthy lack of tunnelvision when it comes to genres. It's enough to make FL60 one of the series' more surprising
column6:
flatly enjoyable offerings.

Finnish vocalist Olivia Merilahti and French multi-instrumentalist Dan Levy are nothing if not aware of other pop music. The best song on the duo's debut album as the Dø
column2: 2008's A Mouthful
column3: is a bittersweet rewriting of Etta James' walking-down-the-aisle standby ""At Last""
column4: a take that makes the 1960 original sound inappropriately boastful by comparison-- not least by swapping out the classic song's orchestral swoon for understated
column5: autumnal indie rock recalling Liz Phair
column6: Mary Timony

column8: ""Playground Hustle""

column11: ""Crazy"".

column1: The Dø's sophomore album-- finally available worldwide after being released in some parts of Europe this past March-- keeps up the genre-hopscotching whimsicality of the debut while also urging us to approach music more innocently. The subtle difference is apparent from the best song on Both Ways Open Jaws
column2: video selection ""Too Insistent"": Where ""At Last!"" holds back from excessively gloating about love
column3: this song rejects our advances altogether; rather than smolder with melancholy
column4: it perches Merilahti's elfin coo atop the kind of meticulously off-kilter
column5: orchestral
column6: and kids-choir uplift that makes Sufjan Stevens' ""Chicago"" or Jónsi's ""Go Do"" such hits with movie licensing dudes. The narrator compares herself to ""a tiny toe
column7: and questions ""people who act like they think they have seen it all/ They're so indifferent."" She's right and she's wrong; it's often easier to dismiss someone else's personal preference by labeling them as too-cool-for-school hipsters than it is to engage with the possibility they're right.

column1: More often than not
column2: the contradictions between the band's knowing appropriations and its calls against jaded cynicism resolve themselves in the album's intricately rewarding attention to rich and unexpected sonic details. As Both Ways Open Jaws traipses from the Tom Waits-via-Lykke Li boho-hobo hoedown of ""Gonna Be Sick!"" to charming electro-folk waltz ""The Calendar""
column3: it makes plenty of detours for unlikely avant-pop percussion and warped vocal effects. There's even another kiddie-M.I.A. song
column4: the tribal chirp of ""Slippery Slope"". On lilting
column5: piano-cracked opener ""Dust It Off""
column6: Merilahti claims
column7: ""Nothing has been before."" Between the elegiac folkie guitars and electronic squelches of ""The Wicked & the Blind""
column8: she adds
column9: ""Forget your knowledge/ Forget the past/ You were somehow born today."" But it isn't that easy
column10:
is it? While this time around the Dø have covered another ubiquitous-in-2008 pop song-- Kings of Leon's breakthrough ""Sex on Fire"" in a recent BBC session-- it might be hard to hear the similarities in terms of head-slapping lowest-common-denominator commercial potential. Then again: Both Ways Open Jaws has teeth like a shark.

It's been more than a decade since Finnish producer Sasu Ripatti
column2: under his Luomo alias
column3: redefined expectations for vocal house with his micro-masterpiece Vocalcity. In the years since
column4: as vocal house has made a comeback in more full-throated
column5: traditionalist terms
column6: Ripatti's kept Luomo shifting
column7: his productions growing increasingly crisp and functional
column8: gradually sweating off the liquid murk of his early releases to emerge as cold and bright tech-house.

column1: While Luomo's evolved
column2: Ripatti's other best known alias
column3: Vladislav Delay
column4: has remained devoted to a singular vision of ambient techno and cold digital dub. With few digressions-- such as last year's exploration of acoustic space and live instrumentation with the Vladislav Delay Quartet-- Vladislav Delay's releases have progressed as a series of subtle tweaks and refinements. Ripatti's as studious and attentive a sound designer as he is a reinventer of genres
column5: and though he saves his game-changing leaps forward for Luomo
column6: his variations on Vladislav Delay's themes are immaculately produced and almost as engrossing.

column1: If there isn't already
column2: there should be a rule that Vladislav Delay only put out albums in the wintertime. Whether it's the influence of Ripatti's northern longitude or merely a reflection of some internal aesthetic
column3: Vladislav Delay's records give off a distinctly frozen feel. Synths hum and hiss white noise like cold wind
column4: drums clatter like ice or crunch like snow underfoot
column5: rhythms break apart from themselves like ice floes. Beyond the individually chilly elements
column6: there's the overall sense of low light and hibernatory slowness: The tracks play out like a still landscape troubled by only the occasional moving figure. If that makes Vantaa sound more like background than foreground
column7: fair enough. Yet rather than being dull or inhospitable
column8: it makes for a consistently habitable environment.

column1: Some pieces gradually come together-- ""Narri"" coalesces into a little melody
column2: as does ""Levite""
column3: the latter teasing a skipping beat out of its soft swaying keys and evaporative sounds. Others
column4: like the title track
column5: seem to be carefully breaking apart as they unfold. ""Lauma"" might be the most unexpected track
column6: and also the album's late climax
column7: an initial echo turning into a rapid fan-buzzing vibration and then a pneumatic double-time drum figure not so far removed from gabber.

column1: While any given moment of the album offers a satisfying sonic foothold
column2: you truly get a sense of Ripatti's skill and vision over the entire course of the record: Hearing any 10 seconds
column3: you might think the stuff static
column4: but Vantaa's glacial movements carve unpredictable channels. In a way
column5: this music is as simultaneously functional and pleasurable as Luomo's more active house tracks
column6:
only it's for an opposite function-- and a more sedate set of pleasure centers.

column1: Where House of Balloons was a debut tour-de-force
column2: and Thursday an arduous journey into the internal turmoil of a self-loathing narcissist
column3: Echoes of Silence exudes a brazen
column4: animalistic confidence: The production is impeccable but never showy. The songwriting is tighter and more streamlined. The slinky
column5: spectral ""Montreal"" is the closest thing to a pure pop song Tesfaye has written since ""What You Need"". And his conversational intonation emphasizes the lingering threat that underlies every lyric.

column1: In lyrical terms
column2: Echoes of Silence is Tesfaye's strongest work. With a clearer and less obtuse narrative arc than Thursday
column3: the album finds his snaky
column4: manipulative persona at its most blatantly corrosive. Album centerpiece ""XO / The Host"" is a stomach-turning tale of corruption and coercion
column5: featuring one of the record's most uncomfortable moments: After Tesfaye sings of reducing some nameless girl to destitution
column6: the beat goes quiet as he self-satisfyingly mocks
column7: ""And if they won't let you in/ You know where to find me... 'cause all we ever do is love."" It's transparently deceptive
column8: and it slips into ""Initiation""
column9: a cringe-inducingly detailed tale of drug-fueled kidnapping and gang-rape told through the part-grunted
column10: part-rapped exhortations of an inhuman goblin.

column1: With drums that stutter and slice more like Trent Reznor than Tricky
column2: ""Initiation"" handily defines what separates the Weeknd from other R&B acts
column3: folding in the post-punk influences
column4: the industrial touches
column5: and that oddly alluring menace into four minutes of captivating hell. While Tesfaye's voice remains the star attration
column6: Illangelo's production is at a high point on Echoes: From the decadent ""Hong Kong Garden"" orientalisms on ""Outside"" to the heart-rending vocal looping on ""The Host"" to the sleepy-eyed
column7: morning-after bluntness of ""Same Old Song""
column8: each lecherous tale is lifted by the attentive and elegant production. Those tiny strokes of detail-oriented genius pull Echoes of Silence from ""yet another Weeknd mixtape"" to its own lithe
column9: cocksure plateau
column10: the same way that the meandering production on Thursday emphasized the numbingly sublime feeling of loss and confusion.

column1: A lot has been said of how Tesfaye has run amok with the introspective R&B of artists like Drake and Trey Songz
column2: but the particulars of self-abuse and excess haven't been profiled so intimately or persuasively by any act of comparable size or influence. Of course
column3: all Weeknds must end: producer Clams Casino guest produces ""The Fall""
column4: and his mournful melodies and distorted synths climax in a locust cloud of buzzing and whirring
column5: suddenly rendering Tesfaye's self-reassurances shaky and hollow. The album's eponymous closing track is stark naked
column6: a hospital-bed lament so unflinchingly bright it recalls the Knife's ""Still Light"" in its mournful fatalism. Tesfaye sounds near tears
column7: and as Echoes peters out with his whimpering
column8: ""Don't you leave me all behind/ Don't you leave my little life
column9: it's difficult to tell whether he's quoting a nameless victim or gasping the words himself.

column1: Those four minutes of unguarded sparsity -- Tesfaye's quivering falsetto and a funereal piano-- unwind 2011's most exciting
column2: conflicting
column3: and self-mythologizing musical universe. On closer ""Echoes of Silence""
column4: is Tesfaye's protagonist finally unraveling or merely beginning anew? That his loosely narrative album trilogy seems like it could begin and end at any one of its entry points seems to hint at the latter. It's a chillingly cyclical picture of decay and self-immolation marking the Weeknd's greatest triumph: an emotional thread so confusing we can love
column5: hate
column6: fear
column7: and be revolted all at once.

column1: Tesfaye's recycling of previous lyrics
column2: melodies
column3: and ideas on Echoes of Silence is bound to give fresh ammo to fairweather fans eager to hurl accusations of diminishing returns and unimaginative retreads at the rising Toronto star. But the repetition is akin to devices used by artists as separate as Terius Nash and Dan Bejar
column4: a self-contained world of idiosyncratic artistry that the Weeknd's trilogy ambitiously embraces
column5: rising above the catcalls of inauthenticity and ""PBR&B"" lashed at it from the very beginning to somewhere else completely its own.

column1: ""I used to do this for the thrill
column2: Tesfaye laments on penultimate Echoes track ""Next""
column3: and even as his world disintegrates into the desolate closer
column4: it's hard to think of anything more morbidly thrilling in 2011 than listening to the Weeknd methodically destroy himself. Echoes may lack the surprise-and-delight factor of House of Balloons
column5: but it's a strong finish to Tesfaye's first trilogy
column6: providing just enough closure to satisfy
column7:
and just enough mystery left to entice us back for the next round.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17292/homepage_large.93fa9c2f.jpg|Thug Motivation 103: Hustlerz Ambition|4718.0|Jeezy|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam'
column3: Young Jeezy was invincible
column4: a superhero. He grew famous  peddling an overblown
column5: over-simplified cartoon of machismo and violence
column6: pumped full of dubious sociopolitical implications and adrenaline. His first three albums were some of the last decade's finest action flicks. The widescreen production
column7: from Shawty Redd
column8: DJ Toomp
column9: and others
column10: furnished the exploding tanks while Jeezy  supplied the boiled-down
column11: bumper-sticker dialogue: ""I remember nights/ I  didn't remember nights."" ""Who
column12: me?/ I emerge from the crack smoke."" He was Stallone in Cobra; he was Schwarzenegger in Commando.

column1: But every decade has its own action heroes. Nowadays
column2: Jeezy is just  another down-on-his luck gangsta rapper being jerked around by his  record company. Rick Ross is the overfed rap kingpin of the moment; the  simmering feud between them has nothing to do with street credentials  and everything to do with the fact that in a rap moment mired in  varsity-lettered
column3: middle-class nice guys
column4: there's room for only one Rambo. Thug Motivation 103: Hustlerz Ambition
column5: which has finally wheezed  its way across the finish line
column6: is a telling moment: It's  a solid effort
column7: but it's also the first time that supply for the Snowman's product has begun to outstrip demand.

column1: Nothing much is visibly wrong with Thug Motivation 103. In fact
column2: a lot of it is pretty great: ""Trapped"" opens with a verse from  boho neo-soul queen Jill Scott that induces misplaced nostalgia shivers  for classic Lauryn Hill. Jeezy sells the hoary details of the song's  poverty lament-- no cable in the house
column3: old milk in the empty fridge--  with gut-twisting force. On ""Way Too Gone""
column4: rising Atlanta producer Mike WiLL Made It (Meek Millz's ""Tupac Back""
column5: Gucci Mane's ""East Atlanta 6"") provides a head-spinning cross-breed of trap-rap and cloud rap. The Fabolous and Jadakiss-assisted ""OJ"" provides the extravagant ignorance. All of it is satisfyingly huge- and evil-sounding.

column1: And yet Thug Motivation somehow feels both airless and over-inflated
column2: the sound of an artist trying to revisit something gone. In the long gap between this record and 2008's The Recession
column3: Jeezy has done almost nothing to tweak his formula-- a brief guest appearance by of-the-moment ATL star Future aside
column4: there's  not much here to suggest Jeezy has been keeping tabs on Southern rap's  furiously molting trends
column5: which means even the exciting moments have a certain ""I am big; it's the pictures that got small"" feel.

column1: You can hear the lack of organic excitement most clearly on the album's curiously flat Huge High-Profile Hard-Sell collaboration: ""I Do""
column2: featuring Jay-Z and André 3000. Jay-Z hasn't appeared on a Jeezy record since the remix to ""Go Crazy""
column3: and André 3000 guest verses pop up about as frequently as the  Northern Lights; the result
column4: however
column5: is shockingly unexciting for the pooled talents involved. For one
column6: the song openly mimics the formula of ""International  Player's Anthem""-- ecstatic soul loop
column7: rapturous André verse about marital love-- and baldly copying one of the best rap songs of the  last decade is just a bad idea. When it leaked
column8: it was greeted mostly with  shrugs and yawns and disappeared into the same
column9: sealed-off rap-buzz purgatory  that has settled around other former gangsta-rap heavyweights like 50 Cent.  Despite all indicators
column10: and without a chart or street single
column11: Thug Motivation 103 sold respectably
column12: and probably  beat his label's projections: 233
column14:
just behind Michael Buble's Christmas album and Adele. The Snowman will live to wheeze another day. But his aura of invincibility has been punctured.

Enough with the stopgaps: Since the 2009 release of Sunn O)))'s gloriously oversized Monoliths & Dimensions
column4: the band's principals
column5: Greg Anderson and Stephen O'Malley
column6: have kept busy
column7: though not by recording any new material for their drone-metal vanguard. Together
column8: they've reunited their old Washington state doom squad
column9: Thorr's Hammer
column10: for two festivals and another reissue. Anderson reformed Goatsnake for similar treatment while steering his Southern Lord label into the knotty world of contemporary hardcore. Meanwhile
column11: O'Malley focused on rare collaborations while launching his provocative label
column12: Ideologic Organ
column13: with albums by composer Eyvind Kang and Russian polymaths Phurpa.

column1: The latest tease is a collaborative reissue between Southern Lord and Ideologic Organ. More than a decade after the release of Sunn O)))'s proper debut
column2: ØØ VOID
column3: Southern Lord offers it again
column4: packaged with a bonus disc of remixes of the material by British experimental masters Nurse With Wound. That same material is available via O'Malley's new imprint as the 2xLP set The Iron Soul of Nothing. If those minutiae seem overwhelming
column5: just trust this conclusion: Sunn O)))'s essential ambitions of grand presentation and aggressive collaboration were intact at the start.

column1: Just after completing Monoliths & Dimensions
column2: O'Malley described collaboration to me in terms of the Buddhist concept of the beginner's mind
column3: or of allowing oneself to proceed through tasks without expectations and preconceptions. ""It comes back to working on the sound itself as its own thing rather than having special guests
column4: he said. It may be difficult to hear that sense of inclusion and openness on ØØ VOID
column5: which from the first bass moan of ""Richard"" to the last guitar decay of ""Ra at Dusk"" sounds mostly like unwavering and unapologetic drone metal. On subsequent albums
column6: Sunn O))) incorporated noise lords like Merzbow and John Wiese
column7: a women's choir
column8: Hungarian maniac and Mayhem member Attila Csihar
column9: and an army of others. As O'Malley's quote suggests
column10: they all played an essential role in shaping the band's sound at that moment.

column1: But here Anderson
column2: O'Malley
column3: and longtime partner G. Stuart Dahlquist-- respectively credited as the Duke
column4: MK Ultra Blizzard
column5: and G:Subharmonia-- trudge through riffs in synchronous
column6: suspended time
column7: making up for a lack of surprises with a wealth of tone. They'd recorded their only previous release
column8: The GrimmRobe Demos
column9: in a small Los Angeles studio
column10: but ØØ VOID was captured in Hollywood's Grandmaster
column11: a high-fidelity location where Stevie Wonder
column12: Neil Young
column13: No Doubt
column14: and Tool have all made records. Sunn O))) have always had a reputation for exacting technical standards and for pushing the limits of their force and fidelity (""Maximum Volume Yields Maximum Results
column15: their credo goes)
column16: and ØØ VOID offers the first perfect sign of that. These recordings are monolithic
column17: dense
column18: and relentless
column19: even if the compositions themselves sound much as you might expect.

column1: There are some allusions to extracurricular influences here
column2: like the ghastly vocals of Scream's Pete Stahl
column3: which circle like ghosts inside the electric tide of ""NN O)))"".  A delicate pluck opens ""Rabbit's Revenge""
column4: and long
column5: thin tones sometimes rise to gird a riff's lumbering end. Speaking of subtle additions
column6: the 14-minute crawl is a cover of an early version of the Melvins song that some have suggested (and others have contested) became 1992's ""Hung Bunny""; listen closely past the five-minute mark
column7: and you'll notice that Sunn O))) seem to have momentarily drafted a drummer and a screamer. It's actually a bootleg of Melvins playing the song
column8: the sample spliced beneath the drone as both acknowledgement and texture. Years later
column9: Sunn O)))'s evolution would come to depend on such outside sounds.

column1: But the Nurse With Wound renderings of the material-- lifted from a transfer of the complete sessions by studio wizard Mell Dettmer in 2007-- offer a prophetically revisionist take on Sunn O)))'s eventual incorporation of mostly everything. The icy ""Dysnystaxis (A Chance Meeting With Somnus)"" punctuates a glowing stasis with short bass throbs and softer sounds that suggest Jon Hassell's recent nuevo-ambient riches playing in the next room
column2: not unlike moments of Monoliths & Dimensions. Both ""Ra at Dawn Part One (Rapture
column3: at Last)"" and ""Ra at Dawn Part Two (Numbered by Her Light)"" quell Sunn O)))'s beastly roar into a sort of barely there industrial static
column4: the signal's strength oscillating like the processes of an assembly line. The most typically Nurse With Wound pieces here
column5: these remixes show that aggression alone isn't enough to make something sound sinister; these hums move as though they're alive
column6: each ghastly manipulation haunting the space as if for the first time.

column1: But these three pieces are mere curios compared to ""Ash on the Trees (The Sudden Ebb of a Diatribe)""
column2: the real reason this set of reissues is worth the investment. Steven Stapleton and Colin Potter pull Stahl's vocals from beneath the mire
column3: pitting his sneered apocalyptic visions against crests and collapses of mutated noise. It's a terrifying maze of tangents
column4: like the early works of Nurse With Wound cronies Current 93 and O'Malley's own Khanate remixed by some actualization of evil. As O'Malley suggested years later
column5:
it's a synthesis that is more about the ""sound itself"" than the special guests lending their name to it.
