Swiss producer Dimlite and his Now-Again label boss Eothen Alapatt
column2: better known as Egon
column3: clearly function with the same voracious appetite for crate digging. Egon's label has released everything from library music to Brazilian psychedelia
column4: as well as their staple funk and soul-oriented work. Dimlite's prior album
column5: the 2010 release Prismic Tops
column6: worked off the hip-hop template he generally beds his sound in
column7: then guzzled a rich bounty of conflicting styles
column8: all cut together without too many joints showing. Grimm Reality behaves in much the same way
column9: except fuller
column10: faster
column11: brighter
column12: and with even more colors ladled into the mix. It's the best kind of grab-bag pop
column13: where each idea is never labored over long enough for it to get old
column14: retaining the same kind of ADD-infused freshness riddled through the Avalanches' Since I Left You or Beastie Boys' Paul's Boutique.

column1: Like those records
column2: Grimm Reality is fired up by a constant desire to disarrange
column3: to put everything together then gleefully throw it all up in the air and watch where the pieces land. But that impulse is mollified by a degree of control. Dimlite may take great joy in jerking his audience from Krautrock to funk to candy-coated pop tones
column4: but he's got a way of getting from A-Z that makes it more palatable than jarring. His whimsical approach is mirrored in train-of-thought song titles like ""Blur
column5: Blur
column6: Blur
column7: Blur""
column8: ""Through the Grimms/Stars Down""
column9: and ""One of Uh Infinity's Countless Uh Tiny Cycles"". Anyone thumbing through sleeves in a record store may mistake Grimm Reality for a Liars or Pavement side project after a cursory glance at the song titles
column10: and the music often bears many allusions to rock. ""Pour Some Blood
column11: We Got This"" even sounds like one of the pitched-down vocal experiments Beck was fostering back on Stereopathetic Soulmanure.

column1: The use-once-and-destroy approach means we never get back to such terrain
column2: but the strength of Dimlite's ideas make the constant forward thrust worthwhile. When he digs into Can-like bass repetition on ""Blur
column3: Blur
column4: Blur
column5: Blur"" or the fresh-faced
column6: new-age drift of ""Yes
column7: Welcome""
column8: it may feel like he's reaching down into areas he could gouge out a little more. But there's always another twist worth navigating
column9: whether it's through the Beach Boys-like harmonies of ""XY"" or the mutant funk of the closing ""Heroine Roof"". This is multitask composition
column10: where it feels like Dimlite has a thousand different ideas stacked up in his sampler
column11: all begging for attention at the same time. Sometimes his attempt to sate those voices falls flat-- the meandering post-rock feel of ""Healing a Random Tyrant"" lacks the clarity on display elsewhere-- but he's quickly back on his feet with the deliriously spasmodic funk-pop of ""Than Them"".

column1: Grimm Reality is an album that ebbs and flows
column2: occasionally slipping into turgid cul-de-sacs (particularly on the malformed bass grind of ""Fridge Note"")
column3: but rarely failing to move relentlessly ahead of itself to make up for lost ground. When Dimlite is at his most successful
column4: he's drawing on strands from everything around him at dizzying speed. ""One of Uh Infinity's Countless Uh Tiny Cycles"" is the best example of that
column5: with wild psychedelic organ
column6: motorik drum patterns
column7: synth drones
column8: and a great globule of distorted bass all churned together
column9: somehow making sense in a space where none should be found at all. That track ends in a brief flurry of strings
column10: completely incongruous to the feel of the rest of the track
column11: but perfect as a way to shut it all down. Those kind of spaces are where Dimlite pulls all his strength
column12:
in the half-light between sense and nonsense.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17274/homepage_large.1078a8f7.jpg|Tragedy & Geometry|29955.0|Steve Hauschildt|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2012-01-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:06.883836|"

The music of Cleveland trio Emeralds is pretty wide
column2: both in the range of sounds and instruments they use
column3: and the expansive feel of their New Age-tinted creations. For his first proper solo release (after a handful of low-run cassettes and CD-Rs)
column4: Emeralds member Steve Hauschildt took a step in the opposite direction. As he told the website Stool Pigeon
column5: Tragedy & Geometry ""came from just wanting to spend time with one instrument and really exploring all the possibilities of sound you can get from that.""

column1: The instrument in question is synthesizer
column2: and the music Hauschildt makes with it is like Emeralds in miniature. He focuses on small
column3: basic patterns that produce two kinds of songs-- slow
column4: drifting drones and pulsing
column5: minimalist loops. The effect can be as big and spacious as anything his group does
column6: but Hauschildt always starts from a base of simplicity. Each track is an exercise in turning tiny sounds and gradual shifts into something large.

column1: The lack of obvious variety could make Tragedy & Geometry sound generic
column2: but Hauschildt's devout tack actually gives the album a distinct personality. Choose any single track
column3: and reference points quickly come to mind-- Tangerine Dream
column4: Steve Reich
column5: and various half-remembered foreign film scores and PBS-doc soundtracks. But listen in sequence
column6: and Hauschildt's consistent way with this kind of sound becomes clear
column7: in a starry-eyed mix of small swells and planetarium-friendly wonder. At times the music can get sentimental and even sappy
column8: but it's never heavy-handed. In Hauschildt's songs
column9: emotion feels closer to a happy accident than an overarching intention.

column1: This comes across strongest in Tragedy & Geometry's best cut
column2: ""Music for a Moiré Pattern"". At 11 minutes
column3: it's by far the album's longest piece
column4: but it's no grand epic. Though its sparkly loops crest into some moving crescendos
column5: its core is simple repetition and the fascinating patterns it creates. Throughout
column6: Hauschildt deftly treads the fine line between guiding his instrument and letting its cyclical mechanisms do the work. You get the sense that he's basically happy to get out of his own way-- a common goal with anything this mantra-like-- and is as awed by the hypnotic aspects of overlapping synths as the emotional ones. Maybe that's the key to Tragedy & Geometry's sneaky power-- by letting his synths tell tales instead of forcing them to
column7:
Hauschildt finds stories bigger than his own.

Lioness is not Amy Winehouse's long-lost gem or interrupted follow-up album
column2: nor is it a revealing view of a tortured star in the fraught final stages of her life. Instead
column3: in true record-industry fashion
column4: Lioness is a collection of odds-and-sods cobbled together over the course of nine years of recordings to create something that kinda-sorta feels like an album. Executive produced by longtime partner Salaam Remi
column5: who helmed her 2003 debut album
column6: Frank
column7: Lioness carries little of the subversive swagger or playful arrogance of the Mark Ronson-dominated Back to Black. Whether it's merely all the material that was left
column8: or an effort to salvage her image after years of tabloid drama and self-abuse
column9: Lioness presents a picture of a talented singer at her most restrained and polite. And let's be honest: Polite is the last thing we expect (or want) from Amy Winehouse.

column1: That's not to say the results aren't satisfying: No matter what she's singing
column2: it remains thrilling to hear that voice come to life again. On Lioness
column3: for better or for worse
column4: she takes on the role of standards singer: It feels like a hearkening back to her jazzy Frank days
column5: the result of having Remi at the head of the project rather than Ronson. When it works
column6: it really works: Opener ""Our Day Will Come"" is a gorgeous blend of triumph and autumnal wistfulness
column7: a savvy intro to a record that's bound to evoke emotions just as nuanced and conflicted in its listeners. However
column8: on tracks like ""The Girl From Ipanema"" or first single and Tony Bennett duet ""Body and Soul""
column9: she sounds like a lounge singer
column10: that unmistakable wit and smarmy charm only a faint glint in otherwise serviceable performances.

column1: Considering that Mark Ronson-- producer of her signature tracks like ""Rehab""-- is probably more responsible for her fame than anyone else
column2: it's surprising to see his involvement reduced to such a minuscule level. As ever
column3: his contributions are the highlight: A new version of the Zutons' ""Valerie"" turns what was a tongue-in-cheek cover into one of her most infectious vocal performances. Meanwhile
column4: his melodramatic rendering of Carole King's ""Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow"" toes the line between elegant and overblown
column5: but better yet it's a shroud of pomp surrounding one of Winehouse's most delicately powerful vocals. When she breaks out into her best falsetto on the track's bridge
column6: it's one of the few moments on Lioness that feels truly
column7: heartbreakingly poignant
column8: enough to cut through its stodgy accompaniment.

column1: Winehouse's best material never came from covers or standards
column2: however
column3: but her personality: her bitter sarcasm
column4: her flagrant profanity
column5: and her dominant-but-demure air of not-giving-a-fuck. Even though half of Lioness is by her own pen
column6: it's a different view of Winehouse's songwriting persona: The gorgeous ballad ""Half Time"" is endearing but lacks the sardonic bite of her other slower material like ""Wake Up Alone"" (which itself is included in an alternate Remi-produced version here)
column7: and it's easy to imagine the fake-cutesy ""Best Friends
column8: Right?"" being more effective given an arrangement that wasn't so transparently cutesy. Back to Black highlight ""Tears Dry on Their Own"" is present in its ""original version
column9: an almost unrecognizably elegiac arrangement that on the other hand not only emphasizes the strength of Winehouse's own songwriting but its diversity as well.

column1: Chalk it up to fine-tuned and image-conscious execution
column2: but there's little on Lioness: Hidden Treasures that sounds throwaway
column3: or like it should have never been released; but there's equally little that sounds absolutely essential. Released before the album
column4: the Nas collaboration ""Like Smoke"" seems like an attempt at a new Winehouse jam
column5: a pertinent reminder of her slightly more adult-contemporary-challenging ""urban"" side
column6: the part of her that made her more than just a Grammy-adorned
column7: technically proficient singer. Here the track sounds like a guide vocal
column8: unsure and smothered in reverb
column9: with Nas filling in an excess of white space rather than just guesting. On the otherwise funny
column10: doo-wop-styled ""Between the Cheats""
column11: her detached drawl enters full-on mumble territory
column12: Winehouse sounding like she either can't remember or can't enunciate the words. The chorus of backing vocals feels mocking as a result
column13: but it's a necessary moment of discomfort on a record that sometimes feels like it's desperately trying to sanitize a wild spirit after years of chaos.

column1: If that all sounds a little negative
column2: it's because Lioness is still weighed down with the baggage that goes along with any posthumous compilation-- but as these things go
column3: it's a pretty strong disc. It flows well
column4: and if Winehouse didn't sound so oddly neutered on so much of it
column5: Lioness could easily be another solid entry in her catalog. As it stands
column6: though
column7: it sounds like the anachronistic time-travel job it is
column8: going backward through the career of an artist who had a very distinct developmental arc. At least in one regard
column9: Island and Salaam Remi have done the ""honorable"" thing: There's no pretense of artistic intention here
column10: and no exploitative stabs at an artist in the most vulnerable moments of her short life. But in their mission to present Winehouse as a singer first and foremost
column11: whiting out her personal problems and demons-- the very things that made Back to Black such a transcendent album in the first place-- they reduce her to her pre-Black standard of budding talent. Instead of adding anything concrete to her legacy
column12: Lioness only reaffirms what we already knew about her
column13:
and hopefully why she deserves to be remembered as an artist rather than a media circus.

Can have long been one of those bands that are more talked about than heard. They were enormously influential on certain kinds of forward-thinking rock artists (their fingerprints are all over Radiohead and the Flaming Lips
column3: not to mention more more recent underground acts like Woods and Implodes); their records have never been out of print for long. But they've got a big
column4: disorderly discography
column5: and they don't really have any signature songs (the Can tracks that pass for pop-- ""Spoon""
column6: ""I Want More""
column7: and not many others-- are alarmingly unlike the rest of their work). They're also tougher to ""get"" than a lot of their contemporaries: They specialized in long
column8: jam-heavy rock grooves
column9: and they had (two different) aggressively difficult vocalists
column10: as well as a guitarist (the late Michael Karoli) who liked to noodle way up in the treble range. So where do you start?

column1: You couldn't do much better than beginning with 1971's Tago Mago
column2: freshly reissued in a ""40th Anniversary Edition"" (whose main difference from previous editions is the addition of a live disc from the following year). It's a colossus of an album
column3: the product of a band that was thinking huge
column4: pushing itself to its limits
column5: and devoted to breaking open its own understanding of what rock music could be. The core of Can was four German musicians from wildly different backgrounds-- when they initially came together in 1968
column6: two of them had studied with composer Karlheinz Stockhausen
column7: one had played jazz
column8: and one was a teenage guitar whiz. They recorded soundtrack music and a few straightforward rock songs early on
column9: but what they were really interested in doing was going beyond kinds of music for which they had language.

column1: For some musicians of that time
column2: that meant replacing (or augmenting) composition with improvisation: letting the unconscious mind take over in the instant
column3: and recording the results. Can's insight was that jamming alone wasn't going to do the trick. One of their solutions to that problem was that
column4: like Miles Davis' electric group at the time
column5: they were not a jam band but a jam-and-edit band. Their working method involved collectively improvising on little riffs and grooves at enormous length
column6: but that's not quite what you hear on Tago Mago. Bassist Holger Czukay chopped up
column7: layered and extensively reorganized pieces of their recordings (including recordings they made when they didn't think the tape was rolling)
column8: imposing afterthought on instinct to create something as densely packed as composition but distinctly different.

column1: Their other solution was smashing the crutch of language. After Can's original singer Malcolm Mooney had left the band in 1970
column2: they'd encountered a Japanese street artist named Damo Suzuki ""singing or 'praying' in the streets of Munich"" (as Czukay put it) and immediately installed him as their new frontman. Suzuki is ostensibly vocalizing in English-- the lingua franca of rock-- but English that's either seriously mangled or almost totally faked.

column1: Tago Mago is seven songs in 73 minutes; the first half is big-beat floor-fillers
column2: the second half yanks the floor away. For those first four songs
column3: drummer Jaki Liebezeit is the star of the band
column4: setting up rhythmic patterns of his own devising (isolate his part of almost any Can song
column5: and you'd immediately know what you were listening to) and repeating them like mantras. His drumming is actually the lead instrument on ""Mushroom""
column6: which could very easily pass for a post-punk classic from 10 years later; everything else just adds a little tone color. (The song might be about a psychedelic mushroom
column7: or a mushroom cloud
column8: or maybe just the kind that comes in a can.) And his deliberate
column9: crisply articulated marching-band-of-the-unconscious beat is the spine of the overwhelming ""Halleluwah""
column10: possibly the only 18-minute song that would be too short at twice its length.

column1: Then the trip turns sour and trembly. ""Aumgn"" is almost as long as ""Halleluwah"" but clammy
column2: deliberately disjointed
column3: and nearly rhythmless; its central sound is keyboardist Irmin Schmidt's repeatedly intoning elongated
column4: mangled variations on the meditative ""om."" Both ""Aumgn"" and its follow-up ""Peking O"" mess with their listeners' perception of time-- everything in them happens much more quickly or slowly than it's supposed to
column5: and as soon as any pattern of sound has stuck around long enough to grab onto
column6: it shudders and evaporates. By the time the dreamy
column7: softly throbbing one-chord piece ""Bring Me Coffee or Tea"" arrives to conclude the album
column8: it's almost hard to trust it not to be a mirage.

column1: The bonus for the new edition (aside from a reproduction of the original sleeve
column2: with four variations on a semi-abstract image concerning the mouth and the mind) is a three-song 1972 live recording: something identified as ""Mushroom"" that shares nothing but a couple of lines with the Tago Mago version
column3: a ""Halleluwah"" that fades out after nine minutes without generating the studio recording's heat
column4: and a half-hour workout on the band's three-minute German hit ""Spoon"". It's okay-- they were a solid jam band
column5: and Liebezeit could pull off those remarkable rhythms on stage
column6:
too-- but it's mostly interesting for its perspective on how much less a band Can might have been without Czukay's keen razor blade slashing away their excesses and preserving their flashes of revelation.

Nicolas Jaar creates slow
column2: strange
column3: cloistered songs with keyboards and field recordings
column4: breath
column5: and drums. He makes synthesizers feel like natural elements
column6: mingled with running waters
column7: murmuring voices
column8: and sighing winds. Jaar called his breakthrough record Space Is Only Noise
column9: expanded on a key track to ""Space Is Only Noise if You Can See"". Titles are often red herrings
column10: but this is the rare case where we might pause and come to understand something essential about Jaar's perspective. No one has found a good box for him yet
column11: likely because he doesn't make a kind of music
column12: but a way of music. (In purely diagnostic terms
column13: our own Mike Powell's ""downtempo minimalism"" is the best shorthand I've read
column14: though it wisely doesn't even venture to address the music's sense.) Jaar's new EP as Darkside
column15: a collaboration with guitarist and bassist Dave Harrington
column16: clarifies things further
column17: but we've got to unpack a little before we come to it.

column1: Listen again: Space is only noise if you can see. The nouns and verbs are flashier
column2: but the devil's in the adverbs and conjunctions. I kind of hate that rogue ""only
column3: that innocent-faced little ""if."" Does it mean that if you can see
column4: you discover space is merely noise? Or that space becomes noise only upon being seen? And what the hell would either of those things mean? Jaar doesn't make it that easy for us. His assertive yet ambiguous phrasing has no solvable outcome
column5: so it sticks in your mind-- or rather
column6: your mind sticks up against it. And this may be the key to how Jaar's music works too. He applies a chilly
column7: commanding logic to disassociated quantities until they fall into a restive equilibrium. He creates biospheres and then adds one extra
column8: destabilizing element
column9: or leaves out something crucial. His songs pose enigmatic questions disguised as bold assertions. Meaning leaks out of the substance to pool in the cracks
column10: and things that shouldn't relate
column11: do.

column1: That Jaar is more about means than ends explains why he's able to transition so seamlessly from dreamy electronic music inflected with impressionist piano
column2: gently digitized French singing
column3: lobby-jazz
column4: and cave sounds to the terse
column5: rugged dub-funk of Darkside
column6: all while still sounding totally Jaar: nocturnal
column7: cerebral
column8: sensuous
column9: paradoxical
column10: and intuitive. (And sounding totally Jaar is a remarkable thing for a young producer with one major album under his belt to be able to do in any case.) The tight
column11: three-song EP
column12: released on Jaar's own Clown and Sunset label
column13: is at once sexy and frigid
column14: cavernous and cramped. Much closer to idiomatic pop than Space
column15: with Harrington's falsetto clenching Jaar's own loose
column16: Matthew Dear-like croak
column17: the EP brings Jaar's highly personalized values to the quality of time
column18: rather than space: because what is funk
column19: if not the creative
column20: slantwise division of metrical time? As Harrington holds down long
column21: deep
column23: Jaar colors the atmosphere around them to give them different senses of brave momentum or back-winding reticence
column24: earthbound heft or atmospheric suspension. On ""A1""
column25: he sets glimmering whorls below the loping guitar and a cushion of static above
column26: holding them in check until the very end
column27: when they burst forth in a high-desert mirage that carries over into the Morricone-tipping ""A2"". It's icy-hot stuff. The importance of Harrington's ace fretwork can't be overstated
column28:
but the frosty austerity could only be a product of the curious mind of Jaar.

Cleaning up your act is tricky for any fuzz-minded garage band
column3: and Austin's the Strange Boys have been weathering that transition a bit roughly. Their demented 2009 debut
column4: The Strange Boys and Girls Club
column5: combined punk and country and even doo-wop into a bold and bird-flipping sound that proved fast wasn't the only way to convey agitated. On last year's Be Brave
column6: they tidied up their sound and refined their songwriting
column7: but lost so much of what made them strange in the first place. And now Live Music takes them further in that direction
column8: adding piano to their guitar-drums-bass-and-sometimes-harmonica lineup. The problem with this trajectory: Every album so far sounds like a transition
column9: pointing to big things but never quite producing them.

column1: The title of the Strange Boys' new album is surely intended to be ironic: Live Music attempts to separate the instruments and create some depth in the production
column2: but it may be the least live they've sounded. Gone is the lo-fi spontaneity and fuck-it-all atmosphere; instead
column3: we get a newfound professionalism that translates to midtempo plods and something like self-reflection. The album is restrained
column4: surprisingly low-key
column5: and-- at its lowest points-- polite. The songs ask for but never demand your attention
column6: then respond with a sociable thank you and good day.

column1: Even so
column2: the Strange Boys' garage remains enormous
column3: with plenty of room to stack boxes of honky-tonk
column4: rockabilly
column5: R&B
column6: and classic rock. That inclusive approach has always been their greatest asset and most distinguishing trait
column7: although for the most part Live Music compacts these competing urges into a very generalized Americana that never takes advantage of their Texas roots. They're not synthesizing disparate styles in the great tradition of Austin
column8: but skimming the surfaces of ideas they once explored more deeply. In this setting
column9: Ryan Sambol's voice
column10: which has been compared to Dylan and any number of Nuggets frontmen
column11: sounds more like Tom Petty
column12: but without the classic rocker's signature deadpan.

column1: When the tempos pick up
column2: so does the album. ""Omnia Boa"" adapts a train-song chug-a-lug for a subtly menacing groove
column3: and ""Punk's Pajamas"" is a jumble of guitars laced together with a gangly harmonica theme. ""You can study the past or dig the future
column4: Sambol sings on the latter
column5: ""but the present will never leave you."" It's a sharp insight that hints at the Strange Boys' goals: to incorporate rock history into a sound that isn't defined by nostalgia or innovation for the sake of innovation. They're trying to find a way to live in the moment
column6: which is certainly commendable. As Sambol unravels that theme across these 14 songs
column7: the album grows more endearing
column8:
if never quite exciting.

Between the books
column2: major magazine covers
column3: pop-up stores
column4: variety shows
column5: and more co-signs than you can hurl a skate deck at
column6: it's safe to say L.A. rap provocateurs Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All's basement days are long behind them. Or as OF member Mike G rhapsodizes on his new EP The Award Tour
column7: ""Went from Call of Duty missions to the center of attention."" It's been a whirlwind year for the collective in general
column8: but between anchoring tracks for Jay and Kanye to winning VMAs
column9: it's easy to forget that Odd Future are largely made up of background figures
column10: all with such varied rhyme and production styles that it can be hard to stand out from the pack. Mike G can probably relate-- his nocturnal flow and a preference for mood-driven beats has left him on the outside of most OF conversations. But still
column11: G managed to find an audience with 2009's Ali
column12: a mixtape that former Pitchfork staffer Tom Breihan called ""something of a lost classic within the Odd Future catalog.""

column1: The Award Tour is the midpoint between Ali and G's proper debut
column2: Gold
column3: rumored to be out sometime next year. And while it doesn't diverge too much from his previous solo effort
column4: it's clear that he's trying to make a name for himself outside of Odd Future: Save from keeping the production in-house (Syd the Kid
column5: Hodgy Beats
column6: and Left Brain contribute music) and the occasional reminiscence (see ""Chevron"") or shout out
column7: The Award Tour is one of the rare OF releases that feels purposefully removed from the collective. It's a smart move for someone who has struggled to distinguish himself outside of this growing pop-culture juggernaut
column8: and with his sandy-eyed demeanor
column9: it's a crucial counter-balance to the crew's super-aggro approach.

column1: The only problem is Mike G himself. Spin The Award Tour half a dozen times
column2: and it's clear why the guy's so often been relegated to the background. As the cousin of West Coast legend Warren G
column3: it's not hard to imagine Mike's ultra laid-back style being something of a genetic trait
column4: but even two years after Ali
column5: he still sounds like a rapper not only still trying to find his voice
column6: but struggling with the basic mechanics. Maybe it's okay to give Mike G a pass because of the inherent charm associated with his zonked-out delivery
column7: or because his raps oddly memorialize the halcyon days of early Odd Future
column8: but his flow remains so stilted that he often isn't even afforded the luxury of simply blending in.

column1: Either jamming too many words into a measure
column2: or too few
column3: he sounds in need of a metronome
column4: his flat and direct observations sounding like unstable free-association raps
column5: when they most clearly weren't intended to be. ""Chanel"" (which finds G in lothario mode) features some chintzed-out Euro-club signifiers which complement his drawl nicely
column6: but watch him peacock by spitting in double-time and getting completely stranded trying to find a way back to his normal operational mode. Most of the time
column7: he simply sounds lifeless and a little unfocused
column8: which is especially hard to take when the content of his rhymes remain so plain and thin. Meanwhile
column9: it leaves his production team to look more like enablers than anything else
column10: offering what sounds like compartmentalized
column11: simplistic
column12: hand-me-down beats that G constantly finds himself inexplicably swallowed by.

column1: But The Award Tour's biggest problem? Showcasing buddy Vince Staples for half the EP's 26 minutes. He appears on five of the seven tracks
column2: including the Mike G-less ""Michael Douglas"" with ""Gucci Gucci"" co-writer Speak!
column3: and where G comes off D.O.A.
column4: Staples is waiting to step in with personality and rhymes that practically crackle with life in comparison. Maybe he's a bit hung up on the played-out sort of violent juvenilia that first grabbed headlines for OF
column5: but there's something about his verses on ""Vicks"" and ""Award Tour"" (both detail school shootings
column6: suicide fantasies
column7: and Staples' conflicted feelings about religion) that are compellingly reminiscent of Anthony Perkins' chat with himself at the end of Psycho. The demon-exorcising feels authentic and dynamic
column8: and downright scene-stealing when propped up against our host.

column1: Maybe Mike G just isn't a show-and-prove kind of rapper
column2: and maybe he doesn't need to be. But you've got to offer your listeners something to sink their teeth into if you're going to follow
column3: ""More complex than architects with any amount of layers
column4: with
column5: ""Life's a videogame
column6: I'm controlled by the best player
column7: and expect to get away with it. Gold might find G in a more ambitious headspace artistically-- while it sure isn't an engaging listen
column8: there's nothing on The Award Tour that suggests he can't come into his own-- but this EP also seems doomed to be lost in the greater Odd Future catalog. Except this time
column9:
no one's going to mistake it for a classic.

For a while in the 1980s
column2: and to some degree into the following decade
column3: many listeners assumed the London-based 4AD record label was defined by arty goth rock. Bauhaus' slashing
column4: poised aggression may have helped kickstart the label
column5: and Modern English created a new wave hit for the ages with ""I Melt With You""
column6: but after a few years acts like the gauzy Cocteau Twins and the medieval-Europe-gone-global-instruments of Dead Can Dance ended up being the big sellers
column7: especially among those inclined toward pale and interesting looks matched with black clothing. Right next to these acts on 4AD
column8: meanwhile
column9: was something even more cryptic
column10: a band that never toured
column11: that never really was a band at all: This Mortal Coil.

column1: This Mortal Coil
column2: the subject of a new comprehensive box set
column3: was in the public eye an encapsulation of 4AD's sound and style spread out over three albums and associated singles and one-offs. And though founder Ivo Watts-Russell didn't want This Mortal Coil to be seen as a label vanity project
column4: there was nothing more classically ""4AD"" from a listener's point of view. Despite the presence of so many performers not signed to the label and the fact that nothing else on 4AD actually sounded like This Mortal Coil
column5: nothing else spoke more to the idea of what the label seemed to be.

column1: The band's identity came not from a specific individual person or group of people but from a sprawling series of studio efforts
column2: packaged in moody cover designs courtesy of photographer Nigel Grierson and designer Vaughn Oliver and always featuring model Pallas Citroen
column3: a kind of monolithic
column4: black-and-white take on Roxy Music's own remarkable run of covers over an earlier decade. Producer/engineer John Fryer
column5: Watts-Russell's key collaborator across the releases
column6: helped maintain a mood of poised
column7: shadowy romanticism
column8: part dark ambient grind and part late-night string-laden recital. This approach to production was combined with Watts-Russell's desire to celebrate obscure songs both old and more recent and transform them into something new and stunning. The project offered a mix of familiar and unknown voices and songs
column9: performers sometimes appearing only for a single song
column10: even simply an instrumental (such as Dead Can Dance associate Peter Ulrich
column11: taking a bow on Filigree & Shadow with the percussion piece ""At First
column12: and Then""
column13: never to reappear).

column1: The first album
column2: 1984's <i>It'll End in Tears
column3: can't escape being dominated by the group's most famous track-- ""Song to the Siren""
column4: a song by Tim Buckley recorded for his album Starsailor and recast by Cocteau Twins' Elizabeth Fraser and Robin Guthrie into a gripping vocal-and-guitar-only performance that has since completely overshadowed the original. First recorded as a B-side for TMC's debut single from 1983
column5: ""Song to the Siren""'s success prompted Watts-Russell to continue with a full-length. It's to his credit that his stated ambition to not simply have a 4AD house band actually came true. The voice of Tears is
column6: if anyone
column7: Cindytalk's Gordon Sharp
column8: ranging from operatic bravura on the opening cover of Big Star's ""Kanga Roo"" to the closing tenderness of ""A Single Wish"". But even that's too simplistic a summary on an album ranging
column9: seemingly haphazardly
column10: from the murky atmospherics of ""Fyt"" to the blunt
column11: mechanistic rockout making up their version of Wire member Colin Newman's ""Not Me"".

column1: Filigree & Shadow from 1986 comes across as a more unified effort in comparison
column2: released as a double album and with each of its four sides planned as a self-contained unit
column3: songs flowing one into the other. If nothing towers above the rest like ""Song to the Siren"" did
column4: the tradeoff lies in the record's feeling of dramatic concentration. Something like ""I Want to Live""
column5: a song taken from an obscure 1972 album on Elektra by Gary Ogan and Bill Lamb and given a remarkable reworking by sister singers Deirdre and Louise Rutkowski
column6: can coexist with ominous near-industrial level pieces like ""A Heart of Glass"" and ""The Horizon Bleeds and Sucks Its Thumb"". Yet it all works in the end
column7: from fragile strings on another Newman cover
column8: ""Alone""
column9: to the dark funk guitar on Talking Heads' ""Drugs""
column10: and no one song moment can fully convey the record's range.

column1: Blood
column2: another double-album release rom 1991
column3: feels in retrospect like the ending of multiple eras
column4: with 4AD about to open L.A. offices and a new decade about to embrace homegrown noise. But in some ways this felt like the most American record they'd done yet

column6: the Byrds
column7: and Emmylou Harris via Rodney Crowell (not to mention a return of sorts to Big Star via Chris Bell's ""I Am the Cosmos"" and ""You and Your Sister""

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17264/homepage_large.b466584a.jpg|Emika|30112.0|Emika|['Rock'
column3: blue-eyed Berlinite turning Aaliyah's ""Try Again"" into an industrial-dub robot dirge seems pretty suspect. But somehow
column4: 25-year old Bristol-bred Emika pulls off ""Common Exchange"" with flying Grisaille colors. Chalk its success up to the electronic composer/sound designer's belief that life and dance music alike are fatally boring when you stick to the blueprint.

column1: Emika's self-titled debut is one of those rip-it-up-and-start-again records. That's not to say that she isn't descended from a tradition of pitch-black and borderless artists
column2: but rather that her influences are varied enough to strand you on Spotify for several hours. There are the obvious trip-hop antecedents: Portishead
column3: the artists on Ninja Tune (Emika's label
column4: where she once interned); there's the THC residue of the dubstep pioneers with whom she's collaborated: Pinch
column5: Mala of Digital Mystikz. Then there are the Bauhaus grooves absorbed during innumerable nights at German techno tabernacle Berghain

column1: If the above paragraph sounds like gibberish
column2: let me re-translate: To the European underground
column3: Emika is a golden child in somber pose. Even the eternally sober Thom Yorke recently endorsed Emika on the BBC and said
column4: ""I hope she gets really famous."" She's not there yet
column5: but it's not inconceivable. After all
column6: few artists emerge as fully formed and self-sufficient. She writes
column7: she produces
column8: sings
column9: plays piano
column10: digital sequencers
column11: and synthesizers. Her old day job was fittingly in sound design for the music software firm Native Instruments. The professional inclination is revealed amidst the poison fog of Emika
column12: a record that's both experimental and precise
column13: well caffeinated and focused
column14: yet always deliberate in its approach.

column1: Over the last few years
column2: dubstep has slowly seeped into the bloodstream of mainstream pop. Everyone from Britney to Rihanna to Korn and (maybe) Kanye have incorporated flourishes or wholesale ideas. In England
column3: Katy B is a star
column4: and Skream
column5: Benga
column6: and Joker have made moves toward the masses with varying success. But the pop realm and the dingy warehouse grime of early dubstep have largely been mutually incompatible. At best
column7: they swap melody for rawness. At worst
column8: they boast the street grit of a Flo Rida and David Guetta MDMA orgy.

column1: Setting the xx aside
column2: Emika comes as close as anyone to bridging the minimalist menace of the 2005-08 run on the Punch Drunk and Tectonic labels to breathy accessible vocals and classical piano. There's enough violence and double-crossing here to fill up a Rihanna record. Single ""Double Edge"" finds Emika moaning damaged syllables of emotional betrayal. ""Professional Loving"" finds her mulling the hollow
column3: workaday love she experienced at her old office in Berlin. ""The Long Goodbye"" finds Emika emulating Beth Gibbons
column4: wraith-like and ethereal
column5: eulogizing friendships that never were.

column1: But at its core
column2: this is about the beats
column3: as silvery and scalloped as a Frank Gehry facade. It's a slippery record
column4: careful to never show Emika's face too clearly. She picks her spots smartly
column5: aware that the mechanized doom rattles
column6: cavernous silences
column7: and multi-mirrored infinity of the production is powerful enough. This is the product of a dynamic and assured vision
column8: one that retains an alluring sense of mystery. No matter how far Emika dances into the light
column9:
she never quite eludes the shadows.

At the 2000 VMAs

column3: bleached hair and all. The performance was an arresting

column7: 000 copes in its first week in stores

column1: It's a presumptive conclusion

column6: but it also involved rocking YoungbloodZ and Ying Yang Twins songs at parties. The pop world has left rap behind

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17259/homepage_large.22a85192.jpg|Bambara Mystic Soul: The Raw Sound of Burkina Faso 1974-1979|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Analog Africa']|2011-12-08 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:12.150444|"

If you're glancing through the CIA World Fact Book
column2: Burkina Faso might not seem to be the most likely source of majestic
column3: electrifying dance band music. It's one of the world's least developed countries
column4: a place people leave so they can support their families back home with the living they make abroad. Its president has his own private plane
column5: but less than 30% of its people can read and write
column6: though a two-decade-long campaign has improved the literacy rate from about 13% 20 years ago. But if there's anything searching for music from around the world will teach you
column7: it's that people find a way.

column1: Back in the 1970s
column2: Burkina Faso was still called Upper Volta. The name was a leftover from the country's colonial era
column3: when the French ruled it as part of their West African empire. The decade was a time of relative political stability-- the country was ruled by a series of military and civil-military governments
column4: but they were all led by the same man: Lt. Col. Sangoulé Lamizana. In the cities of Ouagadougou and Bobo-Dioulasso
column5: a cosmopolitan nightlife had been brewing since the early post-war years
column6: and largely through patronage and foreign connections
column7: a few bands had scraped together the necessary equipment to play a modern repertoire of calypsos
column8: rumbas
column9: highlife tunes
column10: waltzes
column11: and foxtrots. The country's fledgling music industry crystallized in 1974 around two Ouaga-based labels: Volta Discobel and CVD (Club Voltaïque du Disque).

column1: It's this second label that features most prominently on Bambara Mystic Soul
column2: Analog Africa's first foray into cataloging the little-known music of this landlocked country. Analog Africa founder Samy Ben Redjeb began this project back in 2006 after coming across a few Burkinabé records in Niamey
column3: Niger. He visited Ouagadougou and quickly got in contact with Moussa Ouedraogo
column4: the manager of CVD and brother of the company's founder
column5: Adama Ouedraogo. In addition to extensive interviews conducted with some of the musicians featured on the compilation
column6: the liner notes feature Redjeb's account of his crash-course in musique Voltaïque
column7: as well as a humorously harrowing account of an argument between the Ouedraogo brothers and Amadou Ballaké over how to split royalties from a prospective Analog Africa release.

column1: Ballaké is the star of the show here-- six of the disc's 16 tracks feature his booming
column2: nimble vocals-- so the fact that he and the brothers hammered out a deal was essential to getting the compilation together. Ballaké
column3: born Amadou Traoré (his stage name comes from a hit song he wrote called ""Ballaké"")
column4: had played in big groups in Mali and Guinea before returning to Ouagadougou
column5: where he became the music scene's most prominent fixture. In his hometown
column6: the recording conditions were a lot rougher than the ones he'd experienced outside the country-- many recordings were made at the national theater and other venues with a two-track Nagra recorder borrowed from the national radio station-- but the rawness and immediacy suits him well. Whether he's being backed by filthy ""Sex Machine"" guitars on ""Oye Ka Bara Kignan"" or singing sweetly over a hypnotic
column7: air-filled Mandé jazz arrangement
column8: his facility with rhythm is astonishing.

column1: Ballaké’s international profile makes him an outlier on this compilation-- most of the other artists here have rarely been heard outside their homeland. There's not a single track that disappoints
column2: though. Recording time was a very scarce resource in 1970s Burkina Faso
column3: so bands came with their very best when they got the opportunity
column4: and they were well-honed units from night after night of relentless gigging. Mamo Lagbema's ""Zambo-Zambo"" is a tightly performed
column5: intensely funky workout with a slippery rhythm
column6: deft horn arrangement and compex
column7: interlocking guitar and bass parts
column8: and the recording has amazing depth. It's hard to believe it was recorded live to two tracks. Clearly
column9: experience with this rudimentary recording set-up paid off.

column1: This is the sort of release where a review could very easily devolve into a simple accounting of the awesome things each track does-- the way the unique piano part on Tidiani Coulibaly's ""Sie Koumgolo"" bridges a gap between Cuban music and hard funk
column2: for instance-- but that would make for some long reading. Instead
column3: let me say that if you have any interest in West African funk forms at all
column4: this is essential listening. It's also essential reading. The interviews and travelogue are excellent
column5: but just as valuable is the history of modern Burkinabé music contributed by Craig Taylor
column6: owner of the excellent but under-distributed Savannahphone label
column7: the only other Western label to release a compilation of Burkinabé dance bands.

column1: A compilation like this may not really shed a whole lot of light on the country the music comes from as a whole-- these musicians were urbanites
column2: guys who used their talent to forge atypical
column3: middle-class identities. The records they cut couldn't be played in a lot of the villages dotted through the countryside. But the music they made was real. It forged a cultural connection to the wider world from a somewhat isolated society
column4: a country off the most frequently beaten paths. The party came to a crashing end in the 1980s
column5: when a series of coups and short-lived governments put a squeeze on the nightlife in the cities. These recordings from the 1970s survived
column6: though
column7:
and now we have them to hear again.

James Holden's Border Community is a label known for its between-genre dislocation
column2: an imprint that takes dance-music influences
column3: warms them over on the stove
column4: and then buries them in fuzzy pink noise. Home to artists like Nathan Fake
column5: Luke Abbott
column6: and
column7: of course Holden himself
column8: it has a habit of drenching techno in longing nostalgia and stasis
column9: music caught in some dimensional rift between dance and pop. It seems a likely home for Swiss artist Kate Wax then
column10: who made her name six years ago on bizarre spoken-word electronica on Mental Groove
column11: but whose sound has slowly gelled into something more palatable
column12: and certainly more traditionally pop. On her first album for Border Community and second overall
column13: Aisha Devi Enz buries herself in a dark
column14: claustrophobic world blanketed with careful textures both prickly and enticing
column15: and tries to tunnel her way back using mostly her elastic but childlike voice.

column1: With Dust Collision
column2: Enz refigures herself as an alien vixen à la Karin Dreijier
column3: her intensely smoky sensuality problematized by intense vocal processing and pitch manipulation. Vocals are Collision's key feature
column4: its only constant and the element that haunts its darkest corners. ""I Knit You""-- all chugging but suppressed arpeggios and layer after layer of tweaked vocal gasping-- makes an attractive
column5: suitably weird opener
column6: with lyrics about ""heathen scars"" and carving names into kitchen walls. The menacing verses are underlaid by a catchy falsetto chorus. Even when her vocals are the primary focus
column7: they're still occluded
column8: weaving in and out of each other and interrogating several different moods and states at once. By keeping her untouched cadence in tow (""Human Twin"")
column9: the manipulation only serves to emphasize her quavering vulnerability. It's gasping innocence versus jaded hostility
column10: and this sort of dynamic push-and-pull
column11: defines Dust Collision
column12: an album that feels permanently at odds with itself and never quite comfortable in its own skin.

column1: Part of that contrast manifests itself in an ongoing duel between the organic and the artificial
column2: an unstable gradient that constantly tugs the album in opposite directions. Moving past the rubbery ""Dancing on Your Scalp""
column3: Collision enters a phase of unnervingly stark sparsity. ""Human Twin"" and ""Archetype"" are driven mostly by piano
column4: relatively simple singer-songwriter material quietly vandalized by synths
column5: metronomic drums
column6: or fits of distortion. It all leads toward the fantastic ""Maze Rider (Live From the Cave)""
column7: an embellished live recording complete with sumptuous reverb
column8: microphone feedback
column9: and Enz's most riveting vocal melody. It feels uncharacteristically natural-- bar the ever-present vocal processing-- and it stands boldly naked at the center of the album
column10: all strong
column11: pure melody with little else to back it up. It's almost enough to make us question whether the heavy-handed effects are necessary in the first place.

column1: But when the electronics do return
column2: they're on the fritz-- ""Echoes and the Light"" sounds like it's shorting out with each brutal chord stab-- until the record strips itself down again and crawls back into its pseudo-acoustic cubbyhole
column3: more fragile than ever. (Enz's personality begins to splinter across anxious soliloquies as she cries lyrics like ""mad thinker get out of my head."")  The closer ""Les Djinns"" is where the album's ever-edging tension finally gives way
column4: and the uplifting but gentle melody explodes into bursts of harsh static and guitar moans before just fizzling out. It's just the kind of incongruous and torturously quick ending you'd expect from an album that feels like an hour of emotional infighting. (It's the burn-out of that album
column5: one that exhausts itself trying to express emotions with such an odd and unintuitive palette.)

column1: Just as it exhausts itself
column2: Dust Collision can have a similar effect on its listeners. Breathing indulgently in and out without regard for how much space it takes up
column3: Collision takes its sweet time to get its fraught message across
column4: ever a rarity in an age of instant gratification. While her sound isn't quite fully developed yet-- the second half owes a lot to the Knife's Silent Shout-- she's impressively ambitious
column5: toeing the line between two stratified worlds and refusing to give into the confines of either. She can pull off accessibly bare songwriting as well as textural tone-poems
column6: finding formidable power in her singing both when it's untouched and heavily damaged. Damage courses throughout Dust Collision
column7: and it's not the easiest listen
column8: but like most difficult albums
column9: it's eventually rewarding
column10: and her vortex of haywire synths
column11: quaking guitar
column12:
and unsettling helium squawks is powerfully magnetic.

""Yea yea twist again better than we did last summer
column4: laughing in the face of all rock and roll historians collectors revivalists purists inquisition members puritans bores creeps and not forgetting the fussy midgets with obscene hairdos."" So wrote Claude Bessy in the liner notes to Throbbing Gristle's Greatest Hits
column5: one of the five classic Throbbing Gristle albums Industrial Records have just reissued
column6: and which now sit upon my desk
column7: uncanny and accusatory
column8: over 30 years after that pre-emptive fit of snark. Throbbing Gristle were never meant to be reliable
column9: but here they come again
column10: ready to be harvested by the very culture industry they alternately solicited and spat upon so long ago.

column1: Permit me to adjust my obscene hairdo and offer those of you not already in the know some history: In their first incarnation as the Death Factory
column2: they were the house band for Coum Transmissions
column3: an abject performance-art troupe whose presentation of used tampons
column4: anal syringes
column5: and pornography featuring band member Cosey Fanny Tutti in the ICA gallery for their ""Prostitution"" show in 1976 earned them tabloid infamy and denunciations in Parliament as ""wreckers of civilization."" So far
column6: so punk. But the music of the Death Factory
column7: soon re-named Throbbing Gristle after a Yorkshire slang term for an erection
column8: was a horse of a different color: ""industrial music for industrial people
column9: a dystopian
column10: negative form of what the band itself called ""post-psychedelic trash.""

column1: While the rest of the Class of '77 pogoed steadily
column2: Throbbing Gristle blew hot and cold
column3: a passive-aggressive tug of war between the sharp and the slimy: The formal elegance of Chris Carter's synthesizers are scrawled upon by Genesis P-Orridge's bass riffs and Cosey Fanni Tutti's fuzz guitar freakouts
column4: spiced with violin and dubby honks of cornet. This already pungent stew is spiked with taped material selected by Peter ""Sleazy"" Christopherson-- excerpts of everyday intimacy and true crime verité-- and the arsenic tang of Genesis' vocals
column5: either sung in a soft sort of sprechstimme or howled into effects. On their debut
column6: The Second Annual Report
column7: the music alternately chugged along like a squelchy
column8: crude cop of the Velvet Underground
column9: or stretched out into malingering new age
column10: like a syphilitic Tangerine Dream. But they got both more virulent and more ambitious with time
column11: upping the hostility and dread on D.O.A
column12: taking a kitsch detour toward mutant disco on 20 Jazz Funk Greats
column13: auto-cannibalizing their catalog in the live-in-the-studio ritual recording of Heathen Earth
column14: and reasserting a strangely forceful collection of avant garde anti-pop for a Greatest Hits package revealingly subtitled Entertainment Through Pain
column15: which collates their singles output as a quiver of tense stabs at accessibility.

column1: In time for Christmas
column2: a revived Industrial Records has just re-released all five of these classic albums
column3: lovingly repackaged in deluxe gatefolded 2xCD editions. In each case
column4: the original album is (wisely) preserved intact on one CD
column5: while a second CD collects period singles
column6: live performances
column7: and a smattering of alternate mixes and unreleased material. Artwork is supplemented with alternate takes from photo-sessions
column8: and it's a jarring experience for collector scum like myself to see and hear these goofy blooper reels and deleted scenes
column9: in which the avatars of colder-than-thou aesthetics stand on one foot or giggle. Savvily recognizing the waning moment of the CD as such
column10: there are vinyl editions of the albums too
column11: which faithfully reprint the original artwork at full size and format. While so far I've only checked out the vinyl for 20 Jazz
column12: it looks drool-worthy and sounds far stronger than any other pressing that this fussy midget has encountered.

column1: Given that these albums have stayed continuously in print for years through arrangements with Fetish Records
column2: and later Mute
column3: one must ask: Why bother paying attention to these reissues? In a triumphant vindication of sound over image
column4: the real motivation for this re-presentation of a back catalog is that all five of these five albums have been remastered by Chris Carter himself
column5: a labor of obsessive-compulsive love whose consequences I intend to unpack
column6: album-by-album
column7: below. On the face of it
column8: the idea of an ""audiophile TG"" makes for a jarring proposition: The band always seemed weirdly proud of the dismal fidelity of its early recordings
column9: and its stated objective was to be repellent and un-assimilable. As an early Coum Transmisions slogan put it
column10: ""We Guarantee Disappointment."" However off-message
column11: the immersive experience of these new versions redeems what might sound gratuitous
column12: or merely greedy
column13: about this gambit. It's the audio equivalent of a ""director's cut"" edition of a beloved series of seedy cult movies
column14: something to file between your Kenneth Anger boxset and a Hermann Nitsch coffee-table tome.

column1: Assessed as an archival work of restoration
column2: it's a bullseye. I've been listening to these records for 25 years
column3: and for me
column4: this feels like the cleaning of the Sistine Chapel
column5: if the Sistine Chapel were painted by Hieronymous Bosch instead of Michelangelo. Simply put
column6: the heat and noise and grit and dirt and gristle is still there
column7: but Chris Carter has finally put meat on the bones. There's simply more vitality and physicality to the music
column8: and yet it still sounds ""very TG"": The harsh
column9: brittle
column10: and scalpel-sharp high end is preserved
column11: but the kick drums are heavier
column12: the riffs hit harder
column13: and the field recordings now produce a tactile IMAX-theater immersion effect. But going beyond these side effects of possibly overheated fanboy devotion
column14: the re-introduction of Throbbing Gristle into the cultural bloodstream also offers up a temperature-taking opportunity to assess both the entire arc of their career and the harder question of whom it might speak to today.

column1: SECOND ANNUAL REPORT
Recorded in their rehearsal space and at various grubby gigs onto a Sony cassette recorder in a defiantly lo-fi manner in 1977
column2: Second Annual Report makes an oddly recalcitrant candidate for a remastering job. Music this deliberately weedy was never going to please audiophiles
column3: and the wags at Industrial Records know that even today this record is a tough sell. For sheer sangfroid
column4: it's hard to beat a press sheet that boasts
column5: ""Contains three different versions of 'Slug Bait'
column6: a song about eating a baby."" Talking about killing people isn't necessarily interesting (hello
column7: Foster the People)
column8: but when I hear Genesis P-Orridge describe a businesslike psychopath butchering a family (""I cut his balls off with my knife (KNIFE); I make him eat them right there in front of his pregnant wife (WIFE)"")
column9: I still blink and twitch a little. The creeping dread ""Slug Bait"" achieves lies not in the lyrical body count but in the hiccupping repetition of trigger words as Gen's vocal longjumps from a casual speaking voice to a garbled shriek
column10: and in the deliberate misfit between the vocal's desperation and the detuned pastoral synths smeared underneath.

column1: It's hard to say whether this was a raising or a lowering of the bar
column2: but the bunker mentality of ""Industrial"" subculture as a power-obsessed stance of aesthetic nihilism wedded to nasty
column3: lo-fi noise was born on this record
column4: leaving a bloody trail for Wolf Eyes
column5: Brainbombs
column6: Prurient
column7: and others to follow into the present moment. As if that were not prescient enough
column8: Second Annual Report counterbalances the bloodthirsty yang of its first eight songs with the yin of its long
column9: brooding final track
column10: the gauzy
column11: scuttling
column12: 20-minute soundtrack to the Coum Transmissions film ""After Cease to Exist"". Which is to say that
column14: TG already forecasted the ongoing migration of noise dudes toward new age (take a bow
column15: James Ferraro)
column16: a sea-change which has been recursively washing over the underground for the past several years.

column1: D.O.A.: THE THIRD AND FINAL REPORT OF THROBBING GRISTLE
Widely regarded as the band's finest hour
column2: 1978's D.O.A. effortlessly surpasses Second Annual Report both in its ballsy
column3: forceful execution and its passionate range. If TG are Fleetwood Mac
column4: then D.O.A is their Rumors: the sound of a band alchemically transforming romantic upheaval into their sharpest statement. In a proggy gambit worthy of Emerson
column5: Lake
column6: and Palmer
column7: D.O.A. explodes the idea of a unified album into a suite of collective songs punctured by four solo pieces from each band member. Sleazy's ""Valley of the Shadow of Death"" is a fetishistic fly-on-the-wall compilation of working-class men and boys talking shit
column8: a sonic file folder of vanished moments that are naggingly unclear (Chit chat? Hustling?). Gen's melancholic pleading on his solo effort ""Weeping"" couldn't be further from the tranquility of Cosey's idyllic ""Hometime""
column9: and this polar juxtaposition flags the album's messy personal backstory (the album was recorded after Gen and Cosey's ongoing romance imploded
column10: and Chris and Cosey's lifelong partnership began). But the standout solo track is surely Chris Carter's celestial arpeggio staircase ""AB/7A""
column11: a clear influence upon the now-much-imitated Emeralds aesthetic of heart-tugging synth mandalas.

column1: Counterbalancing these solitary excursions
column2: the group efforts on this album are exhilaratingly bleak: From the chemtrails of distortion on ""Hit By a Rock"" to the amplified sound of early computer code stored on cassette on ""I.B.M."" to the final raveup of ""Blood on the Floor""
column3: it's never less than car-crash fascinating. At the center of the record is ""Hamburger Lady""
column4: a nightmarish vision of a burn victim's excruciatingly prolonged survival in the administered world of a high-tech hospital. It's probably Throbbing Gristle's greatest song
column5: and it sounds tougher and more menacing than ever. The re-mastering has put a bass-jeep-worthy oomph into the low end of the kick drum
column6: thickened the seasick
column7: doomy bass dirge that
column8: yes
column9: throbs at its heart
column10: and sharpened the edge of the scything central riff
column11: a party horn run through a custom-built effects unit called the Gristleizer. Witch-house wishes it were this creepy
column12: but even upside-down crosses won't save you from the horror of everyday life. A nauseating masterpiece
column13: and an essential recording.

column1: 20 JAZZ FUNK GREATS
You could write an entire book about the sly wit and polymorphous slipperiness of 20 Jazz Funk Greats

column1: GREATEST HITS

column3: poisonous oeuvre than any particular album. The swells of ""Hamburger Lady"" start us off feeling nausea
column4: and this bumpy ride builds in force from there. You can sense in this victory lap a kind of précis of their career arc that testifies to the strange tractor-beam effect of pop values on an experimental band. The single element from Second Annual Report is ""Tiab Guls""

column1: Having the last laugh while seemingly anticipating this bittersweet outcome
column2: Throbbing Gristle still don't add up: These albums are perversely inconclusive

column4: the work itself remains as profoundly self-differential as ever. To cite a phrase the band used for its LP of the cut-ups of their icon and friend William S. Burroughs

column6: Paul Morley prophesized that ""one day TG's music will sound rich and sweet."" Thanks to Chris Carter's remastering and the necromancy of Industrial Records
column7:
that day has arrived.

column1: Permit me to adjust my obscene hairdo and offer those of you not already in the know some history: In their first incarnation as the Death Factory

column1: While the rest of the Class of '77 pogoed steadily

column1: In time for Christmas
column2: a revived Industrial Records has just re-released all five of these classic albums
column3: lovingly repackaged in deluxe gatefolded 2xCD editions. In each case
column4: the original album is (wisely) preserved intact on one CD

column6: live performances
column7: and a smattering of alternate mixes and unreleased material. Artwork is supplemented with alternate takes from photo-sessions
column8: and it's a jarring experience for collector scum like myself to see and hear these goofy blooper reels and deleted scenes

column11: which faithfully reprint the original artwork at full size and format. While so far I've only checked out the vinyl for 20 Jazz
column12: it looks drool-worthy and sounds far stronger than any other pressing that this fussy midget has encountered.

column1: Assessed as an archival work of restoration

column4: this feels like the cleaning of the Sistine Chapel

column1: SECOND ANNUAL REPORT
Recorded in their rehearsal space and at various grubby gigs onto a Sony cassette recorder in a defiantly lo-fi manner in 1977
column2: Second Annual Report makes an oddly recalcitrant candidate for a remastering job. Music this deliberately weedy was never going to please audiophiles
column3: and the wags at Industrial Records know that even today this record is a tough sell. For sheer sangfroid
column4: it's hard to beat a press sheet that boasts
column5: ""Contains three different versions of 'Slug Bait'
column6: a song about eating a baby."" Talking about killing people isn't necessarily interesting (hello
column7: Foster the People)
column8: but when I hear Genesis P-Orridge describe a businesslike psychopath butchering a family (""I cut his balls off with my knife (KNIFE); I make him eat them right there in front of his pregnant wife (WIFE)"")
column9: I still blink and twitch a little. The creeping dread ""Slug Bait"" achieves lies not in the lyrical body count but in the hiccupping repetition of trigger words as Gen's vocal longjumps from a casual speaking voice to a garbled shriek
column10: and in the deliberate misfit between the vocal's desperation and the detuned pastoral synths smeared underneath.

column1: D.O.A.: THE THIRD AND FINAL REPORT OF THROBBING GRISTLE
Widely regarded as the band's finest hour
column2: 1978's D.O.A. effortlessly surpasses Second Annual Report both in its ballsy
column3: forceful execution and its passionate range. If TG are Fleetwood Mac
column4: then D.O.A is their Rumors: the sound of a band alchemically transforming romantic upheaval into their sharpest statement. In a proggy gambit worthy of Emerson
column5: Lake
column6: and Palmer
column7: D.O.A. explodes the idea of a unified album into a suite of collective songs punctured by four solo pieces from each band member. Sleazy's ""Valley of the Shadow of Death"" is a fetishistic fly-on-the-wall compilation of working-class men and boys talking shit
column8: a sonic file folder of vanished moments that are naggingly unclear (Chit chat? Hustling?). Gen's melancholic pleading on his solo effort ""Weeping"" couldn't be further from the tranquility of Cosey's idyllic ""Hometime""
column9: and this polar juxtaposition flags the album's messy personal backstory (the album was recorded after Gen and Cosey's ongoing romance imploded
column10: and Chris and Cosey's lifelong partnership began). But the standout solo track is surely Chris Carter's celestial arpeggio staircase ""AB/7A""
column11: a clear influence upon the now-much-imitated Emeralds aesthetic of heart-tugging synth mandalas.

column1: Counterbalancing these solitary excursions
column2: the group efforts on this album are exhilaratingly bleak: From the chemtrails of distortion on ""Hit By a Rock"" to the amplified sound of early computer code stored on cassette on ""I.B.M."" to the final raveup of ""Blood on the Floor""
column3: it's never less than car-crash fascinating. At the center of the record is ""Hamburger Lady""
column4: a nightmarish vision of a burn victim's excruciatingly prolonged survival in the administered world of a high-tech hospital. It's probably Throbbing Gristle's greatest song
column5: and it sounds tougher and more menacing than ever. The re-mastering has put a bass-jeep-worthy oomph into the low end of the kick drum
column6: thickened the seasick
column7: doomy bass dirge that
column8: yes
column9: throbs at its heart
column10: and sharpened the edge of the scything central riff

column12: but even upside-down crosses won't save you from the horror of everyday life. A nauseating masterpiece
column13: and an essential recording.

column1: 20 JAZZ FUNK GREATS
You could write an entire book about the sly wit and polymorphous slipperiness of 20 Jazz Funk Greats
column2: whose kitsch seaside holiday photo on notorious suicide spot Beachy Head tips off the viewer to the deliberately fishy insincerity of its sonic contents. In a smash and grab that testifies to both increased musical ambition and a relentless urge to wrongfoot audience expectations
column3: 20 Jazz Funk Greats finds the band waking up from D.O.A's dark night of the soul and feeling curiously frisky. Snacking on not only the titular funk and jazz
column4: the band also takes touristic zig zags through exotica
column5: rock
column6: and disco. Like the alien mimic in John Carpenter's sci-fi horror film ""The Thing""
column7: each song seems almost persuasive as a stab at these genres
column8: but crucially twists itself out of alignment in a perverse reveal.

column1: ""Hot on the Heels of Love"" is a delirious slice of Moroder-esque boudoir-disco complete with breathy vocals from Cosey and
column2: thanks to the remastering

column4: with people who have no business taking over the dancefloor doing it anyway

column9: two-note bass figure
column10: Gen croons a narrative of pornographic photography sessions

column15: you can't hit undo.

column1: But as much as TG tried to deliberately ""guarantee disappointment"" and mutate away from any signature

column3: and the cumulative pressure of their own survival now forces the band members to work harder to surprise themselves. It's in the pathos of their promiscuous liasons with the forbidden territory of various forms of ""real music"" that this album generates a weirdly gripping power of its own. I am biased and perhaps lonely here
column4: but this fussy midget regards it as their peak.

column1: HEATHEN EARTH

column1: GREATEST HITS

column10: more dyspeptic cousin to Depeche Mode and John Foxx.

column1: It's an unintended irony that a band so hostile to the very idea of ""music"" as such should have created recordings that have become enshrined into canonical constellations

column1: In the wake of Sleazy's startling death in 2010
column2: a kind of melancholic asymmetry has settled into place: the archive as mausoleum. The band can no longer re-unite and tour

column4: filed-shared free-for-all of torrents over the material culture of collectables
column5: it's a perhaps deliberately out-of-step gesture to decide at precisely this point to remaster
column6: repackage
column7: and represent these Mosaic tablets of noise into upscale commodities memorializing a vanished moment of rebellion. So much for laughing in the face of historians

column9: and revivalists.

column1: Having the last laugh while seemingly anticipating this bittersweet outcome
column2: Throbbing Gristle still don't add up: These albums are perversely inconclusive
column3: by turns drably ugly and beautifully vital. However much Chris Carter has clarified their sound and stabilized their canon
column4: the work itself remains as profoundly self-differential as ever. To cite a phrase the band used for its LP of the cut-ups of their icon and friend William S. Burroughs
column5: there is ""Nothing here now but the recordings."" But those recordings have a funny way of coming to life. In 1981 in the NME
column6: Paul Morley prophesized that ""one day TG's music will sound rich and sweet."" Thanks to Chris Carter's remastering and the necromancy of Industrial Records
column7:
that day has arrived.

column1: 20 JAZZ FUNK GREATS

column5: rock

column7: each song seems almost persuasive as a stab at these genres

column2: thanks to the remastering

column1: But as much as TG tried to deliberately ""guarantee disappointment"" and mutate away from any signature

I am biased and perhaps lonely here

column1: HEATHEN EARTH

column1: GREATEST HITS
Though they are taking the piss in passing themselves off as band who had ""hits

column3: poisonous oeuvre than any particular album. The swells of ""Hamburger Lady"" start us off feeling nausea
column4: and this bumpy ride builds in force from there. You can sense in this victory lap a kind of précis of their career arc that testifies to the strange tractor-beam effect of pop values on an experimental band. The single element from Second Annual Report is ""Tiab Guls""
column5: a backward version of ""Slug Bait"" that effectively censors the bloody lyrics by upstaging them into a blur. The perkiest and most uptempo high points of D.O.A. and 20 Jazz dominate

column1: In the wake of Sleazy's startling death in 2010

In the wake of the decline of the CD and the seemingly inevitable slide downward in fidelity as the new brigade of information hunter-gatherers settle for the lossy
column4: filed-shared free-for-all of torrents over the material culture of collectables

column6: repackage

column1: Having the last laugh while seemingly anticipating this bittersweet outcome
column2: Throbbing Gristle still don't add up: These albums are perversely inconclusive
column3: by turns drably ugly and beautifully vital. However much Chris Carter has clarified their sound and stabilized their canon
column4: the work itself remains as profoundly self-differential as ever. To cite a phrase the band used for its LP of the cut-ups of their icon and friend William S. Burroughs
column5: there is ""Nothing here now but the recordings."" But those recordings have a funny way of coming to life. In 1981 in the NME
column6: Paul Morley prophesized that ""one day TG's music will sound rich and sweet."" Thanks to Chris Carter's remastering and the necromancy of Industrial Records
column7:
that day has arrived.

column1: Permit me to adjust my obscene hairdo and offer those of you not already in the know some history: In their first incarnation as the Death Factory
column2: they were the house band for Coum Transmissions
column3: an abject performance-art troupe whose presentation of used tampons
column4: anal syringes
column5: and pornography featuring band member Cosey Fanny Tutti in the ICA gallery for their ""Prostitution"" show in 1976 earned them tabloid infamy and denunciations in Parliament as ""wreckers of civilization."" So far
column6: so punk. But the music of the Death Factory
column7: soon re-named Throbbing Gristle after a Yorkshire slang term for an erection
column8: was a horse of a different color: ""industrial music for industrial people
column9: a dystopian
column10: negative form of what the band itself called ""post-psychedelic trash.""

column1: While the rest of the Class of '77 pogoed steadily
column2: Throbbing Gristle blew hot and cold
column3: a passive-aggressive tug of war between the sharp and the slimy: The formal elegance of Chris Carter's synthesizers are scrawled upon by Genesis P-Orridge's bass riffs and Cosey Fanni Tutti's fuzz guitar freakouts
column4: spiced with violin and dubby honks of cornet. This already pungent stew is spiked with taped material selected by Peter ""Sleazy"" Christopherson-- excerpts of everyday intimacy and true crime verité-- and the arsenic tang of Genesis' vocals
column5: either sung in a soft sort of sprechstimme or howled into effects. On their debut
column6: The Second Annual Report
column7: the music alternately chugged along like a squelchy
column8: crude cop of the Velvet Underground

column10: like a syphilitic Tangerine Dream. But they got both more virulent and more ambitious with time
column11: upping the hostility and dread on D.O.A
column12: taking a kitsch detour toward mutant disco on 20 Jazz Funk Greats

column14: and reasserting a strangely forceful collection of avant garde anti-pop for a Greatest Hits package revealingly subtitled Entertainment Through Pain
column15: which collates their singles output as a quiver of tense stabs at accessibility.

column1: In time for Christmas
