'Because']|2011-12-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:15.623853|"

Charlotte Gainsbourg has been in the public eye for most of her life. She's been acting since she was 13
column3: and the first glimmers of her parallel musical career date to the same year
column4: when she dueted with her father
column5: Serge Gainsbourg
column6: on a song called ""Lemon Incest"". He produced her first album two years later
column8: but she left music alone for more than a decade after that
column9: and didn't pick up her solo career again until 2006. I don't know the reasons for the long pause
column10: but I do think that waiting so long to restart her singing career allowed her to create distance between her own identity as a performer and an identity guided by her father. In Air
column11: Jarvis Cocker
column12: and more recently
column13: Beck
column14: she found collaborators who could pitch material perfectly for her-- she doesn't project a huge personality on her records
column15: but she sounds at home in the paleofuturistic musical worlds of her albums
column16: calmly detailing airplane crashes
column17: medical procedures
column18: and a long catalog of ruminations on mortality.

column1: Gainsbourg had her third child earlier this year
column2: which makes the time ripe for a gap-filling release of some sort
column3: and Stage Whisper fills that bill
column4: splitting itself between live recordings of songs from her two most recent LPs
column5: IRM and 5:55
column6: and unreleased studio tracks. Both sections of the record pick up the thread Gainsbourg began unraveling with Beck on IRM. The songs from that album are put forth in all their buzzy glory
column7: with the emphasis on the most kinetic tracks: ""IRM""
column8: ""Trick Pony""
column9: and ""Voyage"" are all among the highlights.

column1: The relatively smooth edges of the 5:55 material are hammered a little rougher by her touring band. The Cocker-penned ""Set Yourself on Fire"" sounds great with a generous helping of fuzz guitar muddying the hook. Gainsbourg's ability to blend into her audio environments is usually an asset on her albums
column2: but on the live recordings it means she doesn't really command the spotlight-- the performance is fine
column3: but there aren't any revelations in her on-stage readings of the material. As if to emphasize the point
column4: the worst thing here is easily the sleepy cover of Dylan's ""Just Like a Woman""
column5: which seems to rest entirely on the premise of a gender switch by the singer
column6: a switch that's not compelling on its own. The new energy heard in some of these songs comes from the revamped arrangements
column7: and listening to the live songs is essentially the same as listening to studio recordings-- the presence of an audience doesn't seem to change her performance dynamic.

column1: The new studio material mostly builds directly on IRM. ""Terrible Angels""
column2: produced by Beck
column3: is a buzzing
column4: fizzy concoction not far outside the realm of what Broadcast were doing prior to the death of Trish Keenan
column5: though it's not as unstable. It has that same effect of sounding like the past and the future at once
column6: though. Gainsbourg has the perfect cold
column7: even vocal tone for electro-pop
column8: and a few of these songs go there. ""All the Rain"" is a nice cousin to ""Trick Pony""
column9: and ""Paradisco"" makes good use of her soft voice against a hard beat. On the whole
column10: Stage Whisper is enjoyable
column11: but the live portion is dispensible
column12: and the new studio tracks
column13: which will likely please anyone taken with IRM
column14:
are the real draw.

You'd be forgiven for thinking Planet Mu is all about twitchy
column3: high-tempo music these days
column4: given prominent albums from Machinedrum and Kuedo
column5: not to mention their ongoing documentation of the Chicago footwork sound that influences those artists. But over the past two years
column6: the English label has placed just as much stock into warmed-over and vaguely nostalgic sounds
column7: riffing off of chillwave and hypnagogic pop but dressing it all up in beat-oriented structures compatible with the UK bass dialogue that Planet Mu otherwise engages with. Artists like Boxcutter
column8: Solar Bears
column9: Oriol
column10: Tropics
column11: and even FaltyDL have all swum down this lukewarm stream of lazy watercolor
column12: and the label ends one of its best years ever with its first release by Greek duo Keep Shelly in Athens.

column1: Making their first appearance on Mu with a remix of fellow dream-popper Tropics
column2: the lead track off of their first solo EP is also a remix. If this move seems a little disingenuous at first-- is their own material just not up to snuff?-- it's easy to understand why once you actually play the thing. Solar Bears' original ""Cub"" was one of their album's more wandering pieces
column3: three minutes of spidery guitar and mellotron
column4: vaguely medieval in its execution. But in Keep Shelly in Athens' hands
column5: it's an achingly poignant quiet-stormer. Unravelling and pitch-bending that guitar riff to queasy extremes
column6: the duo pushes a staggered beat underneath it
column7: along with its usual assortment of wafting vocal samples. Once the drop hits
column8: it pushes forward with a surprising momentum: Spiraling down a vortex of intense color
column9: ""Cub"" is a misty rush of twinkling synths and adult-contemporary vocals molded into wordless but heart-tugging shapes.

column1: It's a hell of an introduction
column2: and it sets up the band for high expectations on their original material. They deliver as well as anyone could expect such a young band to: ""The Chains"" throws a foundation of rolling basslines and taut percussive loops underneath frontwoman Sarah P's soft vocals
column3: and suddenly bursts into a clangorous
column4: banging echo chamber where drums ominously beat in a pseudo-dubstep pattern. It's a tantalizing 20 seconds that never gets less startling or less powerful
column5: and the duo throws those lurching beats all over ""Struggle With Yourself""
column6: where Sarah P's vocals merge with the humid and cloudy backdrop
column7: and the drums glitch
column8: catch
column9: and screech rudely underneath. The surprisingly nasty underbelly keeps the otherwise lightweight songs from floating away completely
column10: and offers a tangible undercurrent separating them from a legion of anodyne dream-pop acts all singing the same pleasantly slurred tune.

column1: The EP's only uncertain moment comes with its title track
column2: which pairs an awfully saccharine piano motif over erratically sliced percussion
column3: a tension between the beautiful and the berserk that recalls Kuedo's majestic Severant only without the careful balance of melodrama and grit. But even here
column4: vocals gently ride the beat with a supple propulsion that
column5: just like on their remix of ""Cub""
column6: proves addictive and persuasive without predictability. They're still dealing with the unassembled spare parts of what sounds like could be a tight
column7: confident outfit
column8: but the configurations they try on here are promising and at the least intriguing. They might not have answered the question of what exactly separates them from the bleary-eyed masses
column9: but considering the caliber of the artists they're now mingling with on Planet Mu
column10:
the possibility for nurturing artistic growth seems high. One's thing for sure: They do one hell of a remix.

Before they morphed into sampler-toting
column3: vaguely psychedelic dream-punks
column4: No Age's Dean Spunt and Randy Randall were plain-old punks
column5: bashing out noisy
column6: art-damaged songs in Wives. A trio
column7: rounded out by drummer Jeremy Villalobos and
column8: later
column9: Roy Tatum
column10: Wives emphasized passion over precision. The band took its basic inspiration from 1980s hardcore bands like Void
column11: but amped up the freak-out factor with explosive bursts of noise and out-crowd abstraction. Formed in 2001
column12: they delivered a handful of 7"" singles and the Erect the Youth Problem LP before Spunt and Randall laid the name to rest. You can still catch a clip of their final gig
column13: performed as a duo
column14: on the 2006 documentary 40 Bands/80 Minutes.

column1: Released to celebrate the 10th anniversary of Spunt's label
column2: PPM
column3: The Roy Tapes are Wives' last gasp
column4: seven songs recorded immediately prior to the band's first and final European tour
column5: then shelved for nearly seven years. As lost albums go
column6: it's not quite Smile or Black Album-grade myth-fodder. It's a slight
column7: unlabored collection of tunes-- 10 minutes of shrill feedback and growl
column8: preserving the last handful of tunes the band wrote
column9: plus one Negative Approach cover (""Can't Tell No One""). If you caught them in 2005
column10: it will set off an immediate
column11: tender pang of nostalgia.

column1: But there's historical value
column2: too-- if only because you can hear the early percolation of the ideas that would drive No Age. On The Roy Tapes
column3: Spunt and Randall's songwriting takes a step back from the abstract and brainy turf that Wives staked out on their debut. The songs are clumsier in execution
column4: but more hummable. Instead of a tool to voice agression and anger
column5: noise becomes a more melodic and textural element
column6: playful instead of pumelling. On ""If You Went Any Lower You'd Hit China""
column7: the trio rides a simple singsong guitar hook through a wave of electronic squealing
column8: tumbling into a primitive rave up.

column1: The Roy Tapes isn't Wives' finest hour-- Erect the Youth Problem is a more fully realized effort and
column2: if you keep an eye out
column3: it's not that hard to find it in the cut-out bin-- but it's an admirable testament to Spunt and Randall's stick-to-it-iveness at a time when their band was very much in flux. In No Age
column4: Randall and Spunt would hit on a brand of positive punk that was explosive and emotionally direct
column5: but never tear-streaked or tedious. If nothing else
column6:
Wives were the first step toward bigger things.

The story goes that the members of Eddy Current Suppression Ring decided to form a band during a drunken jam at an office Christmas party. The ""office"" in that scenario was the Corduroy Records vinyl pressing plant in Australia. The story's captured on their first song
column3: 2003's ""So Many Things""
column4: a track with ragged
column5: propulsive energy; a juvenile sense of humor; sloppy vocals; and a loud
column6: meandering organ. It sounds like the sort of in-the-moment jam that could pop up at any work party-- people have clearly been drinking; the lyrics are frontman Brendan Suppression's bitter rambling about a woman: ""I think about you here and there/ Only because you're a dickhead"" and ""I don't need your boobies/ I don't need your cute little bum."" It's a rough artifact of their first foray in making music. It's also the opening track on the band's new Goner-imprinted singles compilation
column7: which naturally teases out ECSR's chronological trajectory through B-sides and singles.

column1: Since So Many Things shows the group from its inception to the present
column2: it's safe to assume it illustrates some sort of growth. A quick comparison between tracks one and 22 suggest that's probably the case: 2010's ""Rush to Relax"" has markedly better production and displays a bit more patience and maturity in the band. And
column3: throughout the collection
column4: you can hear a more well-defined guitar sound from Eddy Current and more assertive vocals from Suppression. But they never stop having fun-- their sloppy cover of the Go-Go's ""We Got the Beat"" from a 2011 Record Store Day split 7"" on Trouble in Mind proves that. The band sounds reckless in their approach
column5: singing completely off beat (pun probably intended)
column6: like they're having just as much fun as they were at the 2003 Corduroy Christmas party. That's probably the best thing about So Many Things-- it's a document of four dudes having a good time over the course of about six years.

column1: Of course
column2: it's not all drunken staggering through silly jams-- there's plenty of ripping punk and reasonably weighty stuff here. ""You Let Me Be Honest With You""
column3: from their 2008 LP Primary Colours
column4: has a two-guitar barrage
column5: undercut by Suppression's monotonous vocals. In several songs-- especially ""Honest"" and ""It Ain't Cheap""-- his voice sounds a lot like Iggy Pop's on early Stooges records. They've got a cover of ""T.A.L.O.I.G.A."" by Australian punks the Chosen Few
column6: which has Current attacking a dissonant
column7: screaming guitar solo. Then there's ""Iraq (It's on the Map)""
column8: driven by a militaristic snare and that states
column9: matter-of-factly
column10: ""people are dying from west to east."" Their bass gets guttural and their guitars get frantic on ""Demon's Demands"".

column1: They do menace well
column2: something that probably comes from the band's obsession with punk. (Also
column3: drummer Danny Current used to be in a grindcore band called Demonother.) But even when they crank up the distortion
column4: they don't stray too far from their biggest strength-- these guys really are a lot of fun. ""Hey Mum"" is especially awesome-- a two-minute
column5: jumpy
column6: hokey Hallmark card to a mother. The best part about it? It's still a damn fine punk song. Their growth is most apparent
column7: though
column8: in their musicianship. Even on the shortest song of the bunch
column9: ""Through the Trees""
column10: there's subtle
column11: intricate guitar work from Current that weaves between a harmony line and staying in unison with Suppression's vocals. Sure
column12: Eddy Current Suppression Ring are still the goofy drunks from the record plant
column13: but as musicians
column14: they're capable of elegant
column15:
well done rock'n'roll.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17249/homepage_large.d3a054b8.jpg|Undun|3599.0|The Roots|['Rap'
column3: Redford Stevens
column4: dying in reverse
column5: rewinding from the moment he became a statistic and hitting the points in his life where he's at his most self-aware. That he's a criminal who got caught up in the familiar street-hustle trappings that the modern media's documented countless times is a pivotal detail-- it's hit at an angle that seems to emphasize the futile inevitability of it all. His life could be any number of misdirected narratives that ends with a toe tag
column6: and what details listeners learn about him are hazy
column7: buried under archetypal turns of fate and decisive struggles. That this protagonist is a fictionalized composite of a handful of real people
column8: filtered through a matter-of-fact narrative that splits character ambivalence with journalistic impartiality
column9: only makes his lack of direction and the failure of any real closure stand out even more. ""Lotta niggas go to prison
column10: Dice Raw states on ""Tip the Scale""
column11: ""how many come out Malcolm X?""

column1: So the Roots' latest album isn't a sprawling
column2: rise-and-fall crime story
column3: not a condemnation or a veneration of a man living outside the law
column4: not a bullet-riddled grand guignol heavy on explicit details of soldiers getting cut down. It's a character study of a man whose existential crisis ends only with his death-- a death gone largely unspecified
column5: the glamor and tragedy washed over with a doomed resignation. That's a hard thing to pull off
column6: even for a band as given to deep-thinking concepts as the Roots are. And when your main lyrical catalyst is Black Thought-- a man more given to allusions than direct statements-- it's likely that it'll take a while for the full scope of Undun to really sink in.

column1: If and when it does
column2: it might strike listeners as a bit skeletal: omit the mood-setting instrumental bookends
column3: including a brief
column4: four-part orchestral suite that builds off Sufjan Stevens' ""Redford (For Yia-Yia and Pappou)""
column5: and you've got maybe a half hour's worth of material. By ?uestlove's accounts
column6: writing Redford's story introduced the headaches and challenges that come with scriptwriting into their songwriting
column7: and what's left on Undun is the end result of frequent revisions and rewrites that attempt to reconcile character
column8: theme
column9: and continuity. If it comes at the expense of nuance
column10: it's not always obvious: There's an easy-to-trace narrative line from Redford's acceptance of his fate (""Sleep"") to his acknowledgement of how close it's approaching (""Make My"")
column11: back through declarations of aggravated toughness (""One Time"")
column12: and celebratory fatalism (""Kool On"")
column13: along ups and downs that juxtapose motivation (""Stomp"") and helplessness (""Lighthouse""). When the vocal portion of the album ends with two of the bleakest sets of verses in the Roots discography
column14: peaking with the estrangement of ""I Remember"" and the desperation of ""Tip the Scale""
column15: Undun reveals itself as a story where a man's actual death isn't quite as tragic as the circumstances that pushed him to it.

column1: The catch is that the inevitable familiarity of this storyline
column2: even in the service of a deep emotional study
column3: is almost an end in itself-- a cycle seen far too often
column4: played out in terms anyone who's ever been or known someone with their back against the wall can understand. And if Undun succeeds at putting one man's criminal-world struggle with free will and fate in empathetic terms
column5: it does so at the expense of any unique details or unusual traits that would set him apart-- Redford is humanized
column6: but he's not entirely individualized. If you've bought an Apple device in the last couple of years
column7: you can download a free app that includes some world-building video clips and photos that give him more of a full-life context. If you're still relying on a Blackberry and a clickwheel iPod
column8: you're left with the voices of Black Thought
column9: Dice Raw
column10: and the now-more-googleable Greg Porn to fill in most of the blanks. They're admirable technicians and can be charismatic on their own terms
column11: but voicing raw emotion isn't a major strength for any of them.

column1: What you do get is a heightened sense of perplexed frustration
column2: and there are times when Black Thought actually hits another level in his lyrics to meet it. A resilient
column3: on-the-grind turn of phrase like ""I'm never sleeping like I'm on methamphtamines/ Move like my enemy 10 steps ahead of me"" (""Kool On"") is delivered with the same emphasis as a bitter
column4: regretful line like ""I'll leave the memories here
column5: I won't need them/ If I stop thinking and lie
column6: now that's freedom"" (""Lighthouse""). But if that's one of the reasons Undun feels almost relentless in its singleminded dejection
column7: it's also proof that
column8: if Black Thought can't always push through a sentiment with his voice
column9: he can at least deliver the fuck out of an idea.

column1: The other MCs in the Roots' core provide some welcome shifts in tone: Greg Porn's nasal drone often slips into bluntly nihilistic imagery (""Put the knife in ya back cut down to the red meat/ Daddy should've let me be a stain on the bed sheets"")
column2: and Dice Raw's rapper/singer double-threat role continues to provide a heart of much-needed pathos. His closing line on ""One Time"" might be the most pitch-perfect moment of film noir cynicism on the album: ""To make it to the bottom
column3: such a high climb."" When Phonte and Big K.R.I.T. deliver guest verses that still feel like relative afterthoughts
column4: it's a bit disappointing
column5: but they come strong enough to keep the album's fated
column6: introspective mood consistent.

column1: There's one other aspect to Undun that gives it a sense of ambivalence
column2: even if it's a minor and comparative one: The music itself feels less immediate. After How I Got Over channeled frustrated
column3: brooding soul toward a gradual expansion into triumphant liveliness
column4: the limited palette of down-to-mid-tempo dirges here feels almost stiflingly gloomy. Which means it works-- if this album is a cinematic experience
column5: the score here fills in the cues for moods that the MCs mostly just suggest. The drums-and-keys structure feels more delicate and less urgent than the Roots' best meditative moments
column6: and what few tracks there are with some kick to them-- the burbly guitar-driven ""Kool On""
column7: the worried funk of ""Lighthouse""-- have more of a pull in their chorus than anything in the instrumentation does. Yet the cumulative effect of all that mournful weight is effective enough in the story's service. And in the run-up to ""Tip the Scale""
column8: a string-accented elegy loosely reminiscent of ""You Got Me""
column9: the idea comes across that any glimmer of optimism in this album would be beside the point. This isn't the Roots' most accessible album
column10: and it's definitely their most downbeat
column11:
but it comes from a place that isn't always easy to dwell.

Released in a month which most music nerds spend pouring over year end best of lists and gorging on a buffet of unheard
column2: exotic and often wildly disparate music
column3: Flumina is basically the equivalent of a weeklong juice cleanse. While any collaboration between electronic producer Christian Fennesz and composer Ryuichi Sakamoto has always veered safely into minimal territory
column4: this is easily their most ascetic thing yet; across two discs and two hours
column5: it maintains an almost religious focus on the subtle
column6: slyly shifting interplay between Sakamoto's wandering piano melodies and Fennesz's woolly atmospherics
column7: never peaking or troughing in any dramatic or otherwise notable fashion
column8: and in fact never moving too far from the style and sensibility that it establishes in its very first minutes. Whether you consider this discipline or laziness might depend entirely on how long you listen for
column9: and how.

column1: As with all of their collaborations-- as well as a lot of their individual efforts-- the emphasis here is on subtle shifts and interplays
column2: and the rewards therein. Flumina spends the vast majority of its two hours vacillating between holy moments of harmony and others that are subsumed by an undercurrent of atonality and portent. If I were to try to illustrate the pattern by which Sakamoto's cascading piano notes and Fennesz's pulsing and gauzy guitar lines swarmed around each other
column3: I'd guess I'd draw three parts responsiveness for every two parts of randomness. It's a thing that always threatens to unravel but never does.

column1: There's a thrill to that
column2: but there's also an inherent formula
column3: and if these tracks feel more like formal exercises than structured compositions
column4: it's because
column5: well
column6: they kind of are. Flumina is actually a concept record that Sakamoto hatched before going on tour earlier this year
column7: and the concept itself is every bit as elegant as you'd expect from someone of his restraint. Beginning in March
column8: he opened each live show by playing a new composition in a different key. By the end of April
column9: he'd accumulated 24 recordings
column10: each in a different key
column11: thereby covering every tonal variant in modern Western music.

column1: According to Sakamoto
column2: these tracks were composed from afar with a Fennesz collaboration in mind. That's a lovely thought
column3: and the fact that the record was released so soon after speaks to their mutual admiration. And yet
column4: if one can complain about anything on an album as diffuse as this
column5: it's that Fennesz isn't foregrounded often enough. While something like 2007's Cendre benefited greatly from an occasional splash of his cotton-wool electronics
column6: there are very few moments like that here
column7: and frankly
column8: it needs more. Those who listen to Flumina actively for its full two hours might also miss that extra element. If you listen to Flumina like I do
column9: though
column10: passively or in short bursts
column11:
you're ultimately left with variations on the same thought: This is still an inspired combination.

Maybe the smartest thing about Laura Veirs' new children's album
column2: Tumble Bee
column3: is that some of its tracks aren't even children's songs. Researching the rich history of American folk music for material she could interpret
column4: Veirs cast a wide net to include not only tunes written expressly for kids
column5: but any other compositions she felt could reasonably slot alongside the likes of ""Little Lap Dog Lullaby"" and ""King Kong Kitchie Kitchie Ki-Me-O"". Perhaps unsurprisingly
column6: given the way our 21st-century ears tend to hear anything written 50 or 100 or more years ago as comparatively quaint
column7: songs as thematically disparate as the Civil War-era ""Soldier's Joy"" (here a duet with the Decemberists' Colin Meloy) and a calypso tune popularized by Harry Belafonte
column8: ""Jamaica Farewell""
column9: don't feel so out of place on a record aimed at little ones.

column1: Then again
column2: another thing many of these songs have in common is being really strange
column3: and occasionally even quite dark. Listening to some of Veirs' cover choices makes you think of Greil Marcus' famous description of the folk material Bob Dylan and the Band mined in the late 1960s as capturing the ""old
column4: weird America."" There's Woody Guthrie's ""Why Oh Why""
column5: featuring such bizarre existential quandries as ""Why can't a bird eat an elephant?"" and ""Why ain't my grandpa my grandma?"" There's plenty more that's just flat-out macabre
column6: like the title character of ""The Fox"" informing a pen of doomed ducks and geese that ""a couple of you gonna grease my chin."" Sure enough he keeps his promise
column7: his whole family feasts on the fowl
column8: and the song ends by gleefully pointing out that ""the little ones chewed on the bones."" Then there's ""All the Pretty Little Horses"" (also covered in recent years by Calexico and
column9: earlier
column10: Current 93 with Nick Cave)
column11: a superficially gentle (hear the percussive elements kindly mimicing jangling spurs) but deeply haunting African-American lullaby dating back to the days of slavery; many versions have neutered the song by altering its most harrowing lines
column12: but Veirs retains them: ""Way down yonder
column13: down in the medder/ There's a poor little lambie/ Bees and the butterflies pecking at its eye/ Poor little thing cried 'Mammy.'""

column1: The title track
column2: a Karl Blau song
column3: is also underlined by a grown-up recognition of disappointment and loss. The music may be jaunty
column4: riding playful trumpets and sparkly keys
column5: but the words and Veirs' fragile voice point to a more sobering reality. ""She'll sting me as she longs to be free
column6: Veirs sings of the titular insect. Tumble Bee is a welcome addition to contemporary children's music
column7: not only because it's sufficiently involving to appeal to adults
column8:
but also because it further demonstrates that songs for kids don't have to be cloying or sanitized.

Fred Falke is still living in the last century. To my mind
column3: that's no bad thing
column4: but if you're one of those dance fans who thinks the music constantly needs to be mutating into new forms
column5: you may not be quite as excited by this news. Like so many French producers who came up in the wake of Daft Punk's Homework
column6: Falke seems to think house music was perfected around the turn of the millennium
column7: when the twin sounds of Thomas Bangalter's Roulé imprint and Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo's Crydamoure label-ruled Parisian clubs.

column1: There's not a single sound on Part IV
column2: Falke's first solo album
column3: that you also couldn't find on a French dance single from the late 1990s. If you were around at the time
column4: or you've caught up on the pre-millennial Gallic glory days in the wake of DP's pyramid-rocking global success
column5: the sense of déjà vu
column6: of listening to an everything-in-its-right-place collection of familiar and still pungent tricks
column7: will be time-warp disarming. The wildly woozy disco cut-ups of ""Last Wave"" and ""Look Into Your Eyes""
column8: which spend seven or eight minutes chopping and filtering the same bits of insistent boogie bass and mantra-like soul samples
column9: are straight out of Roulé's playbook. The massive synths all over the record
column10: compressed to an overwhelming mid-range buzz
column11: still split the difference between 1980s soft-pop and just-shy-of-dissonant tech-house
column12: just like you'd find on a classic Crydamoure label cut. Even the harsh stuff
column13: say the thuggish electro-goes-metal riff that drags ""Bare Knuckle"" through its paces
column14: which you might think owes something to Justice and the Ed Banger crew's assaults on good taste from a few years back
column15: still has its roots in Daft Punk at their most ear-scouring and inhuman.

column1: Of course Falke's not the only current producer to be acting as if everything from minimal to dubstep never happened. The skyscraper-sized riffs
column2: endlessly bumping beats (pitched between deep-house smoothness and stadium-sized techno ruthlessness)
column3: and extremist pop gloss of circa 1999 French dance are still everywhere these days
column4: including your local Billboard-friendly pop station. Everything on Part IV is unabashedly huge and peak-time (or drive-time) ready. Slap a pop star on a couple of these tracks
column5: and Falke could be competing with mercenary goons like David Guetta. The difference between Falke and the current crop of club-turned-radio kings
column6: however
column7: is that under the Ibiza-ready wall-of-sound there's an audible love for old-school disco
column8: another thing that marks him out as a French heir to a very French tradition. The fluidity of the basslines all across Part IV nods to both Falke's origins as a bassist and the funkiness of the live band disco days
column9: fluidity and funkiness being two qualities decidedly missing from the robotic ruthlessness of Guetta-style pop-house.

column1: The question
column2: of course
column3: is do you need this album if you're already steeped in the classics? It'd be a fib to say that Falke does anything particularly unexpected or inventive with this material. He just knows what he likes
column4: and he's got a very strong
column5: slick grasp on how to assemble the ""perfect"" (if sometimes slightly generic) French house tune
column6: to give you a powerful hit of an old drug. The styles plundered on Part IV comprise a long-proven formula for getting the adrenaline pumping
column7: not something to sneer at when talking dance music. Falke's spent 10 years tweaking these templates until everything is maximally effective
column8: and even if he's no innovator
column9:
at least we get to luxuriate in the rush.

San Francisco's Desertshore ostensibly took their name from Nico's 1970 album
column2: the one where she began writing her own songs and exerting more control over her sound and style. A decidedly more personal than commercial album-- with a few songs in German and one sung by her son-- Desertshore was not a hit
column3: at least not on par with her debut or her albums with the Velvet Underground
column4: but it continues to attract as many listeners as it repels. Similarly
column5: Desertshore the band represents guitarist Phil Carney's first step away from sideman status
column6: after a stint in Red House Painters and a few appearances on albums and tours by former Painters frontman Mark Kozelek. Carney favors patient
column7: shimmery repetitions of notes that establish tone instead of melody
column8: and the group
column9: which also includes pianist Chris Connolly and a rotation of percussionists
column10: trades in glacial instrumentals that echo the sepiatone reminiscences of the best Painters tracks.

column1: Desertshore
column2: however
column3: do not represent a conscious attempt by Carney to escape that band's orbit; it's less a solo or even a duo project than it is a collaborative entity. Kozelek signed the band to his own Caldo Verde label and contributed to their 2010 debut
column4: Drifting Your Majesty. Now
column5: almost inevitably
column6: Kozelek has more or less joined the group: On their follow-up
column7: Drawing of Threes
column8: he plays barely noticeable basslines and adds lyrics and vocals to six of these 10 songs. It may be as close to a Red House Painters reunion as we will get-- at least until Kozelek reconvenes the original Sun Kil Moon line-up.

column1: As a result of Kozelek's participation
column2: Drawing of Threes will sound deeply familiar to anyone who's heard any of the bands mentioned so far. His voice remains distinctively hollow-eyed
column3: his vocal melodies sound as eloquently understated as ever
column4: and the guitars ring in a darkly ruminative mood that sets Desertshore in the same 3 a.m. universe as Old Ramon and Ghosts of Great Highway. In other words
column5: Kozelek dominates this album. Of the four instrumental tracks
column6: only one-- the standout ""Matchlight Arcana""-- exceeds the two-minute mark
column7: while the others sound like soundtrack interstitials consigned to the album's second half. It's an odd dynamic: the guest plays the lead
column8: the name band becomes the support. Whether that speaks to Desertshore's modesty or timidity is never quite clear.

column1: Still
column2: it's obvious why the musicians gravitate toward one another
column3: not only here but on previous tours and Kozelek solo records: Their particular instruments suit each other evocatively
column4: each bringing out something intriguing and perhaps unnoticed in the other. In that regard
column5: Drawing is best when it casts the familiar elements in a new light. ""Vernon Forrest"" sets Kozelek's vocals against Connolly's sunlight-on-water piano ripples
column6: like a demo for the vox-and-keys album you know Kozelek has in him. ""Randy Quaid"" is a laundry list of half-remembered summertime totems that includes ""Immigrant Song"" and the troubled Vacation actor and manages to rhyme ""Spalding Gray"" with ""the Brothers Quay."" It's an especially playful song for a notoriously depressive singer-songwriter
column7: and Carney's chiming guitar evokes a specific perspective rather than a general sense of nostalgia. Crucially
column8: it sounds more like the memory of summer than summer itself
column9: which lends the song a bittersweet tone. Because Drawing sustains a similar mood across 10 tracks
column10: the album sounds cohesive
column11: if not exactly revelatory. For Kozelek
column12: this is a not unpleasantly minor effort that allows him to stretch out a bit
column13:
but it only hints at what all Carney and Connolly can do together.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17247/homepage_large.cfa1bf9e.jpg|We Bought a Zoo OST|28494.0|Jónsi|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Columbia']|2011-12-05 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:22.537222|"

You've got very few choices if you're looking for someone with name recognition and vestigial indie cred to score a big-budget holiday movie called We Bought a Zoo. The Flaming Lips have already done their Christmas movie soundtrack (and
column2: yes
column3: even have a song about Christmas at the zoo)
column4: and this is a Cameron Crowe film we're talking about
column5: one that's being touted as ""from the director of Jerry Maguire
column6: "" as opposed to
column7: say
column8: ""from the director of Almost Famous."" So Jónsi it is
column9: and you can't argue with the decision. As frontman of Sigur Rós
column10: his vocals embody wide-eyed wonder without devolving into unbearable twee overload. So We Bought a Zoo naturally manifests as a work of mutual admiration and mutual benefit and everyone comes out of it feeling better about themselves. Which is to say that above all else
column11: the level of risk and likelihood to satisfy is on par with that of
column12: say
column13: a Cameron Crowe movie being released for the holidays.

column1: What Crowe gets out of this relationship is obvious. But if Jónsi actually ever needed an audio résumé to snag more jobs like this one
column2: he could just slap down a USB of We Bought a Zoo and have it speak for his emergence as a unique
column3: bankable commodity post-Ágætis Byrjun. This is partially by design: one Sigur Rós song is included
column4: but it's an epochal one. Much like ""Svefn-g-englar"" (a major player on the soundtrack to Crowe's Vanilla Sky)
column5: ""Hoppípolla"" has become shorthand for a specific era of Sigur Rós
column6: indicative of their brassier
column7: bolder
column8: and more concise songwriting that came after ( ) stretched their most inscrutable tendencies to infinity.

column1: We Bought a Zoo gets its spark from key tracks off Jónsi's 2010 solo album
column2: Go. Yes
column3: it's hard to separate Jónsi from his day gig
column4: but if We Bought a Zoo gets people to think of Go as far more than something other than a Sigur Rós spinoff
column5: well
column6: hopefully it'll inspire Jónsi to give us more of the same. Despite the greater prevalence of synthetic strings and dance beats
column7: there's something more primal about these songs than those of latter day Sigur Rós. ""Go Do"" speaks to a universal ideal of action and while time will reveal how ""Boy Lilikoi"" fits into this particular movie
column8: the childish primitivism would've worked just fine within Where the Wild Things Are (though perhaps with Disney animation rather than brooding browns and grays).

column1: So what's the draw for those of us who already share Crowe's ardent Jónsi fanhood? That's where a shade over a half hour of new music he composed for the film comes in
column2: with tasteful brass and string arrangements courtesy of Nico Muhly. It's heartening to hear about the film's working title and climactic scene being inspired by 2007 live documentary Heima and the director encouraging Matt Damon and Scarlett Johansson to listen to certain Sigur Rós songs to get their energy correct for certain scenes (I expect plenty of beatific
column3: skyward gazing). And certainly
column4: it's exciting to imagine Jónsi coming from Iceland to hunker down with what Crowe calls a ""a toy sample keyboard and a head full of ideas."" But let's not forget that while Crowe brought Jónsi in for his uniquely whimsical and weighty approach
column5: it's still whimsy-for-hire.  So those trebly piano twinkles
column6: elegiac tempos
column7: octave-shifted vocals that hover and haunt like friendly ghosts? They're all here
column8: treated with a bit of textural abrasion and arranged into small
column9: three-minute packages with utilitarian titles like ""Sun""
column10: ""Brambles""
column11: and ""Humming"". Even one of two vocal tracks Jónsi composed specifically for the film hints a little to the melody from ""White Christmas"". Dude's a good company man.

column1: Of course
column2: it's all lovely and certainly more immediately engaging and compact than Jónsi's mostly-instrumental Riceboy Sleeps multimedia project from 2009. But it also has something going for it more important than gorgeous ambience: the Jónsi seal of quality. Does his work as an arranger and curator rank in the same percentile as his work as a vocalist? Not really
column3: and even if starlit passages like ""Sinking Friendships"" or the luxuriant title track put in fine work with moving images
column4: they aren't likely to dislodge anything from the upper echelon of his past work. But hopefully
column5: offering the bold and evolving gestures of Jónsi's past decade in a relatively safe and compact design allows the possibility that a moviegoer might come out of the theater curious enough to parlay $10 into a meaningful relationship with Jónsi's music. And if that's the case
column6:
I think a lot of us are jealous of those who get to experience Sigur Rós for the first time in 2011.

It's no coincidence that Emerson

column10: and populist-indie (Arcade Fire) origin have embraced the genre's narrative qualities

column12: and theatricality. Montreal's Yamantaka//Sonic Titan are the latest torch-bearers for the city's prog-and-proud tradition. But where the most renowned prog-rock bands have introduced thematic frameworks into their music very gradually over the course several years-- remember

column1: To say the duo of Ruby Kato Attwood and Alaska B have lofty ambitions would be an understatement. Being of Anglo-Asian descent-- the former is Japanese-Scottish
column2: the latter Chinese-Irish-- the two formed Yamantaka//Sonic Titan to address the duality of their cultural identities

column12: stoner-metal heft

column1: Thanks to smart
column2: brisk sequencing

column4: even if the thematic devices linking them aren't so easy to discern: The tribal-ceremonial scene setter ""Queens"" offers references to ravens

column9: as Ruby and Alaska become increasingly reliant on words of indeterminate language and ghostly harmonies. However
column10: inscrutably titled songs like the funhouse-mirrored acid-pop of ""Reverse Crystal//Murder of a Spider"" and the space-age stomper ""Hoshi Neko"" nonetheless display an insidiously melodic quality that suggests Stereolab on steroids. And where these songs foreground YT//ST's eccentric side

column12: seven-minute colossus ""A Star Over Pureland"" showcases their command of brute physicality
column13: pitting the ladies' echo-drenched shrieks against a relentless
column14: jackhammered fuzz-metal assault
column15: like Fly-era Yoko Ono waging war with Lightning Bolt. Yamantaka//Sonic Titan may still aspire to the sort of conceptual grandeur that requires an Olympic Stadium to contain it

column17:
what they're really good at is putting the ""raw"" in prog.

Stop me if you think you've heard this one before: up-and-coming rapper teams with up-and-coming label

column8: day-glo colored shell. Ultraviolet clearly encouraged Kid Sister to reevaluate her career

column1: So it's kind of a shame that

column4: with Fool's Gold labelmate Danny Brown and lobotomized pop-rap experiment MTV Riff Raff

A couple of weeks ago
column2: Pitchfork Editor-in-Chief Mark Richardson wrote a column on what he called ""the Tumblr-ization of indie."" One of his ideas was that an artist like Lana Del Rey is basically a collage-- or in his metaphor
column3: a Tumblr-- of images and sounds she thinks are cool. In a cultural moment when the past is instantly accessible-- not to mention one in which we're used to constant reference and appropriation-- it makes sense that we start conflating ""who we are"" with ""what we're into."" Instead of creating
column4: the artist collects. As viewers-- or listeners
column5: or whatever-- we learn to read between the lines and explore juxtapositions. Is it possible
column6: for example
column7: for me to express something about myself that can't be best expressed by saying
column8: ""I'm pretty into Hawaiian slack-key guitar music and body horror movies?"" Liking things-- something we all do by reflex-- becomes a creative gesture if you do it thoughtfully.

column1: Listening to Daydream Repeater
column2: Ecstatic Sunshine member Matthew Papich's first full-length album as Co La
column3: I revisited an experience I haven't had since college: Walking down the street
column4: seeing someone wearing the t-shirt of a band I like
column5: and thinking
column6: cool. It's comforting to know other people like the same things we do-- in this case
column7: skinhead reggae from the mid-1960s
column8: field recordings from the Cameroonian rainforest
column9: cricket noises
column10: music in major keys. It's an incredibly lightweight album-- thin-sounding
column11: super-repetitive
column12: bright to the point of translucence. (Though Daydream Repeater doesn't sound stylistically like Ecstatic Sunshine
column13: people familiar with them might recognize the directive: feel good all the time
column14: over and over again). Papich is no archeologist
column15: nor do I think he's trying to show off his knowledge of obscure sounds-- most of the time
column16: he doesn't even bother disguising his samples.

column1: Whether you attribute this to laziness or naive grace probably depends on frame of mind. By techno or hip-hop standards
column2: Daydream Repeater would be artless
column3: but my sense is that the music on it is closer to something like Girl Talk for audiences who don't like getting the shit beaten out of them-- music that wants you to say
column4: ""Hey
column5: I recognize that
column6: music that makes you feel included rather than excluded.

column1: When interviewed for a ""Rising"" column a few weeks ago
column2: Papich namechecked Erik Satie
column3: a turn-of-the-century French composer who coined the term musique d'ameublement
column4: or ""furniture music""-- basically
column5: the foundation for what we now call ""ambient."" Clearly Papich wants to be part of that conversation
column6: or he wouldn't have made the reference. Whether he adds much to it or not
column7: I don't know. The irony of Satie's music is that
column8: at the time
column9: it was considered radical and antagonistic. Papich has 100 years of art to validate music as brainless and determinedly relaxing as his own.

column1: I've listened to Daydream Repeater a lot lately
column2: but at moments when I otherwise don't want to be listening to music. To my mind
column3: it sounds less like ambience and more like exotica. Its imaginary world is the yacht deck without seasickness or boredom
column4: jungles without the fist-sized bugs. It's music for imagining you're in a perfect somewhere else. Five songs are named after places: ""Egyptian Peaches""
column5: ""Belgian Pillow""
column6: ""My Jamaican""
column7: ""Siamese in Greece""
column8: ""Burning One in Stockholm.""

column1: That's where the Tumblr thing comes in. Daydream Repeater plays more like a mixtape than an album-- a document of where someone's been and what they've liked. Aside from one surprising flip of ""Be My Baby""
column2: Papich doesn't seem as interested in transforming his source material as much as just presenting it. Here's a reggae song I like
column3: he says
column4: and then plays it with some echo. A couple of minutes later
column5: something else. In the cracks between
column6: some aesthetic takes shape.  Some of my colleagues here seem outright frustrated by how little Papich seems to interact with his material. For a record so airy and noncommittal
column7:
I feel semi-conflicted about it. He doesn't really seem bent on invention. But I like listening to Daydream Repeater. I'd repost it.

Quilt is an East Coast group of Anna Fox Rochinsk
column2: Shane Butler
column3: and John Andrews. They've been touring the basement show circuit and putting out occasional
column4: limited-run releases since 2009
column5: although I hadn't heard of them until this year's SXSW festival
column6: when my band shared a makeshift wooden stage with them
column7: at an unofficial backyard showcase in South Austin
column8: hosted by WNYU. The odor of smoke
column9: brisket
column10: and crawfish stew seemed the perfect accompaniment to their twangy
column11: somewhat ramshackle blend of 1960s psychedelia
column12: mantric blues
column13: and folk
column14: and I remember realizing that they were the first band I had heard all week whose vocal parts included classic
column15: three-part harmonies-- and whose use of a Farfisa was less retro-futuristic than straight-up retro.

column1: Quilt sounded kind of like a flashback to a time
column2: not so long ago
column3: when Sunburned Hand of the Man made the cover of The Wire under the banner of ""New Weird America
column4: and artists like Devendra Banhart and Six Organs of Admittance prompted indie music fans to snap up reissues of outsider folk records by Vashti Bunyan
column5: Jandek
column6: and Alexander ""Skip"" Spence. The members of Quilt are probably old enough to remember and have been impacted by a time-- roughly around the mid-aughts-- when the global economy was still in a boom phase rather than a bust
column7: and much of the independent music community seemed bent on expressing its independent-mindedness through an ethos of retreat: out of the city and into the woods
column8: back through the years to the screaming guitar solos and of the hippy generation and the vulnerable rawness of Anglo-American folk singing
column9: inward to the depths of the psyche and the eccentricites of character. The thing that struck me most about Quilt
column10: at the time
column11: was not that they seemed to be backtracking to a revivalist movement in recent memory that was not exactly their generation's own; it was that the particular reference points they were drawing on simply weren't ones I had heard in a while.

column1: Like their namesake
column2: Quilt's music feels handmade and stitched-together
column3: as though its creators were sifting through a collection of musical hand-me-downs and collating the bits that spoke to them into something new. This patchwork quality extends not only to their juxtaposition
column4: say

column6: but to their melodic sensibility at large
column7: which favors tightly interlocking arrangements of simple motifs. The band's writing process
column8: so they say
column9: consists in endlessly improvising on a collection of predetermined chord progressions
column10: and the resulting intricacy comes particularly to the fore on their self-titled debut for Mexican Summer
column11: which they recorded with the help of Apollo Sunshine's Jesse Gallagher in the summers of 2010 and 2011. Percussion work was split between founding drummer Taylor Mcvay and John Andrews
column12: who has since replaced her.

column1: Quilt unfolds in a series of vividly colored scenes
column2: ranging from the hushed suspense of opener ""Young Gold"" to bouncy
column3: open road cruisers like ""Cowboys in the Void"" and ""Penobska Oakwalk""

column1: Again

column1: In its less captivating passages

column3: Quilt will sound like a pitch-perfect rendition of some 1969 acid-folk reissue that was never quite as memorable as you hoped. At its most exhilarating

column12:
why should we try to make anew/ When we could be intoxicated by this ordinary turn again?""

column3: I'm guessing it'll be Camp. The album maintains some of the overweening humor of Donald Glover's sitcom ""Community""
column4: but Glover's exaggerated
column5: cartoonish flow and overblown pop-rap production are enough to make Camp one of the most uniquely unlikable rap records of this year (and most others). What's worse is how he uses heavy topics like race
column6: masculinity
column7: relationships
column8: street cred
column9: and ""real hip-hop"" as props to construct a false outsider persona. On record
column10: he paints himself as a misunderstood victim of cultural preconceptions who is obviously smarter and funnier than his primetime material suggests. Unfortunately
column11: it's a position that holds up to absolutely no scrutiny whatsoever.

column1: Glover's not doing himself any favors with a rap handle taken from the Wu-Tang Name Generator
column2: but that'd be easy to overlook if Camp functioned as anything more than a series of similar one-note gags. On a song-by-song basis
column3: he scripts a slightly off-brand
column4: fictional version of Kanye West being played for laughs. We could talk about Glover's bloodlines all day
column5: but Childish Gambino's paternity test traces straight back to ""All Falls Down"". ""You See Me"" reimagines ""Niggas in Paris"" as a meme cemetery
column6: with Glover painfully leaning into herniated punchlines like
column7: ""She's an overachiever/ All she does is suck seed."" (Or maybe ""Asian girls everywhere... UCLA!"" will eventually end up on a T-shirt.) The bottle-service electro of ""Heartbeat"" could have been the 10th-funniest song on 808s & Heartbreak-- somewhere between ""The Coldest Winter"" and ""Love Lockdown""-- and it's actually trying for laughs. A few of Camp's tracks focus on more inspirational topics than ""making up for the fucks I missed in high school
column8: but they usually emulate ""Jesus Walks""
column9: or when trying to be slightly more humble
column10: ""Get By"". And any shred of relatability Glover establishes by reminiscing about sinkbaths with his cousin

column2: but his cratedigging begins with The College Dropout and ends with My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy

column6: and even he's widely beloved on account of being an acknowledged pathological liar). This much is obvious from the tone-deaf ""All of the Shine
column7: and especially ""Backpackers""

column9: usually educated haters. Note how its title co-opts the one epithet more outdated than ""hipster"" in rap music circa 2011.

column1: Glover isn't strictly a comedy rapper

Crystal Stilts have always been ahead of the contemporary indie pop learning curve. When most of their peers were products of the widely beloved C86 tape in 2008
column3: the Brooklyn quintet was namedropping the Clean cofounder David Kilgour's the Great Unwashed. The components that make their sound are fastidiously plucked from early-1980s Manchester (Joy Divison) and New Zealand (the Clean
column4: the Chills)
column5: late-1960s New York (the Velvet Underground)
column6: and-- in cases including but not limited to singer Brad Hargett's hair-- early Bob Dylan. But influence doesn't mean anything if it's not siphoned into something worthwhile
column7: and Crystal Stilts do much more than sit on their first-edition copies of Flying Nun vinyl and collect cool points.

column1: Their debut album Alight of Night found them firing off shimmering guitar lines and then simmering into a thick haze
column2: alternating between sunny afternoon clang and after-hours sulk. Using his voice as another instrument instead of a vehicle for dynamic singing or pseudo-profound lyrical messages
column3: Hargett's deep baritone blends low into the mix
column4: the use of reverb rivaling that of an epic fantasy movie narrator. The album was used as the foundation for this year's In Love With Oblivion
column5: though that newer collection was a fuller-sounding affair
column6: more urgent in places (""Shake the Shackles"")
column7: more daring in others (""Alien Rivers"")
column8: and filled with pop tunes brimming with life from corner to corner. Crystal Stilts are a band that doesn't have much use for empty space-- most of the silence gets chased away by the blasts of trebly volume.

column1: Radiant Door is not a radical departure from that default sound; its Kilgour Brothers-indebted style makes it safe to assume kiwi is still the most important item on their tour rider. But not all groups have to rely on the benefit of reinvention. The non-vocalists of Crystal Stilts are incredibly good at adding a Technicolor flair
column2: crafting arrangements so colorful that they often veer into kaleidoscopic territory. Two of the five songs on the EP feature the quintet nakedly putting its record collection at the forefront of its consciousness
column3: this time in the form of recorded covers. The band's take on Blue Orchids' ""Low Profile"" is a key example of this; it's faithful enough to the original to be recognizable
column4: but the Stilts' heavy lifting-- as it mostly always does-- comes from keyboardist Kyle Forester and guitarist/co-songwriter JB Townsend
column5: the former turning in a simple-but-catchy three-note riff
column6: the latter sounding like he's been planting Joshua Trees around Brooklyn.

column1: The EP's other cover
column2: Lee Hazlewood's ""Still as the Night""
column3: finds the band in spaghetti-western outlaw mode
column4: exploring a style they've heretofore never tried. The song is spare in a way that's uncommon to the band. It doesn't quite work with a singer like Hargett
column5: whose booming voice (that sometimes wavers in and out of key) is far more suited to weathering the band's stormier moments than trying to fill in gaps. Though ""Still as the Night"" is a good song that falls just short of being great
column6: it doesn't stall the band-- they've always been adept at playing to their strengths
column7: and the rest of the EP's 21 minutes are full of gleaming keyboard lines and jangly guitars casting sun on everything in sight. For a band that has proven it can do darkness just as well
column8:
Radiant Door is exactly as its title suggests-- the brighter side of one of America's best psych-pop bands.

If you're an indie rocker in need of chamber instruments

column9: Arcade Fire

column15: slotting compositions from St. Vincent's Annie Clark and Son Lux alongside new works from young composer colleagues. The album's existence is a feat of networking savvy and determination-- it was funded via Kickstarter page-- but the music itself is sadly hit-or-miss

column1: Son Lux's titular work

column3: lands somewhere blankly in the middle. Son Lux is no dabbler: He studied composition at Indiana University. But his work  is somehow both antic and utterly frozen-- its gestures twitter away in  different corners of the compositional space without engaging thematically. The work

column1: Annie Clark fares significantly better. In fact
column2: her piece

column8: the sharp

column10: an arch almost-quote from some lost big-band record. The work is a lively jumble of jazzy-French flavors

column1: Shara Worden of My Brightest Diamond also shows up to hand yMusic two sketches-- one vaguely Eastern

column3: which lit last year's Penelope

column7: the composer of Penelope

column1: yMusic are part of a resourceful

column6: Beautiful Mechanical also hints at some of the still-growing scene's nagging limitations: As exciting as all this activity is to behold

column9:
modest and lovely but inessential.

column1: And with that rehearsed conversation with Eminem about making love songs for women
column2: Yelawolf is trying to absolve himself from the responsibility of about one-third of Radioactive being decidedly half-assed. The middle of the album (featuring hooks from the likes of Priscilla Renea and Fefe Dobson) is far and away the worst music of Yelawolf's career
column3: and he knows it. His rapping is passable
column4: but the beats are leaden and uninspired and the hooks are about as canned as possible. It's hard to imagine what the market for those songs is
column5: really-- I can't imagine that Yelawolf's female fans want to hear him rap about conventional romance
column6: or want to hear a potentially good song about blue-collar American life drowned in a syrupy chorus.

column1: The worst part isn't the songs themselves
column2: but that the album didn't have to go this route. Outside the sagging middle section
column3: the subject matter and production will be nothing new to those familiar  with Yela's music; his voice and perspective remain sharp and unique
column4: and he certainly hasn't lost any of his technical skill. The guests  (Mystikal
column5: Killer Mike
column6: Three 6 Mafia secret weapon Gangsta Boo) are also otherwise the type of people that should be on a Yelawolf album
column7: rappers from whom he pulls his vocal style or sharp wit
column8: or to whom his  fans likely also listen. (There is a frame of a great album here
column9: and  in the age of selective iTunes playlisting
column10: maybe the regrettable  portion of the album is merely just forgettable.) This isn't Yelawolf's first foray into trying to make pop songs or songs for women
column11: but it's by far his worst. His previous albums-- last year's Trunk Muzik and its repackaged follow-up Trunk Muizk: 0-60-- showcased an ability and an affinity for pop songwriting that could've been fostered and encouraged here instead of being shelved for industry cast-offs.

column1: And then there is ""Let's Roll""
column2: the song with Kid Rock that unexpectedly shows exactly how the formula can go right. Whether it equals pop success remains to be seen
column3: but it's a collaboration that plays to both artists' strengths. As country boys at heart with an interest in both rap and rock
column4: Yela and Kid Rock are arguably closer kindred spirits than Yela and Eminem
column5: despite the tongue-twisting rapping. ""Let's Roll"" asks Rock to sing a conventional rap hook over a conventional rap beat
column6: but the crux is in the grittiness and twang that Rock brings to the track
column7: which dovetails perfectly with Yela's imagery of life as a rebel in Alabama. It's an inspired pairing
column8: one that amounts to one of the best songs of Yelawolf's career
column9:
and it holds a mirror up to the four or five insipid crossover attempts that come later.

When John Peel said that he was incapable of telling if the Fall had ever made a bad record
column2: that had something to do with the fact that they mostly hadn't until fairly recently
column3: and more to do with the spell that Mark E. Smith's unwavering attitude casts over the faithful. There's no other sound like Smith's spittle-flecked snarl
column4: and no other lyrical sensibility like his; he's never allowed the Fall to rest on its history
column5: or its listeners to get too comfortable.

column1: But that's not the same thing as saying that the Fall are incapable of making a bad record
column2: and although a lot of their discography is difficult but rewarding
column3: their 15
column4: 000th album Ersatz G.B.'s abrasiveness
column5: inscrutability
column6: and tedium are increasingly tough to take with repeated close listening. So it raises a couple of questions
column7: such as: What would a total failure of a Fall album sound like
column8: and how would that be different from this one? And what does it mean when it's impossible to tell a band's new record from a weak parody of what they've been up to for the past few years?

column1: One way that the Fall could go wrong
column2: for instance
column3: if that were possible
column4: would be for their music to fall off. Despite Smith's insistence that he's the only important member
column5: he used to have bandmates who were distinctive musicians-- Brix
column6: Steve Hanley
column7: Marc Riley
column8: the Mouse on Mars guys. These days
column9: he has to work with musicians who will put up with what being in the Fall in the 21st century entails. The lineup on Ersatz G.B.
column10: as it happens
column11: is the same as on the last couple of albums
column12: but it could be yet another anonymous pickup crew-- and if you removed Smith's vocals from it
column13: it would be a nearly irredeemable
column14: almost totally generic hard rock record. The riff of ""Greenway"" is
column15: in fact
column16: copped from Greek comedy-metal band Anorimoi's ""Gameboy""
column17: except that the current edition of the Fall doesn't have anything like Anorimoi's precision and bite.

column1: And Smith? How could a record with him on it ever go entirely awry? Well
column2: he's still Mark E. Smith-- there are always developments to follow. He's got a new voice he uses on a few songs
column3: a death-rattle gargle-growl; as usual
column4: there are a couple of WTF lyrical moments
column5: especially ""Nate Will Not Return""
column6: in which Smith sees how many rhymes he can force with the name of the Gossip Girl character. And there are still a few drops to be milked out of Smith's favorite tricks: mocking middlebrow culture
column7: dragging ""un-songlike"" diction and fun-to-pronounce proper nouns into song lyrics
column8: fracturing the meaning of a sentence mid-phrase. (One line in ""Mask Search""
column9: possibly the best-enunciated on the album
column10: does all of those things: ""I'm so sick of Snow Patrol/ And where to find Esso lubricant/ And mobile number."")

column1: At this point
column2: though
column3: the band's music is so pro forma that most of his lyrics could be applied to any track here with no significant difference. ""I've Seen Them Come"" is an idea for an intriguing 20-second passage of a song
column4: stretched out to an unbearable six minutes. ""Age of Chang"" features a tinny condenser-mic recording accompanied by the properly recorded band
column5: which would be a clever idea if Smith hadn't already recorded ""Paintwork"" more than 25 years ago. When ""Happi Song"" turns up halfway through
column6: it's a relief to not hear Smith out front for a few minutes-- it's a sweet
column7: simple tune written by keyboardist Eleni Poulou
column8: and sung by her in a fragile
column9: thickly accented voice (with Smith occasionally making unpleasant noises in the background).

column1: If you believe the Fall are incapable of badness by virtue of their singularity
column2: then here you go; Smith's Mancunian sneer will always raise a Pavlovian response for those of us who are used to its signaling genius. But hold this shabby
column3: grueling album up next to Hex Enduction Hour or Bend Sinister or The Marshall Suite or any number of the great
column4: challenging records the Fall made when they were challenging themselves
column5: too
column6:
and it falls apart.
