column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17222/homepage_large.4afa1678.jpg|Works: Selected Remixes 2006-2010|8735.0|Radio Slave|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rekids']|2011-12-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:30.055213|"

""Formula"" can be a bad word when it comes to music
column2: but it needn't be. It's really just another term for ""recipe"" or ""rules
column3: and rules are what make particular types of music work the way they do. The blues is a formula. The sonata's a formula. And in house and techno
column4: the four-to-the-floor kick is a formula
column5: the one that makes it all click together like Legos. There are many such formulae in dance music; we could also just call them conventions. A lot of these conventions have to do with accommodating DJs
column6: like 16-bar intros with little more than a steady kick and a hint of the tune to come
column7: to facilitate mixing into the track that's finishing
column8: or 16-bar outros that have been similarly thinned out to pave the way for the next succession of stepping stones.

column1: Some formulae are less about the DJ than the listener
column2: less functional than musically intuitive-- like a drum fill across the last few beats of the fourth bar
column3: to send us hurtling into the next phrase
column4: or a filter sweep at the end of a long breakdown
column5: to build tension before the music returns at full power. These things can easily degenerate into cliché
column6: as evidenced by the current crop of maximum-strength electro-house being flogged across stadium raves and super clubs
column7: in which every functional trope is super-sized to the verge of self-parody. But in the hands of a producer like Radio Slave
column8: the formula becomes the material itself. The form becomes the content.

column1: This is one of the main things you'll take away from Works: Selected Remixes 2006-2010
column2: a collection of the Berlin-based producer Matt Edwards' remix work for artists like UNKLE
column3: Trentemøller
column4: Minilogue
column5: and Roman Flügel's Soylent Green. It's an impressive-- some might say daunting-- collection. There are only 22 tracks
column6: but with the average length of around 10 minutes
column7: they take up three CDs and nearly four hours' listening time. As compilations go
column8: the list of artists remixed suggests a wide stretch of stylistic ground: Edwards tackles not just the work of like-minded dance artists like Len Faki
column9: Mr. G
column10: and Peace Division but also winsome indie pop from Mlle Caro & Franck Garcia and an Arthur Russell cover by alt-R&B types Yam Who?. (Even the Cult's Ian Astbury wails his way into the mix
column11: via UNKLE's ""Burn My Shadow"".)

column1: But as disparate as the source material can be
column2: a remarkable uniformity prevails across the remixes. As Radio Slave
column3: Edwards essentially does one groove. (He explores other styles under aliases like Rekid
column4: Cabin Fever
column5: and the Machine
column6: and in the duo Quiet Village.) It's a rolling
column7: gliding
column8: tech-house cadence built upon sturdy kick drums and immaculately carved hi-hats
column9: so cleanly cut they might be a jeweler's work. It's the archetypal house groove
column10: with shakers and hi-hats on the upbeats and claps on the 2 and 4; every new track feels like a variation upon the last. It's a formula
column11: but Edwards is a master of tweaking the internal proportions
column12: sliding elements forward or backward against the beat to give it a sense of swing. He threads ostinato tones through the upper register like a guy wire
column13: a taut line arrowing off toward the horizon and from which every other element hangs. He favors dry claps and snares to accentuate the cavernous empty space between the beats
column14: and the bass is more felt than heard: rarely could it be called a ""line
column15: just the moody cushion on which everything nervously rests.

column1: He deploys syncopated toms or chord stabs
column2: often buried subliminally deep in the mix
column3: to add even more tension. And he knows how to draw out a phrase for 16 or 32 bars
column4: sketching broad arcs over rhythms that seem never to change
column5: as though teasing the course of time itself. Virtually every track here
column6: at once languid and tightly wound
column7: is a master class in what makes this particular kind of groove tick. Across the 22 tracks
column8: these tropes reappear so often that it's hard to tell whether they're tactics or tics. So I tried a little experiment.

column1: I was inspired by something I found on SoundCloud the other day. Created by a Britsh artist named Paul Chivers (aka ramjac)
column2: it's called ""All Together Now: Everything the Beatles Ever Did""
column3: and that's exactly what it is: ""Every Beatles tune
column4: played together
column5: sequenced in order of lengths
column6: with the longest starting first and all 226 tunes ending together
column7: as Chivers explains in his description. It begins with the familiar loops of ""Revolution 9"" and culminates in a maelstrom that might send Merzbow running for cover. It's a neat conceptual joke
column8: but it also says something about the proportions of the Beatles' own chosen forms
column9: and the way they grew out of them.

column1: I wanted to see how well Radio Slave's remixes conform to an ideal type
column2: so I dragged all seven tracks from the first CD of Works into Ableton Live
column3: a music-production and sequencing application. I changed the tempos of the individual tracks slightly so that the beats were lined up
column4: all of them beginning together
column5: and I hit ""Play."" The result sounded remarkably like one single track-- or
column6: at most
column7: a mixed passage in a DJ set
column8: where both tracks are at full volume.

column1: There are key clashes galore
column2: but that's not the point-- what's striking is how perfectly all the rhythmic elements line up. And
column3: beyond that
column4: how closely the tracks mirror each other in structure
column5: swelling and fading in lockstep. Voices from disparate songs-- Ian Astbury
column6: Mlle Caro
column7: the singer from Trentemøller's ""Moan""-- are teased in at roughly the same points in the composite track
column8: a pile of codas upon codas. The fadeout is a uniform decrescendo. The shape of Edwards' ideal form burns like a filament in a dimly lit room. The results reminded me of Idris Khan's superimposed collages of the work of Bernd and Hilla Becher
column9: photographers obsessed with documenting archetypal architectural forms. All of that
column10: and still: If you were at a club and heard this coming from the speakers
column11: you'd probably think
column12: ""Hm
column13: a little busy
column14: but it works.""

column1: All of this isn't to reduce Radio Slave's remix work to a caricature-- quite the opposite. (Not everything on the compilation follows the pattern: ""Go Bang""
column2: the Arthur Russell rework
column3: is a glorious mess of unhinged disco
column4: and Edwards' remix of Nelski's ""Body Pop"" pairs Latin pianos with dub chords to collapse New York's Body and Soul into Berlin's Panorama Bar-- a superimposition of a very different sort.) In fact
column5: the experiment actually increased my appreciation for Edwards' craft. It's not easy to be this consistent without bogging down in old habits. No matter how formally similar each track may be
column6: the best of them-- like his remixes of Soylent Green's ""La Forza Del Destino""
column7: Matt O'Brien's ""Serotone""
column8: and Mr. G's ""Sometimes I Cry""-- jump out of the speakers with rare intensity. You may not always be able to ID them
column9: but if you've heard them on a dance floor
column10:
you know them in your bones.

"|16087.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16087-works-selected-remixes-2006-2010/|6.9|Philip Sherburne

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17240/homepage_large.5f9a09ae.jpg|Free All the Monsters|616.0|The Bats|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Flying Nun']|2011-12-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:30.666549|"

Things move slowly in the world of beloved New Zealand band the Bats. 2012 will conclude their 30th year as a group
column2: although they're not likely to be in any rush to celebrate that fact. After all
column3: this is a group that took five years to release its debut full-length album (Daddy's Highway) and is only now issuing its eighth record
column4: Free All the Monsters. The long gaps in the Bats' catalog can partly be attributed to singer/guitarist Robert Scott's presence as bassist in the Clean and his intermittent work as a solo artist
column5: including his excellent 2010 album
column6: Ends Run Together. Remarkably
column7: despite long periods of inactivity
column8: the band's original lineup of Scott plus singer/guitarist Kaye Woodward
column9: bassist Paul Kean
column10: and drummer Malcolm Grant remains intact. So too does that dreamy
column11: disconsolate feeling that settles in whenever the Bats' best music takes hold and nimbly seeps under your skin.

column1: This relatively swift follow-up to 2008's The Guilty Office reunites the group with Flying Nun for the first time in over a decade
column2: during a time when the legendary Christchurch label is celebrating its own 30th year in the business. It may be a stretch to imagine that realigning of forces caused the Bats to up their game
column3: but this feels like their best record in years
column4: possibly ever. Free All the Monsters simply consists of a set of plaintive songs that draw on all the stylistic cues this band has worked hard to establish in the past (a Byrds-ian jangle
column5: a touch of Velvets-style dissonance) and tightens everything up a touch. Parallel feelings of warmth and longing criss-cross through much of the material
column6: with songs like ""Long Halls"" and ""On the Bank"" bedded down in Kean's warmly looping basslines
column7: while the vocals cut through the glow with a whole heap of self scrutiny.

column1: Most bands that put in the kind of time the Bats have accrued
column2: either in their natural lives or through reunions
column3: are trading off past glories by the time they hit this awkward middle-age stage. The language of rock simply doesn't lend itself well to concerns that arise once temples start thinning and paunches start widening-- with a few notable exceptions. Scott
column4: it seems
column5: is one of those irregular musicians
column6: someone who has grappled with the aging process and managed to filter his thoughts and feelings on it into compelling material. It helps that he's able to fasten his wistful mindset to a broad base of musical ideas
column7: whether it's in the lilting pop of his co-vocal duties with Woodward on ""Free All the Monsters"" and ""Fingers of Dawn"" or through the meditative exhaust-fume growl of ""In the Subway"". On the beautifully barren instrumental ""Canopy"" there's no need for words
column8: with the Bats overlapping
column9: keening guitar lines that perfectly sink into the pensive undercurrent of the rest of the album.

column1: The nostalgic ""Spacejunk"" works as a précis of the unusual place the Bats find themselves in
column2: with Scott hinting at his malaise (""direction is hard to find"") and indicating how he gets over it (""time is the healer""). That notion of using time to overcome
column3: to iron out kinks
column4: not to rush into resolution or hasty decision-making is why this group has an album on their hands that effortlessly builds on everything that came before. It's an old-fashioned approach in the internet age
column5: but it's better to think of the Bats as a band that's completely out of time
column6: operating in a space (and at a pace) of its own volition. On Free All the Monsters
column7: that place is full of familiar concerns-- woebegone angst
column8: rumination on a life that could have turned out differently
column9: the brutally quick passage of time. It's a bittersweet corner of the world that the Bats have patiently chipped away at over their long history
column10:
but on this record it feels like they're gaining a head of steam instead of resting on any laurels.

"|16093.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16093-free-all-the-monsters/|7.5|Nick Neyland

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17237/homepage_large.6bb63619.jpg|Big Bells and Dime Songs|30091.0|Luke Roberts|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2011-12-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:31.162681|"

Big Bells and Dime Songs
column2: Luke Roberts' debut LP
column3: was released by Thurston Moore's Ecstatic Peace in the spring of 2010; after a limited run
column4: it received a relatively grander rollout this fall via Thrill Jockey. While the record wasn't reissued
column5: exactly
column6: Big Bells' unveiling was gradual-- which feels like a particularly appropriate beginning for Roberts
column7: a deliberate and unhurried folk singer from Nashville.

column1: On first listen
column2: Big Bells and Dime Songs can seem slight-- Roberts' guitar and vocals aren't augmented by much
column3: save the occasional snare
column4: some bass
column5: or a snippet of electric organ or piano-- but their sparseness only amplifies the record's pervasive
column6: echoing sadness. Big Bells is preoccupied with failures
column7: emotional or otherwise: These are faithless laments
column8: dirges for the nights when your glass is empty and no one's coming over.

column1: Roberts' vocals (which contain all the cackle of J Mascis and all the plaintiveness of Townes Van Zandt) are tender and bruised
column2: and their smallness can be legitimately heartbreaking-- like on opener ""Somewhere to Run""
column3: where Roberts blithely offers himself as a kind of last-call solace (""I'll be a hand to hold/ If I'm just a drunk who can't be true
column4: he half-sings). Although folk music is frequently defined by its focus on narrative
column5: Roberts' lyrics can be purposefully ambiguous
column6: if not fully absurd (""I'm on a boat/ And if I only float
column7: he announces in ""Unspotted Clothes""). Still
column8: his oddball storytelling is unusually well-matched by his slow
column9: methodical strums
column10: and these songs move with purpose. The message is buried somewhere in all that empty space.

column1: ""Unspotted Clothes"" is the record's most unforgettable track
column2: and also its most intricately arranged. Roberts gives each syllable its own tragic weight
column3: while a bit of drum and piano complement his guitar; the results are wistful
column4: mysterious. The lingering ""Epcot Women"" showcases Roberts' penchant for fingerpicking
column5: with the crags of his voice providing a compelling counterpoint to the cleanness of his playing. There's only one misstep: ""Just Do It Blues"" contains a puzzling evocation (""Heavens to Betsy/ Nigger knocking at the door"")
column6: and if there's descriptive justification for the usage
column7: it's not entirely self-evident here.

column1: If pressed
column2: Roberts might flash a few Americana bona-fides-- he was born in Nashville
column3: but ran away from home to explore the U.S. via train
column4: settling
column5: for a while
column6: in Brooklyn-- but unlike the bulk of the contemporary Americana canon
column7: Big Bells is largely placeless. These songs are fiercely internal
column8: which also makes them remarkably hard to shake-- here
column9: Roberts is singing about the no-place of everyplace
column10:
the desolation we all know.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17225/homepage_large.c14d9588.jpg|Nothing EP|22489.0|Zomby|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2011-11-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:32.916150|"

Don't let the title or post-album late-year timing fool you-- there are plenty of good things happening on Nothing.  While it sounds like it was taken from the same creative burst that birthed London producer Zomby's recent LP Dedication
column2: here that album's glum funereality gets an almost dance-friendly makeover. With its classic-sounding jungle breaks and ragga vocal samples
column3: opener ""Labyrinth"" immediately recalls Zomby's vaguely conceptual throwback debut Where Were U in '92?
column4: though drenched in noir melancholy. The breaks stutter and sputter
column5: the perfunctory chord progression is oddly defeatist
column6: and the characteristic airhorns are mockingly empty and peripheral: Breakbeat 'ardkore never sounded this tormented.

column1: That's not to say Nothing isn't ever upbeat or danceable-- it's tinged with Dedication's air of quiet
column2: nocturnal introspection but not shackled by its thematic bent or album-oriented sequencing. Thus we get seven shades of Zomby
column3: and even if they're basically different shades of gray
column4: it's exciting to hear him branch out. He tries something new on the unusually dissolute ""Trapdoor""
column5: where grainy synths billow over scattershot percussion that has more to do with footwork than Zomby's usual hardcore continuum. ""Digital Fractal"" and ""Equinox"" take the pseudo-garage bounce of older tracks like ""Tarantula"" and turn it somber in two different ways: ""Fractal"" plays with dulcet
column6: mournful tones and shrouds its cycling arpeggios in reverb so they sound like they're off in the distance
column7: lost in a fog
column8: while the shimmering ""Equinox"" sucks that echo chamber dry
column9: all crisply slicing snares and tactile hand percussion. It's a brilliant realism often missing from an artist whose work is expressed through glassy
column10: artificial textures or borrowed tropes from extinct genres.

column1: Those extinct genres make a determined comeback on Nothing
column2: however
column3: and Zomby's take on them is stronger than ever. ""Sens"" toys gently with its breaks
column4: carefully placing them in the white space of a melody caught between jerky and jilted
column5: and ""Ecstasy Versions"" transitions from a hesitant breakbeat crawler into full-on jungle. Even here
column6: again Zomby's morose melodicism takes center stage
column7: a track more about its sadly cooing vocals-- a common sample source sullied and sullen-- and bleepy melody than the flashy
column8: distracting breaks that should be the center of attention. It's like he's proving once and for all that Where Were U in '92? wasn't just a transparent exercise
column9: blending his hardcore copycat tracks with his more personal
column10: idiosyncratic tendencies.

column1: The Nothing EP was originally included as an appendage to the Japanese edition of Dedication
column2: so it seems almost certain that these were leftovers from the album. But it says a lot about the strength of these tracks-- and Zomby's preternatural propensity for prolific greatness-- that the seven odds and sods on Nothing make for such a strong whole. It's not quite the sound of Zomby having fun-- this music is still too dark for that-- but it's Zomby being his usual tangential self again
column3: after bearing the constraints of a second cohesive album. He recently tweeted: ""jungle is going to come back hard
column4: mark my words
column5: it might be five years from now but we will witness a new great age of jungle in England."" This sounds like the excitable mouthing-off of a delusional purist
column6: but really
column7: with visionary artists like Zomby behind a potential new wave of the stuff
column8:
it's hard not to wonder if he could be right.

"|16086.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16086-nothing/|7.5|Andrew Ryce

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17227/homepage_large.9a800673.jpg|Live in New York|27519.0|Twilight Singers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Infernal']|2011-11-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:33.410780|"

If men are indeed pigs
column2: then Greg Dulli's body of work amounts to a veritable slaughterhouse. And yet
column3: his talent lies not only in his unwavering ability to deconstruct the male ego
column4: but also translating all that psychological tumult and turmoil into rapturous
column5: crowd-pleasing live entertainment.   Debuting in 2000 with an album produced by UK downtempo dons Fila Brazillia
column6: the Twilight Singers were initially conceived as a low-key counterpoint to Dulli's more frenetic previous band
column7: the Afghan Whigs. But over the past decade
column8: thanks to an ever-expanding and rotating cast of collaborators
column9: Dulli has effectively built up the Twilight Singers into a more elaborate rendering of the Afghan Whigs' rock-noir vision
column10: enhancing the cinematic quality of the Whigs' mid-1990s catalog and honoring their reputation for breathless
column11: soul-revue style performances that go on for hours. By feeding Dulli's unsavory songbook through all manner of medleys
column12: impromptu covers
column13: and crowd-participation gambits
column14: the Twilight Singers have essentially become the Bad Seeds by way of Prince-- emotional devastation you can dance to.

column1: All of which makes the Twilight Singers' first live album less of a stop-gap cash-grab than a long-overdue inevitability. And like the canonical
column2: career-making concert documents of the 1970s
column3: Live in New York-- recorded last May at Webster Hall
column4: on a Friday the 13th-- works both as a super-fan keepsake and a gateway for newcomers into Dulli's dense discography. The carefully plotted presentation and weighty nature of Twilight Singers albums-- not to mention Dulli's unvarnished
column5: raw rasp of a voice-- can make them a foreboding proposition for some
column6: but Live in New York eases the entry process with a representative sampling of high points from the band's five albums (albeit
column7: unsurprisingly
column8: with a particular emphasis on this year's Dynamite Steps) while giving shine to a quality not often heard on the band's recordings-- Dulli's gregarious personality
column9: which sees him eagerly playing the master of ceremonies to his own breakdown.

column1: Though Live in New York spreads 21 songs over two CDs (the digital version features only 19)
column2: it shows that Dulli essentially works in three modes: swaggering
column3: nocturnal rockers; desolate break-of-dawn ballads; and gradually intensifying epics that bridge the gap between the two. His gift as a performer thus lies in knowing when to deploy each. Unlike most live albums
column4: Live in New York's CD version presents a complete
column5: unedited concert
column6: but one with perfectly paced ebbs and flows
column7: as songs are radically rearranged and/or grouped together into seamless mini-suites. Dulli is especially aware of how his various songs can complement or even bolster one another through association-- early on
column8: the tension established by Dynamite Steps' slow-boiling ""Blackbird and the Fox"" explodes into a ferocious ""I'm Ready"" (off 2006's Powder Burns) as if they were two parts of the same song
column9: while the set hits a fever pitch two-thirds in with raging revamps of ""Love"" and ""Annie Mae"" (from 2000's Twilight as Played by the Twilight Singers) that highlight the crucial role of Rick Nelson's piano-pounding and Greg Wieczorek's crashing drums to the band's widescreen sound.

column1: Naturally
column2: this mixtape approach to his own discography extends to Dulli's incorporating quotes from other artists' work. Dulli's no stranger to recontextualizing innocent pop songs for more devious ends-- ""Forty Dollars"" shrewdly swipes lines from the Beatles' ""She Loves You"" and ""All You Need Is Love"" to depict a transaction with a prostitute-- but in concert
column3: this instinct goes into overdrive
column4: whether it's using Carl Carlton's 1970s soul classic ""Everlasting Love"" as the closing refrain on ""Esta Noche"" or dropping ""Hey Ya!""-inspired ""I'm just being honest"" ad libs in ""Forty Dollars"" (not to mention a snippet of the Whigs' ""Rebirth of the Cool"" on ""Never Seen No Devil""). Partway through Live In New York
column5: Dulli even interrupts one cover song (Martina Topley-Bird's ""Too Tough to Die""
column6: which is available only on the CD version) to start another
column7: as he slinks into the audience to lead a mass
column8: off-mic sing-along of Tom Petty's ""Breakdown"". Compared to Dulli's other acts of reappropriation
column9: the Petty theft initially seems less purposeful
column10: and more like frivolous
column11: crowd-baiting shtick. But
column12: in hearing how quickly the audience picks up on Dulli's lead
column13: it ultimately provides a perfect snapshot of how
column14: at a Twilight Singers show
column15: one man's anguish can so easily be elevated into communal
column16:
celebratory catharsis.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hideout']|2011-11-30 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:33.961200|"

Bait: Following this year's blindingly sunny Lupercalia and the clip for ""The City"" that had Patrick Wolf uncharacteristically gallivanting about on a Santa Monica beach
column3: the Brumalia EP sounds seasonally appropriate for its late-November release. Switch: It sounds more appropriate for the holiday season
column4: as opposed to the winter. Though there's incontrovertible proof that Wolf is long past trying to recreate the shadowy allure of his first two LPs
column5: I gotta admit to hoping he'd bundle up in black again to at least reconcile his pop impulses with the gothic
column6: brooding exaggerations of his youth. For the most part
column7: Brumalia-- which translates to ""festival of the shortest day""-- does let some blustery weather in
column8: but sonically
column9: it's on par with Lupercalia and The Bachelor
column10: so it's not barren trees and howling winds so much as ostentatious Christmas light fixtures in the pure
column11: driven snow.

column1: Whereas Lupercalia was inspired by the giddiness of a real-life romantic partnership
column2: Wolf sidesteps straight biography to reacquaint himself with instruments
column3: samples
column4: and memories he literally found lying around: A long-dormant theremin seeps through the stately pulse of ""Bitten""
column5: the percussion underpinning ""Nemoralia"" is cobbled together from news footage of London's summer riots
column6: the words of ""Jerusalem"" were adapted from William Blake
column7: while the confessional lyrics of ""Trust"" are straight from Wolf's diary. Though they're as lavishly produced as his proper records
column8: the little sonic footnotes and specificity give Brumalia a demo-level
column9: real-time immediacy that rarely comes through despite his gregarious persona.

column1: Problem is that it begs the question of how exactly to evaluate the positive effects of Wolf's over-sharing: Does prior knowledge of Brumalia's themes and history somehow lessen the value of its contents without it? Perhaps
column2: since rather than using its brevity as a means of cohesion
column3: Brumalia finds Wolf with a batch of songs unsure of what impression it wants to leave-- other than being a sonic appendage to Lupercalia
column4: itself an uneven record. That said
column5: ""Together"" is helped by its new context-- previously
column6: its plainspoken hook (""And I can do this alone/ But we can do this so much better... together"") felt like just another example of Wolf laying it on too thick
column7: but amidst Brumalia's facially darker lyrical content
column8: its contentment at least feels a bit more earned and its opulent disco pulse more striking. Meanwhile
column9: a see-sawing violin riff and an empathetic appraisal of addiction make ""Bitten"" as instantly ingratiating as recent Wolf singles such as ""The City"" or ""Accident & Emergency"" without the unctuous salesmanship.

column1: But like Lupercalia
column2: an auspicious and cohesive start gives way to Wolf sitting uneasily between the poles of his nocturnal mood-setting and major-key wooing. ""Pelicans"" is novel enough as Wolf's first iPad composition as well as a song with an overtly American geography
column3: but without the occasional landmark
column4: it's as turgid as the Florida swamps serving as its inspiration. Meanwhile
column5: centerpiece ""This Time of Year"" goes further into Kevin Rowland fixation
column6: but by trying to double as a Christmas card and an anti-war protest
column7: Wolf's pen strains way too hard to purple up lyrics like ""How many crosses more must we stigmata our soil with/ Until we reveal the blood on our hands?""

column1: And yet
column2: Wolf still remains at least theoretically fascinating because he tries too hard
column3: his artistic stumbles more often revealing a misdirection of ambition and talent than limitations. But is it just a matter of Wind in the Wires diehards not getting what they want? It's not that simple: Like Lupercalia
column4: Brumalia uses Wolf's own experience to craft something that's more sonically and thematically universal. And yet
column5: these supposed tensions don't end up feeling particularly tense or rife with possibility like Wolf's best work. As such
column6:
Brumalia ends up being as frustrating as his previous albums because Wolf appears capable of giving us anything to the point where comfort is not enough.

Bedroom-disco chanteuse Maria Minerva has put out four releases this year
column2: the most recent of which was called Cabaret Cixous
column3: after the French post-structuralist feminist theorist Hélène Cixous. Given the facts that generally circulate about Minerva
column4: aka Maria Juur-- she studied cultural theory
column5: she is interested in deconstructing ideas about female sexuality
column6: she reads books-- it's easy to imagine that the fourth track on her new Sacred & Profane Love EP
column7: ""Another Time and Place""
column8: takes its name from a semi-obscure philosophical tract
column9: à la John Maus' We Must Become the Pitiless Censors of Ourselves. Actually
column10: it's Britney Spears. Over the track's pulsating
column11: murky beat
column12: Maria lifts a question Spears posed in 2001's ""I'm a Slave 4 U"": ""Baby
column13: don't you wanna dance up on me/ Until another time and place?"" Sacred & Profane Love is Minerva's most immediate release yet
column14: but it picks up on her other records' ideas: Her music is a place where academia and pop culture
column15: tastefulness and excess
column16: dominance and submission
column17: and yes
column18: Hélène Cixous and Britney Spears
column19: all commingle in a hazy
column20: libidinous swirl.

column1: The EP's centerpiece is the terrific ""Gloria""
column2: a hypnagogic earworm about corporeal and spiritual bliss: ""Darling
column3: when you touch me/ I feel like I've been touched by the hands of God."" Lest the title deceive you
column4: know that we're a long way from Patti Smith's gravely barroom stomp: This ""Gloria"" swoons and ripples like a reflection in water. Another clear highlight is ""Turn Me On (Working on Full Powwa)""
column5: which features a playful
column6: muffled vocal and a driving beat. The bookends ""A Love So Strong"" and the closing reprise ""Luv So Strong"" aren't quite as compelling but they add a cohesion to the EP's atmosphere
column7: making Sacred & Profane feel like an ecstatic
column8: 30-minute journey to another time and place-- one that makes even familiar pop lyrics distend like musings on power relations and time travel.

column1: Minerva's music remains rough around the edges
column2: and some listeners might wish she'd appropriate the clarity of the more mainstream pop that inspires her-- but that's clearly not her aim. ""I'm exploring the idea of the 'female loser
column3: '"" Minerva has said about her conceptual approach. You get the feeling you've heard Taylor Swift or the dude behind LonelyGirl15 say the exact same thing
column4: but what's so refreshing about Minerva's sound-- along with that of artists like Grimes or U.S. Girls
column5: who are also using DIY dance music to make comments about femininity and alienation in the digital age-- is that it bespeaks a sense of isolation and anxiety that feels refreshingly
column6: and even unsettlingly
column7: authentic. Still
column8: even though it's true to her aesthetic
column9:
Sacred & Profane Love certainly feels like a progression. It's the first of her releases on which the impulse to think or feel takes a backseat-- more than anything this is a record that wants to see you move.

Privately pressed records can be dodgy propositions; if you've ever tittered at a high school marching band's LP
column3: or wondered about that bearded
column4: bespectacled
column5: finger-picking guy pictured on the back of a hand-drawn sleeve from the early 1970s while thumbing the dollar bin of a record store
column6: you know this to be the case. At their absolute worst
column7: these self-published albums are tin-eared things (and invariably tied to local parishes). A select few-- like the kind of Midwest soul and funk oddities that the mindful reissue Numero label constantly unearths-- are redeemable listens. Yet only a few private-press records ever offer portals into alternate realities.

column1: That west coast Yoga Records imprint mostly dabbles in the latter
column2: be it Traveler's Advisory
column3: the beguiling hammer dulcimer-drum machine album from Matthew Young or Ted Lucas' lonesome and stoned folk album. So it's no question that the peculiar strain of heavy metal that Duane Warr recorded to a Tascam eight-track in 1984 while living inside his trailer in Columbia
column4: South Carolina
column5: is a portal to another realm. Dwarr
column6: the one-man band of Warr's
column7: goes to a dark alley in the psyche that few ever feel the need to wander
column8: much less record and overdub-- crafting hand-drawn album art as well as homemade videos for certain songs (not to mention pressing up and distributing
column9: only to be unable to sell them). Warr home-recorded and self-released both 1984's oddly-titled debut Starting Over and 1986's Animals
column10: before a divorce and spiritually harrowing time led to a breakdown and to Warr's becoming a born-again Christian.

column1: With a continued fascination with Norwegian black metal
column2: it makes sense that a rarity such as Dwarr should blip back for recent metal converts. Last year
column3: Yoga (in conjunction with Drag City) re-released Animals
column4: which
column5: despite having a cannibal-populated landscape for a cover
column6: sank without much fanfare. Now follows Starting Over
column7: which is
column8: alas
column9: the weaker of the two albums. Dwarr's records are harrowing experiences
column10: both in their tone and listenability
column11: but despite a visual and aural aspect that seems to forecast doom and black metal
column12: Dwarr never feels quite that dark and depraved. Despite what it predicts for the future of metal
column13: it's genealogy still consists of Deep Purple
column14: Pink Floyd
column15: Tarkus
column16: and Black Sabbath.

column1: From the looks of Starting Over-- whose cover art exists somewhere between Planet of the Apes' Statue of Liberty
column2: The Shining's flood of blood
column3: and whatever that hesher in your high school art class used to always draw on looseleaf-- this should be an evil
column4: teenage suicide-enabling shredder record of the highest echelon. Only
column5: in the greater scheme of things
column6: Dwarr's music isn't like that. While electric guitar shredding is the focus
column7: this isn't satanic
column8: apocalyptic doom heavy metal-- in its weird warped way
column9: it's Christian folk.

column1: The greatest example of Dwarr and his particular kind of genius can be found in the video he shot and edited himself for ""Screams of Terror""
column2: the second song on Starting Over. It conveys his gifts more than making the music can. What else can be genuinely campy and haunting
column3: then campy again
column4: but then bone-chilling by video's end? ""You know you're going straight to hell/ And if you don't straighten your life/ You'll have an endless plight
column5: Warr intones on the lugubrious
column6: doorbell-chimed tune
column7: delivering his lyrics in that portentous Roger Waters whisper. Its early lines invoke that dread children feel in the dark
column8: but Warr's lyrics ultimately veer towards a pat Christian morality
column9: despite the monsters and skull paint. Even if at this phase of his life he's only into the damnation and sulfur parts of the Bible
column10: returning to his religion seems inevitable in hindsight.

column1: He cites the Book of Job directly on the brooding ""Job's Revenge""
column2: though ""brooding"" isn't much of a descriptor when it could describe every aspect of the music. Here he reads from Job 5:2-9 during breaks from a 12-bar blues melody with a rote guitar solo on top. Too often
column3: Warr delivers his lines and plays his parts without much variance. The best moments of the album come when Warr is at his most overt in his worship of Black Sabbath (rather than trying to conjure the ghost of Randy Rhoads via his Eddie Van Halen splatter guitar)
column4: as he does on ""Cannabinol: the Elation"". Only on furious closer ""I've Been Thinking""
column5:
where Warr's guitar cops the ""Sweet Leaf"" power chords and Ozzy's strangulated voice can one imagine a world where a heavy metal god isn't turned into a reality show punchline.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17233/homepage_large.4ee9b846.jpg|The Singles Collection 2001-2011|1767.0|Gorillaz|['Rock'
column3: Gorillaz; you have been a complete failure. Only by the terms of your original premise
column4: mind you
column5: which promised to be the sort of multimedia
column6: multi-platform
column7: multi-everything project that seemed like a real good idea circa Y2K. The novelty of the core Gorillaz gimmick-- an edgy
column8: anime Banana Splits that gave interviews in character and played high-tech projection live shows in place of their creators
column9: Damon Albarn and Jamie Hewlett-- wore off sometime around the group's third video. But in a surprise upset
column10: Gorillaz have evolved into something more than a cartoon prank or a circus-of-stars side-project
column11: instead becoming the most effective achievement of Albarn's post-Blur career.

column1: Though a singles collection in 2011 is as anachronistic as the DVD-ROMs in the early Gorillaz back catalog
column2: this one makes an excellent case for the substance behind the expired high concept of the ""virtual band."" The decade covered here marked a mercurial time for Albarn
column3: who celebrated the hiatus of Blur by eagerly shooting off in a dozen different directions. It was almost as though he set out to tick off every clichéd solo career path simultaneously: jamming melodica with musicians in Mali and the Congo
column4: creating a remixer persona
column5: putting together his fantasy-dub supergroup <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/artists/27585-the-good-the-bad-the-queen/"" target=""_blank"">the Good
column6: the Bad & the Queen
column7: and exploring opera and film scoring.

column1: Gorillaz is far and away the most successful of these projects at the cash register
column2: selling millions of records worldwide
column3: headlining Glastonbury and Coachella
column4: and holographically sharing a Grammys stage with Madonna. The group's artistic success has also kept pace with its commercial success
column5: giving Albarn a way to combine most of his musical distractions into an oddly cohesive whole. In retrospect
column6: the key to the project may have been enabling Albarn to abandon the frontman role and become the man behind the curtain
column7: both figuratively and (up until recent live shows) literally. If you don't think that hiding place isn't therapeutic for Albarn
column8: consider that Think Tank
column9: the 2003 Blur album that essentially became an Albarn solo joint
column10: also attempted to blend all of these interests
column11: to less satisfying results.

column1: Taking the greatest-hits route through Gorillaz's career
column2: it's impressive how few of the tracks sound dated. Genre-free zones were all the rage in 2001
column3: with many groups aiming for futuristic blends of hip-hop
column4: electronic
column5: pop
column6: and rock that sounded past their sell-by within a year. But apart from the Deltron 3030 sequel of ""Rock the House"" and the tacky remixes filling out this collection's runtime
column7: even the earliest Gorillaz singles have avoided the erosion to retro.

column1: Credit an inspirational assist to Hewlett: His music-cliché characters may not have been able to sustain a satire or a storyline
column2: but his trademark post-apocalyptic techno-dread was a suitable environmental muse for the urban Morricone that became the Gorillaz formula. And a surprisingly flexible formula it turned out to be
column3: able to assimilate guest appearances as varied as the artisan-rap of De La Soul
column4: the garble of Shaun Ryder
column5: and the elder croon of Bobby Womack. Off the mic
column6: Albarn found fruitful collaborations with producers-du-jour Dan the Automator and Danger Mouse
column7: borrowing ideas without contaminating the project's core aesthetic.

column1: Behind the protective screen of his invited guests
column2: Albarn used Gorillaz to find a new voice both as a songwriter and a vocalist. There's an unbroken evolutionary line connecting ""Tomorrow Comes Today"" to ""On Melancholy Hill""
column3: and it's got an upward slope-- the latter is a moody-pop masterpiece that would sound completely foreign on any Blur LP. The strictly singles format makes this collection an unbalanced summary
column4: with arguably the weakest LP (2005's Demon Days) given the largest representation. But in its synthesis of Albarn's post-Blur interests
column5: it's a fairly accurate snapshot of a busy decade for the singer
column6:
where he ironically found mid-life maturity inside a cartoon world.

""I changed the rap game
column2: and a lot of people know that-- a lot of rappers know that
column3: says Lil B at the end of BasedGod Velli. The boast comes shortly after he's thrown out a revealing
column4: eyebrow-raising jab: ""I'm the reason you got your deal
column5: bitch
column6: A$AP.""  The line
column7: and the fact that it's clearly true
column8: says a lot about Lil B's unique perch in rap: Without ever abandoning the fringe
column9: he's changed the mainstream conversation enough that rappers like A$AP Rocky can score six-figure signings in part by copping B's producers and calling themselves ""pretty"" like he does. But Lil B isn't your standard neglected innovator
column10: grousing in interviews about more successful rappers stealing his style: He's more popular than ever
column11: still constantly retweeting requests from young girls begging him to ""fuck my bitches."" For a cult rapper with no record deal
column12: the extent of his influence is astonishing.

column1: BasedGod Velli and The Silent President
column2: both released in the past month
column3: will scan to most onlookers like Just More Lil B Mixtapes. It's an impression he doesn't always exactly work overtime to dismiss: After he ignited an Internet firestorm last summer with his lovely
column4: dazed I'm Gay
column5: he followed it up with I Forgive You
column6: a dare-you-to-get-through-it teeth-gritter that worked like bug spray to anyone who'd just climbed on board. But while they lack the unifying-moment ring of I'm Gay
column7: BasedGod Velli and Silent President are both strong entries into the massive
column8: bewildering Lil B canon. If you sit somewhere in the middle of the Lil B-obsessive spectrum
column9: here's the shorthand: You probably need one or both of these.

column1: BasedGod Velli gets the edge over President
column2: for focus and quality of production. The cover
column3: which splits his face with Pac's
column4: Face/Off-style
column5: might get a half-hearted rise out of some rap traditionalists somewhere
column6: but it's difficult by now to imagine many of those types still being undecided about Lil B. He opens the tape up addressing this crowd: ""Niggas talk about 'Lil B done killed rap'/ Stupid bitch
column7: man
column8: I brought the rap game back."" After that
column9: he doesn't waste time defending himself against anyone. The rest of the tape is high-quality #based music
column10: nothing more
column11: nothing less.

column1: Lil B is in open-hearted truth-teller mode on Velli: there are no gangsta-rap or pimp-rap exercises. At his best
column2: Lil B uses his positivity like a blunt-force object
column3: clearing out his lane in front of him with the heat of his convictions. Witness this remarkable tirade
column4: also from the title track: ""It ain't hard to smoke weed and go tote gats/ It ain't hard to pimp hos
column5: man you lame for that/ It ain't hard to rob a nigga at close range/ Much harder to go outside and use your brain/ Much harder to go to college and go get grades/ Much harder to get a job to go feed your seed/ Real easy to give up and go complain.""

column1: This passage bears all the scuff marks of Lil B's without-a-net style-- it's artless
column2: it's fumbling
column3: the lines barely connect with a rhyming syllable at the end-- but it's a remarkable outpouring nonetheless. ""King Cotton""
column4: which borrows the instrumental from Raekwon and Ghostface's ""Heaven & Hell""
column5: is another highlight
column6: a touching lament framed in the simplest and most direct possible of terms: ""How the fuck can I forget about the people hangin' off a tree/ For the simple fact they look like me?"" Those who write off B's style as mindless rambling could spend a chastening few hours watching other rappers' attempts at ""based"" freestyle: B's gift for turning up startling language inside himself with little to no preparation is uncanny.

column1: Silent President is less rewarding and more scattershot than BasedGod Velli. The beat selection and production are lower in quality
column2: and B's real-time fumbling for words occasionally grows outright distracting. But there are some welcome moments: ""Great China Sea"" repurposes the only bit of Watch the Throne's ""Lift Off"" beat worth keeping-- the smooth coda-- and turns it into a parade of softly glowing Christmas lights for B to rap over. On ""The Based One""
column3: he warbles over DJ Khaled/Drake/Rick Ross/Lil Wayne's ""I'm on One"". ""Cap Pillah"" and ""BasedGod 50"" are highly entertaining examples of ignorant Lil B
column4: with gun threats and non-sequiturs thrown out over linoleum-curling beats.

column1: As usual
column2: both tapes have moments of sheer irredeemable silliness: On President's ""Beat the Cancer""
column3: he raps over a sped-up loop of Metallica's ""Fade to Black"" and dedicates it to a terminally ill YouTube follower who requested it of him. It's a nice personal gesture but a profoundly ridiculous song (the chorus is ""beat the cancer
column4: cancer."") Ditto for BasedGod Velli's ""I Got AIDS""
column5: which doubles down on Lil B's personal spit-take title sweepstakes and offers a message song so bluntly literal it inspires mostly disbelieving laughs (""on top of that
column6: she gave me herpes when she gave me AIDS!""). What makes them work
column7: though
column8: is their place within the larger Lil B world: His pratfalls are offered up with the same fearless generosity as his triumphs. Without them
column9: we wouldn't feel the audacity of his creative high-wire act. They're the price of entry into Based World
column10:
which is still a pretty transformative place to spend some time.

column5: man you lame for that/ It ain't hard to rob a nigga at close range/ Much harder to go outside and use your brain/ Much harder to go to college and go get grades/ Much harder to get a job to go feed your seed/ Real easy to give up and go complain.""

column1: This passage bears all the scuff marks of Lil B's without-a-net style-- it's artless
column2: it's fumbling
column3: the lines barely connect with a rhyming syllable at the end-- but it's a remarkable outpouring nonetheless. ""King Cotton""
column4: which borrows the instrumental from Raekwon and Ghostface's ""Heaven & Hell""
column5: is another highlight
column6: a touching lament framed in the simplest and most direct possible of terms: ""How the fuck can I forget about the people hangin' off a tree/ For the simple fact they look like me?"" Those who write off B's style as mindless rambling could spend a chastening few hours watching other rappers' attempts at ""based"" freestyle: B's gift for turning up startling language inside himself with little to no preparation is uncanny.

column1: Silent President is less rewarding and more scattershot than BasedGod Velli. The beat selection and production are lower in quality
column2: and B's real-time fumbling for words occasionally grows outright distracting. But there are some welcome moments: ""Great China Sea"" repurposes the only bit of Watch the Throne's ""Lift Off"" beat worth keeping-- the smooth coda-- and turns it into a parade of softly glowing Christmas lights for B to rap over. On ""The Based One""
column3: he warbles over DJ Khaled/Drake/Rick Ross/Lil Wayne's ""I'm on One"". ""Cap Pillah"" and ""BasedGod 50"" are highly entertaining examples of ignorant Lil B
column4: with gun threats and non-sequiturs thrown out over linoleum-curling beats.

column1: As usual
column2: both tapes have moments of sheer irredeemable silliness: On President's ""Beat the Cancer""
column3: he raps over a sped-up loop of Metallica's ""Fade to Black"" and dedicates it to a terminally ill YouTube follower who requested it of him. It's a nice personal gesture but a profoundly ridiculous song (the chorus is ""beat the cancer
column4: cancer."") Ditto for BasedGod Velli's ""I Got AIDS""
column5: which doubles down on Lil B's personal spit-take title sweepstakes and offers a message song so bluntly literal it inspires mostly disbelieving laughs (""on top of that
column6: she gave me herpes when she gave me AIDS!""). What makes them work
column7: though
column8: is their place within the larger Lil B world: His pratfalls are offered up with the same fearless generosity as his triumphs. Without them
column9: we wouldn't feel the audacity of his creative high-wire act. They're the price of entry into Based World
column10:
which is still a pretty transformative place to spend some time.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17221/homepage_large.23d60612.jpg|I'm Still in the Night EP|27383.0|Salem|['Metal'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['IAMSOUND']|2011-11-29 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:36.924630|"

Remember these guys? Following Salem's conversation-starting debut album
column3: last year's King Night
column4: they embarked on a headlining U.S. tour; counted Courtney Love and Liv Tyler as celebrity hangers-on/onlookers (respectively); posed for some stylish pictures that revealed band member Heather Marlatt's pregnancy; made a meaningless video for King Night's title track with Jann Wenner's son Theo; offered a horrible Britney Spears remix; and gave a performance at this year's Primavera Sound festival in Barcelona that made their infamous 2010 SXSW appearance sound like Live Rust by comparison.

column1: But whatever you think of King Night
column2: the album is still the definitive version of the often imitated sound that Salem brought on the scene. The proper full-length follow-up to King Night is due some time in 2012
column3: and there have been rumors that Salem are pursuing a different direction for the record; the band's latest EP
column4: I'm Still in the Night
column5: carries no indication that they're trying to branch out.

column1: True to its title
column2: the four-track EP mostly feels like a collection of songs that didn't make the LP's cut. I'm Still in the Night is more polished in terms of production
column3: from the clipped howls that open the EP to the acid-rain synths of ""Baby Ratta""
column4: and it includes a seven-minute cover of electronic pop collective Alice DeeJay's immortal 1998 trance anthem ""Better Off Alone"". The cover doesn't come close to matching the original (what does?)
column5: but there's something perversely appealing about Salem draping a simplistic ""why won't you give your love to me"" anthem in their own dingy
column6: smirking
column7: loner outlook. Mercifully
column8: Salem forgo Jack Donoghue's mush-mouthed rapping until I'm Still in the Night's closing track
column9: ""Krawl""
column10: which finds him rambling about Slurpees
column11: global warming
column12: and how ""your bitch
column13: she could suck a dick for me."" True to form
column14: it's repugnant on any number of levels.

column1: So
column2: loud synths
column3: eye-roll-inducing rapping
column4: and more clattering drum machines than you'd find on a footwork compilation-- yes
column5: I'm Still in the Night is more of the same. If you follow along enough to check it out
column6: it offers a predictable mix of what they do well and where they go wrong
column7: but it's also easy to ignore. Which
column8: for a band that thrives on controversy
column9:
is a sign of trouble.

Even if you've never heard a single note from the Louvin Brothers
column2: odds are good that you've at least seen the cover of their 1959 album
column3: Satan Is Real. The discrepancy between that emphatic title and that plywood demon landed it on countless lists of worst or weirdest album covers
column4: usually alongside Paddy Roberts' Songs for Gay Dogs and Orleans' Waking and Dreaming. Charlie and Ira Louvin devised the concept for the artwork themselves and set everything up in an old quarry
column5: cutting Satan from Charlie's son's miniature train table and filling old tires with kerosene to simulate Hell. Then
column6: as if on some Biblical cue
column7: it began to rain
column8: so their poses were hurried and awkward so their white suits wouldn't get drenched. Still
column9: as silly as it may be
column10: there's something curious about that image
column11: especially that folk art figure looming in the background
column12: bucktoothed and cross-eyed. It doesn't look professional or polished
column13: which fits the music: The Louvin Brothers may have been signed to Capitol
column14: but like so many other rural artists who never settled comfortably into either secular or gospel
column15: they still sound both compellingly raw and incredibly sophisticated.

column1: Satan Is Real is the duo's best-known record
column2: not only for its cover but for songs like ""The Christian Life"" and ""The Kneeling Drunkard's Plea""
column3: famously covered by the Byrds and Johnny Cash
column4: respectively. Will Ferrell even incorporated the title track into his one-man show
column5: <i><a href=""http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1386011/"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">You're Welcome
column6: America: A Final Night with George W. Bush. The album represents a shift from secular to religious music after several years away
column7: and yet the Louvin Brothers weren't necessarily trading one for the other. Like Johnny Cash or even Elvis Presley
column8: they blended popular and church music to amplify the qualities of the other. ""There's a Higher Power"" snaps back and forth in a spirited call and response
column9: but it's the shuffling snare that drive those exultant shouts of ""Amen!"" Similarly
column10: the piano that pushes ""The River of Jordan"" along its freighted path belongs more to the barrelhouse than the revival tent.

column1: The Louvin Brothers
column2: despite being brothers and such naturalistic harmonizers
column3: were spiritually and temperamentally mismatched
column4: which may explain the equal emphasis they placed on darkness and light. Charlie adhered strictly to the message of these songs and was likely the guiding force behind Satan Is Real
column5: but Ira was an angry drunk who routinely smashed mandolins on stage and showed up late to concerts. He was shot twice by a wife who claimed he beat her
column6: and he allegedly tried to strangle Presley
column7: whose big beat Ira saw as an affront to country music. Those extremes reflected in their music
column8: at least until Charlie broke up the act and
column9: in a grim irony
column10: Ira was killed by a drunk driver in 1965.

column1: Their entire catalog devises a seemingly contradictory mix of the holy and the worldly
column2: the sacred and the profane. How could an act that revels in ""The Christian Life"" turn around and sing a dire murder ballad like ""Knoxville Girl""
column3: whose grisly details still provoke winces even half a century after they sang it? To the Louvins' understanding
column4: man's boundless capacity for sin matched his boundless capacity for salvation
column5: so they weren't simply going to nudge you along the righteous path; they were going to run you off the highway to hell. ""Satan Is Real"" sets the tone and the churchly tableau
column6: as the brothers harmonize on a hymnal chorus before Charlie interrupts with a monologue reminiscent of Hank Williams' Luke the Drifter homilies. ""You can hear him in the songs that give praise to idols and sinful things of this world
column7: he declares of the devil. ""You can see him in the destruction of homes torn apart."" It's a scare tactic
column8: yet the brothers' precise vocals and Ira's always agile picking lends the song an urgency and gravity
column9: as though they might be that deeply invested in their listeners' faith.

column1: These songs may kill off dear mothers
column2: struggling drunkards
column3: debased sinners
column4: and even innocent little babies
column5: but Satan Is Real somehow conveys jubilation rather than penance
column6: which is likely what inspired 60s country rockers like the Byrds and the Dillards and continues to bear on so many artists today. To that end
column7: Light in the Attic is jointly issuing Handpicked Songs 1955-1962
column8: a compilation of Louvin Brothers songs chosen by musicians representing several generations: Dolly Parton
column9: Chris Hillman
column10: and Kris Kristofferson
column11: as well as Beck
column12: Jim James
column13: and M. Ward
column14: among others. On CD
column15: the sets are packaged together; on vinyl
column16: they're available separately (there's also a vinyl-only reissue of their 1956 LP Tragic Songs of Life).

column1: Sonically
column2: vinyl is the better option
column3: but musically
column4: the 2xCD edition provides a better introduction to the Louvin Brothers. Perhaps because it's set so irremovably in the church
column5: Satan Is Real may not be their most accessible album
column6: which means Handpicked Songs makes for a livelier complement than outtakes or live performances and allows for a secular counterpart to the sacred music. It reaches beyond their hits to unearth some deeper catalog cuts like the spry ""Low and Lonely"" (chosen by Jim James) and the loping ""Scared of the Blues"" (chosen by Devendra Banhart)
column7: which reveal the scope of their songwriting
column8: the agility of Ira's mandolin playing
column9: and the exuberance of their keening harmonies. Especially for an album produced by committee
column10: Handpicked argues persuasively for the Louvins' relevance long after rock'n'roll supposedly rendered their music obsolete. Even at a time when so many church-bred artists were exploring more worldly markets
column11:
the struggle between salvation and damnation has rarely sounded so lively or so gloriously conflicted.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17234/homepage_large.d6ad8107.jpg|Classic|2960.0|M.E.D.|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2011-11-29 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:38.147803|"

M.E.D. is the rap equivalent of a middle-relief pitcher asked to go eight innings. He's left his mark in small doses on Madlib-produced tracks-- Lootpack's ""Level Zero"" and ""Wanna Test""; Quasimoto's ""24-7""; Madvillain's ""Raid""-- but his 2005 full-length debut Push Comes to Shove revealed his limitations in short order. He's never been the most distinguishable member of the Stones Throw camp
column2: for good or for bad: The same thing that's kept him from setting himself apart has also generally kept him from the embarrassments that happen when an MC's ambition outstrips his inspiration. He just punches the clock
column3: drops in for 14 tracks
column4: then punches out again
column5: rapping like a man who keeps his head down and just goes through the motions
column6: as though doing otherwise would get him fired.

column1: That the title is the most egregious thing about Classic is something of a minor relief
column2: though it's also a good way to bait critics looking for something else to say about an album without much personality to it. (I'll bite: ""more like Adequate."") The usual themes come up in his lyrics-- sex (""JWF"")
column3: weed (""Medical Card"")
column4: regional pride (""Where I'm From"")-- and the common universality of his experiences and perspectives on these well-worn topics are relatable at the expense of being actually unique. Occasionally he'll hit on something like ""Blaxican""
column5: which conflates the parallel civil rights struggles in his background
column6: and leaves you wondering just what more he might have to say outside the confines of his indistinct lyrical style.

column1: But it's M.E.D.'s emphasis on technique over everything else that holds this album back. His voice is largely flat and affectless
column2: letting the words do all the work of selling an attitude that should otherwise come through in inflections. And those words don't carry enough weight on their own; there's so much reliance on internal rhymes and assonance in his style that he's sacrificed being quotable for being listenable. But he's at least got a delivery that fuses well to the beat and doesn't get in the way of the production enough to detract from it-- sometimes
column3: it's the other way around
column4: as when a sampled vocal drop on closer ""Magical Mystical"" actually drowns him out mid-verse. (By that point
column5: it's hard to feel like you've missed something.)

column1: In situations like this
column2: it's best to approach an album at this level as a sort of beat tape with added vocal augmentation. A lot of Classic's appeal comes from the heavy Madlib involvement
column3: and his productions here work well as a tidied-up take on the resin-caked density of his latter-day Medicine Show and Beat Konducta entries. The Tesla-coil keyboards of Kurupt/Planet Asia-featuring subwoofer anthem ""Roll Out"" and the stripped-down
column4: dirtied-up drums on Hodgy Beats collab ""Outta Control"" are key highlights. For good measure you can throw in a tension-building violin-tinged Alchemist beat on ""War & Love""
column5: Oh No delivering no-bullshit choppy organ funk on ""Where I'm From""
column6: Karriem Riggins wringing some nice belated summer vibes off the jazz guitar-driven title track
column7: and Georgia Anne Muldrow injecting her eccentric but richly realized neo-soul sensibility into ""INT'L"". It's another solid case study in what makes the Stones Throw aesthetic so appealing to the traditionalist-meets-futurist indie-rap crossover crowd. That sound just has a lot of blanks to fill in: The MC shortened his name from Medaphor to an acronym a long time ago
column8:
but it's still not clear whether M.E.D. actually stands for anything.
