column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17202/homepage_large.ce32334f.jpg|Gish [Deluxe Edition]|3838.0|The Smashing Pumpkins|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['EMI']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:38.677127|"

I remember reading a desert-island-albums list by Billy Corgan in 1993 that was so scarily like my own musical arc-- pop/prog/metal nerd discovers goth
column2: Jane's Addiction
column3: and My Bloody Valentine-- that I couldn't have been more designed for Smashing Pumpkins hyperfandom if I tried. Like no one before him
column4: Corgan made those influences work. As Canadian writer Jennifer Nine once put it in Melody Maker
column5: you got a sense that he was the kind of guy who worked out every last transcription from Guitar Player in the 1980s and then actually did something with it. It helped that the rest of the band had their own skills
column6: especially in the case of Jimmy Chamberlin
column7: a jazz/hard-rock drum freak let loose on alt-rock radio.

column1: Alt-rock radio
column2: at its height of commercial trendsetting
column3: enabled the Pumpkins to not merely survive but thrive. There
column4: Corgan could have his cake and eat it too
column5: daring people to get annoyed at his starlust and reacting in kind while further building up his ambitions. He got his band signed to a major label and used the fig leaf of a corporate indie release for Gish
column6: scored a prime spot on the Seattle-focused Singles soundtrack with ""Drown""
column7: essentially went ""Haters gonna hate"" with Siamese Dream's first single ""Cherub Rock""
column8: and got petulant when any other acts or writers accused him of protesting too much. And not just Pavement
column9: either: ""You hurt me deeply in my heart
column10: he once infamously pouted to Kim Thayil before a 1994 Australian concert
column11: following which the Pumpkins went on ""to play the best set anybody has ever heard them play.""

column1: All of which goes some distance toward explaining why both reissues of Gish and Siamese Dream-- appropriately loaded with rarities
column2: DVD bonuses
column3: fancy packaging
column4: and often-impressionistic song-for-song liner notes by Corgan-- remain remarkable though unequal listens. Even in 1991
column5: Gish felt like something that started off well with songs like ""Siva"" and ""Rhinoceros"" but meandered a bit toward the end. Corgan's voice never sounded as lost in his music as it does here
column6: and most of the emphasis is on the band's collective performance: Chamberlin's powerful
column7: fluid drumming
column8: Darcy Wretzky's strong basslines
column9: and that thick
column10: chunky glaze of guitars.

column1: The rarities disc contains a few never-before-heard numbers
column2: a few that have long circulated among fanatics (the Corgan-sung version of ""Daydream"" is a keeper)
column3: and a handful of remixed selections (including their best full-on rock epic
column4: ""Starla"") that first surfaced on a full-length release via the odds-and-ends release Pisces Iscariot. These tracks do a better job of showcasing the band's various sonic sides than Gish itself. The DVD
column5: a multi-camera cut from a live show at the Metro in Chicago almost a year prior to Gish's release
column6: shows that the band already had their exact arrangements pretty well down
column7: as well as a worshipping fanbase. The highlights include Corgan and James Iha's heavily long hair
column8: curious fashion choices all around
column9: and set-closing covers of Steppenwolf and Blue Öyster Cult; the video quality is pretty good and the sound mix
column10: if heavily favoring the vocals
column11: beats out most bootlegs of the time.

column1: In contrast to Gish's steady flow
column2: Siamese Dream crashes out of the gate. ""Cherub Rock"" remains an absolutely stellar opener with a sense of pure sonic melodrama
column3: thanks to Chamberlin's circus-act drum introduction
column4: a tight clip of guitars quickly matched by equally nimble bass
column5: a volcanic blast of a guitar lead
column6: and then a shift to a woozy
column7: still-building sprawl. And all this before the first verse even starts. Throw in everything that followed-- the overt MBV worship of ""Hummer""
column8: the country-rock-tinged wanderlust of ""Mayonaise""
column9: ""Soma""'s update of Prince's ""The Beautiful Ones"" for a new decade
column10: and inevitably the MTV/radio hits ""Today""
column11: ""Disarm""
column12: and ""Rocket""-- and no matter your take on its mastermind or his divisive whining/sighing vocals
column13: it's an embarrassment of musical riches.

column1: There's also the fact that the album's studio personnel was as essentially stripped down as the White Stripes; Corgan
column2: frantically taking charge in the midst of band dysfunction
column3: recorded nearly everything himself aside from the drums
column4: and he'd probably have handled those too if he could. Siamese Dream's songs don't blend into each other
column5: but some transitions exist; each stands out in a brilliant sequence
column6: forming perhaps the best concept album they ever made.

column1: One of the main things people complained about was exactly what made the band click even further. If Corgan's early lyrics were classic self-centered/self-righteous/self-pitying teenagerdom run amock
column2: he always had an ear for hooks
column3: metaphors
column4: and deft summaries (thus
column5: on ""Mayonaise"": ""Fool enough to almost be it/ Cool enough to not quite see it""). It's catnip for when you have it bad
column6: no matter how minuscule your problems might really be
column7: and any number of later bands (My Chemical Romance most obviously
column8: and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart most recently) took plenty of notice.

column1: As for the many rarities
column2: more Pisces Iscariot remixes and other demos and alternate versions take a bow
column3: including a six-minute version of ""Siamese Dream"" itself (the original B-side version was a shorter and murkier take that ran under three minutes) and twin instrumentals ""U.S.A."" and ""U.S.S.R."". The DVD is the most worthwhile addition of either reissue; taken from another Metro show a couple of weeks after Siamese Dream's release
column4: it vividly illustrates how far the band had come in the three years since Gish: It showcases their more varied sound
column5: Corgan's keener sense for playing to the crowd (there are flashes of his and Iha's underrated sense of humor)
column6: a killer setlist drawing on both albums (plus ""Starla"" and ""Drown"")
column7: and brilliant sound and performances throughout. If Corgan's voice shows strain at many points
column8: the crowd shots are especially entertaining
column9: with endless moshpits and crowdsurfers during most of the loud points and plenty of the slow ones.

column1: The full story of the band's existence has plenty of ups and downs to go through
column2: and there are more reissues to come to spell this out
column3: even as the current version of the band moves along according to Corgan's own cryptic impulses. Yet these two releases still resonate
column4: as both a nostalgia fix underscoring how it was so easy to fall for Smashing Pumpkins in the first place
column5:
and as the best introductions to their music any newcomer could want.

"|16059.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16059-gish-deluxe-edition-siamese-dream-deluxe-edition/|8.3|Ned Raggett

column1:
1|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17203/homepage_large.c7e7bffb.jpg|Siamese Dream [Deluxe Edition]|3838.0|The Smashing Pumpkins|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['EMI']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:38.677127|"

I remember reading a desert-island-albums list by Billy Corgan in 1993 that was so scarily like my own musical arc-- pop/prog/metal nerd discovers goth
column2: Jane's Addiction
column3: and My Bloody Valentine-- that I couldn't have been more designed for Smashing Pumpkins hyperfandom if I tried. Like no one before him
column4: Corgan made those influences work. As Canadian writer Jennifer Nine once put it in Melody Maker
column5: you got a sense that he was the kind of guy who worked out every last transcription from Guitar Player in the 1980s and then actually did something with it. It helped that the rest of the band had their own skills
column6: especially in the case of Jimmy Chamberlin
column7: a jazz/hard-rock drum freak let loose on alt-rock radio.

column1: Alt-rock radio
column2: at its height of commercial trendsetting
column3: enabled the Pumpkins to not merely survive but thrive. There
column4: Corgan could have his cake and eat it too
column5: daring people to get annoyed at his starlust and reacting in kind while further building up his ambitions. He got his band signed to a major label and used the fig leaf of a corporate indie release for Gish
column6: scored a prime spot on the Seattle-focused Singles soundtrack with ""Drown""
column7: essentially went ""Haters gonna hate"" with Siamese Dream's first single ""Cherub Rock""
column8: and got petulant when any other acts or writers accused him of protesting too much. And not just Pavement
column9: either: ""You hurt me deeply in my heart
column10: he once infamously pouted to Kim Thayil before a 1994 Australian concert
column11: following which the Pumpkins went on ""to play the best set anybody has ever heard them play.""

column1: All of which goes some distance toward explaining why both reissues of Gish and Siamese Dream-- appropriately loaded with rarities
column2: DVD bonuses
column3: fancy packaging
column4: and often-impressionistic song-for-song liner notes by Corgan-- remain remarkable though unequal listens. Even in 1991
column5: Gish felt like something that started off well with songs like ""Siva"" and ""Rhinoceros"" but meandered a bit toward the end. Corgan's voice never sounded as lost in his music as it does here
column6: and most of the emphasis is on the band's collective performance: Chamberlin's powerful
column7: fluid drumming
column8: Darcy Wretzky's strong basslines
column9: and that thick
column10: chunky glaze of guitars.

column1: The rarities disc contains a few never-before-heard numbers
column2: a few that have long circulated among fanatics (the Corgan-sung version of ""Daydream"" is a keeper)
column3: and a handful of remixed selections (including their best full-on rock epic
column4: ""Starla"") that first surfaced on a full-length release via the odds-and-ends release Pisces Iscariot. These tracks do a better job of showcasing the band's various sonic sides than Gish itself. The DVD
column5: a multi-camera cut from a live show at the Metro in Chicago almost a year prior to Gish's release
column6: shows that the band already had their exact arrangements pretty well down
column7: as well as a worshipping fanbase. The highlights include Corgan and James Iha's heavily long hair
column8: curious fashion choices all around
column9: and set-closing covers of Steppenwolf and Blue Öyster Cult; the video quality is pretty good and the sound mix
column10: if heavily favoring the vocals
column11: beats out most bootlegs of the time.

column1: In contrast to Gish's steady flow
column2: Siamese Dream crashes out of the gate. ""Cherub Rock"" remains an absolutely stellar opener with a sense of pure sonic melodrama
column3: thanks to Chamberlin's circus-act drum introduction
column4: a tight clip of guitars quickly matched by equally nimble bass
column5: a volcanic blast of a guitar lead
column6: and then a shift to a woozy
column7: still-building sprawl. And all this before the first verse even starts. Throw in everything that followed-- the overt MBV worship of ""Hummer""
column8: the country-rock-tinged wanderlust of ""Mayonaise""
column9: ""Soma""'s update of Prince's ""The Beautiful Ones"" for a new decade
column10: and inevitably the MTV/radio hits ""Today""
column11: ""Disarm""
column12: and ""Rocket""-- and no matter your take on its mastermind or his divisive whining/sighing vocals
column13: it's an embarrassment of musical riches.

column1: There's also the fact that the album's studio personnel was as essentially stripped down as the White Stripes; Corgan
column2: frantically taking charge in the midst of band dysfunction
column3: recorded nearly everything himself aside from the drums
column4: and he'd probably have handled those too if he could. Siamese Dream's songs don't blend into each other
column5: but some transitions exist; each stands out in a brilliant sequence
column6: forming perhaps the best concept album they ever made.

column1: One of the main things people complained about was exactly what made the band click even further. If Corgan's early lyrics were classic self-centered/self-righteous/self-pitying teenagerdom run amock
column2: he always had an ear for hooks
column3: metaphors
column4: and deft summaries (thus
column5: on ""Mayonaise"": ""Fool enough to almost be it/ Cool enough to not quite see it""). It's catnip for when you have it bad
column6: no matter how minuscule your problems might really be
column7: and any number of later bands (My Chemical Romance most obviously
column8: and the Pains of Being Pure at Heart most recently) took plenty of notice.

column1: As for the many rarities
column2: more Pisces Iscariot remixes and other demos and alternate versions take a bow
column3: including a six-minute version of ""Siamese Dream"" itself (the original B-side version was a shorter and murkier take that ran under three minutes) and twin instrumentals ""U.S.A."" and ""U.S.S.R."". The DVD is the most worthwhile addition of either reissue; taken from another Metro show a couple of weeks after Siamese Dream's release
column4: it vividly illustrates how far the band had come in the three years since Gish: It showcases their more varied sound
column5: Corgan's keener sense for playing to the crowd (there are flashes of his and Iha's underrated sense of humor)
column6: a killer setlist drawing on both albums (plus ""Starla"" and ""Drown"")
column7: and brilliant sound and performances throughout. If Corgan's voice shows strain at many points
column8: the crowd shots are especially entertaining
column9: with endless moshpits and crowdsurfers during most of the loud points and plenty of the slow ones.

column1: The full story of the band's existence has plenty of ups and downs to go through
column2: and there are more reissues to come to spell this out
column3: even as the current version of the band moves along according to Corgan's own cryptic impulses. Yet these two releases still resonate
column4: as both a nostalgia fix underscoring how it was so easy to fall for Smashing Pumpkins in the first place
column5:
and as the best introductions to their music any newcomer could want.

"|16059.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16059-gish-deluxe-edition-siamese-dream-deluxe-edition/|10.0|Ned Raggett

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17219/homepage_large.e2d971ac.jpg|Dreama EP|28578.0|Kingdom|['Pop/R&B'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Night Slugs']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:39.215405|"

Last year's EP That Mystic was a good introduction to Kingdom
column3: the Brooklyn producer and Night Slugs/Fool's Gold stablemate who operates in a distinct idiom you could call ""BK funky."" At its core
column4: the EP fused the intricacy of post-dubstep with the production sensibility and anything-goes nature of contemporary pop. And his everything-is-percussion approach built up a sense of bustling hugeness that
column5: speaker-rattling immediacy notwithstanding
column6: never overwhelmed its Swiss-watch rhythmic engineering. That it did so in an intense
column7: almost panicky sort of way was part of the appeal-- the tweaky gallop of the title track's kick-heavy rhythm was one of bass music's best last year-- but it also left a lot of options for new directions to go in the still relatively early stages of an ambitious and wide-ranging style.

column1: Dreama plays with a few of those options
column2: maintaining the balance between keeping his big ideas both upfront and subtly beneath the surface. The songs on this EP are largely less concerned with jostling listeners into its rhythmic space and more prone to luring them in instead
column3: though once they get inside they can still get thrown around a bit. The organized clamor and high tension still jumps out here and there
column4: most notably in ""Stalker Ha"": Its snares are crisp to the point of brittle
column5: it teases out a water-drip piano note just long enough to make it a neat shock when the melody turns into a Halloween homage
column6: and it builds a sharp sense of anxiety out of the way it layers half-ecstatic/half-haunted wordless soul vocals over an insistently ringing old telephone bell. It's brisk stuff
column7: an easy highlight of a repertoire still on the upswing.

column1: But defining Kingdom by the standards of all that taut chaos his earlier work laid down doesn't fit quite as easily with the rest of the EP. Take the title track
column2: a cut that opens with a loping stride of a beat-- a heavy skulk ready to break out into a Rickey Henderson sprint. If you dork out for drum patterns
column3: it's a headspinning juxtaposition of kicks
column4: snares
column5: claps
column6: and snaps that's striking enough on its own. But it's not put in service of deep-pressure dynamics and a mood steeped in turmoil-- it's more like straight-up funk
column7: with an alternately pitched-up-and-down vocal ""ayyy"" careening off fat synths that simultaneously evoke classic boogie and current Dirty South-indebted R&B. It's wide open and airy to the point of almost being calming
column8: but it still thumps. ""Hood by Air Theme"" is a bit more tense
column9: with foreboding atmospherics
column10: teased-out vocal snippets
column11: swelling bass
column12: and floodgate-bursting percussion buildups rolled out as a blatant prelude to a big drop. But the drop itself is what makes it
column13: and it's so audaciously deployed and timed-- and recognizably iconic in just how joyous it is-- that it'd almost feel like a spoiler just mentioning where it comes from. (It also proves that in the right hands
column14: there's no such thing as a too-obvious sample.)

column1: Maybe the best summary of what Kingdom's capable of can be found in the opening track. ""Let You No"" incorporates a comparatively lesser-known R&B track
column2: Sadie Ama's ""Fallin""
column3: to similar dramatic effect as ""Hood by Air Theme"". But it's a more slippery build
column4: capitalizing on sneaking early hints of her voice under cover of the track's whistle-squeak synth and some characteristically skittery beats. We hear her first as faint echoes
column5: then chopped up percussively
column6: then finally breaking through as a full-fledged hook that almost reads
column7: in this new context
column8: like a statement on breaking tension: ""I should've held back/ But I just thought I'd let you know."" For all his polyrhythmic complexity and string-pulling
column9: emotional mood-setting
column10: Kingdom knows his way around a voice-- and that's where he's got his future down on lock. Maybe pop's future
column11:
too.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17217/homepage_large.5d4d2528.jpg|Dive|28474.0|Tycho|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ghostly']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:40.656091|"

Scott Hansen
column2: aka Tycho
column3: is a fairly well-known graphic artist
column4: and you can hear his design skills at play in his music. Like a particularly crisp logo or font
column5: his songs have a good sense of scale and proportion
column6: and it's clear that a lot of work goes into them. Take a look at his artwork and you'll have a good idea of what his electronic compositions sound like
column7: too. Nostalgic
column8: 1970s-inspired imagery
column9: a heavy sense of tranquility and faraway longing
column10: all tied together with a pretty sleek modernity. Several of these elements have been sort of beaten into the ground in indie music over the past few years
column11: but with Dive
column12: Hansen manages to pull them together in a way that still feels compelling.

column1: Tycho's tracks are built primarily with synths and sampled live instrumentation
column2: and his electro-organic approach brings to mind leaders in this field like Boards of Canada and Bibio. Sonically
column3: too
column4: he explores terrain similar to those guys': ""A Walk"" and ""Coastal Break"" nail a pastoral peacefulness with warm
column5: sepia-toned beats and flourishes of acoustic guitar. What separates Tycho
column6: at least from a lot of the bedroom-oriented artists currently exploring similar sounds
column7: is simple craft. These tracks are OCD-level meticulous. Hear it in the percussion: In place of the tinny
column8: synthetic beats favored by lots of indie-ambient startups
column9: Hansen takes extra care to capture real live drum sounds with a crack and thump that makes you feel like you're in the room with them.

column1: His attention to detail goes beyond highlighting individual instruments. It's there in the way Hansen simply builds a song
column2: merging all the synth wooshes and percussive ripples to find a natural arc. ""Daydream""
column3: for example
column4: starts out fairly simple with twinkly guitars and a sturdy
column5: knocking beat
column6: but the song's pulse quickens as it progresses
column7: and by the end you've got something heady enough to live up to its title. Because Hansen clearly wants this to be a deep headphone experience
column8: those subtle shifts go a long way in holding your interest. And in terms of the imagery he builds-- fields
column9: pastures
column10: calming oceanic scenes-- it's all there
column11: and it's pretty easy to set your brain on ""relax"" and conjure up those natural landscapes.

column1: If that nicely detailed tranquility is Dive's biggest selling point
column2: it also exposes a nagging flaw
column3: which is a lack of tension. Hansen is so committed to keeping things serene that he doesn't incorporate much danger or risk
column4: and at times the album can feel a bit one-note. An out-of-nowhere tonal change or an occasional tinge of darkness would give the record more balance
column5: make it more interesting. That missing element of surprise keeps Tycho from reaching the same heights as BoC or Bibio (the former more otherworldly
column6: the latter more adventurously poppy)
column7: but ultimately Hansen succeeds at what he sets out to do. Dive might not be the most ambitious instrumental record you hear all year
column8:
but it almost always sounds good.

"|16071.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16071-dive/|7.0|Joe Colly

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17188/homepage_large.4ded0ba4.jpg|No Kings|24537.0|Doomtree|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Doomtree']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:41.273068|"

Minneapolis' Doomtree let a bunch of their hydra heads have a turn in the spotlight over the last year or so
column2: and the ensuing solo releases were a solid indicator of just how multifaceted a crew they could be. But of all the records that had the potential to raise the collective's profile-- including rapper/singer Dessa's coolly strong <i>Castor
column3: the Twin
column4: Sims' feral
column5: heavy-hitting Bad Time Zoo
column6: Lazerbeak's indie pop-friendly Legend Recognize Legend
column7: and Paper Tiger's intricately soulful beat record Made Like Us-- it was
column8: of all things
column9: a mash-up record that blew up. Funny thing is
column10: the concept behind the Cecil Otter co-created ""Wugazi"" project wasn't just some blog-baiting crossover stunt-- it's a way to look at where Doomtree got their early inspiration as an entity
column11: somewhere between the form-like-Voltron Wu-Tang enclave's early underground mythbuilding and Fugazi's community-building independence.

column1: But the easy-sell concept of Shaolin punk doesn't even really come into obvious play with No Kings. The hardcore continuum isn't as readily acknowledged as it was on P.O.S.'s solo work
column2: while Lazerbeak's Plastic Constellations background doesn't figure in his productions much
column3: either. (The most traditionally and superficially ""punk rock"" sound on the album is the surfer-hoodlum riff that opener ""No Way"" builds around
column4: and that's sourced from an early 1970s soundtrack-library album.) And not even Ghostface in full-blown manic stream-of-imagery Supreme Clientele mode was as relentlessly evasive and tricky to parse as some of the verses on here. Loosely alluded-to themes about camaraderie and identity get buried under waves of abstract allusions that leave behind little narrative impact on first listen
column5: other than the vague sense of some victorious resilience.

column1: Fortunately
column2: that vague sense has some intrigue beneath it. Sims
column3: Cecil Otter
column4: Mike Mictlan
column5: P.O.S.
column6: and Dessa all share a beat-poet sense of tightly-packed extended abstract metaphors
column7: which they vary to subtle enough degrees that differentiating their voices seems beside the point. That's not to their detriment
column8: and the aforementioned solo releases are proof enough that they can each go in their own distinct directions. But as a unit
column9: they complement each others' talents naturally
column10: each providing their own variations on allegorical stress-rap. ""Team the Best Team"" might be the best example of how all five MCs switch up their approaches-- P.O.S. as sincerely intense slow-burner
column11: Sims's slick-flowing
column12: machete-sharp delivery
column13: Cecil Otter throwing pinpoint darts with deadpan calm
column14: Dessa's deceptively cool-headed
column15: subtly melodic shadowboxing
column16: and Mike Mictlan's agitated yet precise internal-rhyming intensity.

column1: Those qualities are easier to pick up on when they shake you away from the duty of parsing their lyrics
column2: which
column3: unbound by typical battle-rap punchlines or persona-building
column4: at least manage to sell their cryptic insights as rallying calls. The dense weight of verbiage on No Kings actually welcomes uninitiated listeners
column5: rather than siphoning them out for not being advanced enough on some impenetrable ultra-battler shit. And for the scattered talk of 10-year tenures and the occasional fuck-these-other-rappers declaration
column6: the album's tone of flag-planting resistance builds off something deeper and more universal than political beef
column7: star status or personal style. The trespassing-as-liberation undercurrents of ""Bolt Cutter""
column8: the solidarity anthem ""Bangarang"" and the self-realized
column9: apocalypse-flip-off ""Own Yours"" are all introspective in their own ways
column10: but they're too busy staring you dead in the eye to gaze at their own navels.

column1: And it's easy enough to give the lyrics plenty of time and space to sink in-- or even just roll off your back for the time being-- when the beats are this up-front and anthemic. With a production that largely draws off the strengths of their two primary beatmakers
column2: the individuals' highlights-- Lazerbeak's grimy
column3: garage-psych-infused ""String Theory"" and ""Punch-Out""; the Super NES prog of Cecil Otter's beats for ""Beacon"" and ""The Grand Experiment""-- are as much a collective triumph as the group efforts
column4:
like the co-produced bookends of motorcycle chain-swinging mini-suite ""No Way"" and the digital brass blowout of ""Fresh New Trash"". Doomtree have been comfortable inside their own space for so long that their individualistic pride in it has grown from defiant to triumphant. That one-off bootleg drew all the attention-- No Kings damn well better keep it.

"|16043.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16043-doomtree-no-kings/|7.9|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17211/homepage_large.edcbdc7a.jpg|Keep Your Dreams|28108.0|Canyons|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modular']|2011-11-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:41.897839|"

Bad timing that Canyons released Keep Your Dreams in the same year M83 and Cut Copy finally put out new albums. I've already read several naysayers make comparisons to both of those acts
column2: in order to dismiss Canyons out of hand
column3: but the connection strikes me as both obvious and inexact. True
column4: Canyons have got a taste for the brittle and buzzing tones of early synthesizer music
column5: just like Anthony Gonzalez and crew. And Canyons are interested in creating heart-stirring epics out bits of 1980s pop culture previously deemed off-limits because they were just too damn kitschy
column6: same as M83 and the Cut Copy boys.

column1: But while Hurry Up
column2: We're Dreaming and Zonoscope can sometimes bludgeon you with their need to be monumental
column3: Keep Your Dreams follows a far more idiosyncratic path into much stranger and less immediately arena-pleasing places. For one thing
column4: there's far more weirdo disco boogie
column5: and early ambient house ala the Orb
column6: and Toto-style sensitive dude rock in Canyons' sound. All those wobbly saxophone solos
column7: for one thing. And the stoned hand percussion and jungle bird sound effects. The best tracks here aren't so much sweeping shoegaze/new wave classics-in-the-making as bedroom producer dance jams that keep sprouting all sorts of weird-pop moments as the beats roll on.

column1: When they're really on
column2: Canyons are maximalists who seem pained to follow one idea to its conclusion when they can keep things mutating
column3: unrepentant oddballs who still love a good earworm but would prefer to have three. Plus they thankfully have little truck with revisionist notions of good taste when it comes 80s dance music
column4: which was often pretty great because it was so gauche. ""Under a Blue Sky"" is so unashamedly campy and overloaded with winning ""bad"" ideas retrieved from the dustbin of dance music history that it makes the DFA's rehabilitative aims sound downright acetic. Slap bass that's so clean and stiff it feels more robotic than fluidly funky? Check. A campy ""menacing"" vocalist
column5: pitched-down Adonis-style
column6: spouting suggestive French gibberish? Got it. Gritless ""funk"" guitar  that makes Power Station sound like Muddy Waters? Yup. An elephant's trumpet call for the hell of it? Sure
column7: why not. Canyons remix and get remixed by ""acceptably"" serious dance dons like DJ Harvey
column8: but the high points of Keep Your Dreams revel in the unacceptable baubles of what was once mainstream pop. They remember that so much of 80s dance-pop blurred the line between novelty music and alien-sounding futurism.

column1: Even when they try to play things straight
column2: toying with more hipster-approved genres
column3: Canyons can't seem to help stretching out the weirdness in the forms they're playing with. ""See Blind Through"" is classic late-80s Chicago house
column4: right down to the purposefully crude vocal cut-ups and the Mr. Fingers bassline. Except the whole thing's been DJ Screwed
column5: a tempo changes that amplifies the darkness of the original sound. It becomes a woozy black hole of faux soul
column6: not too far off from the similarly molasses-ized grooves you'd find on Rub N Tug mixtapes a few years back. And then the vocals evoke not only a drag show diva but a zonked-out Michael McDonald wandering through a warehouse party. It shouldn't work but does. It's just warped enough from its source materials to avoid bland pastiche
column7: but not crassly out-there
column8: weird for the sake of it. Canyons clearly love the stuff they draw from
column9: enough to not merely want to ape it
column10: and they know genre shouldn't be fucked with just to be ""interesting."" ""My Rescue"" could have been a pleasant enough indie rock song
column11: stirring in a generic sort of way
column12: but the deep house piano and percussion give it just enough of an edge
column13: the two distinct genres harmonizing into sound more indie bands should make use of.

column1: What keeps the prize moments of Keep Your Dreams from feeling obnoxiously ""eclectic"" is the smoothness of the production and the arrangements. The tracks may be over-stuffed with ideas
column2: but Canyons have also studied the way 80s producers could make ""big"" tracks where every idea rang out clear
column3: where all the little touches felt integrated into something bigger than the sum of a lot of cute parts. But unfortunately that the zigzagging dance-collage stuff only accounts for little more than half of Keep Your Dreams' running time
column4: and on the rest of the album
column5: Canyons' interest in smoothness drags them down. The least convincing side of Canyons is the soft-rock stuff
column6: and there's a lot of it here
column7: especially in the record's back-end.

column1: Maybe it feels flat and less creative than Canyons' dance tunes simply because there's been so much laid-back yacht gunk over the last half-decade. Or maybe it's because Canyons don't seem to devote half as much creative energy to this side of their output. The deckside reveries on Keep Your Dreams really are played too straight
column2: and hardly convincing
column3: even as homage
column4: when A/B'd with the stuff you can still hear for free every day on classic rock radio. A whole album of disorienting patchwork grooves like ""Under a Blue Sky"" might have eventually worn the casual listener down. But Canyons also want to be songwriters
column5: and though they draw on different inspirations
column6: it's here that they fall short compared to M83 and Cut Copy. Forget Lindsey Buckingham
column7: or hell
column8: even Mark Knopfler. But when they go for manic instead of mellow
column9: Canyons do bring something new
column10: even if it's just intensity
column11:
to the 80s retro party.

""We found love in a hopeless place."" Over a frantic
column2: Calvin Harris-produced
column3: Guetta-meets-""Sandstorm"" beat on her sixth record's lead-off single
column4: Rihanna repeats these words almost 20 times. ""We Found Love"" ranks among Ri's best singles because it recognizes that there's not much more that needs to be said: in three and a half minutes
column5: the line moves from being a great pop lyric to a triumphant mantra to something suggestive of a whole spectrum of unspoken emotion. The best pop music transports you to somewhere beyond words
column6: and Rihanna's strongest singles all seem to be in on this secret. Need I remind you of some of her most powerful hooks: Ella-ella-ella-ay. Oh-na-na. Ay-ayy-ay-ayy-ay-ayy.

column1: But as anyone with a Twitter handle will tell you
column2: these are chatty times
column3: and in 2011
column4: the pop landscape's fittingly caught between two maximalist extremes: the winking theatricality of Nicki Minaj
column5: Lady Gaga
column6: and Katy Perry
column7: and the dribbling confessional-pop of Drake
column8: Kanye West
column9: and (yes
column10: they're more alike than they'd like to believe) Taylor Swift. Barbados-born
column11: millions-selling
column12: armfuls-of-awards-winning Rihanna has found staggering success (23 years old; eleven #1 singles and rising) borrowing a little bit from each of these tendencies. Her recent music videos have dabbled in trendy pop artifice (check out her neon-hued
column13: irresistibly smiley turn in Guetta’s ""Who’s That Chick?"" or the David LaChapelle-aping-- literally-- ""S&M"")
column14: while her brooding and personal 2009 album Rated R commented-- however obliquely-- on her public struggles. Rihanna seems more comfortable flitting between these two extremes than settling on either
column15: but her past two albums have at least had some thematic cohesion. The same can't be said of Talk That Talk: Heavy on filler though it's only 11 tracks long
column16: it feels not only slight but muddled
column17: an assortment of half-baked ideas that never bloom. A stitched-together collection of club bangers
column18: sleaze-pop missteps
column19: and mid-tempo inspirational ballads
column20: Talk That Talk feels at times like three different records
column21: only one of which might have been any good.

column1: Of course
column2: what we're supposed to be talking is about how this is Rihanna's ""dirtiest"" album yet. Early blog chatter reported to lots of critics blushing in preview listening sessions and making questionably bold declarations (""The dirtiest pop album since Madonna's Erotica!"") that suggested that they listen to very little pop radio
column3: or that they have never been to an R. Kelly concert. Talk That Talk's raunchier moments should surprise no one: Rihanna's always been singing about sex-- she's just never shown such an unfortunate proclivity for cheesy lyrics and dessert metaphors. ""Suck my cockiness/ Lick my persuasion
column4: Ri commands on the embarrassingly literal ""Cockiness (I Love It)""
column5: hoping the boldness of the delivery will distract you from thinking about what a clunky line it is (it won't
column6: though Bangladesh's beats might). The Esther Dean-penned ""Drunk on Love"" features a weak chorus lyric and vocal whose bombast feels out of place in the track's laid back
column7: xx-sampling atmosphere. Clocking in at a puzzling-yet-merciful one minute and 18 seconds
column8: The-Dream co-produced ""Birthday Cake"" is even more heavy-handed (lots of icing puns). There are flickers of empowerment here
column9: but mostly it proves little more than the fact that a female artist can be responsible for Jeremih-grade cheese
column10: too. A Rihanna album has never been without the occasional lyrical misfire (""Sex in the air/ I don't care/ I love the smell of it"" comes to mind)
column11: but at least on a track like ""S&M"" she sounds like she's having fun. For a record so preoccupied with passion and pleasure
column12: most of Talk That Talk feels unsuitably robotic.

column1: At least things start out strong. Talk That Talk's saving grace is its first stretch of tracks: the blithe and tropical ""You Da One""
column2: ""We Found Love""
column3: and the album's other Harris track ""Where Have You Been""
column4: which doesn't stray much from the single's winning formula
column5: a simple lyric of romantic longing that explodes into a club-ready beat. And though it's no ""Umbrella""
column6: the Jay-Z reunion ""Talk That Talk"" is one of the more playful moments here
column7: though I'll say that the patented H.O.V.-giggle doesn't feel entirely earned following a line like: ""Had it by a bladder/ She like 'oh I gotta pee'.""

column1: I've read some comment-section conspiracy theorists who believe Rihanna is in single-minded pursuit of Hot 100 domination
column2: and the rate at which she's pumping out albums (roughly one a year since 2005) is an attempt to populate the singles chart until the end of time. There might be some truth to this (her singles collection is going to be killer)
column3: and with ""Death of the Album"" prophecies ever looming it's worth wondering whether or not that's such a crime. But 2011 found plenty of pop artists still breathing new life into the format: Beyonce's 4 and Lady Gaga's Born This Way were probably the most solid examples-- two bombastic records that also explore the nuance of their respective artists' personas. Talk That Talk tries too hard to send a more one-dimensional message and ends up falling flat: Rihanna's obviously going for sexy here
column4: but her music's at its most alluring when she's blissed out in her own reverie
column5:
not taking the time to spell it all out for us.

""When you play music and you're a person on a stage
column2: sometimes people can put you on a pedestal
column3: and that can do a lot of things to your head. And... what if it actually exploded all over the walls during a show?"" That's Ty Segall speaking to SF Weekly earlier this year about his 2011 song
column4: ""My Head Explodes"". It's a fairly straightforward description of a song that isn't terribly complicated. Guy sings. People watch. Guy's head explodes. It's not hard to picture Segall's head exploding. He sings hard and loud and with the shrill fury of a castrated animal. And he does this a lot. Since quitting his band
column5: Epsilons
column6: less than four years ago
column7: Segall has become arguably the most exciting and probably the most prolific member of San Francisco's evolving garage rock scene
column8: which also includes Thee Oh Sees
column9: the Fresh & Onlys
column10: and Sic Alps (with whom Segall formerly played). Since going solo
column11: he's released five albums of original material; two split LPs; a live album; a cassette-only compilation; eight 7""s; four split EPs; a collaborative album with Mikal Cronin; and appeared on four compilation albums. The man is prolific. Trying to keep up will
column12: if not enough make your head explode

column1: This year's Goodbye Bread
column2: his first release for Drag City
column3: is easily his best
column4: the accumulation of learned songwriting tricks and a developing melodic sense
column5: with an emphasis on sonic clarity and the influence of some august icons
column6: notably John Lennon and Marc Bolan. (Oh yeah
column7: Segall recorded a tribute EP to Bolan's T. Rex this year
column8: too.) In the afterglow of Goodbye's success
column9: Memphis label Goner Records
column10: Segall's former home
column11: has compiled Singles 2007-2010
column12: a sort of refresher course and unheard odds-and-ends set that serves as a tenacious
column13: temporary portrait of Segall. There are hints everywhere at the songwriter Segall would become
column14: but Singles is much more about the flail of youth than honoring tradition. In a few years
column15: he's garnered comparisons to a wide swath of artists
column16: from Nuggets-friendly English bands like the Troggs and the Pretty Things
column17: to working-class American menace-peddlers like the Stooges and Ramones
column18: to early recordings by the White Stripes (especially prevalent on this comp)
column19: down to the late Jay Reatard
column20: a significant guidepost for Segall.

column1: Singles is a stew mixing all of those ingredients and more. There are hints of Devo in the mechanized synth and drum tracks on early versions of ""So Alone"" and ""The Drag"". (Before forming his band
column2: Segall often played all the instruments on his records
column3: including drum machine.) Listen for ? and the Mysterians-like organ at the outset of ""Skin""
column4: maybe the best song here. And in that voice
column5: which vacillates from desperate howl to wallowing drone
column6: a little Kurt Cobain
column7: too. It's hard to know what's a relic and what's an advance here. Segall appears in love with surface imitation at times
column8: while peeling the skin back at others. On the faux-British B-side ""Fuzzy Cat""
column9: you can hear John Entwistle of the Who's gothic goof-off ""Boris the Spider"". The appearance of a cover of Chain Gang's coiled
column10: minor punk masterpiece
column11: ""Son of Sam""
column12: feels like a cred grab
column13: but an accomplished one. On ""Caesar""
column14: which would later appear on 2010's Melted in more polished form
column15: there's a little of the stomping acoustic rock that would become the underbelly of Goodbye Bread. Segall
column16: like so many developing artists
column17: seemed to be constantly toggling between ideas of himself.

column1: Singles
column2: while comprising 25 songs
column3: is still less than one hour's worth of music-- this iteration of Segall was economical. Only now
column4: as his ambition grows
column5: so do the lengths of his songs. Just one here exceeds three minutes-- it's the demo version of ""So Alone""
column6: which was eventually whittled down to less than two and a half minutes for Horn the Unicorn. After acclaim for the elliptical and sometimes very pretty Goodbye Bread
column7: one might assume Segall's left the crash-and-bash of Singles 2007-2010 behind. But then
column8: his new single
column9: ""Spiders""
column10: is all doom and drone-- a violent
column11:
glorious devolution-- clocking in just under three minutes. So much for obvious trajectories.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17195/homepage_large.3a153f57.jpg|Boddie Recording Company: Cleveland
column2:
Ohio|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Numero Group']|2011-11-23 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:43.462719|"

Do a quick Google search for 12202 Union Avenue
column3: Cleveland
column4: OH. The top result is a Google map that still shows a Boddie Recording label at the address. Switch to Street View
column5: and there's an attractive red two-story house with yellow trim and a sign out front that says ""Boddie
column6: with eighth notes standing in for the Ds. Down the driveway
column7: a garage is visible
column8: but it's not an ordinary garage. It's the remains of Boddie Recording Company
column9: the long-lived but never well-known recording concern of Thomas and Louise Boddie. The outbuildings behind the house still contain the ephemera of record labels that long ago faded to silence
column10: a studio that hosted its last session decades ago
column11: and a pressing plant that has sat idle since the mid-1980s
column12: some of the components of the pressing line long since sold off.

column1: In this space
column2: a few hundred 45s and LPs were prepared for a world that never bothered to hear them. Though this release doesn't strictly fall under the banner of Numero Group's long-running soul archeology project Eccentric Soul
column3: it fits with the spirit of the project
column4: unearthing not just the music made at Boddie but also the history and personalities surrounding it-- the old
column5: grainy photographs and detailed histories contained in the two liner-note booklets place the music on these three CDs in the context of the people that made it and the place where it was made.

column1: Boddie Recording Company was born out of Thomas Boddie's passion for electronics
column2: a passion he acquired when very young. He built his own radios and speaker systems in junior high
column3: went to tech school (the only black student in his class)
column4: served in the Army Air Force during World War II. He got himself a job repairing organs after his discharge and apprenticed at a local Cleveland studio while amassing a collection of studio gear in the basement of the house he shared with his brother. Boddie's fledgling company cut its first sides in 1959
column5: the same year Berry Gordy founded Motown on the other side of Lake Erie
column6: but the two companies' arcs could not have been more different. Where Gordy assembled a brilliant core of creative people who built long-lasting working relationships and devised processes of production and quality control that turned his company into a powerhouse
column7: Boddie and his wife worked day and night with very limited resources to build a studio behind their new house that wasn't ready for business until 1964.

column1: Even then
column2: there was no team. Boddie recorded local acts but had no house band. The company established several imprints on which to release recordings but had no real avenues through which to promote them. The first disc of this set focuses on the Soul Kitchen and related Cookin' labels
column3: which were active primarily in the early 1970s. The music on these releases falls mostly in the psychedelic soul realm-- during the same period
column4: one of Cleveland's most admired bands was the Purple Image
column5: a funky psychedelic outfit that recorded a classic self-titled LP in 1970. The Creations Unlimited and the Inter-Circle each cut strong fuzz funk singles
column6: Ricky Hodges' ""I Feel It (The Love You Have For Me)"" features fantastically ragged guitar taking bites out of an elastic beat while flute flutters around his soul shouting
column7: and ""Soul Feeling"" finds Frankie Pighee & the Soulettes making their own outstanding contribution to the long lineage of soul roll-call tunes.

column1: None of it is especially polished
column2: and it's hard to pinpoint the potential hits that never were
column3: because there were so many records like this being made at the time; but there is a certain optimism and spirit of hard work in these recordings that makes them an exciting body of work to listen to all at once. The same can be said of the earlier recordings on disc two
column4: which were mostly released on the Luau label. There are some great band names-- the Atomic Aces and the Modern Detergents definitely top the list-- and a lot of rollicking R&B on the disc
column5: which works with disc one to paint a picture of the evolving soul scene in Cleveland during the era. There was a lot of talent toiling down there in the dead-end clubs
column6: and Boddie captured a good cross-section of it.

column1: While these recordings are fun and sometimes even great
column2: they didn't exactly provide the seeds for any money trees
column3: and Thomas Boddie continued to repair organs and radios on the side. He slowly pieced together his own pressing plant
column4: he recorded a lot of out-of-town bluegrass and folk groups touring through Cleveland
column5: he built his own mobile recording unit
column6: he ran a side company called Boddie Audio Advertising (it was a car with a PA on top-- they used it to support Carl Stokes' campaign for mayor)
column7: and he also tapped in to one of the safer-- if not more profitable-- markets in music: gospel.

column1: The final disc of the set is filled with gospel recordings from Boddie's Bounty imprint
column2: spanning from 1967 all the way to 1983
column3: the very twilight of Boddie as a recording concern. Bits of gospel do crop up on the other discs (the King James Version's two tracks on disc one are especially entertaining)
column4: but disc three is a clinic in the numerous ways that singers and bands found to put their faith into music. Some of it is ham-handed and overwrought-- Rev. R.L. Hubbard's operatics on ""Child of the King"" do not complement the spooky soul backing
column5: and the screechy kid vocals of the Wings of Faith Juniors of Grand Rapids
column6: Michigan
column7: are rough sledding-- but a lot of it is clever and enjoyable on its own musical terms. Brother Bill wasn't the only one to wrap religion in a faux-countercultural rap
column8: but he does it with a lot of panache
column9: and Silver King's ""Trouble in the Water"" psychedelicizes a variation on the old ""Wade in the Water"" themes.

column1: A couple of songs engage in some rather un-Christian theft. Sound of Soul's ""Gospel Train"" is actually the Impressions' ""People Get Ready"" lazily retitled
column2: and the Gospel Ensemble's ""What You Need"" liberally borrows from the Isley Brothers' ""It's Your Thing""
column3: to name two examples that give soul fans an opportunity to play detective. Some of the later gospel sides were recorded not at Boddie's studio but in the actual churches
column4: using his mobile unit. As his vinyl pressing operation
column5: never big enough to be a hugely profitable concern
column6: struggled in the early 1980s in the face of collapsing demand
column7: Thomas Boddie got into cassette duplication. He'd often make a recording at a service that would then be duplicated and sold to congregants.

column1: Boddie never shuttered his company. He died in 2006
column2: but he hadn't ever considered putting Boddie Recording Company to bed permanently. Instead
column3: it faded quietly away
column4: years of incredibly hard work and long hours settling silently under layers of dust in the buildings behind his house. Boddie is a footnote to Cleveland's musical history
column5: more or less
column6: but as the city's premier low-cost studio
column7:
he provided a huge service to the city's music scene for over 20 years. This set pulls some of that service into the light and tells a story with the records he left behind.

"|16050.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16050-boddie-recording-company-cleveland-ohio/|7.5|Joe Tangari

Some people travel far from their hometown in order to get away from it
column2: others end up needing a few reminders of where they're from. Singer Brenda Malvini appears to fall into the latter category; after growing up in North Highlands in Sacramento
column3: California
column4: she moved to New York to attend NYU
column5: ultimately naming her band after the place where she was raised. If North Highlands find fame
column6: at least she can never be accused of forgetting where she came from. Wild One is the band's debut full-length
column7: constructed by Malvini and her band
column8: which demonstrates a proficiency seldom heard on the Brooklyn indie rock circuit. Fortunately
column9: this is a group that knows how to juggle the technical gifts at its disposal and the emotional application needed to make this something more than an exercise in indie navel-gazing. Wild One might seem like an inappropriate banner to hoist over such quotidian surface structures
column10: but dig a little deeper and it clearly represents this band's desire to shake things up every once in a while.

column1: Like any new group still etching out an identity
column2: it's not hard to pluck out precedents to the North Highlands sound as this record progresses. In particular
column3: the recently revived Electrelane circa No Shouts
column4: No Calls are a strong reference point
column5: with Malvini's singing mirroring Verity Susman's vocal lines on occasion (""Steady Steady
column6: ""Roundhouse""). The band members are fond of taking her work and interlacing it with jerky rhythms that are clamped to the kind of ultra-bright guitar playing Vampire Weekend practice
column7: ultimately settling into a style that's one part ice-cold detachment and one part fizzy pop encompassment. The juxtaposition is good for creating a space for North Highlands to operate within
column8: where the aloof vocal on a song like ""Chicago"" keeps their audience at arm's length
column9: only for some Tindersticks-y string arrangements to pull them back in with their warmth and vitality.

column1: Those strings add a touch of drama to Wild One whenever they surface. ""Lion Heart"" is a moving piece or orchestral pop that errs close to the kind of drunken flamboyance that Marc Almond or Patrick Wolf are fond of staggering around in
column2: conjuring up a feeling North Highlands would be wise to return to more often than they do here. Much of this record remains solidly grounded in indie rock
column3: with the band members occasionally scattering trails of potential paths they could follow behind them. When they keep it simple
column4: with a guitar jangle and a driving beat (""Bruce"") or by taking the pace down a little (""Best Part"") it works simply as a showcase for Malvini's striking voice. She tends to shy away from revealing too much about herself
column5: falling into a group of similarly minded female singers that includes Broadcast's Trish Keenan and Laetitia Sadier from Stereolab
column6: where the not-knowing leaves a series of questions simply hanging in the air.

column1: That sense of mystery is North Highlands' biggest asset
column2: especially as they can always anchor it in a sound that's flexible enough to allow them to experiment and work up characteristics that are identifiably their own. The next step should be to shore up that sound
column3: in a similar manner to Broadcast's leap from The Noise Made by People to Haha Sound. Sometimes Wild One wears its influences a little too hard on its sleeve
column4: or strives too hard to create something anthemic with across-the-board appeal-- the closing ""Here's"" fulfills both of those criteria. That song has a tension that feels ill-fitting
column5: because when North Highlands relax into their looser material
column6: this stuff just seems to pour out of them
column7:
delivering an elegance that suggests they could shake off their tendency to emulate artists to whom they're so obviously in thrall.

"|16061.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16061-wild-one/|6.7|Nick Neyland

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17214/homepage_large.e079d93a.jpg|Welcome to Condale|28692.0|Summer Camp|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Moshi Moshi'
column3: the California town that's the focal point of UK indie pop duo Summer Camp's debut LP
column4: Welcome to Condale
column5: doesn't actually exist. It was invented by SC members Elizabeth Sankey and Jeremy Warmsley; to drive the whole conceptual thing home
column6: the band's created a zine pressed in limited physical quantities and available to view on their website (hint: click on ""Condale""); along with narrative-extending diary entries and fake interviews with faker bands
column7: there's the cover to a 1977 issue of Penthouse
column8: a poster for the obscure 1974 skin flick Teenage Milkmaid
column9: and <a href=""http://s11.bdbphotos.com/images/orig/e/y/eyqhywf1lh9fyehh.jpg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">the cover of the February 27
column10: 1984 issue of Jet
column11: which features an image of Brooke Shields and Michael Jackson together. On the upper right corner of the band's website
column12: there's a by-the-minute update on the current date and time-- with two small alterations: the year is listed as 1984
column13: and it's specified that no matter where you are
column14: you're living under ""Condale Time"" for the moment.

column1: Obviously
column2: Warmsley and Sankey went to great lengths to create this world
column3: and in a way it's impressive
column4: but the non-musical aspects of Welcome to Condale (especially the ""zine"" portion
column5: which eschews the personal-cultural DIY nature of the form in favor of signifier-collecting scrapbook nostalgia) highlights the pair's predilection for time-distanced cultural references. Anyone who listened to last year's Young EP could have seen this coming
column6: as Sankey sang about ""A boy dressed like Teen Wolf"" and friends taking photos ""with Polaroid cameras"" on a song titled after Winona Ryder's character in Heathers. Still
column7: their (sometimes ironic
column8: sometimes not) devotion to the past is persistent
column9: especially in the face of the growing realization that such devotion in indie culture is exhausting itself: in the video for Welcome to Condale single ""Better Off Without You""
column10: Sankey sings her punchy part under an Instagram'd filter
column11: juxtaposed by vintage-looking footage of teen-focused films. Warmsley is seen playing some guitar
column12: wearing a ""wolf shirt"" (something he's known to wear
column13: it seems).

column1: As some people tend to forget
column2: indie pop's relationship with the past is part of the genre's lifeblood
column3: with bands using out-of-time images and cultural figures to create their own little universes
column4: away from the pain of modern life. Summer Camp
column5: on the other hand
column6: collect such influences like Pogs (a bit of cultural ephemera untouched by these two
column7: thus far at least) and merely throw 'em out here and there
column8: without context or relation to the music. Witness the ill-juxtaposed vocal samples that open the lost-youth lament ""Summer Camp""
column9: a far cry from the Tough Alliance's personal-is-political use of a key line from John Cassavetes' Shadows on ""A New Chance""
column10: or the fact that the album's swaggering bedroom-arena highlight
column11: ""Brian Krakow""
column12: takes its name from the nerdy character on ""My So-Called Life"". The song's a bit of a brilliant kiss-off-but-not-really anthem
column13: featuring a rare lead vocal turn from Warmsley that
column14: truth be told
column15: carries more bold confidence than the actual (fictional) Krakow could have ever possessed.

column1: An entire album of ""Brian Krakow""s
column2: or the winding
column3: ecstatic pop of ""Better Off Without You""
column4: would make all of Summer Camp's nostalgic wrongs somewhat right. Unfortunately
column5: Welcome to Condale is stylistically all over the place and
column6: despite its generally upbeat tone
column7: kind of a drag to listen to (the fact that those two aforementioned tracks kick off the album highlights how front-loaded the thing is). Instead
column8: we get some more sparkly pop (""1988"")
column9: chugging indie rock (""Down"")
column10: sluggish electro murk (""I Want You""
column11: ""Nobody Knows You"")
column12: and a re-recorded version of Young's ""Ghost Train"" that
column13: while improving on the original
column14: shows how little they've grown as a band between then and now. As producer
column15: Pulp's Steve Mackey does a decent job of figuring out what kind of retro-tastic sheen this type of music warrants (hint: kind of like this
column16: or this)
column17: but its application seems tacky and forced
column18: especially since the source material isn't very engaging to begin with.

column1: ""Everything changes when you grow old."" That's the first thing you see when you visit Summer Camp's website
column2: as a line is slowly drawn through the phrase
column3: negating its inevitable truth. The truth
column4: obviously
column5: is things do change as you get older
column6: as they should and as Warmsley should know quite well; prior to starting Summer Camp with Sankey
column7: he released two solo albums of cut-and-paste electro-acoustic pop (2006's The Art of Fiction and 2008's How We Became) that bear little resemblance to the music he's making now. Of course
column8: plenty of musicians change the sounds they're working in all the time
column9: even if Warmsley's recent move toward this particular brand of in-vogue
column10: backward navel-gazing is suspicious in its possible calculation. The fact
column11: however
column12:
that he was easily able to make the transfer from a front-and-center singer/songwriter to a competent sideman to Sankey's vocal talents highlights how little actual personality and originality Summer Camp possess as a project. Settling in and safely blending into the background: I guess this is growing up.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17208/homepage_large.bbdb3f29.jpg|Sepalcure|29967.0|Sepalcure|['Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Hotflush']|2011-11-22 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:44.992126|"

Bass producers tend to treat innovation like daily prayer: If not duly performed at regular intervals
column2: some ill-defined Very Bad Thing will happen. The thirst for innovation is such that some scene-watchers have likened current bass music to post-punk
column3: stratifying its sounds in search of growth. Previous British dance movements-- drum'n'bass and garage-- found such terrifying end-games that the bass scene has made a constant effort to never stop swimming. To brand an artist as someone who simply executes
column4: however masterfully
column5: is to damn him with faint praise. Increasingly
column6: bass producers have looked backward (thumping
column7: linear 4/4 bangers) or forward (mutated footwork fever-dreams)
column8: largely ignoring (as Pitchfork writer Philip Sherburne put it in discussion)
column9: the fertile terrain between Burial and Joy Orbison.

column1: On their debut full-length for Scuba's Hotflush label
column2: New York duo Sepalcure nimbly incorporate current trends but arrive at a sound-- politely mysterious rhythms put to life by haunted vocal samples-- that's familiar and rich. Sepalcure is a collaboration between two dance veterans
column3: Praveen Sharma and Travis Stewart. That their album scans as a bit of a melting pot should not surprise. Sharma runs dance media hub Percussion Lab and records misty
column4: retro-futuristic house as Braille. Stewart hops genres as Machinedrum
column5: whose footwork-fusion album Room(s) is widely regarded as one of the year's best dance releases (I regret underrating its idiosyncrasies).

column1: Admittedly influenced by the scores of talent massing on forward-thinking bass labels like Hotflush and Hessle Audio
column2: their collaboration was the result of boredom and opportunity (Sharma's girlfriend
column3: visual artist Sougwen Chung
column4: was studying abroad; she handles all of the group's visuals). Some combination of serendipity and skill saw the duo's first tracks fall into the hands of Mary Anne Hobbs and Paul Rose (Scuba); two well-received EPs later
column5: a short two-week recording session birthed Sepalcure.

column1: That Sepalcure is so balanced and organized can be attributed to the experience and seeming calm of its principals; that it sounds so lively and inviting is the greater achievement. While syncopated rhythms-- pattering cymbals and kicks with now-familiar handclaps-- and probing bass sponge up dubstep's urban paranoia
column2: Sharma and Stewart add plenty of more explicitly emotional touches to their work. How else to explain the Who's <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AbxxuasmSpA"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""See Me
column3: Feel Me"" stretched transparent over
column4: um
column5: ""See Me Feel Me""? (And how the hell did that sample get cleared?) Or the hammy Italo-disco pianos that build up under the fingernails of ""Hold On"" and ""Yuh Nuh See""? Sepalcure's moody haze and mid-song shifts prevent it from being dance-floor fodder (""The One"" is a welcome exception)
column6: but neither is it music by which to lonesomely stare at rainstorms.

column1: Vocals play a prominent role throughout. During their best moments
column2: Sharma and Stewart subject rave-y house divas to dubstep's pinched nausea
column3: turning the gospel-like fervor of their sources into grimy hymns. (Those new to the group should acquaint themselves with early single ""Love Pressure"".) ""Breezin"" is especially devoted
column4: its tremulous refrain-- ""Mountains high and low!""-- ascending above its buzzy synths. The duo recorded many of the instruments live
column5: and there is a punch especially to the pianos (electric and acoustic) that their contemporaries frequently lack. They layer these instruments expertly
column6: and tracks such as lead single ""Pencil Pimp"" and ""Eternally Yrs"" function as bass-y
column7: house-y suspensions: discrete parts bound by weightless float. Tufts of melody chunk off ""Yuh Nuh See""
column8: as its meticulous
column9: six-note sequence snakes around a vocal hum and sprinkled
column10: choral beauty.

column1: Straightforward descriptions of Sepalcure-- a finely manicured mix of dubstep

Propulsive
column2: careening
column3: and at times
column4: openly dangerous
column5: Thee Oh Sees are like the house band for a runaway train. Much of their appeal comes from the fact that they're a machine with four equal parts: the wide-eyed
column6: cult-leader charisma of frontman John Dwyer
column7: the effortless cool of keyboardist/singer Brigid Dawson
column8: the pulsating low end of Petey Dammit
column9: and the steel-solid rhythmic anchor of Mike Shoun. With unspeakable chemistry and an instinctual bond that borders on telepathic
column10: the band has taken its wildly cacophonous and setlist-free live show to must-see status
column11: turning music venues populated by arm-folding spectators into anarchic riot scenes. An Oh Sees show is a place where combing the floor for your shoes when the house lights come on becomes ritualistic
column12: where getting kicked in the face by a renegade crowd-surfer provokes a shit-eating grin instead of a scowl. Most of the band's best albums serve as recorded documents of their live sets; you can practically hear Dwyer swallowing microphones and spitting upwards to the rafters.

column1: Castlemania-- Thee Oh Sees' first record of 2011-- made it easier to remember that the band started out as Dwyer's solo project
column2: a vehicle forged as a left turn from the eardrum terrorism of his garage-punk cult heroes Coachwhips. Rife with kaleidoscopic woodwind arrangements and vocals akin to the green cartoon monsters that grace the cover art of many Oh Sees full-lengths
column3: the record was a refreshingly weird slab of hallucinogenic psych-pop
column4: a headphones record for the arty garage-rock über-faithful. (You know
column5: the kind of people who own more than two volumes of Back From the Grave or take a road trip to Gonerfest every single year.)

column1: The opening seconds of Carrion Crawler/The Dream feature the squawking of a saxophone-- the last remnants of Castlemania's woodwind-centered psychedelia sputtering out like smoke from a 1920s automobile that ran out of gas. Just as Castlemania was the apotheosis of Dwyer's cracked vision as a singer/songwriter
column2: Carrion Crawler/The Dream showcases the full-band version of Thee Oh Sees at the height of their powers. Many of the album's songs have been road-tested for over a year
column3: and Intelligence brain-trust Lars Finberg was drafted as the band's second drummer. Instead of disrupting the dynamic
column4: Finberg fits in perfectly
column5: occasionally adding some polyrhythmic flair
column6: bolstering the already tight and rock-solid rhythm section. Dammit
column7: Shoun
column8: and now Finberg serve as the grounded basis that allow the songs to veer off on wild tangents without completely falling apart.

column1: Having the bassist and two drummers holding everything in place gives the high end room to explore
column2: a task in part handled by the extraordinary vocal interplay of Dwyer and Dawson. In spite of the former being the creative nucleus of the band
column3: there is no ""lead singer"" designation in Thee Oh Sees-- Dwyer and Dawson singing nearly every lyric in unison. As Dawson's straight-laced vocal presence stays in line on most of the songs
column4: Dwyer naturally plays the madman
column5: his voice coasting below
column6: zigzagging between
column7: and occasionally even scaling above hers-- the latter reminiscent of the way Black Francis would often take the higher octave over Kim Deal on several Pixies tracks. Dawson provides poppy ""ba-bas
column8: while Dwyer shouts his head off on ""Contraption/Soul Desert""
column9: and she's there to eerily coo while he's practically speaking in tongues on ""Crack in Your Eye"". But more often than not
column10: it sounds like Dwyer is singing backup for Dawson
column11: a testament to how equal the parts in Thee Oh Sees really are.

column1: Scratching away at his strings with bloodthirsty ferociousness
column2: Dwyer's guitar playing is best described in terms usually reserved for feral cats. His solos are not as much foot-on-the-monitor
column3: spotlight-capturing moments as they are products of primal instinct. This is particularly evident on the album's two longform tracks
column4: the two songs that combine to make up the album's title. Much like last year’s ""Warm Slime""-- the audio equivalent of a pro-wrestling iron man match-- ""Carrion Crawler"" and ""The Dream"" experiment with what happens when you tighten things to a breaking point and then let go. Short blasts of distortion leave their mark throughout the album
column5: guitar  tones evoking the image of exploding paint cans in a mid-size room
column6: adding to the unruly spirit of the band's albums  and live sets. See
column7:
Thee Oh Sees understand the intrinsic value of making a huge mess.

column3: Boris' self-mythologizing has been the most interesting part of their project. They've thrown plenty of curve balls since forming in 1992
column4: but after 2005's Pink

column1: Atsuo (drums/vocals)
column2: Wata (guitar/vocals)
column3: and Takeshi (bass/vocals) were quiet after 2008's forgettable grab-bag Smile
column4: but they've made up for the silence with three 2011 releases
column5: Attention Please
column6: Heavy Rocks (which echoes the 2002 release of the same name)
column7: and New Album
column8: a generically titled collection that reinterprets tracks from those other records: ""Party Boy""
column9: ""Hope""
column10: ""Spoon""
column11: and ""Les Paul Custom '86"" from AP; ""Jackson Head"" and ""Tu
column12: La La"" from HR II. The 10-song collection
column13: first released in Japan this past March before this rearranged/remastered version
column14: is their most unabashed pop experiment; offering a dollop of sugary atmospherics and dewy hooks. The band insists on labeling this new angle ""extreme
column15: though only because it's an extreme shift by a group best known for its doom metal and fuzzed-out rock. (It makes more sense than you might want to assume that they recently toured with New York City dream-pop group Asobi Seksu.)

column4: and the guy has a way with Candy Land gloss. All of the Attention Please and Heavy Rocks tracks sound better here-- chewier
column5: more refined nuggets. But in most cases
column6: it's more a comment on the quality of the other records than a heap of praise for this one.

column1: When the formula does succeed
column2: the results do dazzle. ""Spoon"" offers a swirl of shoegaze detailed with chimes
column3: synthesizers
column4: atmospheric female vocals
column5: and various bright
column6: shiny things. In this case
column7: as with NA's other best moments
column8: Boris leave remnants of their usual sound within the gentler field: Bigger-than-twee drums
column9: flanged feedback
column10: and a heavy bass hold the elements together. You also get this in the shredding
column11: cascading guitars of the amped ""Tu
column12: La La"" and the mellower closer
column13: ""Looprider""
column14: a new track that comes off like Boris doing Yo La Tengo (via Sonic Youth). The best song
column15: though
column16: is ""Luna""
column17: a rush of gurgling
column18: humming dynamics that continues to hectically spiral upward for its eight minutes and change
column19: creating soaring
column20: stringed
column21: crunchy goodness. (The original appeared on Adult Swim's Metal Swim compilation.) The other real standout-- kinetic
column22: sunburst opener ""Flare""-- didn't appear elsewhere before New Album.

column1: But not everything works so well. Drummer/vocalist Atsuo told Rolling Stone the two albums that provided much of the source material were put together from ""one abandoned record."" You don't often see Boris short on ideas
column2: largely because they can't seem to let them go--  even if they're running them into the ground. Here

column4: hollow at the core. The slow
column5: stoned bedroom-psych of the new song ""Pardon?"" bores. The sketchy
column6: dorky techno pop of Attention Please's ""Les Paul Custom '86"" and Heavy Rocks' Jackson Head"" annoy (Boris as 8-Bit Muse?). During these stretches
column7: you can hear the band struggling to write songs from outside their area of expertise. A pop song can look like a  pop song
column8: but that doesn't mean it is one. And as pretty as it can be
column9:
New Album is another minor Boris album in a string of minor Boris albums.

""It's pretty much all I listen to
column2: Meghan Remy told me when I asked her about pop music last year. ""It's the only thing I am really influenced by."" That might come as a surprise when you hear the music of her solo project U.S. Girls
column3: which buries simple melodies and vocal hooks under layers of noise and echo. She's even turned pop classics like Bruce Springsteen's ""Prove it All Night"" and B.J. Thomas' ""I Don't Have a Mind of My Own"" into basement dirges. But according to Remy
column4: her lo-fi approach is more financial necessity than aesthetic choice. ""I would love to make a really clear recording
column5: she said in the same interview. ""It's my dream!""

column1: That dream is realized on U.S. Girls on KRAAK
column2: which is significantly cleaner and less cacophonous than her previous two full-lengths. The increased clarity reveals some true pop gems
column3: especially the stunning ""Island Song""
column4: in which Remy's expressive singing sounds both stirring and exultant
column5: inspiring chills and smiles in equal measure. Nearly as good are tracks bearing the influence of doo-wop
column6: Motown
column7: country
column8: and R&B. Remy's love of the latter is especially clear in a Residents-like reworking of Brandy and Monica's ""The Boy Is Mine"".

column1: An album made solely of tunes like that would be strong enough
column2: but what makes U.S. Girls on KRAAK great is how Remy mixes in sounds that are just as odd and idiosyncratic as her previous work. For every melodic nugget
column3: there's a hallucinatory loop
column4: a cloudy drone
column5: or what sounds like the remnants of an exploded pop song-- half of a chorus
column6: shards of a hook-- echoing in the distance. In lesser hands
column7: alternating experiments and tunes could come off forced or gratuitous
column8: but Remy connects them in a way that sounds natural and almost effortless. So when the creepy
column9: voice-in-head ""Wells Dubs"" flows into the Patsy Cline-styled ""Peotone""
column10: it's far from jarring. Instead
column11: you can hear how Remy approaches minimalist loops and pop hooks as if they were the same thing and capable of the same infectious effect.

column1: Remy recently signed U.S. Girls to FatCat
column2: so even glossier
column3: higher-fidelity work might be in her future (and will perhaps come in a longer format
column4: as U.S. Girls on KRAAK lasts only 26 minutes). If so
column5:
this album is a perfect launching point in that direction. But it's also a triumph on its own. Remy has widened and universalized her music without losing a drop of what previously made it so special and personal.

The first time I saw Calexico live was in 1998

column7: D.C.

column11: bass
column12: and various other instruments. The sound was larger and louder

column15: Burns and Convertino still approach Southwestern musical and oral traditions through the lens of indie rock records and film scores. And that approach has proved much more durable and rewarding than it might have seemed when they were openers instead of headliners.

column1: So it's fitting that this major retrospective release from the band isn't a greatest hits

column8: instruments
column9: and musical genres. Packed together as Road Atlas 1998-2011
column10: they form a compelling history of Burns and Convertino's partnership as they broke free of Giant Sand and Friends of Dean Martinez and gradually discovered what all they could do on their own. The vinyl set is almost a real-time account of a band feeling its way forward
column11: and the fact that they never intended for these LPs to be ""real"" Calexico releases means they didn't have to worry about adhering to any particular approach or dynamic. Calexico could be a slippery entity
column12: reassessing the possibilities with every note. In that regard
