column1: Even so
column2: Road Atlas is by its very nature and limited availability (only 1
column3: 100 were released) aimed at diehard fans. Selections from Road Atlas proves more accessible
column4: albeit not quite as revelatory or as immersive. Instead of adhering to strict chronology
column5: the CD is sequenced to play like a Calexico album
column6: which means
column7: like Feast of Wire or Carried to Dust
column8: it alternates between vocal-heavy songs and instrumental interstitials. It's not too difficult to distinguish early songs like ""El Morro"" from later tracks like ""Man Made Lake""
column9: but the juxtapositions can be illuminating. With its full sound and Burns' desperate vocals
column10: ""Griptape""
column11: from 2005's The Book and the Canal
column12: sets up the rough terrain of ""Glowing Heart of the World
column13: from 98-99 Road Map
column14: creating a dynamic that flows from Burns' vocal melody on the former to the lonely guitar strum and crashing finale of the latter. Selections is full of such passages
column15: which blur the timeline and allow the songs to comment on one another.

column1: Even as the band has grown in lineup and in sound
column2: Burns and Convertino remain the defining elements of Calexico's aesthetic. The drummer's complex rhythms allow a song like the live version of ""Lost in Space"" to essentially turn itself inside out
column3: and he adds a jazzy spontaneity even to the rigid beats of ""Boletos"" and ""Entrenando a Los Tigres"". Burns may have started out as a slightly distant frontman with a limited vocal range
column4: which actually reinforced certain themes of in-between-ness in their songs
column5: but somewhere in the early 2000s
column6: he developed a much more expressive delivery and became a much more engaged interpreter. On the dark cover of the 19th-century lullaby ""All the Pretty Horses""
column7: he doesn't shrink from the sing-song melody or from the unsettling lyrics about flies feasting on a dead child. It's a fine showcase for both musicians
column8: actually
column9: as Convertino's drums comment on the verses with muted menace.

column1: Selections lacks the impact and narrative thrust of Calexico's best albums
column2: but it doesn't sound like a hastily assembled odds-and-ends collection either. Instead
column3: it showcases one of the band's defining and most distinguishing traits-- its ability to jumble and blur so many different styles and sounds together. Burns and Convertino ambitiously and unself-consciously assert that mariachi
column4: meringue
column5: folk
column6: jazz
column7: rock
column8: soundtrack scores
column9: and studio tinkering all exist on the same plane and all lead ultimately to the same dark desert heart. Road Atlas makes that point with more power and nuance
column10:
but Selections is persuasive in its own right.

On ""Wild Man""

column10: when it comes to modern popular figures-- who often court fame and adulation with an obsessiveness that can be fascinating or just plain sad-- Bush herself is something of a mythical beast. 50 Words for Snow is only her second album of original material in the last 17 years
column11: and she hasn't performed a full concert since her groundbreaking and theatrical Tour of Life wrapped up its six-week run in 1979. So it's no surprise that she readily sympathizes with the misunderstood monster at the center of ""Wild Man"": ""Lying in my tent

column1: But Bush continues to infuse her narratives with a beguiling complexity while retaining some old-school directness. Because while most of this album's songs can be easily summarized-- ""Snowflake"" chronicles the journey of a piece of snow falling to the ground; ""Lake Tahoe"" tells of a watery spirit searching for her dog; ""Misty"" is the one about the woman who sleeps with a lusty snowman (!)-- they contain wondrous multitudes thanks to the singer's still-expressive voice and knack for uncanny arrangements. And mood. There's an appealing creepiness that runs through this album
column2: one that recalls the atmospheric and conceptual back half of her 1985 masterpiece Hounds of Love. Indeed
column3: when considering this singular artist in 2011
column4: it's difficult to think of worthy points of reference aside from Bush herself; her onetime art-rock compatriots David Bowie and Peter Gabriel are currently MIA and in rehash mode
column5: respectively. And while current acts including Florence and the Machine are heavily inspired by Bush's early career and spiritual preoccupations
column6: none are quite able to match their idol's particular brand of heart-on-sleeve mysticism. In an interview earlier this year
column7: the 53-year-old Bush told me she doesn't listen to much new music

column9: it's easy to believe her.

column4: funny

column7: which found her classing-up and often stretching out songs from 1989's The Sensual World and The Red Shoes via re-recordings. So while ""Misty"" is an eyebrow-raiser about getting very intimate with a cold and white being with a ""crooked mouth full of dead leaves

column9: pitter-pattering drums of veteran stick man (but relatively new Bush recruit) Steve Gadd

column12: highlighting her tales of sexual taboo and bizarre yarns with look-at-me musical accompaniment and videos. Those days are long gone. And her heightened sophistication works wonders here. So when the song's titular being is nowhere to be found the following morning-- ""the sheets are soaking
column13: she sings-- there is nothing gimmicky about her desperation: ""Oh please
column14: can you help me?/ He must be somewhere.""

column1: The ending of that song brings up another common thread through Snow
column2: aside from its blizzard-y climate. This is an album about trying

column16: always losing each other along the way. It acts as something of a sequel to Bush's ""Running Up that Hill""

column1: While much of 50 Words for Snow conjures a whited-out
column2: dream-like state of disbelief

but I'm not sleepy.""

In Father James Martin's recent book

column4: Humor
column5: and Laughter Are at the Heart of the Spiritual Life
column6: he notes that some of Jesus' parables had a wry sense of humor underlying them

column1: For most music fans

column3: Ambient 3: Day of Radiance

column6: vitamin stores
column7: lucid dreaming practices

column1: And like other similarly inclined noisemakers (including but not limited to Emeralds
column2: Oneohtrix Point Never
column3: White Rainbow
column4: and Hatchback)

column7: percussive playing
column8: hazy instrument treatments
column9: and sprawling soundscapes-- as evidenced on previous albums like Local Flavor and""Puff""-- it makes a strange sort of sense that Blues Control would reach out to Laraaji for a collaborative album released as part of the RVNG label's ongoing FRKWYS series.

column1: Sonically
column2: it makes for an exquisite follow-up to the previous entry. Recorded in an upstate studio over the course of a single winter's day
column3: the four tracks that constitute the LP (not to mention the sprawling bonus tracks available via digital download and-- in a nod to the New Age genre-- cassette) feel of a piece. Blues Control's telltale murk is evident from the start of ""Awakening Day""
column4: somehow discombobulating and evocative
column5: full of echoing percussion and effervescent melodies from Russ Waterhouse's six-string and Lea Cho's electric keyboard. It actually takes a while before Laraaji's strummed zither rises to the surface
column6: only to have the elegant track slowly dissolve into sounds of running water and trickling percussion.

column1: Laraaji's effects-laden strings kick off the 11-minute exploration ""Light Ships""
column2: as do his bellowing vocal improvisations. Piano and zither ebb and rise like oceanic tides
column3: but soon that deep voice of Laraaji's turns into echoing laughter. Another belly laugh emanates from Laraaji on the half-hour bonus track ""Somebody Scream""
column4: and there's also a chuckle as the droning closer ""Freeflow"" fades from view. From where does such mirth arise? There are no definite answers
column5: but surely the body-moving drum shuffle that leads into ""City of Love"" will startle more than a few listeners as the collaboration somehow moves from Earl Young-worthy Philly disco into cascading kalimba and weightless ambiance into the sort of noise gurgle that Blues Control are expert at. Across the four tracks though
column6: it soon becomes hard to distinguish the two separate entities at play
column7: which by this point is to be expected. As the FRKWYS series continues to make evident
column8:
the perceived generation gap between bustling avant-garde noise musicians and their more steadfast New Age elder statesmen is-- funnily enough-- narrow indeed.

column3: oOoOO

column10: melody that kicks in midway through album single ""Real Love Fantasy""-- a chirpy trance homage to Mariah Carey's ""Fantasy"".

column1: ""Time""
column2: by far the EP's standout

Vague existential musings about a dead-end relationship (""I don't know where I'm going/ Guess I'm leaving/ Time keeps pushing me"") trade off with an almost celebratory refrain: ""I'm a believer."" As with the similarly worded mantra at the close of John Maus' recent We Must Become the Pitiless Censors of Ourselves

column1: EP closer ""Youth II"" offers another tragi-comic slice of technologically mediated emotion

column3: for example

it's less so.

column1: From the Smiths' first single

column1: But the Smiths weren't Morrissey-plus-some-musicians

column3: who were unflashy

column5: and supple. And they had guitarist and writer Johnny Marr
column6: who was responsible for at least half of the Smiths' glory. It's hard to neatly describe what was so great about Marr
column7: because he didn't have a particular gimmick or a signature sound; there are virtually no audible guitar solos on Smiths records. Instead
column8: he worked up a different sound and technique for nearly every song in the band's discography--the breadth of his inventiveness is a good part of what's important about him.

column1: It's safe to say that nobody else

There also aren't a lot of new wave classics with guitar lines inspired by Ghanaian highlife (and a rhythm section that's basically just playing ""You Can't Hurry Love"")
column5: but then there's ""This Charming Man"" to prove the rest of the world wrong. To have come up with the tone and riffs of ""What Difference Does It Make?"" or ""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" or ""London"" would be a coup for any guitarist; to have come up with all of them is astonishing.

column1: Released nine months after The Smiths
column2: Hatful of Hollow

column5: it's a masterpiece

The BBC session tracks have an offhanded spark and swing unmatched in the Smiths' catalog; the recent singles Hatful collects have a sense of delight that made the band whole. (""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" may be the most lighthearted song ever written about suffocating despair.) How wonderful were they at that moment? Both ""How Soon Is Now?"" and ""Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want"" had just seen release for the first time as the B-sides to ""William
column8: It Was Really Nothing"".

column4: especially

column11: but he's giggling about it. He's singing magnificently (those falsetto gasps in ""The Boy with the Thorn in His Side"" are unbeatable)
column12: Marr's redefining ""guitar hero"" to have absolutely nothing to do with machismo (he effectively invents reggaebilly on <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ownZDWNIRs"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Frankly

column1: Even after The Queen Is Dead

column5: a rewrite of T. Rex's ""Metal Guru"" about the same thing); guitar showcases about being trapped inside one's own thoughts (plus ""Ask""
column6: a singalong about how hot sex could free you
column7: yes you
column8: from that trap); and a progressively more relaxed series of meditations about how even hot sex may still not make you want to live.

column2: Here We Come

column8: it's the Smiths' album about desperately trying not to repeat themselves: Their final single couldn't have had a cleverer title than ""Stop Me if You Think You've Heard This One Before"". Morrissey's shifting into his now-familiar lyrical mode of deliberate self-parody (""Death at One's Elbow"" is effectively a camped-up burlesque of ""That Joke Isn't Funny Anymore""); Marr's doing his best to avoid the tingling Rickenbacker picking that was the closest thing he had to a default sound. That's generally a good idea here-- the autoharp he plays on the group's leavetaking

column1: Released nine months after The Smiths
column2: Hatful of Hollow

column7: and ending with the combination of ""Reel Around the Fountain"" and ""Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want"" pulls off the neat trick of casting both of them as hopeful songs. The BBC session tracks have an offhanded spark and swing unmatched in the Smiths' catalog; the recent singles Hatful collects have a sense of delight that made the band whole. (""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" may be the most lighthearted song ever written about suffocating despair.) How wonderful were they at that moment? The BBC session tracks have an offhanded spark and swing unmatched in the Smiths' catalog; the recent singles Hatful collects have a sense of delight that made the band whole. (""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" may be the most lighthearted song ever written about suffocating despair.) How wonderful were they at that moment? There have been better bands than the Smiths
column2: but there has never been a more perfect band
column3: in the sense of having a distinct
column4: deliberate
column5: powerful aesthetic shaped by the tensions of collaboration
column6: combined with the ability to articulate that aesthetic. This box of newly remastered editions of their albums-- four studio records
column7: three compilations of the singles and one-offs that were their greater strength
column8: one live obligation-- would cement their reputation for brilliance and perversity
column9: if it needed cementing.

column2: ""Hand in Glove""

column8: their proudly ashamed fascination with their home town of Manchester

column11: for instance
column12: and thinking <i>ohhh

column1: The most obvious source of their genius was their singer

column3: and spokesman

column5: a career eccentric who idolized Oscar Wilde and took a similar delight in pissing off anyone who had preconceived notions about masculinity. (Or
column6: for that matter
column7: men's singing voices
column8: or what lyrics could and couldn't say
column9: or whether or not it was a good idea to sing lines twice in a row if he was particularly proud of them.) His singing
column10: then as now
column11: was wildly affected and wildly virtuosic
column12: bursting with growls and whoops and sly over-enunciations. And his lyrics and delivery were very
column13: very deeply steeped in the history of gay culture
column14: not least that in that they mimed something like being closeted: Morrissey's claims to celibacy
column15: and early Smiths' lyrical revulsion about sex in general
column16: are kind of hilarious in the light of
column17: say

column1: But the Smiths weren't Morrissey-plus-some-musicians
column2: despite what he'd later try to suggest. They had a magnificent rhythm section in bassist Andy Rourke and drummer Mike Joyce
column3: who were unflashy
column4: tough
column5: and supple. And they had guitarist and writer Johnny Marr
column6: who was responsible for at least half of the Smiths' glory. It's hard to neatly describe what was so great about Marr
column7: because he didn't have a particular gimmick or a signature sound; there are virtually no audible guitar solos on Smiths records. Instead
column8: he worked up a different sound and technique for nearly every song in the band's discography--the breadth of his inventiveness is a good part of what's important about him.

column1: It's safe to say that nobody else
column2: before or since
column3: has opened a significant rock album by hammering the bejesus out of the capoed
column4: open-tuned chord that begins ""The Headmaster Ritual""-- Marr has called his riff what Joni Mitchell ""would have done had she been an MC5 fan."" There also aren't a lot of new wave classics with guitar lines inspired by Ghanaian highlife (and a rhythm section that's basically just playing ""You Can't Hurry Love"")
column5: but then there's ""This Charming Man"" to prove the rest of the world wrong. To have come up with the tone and riffs of ""What Difference Does It Make?"" or ""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" or ""London"" would be a coup for any guitarist; to have come up with all of them is astonishing.

column1: Released in early 1984 after a couple of singles (and rapturous British press) had built up a buzz around the band
column2: The Smiths is a terrific record
column3: and also a slightly frustrating one: It's not quite the Smiths as we know them. (If they'd all perished in a terrible double-decker bus plunge immediately after its release
column4: it'd certainly still be some kind of cult item
column5: but we'd think of them as a much grimmer band
column6: much more rooted in the smoky
column7: post-punk worldview.) Starting a debut album with a slow
column8: six-minute song that hints at working out memories of child abuse through painful sex (""Reel Around the Fountain"") was a particularly audacious move
column9: undercut by overdubbed lounge-act keyboards played by Paul Carrack (the guy who'd sung Squeeze's ""Tempted""). Most of Morrissey's lyrics on The Smiths
column10: in fact
column11: allude to awful doings involving adults and children-- its closing track
column12: ""Suffer Little Children""
column13: is explicitly about the Moors murders.

column1: Musically
column2: they weren't entirely on track yet: Mike Joyce's drums have that big
column3: early-MTV boom
column4: Morrissey's showing off his voice's capabilities even when he doesn't have much of a melody to apply them to
column5: and the bizarre punk rock speed-up of ""Miserable Lie"" doesn't particularly suit them. But their aesthetic was already wholly formed-- the album's murk
column6: sexual frankness
column7: and situational ambiguity were a reaction against the British pop landscape of its time. The Smiths were already a singles band
column8: too
column9: and the album goes from ""quite good"" to ""remarkable"" halfway through
column10: when Marr breaks into the delicious opening riff of ""This Charming Man"" and Morrissey finally gets laid.

column1: Released nine months after The Smiths
column2: Hatful of Hollow
column3: a thrown-together collection of radio sessions predating the studio album and tracks from singles
column4: could've been a lesser companion piece to it. Instead
column5: it's a masterpiece
column6: a snapshot of a band moving too quickly to get a bead on. It's a much happier album than The Smiths-- the sequencing turns Hatful's miscellany into something like a narrative about pickups and breakups and relationships
column7: and ending with the combination of ""Reel Around the Fountain"" and ""Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want"" pulls off the neat trick of casting both of them as hopeful songs. The BBC session tracks have an offhanded spark and swing unmatched in the Smiths' catalog; the recent singles Hatful collects have a sense of delight that made the band whole. (""Heaven Knows I'm Miserable Now"" may be the most lighthearted song ever written about suffocating despair.) How wonderful were they at that moment? Both ""How Soon Is Now?"" and ""Please Please Please Let Me Get What I Want"" had just seen release for the first time as the B-sides to ""William
column8: It Was Really Nothing"".

column1: Meat Is Murder-- which followed Hatful by a mere three months-- is better recorded than The Smiths
column2: although it's more a bunch of songs that didn't fit on singles than a coherent album. When it's good
column3: it's great: ""The Headmaster Ritual""
column4: especially
column5: is full of chills-down-the-spine moments from Morrissey (the wordless
column6: yodeling chorus that rhymes with ""I want to go home/ I don't want to stay
column7: the second verse's thrilling deviations from the first). ""That Joke Isn't Funny Anymore"" is a legitimately uncanny slow one that builds up to a bullseye triple-entendre-- ""it was dark as I drove the point home""-- then recedes
column8: surges back up
column9: and fades away again. Still
column10: Morrissey's often painfully out of tune on Meat's lesser songs
column11: and a lot of tracks here stretch out at considerable length. That works remarkably well for ""Barbarism Begins at Home""
column12: seven minutes of tense funk
column13: but flops for the title track's tedious
column14: eye-rollingly earnest animal-rights manifesto.

column1: 1986's The Queen Is Dead is the one studio album where the Smiths are operating at top capacity all the way through: they're aggressive
column2: funny
column3: rueful
column4: tuneful
column5: inventive
column6: cryptic
column7: tender
column8: murderously furious at everything from Dear Old Blighty to their own miserablist selves
column9: and let's underscore that ""funny"" again. Morrissey's refusing to take anything entirely seriously
column10: particularly matters of life and death (you can practically hear him waggle his eyebrow as he tells Her Majesty ""you should hear me play pi-anner"")-- he's got his wrist taped to his forehead
column11: but he's giggling about it. He's singing magnificently (those falsetto gasps in ""The Boy with the Thorn in His Side"" are unbeatable)
column12: Marr's redefining ""guitar hero"" to have absolutely nothing to do with machismo (he effectively invents reggaebilly on <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2ownZDWNIRs"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""Frankly
column13: Mr. Shankly"")
column14: and the band's at ease with its capacity to speak for every sullen
column15: curious
column16: baffled teenager. Morrissey and Marr's production sounds remarkably undated
column17: too-- the marvelous line in ""Bigmouth Strikes Again"" about Joan of Arc's Walkman is now an anachronism twice over
column18: but otherwise the album could pass for a really great product of 2011.

column1: Even after The Queen Is Dead
column2: the Smiths kept cranking out those three-song EPs
column3: so two competing anthologies of their creative overflow appeared in early 1987. The World Won't Listen came out in the U.K. five weeks before Louder Than Bombs appeared in the U.S. They've got 12 songs in common
column4: some in slightly different versions; of the five other songs on World
column5: three are reprised from The Queen Is Dead and one from Meat Is Murder
column6: and the last is an instrumental. The World Won't Listen starts very strongly-- its first half is singles and might-as-well-have-been-singles-- and then dissolves into a mess of slow
column7: maudlin songs
column8: interrupted by the chirruping of <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=giT_zL8YIcA"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">""You Just Haven't Earned It Yet
column9: Baby"".

column1: Louder Than Bombs augments the 12 core tracks with the not-yet-on-album-in-America songs from Hatful of Hollow
column2: along with the material from the ""Sheila Take a Bow"" single. It's much better sequenced than World
column3: arranged into four six-song suites on the original double LP: hard-headed rockers about being a socially maladjusted freak (plus ""Half a Person""
column4: a soft-skinned lament about the same thing); warped pop songs about frustrated desire (plus ""Panic""
column5: a rewrite of T. Rex's ""Metal Guru"" about the same thing); guitar showcases about being trapped inside one's own thoughts (plus ""Ask""
column6: a singalong about how hot sex could free you
column7: yes you
column8: from that trap); and a progressively more relaxed series of meditations about how even hot sex may still not make you want to live.

column1: The Smiths broke up a few months after they recorded 1987's Strangeways
column2: Here We Come
column3: so it's tempting to hear it as a premonition of the band's doom
column4: as opposed to the album with ""dead"" in its title
column5: the album with ""murder"" in its title
column6: or the album about murdered children. Even more than that
column7: though
column8: it's the Smiths' album about desperately trying not to repeat themselves: Their final single couldn't have had a cleverer title than ""Stop Me if You Think You've Heard This One Before"". Morrissey's shifting into his now-familiar lyrical mode of deliberate self-parody (""Death at One's Elbow"" is effectively a camped-up burlesque of ""That Joke Isn't Funny Anymore""); Marr's doing his best to avoid the tingling Rickenbacker picking that was the closest thing he had to a default sound. That's generally a good idea here-- the autoharp he plays on the group's leavetaking
column9: ""I Won't Share You""
column10: is thrilling-- although the orchestral whomp on a few songs is overdoing it. And the fact that they're devoting so much energy to a song about being annoyed by the record business suggests that they might have been about to pass their sell-by date anyway.

column1: To be fair
column2: ""Paint a Vulgar Picture"" is both funny and painfully accurate about the fate of the Smiths' music after the Morrissey/Marr team split. Rank
column3: released after Morrissey had launched his solo career
column4: is useful as the Smiths' only full-on live album
column5: and as a document of the brief era when Craig Gannon was their second guitarist (the Queen Is Dead tour
column6: basically). It's also a contractually obligated piece of barrel-scraping
column7: and the onstage Smiths were not what they'd once been-- they would play only six more complete gigs after the one recorded here. They're still pretty on-point
column8: and it's fun to hear them swing through a verse of Elvis Presley's ""(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame"" as an introduction to ""Rusholme Ruffians""
column9: but it's uncharacteristically inessential.

column1: And then there was nothing left to do but reissue! Repackage! Remaster! Complete follows the Best... sets
column2: Singles
column3: The Very Best of the Smiths
column4: <i>The Sound of the Smiths
column5: and a few other cash-ins (even this set has an ultra-limited and exceedingly pricey deluxe version). The new mastering job
column6: by Frank Arkwright working with Marr
column7: actually is really good: loud but not bomb-level loud
column8: clear
column9: and airy. (Hatful of Hollow
column10: in particular
column11: is dramatically improved from its previous incarnations.) On the other hand
column12: ""Complete"" is a profoundly inaccurate description of this set. Including both The World Won't Listen and Louder Than Bombs exceeds completeness; omitting the band's non-album tracks means the loss of some decent-to-terrific live B-sides
column13: a bit of later-period filler
column14: and the magnificent ""Jeane"". Well
column15:
they never claimed not to be perverse.

column5: better known as Four Tet
column6: like he's forgotten the clip of the tune that opened their 2007 album

column1: But Reid's story has never really been a tale of quitting. A teenager drummer in New York
column2: he famously gigged with James Brown and the Vandellas before serving a two-year prison sentence for his Vietnam evasion. He returned to the kit upon release
column3: eventually forming his own group (with at least one really great album to their name) and working with legends spread across several different forms-- R&B legend Dionne Warwick
column4: astral jazz traveler Sun Ra and African icon
column5: and iconoclast Fela Kuti. In 1986
column6: he even added a touch of percussion to Miles Davis' Tutu. But for a player who was drumming with the stars by the time he was 16
column7: much of the success and steady work that might've seemed logical for Reid mostly proved elusive. Through the 1990s and into the first half of the last decade
column8: his output could be described
column9: at best
column10: as a trickle. But that all changed when
column11: as legend has it
column12: Hebden watched Gustafsson perform at the Oslo Jazz Festival in 2004. He decided he needed a drummer and
column13: more importantly
column14: a collaborative partner. After Hebden
column15: Reid's trickle became something of a deluge. The two first played together in 2005
column16: and Hebden played on parts of Reid's fantastic record for Soul Jazz that year
column17: Spirit Walk. They summarily released two albums
column18: The Exchange Sessions Vols. 1 and 2
column19: recorded in a single day at London's Exchange Mastering Studios.

column1: Hebden's albums as Four Tet had often seemed about a sort of robotic composure
column2: pairing an elegant sense of melody to a composer's eye for development; these collaborations with Reid
column3: though

column5: in playing with more interest in the perfect personal musical moment than pristine dance-floor momentum. Reid and Hebden continued to flirt with flashes of brilliance on 2007's Tongues and 2008's NYC
column6: but they never seemed to cash in on their true potential. Sometimes
column7: it seemed
column8: Hebden couldn't push away from his compulsion to build big songs
column9: no matter how hard Reid banged the drums at his back.

column1: On South Bank-- the most vital and essential document of Reid and Hebden's five-year partnership-- it feels clear that
column2: at least onstage
column3: they were finally able to go the distance. The invocation ""Morning Prayer"" opens slowly
column4: circling in space with a meditative calm. For 17 minutes
column5: the pair traces lines around the other's rhythm

column7: and vice versa. Back in 2006

column8: too

column13: focused marches (""Untitled"") as they are with open-ended textural explorations (""25th Street"")
column14: this one-time-only trio understood its own extremes-- and how to navigate breathlessly
column15: relentlessly
column16: and brazenly between them.

column2: Reid's fatigue turns out to be only a passing notion. Just three minutes in

like he wants to keep going.

The work of Carter Tanton is relatively unknown outside of tight-knit indie circles
column2: but there's already evidence to suggest he's going to be a lifer. In 2007 he released a record of bullish roots rock with Tulsa titled I Was Submerged
column3: only for that band to disintegrate before their potential was fully realized. Tanton has subsequently worked with Marissa Nadler and Baltimore art punks Lower Dens
column4: establishing himself as a guitarist with both bands. His presence in Lower Dens continues
column5: but he has also found time to record Freeclouds
column6: an all-over-the-map solo effort that tugs strongly on the aura of David Bowie's ""Wild Eyed Boy From Freecloud"" for inspiration. Tanton is more rooted in earthly matters than Bowie
column7: lending much of this record an agrarian feel that meshes with surges of serrated energy
column8: perfectly intersecting his work with Nadler and Lower Dens.

column1: Part of Tanton's appeal to other players surely comes from his studio skills. Freeclouds was mostly recorded at home
column2: but you'd never know it. Tracks like ""Murderous Joy"" and ""Saturday"" may bear tinny drum sounds
column3: but it sounds like an aesthetic choice rather than one forced upon him. Like a lot of people in his position
column4: Tanton's biggest strength is as a composer and arranger rather than a lyricist. There's a mid-section on ""Murderous Joy"" where all the clutter drops away for a few seconds and an affected guitar sound sags and swoons
column5: digging out a feeling of loss that reaches somewhere far more meaningful than his strained Wilco-lite vocals.

column1: But this is an album of ever-shifting modes
column2: where Tanton's singing remain constantly fluid
column3: occasionally spreading out toward a Chris Martin-style rush (""Landlines"") and sometimes wallowing in a lower registry lament reminiscent of Bradford Cox in his Atlas Sound guise (""Fake Pretend""). His desire to process his voice on multiple songs perhaps suggests he hasn't found his feet as a singer yet
column4: although it's more likely to tie into his need to constantly dabble with the overall sound. The most successful experiments are prized out of the glitchy electronics Tanton likes to work with-- ""Gauze of Song"" bears a fizzy backing that sounds like old analog circuitry burning out and going haywire
column5: while ""Pasture Sound"" fixes bright acoustic plucking to a bed of rippling beats that are all buried in a warm coat of fuzz two-thirds of the way through.

column1: There's a sense of hippy idealism that pervades throughout Freeclouds
column2: edging toward the kind of wide-eyed sentiment John Lennon practiced at his least cynical. That feel is best manifested in Tanton's Lennon-like cover of ""Saturday"" by Sparklehorse
column3: which sits at the center of this record and unfolds with an ease that the stilted material elsewhere never quite reaches. It's not clear what Tanton wanted this album to be
column4: especially when he takes wild diversions into the Mary Chain-isms of ""Horrorscope"" and the pitch-bent shoegazer-y backing of ""Land Lines"". It's a loose collection of whims and desires
column5: unrolled over vast expanses of terrain that Tanton could survey for a while to see how they fit. That makes sense for someone who has made a career of gifting his talents to a diverse collection of other artists
column6: but further solo ventures could use some big picture thinking to add the edge of clarity Freeclouds is lacking.

When I was first exploring bass music
column2: Pinch and Shackleton were gateway artists. Both masters erecting sickly
column3: muted environments
column4: their dub(step) was arty and sprawling enough-- both made use of Middle Eastern samples-- to lure an American rock-kid into England's dance culture. The two artists have been quiet lately: Pinch retreated into dance-oriented 12""s in addition to curating his Tectonic imprint
column5: while Shackleton moved to Berlin and released some minimal techno for a minimal-techno label (an excellent one). Announced and released last week by the astute Honest Jon's label
column6: Pinch & Shackleton is a welcome return to each artist's peculiar roots.

column1: Despite obvious common ground
column2: Shackleton and Pinch achieve their thick headspaces in different ways-- Shackleton the austere
column3: death-obsessed perfectionist and Pinch the reggae-savvy producer unafraid to let a mediocre rapper sully his tracks. Rather than a summing of styles
column4: Pinch & Shackleton plays as a vision of what bass music was a half-decade ago
column5: two producers' onetime vision of progress. It benefits massively from a lack of artists interested in these sounds: In 2011 bass music is brighter
column6: or deeper
column7: or more aggressive.

column1: P&S is not very bright or deep or aggressive; its nine tracks often file forward with quiet confidence but without explicit purpose. The duo stresses clarity: Synths float well above Shackleton's exacting percussion (its complexity dialed back here)
column2: sub-bass rumble
column3: and vocal samples applied judiciously. When the music floats hazily by
column4: such as during the opening minutes of ""Levitation""
column5: it is an intentional
column6: manicured float. Four minutes into ""Cracks in the Pleasuredome"" the duo dials up shards of a Middle Eastern vocal cadence
column7: and I'm reminded of a type of mystical-industrial fantasies Pinch and Shackleton are capable of conjuring. ""Selfish Greedy Life"" chatters ominously
column8: little demons competing for attention with steam-vent bursts and saucer-like patches. ""Monks on the Rum"" is the duo's palette stretched on putty
column9: diffuse and manipulated but no less composed.

column1: This is not the foggy
column2: soft-focus paranoia of an artist like Burial
column3: whose work has informed so much underground electronic composition; Pinch and Shackleton don't want to suggest darkness; they want to create it. They do so with familiar tones and structures
column4: but ones that remain effective: see
column5: after three minutes of whispering synths and whinnying flutes
column6: if the bass drop of ""Burning Blood"" doesn't make you smell something. In 2011
column7: Pinch and Shackleton are a sensory experience; their waters are crystal clear
column8:
but sometimes you don't want to know what's at the bottom of the lake. Let's be excited they're showing us again.

Cristi Jo and Jessica Zambri earned their first major notices when they showed up
column2: quite suddenly
column3: as back-up singers at Hooray for Earth's buzzy CMJ performance in 2010. (Jessica Zambri and Hooray frontman Noel Heroux are married.) The two bands subsequently traded remixes
column4: resulting in the cleanly anthemic ""Heather"" and peculiarly incoherent ""Comfortable
column5: Comparable"". The latter was a technological massacre: almost a cautionary fable about what it will sound like if our samplers rise up against us. It didn't raise high expectations for how the Zambri sisters-- talented performers
column6: by most reports-- would fare as composers. Their debut EP
column7: Glossolalia
column8: is better
column9: but it's still a distressing piece of work overall
column10: stranded somewhere confusingly between experimental chaos and idiomatic pop.

column1: A sliver of sweet-spot exists between those poles-- the Knife basically live on it. But it's hard to hit the head of a pin with a bazooka. Zambri's open warfare against any preconceptions we might have about their experimental bona fides makes Glossolalia a chore to listen to. As means to an unclear end
column2: it stages clashes between brutishly misfiring percussion
column3: keyboard lines so aimlessly broken they're barely melodies
column4: and electronically treated vocal textures
column5: all of which cooperate only haphazardly. Drifting somewhere in the morass are the spooky refrains that inevitably get called pop hooks. The seeds of sound ideas have trouble sprouting amid all the eccentricity of style
column6: and the result is like Zola Jesus with a more prosaic vocal presence but plenty of funny noises to make up for it.

column1: The actively unpleasant ""On Call"" is a strange choice for an opener
column2: as its most substantial content is an erratic percussion track that literally sounds like fingernails on a chalkboard. It's a loud machine made of random parts that doesn't actually do anything besides grind down its own ill-fitted gears. The inoffensive but plodding ""Heather"" is more structurally lucid but harmonically blurry
column3: which makes it sound like a competent but imperfect mash-up-- just a hair off. The clarion exception is ""To Keep Back""
column4: where the drum
column5: keyboard
column6: and bass tracks were clearly designed to go together
column7: rather than seeming like a one-legged
column8: seven-armed Frankenstein. It also helps that the anesthesia from the first two songs wears off
column9: and the sisters start to really sing
column10: with humanizing swing and soul
column11: unfettered by robotic caveman and barnyard noises. It's not very ""challenging
column12: but it's a good
column13: dark electro-pop song by any measure
column14: and sounds fucking epic in the context of this slender
column15: weedy harvest. They're really good at singing! The pains they take to undermine that talent are baffling.

column1: While it doesn't reach the modest heights of ""To Keep Back""
column2: the second half of the EP is much more sensible than the first. The bouncy ""News"" boasts interesting bass and melody bits made from filtered vocals
column3: and a more palatable mystic-pop callback of the trainwreck opener probably should have just been the official version. Zambri are still promising-- we may just be hearing the growing pains of a new band figuring out what it's good at. This one seems unaware that its pop instincts are much sharper than its experimental ones. You can tell what they were going for from the title of the EP
column4:
which means speaking in tongues. But that has a double connotation of gibberish and inspiration. We get too much of the former and too little of the latter here.

One of the year's biggest threads in heavy music has centered on the loose enclave of American metal bands reshaping black metal and
column3: in turn

column8: more generalized crowds not overly concerned with someone's respective KVLT credentials. One reason for this

column11: tour
column12: and generally wear band T-shirts and tattered jeans. They're not the first North Americans to mutate black metal

column15: compared to the indie mainstream

column1: For the last 15 years
column2: Blut Aus Nord-- the one-man band French musician Vindsval-- has twisted the idea and essence of black metal into new shapes. He's added the crushing reverberations of prime Godflesh and the militant pacing of Ministry
column3: saturating some of his best moments with relentless drones and splintering noise. Several Blut Aus Nord albums are not only incontrovertible classics but also compelling evidence of the obvious-- that all this talk of metal's experimental interests is accurate

column5: either: He doesn't tour
column6: doesn't issue album lyrics
column7: and doesn't say much in public. In press photos
column8: he is often hooded and shrouded in darkness. The same hermetic mystique that's helped push artists like Jandek
column9: Burial
column10: and MF DOOM into an ironic spotlight has mostly kept Blut Aus Nord in
column11: well
column12: the shadows.

column1: But audiences historically love a trilogy
column2: a supposition that
column3: combined with black metal's recent widespread notice
column4: might deservedly help lift Blut Aus Nord out of relative obscurity. After all
column5: the first two installations of the band's three-part 777 are two of this year's best-built records. 777 Sect(s)
column6: released in April
column7: is an obliterative march through rigorous black metal
column8: apocalyptic post-rock
column9: and speaker-rattling industrial tangents. ""Epitome 4"" encapsulated that approach with vocals that sounded as if Vindsval were being strangled by the battery of drums and guitars marching around him with Teutonic precision. Through its 12 minutes
column10: the song took unpredictable turns-- dissonant counter-melodies here
column11: a choir of ghouls there
column12: even almost-pretty tones suggesting some relief in the distance. Unapologetically heavy
column13: Sect(s) was the trilogy's breathless start.

column1: The Desanctification is less extreme than its predecessor
column2: with generally shorter tracks (only the opener breaks the eight-minute mark) and even an atmospheric instrumental impasse that's as delicate as it is foreboding. Where Sect(s) raced open on a string of blast beats
column3: stage two lumbers forward with a simple mid-tempo throb. Repetitive guitar lines and stabs of noise circle sickly above. Those background coos from ""Epitome 4"" have grown into a full choir by album-opening ""Epitome 7"". (So far
column4: the series lasts just less than 90 minutes
column5: with each of its 12 tracks named and numbered as a sequential ""Epitome"".) That's not to say Desanctification is an easy-listening experience

column10: it's more dynamic than its predecessor
column11: making stops at most every point between the frantic rush of ""Epitome 8"" and the doom-like stasis of ""Epitome 12"". There's more movement
column12: more development
column13: more variety; fitting for a trilogy's middle
column14: it's where the sounds get thicker
column15: where the possibilities simply become more intriguing.

column1: Perhaps Blut Aus Nord's cult status to this point is an unwitting setup for this strange moment

column4: captured here in a so-far
column5: so-perfect trilogy-- will supplant Vindsval's lack of indie rock-ready gestures
column6: like press photos or Scion showcases. After all
column7:
777 Sect(s) and 777: The Desanctification are as distinctive and daunting as anything else that's given buzz to black metal this year.

For better or worse
column2: the science-fiction concept album is a dance-music staple. In addition to being saddled with one of the most ungainly album titles of the year
column3: Biasonic Hotsauce: Birth of the Nanocloud is the first part of a proposed trilogy of albums where UK garage/drum'n'bass/dubstep producer Zed Bias will tell the tale of… an experiment gone wrong? Something vaguely futuristic? To be honest
column4: I've listened to this thing a bunch of times now

column1: And the storyline
column2: confined to a few ignorable skits of kitschy playacting
column3: barely impinges on the music. Instead
column4: the ""Nanocloud"" concept seems more like a flimsy and silly but ultimately harmless way to unite a dozen-plus tracks that might otherwise seem to belong on wholly different albums. Like many producers who refused to go away quietly when grime and dubstep stole UK garage's thunder
column5: Bias has explored as many styles and subgenres as he's been able to get away with since his turn-of-the-millennium UKG glory days. So there's not much of a ""signature"" on Biasonic Hotsauce and certainly not much you haven't heard before if you've been following British dance music for the last 10 years. From hammering dancehall-inflected dubstep to slickly anonymous commercial house
column6: Bias treats BH like an outsider-friendly party tape
column7: heavy on the obvious hooks and boisterous rapping and layer of high-end gloss applied to even the starkest tracks.

column1: This little-bit-of-everything approach to modern UK dance culture is welcome
column2: given how alienating ""pure"" dubstep records can be for non-fans. Biasonic Hotsauce can sometimes feel like an alternate universe take on Kevin Martin's the Bug project
column3: with the nuclear-grade noise swapped out for radio-friendliness. (Or at least pirate-radio-friendliness.) But the jack-of-all-dance-trades tack also reveals that
column4: for all his restless experimentation
column5: Bias' skill set hasn't evolved much over the last decade. What he does best here-- merging the boom of Jamaican ragga with the runway-show opulence of deep house and the punchy-but-still-pop beats of R&B and soca-- sounds remarkably similar to the sound that first brought him to underground prominence over a decade ago.

column1: The great early run of tracks on BH work the same beguiling and unstable middle ground
column2: where the rhythmic dexterity of high-class dance music for grown-ups meets blunt-force street kid grit
column3: which defined the late-1990s/early-00s peak of UK garage. The low-end of ""Yagga"" has all the thuggish heaviness of dubstep
column4: but the frisky rhythms show up the genre's stereotypical thump as a drag. Though BH has enough bass wobble and crass Ibiza synth hooks to mark it out definitively as a 2011 release
column5: the drums on the first-tier tracks still have the intricate and far more interesting syncopations of old-school garage. It's sad but telling that Bias is still leaning on his biggest and best tune here
column6: 2000's uptown dancehall smash ""Neighbourhood""
column7: given a wholly unnecessary dubstep-era update for BH.

column1: After that bracing opening stretch
column2: there are a handful of half-brilliant tracks in the same vein strewn across the album
column3: especially the shiver-inducing ""Lucid Dreams""
column4: echoing the minimalist future funk and disembodied vocals that once defined UKG at its outermost
column5: without the dour murk Burial now brings to the mix. But whenever Bias leaves his comfort zone
column6: the excitement and energy drains away
column7: and he comes up with tracks that settle for being competent style exercises
column8: like ""Koolade"" with its campy take on 1980s boogie. The final trio of ""straight"" dubstep tracks are just too damn polite to even be called bangers
column9: risking neither the grossly enjoyable excess of the genre's populist wing nor the form-pushing innovation of its avant school. As so often when it comes to dance-music full-lengths
column10: Bias' good ideas get lost in the sea of makeweight stuff
column11:
and his attempt to please just about everyone results in a frustratingly spotty album.

column1: Chinoiseries

Maybe if we weren't expected to regard this as a proper album instead of what it really is-- a data dump that's enjoyable in small bursts but incredibly spotty as a total body of work-- it wouldn't be so disappointing. The issue

column1: Though basically any concert performance from Sigur Rós has been considered transcendent due to its underlying material

column12: or any identifiable language for that matter.

column1: But this format does establish commonality between the five studio albums Inni draws from and makes the sequencing and pacing spot-on. This isn't easy to do since none of them really do a good job in terms of substituting for each other. Still
column2: they heavily favor the material that came after 2005's Takk

column1: Still

column6: much like I don't hold it against people who'd rather watch an NFL game in the comfort of their own home

column8: the 15 minutes of ""Popplagid"" (aka ""Untitled 8"") are an investment when you've elected to consume ( ) in its entirety
column9: but here you have to evaluate whether it's worth taking up space that more viscerally satisfying songs like ""Gobbledigook"" or ""Gong"" could've filled.  Practically anyone can admit that two consecutive hours of Sigur Rós is a lot to take in
column10: and if you need to take a bathroom break or check your Fantasy Football lineup after ""E-Bow"" closes out the first disc
column11: there's no shame in that. After all
column12: if the point of Inni is to prove that Sigur Rós are human
column13:
why can't we be given the same luxury in their presence?

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17181/homepage_large.25953bca.jpg|Hello Sadness|5337.0|Los Campesinos!|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Arts & Crafts'
column2:
'Wichita']|2011-11-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:18:59.670974|"

The music of Los Campesinos! has always been about straddling the line between sincerity and irony. It's a tough game to play
column3: but thanks to songwriter Gareth Campesinos' wry humor and self-deprecation
column4: the band has been able to make a career out of writing songs where breakups literally equal death. The music is intensely personal
column5: but it's equally as inclusive-- Gareth paints himself as having it worse than anyone
column6: but the unspoken acknowledgment that makes the band churn is that he really just has it as bad as everyone else.

column1: Hello Sadness is the band's fourth album
column2: and though not much has changed with the band itself
column3: the ground underneath which LC! stand has shifted. Gareth's style of writing-- naked oversharing that goes far past the margins of his pad-- used to feel like a natural outgrowth of the type of discourse found at places like LiveJournal and Blogger
column4: but those mediums are dinosaurs now
column5: replaced by the opacity of Tumblr and the short
column6: controlled blasts of Twitter. Likewise
column7: the band's serrated twee is not exactly in fashion in the world of indie rock right now
column8: a truth that's an undercurrent of their announcement late last year that they would be distributing a quarterly fanzine. But
column9: if LC! are the last men and women left holding the flag for an antiquated era of indie rock
column10: it has only intensified their vitality to those looking for more than chillwave's call to tune in
column11: turn on
column12: and drop out.

column1: Though the album is arguably the band's darkest yet
column2: it starts off with both the album's peppiest song and one of LC!'s best singles to date. ""By Your Hand"" finds Gareth at the very infancy of a budding romance
column3: and it casts him as a sort of lovable hero
column4: a role that he inhabits when he's not
column5: say
column6: fantasizing about burning the skin off his hands before going to a palmist. Gareth narrates himself initiating another round of dirty texting before breaking into one of the more memorable passages he's penned: his fooling around with ""fate""-- ""a cruel mistress
column7: girl""-- who suggests that the two go back to her place
column8: where ""fate"" then
column9: naturally
column10: vomits on him. He does this with gusto
column11: which is accentuated by the chorus
column12: wherein the entire band shouts
column13: ""By your hand is the only end that I foresee."" The exuberance
column14: not just for the romance itself but for his eventual end at the hand of his lover
column15: is crucial to Gareth's ability to write songs about what happens when the relationship is at the other end of the spectrum. We know that he's always coming back for more
column16: even when the rest of us can't stomach it.

column1: Otherwise Hello Sadness is an album largely obsessed with themes of despair and images of death
column2: but Gareth is an able gallows humorist. On the album's final track he enters a slaughterhouse where he sees his guts strung up
column3: only for him to be turned away because ""his sad eyes are too much to bear."" On ""Baby
column4: I Got the Death Rattle"" he gets frostbite from scribbling dicks in the snow for every girl that wouldn't sleep with him before watching a halo slip from the top of his lover's head and
column5: presumably
column6: decapitate her. And then there is ""Every Defeat a Divorce (Three Lions)""
column7: Gareth's long-coming ode to the English soccer team
column8: wherein crosses on the pitch become crucifixes and the team's crest nearly claws him to death. It is the album's centerpiece
column9: if only because for Gareth
column10: and for a lot of us
column11: the one thing more wrenching than romance is sports.

column1: These songs are genuinely affecting
column2: though
column3: both because they explore the darkest depths of a romantic's psyche and because LC! have transitioned rather seamlessly into maturity. The fizzy
column4: excitable songwriting of their early output is far in the past
column5: and they've learned to write songs that build and swell to moments that can knock you off your feet (""To Tundra"" is the killer here). Gareth also explores his range as a vocalist to great success
column6: stretching himself to sing melodically and in a strikingly deeper voice. His vocals have long been a breaking point for many non-converts
column7: and while Gareth hasn't morphed into King Krule
column8: his impressive singing here bodes well for the future of a band whose music largely revolves around him.

column1: The buzz has long worn off of Los Campesinos!
column2: but Hello Sadness is their fourth straight great album
column3: and each of them is close enough in quality that you'd likely get split numbers if you conducted a straw poll at one of the band's shows. Even if there is no breakthrough moment for them
column4: there is something to be said for a band that is this young
column5: this consistent
column6: and this committed to both carrying the torch for and freshening up a style of indie rock that has
column7: for the moment at least
column8:
been left behind.

More than two years passed between Swedish duo Korallreven's first single
column3: the glittering
column4: acoustically-tinged ""Loved-Up""
column5: and their full-fledged debut LP
column6: An Album by Korallreven. In internet years
column7: that's practically a decade
column8: but then
column9: Korallreven and their fellow countrymen work at a pace that exists outside normal measurements of time (the exception being jj
column10: who seemingly churn out slices of heavy-lidded pop at will). It took Korallreven close to a year to follow ""Loved-Up"" with last year's ""The Truest Faith""; the arrival of An Album by Korallreven itself was promised for later in 2010. Considering bedroom dreamers have been waiting four years (and counting) for a follow-up to Gothenburg duo the Tough Alliance's A New Chance
column11: though
column12: maybe we're lucky An Album by Korallreven exists at all.

column1: They do have things in common with the Tough Alliance beyond citizenship and a leisurely working pace: Both acts are duos
column2: both embrace a color palette of popular music so widespread it's difficult to describe what they make with a catch-all descriptor
column3: and both ultimately draw deep from indie pop's dewy-eyed tradition (Korallreven especially-- one half of the band's Daniel Tjäder
column4: who spends time leafing through the Sarah and Labrador catalogues as a member of the Radio Dept.) For all their sentiments
column5: the Tough Alliance are also arch and fairly political; Korallreven
column6: on the other hand
column7: are more concerned with surface beauty
column8: applying layers of gauze that add immense
column9: weightless density to their own pop delicacies.

column1: In a sense
column2: it's music that you don't necessarily have to think about
column3: which is fine
column4: of course-- even the most bookish of Sincerely Yours/Service/Acéphale completists need something to lose themselves in now and again. The album's shortest cut
column5: ""A Surf on Endorphins""
column6: is a redux  of ""The Truest Faith""'s rolling theme
column7: awash in coyote howls and static  distance. As its title suggests
column8: the song's meant to provoke emotion
column9: albeit far from the energized sort. During the bleeping
column10: hypnotic centerpiece ""Keep Your Eyes Shut""
column11: the  phrase
column12: ""A dream within a dream
column13: is repeated like a mantra.

column1: Indie pop's history dictates that many of its practitioners are
column2: first and foremost
column3: ardent fans of the music that's influenced the music they make; accordingly
column4: Tjäder and cohort Marcus Joons come across less as artists as they do expert curators. They move from the 808s of ""As Young as Yesterday"" (a signifier reminiscent of once-label mates Salem
column5: whom Korallreven have featured in mixes frequently) to the space-disco-via-pastoral-ambient beauty of nine-minute album closer ""Comin' Down"" with the ease of a single brushstroke. The pair's series of mixes (the most recent being A Dream Within a Dream) flow with expert sequencing that betrays the amateur nature of mix culture circa 2011.

column1: It's no surprise
column2: then
column3: that An Album by Korallreven works best as an album-length experience
column4: its structure suggesting a sort of trip-- spiritual or chemical or otherwise. It's an album of quiet excellence
column5: one that aims to soundtrack your most idle thoughts while romantically demanding your attention. That said
column6: it doesn't really matter how An Album by Korallreven resonates within our world
column7:
when Tjäder and Joons are so intent in creating their own.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17189/homepage_large.9e0186e5.jpg|Hexagons EP|28544.0|Esben and the Witch|['Rock'
column3: the Brighton-based Esben and the Witch have excelled at the aesthetic component of recent goth-leaning music. Of the many emerging dark
column4: female-fronted acts
column5: they've got some of the slickest packaging
column6: complete with a name derived from a grisly Danish fairy tale and a list of ""Band Interests"" on Facebook that concludes with
column7: ""Victoriana
column8: Romance
column9: Ghosts."" The follow-up to their debut full-length
column10: Violet Cries-- a new EP called Hexagons-- takes their curative framework a step further-- it's a concept piece made up of six Roman-numerically ordered ""Hexagons"" with dramatic parentheticals: ""Hexagons I (The Fall)""
column11: ""Hexagons II (The Flight)""
column12: et cetera. Its release also coincided with a week-long webcast event called ""Hexagons Cinema""
column13: in which the band streamed a series of footage shot in the UK's oldest functioning cinema. At the very least
column14: Esben have shown themselves fine scholars of textbook aspects of spook. But much like on Violet Cries
column15: all of Hexagons' thoughtful ornamentation only emphasizes how frustratingly plotless the songs are.

column1: These songs are sparer than much of the material from Violet Cries
column2: often centered around dramatic piano lines and bare acoustic guitar sheathed in haunting echoes. The bookending tracks
column3: ""Hexagons I (The Fall)"" and ""Hexagons VI (The Thaw)""
column4: aren't even so much songs as they are brief
column5: ambient reminders of the grim mood the trio wants you to experience but seems incapable of fleshing out. By comparison
column6: ""Hexagons II (The Flight)"" and ""Hexagons III (The Surge)"" sound tightly structured and concussive. But they still fall flat: The latter
column7: for instance
column8: hints at the band's promising post-rock tendencies by building a thick
column9: apocalyptic guitar line
column10: but before it's allowed to peak and crash
column11: it peters out and devolves into more thin
column12: aimless piano. None of these cuts reach the guttural fullness of Violet Cries cuts ""Marching Song"" or ""Warpath""
column13: two strong tracks that probably should have been used as templates for Esben's future recordings. Instead
column14: they instilled listeners with what now feels like false hope. In the absence of compelling cores
column15: these songs are carried
column16: sometimes solely
column17: by frontwoman Rachel Davies' strong and brooding British-accented vocals.

column1: Hexagons also emphasizes the extent to which the indiesphere wants to embrace a goth revival in the wake of the success of artists like Zola Jesus
column2: and it highlights an experimental phase that can easily misfire. There's a sense here that these dark waters are being tested unsuccessfully
column3:
explored using well-crafted embellishments without the raw songwriting materials needed to deliver on their promise.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17190/homepage_large.97064a06.jpg|Sonne = Blackbox|27477.0|Ursula Bogner|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Faitiche']|2011-11-16 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:01.605169|"

Earlier this year Tom Ewing wrote a Poptimist column about records with interesting backstories that were probably false. The music released under the name Ursula Bogner-- first an album called Recordings 1969-1988
column2: now a follow-up collection called Sonne = Blackbox-- is an excellent example of what he was talking about. Released on Faitiche
column3: the label started by veteran electronic music producer and theorist Jan Jelinek
column4: this music is purported to come from a woman who was completely unknown during her lifetime and died in 1994. Bogner is said to have lived a life as a housewife and experimented with electronics and tapes away from the public eye
column5: and the music she left behind fits loosely with that made by BBC Radiophonic Workshop experimentalists like Daphne Oram and Delia Derbyshire.

column1: Instead of maintaining the ruse as a cynical PR cash-in-- which would be silly because
column2: let's face it
column3: very few people are going to spend money for this music-- Jelinek is treating the Bogner phenomenon as a multimedia art experiment with musical
column4: textual
column5: and performative components. This second set of Bogner-named works
column6: allegedly curated by frequent Jelinek associate Andrew Pekler
column7: comes packaged with a 130-page book that explores
column8: in pieces written in both English and German
column9: ideas of identity
column10: ownership
column11: gender
column12: and more
column13: along with probing how information is transmitted through the media.

column1: There's a piece in the book by songwriter and commentator Momus and lengthy interviews conducted by Jelinek
column2: where
column3: among other things
column4: he interrogates people on why the Bogner story seems fake. The interviews in particular are an essential part of this project
column5: because they get at how listeners construct narratives around music. One answer to Jelinek's question about the skepticism surrounding Bogner boils down to the press release being too detailed as far as her biography and making too much of her being a housewife. The exchange highlights how music journalists glean ""truth"" from the printed matter they are presented with recordings
column6: and how this exchange can be manipulated. Beyond the accompanying book
column7: Jelinek and Pekler are currently playing the music of Ursula Bogner at shows
column8: improvising new music to accompany her ""old"" tape loops.

column1: In addition to the writing
column2: the book
column3: and the live revue
column4: we also have this
column5: an album of recorded sound that
column6: given its unspecified origins
column7: exists in the context of your choosing. And I'm happy to report that the music is mostly very good
column8: especially if you are a fan of Jelinek's loop-based aesthetic and unfailing ear for texture and musical structure (an approach to sound that has a great deal of overlap with Pekler's recorded work). Whether created by Jelinek
column9: Pekler
column10: or someone else
column11: the Bogner pieces range from engaging electronic curiosities-- notable mostly for mixing vintage-sounding electronics with editing that would have been very difficult to achieve in the year they were supposed to have been created-- to hair-raising collages whose subtle force is
column12: if you're wired at all like I am
column13: completely overpowering.

column1: The pieces here have a general theme
column2: and that is the manipulation of the human voice. The opening title track mixes a banging piano loop with gorgeously rendered vocoder tones
column3: conveying that peculiarly 1950s Disneyfied optimism about the happiness of a robotic future. ""Or Dor Melanor"" consists of a female voice singing the title's words laid next to some weirdly distant vocals processed into an ascending scale. ""Shepard Monde"" is a cracked assemblage of French syllables that sort of hangs together in a twitching clump
column4: but the effect as it moves between the speakers evokes both mystery and profound beauty. ""De Planetarum Influxu"" mixes sine-wave squiggles and a deep drone with a mass of unclassifiable and machine-like voices that seem to be drifting steadily toward you
column5: and then
column6: at the moment when they could get no louder
column7: the piece abruptly cuts off
column8: ending the album on a jarring note. It all works together and there's not a dull patch on the record.

column1: The tracks without vocals mostly recall the kind of elemental electronic tinkering present on the earlier Bogner release
column2: but in ever case the dusty electronic pulses are brought to life with a sense of rhythm
column3: movement
column4: and texture that can be easily connected to records like Jelinek's Kosmischer Pitch and Pekler's Cue. If this were a new album by either of them
column5: it would be enjoyable and ultimately successful purely from a musical standpoint
column6: but packaged as it is as part of the Bogner project
column7: the music can't help but take on a different cast. If nothing else
column8: Sonne = Blackbox is an excellent reminder of Jelinek's restless muse. He made a name with an unusual approach to sound developed during the IDM heyday of the 1990s and early 00s
column9: but he's never stayed in one place long
column10:
and every project he's been involved with since offers an unfamiliar but ultimately rewarding world to be explored.

column2: Part Heart

column5:
'IRS']|2011-11-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:02.179303|"

R.E.M. spent the majority of their 31-year career putting out top-quality albums
column6: while a chunk of their audience wished they would just break up already. Though some of this was a bit reactionary and a by-product of their roots in the nascent indie rock scene of the 1980s
column7: it was mainly a consequence of one of the band's most admirable qualities-- a restless desire to reinvent themselves with each record and create a discography in which each new entry had a distinct character. This much was clear by 1984: R.E.M. could have mined indefinitely the fascinating blend of murky atmosphere and crystal clear chiming guitar parts on their debut
column8: Murmur-- lord knows many other bands of the era tried-- but they took a left turn into the sunnier
column9: more lyrically direct Reckoning and kept throwing curveballs at their audience from that point onward.

column1: This tendency yielded a rich body of work spanning 15 studio albums
column2: but the creative shifts-- however organic they may seem in context-- gave listeners valid reasons to jump ship along the way. It makes just as much sense to enjoy all their records as it does for someone who favors Peter Buck's early jangle-centric guitar style to recoil at his flamboyantly distorted tone on Monster
column3: or for fans of their immensely popular chamber pop records Out of Time and Automatic for the People to shrug off the skewed
column4: highly politicized arena rock of their late 80s records. This isn't even factoring in the uneven albums they made following the departure of original drummer and songwriter Bill Berry
column5: which spanned from the tentative lounge pop of Up to the often dreary melodrama of Around the Sun and the ""back to basics"" rock of Accelerate.

column1: With this in mind
column2: <i>Part Lies
column3: Part Heart
column4: Part Truth
column5: Part Garbage: 1982-2011-- the band's first career-spanning anthology-- does an exceptional job of presenting this body of work as a chronological survey that neatly summarizes their major themes and artistic tangents while being highly listenable. The song selection is exceptional-- a few relatively minor singles didn't make the cut
column6: but every major hit is here
column7: presented alongside crucial album tracks such as ""Country Feedback""
column8: ""Begin the Begin""
column9: and ""Life and How to Live It"". The quality of the material up through at least the middle of the second disc is unimpeachable; the sheer concentration of classic tunes makes a strong case for the band ranking among the 20th century's greatest songwriting partnerships. The set handles the band's leaner years with grace and minimal revisionism
column10: though the electronic and ambient textures of Up are sidelined in favor of that album's delicate Beach Boys homage ""At My Most Beautiful"". A few wild card selections from their more recent records
column11: such as Accelerate's ""Living Well Is the Best Revenge"" and ""Alligator_Aviator_Autopilot_Antimatter"" from Collapse Into Now
column12: shine in this context.

column1: Nearly every hits set must include previously unreleased material
column2: and this one is no different. The three new tracks featured here are the final completed songs of the band's career and serve as a coda of sorts for their recorded output. The single ""We All Go Back to Where We Belong"" is the keeper; a wistful ballad with a delightfully schmaltzy Burt Bacharach-like arrangement that barely conceals its subtext of basically being about the end of R.E.M. The other two cuts sound like a band crossing a few ideas off their bucket list before calling it a day: ""Hallelujah"" comes off like them giving one last attempt at nailing the hazy sophisti-pop they explored on Reveal
column3: while the dreadful ""A Month of Saturdays"" meets the title's ""garbage"" requirement by sounding as though they realized at the last moment that they never wrote a song about loving the weekend and scrambled to remedy that with only a few minutes of studio time.

column1: Though R.E.M.'s dissolution is not necessarily a cause for celebration
column2: having a clearly defined end point makes it much easier to grasp the scope of their achievements. Part of a collective anxiety about R.E.M.'s ongoing existence up until this year was based in a desire on the part of the audience to impose a manageable narrative on their career. Now that they have disbanded
column3: it's much easier to understand the trajectory of their post-Berry output in particular: Basically
column4: they spent some time in the 2000s trying out new sounds and ways of working
column5: but they eventually reconnected with their rock'n'roll roots before wrapping up their career with Collapse Into Now
column6: a set of songs that revisited their creative strengths. Those records are never going to as beloved as their first 10 brilliant and remarkably consistent albums with Berry
column7: but Part Lies makes a good case that their later period has value too
column8:
and that the group had raised the bar so high for themselves that merely being very good could be interpreted as a failure.

"|16032.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16032-part-lies-part-heart-part-truth-part-garbage-1982-2011/|9.4|Matthew Perpetua

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17161/homepage_large.dc614464.jpg|Cold Day in Hell|28274.0|Freddie Gibbs|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['LRG']|2011-11-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:02.590696|"

Freddie Gibbs' latest mixtape
column2: Cold Day in Hell
column3: leaked during a 48-hour-period in which new hip-hop tapes were dropping every five minutes. More than a few of these artists were capitalizing off the hype that surrounded A$AP Rocky's debut record LiveLoveA$AP
column4: a release the internet noise machine took up as its latest cause. Freddie Gibbs may remember that honeymoon period well; a couple of years back
column5: he was the focus of this ruthless media blitz
column6: an artist who rocketed suddenly from major-label reject to being mentioned in The New Yorker. It was an odd position for a rapper whose persona often felt like a simple amalgamation of 1990s Rap-A-Lot records. One of the unfortunate things about this hype cycle is its obsession with novelty at the expense of quality; Gibbs isn't a new artist any more
column7: but Cold Day in Hell is arguably his most well-rounded
column8: accomplished offering. It isn't that he's improved as a rapper
column9: but as an artist. He has recognized his weaknesses and produced a lush
column10: versatile record that works around them.

column1: Gibbs
column2: as a performer
column3: has always been a skilled technician
column4: but in the backlash that followed his early acclaim
column5: some pointed out that his rapping could be dry and impersonal. In impressing folks caught up in the theatrical onslaught of his driving delivery
column6: it was easy for fans to miss the big picture. At his weakest
column7: he is a technician first and a conversationalist second. For his core fanbase
column8: this is the appeal: gangster rap with brutality and self-control the primary goal. These shortcomings become evident
column9: though
column10: when you compare Gibbs to a rapper like Young Jeezy
column11: whose economy
column12: directness
column13: and charisma burst through the speakers on a track like ""Twos and Fews"". But what Gibbs has accomplished on Cold Day in Hell is a challenge to the reliable audience that would prefer him in autopilot mode
column14: and it actually gives his music a lot more replay value. As on his strongest releases
column15: he uses a variety of strategies that value musicality above all.

column1: A major contributor to Gibbs' success here is producer Cardo. His beats have an ethereal
column2: Clams Casino-lite quality
column3: although Cardo works in a more mercenary
column4: less brand-conscious context. There are also more than enough R&B hooks here to scare away the one-note Gibbs fan. These tracks actually introduce a tension and excitement into Gibbs' work that is often missed when he's worked with typical boom-bap production. The perfect example is album highlight ""B.A.N.ned"". Cardo's chopped-up vocal loop infuses the tracks with a haunting melancholy
column5: framing Gibbs' vocals-- always taut with aggression-- with a strong emotional undercurrent. But it's not a one-way transaction; Gibbs' dark story rap on ""My Homeboy's Girlfriend"" is a disquieting factor that charges Cardo's evocative Sade sample. Gibbs' voice is monotone
column6: but it gains a stark power when the music that surrounds it lunges for an emotional jugular.

column1: The record's diverse sound shows a wider range of influences than previous releases. SMKA's beat for the Juicy J-featuring ""Str8 Slammin'"" is a sparkling imitation of the kind of moody arpeggios the Hypnotized Minds camp pioneered a decade ago. Cardo's ""Menace II Society"" is such a pitch-perfect spiritual son of California's gangster rap peak that you'll be pulling out your Celly Cel tapes (or running to RapidShare). One of the album's best moments is ""Anything to Survive""
column2: which samples Bobbi Humphrey's ""Harlem River Drive"" and includes verses from Freeway and underrated Chicago rapper Sly Polaroid. What unites these disparate archetypes is Gibbs himself. What once seemed like a limitation-- the straightforward affect of his rapping-- now serves to balance some riskier
column3:
prettier experiments. His dimension and focus here should give pause to those who've discounted him.

"|16024.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16024-freddie-gibbs-cold-day-in-hell/|8.2|David Drake
