Gonjasufi invented intelligent demon music. The one-man boom began on last year's A Sufi and a Killer
column2: where San Diego-bred Sumach Ecks split the difference between Western aggression
column3: Eastern mysticism
column4: and extraterrestrial idiosyncrasy. Even his stage name is a compound noun: half weed
column5: half wisdom. All rolled up into a blunt
column6: banshee wail.

column1: Released on Warp
column2: A Sufi and a Killer was both futuristic and primitive
column3: a glass pyramid breaking under the weight of his psychedelic bombed squad: Flying Lotus
column4: the Gaslamp Killer
column5: and Mainframe. The evil spirit was summoned by a 32-year old ex-underground MC who found his sediment-strangled singing voice via Bikram Yoga
column6: high grade chronic
column7: and magic mushrooms. A biblically bearded original prone to Twitter jeremiads against the contemporary age of ""LITTLE SAMBO AND HIS PACK OF DEVIL WORSHIPPING BARBIES."" He routinely stresses love
column8: understanding
column9: and the violent overthrow of government-- a peace-seeking yogi who will slap the shit out of you for talking reckless. Some things are not supposed to be logical.

column1: Based in ""the Mojave
column2: the desert-dwelling prophet dropped The 9th Inning EP last month. We owe the free
column3: four-song collection's existence to an arrangement between Sufi and viral video/mixtape portal
column4: Hydroshare. He gets paid for old tracks that had been infecting his hard drives since being first recorded several years ago. We get new music to hold us over until his mini-album MU.ZZ.LE drops in January.

column1: From the first words of The 9th Inning
column2: we're sucked into apocalypse. Industrial noises clank like robots led to the guillotine. John Carpenter synths ooze and ""Demonchild"" starts with Sufi croaking
column3: ""My mama says son/ Look what the world's coming to/ My mama was right/ The sun is colored blue."" What makes Gonjasufi's music so singular is that voice
column4: suspended somewhere between George Clinton
column5: Tom Waits
column6: and something that crawled out of the La Brea Tar Pits-- prehistoric and warped from thousands of pounds of pressure.

column1: ""Eat Fish"" finds Ecks hanging ectoplasmic hooks on boom-bap drums and raps from L.A. left-fielder Blu. The chorus' moral: ""be rich
column2: eat fish
column3: and die."" It's sage advice partially cribbed from the Wu-Tang Clan's Ghostface Killah
column4: and indeed
column5: the spirit of Wu-Tang hangs heavy over this project. With its stripped down organ loops and dusted drums
column6: ""The Lows""
column7: sounds like a distant cousin to Gravediggaz and Tricky's The Hell EP. Opting to spit his tiger style raps
column8: Sufi channels the unhinged delirium of Ol' Dirty Bastard. There are cold-blooded threats of ""wandering eyes getting poked"" and the difficulties of keeping oaths not to kill when there are ""vampires walking around with smiles on their grill."" Lest you think there is a clear father to his style
column9: he calls on ""savasana"" for calm-- the corpse pose in yoga.

column1: Nor can you define the title track. It's not quite rap
column2: and even though it's partially sung
column3: it's light years from R&B. Disembodied vocals coo in the background
column4: and Sufi sounds like someone who attempted to conjure Nate Dogg at a séance and received a demented ghost from a nearby dimension. It's unclear whether he's singing or rapping
column5: and that's the point. It's otherworldly and unclassifiable. Or as he chants about a former partner
column6: ""similarities in our style
column7:
but I took it from here. I took it from here."" Enter the demon.

When Bournemouth
column2: UK-based producer BNJMN burst onto the scene with ""Blocks"" last year
column3: its beauty was as tantalizing as the lack of details surrounding its release. It came out on an Amsterdam-only 12"" with little clue as to ""BNJMN""'s identity. What we did have to go on was the gorgeous music carved into those grooves: All woozy arpeggios and fuzzy chiming chords
column4: the track felt both majestically modern yet mournfully nostalgic
column5: a lost artifact worn as much by time as by digital filters. It was an odd fit for a label known best for its comprehensive house reissue series
column6: but Benjamin Thomas' debut album
column7: Plastic World
column8: revealed how deep ""Blocks""'s nostalgia went.

column1: Plastic World
column2: an album mixing soft-focus IDM introspection with the ongoing house and hip-hop flirtations of so much contemporary ""bass music
column3: more than lived up to the promise of ""Blocks"". Thomas' formula felt more natural than most. What was also striking about BNJMN was not just that he nailed his reference points (ambient and bleep techno
column4: early Warp Records)
column5: but that he had little disregard for what was going on around him aside from what he could and lift and mould to his own specifications. Even when he was playing with familiar structures-- sometimes he sounded like Teebs
column6: other times he sounded like early Autechre-- there was something wonderfully private about it all
column7: as if he were coming at these ideas from behind some impenetrable screen of idiosyncrasy. It was a 40-minute album that easily swelled beyond its own meager confines
column8: a spontaneous overflow of engaging musical ideas that managed to carve a palpable pocket into an overcrowded scene even as it stared in from the borderlands.

column1: Released bewilderingly quickly-- only eight months after its predecessor-- Black Square finds its own success in the reduction of nearly everything that made Plastic World so appealing. Much like the bare cover art
column2: the music methodically removes the extraneous elements from Thomas' deliberately blurry sound and leaves every cog in the machine starkly visible. Even in a realm where repetition is the rule
column3: there's something about Thomas' work that can feel especially rigid: On Plastic World it was a smearing effect that created a dreamy swirl; on Black Square we feel all the ugly edges and jagged rims. The mechanic has a lot in common with producers currently experimenting with footwork forms and other uptempo musics: Take ""Keep the Power Out""
column4: where a harshly chopped vocal phrase and persistently ticking rimshot fashion a symphony of frantic monotony. The effect is still as hypnotic and engrossing as ever
column5: but this time it feels more tactile and real
column6: easier to grasp in its dressed-down guise.

column1: It's this new naked physicality that makes Black Square an even more exciting prospect than past work. Thomas wields the kick drum like a mighty weapon
column2: and the way the record moves from the wooden clack of ""Primal Pathways"" to its midpoint climax of ""Open the Floodgates"" is spectacular. We're given hints with the pulse underneath tracks like the whimsical ""Wisdom of Uncertainty"" and the Velvet Underground-sampling title track
column3: but when that simple kick drops a minute into ""Floodgates""
column4: it's the weight of the real world
column5: the weight of true dance music crashing into BNJMN's cultivated electronica fantasies. It's a formidable strike that highlights texture as Black Square's most important element: The tracks thereafter feel like a hangover from the relative abandon of ""Floodgates""
column6: but they're rich and sensual. The dulcet tones
column7: flinty synths
column8: and buoyant guitars of ""Lava"" are an aural feast
column9: and closer ""Hallowed Road"" is a teasingly sparse disintegration that unwinds the album through resonance and hum-and-buzz
column10: the undoing of the bubbly melodies that were the erstwhile dominant force in Thomas' compositions.

column1: Black Square is definitely not a retread of Plastic World
column2: but it's not the predictable expand-and-improve sophomore effort either. It's a brave sort of refinement that brings what was special about Plastic World into even finer relief: Brimming with opposing currents
column3: from nostalgia to fantasy to decadence and dread
column4: Black Square is not the simple world it appears to be at first
column5: yet it's simple enough to digest. At 32 minutes
column6: it makes a heavier indent than its lengthier sibling and is a more assured statement than most dance albums. It doesn't matter that it comes on one of house music's most lauded archival labels
column7: because BNJMN's music is timeless
column8:
and it belongs on an imprint known for securing dance music history rather than one focused on its trendy and fickle future.

"|15986.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15986-black-square/|7.8|Andrew Ryce

'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Season of Mist']|2011-11-15 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:04.798891|"

Think of Cynic as an expatriate from the land of extreme metal. As with other restless-spirit heavy outfits from Nachtmystium to Mastodon
column3: you can still detect an original accent in the work of this L.A.-via-Miami band; but at this stage
column4: they're speaking a whole other language-- call it pop-savvy prog. And on Carbon-Based Anatomy
column5: Cynic's second EP since an outstanding 2008 reunion full-length
column6: Traced in Air
column7: they're communicating with remarkable fluency.

column1: Cynic's roots stretch back to the fertile early-1990s Florida death-metal scene. Before issuing their own proper debut
column2: the band's co-leaders
column3: guitarist-vocalist Paul Masvidal and drummer Sean Reinert
column4: scored a high-profile freelance gig
column5: backing Death leader Chuck Schuldiner on Human. The concise title of that 1991 classic belies its groundbreaking blend of ferocity and technicality-- not to mention its inescapable influence on the next two decades of chops-happy extreme metal. (A great-sounding reissue is out on Relapse if you're curious.) The pair quickly jumped ship
column6: though
column7: and got to work on its own definitive statement
column8: 1993's rich
column9: puzzling Focus. Even on this first LP
column10: Cynic seemed to regard metal like a vestigial tail. Guest vocalist Tony Teegarden contributed anguished
column11: growling vocals that recalled Schuldiner's
column12: but Masvidal augmented his lines with a pre-Auto-Tune robot speak. And while the band indulged in outbursts of hard-hitting shred
column13: they avoided death metal's signature blastbeats outright
column14: favoring supple rhythms drawn straight from the jazz-fusion playbook.

column1: If Focus had an ugly-duckling appeal
column2: Cynic's hybrid experiment didn't pay off fully until Traced in Air
column3: which followed a 15-year hiatus. The comeback effort pushed metal even further into the background in favor of an increased melodicism; suddenly Cynic seemed like a new standard bearer for 21st-century art rock
column4: flooring you with their technicality while mashing on all your bliss buttons. The record took what it needed from extreme metal (growled backing vocals)
column5: fusion (tricky turnarounds and ornate solos)
column6: and pop (open-hearted hooks). This was a band unmoored from genre but not adrift: The songs were pointing the way
column7: rather than any regard for a clearly definable style. Underscoring that point
column8: the band followed Traced in Air with 2010's Re-Traced
column9: an EP that adapted four of the full-length's tunes in a calmer style
column10: with the metal-- and
column11: for the most part
column12: rock-- siphoned out in favor of folky pop and electronica. It was a startling move
column13: but the material held up.

column1: Carbon-Based Anatomy
column2: consisting of all-new material
column3: is more substantial than Re-Traced
column4: the next best thing to a new LP. A 23-minute suite of six continuous tracks
column5: the EP restores the band's aggressive side but only in measured doses. The three proper songs here-- presented along with a trio of soundscapey mood setters-- are easily Cynic's most accessible to date
column6: favoring straightforward verse-chorus anthems and ditching the death-metal-styled vocals outright. Yet they're also some of the band's strongest
column7: further proof that Masvidal and Reinert's core ideas are sturdy enough to withstand drastic shifts in style.

column1: The title track is a perfectly paced stunner. A sensuous
column2: tribal-y verse (which finds Reinert locking in with Focus-era Cynic bassist Sean Malone
column3: who guests on the EP) alternates with a placid guitar-and-voice passage
column4: mapping out the piece's sing-songy motifs. After a dreamy fusion interlude
column5: the aggression ramps up: Masvidal solos triumphantly
column6: and the band kicks into a stomping
column7: crunchy climax
column8: over which Masvidal recasts the earlier guitar-voice melody as a yearning anthem. Usually not one to present his vocals undisguised
column9: he sings sans effects here and achieves a new emotional directness. The track lasts more than six minutes
column10: but it feels trim
column11: even radio-ready. It's fitting that Masvidal sings about transcending the body (""Drop the knife/ Leave your arms behind/ Just for a moment""); on a piece like this
column12: Cynic sounds fully liberated
column13: not just from their metal past but from any aesthetic concern other than assembling a great song.

column1: Carbon-Based Anatomy might be relatively conventional
column2: but thanks to Masvidal and Reinert's idiosyncratic virtuosity
column3: it doesn't come off as bland. Masvidal shines on the EP's two other core tracks
column4: ""Box Up My Bones"" and ""Elves Beam Out"". On the former-- like the title track
column5: a catchy
column6: profoundly dynamic mini opus-- the guitarist whooshes in during a mid-song breather
column7: playing a gorgeous series of notey trills and demonstrating how he's re-purposed his metal-honed chops in the service of pure textural beauty. In ""Elves Beam Out""
column8: a strange
column9: dazzling little song
column10: he connects the dots between John Lennon and Yes' Steve Howe
column11: moving from gloomy
column12: ""I Want You (She's So Heavy)""-style riffage to feverishly grandiose filigree. Throughout the release
column13: Reinert deftly balances ornament with groove. On the ""Carbon-Based Anatomy"" verse
column14: he peppers his beat with a flurry of tasty tom and snare accents
column15: while on the ""Elves Beam Out"" chorus
column16: he blends brisk bass-drum stutters and half-time cymbal accents into an infectious stop-start pattern.

column1: Carbon-Based Anatomy's three remaining tracks-- bookends ""Amidst the Goals"" and ""Hieroglyph""
column2: which feature chanting and narration from singer-songwriter Amy Correia
column3: and mid-EP breather ""Bija!""-- set aside chops in favor of atmosphere. (James Cameron's sci-fi-meets-New Age mysticism is an apt reference point for the moods these pieces conjure.) Unlike the songs that sit next to them
column4: this material depends entirely on context. Listen to the release front-to-back
column5: and they function as respectable palate cleansers and thematic signposts; but consider them individually
column6: especially the tablas-and-chanting-heavy ""Bija!
column7: and they scan as too mundane
column8: paling next to the ecstatically inventive material that surrounds them. To be fair
column9: Cynic has skirted this line since Focus
column10: which wasn't without its over-the-top moments; there
column11: as with Carbon-Based Anatomy
column12: though
column13: the quality of the surrounding songs is too high for it to matter much.

column1: Lofty as it is
column2: the text Correia speaks in ""Hieroglyph"" resonates strongly with Cynic's creative ambitions. She tells of a soul who's been ""blown to all corners of the universe… his whole being an explosion into infinity."" When she observes
column3: ""No walls/ No specific personality
column4: it's hard not to think of Masvidal and Reinert's fearless two-decade-plus quest to evolve
column5: their willingness to cast off metal-oriented trappings that no longer suited their compositional needs. For a band that's come this far
column6: maybe a metaphor involving the transgalactic dispersion of the soul really is appropriate. When you're functioning at as high a level as 2011-model Cynic
column7:
you're entitled to a bit of grandiosity.

column1: The same could be said of Drake

column3: Take Care. Running with Gaye's ghost

column1: In this age of reality television

column4: creating an ever-morphing
column5: ever-more-self-aware new normal-- Drake is an apt avatar. Naturally

column9: ""In a time where it's recreation/ To pull all your skeletons out the closet like Halloween decorations."" We can thank Kanye West for legitimately kicking off this open-book hip-hop era
column10: and it's increasingly apparent that Drake is the most engaging new rap star since Ye. While fame causes some to withdraw and cling to what little privacy they have left
column11: this 25-year-old Canadian's penchant for poetic oversharing has only been emboldened by his success. When he's not making the most epic drunk-dial song in pop history with ""Marvins Room""
column12: he's openly pleading with former flame Rihanna on the record's title track
column13: or duetting with Twitter wife Nicki Minaj on ""Make Me Proud"" only to call out such publicity-baiting ""relationships"" two tracks later
column14: where he raps
column15: ""It look like we in love
column16: but only on camera."" With its startlingly frank talk and endless heartbreak
column17: Take Care often reads like a string of especially vulnerable-- and sometimes embarrassing-- Missed Connections.

column1: This time around
column2: Drake has a better grasp on his own notoriety and the mind-fucks that come with it. While he expressed wonderfully wounded trepidations about his sudden rise on Thank Me Later
column3: he's learning to embrace it more here. ""They say more money more problems
column4: my nigga
column5: don't believe it
column6: he raps on closer ""The Ride"". ""I mean
column7: sure
column8: there's some bills and taxes I'm still evading/ But I blew six million on myself
column9: and I feel amazing."" And on ""HYFR (Hell Ya Fucking Right)""
column10: he all but gives away his hand

And while he claims ""I think I like who I'm becoming"" on ""Crew Love""-- about as ringing an endorsement you'll get from a guy so bent on exposing his own disappointments-- he's still more interested in contradiction than triumph. Even when staring at a pair of unnatural breasts
column12: he highlights the incision rather than the size: ""Brand new girl and she still growing/ Brand new titties
column13: stitches still showing/ Yeah
column14: and she just praying that it heals good/ I'm 'bout to fuck and I'm just praying that it feels good.""

column1: Just as his thematic concerns have become richer

Its subtlety is a direct rebuke to the rash of in-the-red Eurotrance waveforms clogging up radio dials. Even the more upbeat tracks take pains not to rely on a simple thump. ""Take Care"" features Rihanna and a four-four beat

column8:
taking it all in.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17178/homepage_large.ea884dd7.jpg|Bangs & Works Vol. 2|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-11-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:05.887095|"

When the first Bangs & Works compilation was released by Planet Mu last year
column2: it emerged in a climate of controversy and accusations surrounding its authenticity and propriety
column3: with some seeing it as a document of a Chicago scene as viewed by certain UK electronic tastemakers. This time
column4: however
column5: the circumstances feel simpler: Footwork influences and references are the norm for a whole international world of ""bass music
column6: and the questions of exploitation and gimmickry seem to have been put to rest
column7: or at least pushed aside. Good timing
column8: too-- the second Bangs & Works is a marked improvement over its predecessor; as if unconcerned with being comprehensively representative to outsiders
column9: its curator
column10: Mike Paradinas
column11: can delve into the very depths of the sound's weirdness.

column1: Part of the reason that footwork proved so fascinating to so many different sectors of dance music simultaneously was its unforgiving extremity: Sonically rough and rhythmically brutal
column2: it laced together latent impulses from jungle
column3: breakcore
column4: and house into something that sounded like mutant hip-hop-- booty house gone berserk. Compatible with so many universes yet still alien enough to be ineffably hip
column5: it was the outsider of music of 2010 that stubbornly fought its way into the conversation. Hip-hop and R&B samples were the theme of the first Bangs & Works
column6: emphasizing the Chicago scene's connection to and identification with hip-hop culture
column7: but the focus on the second has changed.  Instead of the staccato vocal clipping and syllabic repetition
column8: you're more likely to hear swerving synths or pounding drums on Bangs & Works 2
column9: a document of the scene that emphasizes its house roots.

column1: The first track sets the mood appropriately: RP Boo's ""Heavy Heat"" is a stormer of sub-bass and grim horn stabs
column2: nary a vocal to be found outside of Boo's own producer tag drops (a common sound on Bangs & Works 2). There are still tracks with vocals-- rapping on DJ Earl's ""Hit Da Bootz""
column3: chipmunk crooning on DJ Solo's ""What Have You Done""
column4: hype-man hypnosis on DJ Roc's ""Get Buck Juice""-- but they're the exceptions. Instead we get the lush synth-funk of DJ Rashad & Gant-Man's ""Heaven Sent"" or the pendulous insanity of DJ T-Why's ear-piercing ""Finished"". That same producer's ""Juice"" and tracks from DJ Metro like ""Smak My Bitch Up"" show how dissociative and trippy footwork can be without sacrificing its crucial danceability-- not that it was ever easy to dance to in the first place.

column1: It's two new-- to Mu
column2: anyway-- producers who run with that weirdness
column3: standing out on the compilation's most progressive moments.  Young Smoke provides vivid psychodrama with his string of lush tracks at the compilation's end
column4: like the sparse funk of ""Space Muzik Pt. 3""
column5: not too far from a Pearson Sound production. But it's Jlin who steals the show early on with ""Erotic Heat""
column6: all tremulous low-frequency throbs
column7: cracking snares
column8: and drum patterns that snake and writhe with unusual precision. So many footwork producers are content to let their tom-toms skate across a slippery surface of undulating sub-bass
column9: but Jlin's are unusually tactile and exact
column10: little miniature cascades unfolding separately at will. Sharing the same Mortal Kombat sample as DJ MC's ""Y Fall"" but utilizing it so much more effectively
column11: Jlin proves what makes her particularly special with the swampy psychedelia of ""Asylum""
column12: harboring some of the hardest and heaviest-hitting percussion of any footwork track released on Planet Mu to date.  Jlin's tracks are captivating because she relocates footwork's focus
column13: rendering those bass rumbles even more isolated as she scatters the percussion to far-flung corners of the stereo spectrum. Her tracks show not only footwork's room for experimentation but the raw power that shines through even its weirdest moments.

column1: Just like its older brother
column2: Bangs & Works 2 is an exhausting listen
column3: 80 minutes of intense syncopation spread over 26 dense nuggets.  But whether it's the generally higher production values this time around or simply a more agreeable palette
column4: the whole thing feels a little easier to swallow.  It's hard not to jump from track to track getting excited with each producer that steps up to the plate
column5: almost enough to override the sometimes slipshod feeling of compilations like these-- and with the newfound thematic coherence
column6: hodgepodge isn't an issue.  Paradinas' library of footwork tracks numbers well over 1
column8: and he's done an admirable curatorial job of finding some common threads in a sea of cobbled-together mania.  No longer dealing with the pressure to bring a new sound to the masses
column9:
he's instead coaxed out one of its most curious aspects for a disc of strange musical delicacies likely to appeal as much to footwork fanatics as those looking for new avenues for the avant-garde.

There's a common misconception that you need CliffsNotes
column2: or perhaps a Ph.D. in Carey Mercer
column3: to enjoy a Frog Eyes record. This is because a Frog Eyes record often sounds like a Shaksepearean play on amphetamines

column7: the soundscapes around him melting into a hallucinatory drip.

column1: It's true that Mercer's music is demanding and dense (along with his Swan Lake cohorts Spencer Krug and Dan Bejar
column2: he seems perennially intent on treating the album like an epic poem)
column3: but there are also plenty of thrills on the surface. Somewhere in the last Frog Eyes album
column4: Paul's Tomb: A Triumph
column5: there was a knotty narrative of violence
column6: guilt
column7: and redemption
column8: but-- check the soaring
column9: firecracker riffs on ""Styled By Dr. Roberts"" and ""Lear in Love""-- it was also a hell of a guitar record. (There's even something morbid about his choice of gear: Mercer got the guitar tone on that record by using old
column10: dying amps.)

column1: Similarly
column2: Skin of Evil
column3: the second proper record from his solo project
column4: Blackout Beach
column5: was full of luxuriant texture. Even the lyrics themselves possessed a phonetic beauty. Who is Donna
column6: the elusive muse who haunted Skin of Evil? An obscure goddess from a test you failed in high school English? No
column7: Mercer's said he just likes the way the name sounds-- it reminds him of ""dawn."" So it is with Fuck Death: a record like any other
column8: best listened to with the search engine browser closed and the encyclopedia left on the shelf. The story's there should you wish to untangle it
column9: but don't let it distract you from the luminous atmosphere and synth experiments whose rewards lie much closer to the surface.

column1: ""Did you ever think of yourself as a runaway?"" Mercer murmured on an unusually hushed moment of Frog Eyes' clanging
column2: 2007 opus Tears of the Valedictorian. Throughout his career
column3: he's been preoccupied with themes of masculinity
column4: cowardice
column5: and destiny. How fast must a man run to outpace his own fate? Or
column6: perhaps a better question
column7: one he probably should have asked before he started running: Where can he go? Set during wartime
column8: Fuck Death takes inspiration from soldiers' desertion to probe these dark themes. The pulse of hypnotic opener ""Beautiful Burning Desire"" beats
column9: ""We got to run away/ Run run away/ Going to run away
column10: while the corroding
column11: industrial tones of ""Torchlights Banned""
column12: featuring backing vocals from Frog Eyes keyboardist Megan Boddy
column13: underscore the tenderness and urgency of a letter home: ""I'm going to be a while/ I'm in a fortress of flame/…And your love is all I shall stand for/ And I'm standing in the rain.""

column1: Unlike the more recent
column2: guitar-heavy Frog Eyes records
column3: the sound of Fuck Death mostly comes from intricately layered monophonic synths. In the middle of ""Beautiful Burning Desire""
column4: they take on the ominous quality of air-raid sirens; on ""Torchlights Banned"" they are the commanding chop of helicopter blades; and perhaps most effectively
column5: during the narrator's flight from his camp on ""Be Forewarned
column6: the Night Has Come""
column7: they give the impression of searchlights. On paper it probably seems too literal-- like avant-garde Foley art-- but the tones Mercer employs effectively create an atmosphere of chilly foreboding
column8: and their luminous tones also provide a sonic link to the record's thematic preoccupation with light and darkness. Mercer generally throws so many ideas at you that you're left huffing and puffing with barely a moment to process it all
column9: but Fuck Death is the first record of his that feels like a genuine meditation on the themes it explores. Instead of pummeling
column10: it actually awards the listener with moments of pause
column11: making its atmosphere that much more immersive.

column1: Throughout Fuck Death there's also Mercer's requisite musings about art and the artist (""You should be ashamed
column2: Philistine
column3: goes one ironic
column4: spittle-filled taunt) on which you can faintly detect him grappling with his own persona-- obstinately refusing to go easy on us
column5: to crack a smile
column6: or to let in some light. It's this monochromatic darkness that ultimately makes it a less compelling record than his pal Bejar's 2011 offering Kaputt
column7: and in particular its closing number
column8: the irresistible
column9: cagily autobiographical
column10: 11-minute-roller-skate-jam-on-quaaludes ""Bay of Pigs"". ""Bay of Pigs"" is indulgent and artful
column11: but it's also breezy and inviting
column12: the kind of song you'd play for those who have previously dismissed Destroyer as being pretentious or an acquired taste in the hope that it might convert them. There are no such songs on Fuck Death
column13: and so the Mercer camps will remain divided. His admirers will find this record beautiful in the strangest places
column14: while his detractors might choose to see its occasional impenetrable gloom as a kind of desertion in itself: In the end
column15:
he's still running from us.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17176/homepage_large.24367aa9.jpg|Pan Am Stories|29974.0|Rangers|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Not Not Fun']|2011-11-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:07.025550|"

Rangers' 2010 album Suburban Tours brought to mind alienated youthful evenings spent in identikit housing
column2: so cut adrift from the world that the only place to escape was deep into your own head. Skip forward a year
column3: and we have Pan Am Stories
column4: an album title that's superficially linked to the process of escape
column5: tied into a company that went bankrupt after misjudging the flux in demand to get away from it all. Rangers is a solo project conducted by the San Francisco-based Texas transplant Joe Knight
column6: who put out a flurry of cassette-only releases on As Above So Below and his current label Not Not Fun toward the end of the last decade. Suburban Tours was a surprisingly concise effort after the freeform sprawl of those releases
column7: but the central Rangers sound-- dense layers of fudgy guitar melancholia engulfed by acres of tape dust-- remained intact.

column1: On Pan Am Stories
column2: Knight attempts to build a better link between his past and present selves
column3: retaining some of the expansiveness of earlier Rangers releases and stacking them up against exercises in cropped lo-fi pop. It's a double album
column4: with many tracks stretching well over the four-minute mark
column5: and a focal point in ""Zeke's Dream"" that runs to 13-and-a-half minutes. That song
column6: like most of the others here
column7: is marked by a strangulated guitar tone reminiscent of the heavily processed work Jonathan Donahue and Grasshopper were dabbling in on Mercury Rev's Yerself Is Steam. Like that band
column8: Knight appears obsessively occupied with severing open altered states of consciousness through his music. ""Zeke's Dream"" feels like several different songs all pushing one another out of the picture
column9: with the feverish playing cascading through basic riffing
column10: rippling solos
column11: and even some Tangerine Dream-like keyboard drones.

column1: It's no surprise
column2: then
column3: that a search for Rangers throws up a story of people tripping balls to the ever-unfolding Low Cut Fades cassette while driving through the desert. That tale seems particularly appropriate when you consider Knight's fascination with travel
column4: where the mode of getting somewhere appears more attractive than the final destination. In a sense
column5: that's how Rangers' most expansive music plays out too. ""The Mule""
column6: at the back end of this album
column7: is a loosely woven ballad that ebbs and flows as keyboard noise and fat guitar excess is worked in. Despite those elements
column8: it never deviates from its central riff
column9: which coils over and over
column10: locked down in a journey with no particular goal in mind. Even at its most tuneful
column11: on tracks like the poppy and more tightly structured ""Luncheon Ghana""
column12: there's a sense that these songs are fragments of works that could easily be pushed out into ""Zeke's Dream""-sized spaces.

column1: What makes Pan Am Stories worth returning to is the scope Knight works within
column2: where elements of prog
column3: folk
column4: and psychedelia blur in and out of focus
column5: often mirroring the superior work Bristol explorers Flying Saucer Attack were practicing in the 1990s. At times it does lag
column6: especially when the buried-in-the-sand vocal exercises on tracks like ""Khyber Pass"" and ""Sacred Cows"" don't add much to the overall picture. But it feels like Knight is finding his confidence as a singer here
column7: perhaps prepping to step out of the dimly lit corner he was sporadically crooning into during the making of this record. In particular
column8: the twinned ""Zombies (Day)"" and ""Zombies (Night)"" are among his most fully formed pop efforts yet
column9:
indicating that his music can be as much about design and execution as it is about voyage and discovery.

"|16028.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16028-pan-am-stories/|6.2|Nick Neyland

column2:
True Whore|5778.0|Leviathan|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2011-11-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:07.682535|"

On the morning of Sunday
column3: January 9
column4: the tattoo artist Jef Whitehead was arrested in Chicago on charges of sexual assault and domestic violence. According to the Chicago Tribune
column5: Whitehead-- a specialist in colorful and morbid depictions of demons and reapers-- was working as a guest at Taylor Street Tattoo following an international inking tour. After midnight
column6: he got in a fight with his girlfriend and
column7: as a Tribune reporter wrote
column8: allegedly ""used the tools of his trade to sexually assault his girlfriend after he slammed her head against a floor and choked her."" Whitehead posted bail and
column9: 10 months later
column10: has yet to go to trial.

column1: For more than a decade
column2: Whitehead
column3: under the name Wrest
column4: has been pressing the bounds of black metal
column5: adding psychedelic textures and hints of mid-tempo punk to fairly brutal marathons. By himself as Leviathan and the great Lurker of Chalice
column6: and with the misfiring supergroup Twilight
column7: Whitehead made weird
column8: unexpected moves within United States Black Metal long before the form broke into indie rock circles or The New Yorker's pages. He's long been heavy on horror and violence
column9: too
column10: with song titles like ""A Bouquet of Blood for Skull""
column11: ""I Miss Watching You Die"" and
column12: notably
column13: ""The History of Rape"". He often wrote and spoke of suicide and
column15: told an interviewer that being alive at least allowed him ""to voice anti-human disgust."" Still
column16: his arrest was surprising and a big deal; for the last 10 months
column17: questions about him have become boilerplate in extreme metal interviews.

column1: The inevitable summary of Whitehead's January arrest isn't meant to romanticize the actions of the occasionally violent black metal scene
column2: or to give him the Burzum-sized brand of black metal authenticity. It's not meant to scorn Whitehead
column3: either
column4: as he has yet to be convicted of anything. Rather
column5: as Whitehead admitted in a rare interview with Pitchfork's Brandon Stosuy in September
column6: the incident and subsequent fallout served as the inspiration for his most recent album
column7: the unashamedly titled <i>True Traitor
column8: True Whore. ""The true harlot has been revealed
column9: ” Whitehead wrote in the email interview. ""[<i>True Traitor
column10: True Whore] is most definitely an expression of what I've been thru in the past year... Everyone's met one by now
column11: I'd imagine-- not too cryptic.""

column1: At the risk of sounding dismissive
column2: <i> True Traitor
column3: True Whore sounds like the work of a one-time innovator who's since been preoccupied. Sure
column4: as on with almost all Whitehead releases
column5: the multi-instrumentalist starts from a rigorous base of black metal and floods that sound with extrinsic influences. ""True Whorror"" sprints with a near-grindcore jolt
column6: while ""Shed This Skin"" intersperses black-metal blurs with moments of funeral doom and glimpses of thrash heroics. On ""Harlot Rises""
column7: an acoustic-guitar breakdown clashes with sound effects that mimic industrial 1980s drums. There are drones and noise
column8: post-rock climbs
column9: and smoldering comedowns
column10: too. But True Traitor often circles back or collapses on itself
column11: with many of these eight songs eventually devolving at various points into messy psychedelic maelstroms that
column12: compositionally
column13: Whitehead doesn't seem good enough to redirect. On ""Contrary Pulse""
column14: he builds tension by slowing the song's tempo
column15: allowing its more aggressive elements to claw against its dirge-like undercarriage. It's an intriguing setup
column16: but he never capitalizes on that unease
column17: eventually letting the song escape into a web of meandering guitar. What starts with a roar ends
column18: then
column19: with an unsatisfying whimper. Leviathan's best work has been about pushing momentum from one extreme to another; on True Traitor
column20: that sense of movement is generally squandered
column21: as Whitehead struggles and frequently fails to make his many strains of interest cohere.

column1: What's more
column2: for a sub-genre that's not only itself full of interesting ideas but that's also recently spawned compelling sounds in other niches
column3: True Traitor feels redundant. Leviathan has done brutal black metal better than this (see 2006's too-brief The Blind Wound)
column4: and he's previously been much more convincing when tying that ferocity to outside sounds (see 2008's great Massive Conspiracy Against All Life). At various points here
column5: Whitehead sounds like a less developed Locrian
column6: a smaller Wolves in the Throne Room or a less intricate Absu. Thematically
column7: <i>True Traitor
column8: True Whore is a work of pure juvenilia
column9: comprised of songs with puns for titles that would be more understandable coming from the pen of a pimply 13-year-old boy aggravated by the rage of puberty. There's opener ""True Whorror""
column10: the chaser ""Her Circle Is the Noose""
column11: and the mid-album ""Every Orifice Yawning Her Price"". Not only are those titles ripe for parody (and prosecutors)
column12: but they're also repetitive
column13: another symptom of the unimaginative core at work throughout Traitor. Leviathan's 2004 album
column14: Tentacles of Whorror
column15: already cashed in on a lot of these jokes; it was a much better album
column16: too.

column1: Since January
column2: some critics and listeners have advocated for a yimakh shemo approach to Whitehead
column3: meaning that-- if the charges against him are true-- his work should be ignored
column4: his musical legacy ruined by the deplorable thing he might have done. Without Wrest
column5: though
column6: it's impossible to imagine black metal's current stateside currency or creativity. He's made some remarkable records that have rightfully had a widespread effect on many of the bands that followed him. <i>True Traitor
column7: True Whore isn't ultimately dismissible because of what Whitehead allegedly did in January; rather
column8: it is dismissible because it does not improve what he certainly did for the decade-plus prior
column9: which was to help map new territory in a field that has since raced forward independently-- and ahead
column10:
it seems-- of him.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17174/homepage_large.69b59191.jpg|Replica|28187.0|Oneohtrix Point Never|['Experimental']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Mexican Summer'
column2:
'Software']|2011-11-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:08.214124|"

Everyone who reads about music has a list of descriptors made meaningless by overuse. ""Hazy"" (rhymes with ""lazy"") is right up there for me
column3: but another that makes me wince though I've used it myself dozens of times over the years  is ""cinematic."" It's the term we reach for with instrumental music because movies are where we first learned about the emotional impact of abstract sound. If we'd have grown up in the silent era
column4: we'd be leaning on different adjectives
column5: but given our level of ""moving image + instrumental music"" saturation
column6: ""cinematic"" is what comes to mind. Fair enough. In the past
column7: the music of Oneohtrix Point Never-- the main project of the busy producer Daniel Lopatin
column8: also of 1980s pop revivalists Ford & Lopatin-- fit this term. Albums like the Rifts collection and 2010's Returnal had drones and moods and thematic shifts that hinted at some kind of on-screen drama. And Lopatin has said that he's been influenced by film music and would love to work on movie scores. But the new OPN album
column9: Replica
column10: which also happens to be Lopatin's best work to date by far
column11: is coming from somewhere else. This is music that exists independently
column12: each track a tiny universe with its own cracked logic.

column1: A few people have mentioned the Books to me in reference to this album
column2: and the comparison holds water. It's not that Replica sounds anything like the Books-- though it uses tight loops of sampled voices
column3: the voices exist to convey texture rather than language-- but Lopatin shares with them a fresh ear that creates an uncanny sense of wonder in the music. Also like the Books
column4: Replica puts a premium on silence; just as important as all the odd
column5: hard-to-place sounds is the space that frames it. And the combination of unusual textures and all the room
column6: plus the way the music seems unbound to any particular era or aesthetic
column7: makes the whole thing feel playful. The music is by turns dark
column8: ethereal
column9: frightening
column10: and silly
column11: but regardless
column12: it carries in it a feeling of joy. There's a real sense of discovery here
column13: or possibilities being probed
column14: and that feeling is infectious. You can hear the person making it getting deep into what these sonic elements could mean
column15: and he's bringing us down into this fantastic place with him.

column1: Aside from the intricate production detail
column2: what's most striking about Replica is how well-constructed these tracks are
column3: which is especially impressive given the record's brevity (the first nine average less than four minutes each). Each has an arc and the music is constantly changing
column4: but the tracks go into unexpected places. The opening ""Andro"" starts with a lonely
column5: distant synth tone and fuzzy layers of robo-voices before becoming overtaken by noisy samples and
column6: eventually
column7: an explosion of percussion from what sounds like a a digital jungle. ""Sleep Dealer"" starts off like a pop version of a Steve Reich tape piece
column8: zeroing in on percussive phonetic ticks and a loop of a human sigh
column9: but it gradually resolves itself in an almost geometric way
column10: as the relationship between the various samples snaps into focus just before the ending. The title track pulls us out of the machine by starting with a simple piano figure and then folding in bits of synth and finally a buzzing drone
column11: becoming something alien and foreboding after starting so warm and melancholy. Lopatin doesn't just introduce sounds
column12: add loops
column13: and fade out; his pieces move
column14: tripping from one place to somewhere far away over the course of just a few minutes.

column1: A couple of tracks
column2: like ""Submersible"" and ""Remember""
column3: come closer to the pure synth drone work that marked earlier OPN material
column4: but even these are full of weird surprises
column5: like the distorted and warbly vocal loop at the tail end of ""Remember"" that manages to sound like a field recording of some ancient religious rite
column6: even though it's probably something like a processed syllable taken from a life insurance advertisement. ""Remember""
column7: like the album as a whole
column8: feels peculiar and just out of reach
column9: and it makes me realize how hard it is these days to find music imbued with genuine mystery. A huge part of the fun with this record is that these sonic miniatures are truly puzzling even as they remain accessible and highly musical; Replica is ""experimental"" music that also feels open
column10: and somehow
column11: despite coming out of two speakers like all my other records
column12: it manages to feel participatory. I can feel myself filling in space and making connections as I listen.

column1: Most film music is functional and is meant to reinforce images and amplify what's happening in the story. It is manipulative by design
column2: serving to bend the affect of the viewer in accordance with the director's wishes. These 10 tracks are packed with detail and rich with feeling
column3: but they are also
column4: to a strange degree
column5: devoid of manipulation. Even though they're uniformly stirring
column6: they don't point you in any direction in particular
column7: and you could see each listener creating his or her own meaning. Instead of pushing
column8: they serve mostly to draw you closer and remind you of the power of sound as sound. Lopatin may have used samples from 1980s commercials to create many of these tracks
column9:
but Replica doesn't use nostalgia as an end in itself. This is music that digs deeper and burrows beneath the level of shared associations to discover the sparkling emotional potential of carefully arranged vibrations moving through the air.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17149/homepage_large.e98144dd.jpg|King Krule EP|29959.0|King Krule|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['True Panther']|2011-11-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:08.681395|"

This summer's riots in London were unique in that a great deal of those taking part were essentially kids-- young people whose opportunities have been squeezed tight over the past years with widespread youth unemployment and huge University fees. Generational divides can often make the things young people do seem kind of alien
column2: and the riots-- with no spokesperson and no manifesto-- were difficult for some people to comprehend. At just 17 Archy Marshall
column3: aka King Krule
column4: belongs to that frustrated section of the populace
column5: and although he told Pitchfork recently that he didn't riot himself
column6: he understood why others did.

column1: His debut EP might not be overtly political lyrically
column2: but there's a wellspring of tension and bleakness running through the record that taps into those feelings of discontent that hung in the air this summer. Often the tension in Marshall's songs is restless and unresolved. ""Lead Existence""
column3: for example
column4: builds for just a minute before snapping shut on the line ""I lost the soul to my blues
column5: a long time ago""-- in itself a pretty haunting line for somebody so young.

column1: Then there's his voice
column2: which doesn't seem like it should come from a figure so slight-- it's at turns gruff
column3: deep and often cracked. There are shades of Leonard Cohen in that delivery and a similar drawl at times to Billy Bragg (who himself championed Marshall back when he was going under Zoo Kid). It's an expressive voice
column4: changing and morphing with the mood of the songs. On ""Bleak Bake"" Marshall sounds more laidback over a canvas of dubby keys
column5: 808 drums
column6: and deep bass. That calm delivery makes the violence in the lines
column7: ""My heart got hold of my head and ripped it to its seams
column8: and
column9: ""Now I'm covered in blood on the bed/ And its a familiar scene
column10: seem all the more chilling.

column1: While most of Marshall's lyrics can be bleak or even violent
column2: the instrumentation almost always strikes a warm contrast. There's beauty in the clean
column3: echoing guitars that are all over King Krule and some unexpected moments too-- the jazzy stand-up bass on ""363N63"" or the string hits in ""Bleak Bake""
column4: for example. These textures and sounds lend a redemptive
column5: hopeful quality to the music.

column1: EP highlight and closer ""The Noose of Jah City"" is the most complete and focused song on the record. It pivots on an echoing guitar line and sparkling keyboards as Marshall's vocal
column2: enveloped in reverb
column3: spills across that background. In the verses he sounds poised
column4: imagining his own death
column5: stoically predicting
column6: ""My body found
column7: but my soul was left to drown/ Suffocated in concrete."" Marshall's anxiety about his mind and soul is a recurring motif throughout the EP and
column8: like the beauty in some of the instrumentation
column9: makes for a detached
column10: almost mystical contrast to the kitchen-sink vibe of the rest of the drama.

column1: There's a documentary realism to much of these recordings
column2: from Marshall's cough at the start of ""Bleak Bake""
column3: to his spoken introduction to ""The Noose of Jah City"". Those moments make you feel like a voyeur sneaking a listen to a work in progress. If there's one flaw
column4: it's that King Krule does seem quite slight in its brevity
column5: and ideas are often left to hang in the air rather than chased to their conclusion. But the record also feels like an important moment in time marked on a door frame-- it's an intriguing peek into the restless
column6:
youthful development of King Krule.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17158/homepage_large.0bcd2c4f.jpg|Atlantis|28128.0|FaltyDL|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2011-11-11 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:09.138540|"

Drew Lustman (FaltyDL) has had a busy year. The New York garage/house/whatever producer dropped his second album
column2: You Stand Uncertain
column3: to much acclaim. With the arrival of the four-track Atlantis EP on Ninja Tune
column4: he has also released several EPs/singles of material frequently more vibrant than that which graced the album. (The best of these
column5: ""Hip Love""
column6: received a Jamie xx remix and stands as Lustman's finest track to date
column7: as well as one of Jamie's finest re-works.) Always difficult to pin down
column8: Atlantis proves Lustman hasn't run out of tricks; on a track-to-track basis
column9: it's his most eclectic
column10: challenging release
column11: jumping nimbly between styles
column12: tempos
column13: and moods over the course of each song.

column1: Atlantis serves as a showcase for its title track
column2: a five-minute bruiser that is equal parts menacing and optimistic. Built on a powerful
column3: pulsing bass progression
column4: Lustman slips in garage's trademark syncopated percussion; the effect is like hearing Four Tet's streamlined ""Love Cry"" mischievously tweaked then pushed into the red. When the drums momentarily collect and simplify themselves
column5: they act as a release valve for the bass' budding steam. Lustman might have had an anthem but instead chose nervy
column6: sustained energy
column7: and it seems wilier as a result.

column1: The remainder of Atlantis is more scattered but no less enjoyable. ""Can't Stop the Prophet""
column2: in particular
column3: feels like a breakthrough: sharp orchestral samples rub against detuned snippets of a dusty torch song
column4: creating enough friction for the drums to slip into 180bpm drum'n'bass. The sampledelic joy of the Avalanches mingles with bass music's natural paranoia and the result is bliss-y
column5: idiosyncratic mindrock. The final two songs
column6: ""My Light
column7: My Love"" and ""The Sale Ends""
column8: hew closer to Lustman's trad garage work
column9: but they're more variant in tone and structure than much of You Stand Uncertain
column10: employing ringing laser blasts and croaking anti-divas.

column1: Atlantis is the most manic
column2: undecided release for Lustman to date. Shiftiness can be a curse in dace music-- a realm that often asks its tracks to play nice with others-- but he changes gears frequently in the name of contrast and genuine surprise. Lustman
column3: whom I enjoy more with each subsequent release
column4: already stands as one of the most productive and reliable American dance producers. At the rate he's been putting out music
column5:
it may not be long before he removes those qualifiers.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17146/homepage_large.60f3205e.jpg|Empros|4785.0|Russian Circles|['Rock'
column3: Empros-- the fourth LP from mostly instrumental Chicago trio Russian Circles-- marries light to dark
column4: order to chaos. Empros swings from the exceedingly beautiful to the punishingly physical in seconds flat. Every note on Empros is its right place
column5: every surface scraped-up just so; a recent Decibel writeup found bassist Brian Cook claiming he'd never make another record ""from the ground up"" like the meticulously constructed Empros. Shame
column6: that; as on 2009's swarmed-with-strings Geneva
column7: the expanse charted by the grandiose Empros is very vast indeed.

column1: Building on the strides they made on Geneva's adventurous first half
column2: Russian Circles complicate the drift-and-build of most post-rock
column3: injecting craggy climaxes
column4: letting the low end take the lead. Highlight ""Mlàdek"" finds a rousing
column5: almost Broken Social Scene-style guitar chug careening headlong into a patch of black metal-inspired ballast; the shift in tone's a bit jarring
column6: but considering the disparity of styles at play
column7: the transition's pretty flawless. Empros' best moments-- the snowdrift strings that blow across the end of ""Schiphol"" and into ""Atackla""
column8: the patch cord static and drums that open ""Batu
column9: the aforementioned ""Mlàdek"" assault-- find some little sliver of gorgeousness overwhelmed by some orbit-upsetting rumble from Cook or some out-from-nowhere turnaround from drummer Dave Turncrantz.

column1: Complexity for its own sake muddled the Circles' first few LPs a bit; Empros
column2: like Geneva before it
column3: is less prone to wriggle

L.A.-based artist Mtendere Mandowa has always stood out from the Brainfeeder pack of weirdo hip-hop producers: his beats are shrouded in dewy mist and subtropical condensation rather than the crunchy boom-bap of producers like Flying Lotus or Samiyam. The way he uses filters and closely clipped loops has the effect of a pleasantly smudged watercolor painting (much like those he designs himself)
column2: vague hints of otherwise implacable sounds rotating and repeating in a whimsical way. It's eminently accessible music
column3: full of tiny ""eureka"" moments of subtle bliss
column4: deft touches
column5: and minuscule finishes so that even a two-minute sketch could feel like a whole world waiting to be dissected. Alas
column6: it's probably that part of his sound that most works against Teebs: His debut album
column7: Ardour
column8: was probably one of the most pleasant things released from this particular sector last year
column9: but it was easy for track after track of dense nature-scapes to blur together and to lose sight of Teebs' own fascinating personality in the grand scheme of faceless beauty.

column1: Part of the reason for that was Ardour's length-- at 18 tracks long
column2: it was a hard album to digest without fatigue or boredom setting in
column3: a record that could easily start to feel like style over substance. Whether it's a wise lesson learned or merely serendipity
column4: Mandowa's quick successor is a 10-track
column5: 30-minute affair and all the stronger for it. Collections 01
column6: if you want to be nerdy about it
column7: sits somewhere between an EP and a ""mini-album
column8: but a surprisingly cohesive statement like this exists outside the need for nit-picky classification. Teebs himself describes Collections 01 as ""a side project or group of mine that just so happened to make the same exact music as I'm making now
column9: and as bizarre a description as that is
column10: given that the record features Rebekah Raff's harp and Brainfeeder-associated composer Austin Peralta
column11: maybe it's justified.

column1: While the music on Collections is very identifiably Teebs
column2: it's not merely 10 more tracks of Ardour. Whether it's the presence of collaborators with discrete roles
column3: maturity
column4: or merely a different headspace
column5: the tracks here feel grounded and focused
column6: with more to hold onto even at their most weightless.  The colorful
column7: soft-focus smear is partly replaced with discrete space and  Take ""LSP""
column8: with Peralta
column9: a track that incorporates the same kind of meandering chimes and aquatic nature sounds as so many tracks on <i>Ardour
column10: but now it feels like every element has newfound purpose. On this record
column11: dulcet keyboards paint silky melodies like brushstrokes
column12: the drearily rustling beats are sewn into the fabric rather than tacked on
column13: and tracks have real beginnings and endings rather than just floating by. Texturally
column14: it's some of Mandowa's most gripping material yet
column15: like the simultaneously slamming yet impossibly airy ""Pretty Polly"" or the queasily determined sub-basslines on closing duo ""Red Curbs Loop"" and ""Yellow More New"".

column1: It says something for the fleeting nature of Teebs' music that what
column2: for most artists
column3: would be a stop-gap release turns out to be an arresting career highlight. It might be a slight little package
column4: but somehow it makes even more of an impact than its considerably larger sibling. Attractively structured
column5: confident
column6: and executed without the stoned daydreaming that defined Ardour
column7: Collections marks a new high-water mark for a producer that was already eminently accessible. Even for those who aren't fans of the kind of rambling and tangential ADD music usually proffered by Brainfeeder
column8: the little readjustment on Collections might be just enough to rope in former skeptics. Either way
column9: his new record is another collection of effortlessly gorgeous ruminations on hip-hop expressed through thermal updrafts
column10: babbling brooks
column11:
and cracking twigs: This time it just sounds like he knows his way around the forest a little better.

A$AP Rocky violated rule number one of the 10 Crack Commandments: Never let no one know how much dough you hold. The cheddar bred $3
column4: 000 worth of jealousy after the 23-year old New York rapper disclosed the value of his deal with Sony/RCA last month. The offer was tendered largely off the strength of his first two videos
column5: ""Purple Swag"" and ""Peso""
column6: a pair of codeine fever dreams that recast Harlem World as a slick-talking color-corrected suburb of Houston.

column1: To cool-hunting 360-wielding record executives
column2: the videos might as well have been advertisements for the A$AP lifestyle: Colt 45
column3: purple weed and purple drank
column4: dice games
column5: bike riding
column6: brandishing Berettas
column7: clothing designers ostensibly known only to Kanye
column8: and a pretty blonde girl in a grill mouthing the phrase: ""this is for my niggas getting high on the regular."" Picture an episode of ""Gossip Girl"" where Blake Lively watches Traffic and subsequently opts to explore the Danger Zone of 125th and Lennox.

column1: Unavoidable in the conversation is the enduring absence of a New York commercial force under 30. Since the emergence of Dipset and G-Unit in the first half of the last decade
column2: NYC rap aspirants have largely fallen into four categories: ringtone wunderkinds (""This Is Why I'm Hot""
column3: ""Chicken Noodle Soup"")
column4: technically skilled personality voids (Papoose
column5: Saigon)
column6: artful traditionalists (Action Bronson
column7: Roc Marciano
column8: Ka)
column9: and Maino.

column1: By contrast
column2: Rocky was telegenic and chanting swag. His lead singles poured syrup-slow Houston ride music atop the malt liquor melodies of Harlem's Max B. What Rocky lacked in lyricism
column3: he made up for in narcotic charisma. Seeking street-cred
column4: Drake announced plans to take Rocky on tour. Seeking swag-cred
column5: Lloyd Banks and Jim Jones hopped on tracks with him. Hype metastasizes fastest in New York
column6: and it's easy to conflate the need for a standard bearer with the desire for a savior. Rocky was the chosen one. Hence

column1: Commence the hating. Odd Future's Hodgy Beats called him ""A$AP Copy."" Old heads looked askance at his appropriation of styles alien to the five boroughs. Blogs painted it as the worst New York investment since the Yankees gave Brien Taylor $1.55 million. Rocky didn't help matters when he allegedly punched out a soundman at the Fader Fort and announced that he and his whole crew had adopted vegetarianism. Thus
column2: every mention of his debut mixtape
column3: LIVELOVEA$AP has pondered whether it justifies the price tag of a Bugatti and several dozen ivory backscratchers. Good isn't enough. People expect Rakim Mayers to be the second coming of his namesake.

column1: Of course
column2: the odds are slanted in your favor when you're a rapper named Rakim. You can't exactly sell life insurance. And throughout LIVELOVEA$AP
column3: Rocky embodies the sweat-free cool of someone who has stolen the test and memorized the answers ahead of time. It sidesteps the usual pitfalls of the heavily anticipated debut; there are no ill-fitting famous rapper cameos or last-cup leftovers from $10
column4: 000-a-beat producers. Rocky makes no cornball radio plays
column5: nor any awkward attempts to prove his depth.  Even on ""Demons""
column6: the record's most emotionally raw track
column7: Rocky is preternaturally self-assured. He's got stomach pains but dreams with the inevitable triumphalism of someone who can convince RCA/Polo Grounds to hand over their Pitbull blood money. After about a minute of complaining
column8: he's back to ""fucking the chick you're next to."" By rough estimate
column9: Rocky fucks about 13 or 14 different girlfriends in the course of the album's 56 minutes. There are two different mentions of Naughty by Nature's ""O.P.P."". He is nothing if not efficient.

column1: That's the thing. It's pretty easy to point out the pitfalls of LIVELOVEA$AP. Thematic and lyrical concerns are basically limited to Rocky being a pretty motherfucker
column2: repping Harlem
column3: doing drugs
column4: and getting more women than James Worthy in Houston.  Rocky raps effortlessly
column5: switching back and forth between Midwestern double-time to something that resembles Wiz Khalifa auditioning for Byrd Gang. The dark
column6: drugged visions of Memphis rap also creep in throughout. But to his credit
column7: he doesn't waste much time persecuting haters
column8: preemptively striking only once on ""Leaf"": ""They say I sound like André/ Mixed with Kanye/ A little bit of Max/ A little bit of Wiz/ A little bit of that/ A little bit of this/ Get off my dick.""

column1: It's more difficult to point out where exactly Rocky excels. He's a good rapper
column2: but he's not Kendrick Lamar. He's melodic
column3: but he's not a walking hook like 50 Cent. His voice is strong but not completely singular. Instead
column4: Rocky has great instincts: the moment when he abruptly switches to his Bone Thugs-N-Harmony flow for a few bars in ""Trilla""
column5: the bizarre song structure of ""Bass""
column6: where he just repeats ""Bass"" in lieu of a hook; the last minute and a half of ""Demons""
column7: where his scrambled lo-fi refrain fades into the chlorine fog of the Clams Casino beat.

column1: If anything LIVELOVEA$AP is a triumph of immaculate taste. Rocky's ear for beats is worthy of Rick Ross or early Game. Courtesy of Clams Casino
column2: Burn One
column3: Beautiful Lou
column4: A$AP Ty Beats
column5: and SpaceGhostpurrp
column6: the stellar production makes this something like a swag-rap generation The Documentary. He cherry-picks from the best of internet micro-trends-- taking celestial based weirdness
column7: the funk of country rap
column8: the stoned pace of screw
column9: and the tape-warp of Memphis. But at the core is the French-braided
column10: gold-toothed kid from money-making Manhattan
column11: inflecting his songs with hints of third-generation Spanish Harlem and West Indian patois. For someone who brags
column12: ""the only thing bigger than my ego is my mirror
column13: Rocky wisely cedes the spotlight to well-chosen guests
column14: including Oakland's Main Attrakionz
column15: Houstoner Fat Tony
column16: and the larcenous intensity of L.A.'s Schoolboy Q. Meanwhile his A$AP crew shows few signs of being there for reasons of nepotism or weed carrying.

column1: ""Houston Old Head"" might be the best sign that Rocky can deliver on his seven-figure potential. It's not necessarily the most memorable song
column2: but it's his most surprising-- a swaggering lean-sipping version of Neil Young's ""Old Man""
column3: with it's chorus
column4: ""If you listen when your old head talk/ You'll be straight."" It's basically the opposite of Odd Future's youth worship-- the admission that occasionally your elders can put you up on game. It shows he's willing to listen and soak up different styles and sounds-- crucial elements for evolution. Even if the fusion initially seems unorthodox
column5:
LIVELOVEA$AP is exactly the sort of record you'd expect to hear in 2011 from a New Yorker who was 13 when ""Big Pimpin'"" came out. Rocky did what should've been expected of him; he made a very good record. Now we wait to see if he'll get clientele.

Like so many groups fond of noise
column4: lo-fi recording

column6: Royal Trux were often classified as a garage band. But for the duo of Neil Hagerty and Jennifer Herrema
column7: the word ""garage"" didn't so much represent a dirty-D.I.Y. aesthetic as a messy
column8: greasy place where things get stripped down
column9: torn apart
column10: and welded back together. Throughout their 12-year run (from 1988 to 2000)
column11: Royal Trux took a chop-shop approach to pop history
column12: deconstructing their favorite FM-radio icons-- in particular
column13: Mick Taylor-era Rolling Stones-- and reassembling the scrap metal and wires into heaving junkyard jalopies
column14: with the hoarse-voiced but imposingly beautiful Herrema serving as the hood ornament who could sell their mutant custom jobs as classic rock.

column1: Given their amorphous aesthetic-- which yielded works as incongruous as 1990's byzantine bricolage Twin Infinitives
column2: 1995's biker-bar boogie-fest Thank You
column3: and 2000's ghetto-blasted breakdance-athon Radio Video EP-- there is no truly definitive Royal Trux album

column5: who range from Bradford Cox
column6: Liars
column7: and the Kills to Bat for Lashes
column8: Hot Chip
column9: and MGMT. As a 3xLP collection of the band's early-90s ephemera
column10: <i>Singles
column11: Live
column12: Unreleased may not seem like the most logical entry point into the Trux's phantasmagoric universe. But for newcomers

column1: Originally released in 1997 (and now reissued in unchanged form)
column2: <i>Singles
column3: Live
column4: Unreleased was more than just a stop-gap measure between albums; it also represented a symbolic homecoming to Drag City after a brief stint on Virgin that constituted one of the more bizarre byproducts of the post-Nirvana major-label signing blitz. After Thank You and 1997's Sweet Sixteen failed to realize Virgin's dreams of turning Royal Trux into the next Black Crowes (the puke-stained album covers probably didn't help)
column5: <i>Singles
column6: Live
column7: Unreleased heralded the band's eventual return to the weird with 1998's fuzzed-out triumph Accelerator. Its chronology-- covering the years of 1988 to 1995-- roughly aligns with the period when Hagerty and Herrema were in the throes of an infamous heroin habit that effectively defined the band in its early years and provided an unavoidable lens through which to interpret its music. But as far as junkies go
column8: they were highly functional-- on top of the four official albums released over that span
column9: the band recorded several non-album singles
column10: compilation tracks
column11: and Peel Sessions. (Of the 32 songs collected here
column12: only five appear-- in different form-- on Trux albums proper.) And just as the duo was struggling to get sober over this period
column13: its music was also undergoing its own slow
column14: difficult lurch toward trad-rock accessibility.

column1: Going one step further than Hagerty's Rolling Stones desecrations in Pussy Galore
column2: Royal Trux's initial singles sound like all the individual recording tracks from Exile on Main Street spliced up and reassembled at random. Songs like ""No Fixed Address"" and ""Hero/Zero"" possess discernible raunch-rock riffs
column3: vocal hooks
column4: and rhythms
column5: but they sound like they each belong in different songs; at the same time
column6: the duo's use of drum machines and weird synth frequencies-- not to mention Hagerty's Hendrixian facility at pushing standard blues-rock scales and solos into lobotomizing squalls-- lend this primitive music an oddly futuristic
column7: temporally dislocating quality. In the same spirit
column8: <i>Singles
column9: Live
column10: Unreleased negates any kind of linear reading of Royal Trux's evolution
column11: favoring instead jarring juxtapositions of era
column12: musical style
column13: and recording quality. But now
column14: with the band defunct for over a decade
column15: this illogical approach makes a lot more sense today than it did in 1997
column16: transforming the listening experience into an archaeological mission
column17: as each excavated track provides another clue to decoding this strange band. Royal Trux's music may not always make sense to you
column18: but even at its  most-messed up
column19: you can still hear how it made sense to them.

column1: The more straightforward rockers here (""Steal Your Face""
column2: ""Gett Off"") aren't quite on the level of the ones heard on 1992's self-titled effort and 1993's Cats & Dogs
column3: while the glaring omission of ""Delta 70 of Hearts""-- a ""Can't You Hear Me Knocking"" to call their own-- from the 1994 Hey Drag City compilation still confounds. But Singles
column4: Live
column5: Unreleased reveals intriguing new sides of the band that were lamentably never explored on their official albums
column6: like the sampledelic pimp-funk of ""Shockwave Rider"" and the blissed-out proto-chillwave of essential '93 Sub Pop single ""Back to School"" (recently covered by Of Montreal). And in contrast to Royal Trux's formative kill-yr-idols tack
column7: we hear a more sincere interpretation of their influences here
column8: including faithful covers of Milton Nascimento's Tropicália chestnut ""Faca Amolada"" and Jefferson Airplane's freedom-rockin' ""Law Man""
column9: and
column10: most curiously
column11: a '93 Peel Session take on ""The Theme from M*A*S*H"". But in the last case
column12: what on paper appears to be a cheeky exercise in 70s revivalism proves surprisingly devastating
column13: as the song's chorus-- ""suicide is painless""-- takes on a several layers of significance when sung by a couple who once endured prolonged spells of addiction
column14: poverty
column15:
and homelessness. Only in the hands of a band as peculiar and indefinable as Royal Trux could kitsch sound so affecting.

column1: Obviously

column8: ""With Apologies to Emily Pankhurst"" hurtles forth with a velocity that can obscure a rhyme of pure gold like
column9: ""I fear most women like I fear tomorrow-- absolutely/ I can't let something as French as fear determine this insecurity."" But when ""destroywhitchurch.com"" and ""My Wife Is Unhappy"" take turns into dead-eyed

column10: acid-fueled spin on a creaking Coney Island ride

column1: At a point when ear-to-the-ground actually meant eye-to-MySpace
column2: Jones made an account
column3: uploaded some songs
column4: and friended Woodsist and Captured Tracks. The latter label messaged him about a 7""
column5: ""Leave Me Be""
column6: which followed in November of that year
column7: and is now one of the imprint's most essential out-of-print singles. It ushered Spectrals into what ought to be remembered as Gen Y's International Blog-Pop Underground-- a scene that in 2009 included hyper lo-fi acts like Dum Dum Girls
column8: Real Estate
column9: and Twerps. Whether the ramshackle renaissance of 2009 was rooted in fashion or necessity is an open question
column10: but Spectrals were in and of that underground Spector-fueled wave
column11: and have since released material on a handful of international D.I.Y. labels.

column1: These groups have all shed some fuzz by now
column2: so it's no surprise that on Jones' first proper full-length
column3: Bad Penny
column4: he makes a similarly slick departure. Indeed
column5: the sound of Bad Penny is related only peripherally to his previous releases. Though it's hardly overproduced
column6: Jones barely employs any reverb at all
column7: and while his evolved sonic identity might be jarring to existing Spectrals fans
column8: the polish sounds better over time.

column1: Indie rock readings of Phil Spector pop are almost passé at this point
column2: but Jones makes it work due in no small part to his English wit
column3: articulation
column4: and gray mood. ""Get a Grip"" opens with a small
column5: fun riff
column6: prefacing a crooned rhyme: ""I need to get a grip
column7: I always seem to let my smile slip."" His delivery is slow and monotone
column8: as he stretches each fifth syllable or so
column9: but it's a toe-tapper
column10: underpinned by cool bits of bongo and guitar. The bongo drum returns later on ""You Don't Have to Tell Me""
column11: and whether or not the 50s jazz-club feel comes with a wink
column12: its faux-sophistication still comes over as charming. ""Luck Is There to Be Pushed"" has a similar effect
column13: but this time with the runs of jazz piano that fleck its dramatically soft guitar strums and subtle
column14: gliding synths.

column1: The upbeat punch and texture on ""Big Baby"" and ""Confetti"" make for two of the album's most lively tracks
column2: the latter offering a clever joke about dating: ""If what you call fun is courting
column3: bring on the confetti."" That hidden humor makes it easy to celebrate the record's smoothness
column4: even on its more mysterious side. ""Many Happy Returns""
column5: for example
column6: is a slow-moving piece of pop poetry that recalls a hard-boiled Dashiell Hammett novel. Its sway starts with a sharp sentiment of after-school romantic uncertainty: ""Stood waiting for your Ma to collect you/ Wondering if she ever asked you/ Who I was to you?/ And wishing that I knew.""

column1: Bad Penny has its weak points. The second track
column2: ""Lockjaw""
column3: is soulful but tired and awkwardly placed
column4: tearing down the mood of the album after a sharp opening
column5: and Jones' lyrics in general can seem recycled. Still
column6: the record's main dividing line is the production
column7: as there is a real philosophical shift that comes with moving away from lo-fi. Slumberland devotees might identify more with Spectrals' original grassroots mentality
column8: but the album's more broadly inviting sound ties the band into a realm of music that rock critic Ellen Willis called ""ecumenical pop."" It's music pleasant enough to carry intergenerational appeal
column9: characterized by a youthful spirit but rooted in a classic sound. Bad Penny
column10: then
column11:
is ultimately a solid debut that is still surprisingly safe.
