0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17159/homepage_large.e02a65e3.jpg|Achtung Baby [Super Deluxe Edition]|4404.0|U2|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Island']|2011-11-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:15.059787|"

""If you give a pop star a shit pile of dough and he refuses to self-destruct
column2: I think it is a bit wet
column3: said a smoking
column4: slicked-back
column5: black-sunglasses-clad Bono in a 1993 interview on the UK music show ""Naked City"". ""I think it's part of the deal. If they don't die on a cross by 33
column6: I'd ask for your money back."" Like many of the knowingly audacious quotes from the singer and his U2 mates during this period
column7: it's a little tough to deduce the exact level of sincerity involved. And that was the whole idea. In the early 1990s
column8: U2 were sending up the idea of a ""rock'n'roll star."" They were offering themselves as an ironic
column9: postmodern band for similarly confused times. They were making fun of themselves and their own humorless
column10: slate-faced 80s reputation. A year after Bono's casual quip about pop stars dying on a cross
column11: Kurt Cobain killed himself. And in Nirvana's final video
column12: for ""Heart-Shaped Box""
column13: Cobain could be seen making wild eyes in front of one.

column1: Achtung Baby and its accompanying Zoo TV tour lived within the slippage between perception and reality. ""Sometimes you can get far closer to the truth of what you're trying to say by highlighting what it isn't as if it were true
column2: said the Edge on ""Naked City"". ""That's assuming we know the truth-- 'truth' is one of those words that's lost its meaning."" In the 80s
column3: U2 seemed endlessly in search of a definite truth
column4: whether in peace or god or love or some ambiguous combination of the three. Famously
column5: they didn't find it.

column1: But the quest was thrilling-- at least until 1988's album and film Rattle and Hum
column2: which found the group looking and sounding spectacularly self-serious while gawkily paying tribute to some of their American heroes like Elvis Presley and B.B. King. The resulting critical backlash caused these open-hearted Irishmen to reflect
column3: and they weren't crazy about what they saw in the mirror. ""We looked like a big
column4: overblown rock band running amok
column5: says Bono in an excellent new documentary called From the Sky Down that chronicles the band's pivotal turn-of-the-decade moment. And while that might seem like an aptly derisive opinion of today's incarnation of U2
column6: it's important to remember that these guys originally came out of the cacophony of rule-breaking post-punk
column7: a realm where bloated arena rock was the enemy. So they went away and tried to come up with a new way to seek some truth.

column1: Achtung Baby is rightly known as one of rock's greatest reinventions because it was so complete. Sure
column2: U2 changed their sound from chiming melodics to lurching
column3: distorted rhythm. But they also changed their attitude
column4: their demeanor
column5: their look
column6: their ideas on how to deal with celebrity. All of a sudden
column7: they were funny
column8: sexy
column9: a bit dangerous-- three things few would've associated with U2 in the 80s. And yet
column10: at their core
column11: the band's values remained constant. They were still ethically minded and interested in the real-life connection between living beings. But the way they went about projecting those core tenets flipped. In TV-news parlance
column12: their attitude switched from ""60 Minutes"" to ""The Colbert Report"".

column1: This new era was conveniently spelled-out on Achtung's first single ""The Fly"" with the Edge's metallic skronk and Bono's conspiratorial
column2: effected whisper of lines like
column3: ""It's no secret that a conscience can sometimes be a pest/ It's no secret that ambition bites the nails of success."" And just as the album goes lengths to both fulfill and upend rock'n'roll myths with thorny tales of deep betrayal
column4: questioned fidelity
column5: and ambiguous artifice
column6: this coffee-table-book sized
column7: 6xCD
column8: 4xDVD set both props up Achtung and pokes a few holes in it
column9: too.

column1: Take the album's much-ballyhooed place of origin
column2: Berlin's Hansa Studios. This was the location that played host to David Bowie and Iggy Pop's electronic-inspired masterworks Low and The Idiot. And Hansa is located near the Berlin Wall
column3: which had only recently been breached when U2 set up there in the fall of 1990. Perched literally in the middle of historic liberation
column4: U2 were meant to find inspiration in the world events around them and turn that spark into a new version of the band for a new decade. It's a great backdrop for a great story. But it didn't really go down that way. ""We're there
column5: and greatness has left the building
column6: Bono recalls in From the Sky Down
column7: which features the band returning to Hansa earlier this year in preparation for their headlining set at Glastonbury.

column1: While Berlin did inspire bits of the record-- ""Zoo Station"" was named after one of its prominent train terminals-- it hardly lived up to its lofty reputation. This serves as a lesson for U2
column2: a band that shamelessly worships past rock heroes
column3: to move past such naïve mythologizing. ""Berlin was a baptism of fire
column4: says bassist Adam Clayton in the documentary. ""It was something we had to go through to realize what we were trying to get to was not something you could find physically
column5: outside of ourselves
column6: in some other city-- that there was not magic to it and that we actually had to put the work in and figure out the ideas and hone those ideas down."" This newfound pragmatism would help them to move past their fantasies about the sanctity of rock. So while Berlin played a part on Achtung Baby
column7: it did so in surprising ways; though ""One"" was mostly written in a burst of inspiration in Hansa
column8: most of the album truly came together once the group went back home to Dublin.

column1: Most of the audio bonuses in this set are unfortunately superfluous
column2: and don't offer much in terms of insight. There are two CDs filled with dance remixes
column3: and while U2 were at the vanguard of big time rock bands embracing the notion of the remix
column4: even the most devout rave nostalgist would have little use for six remakes of ""Mysterious Ways"". The disc of bonus material and B-sides is disappointingly slight
column5: and another filled with early versions of every song on Achtung offers a few revelations-- an Irish jig-style version of ""Tryin' to Throw Your Arms Around the World"" has an easy charm
column6: but generally
column7: it's easy to see why these attempts were improved upon later. Achtung's even more electronic and weirder follow-up
column8: 1993's Zooropa-- which was recorded in a creative frenzy during a break in the Zoo TV tour-- is also included
column9: though it's generally (and somewhat unfairly) glossed over in all the accompanying materials.

column1: The worthy additions in this ""super deluxe edition"" are nearly all visual. There's Anton Corbijn's gorgeous and colorful photography that covers its case
column2: as well as a big
column3: sturdy 84-page book. And then the four discs of video: It Might Get Loud director Davis Guggenheim's new 90-minute doc From the Sky Down
column4: every video from the era
column5: a full live gig taped in Australia in 1993
column6: interview shows (like ""Naked City"")
column7: and
column8: best of all
column9: a playfully subversive TV special from 1992 that includes live footage from the Zoo TV tour as well as goofy interludes that play up the surrealism and insanity of the whole project. Moments like the ""Even Better Than the Real Thing"" video
column10: with the band playing in a glass case while fans look on outside
column11: successfully tie in all the pomo flourishes U2 were chasing. The group was at the forefront of bringing huge video screens into the live arena
column12: and some of the tricks they pull off-- Bono ""dueting"" with a static-y Lou Reed or flipping channels to live local stations-- still look impressive. And for all the technical wizardry of the stage setup
column13: the band still uses it to complement the music rather than overshadow it. Even 20 years on
column14: the tour looks like something to behold
column15: a singularly inventive experience that no band-- including U2 itself-- has been able to really expound upon in a meaningful way.

column1: In the Zoo TV special
column2: which originally aired during Thanksgiving weekend in 1992
column3: a ""news commentator"" covering the show dubs it ""the most significant and exciting TV event since the Gulf War."" Some of the ideas behind Zoo TV and Achtung Baby were inspired by the television coverage of that initial Gulf War in 1991
column4: and the bizarre reality of being able to switch channels from home shopping to MTV to the bombing of Baghdad. U2 recognized the dangers of this idea
column5: when war turned into just more filler for the burgeoning 24-hour TV-news cycle. And instead of preaching against it in a high and mighty fashion
column6: they embraced that chaos in an effort to expose it. Of course
column7: our collective information overload has been upped exponentially since thanks to the internet
column8: making the flashes of words and slogans that backed U2 during their live campaign seem eerily prophetic. Talking about the Zoo TV audience in the ""Naked City"" interview
column9: drummer Larry Mullen
column10: Jr. says
column11: ""They're coming to a rock'n'roll show and watching television
column12: what more can you ask for?"" He's joking
column13: but as we go to arenas and see singers on big screens through our cellphone cameras
column14:
the question begins to answer itself.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17148/homepage_large.2507584a.jpg|Humor Risk|2714.0|Cass McCombs|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2011-11-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:15.527215|"

Say it quickly
column2: eliding the r's that cap the end of the first word and the beginning of the second
column3: and the title of Cass McCombs' second full-length this year becomes Humoresque-- a genre of Romantic-period classical music that favored lyrical
column4: mood-based expressions intended to be funny. As a title
column5: Humor Risk functions as a sort of riddle
column6: one where the answer comes quickly but you still feel silly for not getting it earlier. McCombs probably prefers it that way. In a rare
column7: cagey interview with Pitchfork's Ryan Dombal
column8: he defended the grim and elegantly dark WIT'S END: ""You can't just explain a joke
column9: can you? Either it isn't funny
column10: or the person just totally missed the punchline.""

column1: To be fair
column2: that record did have a punchline or two buried beneath its incessant gloom. But McCombs' work has never really been expressively funny
column3: and by his standards
column4: Humor Risk is something of a laugh riot. There's a hapless drug deal that ends in murder (reminiscent of Silver Jews' also-pretty-funny ""San Francisco
column6: a philosophical discussion on the nature of beauty in a mannequin factory
column7: and a domestic ghost story that may or may not compare California to <a href=""http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chimera_%28mythology%29"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">a mythical
column8: fire-breathing creature.

column1: Another topic raised in that interview is McCombs' reclusive nature and his penchant for personal privacy
column2: which in the Internet age
column3: fairly or not
column4: seems like an unusual character trait. Since we don't know much about McCombs
column5: save for his fascination with death and that he's lived as a nomad for most of his life
column6: it's unclear whether his reservations about giving away personal details are due to something darker within him
column7: or an intent to lend mystique and character to an otherwise relatively normal nomadic singer/songwriter type.

column1: Either way
column2: McCombs isn't any more ready to reveal himself on Humor Risk; he delivers many of the lyrics to ""The Living Word""
column3: a meditation on personal and universal spirituality
column4: in a warm half-mutter that requires a lyric book to truly comprehend what he's saying. Religion is a touchy topic for McCombs
column5: and here
column6: even when he's embracing a somewhat positive message of universal existence on ""The Living Word"" and ""The Same Thing""
column7: he's reluctant to say too much.

column1: Sonically
column2: however
column3: Humor Risk is his most straightforward and outgoing record to date
column4: and the first time he's cranked up the electric guitars and dry drums since 2007's Dropping the Writ. The album's most upbeat songs chug like poppy mantras-- if McCombs were into such a thing
column5: opener ""Love Thine Enemy"" could comfortably soundtrack some movie or TV commercial-- while the straightforward beauty contained in other cuts is often designed with tricky simplicity. There's an easy likability to most of this album
column6: even if McCombs' ever-present opaqueness seems somewhat superfluous when he's in this zone.

column1: Production-wise
column2: McCombs and frequent collaborator Ariel Rechtshaid have made the most of this album's piecemeal-recorded nature (recording was spread out in various homes and studios in California
column3: Chicago
column4: and New Jersey). The backing vocals on ""The Same Thing"" are chilly and hair-raising
column5: while ""To Every Man His Chimera""
column6: which sounds like a WIT'S END cut with enjoyably hammy theatricality added for good measure
column7: is interrupted intermittently by distant voices and barking dogs. Like its creator
column8: Humor Risk just sounds all over the place. In a certain sense
column9: that's a good thing
column10: as it only takes some homespun recording trickery to make McCombs seem distant and vaguely in-transit on even the most hard-driving songs here.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: Humor Risk is a minor work in his growing (and impeccably consistent) catalog; unlike WIT'S END and 2009's soft-focus career-high Catacombs
column3: it plays less like an ""album"" and more like a ""collection of songs
column4: a factor that may make it something of a difficult initial listen. There are a handful of solid songs on Humor Risk
column5: though
column6: without an outright dud in the bunch-- and if that represents a disappointment
column7: then in the end
column8:
the joke might be on us.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17154/homepage_large.40ea1711.jpg|You're Never Going Back|28978.0|Coasting|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|"[""M'Lady's""]"|2011-11-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:16.069462|"

The charm of Brooklyn duo Coasting's debut
column2: You're Never Going Back
column3: is largely the same as the charm of an early White Stripes record: It's not terribly hard to believe it was made by two people. Make no mistake
column4: that's a compliment: Were indie rock its own island nation
column5: Minutemen's credo of simplicity and Emersonian self-reliance ""We Jam Econo"" would be stitched proudly on the flag. So
column6: in a moment when every bedroom recording artist can GarageBand her own backing Polyphonic Spree into existence
column7: there's something refreshing about a band like
column8: say
column9: Japandroids
column10: whose music sounds like a sonic tribute to the camaraderie of the flesh-and-blood
column11: guitar-and-drums duo. Coasting's crash-pop-meets-surf-rock works like this too: combining rumbling riffage; hyperactive
column12: cymbal-heavy drumming; and fervent
column13: back-and-forth vocals into a classic D.I.Y. sound. This isn't minimalism
column14: exactly: It's the joyful sound of two people trying to make as much noise as they possibly can.

column1: Those two people are guitarist Madison Farmer and drummer Fiona Campbell
column2: a New Zealand transplant who's also been drumming with Vivian Girls for a little over a year. Over the first few tracks of You're Never Going Back at least
column3: Farmer and Campbell create irresistibly shambolic tunes (""Starts and Stays""
column4: ""Portland"") that escalate in breathless energy as they creep toward the three-minute mark. ""Kids"" starts unassumingly
column5: in a steady blizzard of cymbals and power chords before it picks up with the intensity of a couple of kids running down a steep hill
column6: hollering double dares all the way down: Pick up the tempo! Play louder! Sing ""Ohhhh!"" Louder still! As in Campbell's other band
column7: echoes of girl-group melodies poke through the grit
column8: as though plucked from fuzzy memories. The feeling is reminiscent of Kicking Giant's 1990s cult classic Alien ID: Its emotional climax is the sound of imperfect
column9: warbling voices imploring
column10: with more volume and punch each time
column11: ""Be my/ Be my baby.”

column1: Up until now
column2: Coasting have lived largely in the world of 7""s. The problem with their debut album is one that's befallen countless perfectly good indie bands before them: They don't have enough ideas to fill a whole LP. You're Never Going Back definitely boasts their best standalone tracks
column3: but after a while
column4: the limitations of their sound become apparent. The energy lags in the record's middle section
column5: over a stretch of samey-sounding
column6: mid-tempo numbers. Bill Skibbe and Jessica Ruffin's production keeps things simple and thus captures the freewheeling spirit of the band's live performance
column7: but by the fourth mid-tempo
column8: quiet-loud-quiet jam
column9: you get to wishing for an experimental streak-- or at least another pedal.

column1: This might not be a problem for you. There's something inherently affable about Coasting's sound
column2: which has the grimy
column3: big-hearted spirit of an early K Records release. And if you're predisposed to liking garage rock or music that extols the virtues of all things handmade (check that punk rock cross-stitch on the album cover)
column4: you are not likely to hold Coasting's lack of sonic variety or next-big-thing ambition against them. This year
column5: though
column6: I'm feeling extra critical
column7: still under the moment-defining spell of tUnE-yArDs' w h o k i l l. That record sounds nothing like You're Never Going Back
column8: but it affirmed something important-- that a record can be brimming with ideas and unabashedly huge
column9: and yet still sound unmistakably handmade. Like a lot of the classics in the indie rock canon
column10: w h o k i l l stands as a provocative D.I.Y. challenge: You can do more with your bare hands and your own voice than you ever dreamed. (No
column11: this idea isn't new; even the dudes who said
column12: ""We Jam Econo
column13: made a record with 45 songs on it.) ""I've seen the future and it's perfectly all right
column14: Farmer sings with muted pathos on the album's last track
column15:
a bittersweet ballad called ""Delusions of Grandeur"". Those aren't always such bad things.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17155/homepage_large.ff732812.jpg|200 Years|30053.0|200 Years|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2011-11-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:16.576818|"

Music fans like to engage in speculative match-making
column2: imagining what one distinctive artist might sound like in collaboration with another. In real life
column3: of course
column4: such collaborations have a notoriously checkered history. Yet there are still instances when the artists in question present a match too tantalizing to resist
column5: and 200 Years is one such example. The duo is comprised of Six Organs of Admittance's Ben Chasny and Magik Markers' Elisa Ambrogio
column6: and together they draw on the quieter echoes of their other projects to create a charming new hybrid.

column1: It helps that Chasny is an old hand at just this sort of collaboration
column2: and a bit of a chameleon besides. In addition to his gigantic Six Organs of Admittance catalog
column3: he has been a member of noise rock troupe Comets on Fire and improv units Rangda and Badgerlore
column4: and his endlessly creative guitar work has been a welcome presence everywhere it has turned up. Each has served as a touring musician for the others' main gig
column5: and Chasny and Ambrogio previously collaborated with Mouthus' Brian Sullivan in the noise-drone Basalt Fingers
column6: but there is nothing from that trio that anticipated the hushed
column7: song-based style of 200 Years.

column1: The biggest surprise on 200 Years is Ambrogio and the gentle
column2: almost demure performances that she delivers throughout the album. Though her work with Magik Markers has usually been distinguished by the wide-ranging ferocity of her vocals
column3: there have been glimmers of her quieter side on such studio albums as BOSS and Balf Quarry. Still
column4: it is unexpected to hear her sing so softly at such length
column5: with her voice providing a natural foil for Chasny's predominantly acoustic guitars. At times she recalls the solo work of Barbara Manning or Lois Maffeo
column6: a fact that would be astonishing to anyone only familiar with Ambrogio via one of Magik Markers' feral live recordings.

column1: Consisting almost entirely of voices and guitars
column2: there is an ageless quality to 200 Years. The album is bookended by its two most immediately mesmeric songs
column3: ""Wild White"" and ""More Than Alive""
column4: both of which are sturdy
column5: melodic gems that could seemingly translate into any idiom. Here they are given the simplest possible treatment
column6: riding along only on the interplay of Ambrogio's voice and Chasny's expertly filigreed guitar lines
column7: the production so intimate that it feels like eavesdropping on a private conversation.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: as on ""Partin Wayz"" or ""Thread""
column3: the duo adds discreet electric guitar effects or a quietly droning harmonium to the mix
column4: always with the lightest of touch. None of these effects will shock those familiar with Chasny's previous work
column5: and in its drowsier patches 200 Years can seem to be merely a Six Organs of Admittance tape with female vocals placed overhead. Which is hardly a bad formula in itself
column6: but it might disappoint those hoping for more in the way of improvisational fireworks. On ""Bees"" Ambrogio does deliver what sounds like a front porch version of her Magik Marker lyrical cascade
column7: with her words casually spilling out just as quickly as she can enunciate them.

column1: The most impressive aspect of 200 Years
column2: especially considering it as the debut of a new collaboration
column3: is its overall aura of cool confidence. Chasny and Ambrogio are clearly two talented musicians with a wide variety of tools at their disposal
column4: yet to their credit they don't feel the need to try and show every trick at once. Instead they show an innate sense of trust in one another and in this resonant collection of songs
column5:
secure in the knowledge that this should be plenty.

"|16018.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16018-200-years-200-years/|7.7|Matthew Murphy

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17157/homepage_large.cfdc7ce4.jpg|Genre-Specific Xperience|30056.0|Fatima Al Qadiri|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['UNO']|2011-11-09 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:17.266948|"

About a month ago
column2: Fatima Al Qadiri released an EP on Tri Angle called WARN-U under the name Ayshay
column3: adding another line to her already crowded résumé. The moody tracks centered around the spectral chanting of traditional Islamic songs in Arabic (Al Qadiri was born in Senegal
column4: raised in Kuwait during the Gulf War
column5: and lives in Brooklyn now). Given the content of that EP
column6: it makes sense that she chose to release Genre-Specific Xperience using a different name
column7: and on a different label. GSX harnesses the eerie mysticism of WARN-U that sat nicely under Tri Angle's shrouded
column8: echoey umbrella but channels it into a percussive
column9: neo-global club sound driven by an unexpectedly sinister synthetic steel drum-- and with a more compelling result. It picks up nicely where L.A. mixmasters Nguzunguzu left off when they made a 12-minute ""megamix"" of WARN-U
column10: pumping the EP's original three cuts full of skittery beats and bass.

column1: This EP could stand on its own as a piece of music suited for dancing under the right combination of fog and lasers
column2: but it remains connected to her aesthetic as a whole. GSX showcases Al Qadiri's ability to evoke
column3: using sound only
column4: the uncanny and seductive themes she dreams up and explores visually. So it makes sense that the release party for the EP took place at New York's New Museum
column5: complete with a screening of corresponding videos created by a horde of collaborators. But you don't need videos to get a grip on Al Qadiri's haunting
column6: pan-cultural visions. Looking at the tracklist before listening to the EP
column7: you might figure the title ""Hip Hop Spa"" to be just a nifty and offhanded combination of words; listening to the bassy
column8: new age-bending song
column9: though
column10: it's clear that Al Qadiri has thought about exactly what music might be played at a hip-hop spa
column11: if such a thing existed (in fact
column12: she should probably open one). ""Vatican Vibes""
column13: the EP's centerpiece
column14: is a degree more suggestive still
column15: folding Gregorian chants into a thumping
column16: futuristic synth-and-steel-drum backdrop. All five songs deliver on the slickly gaudy
column17: pillar-laden poolside setup gracing the cover.

column1: GSX can lean toward gimmickry

and exhibits her visual art in galleries around the world-- but GSX gives her original solo music a solid push to the forefront of her broad output.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17135/homepage_large.5d7d144c.jpg|Crazy Clown Time|5816.0|David Lynch|['Rock'
column2: 'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['PIAS'
column3:
'Sunday Best']|2011-11-08 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:17.920413|"

If you've ever thought of director David Lynch as being ""weird
column4: suspend that thought for a moment. That weirdness-- the visceral
column5: surrealistic imagery and fragmented plots in his movies-- is  exactly what we as viewers want from him. You probably like it  weird now and then. I do too. It's what thrills us
column6: confuses us
column7: and keeps us coming back for more.

column1: One of the elements that defines Lynch's films is the way he uses music
column2: especially music from the 1950s and early 60s. Seemingly innocuous songs are set in relief against scenes of violence  or desperation in ways that reveal some latent passion that might be  hard to hear on oldies radio. The era is crucial: Slowdances and  big-bad-wolf blues are styles whose tensions are born of repression.  Making your sexual desires known was not much of an option in the 1950s
column3: so the music worked via metaphor and concealment and
column4: as a result
column5: quaked  with subterranean energy that had no safe outlet. Lynch's scenes provide that outlet. When he uses a song as soundtrack
column6: he transforms it.

column1: Music in his movies arrives at high-water moments. Dennis Hopper does himself up in lipstick to Roy Orbison's ""In Dreams"" before assaulting poor Kyle MacLachlan in Blue Velvet
column2: Naomi Watts and Laura Harring sob to Rebekah del Rio's performance of Orbison's ""Crying"" in Mulholland Drive
column3: and Jack Nance
column4: saddled with his horrible alien baby at the edge of domestic sanity in Eraserhead
column5: is <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Qrl3n2ZtK2E"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">serenaded by a tiny
column6: grotesque woman inside his radiator. In these scenes
column7: the music is used in the same way that we as listeners  often use it: to pump ourselves up
column8: to give us space to emote
column9: or to  find solace. Lynch's sense of music is intuitive that way
column10: and probably one of the most plainly sympathetic aspects of his movies.

column1: Crazy Clown Time
column2: while technically a proper debut full-length
column3: is far from the first time Lynch has had a hand in the actual writing and performing of music. He was making noises with Alan Splet as early as Eraserhead
column4: and has done soundtrack work on nearly every movie he's directed through 2006's Inland Empire. He recorded a pleasant-enough ""soundscape"" titled The Air Is On Fire in 2007
column5: and in 2009
column6: he released the Fox Bat Strategy EP
column7: a collaboration featuring musicians with whom he'd worked since Fire Walk With Me
column8: including deceased vocalist Dave Jaurequi
column9: to whom the record was dedicated. And before these
column10: he produced and wrote lyrics for two airy makeout albums by singer Julee Cruise in the late 1980s and early 90s which ought to be studied by all young women who try to sing like undead phone-sex operators.

column1: But Crazy Clown Time is largely a solo project
column2: and most of its material is what you might expect from an album made by David Lynch: tense
column3: repetitive bluesy music permeated by reverb and echo. The remaining few songs-- including the record's first single
column4: ""Good Day Today""-- are not. These other songs are disco
column5: sort of: dark
column6: mid-tempo electronic pop. Karen O sings in places (most prominently on the album's standout opening track
column7: ""Pinky's  Dream"")
column8: but the bulk of the album is actually sung by Lynch through  vocoders and other modulating effects. (If you've seen Lynch's movies  but never heard him speak
column9: you are depriving yourself a harmless treat. Here.) His lyrics are also more or less what you might expect: simple
column10: fragmented
column11: and a bit dull on the page
column12: but threateningly voiced in his  high
column13: twanging pitch.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: none of these songs actually feel like songs. Only a few have choruses or any significant chord changes. Instead
column3: they're set pieces
column4: which makes sense: Lynch's films often seem to be more about luxuriating in his atmosphere than about following his plots
column5: and that carries over to this music as well. But as unfair as this observation might seem to Lynch as a musician
column6: the question I end up asking after listening to Crazy Clown Time is: Hasn't he already accomplished all this in his movies more successfully? In light of his filmography
column7: the album feels familiar to the point of redundancy. Why does he stop with seven minutes of lecturing in a robot voice about how to think positively? Couldn't the album use more abstraction-heavy lectures about positive thinking conveyed in robotic voices? I think so. But maybe I only think that because I come to Lynch for surprise and disruption.

column1: It's been five years since Lynch made Inland Empire. From what I can tell
column2: he spends a lot of his time in the spotlight eagerly promoting  Transcendental Meditation. He recently designed a nightclub in Paris.  So
column3: alright. My purely speculative guess is that Crazy Clown Time is just part of a temporary break from feature filmmaking-- not as heinous as some vanity projects
column4: but an album that will satisfy some personal  need
column5: be minorly exciting to fans who will follow him wherever he goes
column6:
and end up ignored by both parties in time. Anyone who hasn't seen his movies would benefit from seeing almost all of them before listening to it.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17147/homepage_large.eb4daf00.jpg|Fear of God II: Let Us Pray|6310.0|Pusha T|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Decon'
column2: 'Re-Up'
column4: Pusha-T has a home in popular rap
column5: but that doesn't mean he also isn't out of place. After an infamously torturous decade or so in the industry
column6: Pusha now resides comfortably at G.O.O.D. Music
column7: the imprint run by Kanye West that most notably houses guys like Common
column8: Kid Cudi
column9: and Big Sean. Pusha is the only guy remotely resembling a street rapper at the label
column10: and though it's hard to figure out exactly what role he plays in the context of the label or even the genre writ large
column11: it's a marriage that probably makes more sense than not. The days of Pusha
column12: Drug Kingpin are long gone and have been for a while.

column1: Maybe the rapper that Pusha most resembles now is Rick Ross. Though Pusha's cocaine-dealing past is bona fide (or close enough that no one bothers to question it)
column2: his identity as a drug dealer is now merely an imagined idea
column3: a cachet that he rides but one that's far back in the rearview. The act of selling drugs
column4: and the burdens and spoils that come with it
column5: rarely enters his music anymore
column6: and when it does
column7: it rings as hollow as Ross' claims that you can call him up right now on his iPhone and score some dope. But of course it doesn't really matter if Pusha and Ross slip into personas either old or imagined
column8: because a lack of proper reality or authenticity in rap has never dragged down music that was good in the first place. Where the Pusha of old was a witty and smart street hawk
column9: the Pusha of the last five years or so has mirrored Kanye's and Ross' obsessions with luxury. If anything
column10: it's in his ability to bridge the gap between those two rappers that Pusha finds his identity; he is as comfortable rapping about a yacht that a drug dealer might own as he is rapping about a scarf that a fashion designer might own.

column1: But as Pusha has inched his way into the elite of rap
column2: his music (including the material he recorded with his brother as Clipse after their 2006 album Hell Hath No Fury) has become exponentially less vital. He raps about luxury because he's a rich and famous rapper
column3: and that's what rich and famous rappers do
column4: and while there's nothing inherently wrong with that move
column5: it's decidedly dulled the impact of his writing. Pusha has always carried himself with the bravado and ego of a star
column6: and that was galvanizing when in his early years he played the role of a dealer-turned-rapper. But as a regular rapper who pops bottles in penthouses with a bunch of other rappers
column7: that egotism has become commonplace
column8: if not off-putting.

column1: Yet here's the funny thing about Fear of God II
column2: his first commercially released solo album: It proffers that
column3: well
column4: maybe none of that even matters. Pusha's rapping still noticeably pales in comparison to his peak years
column5: and it would be hard to argue that there is any justification for the album's existence beyond Pusha needing to do something-- yet the stakes are so low that the sheer listenability of the album can sneak up on you. Its quality is mostly a testament to Pusha's connections and his ear for beats
column6: but the rapping is sufficiently competent enough that the album never drags
column7: which is less of a backhanded compliment than it might read.

column1: It doesn't seem like much thought was put into sequencing (French Montana shows up on two straight tracks) or thematic cohesion (""Feeling Myself""
column2: the album's one slick R&B song
column3: is followed up by the metallic jitter of the HHNF throwback ""Raid"")
column4: but that strangely only intensifies the strength of the album
column5: which is that Pusha collected seven or eight great tracks and then mostly got the hell out of the way. The process of releasing a rap album through a major label is so arduous now that albums often arrive in stores pushing 20 total songs with almost the same number of guests. Fear of God II's brevity is both refreshing and crucial to its success
column6: and it likely speaks to Pusha's self-confidence that he felt comfortable clipping the tracklist at 12.

column1: This is ruthlessly professional rap music
column2: and though that might seem like the baseline for releasing a major-label rap album
column3: 2011 has been an awful year so far big-box releases. Pusha may be a fish out of water performing on a weepy Kanye ballad or being in a crew with John Legend
column4: but releasing a major-label album with consistent rapping
column5: great beats
column6: a rational guest list
column7:
and a sane running time qualifies as a minor miracle right now.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17143/homepage_large.da6d4955.jpg|Panic of Looking|526.0|Brian Eno|['Jazz'
column3: released in conjunction with a little mountain town's music festival-- doesn't sound very exciting
column4: does it? But you could put Brian Eno's name on the cover of just about anything and generate intense anticipation and scrutiny. Our prime architect of interdisciplinary electronic art has so much authority that when I don't love one of his records
column5: I feel disappointed in myself. That was the case with Drums Between the Bells
column6: a worthy but uneven collaboration with the poet Rick Holland
column7: where sonic miracles sat cheek-by-jowl with dated electronic styles perhaps better left in mothballs. Now
column8: from the same sessions
column9: comes Panic of Looking. It's very slight
column10: and its clearest purpose is to augment Eno's recent residency at Asheville
column11: N.C.'s Moogfest (which honors electronic music pioneer Robert Moog)
column12: where the EP received an early release. But even Eno's spare parts give us something of substance to chew over.

column1: Panic of Looking is distinguished from its father LP by placing more emphasis on the words. This is a happy development
column2: because poetry is delicate. It can sound strained
column3: or even fake
column4: when it tries to scale the visceral heights of music. Instead
column5: music must lay back. If the glitchy sonics of Drums Between the Bells sometimes ran roughshod over the words
column6: Panic verges on overcorrection. Eno has engineered it to feel like Holland's show-- spoken-word with accompaniment
column7: sometimes engaged and sometimes desultory. It can be difficult to discuss the musical quotient because there's so little of it. The most developed tracks are ""In the Future"" and the title piece. The former draws out the tonality of speech via placid melodic counterpoint and euphoric backing vocals
column8: recalling the joyous world-pop of Eno/Byrne collaboration Everything That Happens Will Happen Today. The latter may be the best-balanced effort the collaboration has produced
column9: with Eno's taut textural background sensitively augmenting Holland's staccato verse. Beyond those
column10: we get a minute-long lite-industrial curio
column11: a pro forma instrumental
column12: and a couple less memorable fusions of orotund speech and crepuscular atmosphere.

column1: Poetry writing and poetry recitation are two very different talents that don't always-- or even often-- coexist. Inverting classical music's emphasis on the concert hall over the recording
column2: modern Western poetry favors the written word over the oral performance
column3: which has become something you do mainly in order to sell books
column4: regardless of whether or not you're any good at it. It's a weird cultural construct: Imagine if musicians were expected to promote their work by juggling. As a result
column5: even poetry lovers may emit a long-suffering groan at the prospect of attending yet another reading. But there are things oratory can do that text simply can't
column6: and Holland exploits them to his advantage
column7: especially on the title track. One of them is homophonic ambiguity: Is he saying ""speed and weight"" or ""speed and wait?"" Both concepts are compelling
column8: especially in flickering juxtaposition. Biting off words one by one
column9: Holland creates hard enjambments (""Men… shake… hands"") that deliver doses of meaning
column10: each altering the last
column11: as if from a time-release capsule. If all of this sounds more geared toward Eno completists and poetry fans than the general listener
column12:
that's about right.

His Cannabis Club card (probably) reads ""Jesse James
column2: but Seattle rapper Nacho Picasso willingly shares a name with something you'd expect to find at a Johnny Rockets in Barcelona. You will either think the alias is awesome or awful. There is no in-between. Yet it's instantly memorable and more fitting than anything that references a Jack Black/Lucha Libre vehicle has any right to be.

column1: Since Rick Rubin tried to create the ""worst shit ever
column2: rap has a long history of the highbrow-lowbrow game. Or what Ghostface Killah called the ""smart dumb cat."" Robinson is Nacho and Picasso
column3: part fast food
column4: part real deal. He is the hardcore hood nerd
column5: the walking talking paradox writ large. Or as he describes himself on For the Glory: ""Think like George Carlin/ Dress like Carlton/ Ball like Damon/ And wild like Marlon.""

column1: Nacho openly claims he's an arrogant asshole
column2: not to be trusted
column3: a bridge burner
column4: and a numbnuts. He dedicates his orgies to Dionysus. His album cover is a picture of him riding a horse dressed as Sir Lance-A-Lot
column5: while flanked by a Harry Potter castle and three nude goddesses. The latter continue Sir Mix-A-Lot's proud Emerald City tradition.

column1: Picasso proves that you don't need to practice the art of storytelling when you've mastered the art of saying nothing. And For the Glory is basically a paean to girls
column2: guns
column3: tattoos
column4: chronic
column5: and comics. There is an entire song
column6: ""Marvel""
column7: wherein Picasso basically compares himself to every summer blockbuster of the last decade. While it should feel like second-rate MF Doom
column8: Nacho spits slick and (partially) revelatory internal rhymes. He repeats
column9: ""Smoking/ Reading comic books
column10: until it becomes mantra
column11: like the kid from the cover of OutKast's ATLiens grown up.

column1: If anything
column2: For the Glory is a snub-nosed self-portrait. Picasso condenses information into one or two bars with the ease of a 1990s 5 Percent rapper. ""He's been a bad guy/ Since his dad died."" The self-aware scumbag redeemed through his honesty and arrant goofiness. On ""Moor Gang""
column3: he describes his life as ""Big butts and boobs/ Blunts and booze/ Watching Ninja Turtles II: Secret of the Ooze/ With my Steven Urkel frames and custom-made shoes."" And he even has the restraint to refrain from a Vanilla Ice punchline.

column1: That's the thing about Picasso
column2: he knows how to vividly render an image and largely avoid cliché. Even when he resorts to the tired mobster/rapper dualities of ""Benjamin Segal""
column3: he avoids the obvious Tony Montana trap. Circa 2011
column4: the norm is rappers so tatted-up they might as well be married to Sandra Bullock. But Picasso is one of the few who makes it seem like more than fashion accessory. On ""Sweaters""
column5: the self-proclaimed ""tat in the hat"" describes his body as a timeline and his face as something ageless. Later
column6: he says he's inked like a Rorschach blot and a fourth-grade desk.

column1: Half of the record captures Picasso as the affable stoner drawling in a seen-it-all baritone about 1980s professional wrestlers and characters from Half Baked. The guy who would insert a lesser remembered clip of White Men Can't Jump just for the fuck of it. The other side is the ruthless hustler whose car ""looks like Iceland
column2: who lashes out against ""bitches who say that he looks like Chris Brown."" The Black Flag-shirted
column3: bare knuckle-gypsy
column4: who shares his dead dad's love of anarchy. The end result is language-drunk and spliff-lit disorientation in the cold vein of vintage Cam'ron
column5: late-period Curren$y
column6: and the post-Def Jux disorderly conduct of Mr. Muthafuckin' eXquire.

column1: Picasso references his internal turmoil but never delves too deep. Nor does he need to. In his worldview
column2: there is little nostalgia for the past or dreams of the future-- just the weary gray of the hustle. Lyrically
column3: Seattle doesn't factor in much
column4: other than a stray reference to being from the city where they ""bust heads and clean clocks."" Thankfully
column5: producers Blue Sky Black Death and Raised by Wolves provide the requisite Pacific Northwestern pallor
column6: providing moody beats that suture ""Stepfather Factory""-era El-P to the mercury float of Clams Casino.

column1: During a year in which Shabazz Palaces has earned Seattle hip-hop more buzz since the last time slackers wore flannel
column2: Picasso grabs his fair share of the spotlight. For the Glory is one of the best rap debuts of the year
column3:
one that simultaneously manages to say everything but reveal nothing. Or as George Carlin would have said: Language is just a tool for concealing the truth.

column3: Misfits founding bassist Jerry Only successfully sued Danzig for the rights to perform and tour under the Misfits name. Ever since
column4: the reconstituted Only-lead group
column5: staffed by a rotating cast of punk-rock yeomen
column6: has traipsed across the globe
column7: delivering a Misfits-like product. It's not that the Only-Misfits are terrible-- the music hews closely to the group's original Buddy Holly-meets-B-movie template
column8: albeit with an added dash of metal riffage-- but it is goofier. Without Danzig's combustible presence
column9: the band softened into predictability
column10: their previous menace petering out into Scooby Doo villain-hood. In 1999
column11: they even popped up in a WCW cage match (and got creamed).

column1: Misfits' first album of new material in 12 years
column2: The Devil's Rain
column3: finds the band-- Only
column4: former Black Flag guitarist Dez Cadena
column5: and Murphy's Law drummer Eric Arce-- coldly chugging through the motions. In their original incarnation
column6: Misfits made blistering music out of seemingly contradictory impulses. They were muscle heads who bashed out primitive rhythms but sang like third-string crooners and obsessed over B-movie imagery. The sound was aggressive
column7: but romantic in its own tacky

column1: But nothing on The Devil's Rain growls with the unschooled simplicity of the early years-- songs like ""Come Back"" and ""Horror Business"" pitched and yawed on violent
column2: stone-age rhythms. Only
column3: who has taken over frontman duties

column5: Only strays too far into the latter category. On ""Curse of the Mummy's Hand""
column6: he sounds like Pat Boone doing Halloween karaoke. His songwriting is largely driven by straight-faced retellings of midnight movie clichés that come off silly rather than sinister. Like the previous Misfits Mk. II records-- American Psycho and Famous Monsters-- the production is notched up to contemporary pop-punk standards
column7: but added polish makes the music feel remote and impersonal.

column1: It didn't have to be this way. Since the 1980s
column2: Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan have lost some of their cachet as punk rock cannon fodder
column3: but Misfits' go-to protagonists
column4: the undead
column5: are having something of a renaissance as of late. Between The Walking Dead
column6: True Blood
column7: and Twilight
column8:
horror business is good. The Misfits' schtick should stand the test of time. But The Devil's Rain makes supernatural feel like fairly workaday stuff.

Bradford Cox knows a thing or two about creating a schism between his everyday self and the one he presents on record. In interviews he's garrulous and outspoken
column2: ostensibly brimming with confidence
column3: yet plagued by insecurity. All that self-doubt manifests itself in his solo project
column4: Atlas Sound
column5: where he often sounds small
column6: alone
column7: and cut adrift from the world. At times Cox seems at odds with himself
column8: but dig deeper and there's usually a thread running through his real-world activities and the ideas he obsesses over when recording.

column1: And he's always recording. Last year
column2: Cox released four albums of Atlas Sound demos as the free-download Bedroom Databank series. It's a wonder he can keep track of all his work
column3: but one of his biggest talents-- aside from his rich vein of form as a songwriter-- is as an editor. Not only does he know exactly what to release officially and what to preserve as a blog-only treat for fans
column4: he's also intuitively adept at compartmentalizing material into his Deerhunter and Atlas Sound worlds.

column1: Despite the separation
column2: those two modes aren't mutually exclusive
column3: and it's always interesting to see how Cox's two guises feed off each other while retaining strong individual identities. The last Deerhunter album
column4: Halcyon Digest
column5: ended with ""He Would Have Laughed""
column6: built around a spaghetti-like loop of synthesized noise. It mirrors a trick that's revisited just a few songs into <i>Parallax
column7: on ""Te Amo"". Here
column8: Cox leans on a repeating pattern
column9: then pulls away from it by testing the elasticity of his vocal range
column10: stretching into a gruff register he's rarely tried out before. Atlas Sound often functions this way
column11: taking baby steps on the road to evolution and leaving traces of previous material to ground the listener. The two constants are Cox's fascination with ambient music and the unabashed sadness at the heart of his writing. ""When you're down
column12: you're always down
column13: he croons on ""Te Amo"".

column1: Crooning has held Cox's interest for a while now. Versions of Hank Williams' ""I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry"" and the Rodgers and Hart standard ""Blue Moon"" appeared on his blog back in 2008
column2: and his cover of Joe Meek's ""Valley of the Saroos"" is one of his most impressive giveaways. Lately
column3: Cox has been playing around with image
column4: something he hasn't attempted much since his early dress-wearing days in Deerhunter
column5: and he appears to have settled on a hybrid of Meek-ian high hair and David Bowie's plastic emulation of the rock'n'roll era circa Let's Dance. On the Mick Rock-shot cover of Parallax he's even depicted clutching a vintage 1950s microphone. So it's appropriate that this record begins with ""The Shakes""
column6: where Cox casts himself as an idol who's grown bored of fame
column7: money
column8: and hangers-on masquerading as friends. It echoes Bowie's weary exasperation at the clamor for fame in the documentary Cracked Actor
column9: where he rides around middle America in a limo and compares himself to a fly swimming around in his glass of milk.

column1: That link to Bowie loops back to the Young Americans-style sax solo on ""Coronado"" from Halcyon Digest
column2: further indicating how one Cox project informs his others. But his omnivorous approach to music history
column3: and the restraint that keeps him from drawing too much from his heroes' own sounds
column4: makes Parallax a constantly shifting delight. In the past
column5: Cox's affinity for masked vocals allowed him to keep his guard up
column6: stopping listeners from encroaching on his malaise. Here
column7: he uses fewer vocal effects
column8: and the gentle balladry of ""Modern Aquatic Nightsongs"" and ""Terra Incognita"" benefit greatly from it. This cleaner approach to his art demonstrates his growing confidence as a singer and songwriter and feels more involving.

column1: But that's only part of the picture. Because Cox likes to confound
column2: surprise
column3: and keep his audience guessing
column4: one of his shiniest pop moments yet lies at the center of this record. ""Mona Lisa"" is a jaunty piece of melancholia-tinged guitar rock
column5: hung up somewhere between the livelier moments on R.E.M.'s Green and the rural tug at the heart of the Kinks' best material. Comparing this track with the deliberately jaded lyrical framework of ""The Shakes"" highlights one of the most fascinating juxtapositions about Cox; he's so well versed in music history that he knows he'll hate the pitfalls that await him if proper fame comes beckoning
column6: and yet his inclination toward deeply accessibile songwriting and infernally catchy pop melodies might drive him in that direction anyway. There's also more bridge-building on ""Mona Lisa"" and the garage-y ""My Angel Is Broken""
column7: where he sounds confident and vulnerable at the same time
column8: drawing some of that swagger he possesses in real life into his art.

column1: Parallax feels like a more complete work than any other Atlas Sound record
column2: with the differences between the songs less distinct and everything flowing together more naturally. ""Quick Canal"" was a standout on Logos but it also stood alone
column3: feeling like a neat one-off collaboration with a hero (in that case
column4: Stereolab singer Laetitia Sadier) that didn't readily come into focus in the overall picture. There are no such loose strands here
column5: and the closing ""Lightworks"" ends the album wonderfully with a tremoloed guitar shuddering against Cox's hankering vocal line and uncanny pop nouse. It's another testament to his editing skills; he can effortlessly balance a sizable load of contrasting styles and slot them together like it's the most natural thing in the world. That lightness of touch is on display throughout this album
column6: providing greater gravitas to Cox's brittle self-examination. Parallax still makes him sound small
column7: alone
column8: and cut adrift from the world
column9: but the way these songs breathe suggests he's more comfortable in his own skin
column10: allowing him to draw his audience closer than ever.

The songs on So Outta Reach were technically written during the same sessions that brought us Smoke Ring for My Halo
column2: Kurt Vile's still-resonant 2011 breakthrough
column3: but the boundaries separating Vile's recordings
column4: at this point
column5: are growing irrelevant: His discography is starting to blur into one long
column6: drawn-out sigh. Listening to hours of Kurt Vile
column7: you get the impression that he once discovered the Neil Young lyric
column8: ""Though my problems are meaningless/ That don't make them go away"" from ""On the Beach""
column9: decided to lie down in it a while
column10: and just never left.

column1: Like other cultishly obsessive songwriters
column2: however
column3: Vile manages to repeat himself without strictly repeating himself. Images and phrases cycle through his lyrics like tumbling socks in a dryer-- he mumbles the phrase ""two packs of red apples"" on both ""Red Apples"" from 2009's God Is Saying This to You
column4: and again on Halo's ""Runner Ups"". His releases often feature alternate versions of the same song
column5: which happens here with ""Life's a Beach"" and ""(so outta reach)""
column6: the second a faint echo of the first's muted shuffle. These are the sorts of subliminal tugs that map out the contours of a universe
column7: and Vile has carefully built one with small tools-- his mutter
column8: a bottomless cavern of reverb
column9: and glimmering tangles of guitars-- and painted it a dozen shades of steel-blue and watery gray.

column1: So Outta Reach
column2: then
column3: is a dispatch
column4: another stop along a journey
column5: and it's as good a place to tune into his frequency as any. ""The Creature""
column6: the opening song
column7: spins out another fragile variation on the wearily bemused blues he's perfected.  His acoustic fingerpicking remains stunning
column8: a narcotic blur of voicing that recalls his friend and former touring partner Jack Rose. Like Rose
column9: or like early Elliott Smith
column10: Vile's playing retunes your hearing to the limitless possibilities of the plain old acoustic guitar.

column1: Fingerpicking is
column2: of course
column3: a skill acquired only through endless hours hunched over the guitar; it's no coincidence
column4: perhaps
column5: that Vile's lyrics speak overwhelmingly of friends lost
column6: the dull pain of being left behind
column7: and the sad savor of solitude. So Outta Reach includes a cover of Bruce Springsteen's ""Downbound Train""
column8: blanketed in stoner-rock distortion
column9: and its hard-luck
column10: ""now I work at a car wash
column11: story folds seamlessly into Vile's landscape. But a careful study of his lyrics turns up little Zen-stoner nuggets of wisdom
column12: like this one from ""Life's a Beach"": ""Life's a while."" The line reminds me of Chevy Chase advising that ""a donut with no hole is a Danish"" in Caddyshack
column13: and suggests there's a sense of humor lurking beneath Vile's drooping curtain of hair.

column1: Dependability is an unglamorous virtue to champion
column2: yet at this point I reach for Vile's music like a glass of water. There's simple joy in the knowledge that falling for one Kurt Vile song practically ensures I will love a dozen others. I don't often find myself thinking about Vile when his music is not playing
column3: but his music nurses a profound ache
column4: and he's now made enough of it that it's become a whole corner to visit
column5: a unique transmission that feels like its own sentient being. As an artist
column6:
it's hard to aim higher than that.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['DFA']|2011-11-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:22.699594|"

The Juan MacLean
column3: aka John<span class=""st""> MacLean
column4: has been with the DFA since the beginning. In many ways
column5: his story is the story of the label itself. Much like DFA's core group
column6: LCD Soundsystem
column7: the ex-Six Finger Satellite musician came to dance music from an indie/punk rock background. He released a string of well-received 12""s-- his first predating LCD's breakout ""Losing My Edge"" and beaten onto the tracks only by the Rapture's ""House of Jealous Lovers""-- before eventually maturing into a solid album artist. These transitions from rock to electronic
column8: and from DJ-oriented 12"" to albums
column9: are also the tensions that animate the label.

column1: With that in mind
column2: it's been interesting to see how MacLean has responded to releasing one of the label's strongest
column3: and perhaps least expected albums
column4: 2009's The Future Will Come. First
column5: he offered the house classicism of his 2010 DJ-Kicks mix; now we have the previously released odds-and-ends of Everybody Get Close
column6: a collection that both dimly mirrors Future and shows MacLean stretching into the production of more faceless but more functional dance tracks.

column1: Like The Future Will Come
column2: this record's varied electro tracks are anchored by one awesome 10-minute workout. Here it's ""Feel So Good""-- with its endlessly building house pianos
column3: rolling background percussion
column4: and Nancy Whang's clipped come-ons
column5: it almost reads like a dub version of his 2008 single ""Happy House"". (In fact
column6: it makes the actual version of ""Happy House"" that's included here-- an alternately wan and annoying nu-Balearic rework by Cut Copy-- feel more superfluous than it already is.)

column1: Two remixes of Future's lone ballad ""Human Disaster"" appear as well-- the Holmes Price version holds onto MacLean's regretful singing and heavy
column2: hanging piano chords
column3: but sets them against trilling synths and an old-school electro beat; Jee Day smears the piano chords into a haze of reverb then brings them back as a muffled loop that echoes the triplet pattern of ""Happy House"" amid an unnecessarily busy rhythm track. The album is bookended with the two cuts that sound most like Future B-sides
column4: the vocal electro of ""Find a Way"" and its vocodered echo ""Everybody Get Close"".

column1: The tracks that fare best are those that veer furthest away from Future's Human League-meets-house template. For instance
column2: ""Let's Talk About Me"" is a squealing
column3: percolating acid track with pitched-up vocals reminiscent of Zomby's ""Fuck Mixing
column4: Let's Dance"" (and therefore of a whole swath of circa 1992 rave). ""X2"" is a dark
column5: sonar-pinging track that could pass for Shit Robot. ""Deviant Device"" is a floating bit of dubby ambient techno that slowly unfolds over nine minutes to become one of the most enjoyable tracks on the collection.

column1: Sadly
column2: Everybody Get Close doesn't function as a benchmark of MacLean's between-album progress
column3: as it collects tracks dating back at far as four years. Some of these feel like scraps and sketches
column4: others like the B-sides they are-- which is fine when the scraps are this frequently exciting-- but given the range of his output so far
column5:
what would be most satisfying would be to get a glimpse of where MacLean's heading next.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17144/homepage_large.5a530362.jpg|IOTDXI|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['R&S']|2011-11-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:23.296962|"

Of all the great hubs for forward-thinking bass music the past half decade (see: Hotflush
column2: Hyperdub
column3: Punchdrunk
column4: Hessle)
column5: Belgian-born
column6: London-based R&S Records has the deepest roots. Since its founding in 1984
column7: artists like Model 500
column8: Joey Beltram and Aphex Twin have roosted there; its logo was parodied by London's queer disco party Horse Meat Disco. When the label returned from an absence in 2006 and set up shop in London
column9: bass music was a natural focus. Concentrating on singles and EPs
column10: the label has since released some of the most adventurous material by James Blake
column11: Untold
column12: and Lone. IOTDXI is a 2xCD/3xLP compilation that collects highlights from the past 18 months and
column13: as is the custom these days
column14: presents 10 exclusive tracks as well.

column1: Everyone (including myself) has pontificated about the spreading tendrils of bass music
column2: but sometimes it feels less like evolution and more like insects scattering after a rock's been lifted. The fervor with which the bass community has adopted deep Chicago house
column3: Berlin minimal
column4: and Detroit techno has begun to feel like an abandonment of purpose. What's most refreshing about IOTDXI is listening to a group of artists who have largely clung to quick syncopation
column5: mildly aggressive bass
column6: and arrested vocal samples.

column1: High praise: The highlights disc contains a handful of songs so familiar they threaten tedium. Blake's ""CMYK""
column2: Lone's ""Coreshine Voodoo""
column3: and Pariah's ""Orpheus"" form a potent trio in the middle of the first disc; anyone who hasn't worn their bytes thin on mixes and DJ sets the past two years is encouraged to do so here. The disc is better
column4: perhaps
column5: at reminding us of the young talent R&S has put to wax. Cloud Boat offers sighing dubstep heartbreak on ""Lions on the Beach"" (and is noticeably absent from the exclusives disc)
column6: while the lightly whipped synth-pop of Vondelpark's ""Camels"" feels refreshing at the close of the first disc.

column1: Appending an exclusives disc to a retrospective has become common practice for electronic music labels
column2: but I wonder if a game-theory course or two wouldn't help them better incentivize their artists. Knowing that the label will be judged
column3: not the artists
column4: seems like a surefire way to collect the fourth-best track sitting on every producer's hard drive. (Another problem
column5: of course
column6: is that these exclusives sit opposite the producers' best by design.) R&S has enough talent on the roster to remain appealing. Lone places piano house in a blender on ""Cobra"". Blawan returns to form after his disappointing ""What You Do With What You Have"" single
column7: offering aggressive
column8: hoofed dubstep. The curious Space Dimension Controller apply lush
column9: lounge-y tempos to analog video game patter.

column1: You'd be right to assume that your collection doesn't need Oneohtrix Point Never's gassy remix of ""Orpheus"" or the Chain's tech-y
column2: mundane ""Suffer for Your Art"". We can safely write these off as consequences of format
column3: because the overriding message that IOTDXI delivers is that R&S is a healthy
column4: engaged label equally capable of housing established talents and coaxing out fresh ones. If there's no explicit sense of direction or momentum
column5:
perhaps that's because R&S understands permanence more than most of its peers.

"|16007.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16007-iotdxi/|7.1|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17145/homepage_large.8f32e257.jpg|GLAQJO XAACSSO|27829.0|patten|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['No Pain in Pop']|2011-11-07 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:23.836497|"

GLAQJO XAACSSO is a fittingly obtuse name for London producer Patten's debut EP. The record-- full of scrambled sounds you recognize from elsewhere-- feels like it could exist in a parallel universe. The sensation of this music
column2: which does have a peculiar thrill to it
column3: can also be a frustrating riddle: At times
column4: you'll want to dive into the waveforms and pull the fragments back into a right order and find some sense.

column1: The collection's probably more engaging a concept or idea than straight-up listen
column2: but there is fun to be had in the way the beats spin your head. Less concerned with the relentless drive into the future than some of his peers
column3: Patten's forging a sound off the beaten path
column4: cherry-picking past sounds and twisting them.

column1: Much of the record finds Patten looking toward 1990s Warp acts. ""Blush Mosaic"" takes Boards of Canada's icy synths and softly pushes fast-forward
column2: revving something glacial into something manic-- the aural equivalent of a stop-motion nature video. Vocals drift in and out as rhythms weave around each other. It's one of the record's strongest statements
column3: and a track where Patten's sometimes unfocused energy comes together to make something engaging
column4: trippy
column5: and destroyed.

column1: On ""Fire Dream"" there are shades of Plaid and Autechre
column2: especially in the pale analog synths. Patten matches that patchwork with powdery hi-hats and head-knocking beats. It's not only piecemeal scraps of Warp influence in the music
column3: though-- there's a general influence in attitude and approach. Even the baiting LP title seems like the kind of brick wall Richard D. James or Chris Morris would erect. That approach carries over to the source material: Nothing feels too holy for Patten to throw into the blender.

column1: On the strongest moments
column2: like ""Blush Mosaic"" and ""Fire Dream""
column3: the bent circuitry is visceral and engaging
column4: but there are instances where those loose rhythmic threads don't knot together so well. Take the motion-sick ""Out the Coast""
column5: where the beats collapse into each other and don't quite blend with the rest of the action. It feels like there's something good buried within
column6: but the effect is jarring and disorientating (not pleasantly so).

column1: A problem with his whirlwind approach is that each idea's so quickly processed it can leave the results feeling too breathless or rushed. A nice moment passes so quickly that it immediately becomes a dot on the horizon. There also isn't a great deal of contrast on the record. And not a lot of warmth. It's here Patten strikes the biggest contrast with the artists he might be referencing or reminding you of: A great deal of music on that IDM spectrum that Patten picks apart has heart to it. On his Come to Daddy EP
column2: for instance
column3: Aphex Twin closes the record with the gorgeous ""IZ-US"". Likewise
column4: Squarepusher
column5: at his busiest on ""Port Rhombus""
column6: pulls away the rhythmic carpet to reveal a lilting
column7: lush guitar. There are no moments like this for Patten
column8: and for all its movement
column9:
GLAQJO XAACSSO feels a little frozen.

"|16008.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16008-patten-glaqjo-xaacsso/|6.7|Hari Ashurst

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17140/homepage_large.97331cde.jpg|The Vision|22494.0|Joker|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['4AD']|2011-11-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:23.992337|"

Pop music amplifies and lionizes its creators by default
column2: while empathy comes from the capital-M music and the community. This has remained true as the music industry has changed and it has remained true as DJs-- Daft Punk
column3: David Guetta
column4: Deadmau5-- have risen to pop-culture prominence. It's why so much of the coverage of an artist like Robyn focuses on her smallness and approachability; it is not the norm. On his debut album
column5: Bristol-based producer Joker (Liam McLean) wants to be a hero. The Vision
column6: arriving after years of delays and false starts
column7: is not for the industrial streets of Bristol
column8: London's maturing club culture
column9: or the small pockets of hyper-aware American undergrounders eager for bombast that doesn't result in our getting wedgied in a mosh pit. All of those scenes are made to feel small next to the righteous blockbuster-ing of The Vision
column10: an album so impressed with itself that there's little need for the listener to be so.

column1: It's not hard to figure out how Joker arrived here. As part of the ""purple"" (post-) dubstep movement
column2: Joker (along with Gemmy and Guido) suggested that the end-game for dubstep's engorged bass rumble did not have to be masculine aggression. He unleashed a nearly bulletproof string of singles and for well over a year did seem heroic-- his superpower a Magneto-like control of your mid-range dial
column3: his age proof that there were skills yet to harness. His breakout came as dubstep was graduating from pervasive force to ubiquitous cultural presence (in England) and seemed to cement his status as a comer.

column1: That The Vision is more pop-oriented
column2: more streamlined
column3: and more self aware won't be a surprise to anyone who has paid attention. It paints the picture of a producer who not only missed his moment but whose verve and craft dissolved as he waited. The Vision buckles
column4: repeatedly
column5: under a mass of unwieldy guest appearances
column6: pandering pop moves
column7: and Joker's ever-present
column8: oxygen-eating synths. An album meant to display a producer's power and confidence-- from the title to the cover art on down-- instead reveals a reliance on formula and a crippling indecisiveness. Grime
column9: R&B
column10: stadium pop
column11: and dubstep all come in for the most tepid of updates.

column1: Most of the collaborators-- on board to tease out those genre plays-- are ill-chosen and marginally talented. With the exception of Jessie Ware (Santigold to Katy B's M.I.A.
column2: right down to her bigger voice and handful of kickass tunes)
column3: they serve as haughty ciphers
column4: funneling heaps of entitlement and no small amount of paranoia into these tracks. Silas
column5: on the functionally widescreen ""Slaughter House"": ""They wrap you up in plastic and ship it to the store."" Who? 4AD? (More damning still
column6: from Silas: ""You can hang around and see what the hook brings."" I can!) ""On My Mind"" is ""Love in this Wal-Mart"" for the post-Timbaland set. It features the line
column7: ""Rumor has it that you want a man with a big di-di-[ed. note: wait for it] digital following."" This is presented without a hint of humor or irony; somewhere Lonely Island's number three is slapping his forehead. Joker's most fruitful and charming vocal collaboration-- ""Music (4am)""-- perplexingly misses the cut.

column1: What's most distressing is that The Vision doesn't sound like Joker's version of R&B and hip-hop ruined by less talented collaborators; it sounds like Joker's version of the same ruined by Joker. He has strip-mined his chewy
column2: mid-range melodies for their largess
column3: applying it liberally to standard verse-chorus-bridge structures. Removing the cast of self-aggrandizing twits from ""Back in the Days"" doesn't get you to ""Digidesign""; the children's choir on ""Lost"" is a far cry from the whirling-dervish-house of ""Snake Eater"". The best ""classic"" Joker track included is ""Tron""
column4: an early-2010 offering that preceded the unrelated Hollywood remake that you've already forgotten about and was thought at the time to be among his weakest tracks.

column1: The comparison I keep coming back to for The Vision is Canibus' Can-I-Bus
column2: American hip-hop's nuclear option for unrealized potential and perceived slights. Like Can-I-Bus
column3: The Vision required a perfect storm of bad advice
column4: arrogance
column5: and wretched timing. It irks that a series of Joker's peers-- among them SBTRKT
column6: Rustie
column7: and Magnetic Man-- have established a blueprint for bass producers looking to go pop without sacrificing direction or personality. On ""Slaughter House"" Silas finishes his rhyme: ""They wrap you up in plastic and ship it to the store/ But deep in your bones you know you were made for something more."" On an album of terrible
column8: throwaway lines
column9: this is the worst: Joker was absolutely made for this. He arrived fully formed
column10: a shy kid buried in synthesizers and video games
column11: born for music. Whatever has transpired since
column12:
The Vision seems to be exactly what Joker wants: UK pop&B of the vainest and most vacuous possible variety.

"|16003.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16003-the-vision/|4.2|Andrew Gaerig

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17142/homepage_large.93d4396f.jpg|Ambition|10147.0|Wale|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.'
column2:
'Maybach']|2011-11-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:24.562500|"

Ambition: Wale certainly can't be faulted for it. After his 2009 Interscope debut Attention Deficit bricked
column3: selling a chastening 28
column4: 000 copies its first week
column5: most presumed he would disappear soundlessly
column6: like his fellow 2009 XXL Freshmen classmates Asher Roth and Charles Hamilton. He had failed to become a serious pop star
column7: represent his D.C. hometown
column8: or smuggle social consciousness  into the rap mainstream-- his three bedrock campaign promises. But instead of disappearing
column9: Wale caught the eye of Rick Ross
column10: just as the Miami kingpin was transforming into commercial  rap's all-devouring center of gravity
column11: and climbed aboard Rozay's ascendant Maybach Music Group. Ambition
column12: the result of a pairing nobody saw coming
column13: inaugurates the curious second phase of Wale Folarin's increasingly fascinating career.

column1: The record is a testament to the virtue in the album's title. Never say Wale doesn't learn from mistakes: Everything that dragged down Attention Deficit
column2: from  hipster-baiting to its bewildering guest roster
column3: has been jettisoned
column4: along with introspection and any lingering modicum of respect for women. On Ambition
column5: Wale is reborn as an unrepentantly shallow  strip-club rapper
column6: and the production is a gleaming phalanx of freshly minted beats from Ross' MMG assembly line.  The album is unmistakably a product of Planet Boss
column7: the lurid neon kingdom of B-movie saxes and cartoon excess in which Rick Ross has built his empire. And Ambition provides a remarkably effective demonstration in how a shpritz of Planet Boss can jumpstart a flagging rapper's fortunes.

column1: Wale's complete persona 180 will strike his original fanbase as repellantly cynical
column2: and there is something vaguely unsavory and disorienting in the eagerness with which he embraces his new role. But it turns out that many of the gifts that got him noticed in the first place-- a nimble tongue
column3: a high-stepping flow-- lend themselves as well to flossy nonsense about watches and women as they did to examining the sociopolitical implications of Soundscan. And Ambition is a high-velocity parade of flossy nonsense
column4: with an extremely dense ratio of Headslaps-Per-Minute: ""I'm sort of like Socrates in a Prada T""; ""I aspire  for awesome/ That requires some flossin'""; ""Fuck rap
column5: I get pussy off of haiku."" There is a Sandra Bullock namedrop that references the 1992 sci-fi comedy Love Potion No. 9. Everything is fast-moving
column6: breezily entertaining
column7: and patently ridiculous.

column1: Even swilling champagne at the winners' table
column2: however
column3: Wale remains something less than ""fun."" He always had the gift for seeing the negative that you might expect from someone who structured an entire mixtape around clips of old Seinfeld dialogue
column4: and it rears its head in a  lot of ranting about silencing his critics. ""Sippin Moscato with models
column5: havin exotic  dishes/ But it don't mean shit unless I know that my genre respected
column6: he gripes on ""Don't Hold Your Applause"". And his smooth-loverman  approach
column7: bluntly
column8: needs fine-tuning: on the treacly slow jam ""Lotus Flower  Bomb""
column9: he offers the hilariously stilted compliment ""Took you forever to  get dressed/ I acknowledge your effort."" Uh
column10: thanks
column11: Wale!

column1: The production
column2: however
column3: from a cannily sourced collection of lesser-known  beatmakers and big names
column4: sounds uniformly incredible: Ambition is the first sign that Maybach Music Group has flowered into a full-blown production house. Mark Henry
column5: who  has produced some sledgehammer beats for Fat Joe
column6: gives Wale the  fleet-footed ""Miami Nights""
column7: which pipes in some woolly sax from Ross' ""Maybach Music II""
column8: and the window-fogging funk of ""Double M Genius"". Toomp chops up strings like early-millennium Just Blaze on ""Legendary"". MMG stalwart Tone P serves up
column9: among others
column10: the brain-rattling ""Chain  Music"". The album will sound devastating pounding out of passing Escalades
column11: and it is currently slated to pound out of many; early estimates peg Ambition's first-week sales at around 170

column1: Those numbers will surely provide a certain vindication for Wale
column2: but above all they signal a triumph for Maybach Music. When Ross signed  Wale
column3: I joked that Rozay must have lost his taste for money. But his imprint has taken a temperamental rapper whose name had become synonymous with commercial kryptonite and molded him into a passable pop star. Listening to Ambition
column4: I began to wonder what delirious commercial miracles Bawse might cook up for Pill
column5: Meek Mill
column6: and the other seemingly unmarketable rappers on his roster: Meek Mill with a No. 1? Pill with a gold plaque? Who knows. What Ambition proves beyond a doubt
column7: however
column8: is that commercial rap
column9: right now
column10: is Ross' world. People like Wale
column11: if they are lucky
column12:
get to live in it.
