0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17084/homepage_large.2c1f20d9.jpg|Uget|22117.0|Theo Parrish|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ugly Edits']|2011-11-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:25.091627|"

It's hard to imagine disco music (much less modern dance music and hip-hop) without the edit
column2: wherein songs had their choice drum breaks extended
column3: were trimmed of excess
column4: or looped for greater duration and danceability. Or as one DJ put it to me
column5: edits arose from the pleasure principle
column6: that ""when you hear something great
column7: you want it to continue."" Early disco DJs used them as secret weapons for their dancefloors
column8: as did hip-hop's pioneers
column9: spinning familiar songs into alternate universes
column10: but after the heyday of Chicago house masters like Ron Hardy and Frankie Knuckles
column11: the edit as a DJ tool faded from view.

column1: While London's DJ Harvey dropped his series of ""Black Cock"" edits in the mid-1990s
column2: it was when Detroit producer Theo Parrish's self-deemed ""ugly"" edits (complete with slapdash spray-painted labels) lurched into view at the turn of the 21st century that the trend came back in full force. Rather than resort to using scalpel and cutting block
column3: the technology allowed dancefloor professionals like Prins Thomas
column4: Pilooski
column5: and even James Murphy to drop such reconfigured tunes. It also allowed newbies and bedroom DJs alike to make their own edits
column6: albeit to diminishing returns.

column1: Theo Parrish's limited disco edits remain in high demand
column2: getting bootlegged repeatedly (a bootleg of a bootleg?) and going for ludicrous sums online. And while this collection has neither ""Ugly Edits"" nor Theo Parrish's name anywhere on the art
column3: the handy 2xCD set compiles the first eight editions of those edits released over a three-year period. It's not just an affordable compendium of the wiggly
column4: playful
column5: grimy
column6: and irreducible disco edits the man had his way with
column7: but also a fine gateway into his wholly idiosyncratic soundworld
column8: suggesting a common ground between Larry Levan and Brion Gysin.

column1: Always an inscrutable music-maker
column2: with productions eschewing the distinctions erected between house
column3: jazz
column4: funk
column5: avant-garde electronic
column6: and soul music
column7: all of Parrish's traits can be heard in the perfect opening track
column8: a woozy
column9: spiraling edit of Jill Scott's ""Slowly Surely"" from her 2000 debut album. Starting with a glitching CD
column10: tocking drum machine
column11: and a voicemail from the singer herself
column12: she thanks him for a CD that she has yet to listen to. She talks of her over-protective manager but that polite backpedal transforms into a gently cycling whispered plaint: ""I just don't know where I should go."" Pillowy soft chords lift and drift back down; a woodblock and some other random percussive moments get foregrounded only to dissipate. Yet somehow 12 of the most effervescent minutes in house music have surely drifted past.

column1: The set's bread and butter is in how Parrish dices and lengthens funk and soul cuts by acts such as the Dells
column2: Minnie Riperton
column3: Willie Hutch
column4: Funkadelic
column5: and Kool & the Gang. He takes Sylvester's ""Dance"" and boils it down to rubbery bassline
column6: incessant hi-hat
column7: and a pickup line for its first three minutes before the dancefloor release comes. In teasing out Sugarhill Gang's late-period joint ""Hot Hot Summer Day""
column8: he lobs off all their wack rapping and instead elevates the melted-butter backing vocals from the last third of the song
column9: spinning a nine-minute epic out of it.

column1: Which is not to say he emphasizes only the bright
column2: dancefloor-friendly aspects of tracks. When he takes incidental music from Quincy Jones's score for The Color Purple
column3: a clanging polyrhythmic vocal chant dissolves into a disquieting stab of strings. In reworking slick boogie band GQ's ""Lies""
column4: he offsets a loop about ""a party going on"" with a man agonizing
column5: ""I got to know why
column6: to a cheating woman.

column1: On the easily recognizable Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes' Philly-Soul classic
column2: ""The Love I Lost""
column3: Parrish drops us midway into the track. He makes Teddy Pendergrass' honeyed yet gritty vocals bump against the sparse organ and guitar opening of the song (with plenty of vinyl crackle at the edges) before dumping both atop the propulsive middle section. What makes its sloppy nine minutes work is how he swings the equalization to extremes on every component
column4: finding new spaces and juxtapositions where there previously were none. What should be familiar and mere repetition is anything but. As he once told Resident Advisor: ""Repetition kind of sets a certain mass in a song… then there's little bits that come in and out and these changes that kinda shift on that pivot. This is where I go in my head sometimes… shifting
column5: spinning
column6: all kinds of stuff."" Consider these 18 tracks
column7: then
column8:
the results of Parrish's ever-spinning musical centrifuge.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17129/homepage_large.be7a4fbb.jpg|Far Side Virtual|28709.0|James Ferraro|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippos in Tanks']|2011-11-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:25.716887|"

James Ferraro's latest stares down our contemporary world of the future
column2: invaded by iPads
column3: overwhelmed by Skype meetings
column4: and caught up in the unnecessary conveniences of self-serve frozen yogurt spots
column5: with an equal sense of dread and awe. All those 1980s and 90s approximations of the future
column6: in which we'd collectively have luxury stacked on top of luxury
column7: actually sort of arrived
column8: and they're totally awesome-- and really fucking creepy.

column1: Far Side Virtual is inspired by goofy junk like the Windows 95 sound (composed by Brian Eno
column2: it should be mentioned) and the melodies that kick out of a medium-priced keyboard when you punch the ""demo"" button. It's a collection of eerily wholesome sounds delivered in an uncomfortably straightforward manner. Either a whole lot of work or very little work went into this record.

column1: This is a ""sell-out"" album. Not in the pejorative sense of pandering-- it's actually a much more difficult listen than his previous work-- but because it's intended to score mindless comfort and endless hours of outlet shopping. And unlike his other releases
column2: which toyed with similar concepts of getting lost in the technological
column3: consumerist singularity of energy drinks
column4: action flicks
column5: and worldwide web convenience
column6: this one doesn't send the soundtrack through the gossamer hum of a VHS. There's no distance between the concept and the execution here. Every sound on
column7: say
column8: ""Fro Yo and Cellular Bits""-- a triple threat of rocking drums
column9: melting synths
column10: and a guitar solo that wants to be Eddie Van Halen but comes closer to Stan Bush-- is clear as a bell.

column1: Indeed
column2: the songs here are exactly the same as what they're ostensibly parodying
column3: which is bold and maybe even the point. Such dedication to an aesthetic means Far Side Virtual gets a little tedious: It's 16 songs that aren't all that catchy but aren't exactly ambient either. Subsumed by his concept
column4: Ferraro is one with the buying and selling machine
column5: which was perhaps his perverse goal all along. ""Hopefully these songs were made available for ringtone
column6: he declared in this Elle interview
column7: ""and the album will be condensed into ringtone format
column8: so the album won't be the centerpiece
column9: it will just dissipate into the infrastructure.""

column1: There is however
column2: an obsessive focus on authenticity that really works towards justifying the album's goofy indulgences. Quite a few tracks feature a robotic voice speaking to you (""Sir
column3: Richard Branson's avatar says hello"")
column4: providing a bizarre
column5: world-building aspect to the project. And
column6: hey
column7: this kind of music is pretty great! There is a place for pleasant
column8: lilting tunes made to be ignored. The propulsive MIDI symphony of ""Dubai Dream Tone"" and the stiff jazz on ""Adventures in Green Foot Printing"" are undeniable and surprisingly affecting-- like a cyborg Vince Guaraldi was placed in front of a keyboard and told to knock out some somber tunes.

column1: The nightmarish qualities of the music begin to break through on ""Dream On"" and ""Condo Pets""
column2: both of which possess some of the creepy
column3: cacophonous drone of Citrac or Night Dolls With Hairspray
column4:
subtly unveiling the horrors behind music that's just way too springy and wide-eyed. You suddenly realize you're listening to 45 minutes of utilitarian music that doesn't really have a purpose. Can something be utopian and dystopian at the same time? Probably. Maybe even always.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17131/homepage_large.d34da787.jpg|In Animal Tongue|5716.0|Evangelista|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Constellation']|2011-11-04 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:27.244835|"

Through all her varied disguises
column2: from the Geraldine Fibbers to Ethyl Meatplow and back
column3: Carla Bozulich's barbed voice has always been an instantly recognizable instrument. With her versatile project Evangelista
column4: she seems at last to have found its ideal vehicle. In Animal Tongue is the latest album under the Evangelista name
column5: and hearing it can feel like watching a veteran character actress with an expertise for perfecting new accents finally sink her teeth into a meaty
column6: recurring role. Though In Animal Tongue stills draws on many of the same elements that have informed her previous work (blues
column7: industrial noise
column8: spoken word) they have here been distilled ever further down to a murky
column9: brooding essence.

column1: Never an especially conventional band to begin with
column2: Evangelista have been gradually edging away from standard rock textures. Whereas previous albums <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11360-hello-voyager/"" target=""_blank"">Hello
column3: Voyager and Prince of Truth contained sudden moments of loud metallic catharsis
column4: In Animal Tongue is almost entirely percussion-less and frequently arrhythmic. Bozulich is joined once again by bassist Tara Barnes and arranger/multi-instrumentalist Dominic Cramp
column5: who provide a necessary degree of continuity
column6: but there is something essentially solitary and lonesome about Evangelista's music. With her lyrics filled with references to blood
column7: natural danger
column8: and combat
column9: Bozulich gives In Animal Tongue the impression of a wild animal crouched ominously in a darkened corner
column10: waiting patiently for the opportunity to strike.

column1: From a sonic standpoint
column2: Evangelista's most natural ancestor is the noisier work of Tom Waits circa Bone Machine or The Black Rider. Unlike Waits
column3: however
column4: Bozulich makes no use of either grand
column5: weepy melodies or any vestige of wry humor. Indeed the semi-spoken whispers and mutters of such tracks as ""Black Jesus"" or ""Die Alone"" can seem to lack any sense of movement
column6: with Bozulich’s bleak and emotive vocals (""My body has failed me on this cold night
column7: and I'll die by myself in the dark"") destined to circle endlessly through the shadowy wilderness.

column1: After a point this lightless gloom can get a tad oppressive
column2: but Evangelista are able to leaven the mood somewhat through consistently inventive instrumentation. The album's most percussive track
column3: ""Hands of Leather""
column4: is driven by guitar and handclaps
column5: and though its lyrics might easily be about a boxing match
column6: the impact is that of accidentally stumbling onto an ancient forest ritual. On ""Tunnel to the Stars""
column7: the rhythms drop away to be replaced by a churning string quartet
column8: composed by Dominic Cramp
column9: with Bozulich's distorted vocals riding queasily over the din.

column1: Most arresting of all might be the closing piece
column2: ""Hatching"". On this track Bozulich's voice makes the briefest of cameos
column3: while the rest of group shudders through what could be an obscure horror-film score. It is a sound that is not a million miles away from the haunted
column4: sample-based soundtracks of Demdike Stare
column5: blending live instrumentation with Dominic Cramp's cut-and-paste arrangement
column6:
and one that suggests that Evangelista should continue to find ways to cut new paths through the darkness.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17137/homepage_large.782ca7d9.jpg|Ceremonials|26688.0|Florence and the Machine|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Universal Republic']|2011-11-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:27.801303|"

When I first saw Florence and the Machine two years ago at New York's cozy and beloved Bowery Ballroom
column2: leader Florence Welch's voice was simply too loud for the room. She sounded massive
column3: but shrill. Overpowering. If the show took place in an X-Men movie
column4: the wind gushing from Welch's lungs would have propelled several patrons smashing through the Bowery's back window onto Delancey Street. The next time I encountered That Voice
column5: it was five months later
column6: in the relatively gigantic Terminal 5 on Manhattan's far west side. And while that venue is often knocked for its booming
column7: detail-abolishing acoustics
column8: and concrete-slab atmosphere
column9: it was a much better fit for Welch
column10: who hopped
column11: ran
column12: and wailed while 3
column13: 000 giddy fans looked on
column14: awestruck. For this band and this singer
column15: nothing could be too big. Or so it seemed.

column1: Growing up
column2: Welch was met with stern eyes when she was caught singing her favorite hymns with a bit too much verve. Her unbridled talent is the type of thing producers of TV singing contests fantasize about. It's soulful. It's instant. It's blaring. On ""American Idol""
column3: contestants like Welch are invariably deemed ""quirky"" and doomed to runner-up status. And though Welch is a more convincing Artist than even the best ""Idol"" has to offer
column4: make no mistake that her voice-first delivery is perfectly tailored for a generation who grew up judging singers as much as they listened to them. Even the hopelessly hip crowd that showed up to see Welch at Vice's Creators Project event last month saved one of their biggest ovations for the moment when she held out one piercing note for an exaggerated period of time-- a primal sign of skill that banks on nothing less than sheer audacity.

column1: The same can be said of Florence and the Machine's second album
column2: Ceremonials
column3: which can feel like Welch simply holding out a single note at top volume for an hour. On paper
column4: the album takes a wise path. After trying out a few different producers and styles-- garage-pop; vampy twinkle-pop; and tribal
column5: mystic-pop-- on her debut
column6: Lungs
column7: Welch settles almost exclusively on the latter for Ceremonials
column8: bringing along producer Paul Epworth
column9: who was so good at the mystic stuff on the first record
column10: to oversee the whole thing. So what we get is Florence trying very hard to top the gargantuan drums and cascading harps and chest-thumping choruses of Lungs hits like ""Cosmic Love"" and ""Rabbit Heart (Raise It Up)"" on damn near every song. Instead of Lungs' largely charming yet discombobulating diversity
column11: Ceremonials suffers from a repetitiveness that's akin to looking at a skyline filled with 100-story behemoths lined-up one after the other
column12: blocking out everything but their own size.

column1: Some of these world wonders stand tall despite their surroundings. First single ""Shake It Out""
column2: a stadium-willing anthem about getting past one's troubles
column3: sets a new high for this group. As does the similarly barreling ""No Light
column4: No Light""
column5: which is one of the few tracks where Welch sets aside her usual flighty
column6: dreamy
column7: goth-y lyrical go-to's-- ghosts
column8: graveyards
column9: devils
column10: angels
column11: myths
column12: drowning-- for something a bit more personal. ""Would you leave me
column13: if I told you what I'd become
column14: she sings during the track's magisterial bridge
column15: ""'Cause it's so easy to sing it to a crowd/ But it's so hard
column16: my love/ To say it to you out loud."" The lines double as a snippet of self-criticism; perhaps Welch finds it ""so easy"" to sing her tunes to thousands because they often lack an individual touch that could send them even further skyward-- the same touch that comes so naturally to fellow UK chart queen Adele. But by the midway point of the LP
column17: its endless crescendos start bleeding into each other
column18: and the loudness soon tires itself out.

column1: The few tracks that deviate from the heavens-broken-open formula hardly curb frustrations. The haughty ""Breaking Down"" could be an outtake from MGMT's career-stalling Congratulations
column2: dirge-y ""Seven Devils"" aims for Beelzebub but is about as haunting as a toddler with a pitchfork. In what's becoming an increasingly annoying problem in this era of iTunes bonus tracks and myriad deluxe editions
column3: it's the extras not included on the proper album that offer reasonable outs for Florence's Big issues. ""Remain Nameless"" replaces the record's corporate-rock drums and overzealous whoosh with an electronic minimalism similar to Welch's pals the xx. The song's allowed to breathe
column4: and is all the better for it. Other bonuses include a few demos of some of the record's huger cuts (and the term ""demo"" is relative here-- these stripped-back tracks are still pristine). Backed by only acoustic instrumentation
column5: we finally hear the creases in Welch's voice that the album whitewashes at every turn.

column1: ""I don't want your future
column2: don't need your past/ One bright moment
column3: is all I ask
column4: sings Welch on choir-aided closer ""Leave My Body"". Ceremonials is so hell-bent on providing such ""bright moments""-- that flash of overwhelming emotion resulting from ramped-up strings or a frantic harp or a particularly audacious vocal run-- that it never zooms out to consider its own listenability. Welch is 25
column5: and she's likely chuffed at the thought of bringing these massive songs to equally immense crowds at festivals all over the world for the next two years. And that's where many of these tracks will have the greatest chance to thrive-- in the open
column6: with heads as far as one can see. On record
column7: though
column8:
too much is crushed by blind ambition.

"|16004.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16004-ceremonials/|6.0|Ryan Dombal

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17130/homepage_large.b6d3aa16.jpg|Blouse|29693.0|Blouse|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2011-11-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:28.440822|"

I often return to this line from Simon Reynolds' Retromania: ""Unlike digital formats
column2: analogue degrades through overuse: each listener kills the sound she loves."" There's a certain comfort in that kind of reciprocity
column3: and anyone who's ever accidentally reset the listening history on their iTunes library and felt like they'd wiped a part of their identity clean is familiar with the digital world's maddening indifference to our affection. With that observation
column4: Reynolds hits on the unifying and fundamentally human allure of chillwave
column5: lo-fi
column6: smear-pop
column7: and any other kind of contemporary music that makes a conscious choice in an Auto-Tuned world to sound less than pristine. It's music trying to approximate the grubby
column8: hopelessly destructive way we love books
column9: records
column10: and each other.

column1: Like a pre-owned Delorean or a Berlin cassette slowly decaying in the bargain bin
column2: Portland trio Blouse's self-titled debut comes to us sounding like it's already been colored by somebody else's use. Though it's got an unabashedly Reagan-era sound
column3: it's the record's almost pathological obsession with the past that places it so squarely in the now. Any of its 10 tracks could sit comfortably on pretty much anyone's 2010s playlist: it broods like a lower-fi version of Charli XCX's Cold War-tinged tunes
column4: it beams through cloudy dark like John Maus' murky pop
column5: and it even boasts a song called ""Videotapes"" on which the synths sound like warping videotapes.

column1: And yet
column2: Blouse amounts to something more evocative and suggestive than trendy pastiche. There's one obvious reason: Some of these songs are just really that good. ""Into Black"" strikes the right balance of lush atmosphere and driving force
column3: while the mid-tempo ""Controller"" evokes an austere cool. It's album opener ""Firestarter""
column4: though
column5: that best expresses the young band's manifesto
column6: introducing them as a dream-pop group intent on razing the roof. ""Let's forget the ceiling
column7: vocalist Charlie Hilton beckons beguilingly over a wash of twinkling synths
column8: ""It's just made of stone.""

column1: Hilton's voice is breathy and commanding though not terribly distinct-- think Victoria Legrand channeling Trish Keenan minus a bit of je ne sais quoi. The propellant at the heart of Blouse is bassist Jacob Portrait
column2: who also plays with Portland psych-poppers Unknown Mortal Orchestra: His steady pulse gives the songs just enough oomph to keep them from getting lost in their own gloom. Unlike many of their contemporaries
column3: Blouse aren't out to deconstruct 1980s pop so much as dutifully replicate its essence. It's an easy thing to do wrong
column4: but Blouse find success by not overreaching their grasp. It's beside the point to fault a record like this for not being innovative; by the end of this stretch of songs
column5: there's something almost noble about their poker-faced commitment to time travel.

column1: There are a few moments when all the backward glancing becomes a bit heavy-handed
column2: but in their most inspired moments
column3: Blouse find the connection between the limits of outdated technology and the terrible bliss of desiring something impermanent. (In one song Hilton's idea of fun is watching a lone blackbird perched on a telephone wire
column4: ""Just long enough to notice when he flies away/ Because he always flies away."") Blouse <span style=""font-style: normal;"">aren't just nostalgic for the golden years of MTV pop
column5: but for an entire way of interacting with the world-- for the romance of a time when some things still felt out of reach. ""Videotapes"" finds Hilton longing to see the face of her perennially camera-shy lover. ""What it would be like to see you again
column6: she croons
column7:
wishing she had a videotape to remind her. That this sentiment feels like such an anachronism in a culture satiated by instant gratification only makes the track more heartbreaking. Blouse harkens back to love in the time before GPS to mine an enduring truth of pop music: getting lost has always sounded good.

"|15993.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15993-blouse-st/|7.4|Lindsay Zoladz

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17122/homepage_large.341053fe.jpg|Fatty Folders|10842.0|Roman Flügel|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dial']|2011-11-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:28.908460|"

Techno thrives on agendas. Whether innovation
column2: futurism
column3: rebellion
column4: or austerity
column5: such creative constraints help rein in the limitless possibilities of synthesizers and samplers. Roman Flügel is not exempt from this. A veteran of leftfield electronic production
column6: Flügel has released professional DJ mixes and collaborated on a jazz/techno hybrid; he works under different aliases (Soylent Green
column7: with collaborator Jörn Wuttke in Acid Jesus and Holy Garage) for varying styles. (Several years ago he made waves with his ""Dirty Dutch"" anthem
column8: ""Geht's Noch?"".) Many of his releases are 12"" singles
column9: utilitarian in purpose if not sound. So naturally one of the greatest aspects of Flügel's debut LP under his given name
column10: Fatty Folders
column11: is how untethered and adrift it is. This is not to say that Folders is experimental
column12: just that it's difficult to place. As best I can tell
column13: Flügel has no overriding purpose other than to produce gummy techno
column14: the kind that sticks to the roof of your mouth (and the kind you happily leave up there).

column1: Flügel has seen a decade-plus of singles
column2: collaborations
column3: and live sets receive near-unanimous praise. His 12""s
column4: while diverse
column5: have tended toward the mechanistic and throbbing
column6: though he's always been slightly out of step with his contemporaries in the German scene
column7: eschewing the severe austerity of Ostgut Ton and the lush minimalism of Traum. (Dial
column8: a Hamburg-based label whose releases often seem rote and plain before revealing intricacies
column9: is as good a home as any for Flügel.) Folders collects a handful of tracks from recent EPs and singles but offers mostly new material and
column10: as such
column11: stands as the most accessible and robust barometer of his work to date.

column1: Folders doesn't offer any kind of narrative-- not of Flügel's career
column2: not of a broader music scene
column3: not even intra-album. On display instead is the sheer variety of sounds Flügel conjures
column4: and how vibrant they seem in his arrangements. If Flügel has a trick-- though he is not really the type of producer who relies on them-- it's saving his tiniest
column5: most erudite melodies for his bangers and getting big-eyed and starry during his softer moments. ""The Improviser"" falls into the former category
column6: its rude
column7: burping bass barely ceding any ground to the dubby vibraphone sounds that sneak in. On the other end of the spectrum
column8: the panning
column9: glowing sunrays of ""Krautus"" would be at home on any Field record
column10: and ""Don't Break My Heart"" sounds like a pleasant Saturday morning in a clock repair shop.

column1: If there's one true monster track on Folders
column2: it's the previously released ""How to Spread Lies""
column3: a patient
column4: autumnal mid-tempo caress that relies equally on a descending piano melody and a subtle
column5: four-note bassline. That it's been out for over a year won't matter to anyone but the most vigilant Flügel fans. (Considering both ""Lies"" and ""Geht's Noch?""
column6: it would be somewhat ironic if the versatile
column7: understated Flügel were remembered mostly for a few standout tracks.) Fatty Folders is a summation of Flügel's career not in sound but in scope: It's multifaceted
column8: rich
column9: and cagey. He's worth the investment for casual techno fans
column10:
even if you only have time for the CliffsNotes.

"|15983.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15983-fatty-folders/|8.0|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17138/homepage_large.e3abe430.jpg|Time's Arrow EP|3478.0|Prurient|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hydra Head']|2011-11-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:29.490788|"

""Time's arrow"" is a lovely phrase to describe the seeming unidirectional progression of time
column2: the sense that it's been traveling perpetually forward from the Big Bang to whatever the ending point of the universe will happen to be. It's also the cheeky title of Dominick Fernow's new Prurient EP
column3: which itself rumbles inexorably and sometimes unbearably forward until it reaches a Big Crunch that sounds as apocalyptic as the one promised by some physicists. The five tracks here seem to be slowly shedding the trappings of music itself
column4: all the dark-pop armature Fernow has grafted onto Prurient's old shriek-the-pain-away sound over the last few years
column5: until all that remains is fearsome and formless noise.

column1: On Time's Arrow
column2: the comforts of familiar rhythm and melody are stripped back
column3: track by track
column4: to reveal the snarling
column5: primal sound mass from which they were beaten into shape. With a jittery programmed beat that recalls Big Black at their most despondent and yet more sour synth squiggles that prove John Carpenter is the biggest influence on the darker end of electronic music in the 21st-century
column6: the title track takes off from the creepy-but-clearly-defined hooks of Prurient's brilliant Bermuda Drain album from earlier in 2011. It's a possible contender for jam-of-the-year for all the ex-goths
column7: one-time industrial obsessives
column8: and collectors of soundtracks from obscure 1980s horror movies. But the rest of the EP sounds like it was made by a lunatic from one of those obscure 80s horror movies
column9: as if that deranged slasher had somehow escaped into real world and been asked to record a few tunes for a cassette label. And you can imagine the sort of emotions such a jolly fellow would want to express through sound.

column1: So the beat becomes a nearly arrhythmic clattering on ""Let's Make a Slave"". They keyboard melodies become cover-your-ears squeals of distortion
column2: as if someone were jabbing a knife into an amplifier. Following the brooding but almost catchy ""Time's Arrow""
column3: Fernow's most conventional song yet
column4: order itself seems to be breaking down across the rest of the EP
column5: a vibe brought home by the blasted
column6: end-of-the-world atmosphere and Fernow's increasingly desperate last-man-on-Earth vocal perfomances. By ""Maskless Face""
column7: his eerie monotone monologues have given away to frustrated howlings that express nothing but rage
column8: and even that connection to human pain is severed by the EP's end. ""Slavery in the Bahamas"" plays like a rapid-fire tape collage of the ugliest sounds the post-industrial world has to offer-- the spluttering of downed power lines
column9: the disembodied groans of information sluicing through a modem
column10: buildings and machinery being crushed to nothing-- as if the whole show was coming to a swift and brutal end.

column1: But Time's Arrow ends not in a deafening silence after the final track’s implosion. It's perhaps no accident that ""Slavery in the Bahamas"" ends with the faint sound of a lovely tune sneaking its way out of the squall. If you play the EP on a loop
column2: this snatch of pleasant human music-making seems to lead quite naturally back into the title cut. Of course if you then play the EP straight through again
column3: everything comes crashing down once more. With a kind of grim pleasure
column4: Time's Arrow suggests that all that effort
column5: writing songs and constructing coherent albums
column6: will always eventually give way to the chaos that rumbles dangerously under any attempt to impose control over noise
column7:
if you just let go.

"|16006.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16006-times-arrow/|7.0|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17058/homepage_large.76483ee4.jpg|Neverendless|27151.0|Cave|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2011-11-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:30.068028|"

CAVE's newest album is all movement. The first quick
column2: rhythm-dominated moments of opener ""WUJ"" propel Neverendless forward. The Chicago psych collective has likely been studying up on krautrock for a long time
column3: and it dives headlong into that territory with a motorik drive
column4: bass grooves
column5: and Neu!-reminiscent synths. It's a lead track that knows how to build-- beginning with a sparse canvas
column6: over the course of seven minutes it maintains a steady groove while adding and switching out layers. CAVE don't throw away that psych fuzz they do so well-- halfway in
column7: the volume ramps up and the guitars become markedly heavier. That sturdy rhythm remains for the entire seven minutes
column8: but they don't settle on one sound: They quiet down
column9: increase the volume
column10: add subtle licks
column11: string airy synths above their guttural guitars
column12: and all the while
column13: establish a few central hooks.

column1: The band's bread and butter is creating spacey psych jams; in that sense
column2: Neverendless doesn't break new ground. What is new is the feeling of focus and structure in their music. While previous albums Psychic Psummer and the Pure Moods EP felt looser
column3: more spontaneous
column4: jammy
column5: and sometimes more erratic or meandering
column6: Neverendless sounds premeditated and perfectly executed. They've never been sloppy or careless
column7: but never quite this tight. That structure likely comes from a semi-rigid percussion blueprint and a few well-defined melodies within each song. This is CAVE's first outing as a four-piece
column8: and they find an easy synchronicity with each other-- when they make a change in the groove
column9: everybody falls in line (except maybe the drummer
column10: who maintains the largely unswerving drive). Even spastic guitar solos fall neatly into the confines of the beat.

column1: It's also CAVE's most elegant record to date
column2: mostly because of ""On the Rise""
column3: six minutes of warm
column4: slow ebullience. Soft synths mimic wind instruments and pepper a steady beat. They introduce a handful of melodic
column5: joyous guitar hooks. In the only prominent vocal of the album
column6: they chant
column7: ""on the rise
column8: repeatedly
column9: in an almost ceremonial way. The song is a surprising move. On plenty of albums by jammy psych rockers
column10: one go-to vibe is menace-- it's easy to make a largely instrumental song with prominent bass sound big and intimidating. It's much harder to create something that sounds warm or inviting. They achieve that here without compromising their established feel-- a reverb-drenched
column11: rapid-firing guitar leads the chanting vocals into another calm groove. Neverendless also suggests that they do much better when given time to spread out. The four-minute ""Adam Roberts"" is the shortest and worst track of the bunch. The bassline is oppressively big and repetitive
column12: followed by an organ that evokes obnoxious circus music. There's no build
column13: no contrasting elements
column14: and
column15: in the end
column16: nothing to look forward to-- just four minutes of the same semi-obnoxious riff in the middle of the album.

column1: Regardless
column2: the record keeps moving. Sometimes it moves with warmth
column3: and sometimes with motorik rhythm. On the 14-minute ""This Is the Best"" it pushes forward with a droning synth that lies underneath the rest of the song's layers. Seven minutes in
column4: crunching guitars and buoying bass runs bury that synth. There are swirling
column5: moaning vocals for a moment
column6: and the guitar goes from a quick riff to an evenly spaced trudge. And through those gradual changes in the song's structure
column7: the percussion holds sway. The drums make one change that stretches out for the song's final minutes
column8: going to a hurried snare. It meets up with some equally hurried synths
column9: which lay out a cluttered feeling of anxiety. And it doesn't stop for a few minutes. With hit after hit of urgent-sounding synths and drums
column10: CAVE never let up or get faster
column11:
either. That's what they do best on Neverendless-- they just keep going.

"|15921.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15921-cave-neverendless/|7.9|Evan Minsker

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17136/homepage_large.4befca87.jpg|The Smile Sessions|310.0|The Beach Boys|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2011-11-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:30.728673|"

It's a rite of passage for students of pop music history: At some point
column2: you learn that the Beach Boys weren't just a fun 1960s surf band with a run of singles that later came to be used in commercials; at their best
column3: they were making capital-A Art. The record that convinces most is Pet Sounds
column4: that understated 1966 masterpiece that articulates a specific kind of teenage longing and loneliness like nothing before or since. Once you've absorbed that record
column5: you find yourself going back through songs like ""Don't Worry Baby""
column6: ""The Warmth of the Sun""
column7: and ""I Get Around""
column8: finding a deeper brilliance where you once heard only pop craftsmanship. As you make these discoveries
column9: you come to learn about the auteur at the center of it all
column10: Brian Wilson
column11: who shouldered the burden of being the creative force in one of the most successful and musically ambitious pop bands of the era. And then you find out about SMiLE.

column1: Conceived
column2: recorded
column3: and ultimately abandoned in 1966 and 1967
column4: SMiLE was to be something like Brian's Sgt. Pepper's
column5: his attempt to make the great art-pop album of the era. He followed his muse to the ends of the earth
column6: putting a grand piano in a massive living room sandbox
column7: outfitting another room with an Arabian tent
column8: making session musicians wear fireman's hats for the recording of a song about the elements
column9: freaking out when an actual fire broke out down the street from the studio around the time of recording of said track
column10: and
column11: no surprise
column12: taking enough drugs to amplify the whole scene and turn it into something terrifying. But the record was not to be. The music recorded for SMiLE was too far-out for the rest of the band (lead singer Mike Love hated the lyrics penned by Wilson's collaborator
column13: Van Dyke Parks
column14: an opinion he still holds) and Wilson had trouble finishing tracks. Eventually
column15: he shelved the record for good and the band issued the low-key
column16: weird
column17: and supremely stoned Smiley Smile. By setting the record aside
column18: Wilson became afraid to indulge his talent
column19: and his contributions to the Beach Boys would never again be central to the band.

column1: If you're wired a certain way
column2: once you learn the SMiLE story
column3: you long to hear the album that never was. It looms out there in imagination
column4: an album that lends itself to storytelling and legend
column5: like the aural equivalent of the Loch Ness Monster. And the songs from the sessions that eventually made it out on other records-- ""Surf's Up""
column6: ""Cabin Essence""
column7: ""Heroes and Villains""
column8: and more
column9: including material on the 1993 Beach Boys career-overview box Good Vibrations-- were so brilliant that the lack of proper release becomes almost painful. So you might start hunting down bootlegs
column10: poring over the fragments
column11: and finding competing edits and track sequences
column12: which only feeds your desire to know what the ""real"" SMiLE could have been.

column1: Only in 2003
column2: when long-time Beach Boys fanatic and tape trader Darian Sahanaja and his band the Wondermints collaborated with Brian on a live version of SMiLE and 2004's Brian Wilson Presents SMiLE album did the lost record assume a definitive shape. But as exciting as that record was at the time
column3: the lure of the originals never went away. So there was naturally a great deal of excitement when
column4: early this year
column5: we heard that the original tapes were being assembled for official release. This epic story finally has an ending
column6: and it's a very happy one. As archival projects go
column7: SMiLE is as surprising
column8: generous
column9: and successful as anything in recent memory. The version of the album
column10: based on the Wilson/Wondermints sequence
column11: feels remarkably complete and whole
column12: even though it was largely built from unfinished scraps.

column1: During this period
column2: Wilson and Parks were working on an enormous canvas. They were using words and music to tell a story of America. If the early-60s Beach Boys were about California
column3: that place where the continent ends and dreams are born
column4: SMiLE is about how those dreams were first conceived. Moving west from Plymouth Rock
column5: we view cornfields and farmland and the Chicago fire and jagged mountains
column6: the Grand Cooley Damn
column7: the California coast-- and we don't stop until we hit Hawaii. Cowboy songs
column8: cartoon Native American chants
column9: barroom rags
column10: jazzy interludes
column11: rock'n'roll
column12: sweeping classical touches
column13: street-corner doo-wop
column14: and town square barbershop quartet are swirled together into an ever-shifting technicolor dream.

column1: Befitting an album concerned with history
column2: SMiLE feels strangely adrift from time
column3: using the technology of the day and an avant-garde approach to pop song form to make the past look both familiar and strange. In 1966 and 1967
column4: old-timey music
column5: if you squinted at it just so
column6: could be imbued with a haze of psychedelia. And this is a deeply psychedelic album
column7: though disorientation mostly comes from its juxtapositions
column8: how the orchestral miniatures (or ""feels
column9: as Wilson called his modular melodic ideas) bump into each other and find their way from one song to the next
column10: the ""Heroes and Villains"" refrain here
column11: the ""Child Is Father of the Man"" refrain there.

column1: The 2004 sequence divided the album into three ""movements
column2: with songs connected thematically
column3: and this reissue wisely puts each on its own side of vinyl (if you want only the record proper
column4: the 2xLP
column5: with key outtakes added on the fourth side
column6: is absolutely the way to go). Each movement has at least one pop masterpiece. On the first
column7: there's ""Heroes and Villains"" and ""Cabin Essence""
column8: both exploring western themes in Parks' bent style. Here and especially on side two's ""Surf's Up""
column9: the level of Parks' writing is astounding. He had the sound-driven jumble of imagery of contemporaneous Dylan
column10: but his words were far tighter and more disciplined. He also understood the power of a good pun. Sounds are slurred together to take on new meaning through clusters that extended beyond the spaces between the words. So
column11: ""The music hall
column12: a costly bow
column13: in ""Surf's Up"" also sounds like
column14: ""The music holocaust
column15: and lines like
column16: ""canvas the town and brush the backdrop
column17: layer image atop image with breathtaking efficiency.

column1: Each side's arc also serves to push forward the record as a whole. Brian Wilson Presents SMiLE has made this sequencing seem canonical
column2: and there were enough raw materials in the vault available to piece together a worthy approximation. Once in a while
column3: you can hear a stitch or shift that would have no doubt been done over later
column4: but those moments are rare and ultimately only add to the record's charm. By the time the tense and throbbing neo-classical piece ""Fire (Mrs. O'Leary's Cow)"" comes along in the third movement and then leads into ""Love to Say Dada"" (mostly an instrumental
column5: it was meant to have lyrics; they were added for Brian Wilson Presents Smile
column6: the song titled ""In Blue Hawaii"") and then to the extended ""Good Vibrations""
column7: the strength of the album as a full piece is staggering.

column1: But part of the allure of SMiLE will always be the pieces
column2: and the deluxe box has a lot of them. There's almost a full disc of ""Heroes and Villains"" fragments and another entire CD with bits of ""Good Vibrations"". Given the nature of this release
column3: the extras are illuminating
column4: arguably more essential than most outtakes included with bonus albums. Having source materials hints at roads not taken
column5: and also offers insight into the difficulty of actually creating a record on this scale
column6: given how much we've heard about all the bouncing and layering that SMiLE entailed (the complexity of which is partly to blame for the project's being late and ultimately abandoned) and how many of the basic tracks were recorded live in the studio with a dozen or more musicians at once. There were only four and eight tracks to work with on the tape of the time
column7: so one of them would need multiple instruments just to have voices and overdubs added later. Not to mention that these modular sections were eventually going to be stitched together with tape and razorblades. Beyond the fragments
column8: there are brilliant single performances
column9: like the two demo versions of ""Surf's Up"". To my ears
column10: the song is a high-water mark of pop songwriting
column11: positively haunting with its melodic twists and turns. And Brian's vocal performances
column12: with wild leaps into the upper reaches of his falsetto
column13: give the track an almost unbearable poignancy. It's incredible to think that ""Surf's Up"" would remain in the vault for five years
column14: until it appeared in re-worked form on the 1971 album of the same name.

column1: On the sessions material
column2: you also get to hear Wilson running the show in the studio
column3: and apart from a few asides where he talks about hash and LSD
column4: he sounds excited
column5: patient
column6: and kind
column7: offering encouragement about mood
column8: timing
column9: and tempo. He surely wasn't an easy guy to work for
column10: but hearing his voice on these tapes
column11: it's remarkable how together he seems and how willing he is to work with these musicians to make something great. Most of all
column12: his studio patter provides a nice counterbalance to SMiLE's prevailing narrative
column13: of a crazed genius unraveling in the face of trying to create his masterpiece. We love crack-up stories. There's something in the Western psyche that loves to romanticize the alleged connection between madness and genius. And someone like Wilson-- fragile
column14: paranoid
column15: childlike
column16: and dreamy-- fits one template of the crazed genius to a T. Never mind that he was a student of music
column17: put in twice as many hours of extremely hard work as anyone else in the band
column18: and relied greatly on collaboration and outside inspiration. When thinking of SMiLE
column19: the guy in the fireman's hat thinking his music could burn down buildings is who we remember. But now we have the full picture. SMiLE was never finished
column20: and it still isn't
column21: but we can safely say this is as close as it'll ever come. What's here is brilliant
column25:
finally able to stand tall on its own.

"|16000.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/16000-the-smile-sessions/|10.0|Mark Richardson

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17108/homepage_large.fbe51890.jpg|Without You|27867.0|King Midas Sound|['Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hyperdub']|2011-11-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:31.211888|"

For all its eerie qualities as a work of music
column2: King Midas Sound's Waiting for You was just as striking in spatial terms-- bass throbs
column3: snare hits
column4: and voices
column5: usually broodingly quiet or tautly fretful
column6: reverberating in sonic dub chambers that practically dwarfed them a thousandfold. With all that room
column7: there's plenty of scope to rebuild things
column8: rearrange the elements
column9: and see how the angles of all those deep echoes change. Dabrye's 2008 chrome-and-neon g-funk remix of ""One Ting"" was one of the earliest reinterpretations of Kevin Martin and Roger Robinson's collaborative efforts
column10: and possibly the best to date. But it also shared space on the ""Cool Out"" b-side with Flying Lotus' twitchy
column11: boiling-water mutation of ""Lost""-- a remix just as eager to coax out the ghostly elements of Robinson's voice
column12: but approaching it more like a counterpoint than a complement.

column1: Both cuts appear on Without You
column2: a remix album that largely pulls off the rare feat of adding to its source material's mystique without necessarily displacing it. It's not really a track-by-track revisit
column3: and there's a deep focus on some songs in particular-- like the Kiki Hitomi feature ""Goodbye Girl""
column4: which gets three different reinterpretations from three different remixers. (And that's on the digital/CD version; the 2xLP has five.) But while the versions spring from the same source material
column5: and they all preserve the source track's heartbroken bitterness
column6: it's all to different ends. Take note of Jamie Vex'd's rework under his Kuedo alias
column7: which pares back and pitches up Robinson's voice to put more attention on Hitomi's sharp-edged purr
column8: and ramps up the drums while turning the backing track into a borderline-gothic drone. Put it next to the Robert Aiki Aubrey Lowe rework
column9: and that only makes the latter track's ambient bent sound that much more austere and suspenseful
column10: like the noise of an abandoned space station. And there's still room for Echospace's all-analog reassemblage
column11: which streamlines near-subliminal rumbles of the vocal track into an ultra-dense
column12: bass-heavy yet still billowy minimal house groove.

column1: It's easy to lose track of things with this multiple-version lineup. Gang Gang Dance and Mala take turns shifting the foreboding environmental-crisis warnings of ""Earth a Kill Ya"" into opposite avenues
column2: the former constructing a hiccupy bionic junkshop skank rhythm around it while the latter drops propulsive
column3: bongo-driven vintage dubstep breaks into the original track's once-austere surroundings. And the other take on ""Lost"" besides FlyLo's belongs to Nite Jewel
column4: and her sun-bleached electro-pop is enriched enough by Robinson's voice to defy any chillwitch dreamhouse associations you could throw at it. And yet all these reworks and revisions stay in the general vicinity of the original album's tone of massive yet starkly open spaces
column5: adding a few new facets but always staying close to the fine line Waiting for You treaded between bleak and euphoric.

column1: The other trick is to scatter in some revoices along with the remixes
column2: with different singers and vocal tracks versioning dubs of the original Martin productions. ""Spin Me Around"" is the most revelatory
column3: as Cooly G uses the 100-story-high swoon of ""Meltdown"" to lay down what is more or less a straight-up R&B vocal-- and a knockout at that
column4: love-stoned and out of her own mind with ecstasy. And D-bridge's title-track revoice of ""Without You"" matches Robinson's rich yet vulnerable precedent with a resonantly fragile deep house-indebted vocal lead of his own. Others feel a bit more dispensable: there's some attention-getting restrained intensity in Hitomi's voice in her takeover of ""Cool Out"" on ""Tears""
column5: but it's more of a pleasant variation on the original's lover's-rock bliss than a bonafide transformation. And revoices featuring Ford & Lopatin's Joel Ford (""Say Something"") and Scritti Politti's Green Gartside (""Come and Behold"") sound a bit too bright and upbeat
column6:
getting a bit at-odds with the original deep-dub atmosphere to click as strongly as the others. No matter-- there's still plenty of room for them.

"|15975.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15975-king-midas-sound-without-you/|7.7|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/17132/homepage_large.f4ea5f91.jpg|Meçhul: Singles & Rarities|30037.0|Erkin Koray|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sublime Frequencies']|2011-11-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:31.796187|"

It's pretty common for English-speaking critics to refer to Erkin Koray as the ""Turkish Jimi Hendrix."" Obviously
column2: there are reasons this has caught on as the party line
column3: but I want to be careful about picking apart the reasons the comparison is accurate
column4: as well as the ways it's not. Direct comparisons between their music aren't much use. Hendrix was coming from a background in blues and R&B; Koray was a co-founder of Turkey's first (as far as we know) rock band in 1957
column5: but from his home in Istanbul he didn't have to look too far to the east to find a host of interesting sounds to combine with rock'n'roll. I think the comparison
column6: more than anything
column7: ultimately has more to do with Koray's impact on the use of the electric guitar in Turkish popular music than it does with any similarity in their music.

column1: And in that sense
column2: the comparison holds some water. Koray's use of the guitar had a profound effect on the way the instrument's role was perceived by his fellow musicians. His use of effects and his deft playing were pioneering
column3: and he was one of the first handful of musicians to actively push for the integration of Turkish folk sounds with rock and psychedelia
column4: even going so far as to electrify the bağlama
column5: a traditional Turkish stringed instrument. From 1965 to 1968
column6: the national Turkish newspaper Hürriyet organized annual contests called Altin Mikrofon (Golden Microphone) with a set of simple rules that did much to create a distinctively Turkish style of rock: Contest entrants had to either compose new songs in Turkish or cover a traditional song
column7: but the arrangements had to be in a rock style
column8: played on Western electric instruments.

column1: It's a strange
column2: top-down way of creating a scene
column3: but it worked
column4: and Koray was among the many musicians whose music evolved through entering the contest. Sublime Frequencies' Meçhul: Singles & Rarities compilation picks up a couple of years after his last Altin Mikrofon entry
column5: after he'd really honed his style and come into his own as a composer and arranger. The title is a giveaway that there's little in the way of an organizing principle behind the set-- the compilers essentially chose a smattering of Koray songs from the 1970s that they really liked
column6: with no eye toward telling a coherent story about his career. That said
column7: they did pick very well
column8: and nearly every track is a killer.

column1: For a good glimpse of Koray's singular ethno-rock style
column2: it's hard to beat 1970's ""Gün Doğmuyor"" (""No More Daybreak""). Koray's guitar part
column3: accented by audibly snapping spring reverb is prettily melodic
column4: but his softly sung vocal melody has hints of modal Turkish folk-- Koray clearly was feeling the influence of early progressive rock
column5: too
column6: and you can hear it in the dramatic double stops at the beginning of the refrain. The ethnic element grew stronger with time. On 1977's ""Olmayınca Olmuyor""
column7: Koray's electrified <span>bağlama has supplanted the guitar
column8: and the music has a thrilling progressive folk thrust to it that still sounds strangely modern.

column1: Some of it is a little more directly relatable to American and British rock. ""Krallar"" sounds a little like the Amboy Dukes' ""Journey to the Center of the Mind""
column2: for example
column3: but for each of those
column4: there are two ""Goca Dünya""'s
column5: where Koray plays his guitar in a style directly influenced by traditional saz and <span>bağlama players. In part thanks to the lasting effects of the Altin Mikrofon contest
column6: exploring Turkish rock constantly reveals startling juxtapositions and unique sounds
column7: and Koray's music is rich with such moments. If you're looking for an entry point into the world of Anatolian rock
column8: he's an excellent place to start
column9: and this compilation
column10: so well-stocked with great songs and good playing
column11: is good introduction
column12:
even if it doesn't approach his career systematically.

"|15994.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15994-mechul-singles-rarities/|8.1|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17133/homepage_large.75f534a2.jpg|The Clearing|28801.0|Locrian|['Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fan Death']|2011-11-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:32.296388|"

Plenty of bands play music that sounds dark
column2: but few can make every note bleed black and breathe smoke. Count Locrian as part of that select circle. Something about the Chicago trio's sound is inherently ominous-- it's hard to imagine them playing ""Chopsticks"" without turning it into an earth-threatening thunderstorm. That effect is obvious in their noisier
column3: more chaotic moments
column4: where metallic noise and intense howls coalesce into scary crescendos. But it's just as strong in their quieter
column5: more ambient stretches
column6: when they build tension not from heightened climax but from sustained nuance.

column1: The Clearing could be Locrian's most nuanced record so far. Throughout
column2: they use slow
column3: far-off sounds rather in-your-face noise to thicken the atmosphere. A frozen piano line
column4: distant drum roll
column5: or shadowy bass loop is often all the group needs to forge a palpable mood. More than half of the side-long
column6: album-closing title track is made of such minimal material. Yet somehow the band mines it for 17 minutes of sonic pressure. When the song eventually swells into a gnarled thatch of static and low end
column7: Locrian sound less like a group gaining momentum than a mountain rising up through the ocean after years of rumbling below the surface.

column1: There are more covert moments of tension on The Clearing
column2: and they're pretty powerful
column3: too. Most pulverizing is ""Augury in an Evaporating Tower""
column4: whose mix of tones showcases the band's agility. At points
column5: the cascading drums and elongated screams conjure Prurient screamer Dominick Fernow's black metal band Ash Pool. But the band deftly shifts to oscillating drone and sky-seeking guitar that sound like Earth's Dylan Carlson battling a synth monster. ""Chalk Point""
column6: on the other hand
column7: takes a more traditional path to its climax
column8: building piano chords into a kind of post-rock metal dirge.

column1: Still
column2: what impresses most about The Clearing is not specific turns or isolated moments
column3: but the overwhelming mood it creates. That's what makes the album title apt-- Locrian's dark atmospheres aren't empty spaces
column4: but stark traces of something that was there not long before. In other words
column5: they're as good at creating negative spaces as they are at filling them in. Even when they get so subdued that they approach silence
column6:
you can hear ghosts echoing in their void.

"|15997.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15997-the-clearing/|7.4|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17125/homepage_large.defbad46.jpg|Some Motherfuckers Gonna Be Walking 'Round With a Size 9 Diehard up Their Ass...|28857.0|Weird Wives|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['West Palm Beotch']|2011-11-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:32.867636|"

A couple of dudes from Surfer Blood have an abrasive
column2: noise-rock side project? Of course a couple of dudes from Surfer Blood have an abrasive
column3: noise-rock side project: while Astro Coast derived much of its strength from mastering a very narrow set of alt/indie touchstones-- Pavement
column4: Weezer
column5: Built to Spill
column6: all ca. 1994-- you had to figure such intense focus was a conscious choice to hide their freak flags rather than hard evidence that they didn't have any to begin with. The funny thing about Weird Wives-- which includes SB guitarist Thomas Fekete
column7: bassist Brian Black
column8: and former tour percussionist Marcos Marchesani-- is that they don't really have to travel all that far to get to the grimier confines of <i>Some Motherfuckers Gonna Be Walking 'Round With a Size 9 Diehard up Their Ass
column9: Cause Apparently They Ain't Never Seen a Short AC Man Get Bad Ass on Methadone. Just turn the radio dial a little to the left from your mainstream alt-rock station or wait out the next the commercial break of ""120 Minutes"" for the likes of the Jesus Lizard or Butthole Surfers to make their brief flirtations with mainstream attention. Surely
column10: Weird Wives' hearts are in the right place here
column11: but Some Motherfuckers turns out to be the kind of record where you can see where its creators' interests lie and
column12: unfortunately
column13: where their expertise does as well.

column1: At the very least
column2: this isn't some sort of bid to totally negate Surfer Blood's populist charm for acceptance from the academics and arm-crossers. Everything from the album title to Weird Wives' website to the cover art and the names of most of the songs themselves (""Fresca""
column3: ""Predator 4"")
column4: and… well
column5: you'd be forgiven for thinking this was a chillwave record. At some points
column6: it sorta is: Instrumentals ""Alone Times"" and ""Peak Commute"" feature the kind of drippy
column7: amniotic keyboard textures signifying a greyscale rendering of Black Moth Super Rainbow. And for the most part
column8: Weird Wives maintain a loose grind
column9: most of Some Motherfuckers cycling through a four-bar pivot where the band locked in and decided to turn it into a four-minute jam.

column1: But while there's plenty of feedback splatter
column2: drone
column3: and flatted-fifth skronk
column4: what Weird Wives lack above all else is a sense of true aggression or purpose. Or at least some impression of danger: this is the sort of thing that works best when something feels like it's at stake
column5: whether it's a show that's verging on police intervention or the sonic excavation of an ugly
column6: malignant tumor that simply couldn't stay inside of its host. Hell
column7: maybe this slays live
column8: and their earlier singles did show some fangs
column9: but Weird Wives' brute force runs up against reverb that deadens Some Motherfuckers like so much pink
column10: puffy insulation. The occasional hook does exist-- the fretboard-corroding riff of ""Plastic Masks""
column11: the headbanger repetition driving ""Michaels""
column12: and heck
column13: the grotty
column14: downstroking post-punk of ""Predator 4"" recalls an ornery Interpol jacked on truckstop coffee or speed. But they're only hooky within the context of Some Motherfuckers.

column1: Of course
column2: melody isn't paramount in this realm
column3: and you could troubleshoot in the form of a compelling frontman
column4: but Nick Klein (a Weird Wife not from Surfer Blood) sounds uncertain that he's even up for the job. His megaphone yawps blend in just fine with the surrounding sheet-metal timbres
column5: and the occasional lyric you can make out-- ""building new homes"" on ""Gila""
column6: ""It's gonna be one of those nights again"" on ""Predator 4""-- don't really accumulate much tension out of their repetition and instead just sit as vaguely ominous placeholders. But how much of Some Motherfuckers itself is supposed to be a vaguely ominous placeholder instead of a definitive statement from a popular band's side project? That's tougher to parse-- it's easy to understand why Weird Wives felt the desire to make a record like Some Motherfuckers
column7:
less so to understand why they felt the need to share it.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/17127/homepage_large.001133e9.jpg|Lulu|3550.0|Lou Reed|['Rock'
column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2011-11-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:33.375461|"

When Metallica announced last June that they had recorded a new album with Lou Reed
column3: fans of both artists responded with confusion
column4: if not outright despair. But  while this partnership may seem random
column5: the two actually have a lot in common. Both abuse electric guitars; both like to wear black and be photographed by Anton Corbijn; both have indulged in lifestyles that threatened to become death-styles; both have a habit of alienating their fans by taking ill-advised stylistic detours and
column6: by extension
column7: both are considered by many to be class-A assholes. But while these surface similarities may provide the two parties with small-talk/commiseration fodder when
column8: say
column9: hanging backstage before murdering ""Sweet Jane"" at a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony
column10: they're pretty miserable grounds for a full-on collaboration
column11: especially one that spans two discs and close to 90 minutes. And yet
column12: showing their usual proud disregard for their fans and music in general
column13: Lou Reed and Metallica have gone and made Lulu anyway.

column1: It'd be one thing if Lulu were being slipped into the marketplace as a low-profile curiosity
column2: akin to a 90s-era spoken word album with some alt-rocker screeching away in the background. Instead
column3: it's being trumpeted by its makers as a historic event. In a now-infamous interview
column4: James Hetfield and Lars Ulrich recall  bursting into tears of pride during the recording sessions
column5: while in another Reed grinningly insists that Metallica has ""pushed me to the best I've ever been."" It was one of many unintentional jokes in an online promo campaign that effectively ruined Lulu's chances of being taken seriously before it was even heard.

column1: Lulu was first previewed with an especially repellent 30-second tract of ""The View"" that confirmed everyone's worst suspicions of the project-- namely
column2: that Reed's crotchety
column3: atonal poem-rants would be wholly incompatible with Metallica's fidgety riffage. The clip's most prominent lyric (""Throw it away/ For worship someone who actively despises you!"") seemed to mock both artists' most forgiving fans for even clicking on the link. By the time ""The View"" was released in <a href=""http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8LWtb621DRg"" rel=""nofollow"" target=""_blank"">its full
column4: five-minute ghastliness-- with Hetfield variously professing himself to be a table
column5: a 10-story building and
column6: possibly
column7: the premier member of Philly hip-hop band the Roots-- the Internet had all the evidence it needed to preemptively crown Lulu the Worst Album of All Time.

column1: But even in that regard
column2: Lulu disappoints. For all the hilarity that ought to ensue here
column3: Lulu is a frustratingly noble failure. Audacious to the extreme
column4: but exhaustingly tedious as a result
column5: its few interesting ideas are stretched out beyond the point of utility and pounded into submission-- the average song length clocks in at eight excruciating minutes. Still
column6: it's kind of fascinating to hear two veteran entities trying like hell to excavate common ground that simply does not exist.

column1: Lulu's source material-- a series of transgressive plays by Munich playwright Frank Wedekind about a stripper who becomes a social-climber only to wind up a prostitute-- allows Reed to set a familiar Berlin scene with ""Brandenburg Gate""
column2: a would-be anthem that
column3: with a less torturous delivery
column4: could almost pass for something from Reed's mid-1970s songbook. Instead
column5: we get Hetfield belting out its ""small town girl"" chorus like he's trying to summon the next featured attraction at a strip club.

column1: Reed's influence also feels responsible for the ominous
column2: omnipresent Velvets-esque string textures and a couple of curiously avant guitar solos from Kirk Hammett (see: ""Dragon""). Metallica
column3: meanwhile
column4: inspired Reed to come up with at least one perfectly metal lyric (""I cry icicles in my stein"")
column5: while getting him to update the S&M suggestiveness of ""Venus in Furs"" to the bloodlusty standards of the modern-day headbanger. However
column6: a great deal of Lulu's songs find Reed graphically describing violent
column7: depraved sexual trysts from the female protagonist's perspective
column8: and with lines like ""I will swallow your sharpest cutter like a colored's man dick"" in abundance
column9: some dyed-in-the-denim Metallica fans could be squirming like they did when Kirk started wearing eyeliner.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: these small surprises can't save Lulu from the much larger issue that lies directly at its core: For most of the record
column3: Lou Reed and Metallica barely sound like they're on the same planet
column4: let alone in the same room; the album works neither as powerful rock music nor as an impressionistic soundtrack to a spoken narrative. Reed's monotone remains unresponsive to what's happening around him whether the occasion calls for full-torque thrash (""Mistress Dread"") or dreary acoustic mood pieces (""Little Dog"")
column5: while Lars Ulrich's flailing fills during the breakdowns on ""Pumping Blood"" and ""Frustration"" are essentially drummerese for ""what the fuck do I do with this?"" But for all of Reed's meandering
column6: a-melodic verbosity
column7: it's actually Hetfield who sounds the most out of place here; beyond his self-parodic turn on ""The View""
column8: he contributes intrusive back-ups to the bar-band slog ""Iced Honey"" and the maddeningly repetitious ""Cheat on Me"" like someone in the back row of a class photo trying to mug his way into the frame.

column1: Remarkably
column2: there is actually a light at the end of this dark
column3: despairing tunnel-- and
column4: not coincidentally
column5: it's the song least connected to the Lulu concept. Clocking in at an absurd 19 minutes
column6: ""Junior Dad"" is-- like almost everything else here-- too long by half
column7: with its last eight minutes taken up by an extended string drone. But
column8: despite its laughable title
column9: ""Junior Dad"" possesses everything the rest of Lulu doesn't: a graceful
column10: affecting melody
column11: a logical arrangement
column12: a pretty guitar line
column13: a sympathetic narrator and
column14: most importantly
column15: a true synthesis of each principal's strengths
column16: outfitting a Reed streetwise hymn with Metallica's stadium-sized crunch; it's like ""Street Hassle"" refashioned as a Black Album power ballad. ""Junior Dad"" is a song that seemingly does the impossible: it momentarily redeems the idea of a Lou Reed/Metallica collaboration as a plausible
column17:
potentially fruitful concept. But its late appearance also serves as a potent reminder of just how terribly that concept is executed on everything that precedes it.

Gold Panda's 2010 debut
column2: Lucky Shiner
column3: asked you to accept a number of seeming contradictions
column4: echoing some of the great contradictory artists of electronic music as it went along. Like the work of Boards of Canada
column5: its emotion-loaded melodies were both whimsical and mournful. Like the collage-funk productions of Matthew Herbert
column6: it built tracks from a myriad of tiny samples
column7: but warped them so that even field recordings and snippets of analog instruments felt denatured
column8: computerized
column9: alien. The production had the crammed-waveform fullness of the Field's fluffy maximalist trance epics
column10: but the way GP put his tracks together from all those little bits somehow also recalled the fragile
column11: handmade miniatures of not-quite-dubsteppers Mount Kimbie.

column1: Whether or not GP would claim any or all of those acts as influences or peers
column2: it was clear he was enjoying the same sort of freedom as they did
column3: the freedom of belonging to no one particular electronic music niche. He drew inspiration from sounds as far-flung as the more obvious physicality of London's ever-evolving beats-and-bass subculture
column4: the twitching and gurgling micro-syncopations of experimental techno
column5: and the shameless and affecting melodicism of IDM. More crucially
column6: he also found ways to layer them into something his own. On GP's new DJ-Kicks entry
column7: he attempts to fuse these strands of modern dance
column8: just as he did on Lucky Shiner
column9: except this time using mostly other people's records as raw material. The result is another seeming contradiction
column10: a DJ mix that's both a pulsing paean to up-to-the-minute club rhythms and a total headphone-dependent feast of electronic sound at its most miniaturized and luscious.

column1: He does this quite simply
column2: pairing left-field bangers with tracks that tend more toward the art-techno end of the spectrum
column3: accentuating the subtleties of the former and teasing out the grooves in the latter. And in the mix's most effective moments
column4: he mingles them until they create new hybrids
column5: not quite dancefloor ready and always with so much to listen to that you could never call them ambient. GP draws out the strange staggering gait of Bok Bok's ""Charisma Theme""
column6: what might have seemed like a slab of party-ready bashing and clonking in a mix of similar post-dubstep party tunes
column7: by linking it with the more steely
column8: abstract electro of Decay's ""Charisma's Theme"". He hears a bit of gnarled drums and synthesizer murk
column9: clipped from a Brainiac record of all things
column10: as the perfect perverse segue into Untold and LV's spartan dubstep.  He ranges as far as he ever has on his own records
column11: from Berlin minimal to American indie rock
column12: divining brilliant connections between artists who seem to come from opposing aesthetic universes.

column1: Amazingly
column2: this rarely makes for choppy transitions. Given the wildly disparate materials used to construct it
column3: the bubbling
column4: slurping
column5: rustling flow of this DJ-Kicks is a marvel
column6: the kind of seamless weaving together of tiny sounds into a new tapestry that's been sadly unfashionable since the days of old-school micro-house mixes. And like vintage micro-house
column7: many of the tracks take minimalism not as an opportunity for acetic reduction but a chance to revel in all the ear candy sound-as-sound qualities of electronic music
column8: without totally skimping on the funk. Tune your ears down to its reductionist frequency
column9: and the vinyl-esque crackle and barely audible hiss of Jan Jelinek's ""If's
column10: And's
column11: and But's"" feels as lush and wombing as any massive
column12: bass-booming deep house jam operating on a similarly warm tip. Like the records that make it up
column13: Gold Panda's DJ-Kicks is too interested in these (often literally) small pleasures and subtle entwinings to say it demands your attention. But in his own dogged
column14: idiosyncratic way
column15: he's keeping a neglected strain of dance music alive here
column16: and while the joys are subtle
column17: the more attention you give the mix
column18:
the deeper they feel.

Hearing Pandr Eyez for the first time recently on Air France's FACT mix was slightly disarming. That's not to say that this is weird music. It's actually pretty accessible pop music
column2: but something about their song ""Little Bit"" is hard to place. The pitch-perfect execution feels like something you should already know-- a producer retooling a forgotten acapella
column3: maybe
column4: or perhaps a radio cut from a new R&B singer. As it happens neither is exactly true: Pandr Eyez is the work of a London-based duo made up of producer Tom Lloyd and singer Ferren Gipson.

column1: The story is that they met while living in a shared university dormitory then started exchanging musical ideas. Something about that enthusiasm and shared love of certain styles carries over into Pandr Eyez
column2: giving the project an infectious
column3: off-the-cuff energy. That
column4: combined with the absence of samples or acapellas
column5: makes Eyes on You feel both homespun and playful in execution
column6: though perhaps a couple of steps away from ""the real thing."" That lingering feeling makes this seem like more of an outside-looking-in take on R&B
column7: and it's tempting to compare it to the kind of thing jj went in for on their mixtape Kills
column8: but this isn't anywhere near as drugged or sad-eyed.

column1: ""Little Bit"" stands out from the rest of their material
column2: with woozy synths and a shuffling beat pushing rhythms in all the right spots. Above that backdrop Gipson buries her verses in rap standards like ""Didn't have too much when we started this game/ Now we're doing alright
column3: check my diamonds and rings."" But lines like those-- and others about brand new kicks
column4: seeing her face on TV
column5: and referencing 16 bars-- sound different coming from what is essentially a bedroom duo rather than guys like 8Ball and MJG. There's an element of dress-up to Gipson's lyrics
column6: and a gooey soft center that isn't quite concealed by the fronting. (It's not a million miles away from the effect of Robyn on ""Konichiwa Bitches"".)

column1: A lot of the success of these tracks is centered on feel-good vibes though and the impressive production-- handled by the other half of the duo
column2: Tom Lloyd-- goes a long way toward making the record work so well. His beats are characterized by a dreamy feel thanks to the big
column3: romantic synths on all of these tracks
column4: but there's range to his production too. ""Shinin'""
column5: for example cuts a contrast to the rest of the EP's softer palette gliding
column6: instead
column7: on a minimal
column8: deep rumbling bass pattern and cheap sounding samples. It's a slightly harsh exterior
column9: one that Gipson matches toe-to-toe with bravado. The track really takes off towards the end
column10: though
column11: as Lloyd grabs the spotlight
column12: throwing all those cheap samples in the air and letting them drop around each other.

column1: For all their individual nuance and personality
column2: it's clear that the duo have hit a collaborative sweet-spot: Lloyd and Gipson play to each other's strengths and egg each other on at every turn. While there is plenty of recontextualizing rap and R&B going around
column3:
the fun of this record is that Pandr Eyez seem to understand that sometimes pop music is just about letting your hair down and singing along in whatever language you can.
