0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17116/homepage_large.dbb6de53.jpg|Scion A/V Presents: The King Khan Experience|30024.0|The King Khan Experience|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Scion A/V']|2011-11-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:35.936864|"

Last year
column2: Lou Reed and Laurie Anderson asked the King Khan & BBQ Show to join their curated Vivid Live festival in Sydney alongside Tuvan throat singers
column3: Reed's Metal Machine Trio
column4: and the Blind Boys of Alabama. According to Khan
column5: Reed and Anderson wanted the duo to ""put back the danger into the devil's music."" His antics at the event
column6: which ultimately led to his breakup with Mark Sultan
column7: proved that assessment accurate. His live shows are unpredictable and wild. His music with BBQ
column8: Tandoori Knights
column9: and the Shrines is driven by an energetic
column10: fiery soul that jumps straight out of the 1950s and 1960s-- a time when several of pop music's central characters were handsome
column11: wild-eyed men screaming and pushing that ""devil’s music"" to America's children. King Khan is the same sort of dangerous and then some: He's usually shirtless (in the very least) and he unleashes Wilson Pickett shrieks
column12: exudes grease and sex
column13: and has a knack for being gratuitously crass.

column1: That's why this Scion EP by ""the King Khan Experience"" is so disappointing. The palpable feeling of danger from Khan's work never comes into play. Where his material with the Shrines felt like a sharp rock and soul review
column2: the Experience comparatively sags. The Shrines' What Is?! was backed by a tight horn section and some on-point melody-accenting guitars. Meanwhile
column3: the Experience features organ and poorly utilized horns. Many of the reference points seem to come less from the 60s and more from the indulgent
column4: jammy 70s-- the wandering organ and the loose blues guitar solo of ""Knock Me Off My Feet"" feel sloppy in comparision to past material. What's worse
column5: Khan sounds tired. His vocals frequently drag
column6: and even his ""OWW""'s come off less wild than usual.

column1: A few songs hint at the electrifying promise he made with the Shrines
column2: but they ultimately slip up somewhere. The opening guitar and percussion drive of ""Come Levitate With Me"" sound like they're about to build into a party song
column3: but then the song just slows down with a Herbie Mann-ish flute solo and Khan's monotonous
column4: dragging vocals. ""I Got Love"" is the song that begs for horns and speed
column5: but neither happen. The only track that truly hits is his tribute to Jay Reatard: ""Hammer Ich Vermisse Dich""
column6: a German cover of Reatard's ""Hammer I Miss You"". It’s unclear why the song is in German
column7: but through the language barrier
column8: you can hear Khan's passionate delivery. He's backed on the chorus by what sounds like German schoolgirls
column9: and there's glitchy percussion driving the whole thing. It’s a touching tribute to his friend
column10: if only from the titular message: ""I miss you.""

column1: Maybe the EP was a place to put out some odds and ends that don't have a clear place with any of his other bands-- it really does sound like a hodgepodge. We get ""Are You Serious?""
column2: a lo-fi goof on Jimi Hendrix's ""The Wind Cries Mary"" and Are You Experienced. (The song might explain the new band name.) He also offers ""Keep It Simple Stupid""
column3: a bit of clichéd Eastern psych with a too-long whine. There is ""Bob Log Stomp""
column4: a track that would fit tidily with BBQ or the Shrines
column5: but it's basically a ""somebody pooped in my scotch"" joke
column6: and it's not even as funny as ""Tastebuds"".

column1: Throughout
column2: we get a  shadow of Khan as ""wild man"" as joker as rocker. His best work comes from a place that's  unhinged. This material's too toned-down and wandering. In ""I Got Love""
column3:
he sings: ""It's a question of soul/ Some people got it and some people don't."" This turns out to be a supremely a misplaced lyric on an EP where the man's delivery is so flat.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17109/homepage_large.54f0130a.jpg|Nightlife EP|28373.0|Phantogram|['Rock'
column3: the New York-based electronic pop duo better known as Phantogram
column4: make music refreshingly disinterested in pulling punches. With Eyelid Movies
column5: their debut full-length from last year
column6: the rhythm-heavy foundations and a twilight-lit mix of melody felt streamlined
column7: yet still demonstrated vision and character. Taking cues from trip-hop and dream pop (Portishead seem to be an important reference point)
column8: they never seemed shy about being upfront with their influences. Despite cryptically nicknaming their sound ""street beat
column9: the tag made some sense-- the hard-edged urgency of said beats undercutting such lush romanticism felt perfectly suited for those long
column10: late staggers home. So it's with the appropriately titled Nightlife EP that we find the twosome refining and tweaking some of the ideas put forth on its debut without entirely resting on its laurels
column11: and offering a few of the band's best songs to date.

column1: In a press release
column2: Carter explained that Nightlife ""couldn't have been written anywhere other than in clubs and hotel rooms during this experience we've been having for the last year or two
column3: describing the time Phantogram has spent promoting Eyelid Movies. The nocturnal states that often accompany life on the road have proved beneficial in the case of Nightlife
column4: convincing the duo to push their music outside of their collective headspace and into a more social setting. Bands trying to provide an honest snapshot of a night out on the town often fall short by focusing solely on the highs of the party (those are included here too
column5: of course)
column6: but Phantogram seem to find just as much clarity in the comedown (""It's a new day
column7: and I got new ways of turning into stone
column8: goes the chorus on ""Turning Into Stone""). As much as you can move to Nightlife
column9: moments of austerity and romance are still guiding lights here-- when measured correctly
column10: Barthel and Carter are often able to craft appealing
column11: ambidextrous tracks that feel suited for dancefloors as well as the backs of cabs.

column1: Part of this notably animated reupholstering likely has something to do with that fact that Phantogram have been performing live as a trio
column2: with Tim Oakley handling drum duties. And while Carter is in charge of all things drum-oriented on Nightlife
column3: the temporary change-up clearly made its mark
column4: as Phantogram sounds more like a bonafide rock band and less like the flimsy pop act they could've dissolved into. Take single ""Don't Move""
column5: a dance track that feels perfectly proportioned for starry eyes in close quarters. But look closer
column6: and you'll find a proper heir to <a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/11887-the-top-the-head-on-the-door-kiss-me-kiss-me-kiss-me-blue-sunshine/"" target=""_blank""><i>Kiss Me
column7: Kiss Me
column8: Kiss Me-styled bombast
column9: complete with horn clippings
column10: Middle Eastern vocal samples
column11: and marching band drum rolls. And while the Mazzy Star-esque coda that reduces the appealing bass knocks on ""Turning Into Stone"" into something plush and more intimate might not be necessary
column12: it all suggests that this is a more realized pop voice willing to expand
column13: experiment with and reinvigorate their sound.

column1: Not everything here is as compelling
column2: but the true takeaways (the first three cuts
column3: including the outsized
column4: life-affirming ""16 Years"") are well worth the misguided ambition and watered down moments that inhabit the EP's second half. Closer ""A Dark Tunnel"" means to shade the buzzing urgency of Return to Cookie Mountain-era TV on the Radio but misses the mark; squint hard enough and you'll see that ""Nightlife"" probably isn't going to succeed in any context outside of a CW show. Unfortunately
column5: this means that
column6: at only six songs
column7: Nightlife's batting average takes a considerable dip. But what remains is good enough to encourage you to root for Phantogram
column8:
and to really hold onto those few great tracks that you'll be taking home with you at the end of the night.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/17118/homepage_large.77ba20be.jpg|Long Live the King EP|1043.0|The Decemberists|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Capitol']|2011-10-31 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:36.972210|"

Colin Meloy can read. This fact should surprise no one who has heard the Decemberists
column2: or who has only so much as read one of their press clippings
column3: nearly all of which seem bound
column4: as if by secret contract
column5: to make mention of the music as ""literate."" It's shorthand
column6: of course
column7: for Meloy's tendency towards narrative and metaphor and occasionally inscrutable vocabulary-- a way for writers to telegraph his interest in words without indulging in much of the same.

column1: The matter of the L-word has been the primary talking point about the band since Portland's HUSH records released their first EP nearly a decade ago
column2: joined in 2006 by their signing to Capitol
column3: and earlier this year by the somewhat surprising debut of their sixth album at number one on the Billboard charts. Somewhere in there
column4: too
column5: is nearly always talk of Meloy's glasses (well
column6: he wears them) and a mention of the band's fans
column7: usually classified as gawking drama-club nerds (which are indeed there
column8: though for a while now the crowds at their live shows have been comprised less of folks in ""three-button vests"" and more in just plain t-shirts
column9: usually also in pants). To echo an old trope (one that sounds
column10: by coincidence
column11: like the premise of a Decemberists song)
column12: the cobbler's children have no shoes: The band that's done more than almost any other in recent years for the art of narrative songcraft can't seem to get a decent story told about its own damn self.

column1: But the release of Long Live the King
column2: the follow-up EP to the chart-topping The King Is Dead
column3: offers as good a chance as we may get for a while to pause and take stock of what we might have been missing. The six songs comprise a few nearly-fleshed-out tracks and one demo rescued from the cutting-room floor (plus a previously-released cover of the Grateful Dead's ""Row Jimmy""
column4: which the band sounds like they had a good time recording
column5: making it at least a slight improvement over any of the seven hundred thousand versions of the Dead's original). It's not a cohesive artistic effort so much as a jumble of remainders-- unhemmed
column6: lots of loose strings. Still
column7: like rifling through a quilter's scrap bag
column8: it's easy to see what bits were trimmed off from where
column9: and worth it to see how they now might be put to their own uses.

column1: Even moreso than the album they were axed from
column2: these songs are heavy on the literary references; ""Sonnet""
column3: in particular
column4: reconstitutes a Dantean ode to bromance as a jaunty folk romp
column5: punctuated by the welcome
column6: if not a bit startling
column7: appearance of a horn section. But as always
column8: the bookish nods aren't the most interesting things going. Running throughout The King Is Dead and present here too are some striking examples of what may be Meloy's secret strength as a songwriter: not the dispatching of triple-word-score contenders or the re-imagining of ancient archetypes
column9: but the mining of the emotional and physical expanses that separate and unite his characters
column10: who seem to be growing more and more real all the time. Turns out
column11: the fabulist is a humanist
column12: too.

column1: Earlier Decemberists songs tended towards thumbnail sketches of individuals-- ghost-babies
column2: destitute barrow boys
column3: slain soldiers. The scope was narrow
column4: a few degrees removed from reality
column5: and focused on death. On Long Live the King
column6: though
column7: when there is killing
column8: we remain fully topside of the grave
column9: and though it may not always be brighter
column10: the emphasis is on the living. More and more now there are songs about ""we's
column11: about collective efforts
column12: about sharing the load. (It's not surprising
column13: then
column14: that the stage musical Meloy has been working on for years is about an early-20th-century miners' strike.) The King Is Dead opened with ""Don't Carry It All"" and its cryptic reassurance that ""we are all our hands and holders
column15: and while there's nothing so frankly heartening on the EP
column16: the spirit appears in flashes.

column1: Everything here is a group effort: the murder of ""E. Watson""
column2: the interring of ""Burying Davy"". These two opening tracks have less of the sunny
column3: rough-handed looseness of the best tracks of The King Is Dead
column4: perhaps explaining their exclusion. Texturally and technically
column5: the shambly home recording of ""I4U & U4ME"" sounds more like a lost track from Meloy's college band Tarkio; it's been since ""Angel
column6: Won't You Call Me?""
column7: on The Decemberists' very first EP
column8: that he
column9: in character or otherwise
column10: has offered himself for a romantic partnership with such indifference: ""We could go together some/ And we could get each other through the night."" It's a jangly
column11: sweet
column12: impatient song
column13: and it's a bummer that it may languish here in demo form for all time; if anything
column14: it would be great to have version where ""fouled up
column15: on the pre-chorus
column16: becomes ""fucked up

column1: ""Foregone"" is one of Meloy's more directly personal lyrics

column3: the new collaborative EP from Detroit indie-rap producer Black Milk and shock-rap loose cannon Danny Brown
column4: feels ""half-finished"" would be over-generous. Covering 10 tracks in a scant 22 minutes and bearing a forehead-slap obvious title that probably existed before the project did
column5: Black and Brown is hastily assembled
column6: thoughtlessly sequenced
column7: and conspicuously truncated. There are two songs
column8: back to back
column9: titled ""WTF"" and ""LOL"". Four songs don't exceed the two-minute mark. The overwhelming impression is that the EP exists because an assistant stumbled across an ""in-progress"" folder of mp3s on Black Milk's desktop and leaked the results.

column1: And yet
column2: Black Milk is one of indie rap's best and most reliable producers
column3: and Danny Brown
column4: fresh off his brilliant XXX
column5: is riding a white-hot creative streak: which means that Black and Brown is 22 hastily assembled
column6: thoughtlessly sequenced minutes of vivid beats and incredible rapping. Black Milk's beats are boilerplate Black Milk-- post-Dilla instrumentals hitched to hard-knocking drums-- and Brown brings none of the songwriting skill or emotional range that marked XXX
column7: with its tales of stripping hot water heaters from abandoned houses and harrowing accounts of substance abuse. It's a low-stakes affair

column1: Brown tamps down the keening high edge in his voice
column2: with the result that he sounds more like Pharaohe Monch than usual. Lyrically
column3: he mostly coasts
column4: but even on autopilot he remains absurdly quotable. ""Morphine metaphors make you do the shoulder lean
column5: he spits on ""Loosie""
column6: and the line is a finely tuned mini-marvel of alliteration and craft. Few rappers are as creatively disgusting as Brown-- his missing tooth is ""perfect for lickin clits
column7: he informs a potential partner-- but even his shock raps hit their target
column8: more often than not
column9: through some deft bit of linguistic three-card Monte: ""Used to make out with runaways in crack houses/ Now I run away from making out with brick houses
column10: he leers on ""Loosie"". Got that?

column1: Black Milk's production
column2: meanwhile
column3: continues his career-long argument for the power of immacuately prepared comfort food. His work gathers a lot of strength from old-fashioned flipped samples
column4: but the sound he wrings from them is compellingly tactile
column5: as if the samples were made of some dense-but-yielding material only he knows how to manipulate. His drums have so much character and texture they almost seem to hit twice; ""Zap""'s bone-jarring backbeat lands somewhere indistinct in headphone-space
column6: over a feebly quavering mini-choir of chipmunk-soul voices
column7: and it sounds like you could reach out and run your fingers over it. Milk switches the beat up every one or two minutes
column8: like impatient channel flicking
column9: which both reinforces the beat-tape feeling of Black and Brown and handily keeps it from getting boring. The whole EP is over seemingly as soon as it begins and is the definition of a simple A+B proposition
column10: right down to its name. But it works
column11: and if it means there's a more considered full-length from these two on the way
column12:
even better.

column9: of course

Luis Vasquez works alone

column3: the San Francisco musician sets and triggers every sound associated with the Soft Moon
column4: drawing from the coldest
column5: most metallic zeniths of post-punk and industrial rock. He builds isolation out of isolation

column11: are singular and self-contained

column15: given the music's dark antagonism

column1: Notice that I haven't used the word ""songs"" to describe the result of Vasquez's creative process. That's because the Soft Moon aren't really about ""songs
column2: per se; they're about moods
column3: how they're conveyed
column4: and the specific images they conjure. On The Soft Moon
column5: the titles ascribed to the music were all the lyrics one needed (and
column6: more often than not
column7: was given)

column9: the most notable element of ""Repetition"" is its-- you guessed it-- repeating bassline
column10: sinisterly gyrating in place while whimpered buzzing and oscillating machines rise and fall around it. The title track's zombie-eyed buzzsaws sound like the aural equivalent of having your skin slowly ripped off
column11: while ""Visions"" takes a feral drum circle and throws space-disco drum machines into the mix
column12: a combo queasy enough to make even the steeliest soothsayer run from the opium den
column13: hopelessly choking back vomit.

column3: accessible stuff that casual observers might expect from Captured Tracks
column4: a label that stakes its chips as much on M.O.R. indie-pop like Beach Fossils as on chilly synths and brutal coldwave (although they've been focusing a lot more on the latter in the last 12 months). When Vasquez decides to create something like an actual song
column5: though

column7: a highlight from The Soft Moon
column8: smoldered with sexual confusion and the allure of 4AD's shoegaze glory days; here
column9: it's the title track that burns brightest

column14: and whatever baggage you bring along with you.

column1: If Total Decay's composition amounted to the spoils of its title track repeated four times over
column2: it'd simply be too much
column3: which highlights Vasquez's ability to conjure different sounds and styles track-by-track. However
column4: that fact also points out how the Soft Moon's brand of cold
column5: nocturnal malevolence works best in small smatterings. At first
column6: I found myself underwhelmed by Total Decay

column8: though
column9: I came to realize that the EP's controlled-dosage brevity is exactly what makes it rise above its predecessor. It's short and intense

just to feel the pain again.

An interesting thing about the Night Slugs label is that it's managed to maintain ""Next Big Thing"" status over the past couple of years without ever really defining what it's about. The London imprint
column4: partly known for launching bass hotshots Kingdom and Girl Unit

column7: it's just held together by a vibe
column8: the former said a little ways back. This slipperiness has served Night Slugs well
column9: but at a certain point you want something a little more concrete-- what is that vibe
column10: exactly?

column1: Neon Dreams
column2: the solo debut from L-Vis 1990 (real name James Connolly) does not answer this question. If Night Slugs' loose guiding principle up until now has been a colorful counterweight to dubstep and grime's murk and grit
column3: Neon Dreams spins that idea in a hundred different directions. The record is (sometimes intriguingly
column4: often frustratingly) all over the place. The starting point
column5: though
column6: seems to be pop. From the album title and M83-esque cover art to the use of guest vocalists
column7: it's clear that Connolly is interested in making songs rather than just club tracks. And sometimes he does this really well. On ""Tonight""
column8: for example
column9: he throws some 1980s radio sheen on stuttery disco-house and winds up with catchy
column10: retro-futurist boogie.

column1: ""Play It Cool""
column2: arguably the best song here
column3: also fits into this pop mode. Gooey synths
column4: heavy drama
column5: breathy female vocals-- it nails a very specific kind of dark and dreamy electro-pop. (Worth noting that it fits comfortably alongside such 2011 standouts as the aforementioned M83
column6: Neon Indian's Era Extraña
column7: and the Drive soundtrack.) If Connolly had extended this format (or even this vibe) throughout the album
column8: the rest of it may have been as successful
column9: but instead he incorporates so
column10: so many other sounds. There's a different style on almost every track. You've got a quirky
column11: Chromeo-style one
column12: some brooding instrumental ones
column13: one where a dude talks quasi-motivationally over revved up Chicago house
column14: and so forth.

column1: None of these tracks are particularly bad; it's simply a case of too much. Too many songs with varying themes and no overarching vision to tie them together. It feels more like taking in a label compilation where you're hopping from one artist's style to the next
column2: and even if that were the case I'd still probably say the sequencing is off. But it's possible that this is precisely Connolly's point-- to make something boundary-less and genre-agnostic

column4: after all
column5: is an ever-evolving thing

column7: and this corrals a bunch in one place. Still
column8: offer a bunch of diversions instead of a clear path
column9:
and folks might get lost along the way.

Void are one of those bands whose reputation thrives on scarcity. Up till now
column3: this early-1980s D.C.-area hardcore quartet's entire discography (aside from a few compilation tracks) could be heard in under 16 minutes-- and not even on a proper full-length but a split LP
column4: shared with the equally obscure Faith.

column1: There's something about that split
column2: though. Thanks to devoted bloggers and high-profile superfans like Damian Abraham and Matt Korvette (of Fucked Up and Pissed Jeans
column3: respectively)
column4: hardcore has become something of a scholarly discipline in recent years
column5: and few records are more revered in that DIY academia than 1982's so-called Faith/Void. Drummer Aesop Dekker (Agalloch
column6: ex-Ludicra) quipped
column7: ""Faith v. Void (1982)
column8: was a landmark decision of the United States Supreme Court that overturned mediocrity in hardcore splits."" Sam McPheeters (Born Against
column9: Men's Recovery Project
column10: and more) dubbed it one of ""the best records of the 20th century."" And none other than Bill ""Smog"" Callahan named a song after the damn thing (""Faith/Void
column11: from 2009's Sometimes I Wish I Were an Eagle). ""It's one of my favorite records
column12: he told Impose
column13: ""especially the Void side.""

column1: There's no denying the bottled-lightning brilliance of said side-- a sputtering
column2: cacophonous masterpiece
column3: the unhinged id to the comparatively orderly ego of fellow Washingtonians Minor Threat-- but when considering its sterling reputation
column4: you have to factor in its singularity. Underground obsessives love not just the music
column5: but also the idea that Void made one perfect half of one record and that's pretty much it. (That might be why you don't hear too much about Potion for Bad Dreams
column6: the never-released but widely fileshared LP that Void cut for Touch and Go after the Faith split.)

column1: So in issuing Sessions 1981-83
column2: a compilation of demos and rarities spanning Void's brief career (except for two outtakes from the split itself and two 1983 live tracks
column3: everything here predates Faith/Void)
column4: is Dischord downgrading the band's priceless cachet? In one sense
column5: maybe so
column6: since these sides humanize Void. Listening to the initial 30 of the comp's 34 tracks
column7: sourced from the quartet's first two studio visits in November and December of 1981
column8: you quickly realize that Void's members weren't unsocialized head cases who managed to focus long enough only to record 12 exquisitely fucked-up songs. On the contrary
column9: vocalist John Weiffenbach
column10: guitarist Bubba Dupree
column11: bassist Chris Stover
column12: and drummer Sean Finnegan (sadly deceased as of 2008)
column13: were angry
column14: sometimes goofy suburban kids from Columbia
column15: Md.
column16: playing hard
column17: writing prolifically
column18: and steadily developing the confidence to embrace pure
column19: howling chaos-- not so different
column20: in other words
column21: from all the other high-school-aged architects of hardcore across the U.S. The majority of Sessions 1981-83 doesn't transcend its genre the way Void's contribution to Faith/Void does
column22: but it does provide enlightening context for that deservedly obsessed-over release.

column1: Just as importantly
column2: this stuff is good
column3: snotty fun. Void's bread and butter was the turbo-speed rant
column4: and the November '81 recordings here feature many prime examples
column5: like the self-explanatory ""Suburbs Suck""
column6: ""Annoyed""
column7: and ""Don't Wanna Be Like You""
column8: which last 38
column10: and 49 seconds
column11: respectively. These songs may represent rock's lowest common denominator-- a pair of buzzsaw riffs
column12: a coming-off-the-rails oompah beat
column13: and a litany of adolescent gripes-- but Void's disaffection is the kind you can't fake
column14: the definition of troubled teenhood.

column1: Unlike Minor Threat's Ian MacKaye
column2: whose cogent statements clued you in to a sharp political mind
column3: Weiffenbach's raw-nerve howl often gave voice to straight-up nihilism; witness ""War Hero"" (which would later appear on Faith/Void)
column4: with its ""I want to die… in a war!"" refrain. But just when you think you have Void pegged as one-note rageaholics
column5: they surprise you with a bit of poignant social commentary (""Black
column6: Jewish
column7: and Poor""
column8: where Weiffenbach's slurred
column9: sneering voice sounds like the blueprint for Wavves' Nathan Williams) or charming self-satire (""Please Give Us a Chance""
column10: which disclaims
column11: ""Just because Chris sucks shit on bass/ Just because Sean can't keep up a beat/ Just because Bubba doesn't know any chords/ Just because I don't know my words…""). Void shouldn't have been so hard on themselves: As primitive as this material is
column12: much of it is unshakably catchy
column13: especially ""Organized Sports"" and ""My Rules"" (both re-recorded for the split)
column14: which feature anthemic choruses driven by Dupree's metallic midtempo crunch.

column1: Even as the 1981-model Void were learning how to write effectively in the still-nascent hardcore mode
column2: they were also beginning to deconstruct the form. Right from the beginning
column3: the band wantonly tested the limits of what a song could be. Consider ""Draft Me Please""
column4: which moves from a textbook speed-punk verse into a weird pile-up of a chorus; here
column5: Dupree peels off a snarling phrase
column6: and Finnegan answers with a series of impressionistic taps
column7: abandoning the beat in the process. For a few frantic seconds
column8: the whole band jettisons the idea of tempo
column9: to intoxicating effect.

column1: These chaotic episodes would become more and more pronounced
column2: until they were as much a part of Void's compositional style as the more intelligible material. The most valuable aspect of Sessions 1981-83 is how it illustrates this steady march toward violent abstraction
column3: especially in Dupree's playing. As wild as his bandmates were
column4: the half-black
column5: half-Filipino guitarist was a maniac of a different order
column6: the X-factor that gave Void a whiff of dangerous insanity. (Dave Grohl
column7: an avowed Void fan
column8: was among those taking note; he tapped Dupree for a frenetic cameo on his 2004 Probot record.)

column1: The three versions of ""Dehumanized"" here-- one apiece from November and December of '81
column2: and a June 1982 outtake from the session that yielded Void's contributions to Faith/Void-- tell the story plainly. Listening to them in succession
column3: you hear Dupree's ""Eureka!"" awakening to the aesthetic potential of noise. On the first attempt
column4: he plays the dutiful riff machine
column5: clearly stating the song's start-stop verse motif and chugging
column6: downstroked chorus. During the much faster December take
column7: he fills the gaps in the first verse with bursts of feedback; by verse two
column8: he's in full-on assault mode
column9: scraping out tortured growls and squeals that make Black Flag's Greg Ginn
column10: hardcore's most notorious six-string sicko
column11: sound cautious by comparison. The final ""Dehumanized"" is a glorious mess
column12: with Dupree alternating between proto-thrash attack and what sounds like a malfunctioning power saw. Weiffenbach responds with a borderline black-metal snarl
column13: and we're finally hearing the band at its peak derangement.

column1: Sessions 1981-83 offers one final masochistic delight: a 1983 live version of Faith/Void's concluding track
column2: ""Explode""
column3: which feels like the missing link between hardcore and ruthless modern-day noise. ""Our last song
column4: Weiffenbach blankly announces
column5: and Stover launches into a manic cyclical bass riff. Dupree answers with a gradually accelerating throb; Weiffenbach lets out a tortured yowl; and suddenly the full band whooshes in. The aural dogpile that follows out-extremes even the hallowed split LP. It bears little resemblance to punk rock
column6: or any sort of song-based soundmaking; instead
column7: it's a mini exorcism that places Void in the illustrious lineage of amplified din
column8: stretching from Jimi Hendrix up through Keiji Haino and Prurient. Appropriately
column9: it's Dupree we hear last
column10: conjuring spiky
column11: alien sound shapes.

column1: If the rest of Sessions 1981-83 serves as a entertaining and educational scrapbook
column2: this track reminds you why
column3: three decades on
column4: Void are still spoken of in hushed tones. Much like John Coltrane toward the end of his life
column5: this band
column6: near the conclusion of its own too-short existence
column7: pierced the veil separating its musical style from an ultimate
column8:
unbound-by-genre catharsis. Not bad for a couple of pissed-off suburban kids.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/17117/homepage_large.b9a5d768.jpg|Preserved|30028.0|Young Bleed|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Strange Lane']|2011-10-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:19:41.680490|"

The No Limit record label has long been treated with a patronizing condescension from critics
column2: although in much of the country
column3: the label's stars were the biggest and most influential of their era. Baton Rouge's Young Bleed was one of Master P's many late-1990s marketing successes. 1998's My Balls and My Word sold half a million copies-- not Mystikal-levels
column4: but certainly a respectable number for a 20-year-old rapper advertised solely in No Limit liner notes and the pages of Murder Dog magazine. Since that time
column5: Young Bleed has continued to release material
column6: with his trademark laconic delivery effortlessly masking suave precision. Now his alliance with Tech N9ne's Strange Music label has found the rapper releasing his best collection of songs since 1999's Priority Records release My Own.

column1: Preserved could easily describe Young Bleed's loyalty to the reliable sound of his earliest work. Because the sound is such an un-mined era in rap history
column2: it is a comforting approach to anyone who fondly remembers the country-fried g-rap of ""How You Do That"". Leadoff track ""Put Your Stamp on It""
column3: which was actually released in YouTube-only format back in 2006
column4: is an easy standout
column5: with its nonchalant swagger. Although ""Make Em Say Ugh"" might give dilettantes the notion that No Limit was all aggressive energy
column6: raw and explosive
column7: Young Bleed was always at his strongest with the kind of strutting restraint on display here.

column1: The variety of production within that framework makes Preserved an especially interesting listen. Lead single ""Holla at Uh Dog"" is built upon bongos and an exotic flute loop. The way it injects the music video's swamp setting with a particular magic is representative of Bleed's approach as whole: giving the everyday or the cliché a mythical significance. ""It's Nut'n""-- Bleed often writes his track titles out phonetically-- is one of the record's more adventurous beats. Along with stammering horns
column2: the production is all texture
column3: layered money-counting machines and clattering drums giving it the feel of a factory at full-tilt; it is like a ghost of the record's implied setting
column4: the post-industrial landscape of neighborhoods and cities of the economically abandoned. ""Call the Police""
column5: meanwhile
column6: places the album in a specific geography
column7: with its accordion-accompanied zydeco groove
column8: while ""City Uh God"" has an extremely effective live-music feel with its strummed  guitars. Only ""Wall Uh Fame""
column9: which has a Lupe Fiasco-esque ""inspirational"" melody
column10: breaks the record's general mood
column11: aiming for emotional transcendence a bit too blatantly.

column1: Of course
column2: it's Young Bleed himself who primarily carries the record by focusing the listener's attention to his lyrics. Fans of Curren$y might find something to like here; Bleed's flow has always utilized a similarly slick
column3: imperturbable delivery to buttress more intricately musical rhythms and rhyme schemes. His persona
column4: however
column5: differs considerably from Curren$y's newer incarnation as a jet-setting stoner; Bleed emphasizes the individualism
column6: agency
column7: and nobility of the street soldier
column8: weaving a universal story of hustle and struggle through implied
column9: writer-ly details and a sixth sense for style. Preserved could as easily refer to his stylistic approach as the quality of his output
column10:
which remains high 13 years into the game.
